title: News Summary
description: China's leaders seem to be trying to restore an orderly government and regain popular confidence after a decade of turmoil caused by the Cultural Revolution. The leaders have begun a drive to correct a variety of abuses in which Chinese have been persecuted for political reasons or mistreated by arrogant and corrupt officials. A number of such reforms have been given wide publicity in the Chinese press and could involve one of the most significant changes since the death of Mao Tsetung. LPage Al, Columns 56.]

title: TV:True ,story, 'Death in Canaan'
description: ON SEPT. 28, 1973, Barbara Gibbobs was brutally murdered in her cramped and shabby Connecticut home. Her 18yearold son, Peter Reilly, was indicted for the crime, and after two trials, charges against him were dismissed on Nov. 24,1976. The press was highly Instrumental in keeping the case unael public scrutinyInitial national attention was generated in a New Time; magazine article by Joan Barthel, freelancewriter. Later, two long investigative articles by John- Corry in The New York Times led to a reopening of the case following the first trial.

title: China Reviving the Social Sciences
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 28In a move to improve China's educational system after a decade of disruption, Peking said today that the graduate schools in history, law, religion, philosophy, literature and economics would reopen next fall for the first time since the Cultural Revolution.

title: About New York
description: The last tap dance does not seem very sad. The women are in all manner of rehearsal clothes, from legwarmers to baseball cap, and their disunity of dress is refreshing  as colorfully curved and taut as their personalities and bodies, They go through the hours of learning the last tap dance with laughter and energy, aches and exhaustion, and frequent stares at themselves dancing long and angled in the rehearsal hall's mirrors.

title: Q&A

title: Theater:'Ruffian,' Orton's Firsr Play
description: 'THE RUFFIAN on the Stair,' Joe Orton's first play, written for radio in 1963 and later adapted for the stage; takes its title from a poem by W. E. Henley: Madam Life is the tenant of the room' and Death is the ruffian on the stair! The tenant is harassed and bedeViled, but it is the ruffian who is eventually murdered, welcoming his fate with a calmness, that is characteristically. Orton. My will Is in my overcoat jibcicet, the Uffian says matteroffactly. to his killer.

title: A Host With Many Guests but Few Friends
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The rich and the politically powerful flocked to his elegant parties. Some called him the Onassis of the Orient.

title: Others, Too Love You
description: OREM, UtahFreddie was my love in nursery school. I recall with a certain warm nostalgia our clandestine fountainside meetings at recess, the shared giggles over graham crackers and apple juice,, blushing peeks through cracks between folded arms at rest time.

title: Coal Strike and Its impact on Carter's Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The coal strike may be ending but the repercussions may only be starting. Quietly at first, but now more vocally, energy experts are suggesting that the if rike could hamper the Carter Admnistration's often- trumpeted plan to shift the nation's energy consumption toward coal from quickly depleting oil and natural gas. The strike appears likely to do nothing to reform the Industry's volatile labor relations, an instability that has repeatedly been cited as a major obstacle to increased coal production. At the same time, the threat of largescale job layoffs and stalled economic growth as a result of the strike could dissuade industry and utiliti's from converting to coal, President Carter's central strategy.

title: Since the 1967 Riots, Detroit Has Moved Painfully Toward a Modest Renaissance,
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Mrs. Gandhi Says Her Par s Now Main Opposition
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 28The governing Janata Party won the largest number of seats in the legislatures of the major western state of Maharashtra and the eastern state of Assam today, but former Prime Minister Indira Gandhi said that the strong showing of her newly organized party Proved that she had become the real opposition, the only opposition.

title: Robert Sobukwe, Beyond Banning
description: To meet the most vibrant black leader in South Africa you had to go first to a shoe store on the main square of Kimberley, a museum of a mining town halfway between Cape Town and Johannesburg. The Indian pro- prietor, operating under a white man's nominal ownert ship on a street reserved for white commerce, would then lead the way to his home in the colored section, presided over by a Malay woman who was alternately his wife or companion, depending upon shifts in the law that governed an Indian's marriage to a colored and the places where such a combination could reside. In the manner of Biblical disciples, these two served their friend, Robert Sobukwe.

title: Jackson  Connects With
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 28Fram the moment he quietly and unexpectedly appeased in front of hislocker until he signed his last autograph more than four. hours., later, Reggie Jackson once again was the center of attention todayfor everybody except his teammates.

title: SpinksAli Return Likely, Norton Insulted by Offer
description: Ken Norton feels insulted by $200,000 offer to fight for .the world heavyweight championship, but even while the No. 1 challenger is deciding whether he should work that cheaply, a Leon SpinksMuhammad Ali rematch becomes more and more a certainty.

description: JERUSALEM: Feb. 28Orthodox control over religious affairs in Israel was strongly challenged today by actions of the World Zionist Congress meeting here.

description: ROSEMONT, Ill., Feb. 28 (UPI)The Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, which has about 1,000 members, has concluded a merger with the Brotherhood of Airline and Railway Clerks, it was announced today. The porters are to be separate division of the clerks union.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: DINNER CELEBRATION: Hugh J. Addonizio, center, former Newark Mayor, being served by his wife, Doris, as the family bailed ruling by Federal appeals court on Monday upholding his release from prison. Mr. Addonizio had served Live years and two months for extortion and conspiracy.

title: Of York College, Jamaica
description: When is a college. a college? When it has existed rfor a decade? When its faculty has received national recognition? When an urban center declares, through its merchants, through . its clergy, through its civic associations, that the school must: continue to exist, and rescues it from.emasculation by hostile or indifferent chancellor?

title: Song: Miss Schonbrun
description: THE Women's Interart Center began what it calls the First Festival of Women's Music Monday night at the City University of New.. York's Graduate Center, 33 West 42d Street. Subsequent concerts there, with a variety of instrumental forces, will take place on March 13, April 24 and May 8, and electronicmusic concerts are scheduled for the Interart Gallery, 549 West 52d Street, on March 28 and May 2. All concerts are at 8 P.M.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Governor Carey announced Federal grants of $1.3 million, the largest such appropriation ever, to repair and preserve 58 sites listed in the National Register of Historic Places. The sites are in 32 counties. The largest grant, to be matched by local contributions, was $200,000 to help restore exteriors and landscaping at nine buildings in the Cobble Hill Historic District in Brooklyn.

title: West German Papers Are Struck
description: BONN, Feb. 28 (Reuters)Printers went on strike at five West German newspapers today to back demands for the preservation of skilled jobs threatened by new computer technology. Near- ly 2,000 printers in Munich, Dusseldorf, Kassel and Wuppertal took part in the walkout. The Newspaper Publishers Federation here retaliated by saying all five Munich papers would enforce a lockout if printers at the two papers affected there did not go back to work tomorrow.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Suffolk Legislature Votes to End Medicaid Abortions
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 28Ignoring the opinions of its own legal counsel and of the County Attorney, the. Suffolk County Legislature today overrode a veto by the County Executive and directed that Medicaid financing for all abortions be halted.

title: Fukuda-Carter Meeting on Trade Arranged for May 3 in Washington
description: TOKYO, Feb. 28 (UPI)Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda will meet with President Carter in Washington on May 3 to try to end a rift caused by a trade conflict between Japan and the United States.

title: Carter's Urban Policy Is Delayed, With Mayors and Governors Split
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A delegation of mayors was told at the White House today that President Carter's urban policy, scheduled to be announced by March 15. would be delayed by one week:

title: 2 Supermarket Chains Offer Cheaper`Generic'Foodltems
description: Two major supermarket chains in the New York area have announced plans to introduce generic products  unbranded items that will sell for significantly less than either brandname or iibusebrand merchandise.

title: India Increases Rural Investment
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 28The Janata Party Government announced today that over the coming year it would sharply increase investments., in rural projects to provide jobs for the unemployed,

title: Youth Summer Jobs Planned
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 28 (UPI)Labor Secretary Ray Marshall said today that $706 million would be spent this summer to hire about 1 million disadvantaged youths in summer jobs. He said that the money would be apportioned among 405 state and local governments serving as prime sponsors under the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act.

title: A Dispute Over Jersey Jobless Figures
description: When he picked up the daily newspaper one morning early in February, William C. Freund, the chief economist for the New York Stock Exchange, recalled in a recent interview, he was surprised and shocked The Economic Scene over some of the data in the Federal Government's monthly survey on unemployment. Many other analysts have been skeptical of the numbers in that series for some time, particularly those for December and January. Mr. Freund has been one of the skeptics, but a month ago he was even more convinced that something was wrong.

title: Italian Christian Democrats Reject a Pact With Reds
description: ROME, Feb. 28The leadership of Italy's governing Christian Democratic Party decided today against offering the Communist Party a contractual, agreement that would make the Communists formally a member of the Government majority.

title: CARTER ASKS 24% RISE IN EDUCATION. FUNDS, WITH FOCUS ON BASICS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. .28  President Carter urged today that the nation focus on basic educational skills as he asked Congress for a 24 percent increase in Federal funds for education.

title: Fugitive Charged With Kidnapping
description: RICHMOND, Ind., Feb. 28 (UPI)The Indiana authorities have filed charges of kidnapping, robbery and attempted murder against an Ohio prison fugitive. Byron Bell, 40 years old, of Springfield, Ohio, was being held in Dayton on Fed.; eral kidnapping charges when the latest charges were filed in Wayne County Cir. cuit Court here. Mr. Bell was accused of abducting Robert Hermann and his two sons after a bank holdup last Tuesday. While Mr. Bell was negotiating with police in Springfield, Mr. Hermann, grabbed the kidnapper's pistol and officers seized the suspect.

title: How and Why Golda Sank
description: IN preseason predictions, Golds looked as if it would be a certain winner on Broadway. This stage biography of Golda Meir reunited the highly successful Broadway team ('Two for the Seesaw and The Miracle Worker') of Anne Bancroft as star, William Gibson as author and Arthur Penn as director. Theatergoers salivated in anticipation.

title: HOUSE VOTES TO EASE FEDERAL. COURT LOAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Without single vote to spare, the House of Representatives today approved a major change in. Federal court procedures designed to ease congestion by diverting more than 30,000 cases a year into the state courts.

title: About Education Colleges Are Sharing Resources
description: The Rhode Island School of Design wants to accept more students but does not have the space. The Santa Fe, N.M., campus of St. John's College of Maryland has some empty dormitory rooms. Wouldn't it be nice if the design school could send some, students to Santa Fe?

title: Anderson, Miss Nelson Take U.S. Titles
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 28High up on Whiteface Mountain, Karl Anderson, the seasoned 24-year-old ski racer from Greene, Me., was clocked traveling at 81 miles an hour today. Anderson kept whizzing fast enough for the rest of his 11,875foot plunge to capture the men's downhill crown at the United States Alpine championships. Earlier, Cindy Nelson, the blonde star from Lutsen, Minn., captured the women's downhill.

title: Koch and Queens Group in Standoff
description: Mayor Koch and a Queens community group whose meeting Mr. Koch stalked out of Monday night accused each other yesterday of fomenting a confrontation.

title: Enid Nemy
description: There are women around who always get a second or third look. And there are women around who don't. Not to worry. The new Edward Rayne shoes at the Delman Shoe Salon will practically guarantee you a couple extra looks. Actually, the shoe itself is rather prettyin Wedgwood blue, primrose, lilac and greenbut it's the heel that counts. The heels are made from Wedgwood's Jasper Ware, the last of the ceramic bodies developed Josiah Wedgwood. And on each of. them there is handornamented figure of a winged Zephyr in white bas relief. They (Delman) say the heels are practically indestructible, but they may not have walked on New York pavement. Anyway, these sandals are meant for evening and carpets and candlelight and all that jazz. The Delman salon is in Bergdorf Goodman, and the price is $115, but even heels come expensive these days.

title: Mrs. Gay Facing Trial Tomorrow For the Murder of Her Husband
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 28In a case that has attracted widespread interest from'20;women's groups concerned about battered wives, Roxanne Gay goes on trial Thursday for the fatal stabbing of her husband, Blenda, while he slept in their Gloucester Township apartment Dec. 20, 1976.

title: Egypt Expects No Accord Before Begin Visits U.S.
description: CAIRO, Feb. 28Egyptian officials haye generally concluded that there is virtually no chance of agreeing with Israel on a declaration of peace principles before Prime Minister Menachem Begin. visits Washington, in two weeks.

description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 28 (AP)Clint Johnson scored 16 points and Paul Tv1okeski added 12 points and 16 rebounds tonight to pace fifthranked Kansas to an 8266 victory over Colorado in the first round of the Big Eight postseason basketball tournament.

description: Braniff Airways announced yesterday that, because of the BritishAmerican deadlock over fares, it had canceled today's scheduled beginning of, air service between London and DallasFort Worth.

title: States Seek Top Water Policy Role
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28'4;The nation's governors today adopted resolutions urging that the states be given primary authority in water management policy and that more Federal funds be used to compensate the states for increased unemployment compensation costs in recessions.

title: BLUMENTHAL TO SEEK GUARANTEES FOR CITY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal will propose a longterm loan guarantee together with the elimination of further shortterm or seasonal loans to New York City when he offers a fiscal rescue plan for the city Thursday. This was disclosed today by Representative William S. Moorhead, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who heads the Housing banking subcommittee involved with the city's finances.

title: Troubled Atlanta Bank Gets Chief
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 28Bennett A. Brown, assistant president of the Citizens and Southern National Bank for the last seven years, was named its president and chief executive officer today. He succeeded Richard L. Kattel, who resigned yesterday in the wake of the big financial institution's continuing setback in the collapsed Atlanta real estate market.

title: About Real Estate Former Army Induction Center to Become a Health Club
description: The former Army induction center at 39 Whitehall Street processed bodies in peace and war for 86 years until it closed in 1972. It has deteriorated drastically since then, awaiting a new owner and savior.

title: Echoes
description: The Sixties were, among other things, the decade of Presidential commissions. There have been commissions before and since, but then blueribbon panels were appointed to deal with crime, riots and violence; with urban housing, rural poverty and campus unrest. The proliferation of reports inspired cynicism. When Lyndon Johnson appointed the Kerner Commission on urban riots in 1967, he also declared a national day of prayer. One wiseacre suggested that it would have made as much sense to appoint a commission on prayer and declare a national day of riot. Even after the Kerner Commission issued its celebrated report, ten years ago today, Murray Kempton observed, As America gets worse and worse, the reports get better and better.

title: Declining British Village Saves Pub and, Perhaps, Itself
description: GOOSEY, England, Feb. 26Goosey is going to survive after all.

Moorhead, Democrat of Pennsylvania, who heads the House banking subcommittee involved with the city's finances.

title: Environmental Unit Urges Merger Of Opposing Strategies on Energy
description: The nation has still not figured out how to meet its future energy needs, or even what those needs may be, although severe shortages of established fuels are certain, the Federal, Council on Environmental Ouality said yesterday.

title: WARNERLAMBERT RAISES PROFIT 76.1%
description: The WarnerLambert Company, a leading drug, optical and consumer products maker, reported yesterday profit increases of 76.1 percent for the quarter and 18 percent for all of 1977.

title: N.C.A.A. Policies Criticized
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The National Collegiate Athletic Association enforcement policies were described before a Congressional subcommittee today as leading to bewildering and hostile concepts of due process.

title: Market Place
description: Extending its recent sharp decline, the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled yesterday to a threeyear low. Among the reasons for the latest slide was a substantial drop in the Government's index of leading economic indicators reported for January. Yesterday,

title: ExFirestone Official Admits Fraud
description: Robert P: Beasley, a former top official of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that he had paid personal expenses with corporate money kat was supposedly being used for illegal political campaign contributions.

title: Yamaha Recalls Motorcycles
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 28 (AP)About 36.000 Yamaha motorcycles have been recalled because of a defect the company says could cause the rear wheel to lock up. A spokesman for the Yamaha Motor Corporation said that four models of the XS750 had defects that would lead to vehicle crash without warning. Notices mailed to owners say the defect involves a stopper bolt that could allow the gear shifting drum to move laterally and lock up the rear wheel.

title: O'HAGAN IS REFUSED A TAXFREE PENSION
description: Former Fire Commissioner John T. O'Hagan's bid for a taxfree disability pension of $41,665 a year was turned down yesterday, but he was granted a disability stipend of $35,657 a year on which he will have to pay income taxes.

title: Albany Is Looking Into Charges of Rebates' on Drug*s; PROSTITUTION; DEFICIENCY BUDGET
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28The chairman of the Assembly's Consumer Protection Committee charged today that large pharmaceutical companies were offering rebates to selected pharmacists to encourage them to carry their products.

title: Opera: Pelleas at Met
description: GREAT DEAL of dedication has gone into the Metropolitan Opera's fine production of Debussy's Pelleas et Melisande, from the manner of James Levine's entrance to the conducting stand, which precludes applause, to the interruption of the fiveact work by only one intermission, in order to sustain its dreamlike mood.

title: Policing of Antarctic Environment Is Proposed by U.S. at Conference
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 28 (UPI)The United States delegation to an Antarctic conference here called today for observer teams to police conservation rules in the area.

title: Carey and Duryea Woo Business

Duryea, went head-to-head tonight for the first time in the 1978 race for Governor, exchanging gags, blows and pledges before an audience of businessmen at the Empire State Chamber of Commerce dinner.

title: Ceremony for General James
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)A graveside ceremony with full military honors is to be held at Arlington National, Cemetery Thursday for Daniel James, the first black four-star-general. General James, 58 years old, died Saturday after a heart attack. The Pentagon said that the 11 A.M. service would follow a mass at 8 P.M. tomorrow at the Shrine of the Immaculate Conception in Washington. General James body will lie in state at the Shrine tomorrow evening.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney reports that the Federal Government's January figures on unemployment in New Jersey surprised and shocked William C. Freund, chief economist for the New York Stock Exchange and an economic adviser of Governor Byrne. Page. D5.

title: Mets Peace: Randle Cancels His War
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Ma., Feb. 28Lenny. Randle ended the briefest retirement on record today when he canceled his contract war with the New York Mets; beaded South and promised to appear as scheduled tomorrow morning for spring training.

title: Koch and Queens Group in Standoff
description: Mayor Koch and a Queens community group whose meeting Mr. Koch'stalked out of Monday, night accused each other yesterday of fomenting a confrontation.

title: Lenny's Short and Unhappy Holdout
description: Lenny. Randle, whose agent believes he is underpaid by $80,000 a year, has flung himself on thepercy of the people who pay him. Abandoning his plan to quit baseball and sell real estate in Arizona, the New York Mets third baseman, leading hitter and most larcenous thief of bases has decided to play this year for the salary provided in his contract unless the Mets come through with more on their own initiative. Experience has taught him, however, not to hold his breath until his employers loosen up. When the Mets bought him from the Texas Rangers for the waiver price last April, they signed him to a fiveyear contract, starting at $85,000 with small annual increases. During the season, because of his outstanding defensive play and his 304 batting aver- age. they tore up the contract and gave, him a $5,000 raise. Lenny considered it extraordinarily insignificant, said his agent, Gary Walker of Phoenix, Ariz.

title: Plan Offered for Times Sq. Hotel
description: The longstalled Portman Hotel will be built on Times Square if New York City can obtain $15 million in. Federal funds to help finance the project, according to officials at Portman Properties.

title: 5-YEAR P.O.W.  STUDY CITES LONG-TERM ILLS
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 25-Five years after their return, Americans who were prisoners of war in Vietnam have an unusually high divorce rate and suffer from continuing physical problems, but appear to have readjusted to military life with surprising speed.

title: APPROVAL OF MILLER SUPPORTED BY MOST ON KEY SENATE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A majority of the Senate Banking Committee said that they would recommend confirmation of G. William Miller, President Carter's nominee to head the Federal Reserve Board, after warmly receiving Mr. Miller's testimony at a committee hearing today.

title: Pop: Two of a Kind
description: THE BOOKING of Stanley Turrentine, the saxophonist, and Arthur Prysock, the singer, on the same bill at Avery Fisher Hall Monday evening created a sort of mirrorimage effect. Mr. Prysock is a stolid, heavyvoiced singer who delivers his songs in a deliberate manner and with a suggestion of sensuous, intimacy. Mr. Turrentine's saxophone has a tone, that is very much like Mr. Prysock's voice and, much of the time, his approach to his material is similar to Mr. Prysock's. One got the feeling that if Mr. Turrentine were a singer, he would sing like Mr. Prysock, and if Mr. Prysock played saxophone it would be vice versa.

title: Another Train Derails As CrewsWork on T racks In Florida and Tennessee
description: As crews in Youngstown, Fla., and Cades, Tenn., worked to clear railroad tracks of derailed cars filled with hazardous materials, another train derailed near Bowling Green, Ky., yesterday, with one load of insecticide and a carload of dangerous industrial chemical.

title: 1,500 Attend. U.S. Briefing to Hear What New C P.1. Means to Them
description: Sue I erner was in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel to find out how the new Consumer Price Index vill work because it will affect the prices of the magazines that are sold. by the company she works for, the Publishers Clearing House.

title: In Last Decade, Leaders Say, Harlem's Dreams Have Died
description: Harlem:.is now that brokenwinged bird. Its dreams are dead, its people are despairing and worse off than they ever were, and all the high hopes of the 1960's are gone.

title: Top South African Quits Tennis Team
description: Ray Moore, South Africa's most prominent professional tennis player and an outspoken opponent of apartheid, withdrew from his country's Davis Cup team yesterday.

title: Pop: Johnny Paycheck
description: JOHNNY PAYCHECK, who was at the Bottom Line Monday night for the first of several Manhattan appearances this week, is in the news these days for his catchy country hit, Take This Job and Shove It. But Mr. Paycheck, who was born, in Ohio and was originally named Don Lytle, has been around for years. He was a Nashville regular as a session man and soloist, a rockabilly singer, a selfconfessed alcoholic and, more recently, an honorary Texas outlaw.

title: Ban on Children's TV Ads Weighed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)The Federal Trade Commission today decided to hold public hearings on whether to order a curtailment of television advertisements directed at children.

title: New Westchester Airport Plan Supported by G.O.P. Legislator
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 28The chairmen of the Westchester County Board of Legislators and a group representing Connecticut residents said today that they would support the installation of a second Instrument Landing System (I.L.S.) at Westchester County Airport, 'the state's third largest airport.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A potential new hurdle to the resumption of coal Mining operations loomed today in the form of stalled contract talks involving 30,000 mine construction workers who are negotiating separately from the miners.

description: OS ANGELES, Feb. 28(AP)---2ara cully Brown, the doting Mother Jeftierson of the CBSTV show The Jefferson, died today at CedarsSinai Medical Oenter. She was 86 years old.

title: Police Correct DrugArrest Report
description: The New York City Police Department said yesterday that one of its spokesmen had incorrectly told The New York Times late Tuesday that 54 civilians, arrested on drug charges during a twoyear investigation of police involvement with narcotics, had been its employees.

description: Jahn O'Donnell, general counselof the Transport Workers. Union, warned yesterday of the possibility of another transit strikc on April 1 like the 12day walkout that all but paralyzed New York City in 1966.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Senator Thomas J. McIntyre, Democrat of New Hampshire, will announce his support for the Panama Canal treaties tomorrow, Congressional source disclosed.

title: THOMAS C. SHEEHAN
description: Thomas C. Sheehan Jr., a retired lieutenant colonel, who served with the 44th Division in the National Guard and was an intelligence officer in Europe in World War II, died Monday in a nursing home in Richmond, Va. He was 74 years old and had Uwe( in Arlington, Va.

description: In this country we live in a modified market economy where wages are determined by the supply of a particular type of labor or skill, by tradition, by the power of labor unions and to some extent by government intervention. As wages rise, so do prices.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ALL SET A welcome sign of spring is the new season of free midday programs starting today at the downtown branch of the Whitney Museum at 55 Water Street. Today's per- formers at 12:30 P.M. are the Mozart on Fifth ensemble, formerly the Mostly Mozart Ttio, in works from the Classical woodwind repertory. In addition to music, the series, also includes dance, readings and experimental shows as a diversion for visitors and Workers.

title: F.B.I. Memo Says Agency Kept Data On Panther Phones
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 28A newly released memorandum from the Federal Bureau of Investigation discloses that the agency kept telephone records of the Black Panther headquarters here during the time that Alex Rackley, a Panther member, was murdered.

title: In Last Decade, Leaders Say, Harlem's Dreams Have Died
description: Harlem is now that brokenwinged bird. Its dreams are dead, its people are despairing and worse off than they ever were, and all the high hopes of the 1960's are gone.

title: Corporation Affairs Dow Chemical and Soviet Sign a Technological Pact
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday it signed a 10year technical cooperation agreement with the Soviet Union's State Committee for Science and Technology. Dow also disclosed it was discussing a possible arrangement under which the Soviet Union would provide petroleum products for Dow's European operation's and Dow would increase its exports of agricultural chemicals to Russia.

title: Mineo Suspect Loses Motion
description: LOS ANGELES, eb. 28 (UPI)Judge William Ritzi of California Superior Court denied today a motion to dismiss an indictment against Lionel Williams, charged with the 1976 stabbing death of Sal Mineo, the actor. Mr. Williams's attor- ney, Robert Harris, had argued that only half a percent of felony cases were taken before a grand jury and that there was was no reason to take that route in his client's case. Under a grand jury indictment, there is no preliminary hearing to give the defense a chalice to see how the case is shaping up.

title: Industrial West Sets A Convoy Approach
description: PARIS, Feb. 28Western industrial countries formally announced today that they were switching tactics in their struggle to help the, world out of its economic doldrums. They said they planned to replace their locomotive approachof a few economies trying to pull others out of their problemswith a convoy approach.

title: About New York
description: The last tap dance does not seem very sad. The women are In all manner of rehearsal clothes, from legwarmers to baseball cap, and their disunity of dress is refreshing  as colorfully curved and taut as their personalities and bodies. They go through the hours of learning the last tap dance with laughter and energy, aches and exhaustion, and frequent stares at themselves dancing long and angled in the rehearsal hall's mirrors.

description: NASHVILLEDr. Sallie McFague, the tweedy, softspoken dean of the Divinity School at Vanderbilt University, is strong in her convictions but normally reserved in heir actions.

title: John J. B. Shea, Reform Democrat
description: John J. B. Shea, a leader in the Democratic reform movement here, died Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 21 East 87th Street. He was 54 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times Monday incorrectly reported the terms of an agreement between the trustee for the estate of the bankrupt W.T. Grant Company and 26 bank creditors. The agreement, which is subject to court approval, provides for about $95 million to he reserved by the trustee pending a determination of the portion to be paid to the holders of two classes of convertible subordinated debentures issued by Grant.

title: ATTEMPT TO BAR DATA ON CANCER REPORTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)The Nivy and the Energy Department both tried to block a study into a high rate of cancer deaths among civilian workers on nuclear submarines, Dr. Thomas Najarian told Congress today.

title: Remembering the Man Who Shaped the Boy
description: Death stirs the most primitive fears and the richest memories, so when a stranger went back for a relative's funeral to Kansas City, the place where he had been born but had visited only once since he left there 37 years ago, his mind returned again and again to the forces that had shaped him.,

title: LANCE GIVES STATEMENT FOR BANK INVESTIGATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (UPI)  Bert Lance gave the Government a sworn statement today in its investigation of an alleged takeover attempt of a bank holdine company.

title: Racing Group Predicts Sharp Gains If Takeout Drops
description: New York's thoroughbred racing industry said yesterday it would have a prosperous future if Governor Carey's bill to reduce the state takeout from parimutuel revenue was passed.

description: The Islanders scored twice in the third period last night and defeated the Maple Leafs, 43. Details, Page A22.

title: Private Lives
description: IT IS Sunday morning. I have emerged from the newspaper and climbed the stairs. The living room, mysteriously, is finished, except for one blank wall: We are waiting to be, surprised by a work of art. We have no Idea what this work of art will look like, but it is somewhere, in a bin, or a loft or a dream, and it will pounce. The blank wall knows. The art will be sincere.

title: Coal Strike and Its Impact on Carter's Energy Plan
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The coal strike may be ending but the repercussions may only be starting. Quietly at first, but now more vocally, energy experts are suggesting that the strike could hamper the Carter Adm'nistration's often- trumpeted plan to shift the nation's energy consumption toward coal from quickly depleting oil and natural gas.

description: WHEN one lives in a city where a woman roller-skating around a discotheque doesn't rate a second glance, it's obvious that mere fashion innovations aren't going to twich an eyebrow.

description: The coal strike may end this weekend. But the coal, problem will not. That cannnot be resolved by a single contract, no matter how long negotiated nor how cleverly crafted.

description: ATHENS, Feb. 28 (AP)The Public Order Minister said today that trained dogs would be used to stop soccer violence.

description: Paintings and sculpture valued at $300,000 that are the property of the Philippines Government were recovered by detectives last night from a Queens residence after they were stolen while awaiting shipment hack to the Philippines, according to thepolice.

description: O F ALL THE foods cookbook authors call for in  their lists of ingredients, none gets shorter shrift than potatoes. For though potatoes are designated by weight or number required, rarely does a recipe indicate which type is the best for, the preparation at hand.

title: A Night at the Moviesat Home  on Tap
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28-Quietly and with a certain fear of the unknown, 20th CenturyFox has become the first motionpicture company to make, its movies available for sale to the homevideocassette audience. Last summer, Fox licensed to the Magnetic Video Corporation 50 of its movies, including Hello, Dolly! Beneath the Planet of the Apes, Cleopatra and The French Connection.

title: DOW PLUNGES 623 TO 742.12, LEAVING IT AT A 3YEAR LOW
description: The Dow. Jones industrial average plunged yesterday to its lowest level in three years on the heels of a declining dollar in foreignexchange dealings and negative .economic developments on the domestic front.

title: China's Army N Not Believed Geared For an Invasion of Taiwan at Present
description: Although Chairman Hua Kuofeng has ordered the Chinese Army to make all the preparations necessary for the liberation of Taiwan, the implied threat has little credibility, in the immediate military and- diplomatic situation.

title: New York Sets SolidWaste Plan
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28Following Republican demands for a proposal dealing with solid wastes, the Department of Environmental Conservation made public today a $1 billion plan to recover usable materials from 64 percent of the state's solid waste by 1985.

title: RIGHTS GROUP ACCUSES IRAN OF NOT GIVING FAIR TRIALS
description: LONDON. Feb. 28 (Reuters)Amnesty International said today that procedures before military tribunals in Iran denied defendants the possibility of a fair trial.

title: Carter's Urban Policy Is Delayed,
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A delegation of mayors was told at the White House today that President Carter's urban policy, scheduled to be announced by March 15. would be delayed by one week:

description: TRENTON, Feb. 28Governor Eyme  said today that he would rocket veto 24 hill: pvsm?d by the last Legislature, including one that would have allowed each of the state's 567 municipalities to set its own pornography standards.

title: I. KAUFMAN, 85, DIES; 54 YEARS A NEWSMAN
description: I. Kaufman, a reporter for The Brooklyn Eagle in its heyday and chairman of its Newspaper Guild unit when the newspaper ended its 114year career during a 1955 guild strike, died yesterday at BeekmanDowntown Hospital, where he had been a patient since Dec. 19. He was 185 years old and lived at 84 Remsen Street, Brooklyn.

title: Miss Krupsak Says
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28Lieut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said today she had finally burrowed her way into the Inner workincis of Gov'rnor Carey's administration, but still had not yet decided whether to accept Mr. Carey's request to run for reelection with him this year.

title: Key Indicators Fall 1.9%; Drop Sharpest in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The index of leading indicators, a Government barometer of the economy, took its sharpest drop in three years in January, the Commerce Department reported today, but economists both inside and outside the Government said the prospects are not so bleak as the index suggests.

title: Soviet War. Games a Hit With First U.S. Spectators
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28For the Soviet Army, a largescale military exercise in the dead of winter is nothing out of the ordinary. But for two United States Army officers, who two weeks ago became the first Americans to witness military maneuvers in the Soviet Union since World War II, the experience was something special.

title: Germans Hypnotize Croats
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Feb. 28 (AP)Ten spectators were reported hypnotized while attending a West German circus in a small Croatian village and three of them could not be brought out of their trance after the performance. The Bel- grade newspaper Politika said today that a local physician succeeded in breaking the hypnosis after several hours. The police are planning criminal proceedings against the circus for violation of Yugoslav regulations banning hypnotist shows from using spectators.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, Feb. 28Any wouldbe Edisons may have, an easier time of it in New Jersey under a new state law signed today.

title: World News Briefs

title: Elizabeth Wolff, Pianist
description: AD CHOPIN dropped into Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night to hear Elizabeth Wolff play his Op. 28 P udes, he might have done a swift double take. There was Miss Wolff seated at the keyboard dressed in a beauti fully tailored black pants suit complete with vest and velvet red bow tie, looking for all the world like a reincarnation of George Sand.

title: CARTER ASKS 24% RISE IN EDUCATION FUNDS, WITH FOCUS ON BASICS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  President Carter urged today that the nation focus on basic educational skills as he asked Congress fora 24 percent increase in Federal funds for education.

title: Dollar, Losing Gains, Is Lower in Trading Here and in Europe
description: The volatile United States dollar slid lower in foreignexchange trading here and abroad yesterday, erasing its sharp gains earlier in the week, The Associated Press reported.

title: Beker Industries Chief Executive To Resume Position Temporarily
description: Erol Beker, chairman of the Beker Industries Corporation, said yesterday that he had resumed his former position as chief executive officer of the agricultural fertilizer company. He said he would serve in that post until A. P. Gates, the company's president, had recovered from a recent illness.

description: EVERY time there's a big snow, we hear the dedicated souls who brave the elements and about the legions who take one look out the window and call it a day. And then, somewhere between the determined and the bedbound, there are people like Sonny Orr.

title: U.S. Denies Soviet Cheats on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Carter Administration asserted today that the Soviet Union had not violated. the 1972 strategic arms, accords despite charges that some aspects of its defense activity were, violations.

title: Drug for Epilepsy Gets Fast Approval. For Patients in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)The Food and Drug Administration today approved an anticonvulsive drug that experts predict will help more than a half million victims of epilepsy, some of whom are incapacitated by seizures.

title: FINANCING VOLUME IN BONDS IS HEAVY
description: Corporate bonds yielding almost 9 percent and taxexempt bonds with slightly more than WA percent were offered to investors yesterday as the credit markets handled a moderately heavy volume of financing.

title: Prices Paid Farms Up 3% in February For 5th Rise in Row
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28 (AP)Prices farmers received for the products were 3 percent higher in February than in January for a fifth consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture. Department reported today. The Department said higher prices for cattle, hogs, eggs, oranges, broilers and calves accounted for most of the increase.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS STAND OF I.RS. ON TAX IN LUNCHMONEY CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28The Supreme Court ruled today that the Internal Revenue Service could not compel an employer to withhold retroactively Federal income tax on lunch allowances paid employees but not considered at the time to be a part of their wages.

title: VIEW HURDLE LOOMS IN COAL NEGOTIATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28A potential new hurdle to the resumption of coal mining operations loomed today in the form of stalled contract talks involving 0,000 mine construction workers who are negotiating separately from the Ininers.

title: Wine Talk
description: THE initial step toward master ing any subject is learning its jargon. Wine is no exception, although, unfortunately, too many people know the, jargon and nothing else.A familiarity with the language of wine is no substitute for an ability to, taste, but it makes tasting and enjoying wine easier and more meaningful.

title: Careers
description: Jobs in international business require many of the same qualifications that might be expected for diplomatic posts abroad, according to J. Tylee Wilson. An executive vice president of R, J. Reynolds Inc., he serves as chairman of its tobacco subsidiary, R. J. Reynolds Tobacco International Inc.

title: Notes on People
description: THREE lawyers prominent in the civil liberties field have formed their own firm and will charged some clients the current hourly rates for legal services, some reduced fees, and some no fee at all if the clients cause is just, their need real, and their rights undefended. Partners in the Manhattan firm are Ramsey Clark, the former Attorney General; Melvin L. Wulf, former legal director of the American Civil Liberties union, and Alan H. Levine, former staff counsel of the New York Civil Liberties Union. In a letter to friends, the attorneys said; We will extend our practice to any area of law we find interesting, any cause which is just, any principle we see imperiled, any worthy enterprise needing our skills. We will not appear on behalf of any cause which we believe is wrong. We shall try to divide our time equally between free, reduced, fee, and full fee cases.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IN ANY broad concept of 60minute cookry, gourmet style, it would impossible to ignore some of the more expensive cuts of meat, for many of these most emphatically play an important role in what might be called the resources of the hasty cook.

description: LLEONARD BERNSTEIN has contributed a number of pieces to the popconcert repertory, among them the ubiquitous Overture to Candide, so ears were cocked for his latest entry on Monday night at Carnegie Hall. Entitled Slava! (A Political Overture), the 4minute work was dedicated to Mstislav Restropovich, who con- ducted Washington's National Symphony Orchestra in the premiere last October in Washington. Slava, you must understand, is Mr. Rostropovich's nickname; it also means glory in Russian.

title: News Summary
description: China's leaders seem to be trying to restore an orderly government and regain popular confidence after a decade of turmoil caused by the Cultural Revolution. The leaders have begun a drive to correct a variety of abuses in which Chinese have been persecuted for political reasons or mistreated by arrogant and corrupt officials. A number of such reforms have been given wide publicity in the Chinese press and could involve one of the most significant changes since the death of Mao Tsetung. [Page A1, Columns 56.]

title: British Soldier Killed in Ulster; Army's First Death There in 78

Dodge division of the McGraw Hill Information Systems Company.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Thirtyseven years ago, while still a student at George Washington University, William Frederick Leonard Bolger started to work as a postal clerk. Today he was named Postmaster General.

title: Accused Rapist Freak Dead Riitger Seized
description: In a case of mistaken identity, James Glover, a 34-year-old man with close. cut hair and a short beard, spent six weeks in jail, charged with a series of rapes on Manhattan's East Side that the police now believe were committed by another man.

title: Blumenthal to Press City Aid Plan In Hearing of House Unit Today
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal will testify tomorrow before a subcommittee of the House Banking Committee on an Administration plan for cooperation among New York City, New York State and the Federal Government for fiscal aid to the city. The plan involves continued Federal loan assistance for the city beyond the scheduled June 30 cutoff date.

title: Film: The 'Life' of a Saint in Latin:Well-Muscled Cast
description: BEFORE you take any budding little linguists in the family to see "Sebastiane," think it over. Yes, this is the first feature film ever made in Latin, and yes, it deals with the life of a saint. But what is the tanned, well-muscled male cast intoning about in such a serious-sounding tongue? Piles. Insects. St. Sebastian's famous masochism. And the contents of one another's very skimpy loincloths."Sebastiane," a soft-core gay porno epic, is prettily photographed by Peter Middleton and rather languidly directed by two Englishmen, Derek Jarman and Paul Humfress (Mr. Jarman, the set designer for Ken Russell's "The Devils," reflects a bit of Mr. Russell's extravagance but none of his wit). The film includes footage of the martyrdom of St. Sebastian, whose nude body is punctured by arrows in some remarkable places.

title: New China Charter Stresses Economy Over Ideology
description: HONG KONG, March 1China's nominal legislature was presented today with the draft of a new constitution that stressed the Government's concern for economic development rather than revolution.

title: Anger Greets the Coal Pact in Ohio
description: MLLES BOTTOM, Ohio, March 1Struggling valiantly but unsuccessfully to disguise their disdain for the assignment, Floyd Lamb and a dozen other officials of the militant District 6 of the United Mine Workers tried to explain the details of their newly negotiated contract today to a smoldering audience in the auditoriurn of the local high school.

title: Texas Recipient of Transplants Dies;
description: HOUSTON, March 1 (UPI)A 21-yearold oilfield worker who received heart and kidney transplants two weeks ago died today at St. Luke's Hospital.

title: CANCER SCIENTISTS TO BOYCOTT PARLEY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP)Because of reports of repression of Argentine scientists, some of the United States leading cancer researchers plan to join hundreds of other scientists in boycotting the world's largest conference of their peers

title: Aviva Players Give Premiere of Quartet
description: AVIVA, like Eve, is one of those palindromic words that $:ion't :care whether they are coming or going, But the group that calls itself the Avlva Players is unambiguous about its objective, which is to present concerts of instruments and voices with mostly women pertorming old and new music and introducing new .works by women cotnposers. That aim was carried out in almost every respect kn Tuesday night when the AViva Players gave a concert at Christ and St. Stephens Church on West 69th Street.

title: Yank Rookie Stuck in Catch22 Spot
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 1 Darryl Jones, an unheralded occupant of a locker in the corner of the Yankee clubhouse, is an example of baseball's Catch 22.

title: New Construction in January Off By 4%, Largest Decline in a Year
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)The Commerce Department reported todaythat the value of new construction nationwide during January was down 4 percent from the December total, the largest decline in a year.

title: No One Sings Happy Birthday For 200Mile Fishing Limit
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass.:March 1The 200--mile limit designed to protect AMerican fishermen from the competition of mechanized foreign fishing fleets is one year old today, but no one here is celebrating.

title: Iranian Police Official Is Killed In Renewal of Violence in Tabriz
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 1 (UPI) police precinct commander died in renewed violence in the west Iranian city of Tabriz, where nine people were killed last month in.the country's worst rioting in 20 years, unofficial reports said today.

title: La Salle 89, St. Joseph's 82 Temple 99, American U. 80
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP)Michael Brooks scored a gamehigh 31 points and grabbed 20 rebounds as La Salle defeated St. Joseph's, 8982, in an East Coast Conference quarterfinal playoff game tonight.

description: BONN, March 1The dollar fell today for the first time to a value of less than two West German marks, plunging below a psychological barrier that was regarded as having a crucial bearing on business confidence in many Western industrialized countries.

title: SUPPLIES OF FOOD DONATED TO PHILADELPHIA RADICALS
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 1 (AP)Mayor Frank Rizzo's promise to cut off food to a group of armed radicals in their ratinfested home brought an outpouring of supplies today.

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 1African nations asked today for a meeting of the Security Council with the aim of denouncing the Rhodesian internal settlement reached recently by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black leaders.

title: A New Postal Chief Is Selected, First Since 47 to Rise From Ranks
description: WASHINGTON, March 1William F. Bolger, a veteran of 37 years in the Postal Service, was named Postmaster General today and became the first to rise to that job from the ranks since President Truman tapped Jesse M. Donaldson of the Kansas City Post Office in 1947.

title: Hopkins Named Raceway Head
description: William B. Hopkins, vice president and general manager of Roosevelt Raceway, was named president of the harness track in Westbury, L. I., yesterday. The announcement was made by David A. (Sonny) Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, the track's parent company.

title: World Cup Skiing Starts Today
description: STRATTON, Vt., March 1In an event some natives maintain:, is. the most important since Daniel Webster spoke on Stratton Mountain in 1840, the fourday World Cup skiing races get under way tomorrow.

title: GARDENING
description: THE arrival of March closes the door on winter, by the calendar at least, and starts an annual garden ritual; seed planting indoors. Those new to this spring activity may not realize how much a house or apartment has to be rearranged to make room. Young seedlings need two essentials: warm sunshine and plenty of growing space.

title: Japanese Color TV Exports Off
description: TOKYO, March 1 (Reuters)Exports of Japanese color television sets fell 23.9 percent to 242,000 sets in January from 318,000 sets in. December, the Japan Electronic Industries Association said today. The latest figure was off 16.1 percent from 288,500 sold in January, 1977. Japan agreed in. July to limit its exports of color television sets to the United States,

title: ExC.I.A    Man Says Johnson Heard in 68 Israel Had ABombs
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Central Intelligence Agency informed President Johnson in 1968 that Israel had nuclear bombs, whereupon he instructed the agency not to tell anyone else, not even his Secretary of State. or Secretary of Defense, according to a former C.I.A. official.

title: Sabres 4, Flames 3
description: ATLANTA, March 1 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres, with steady goaltending by Bob Sauve and a thirdperiod goal by Jocelyn Guevremont, beat the Atlanta Flames tonight, 43. Sauve faced 40 Atlanta shots, including 11 in the scoreless first period when Buffalo could muster only four shots on the Flames goalie, Dan Bouchard.

title: Stocks Stage a Modest Recovery
description: Stock prices steadied yesterday, reflecting a modest improvement in the dollar in foreignexchange dealings, one day after the Dow Jones industrial average had plunged to a threeyear low.

title: U.S. Hardening AirFare Stand Against Britain
description: A source in the Carter Administration said yesterday that the White House was hardening its. position in the airfare dispute with Britain and that the Administration was considering renouncing the BritishAmerican air pact signed last summer.

title: Southwest Forest Appoints
description: W, A, Franke, president of Southwest Forest Industries, has assumed the additional positions of chief executive officer and chairman of the executive committee, the Phoenix company announced yester- day. In these posts, Mr. Franke, who 40 years of age, replaces Raymond E. Baker, who reached the company's mandator retirement age of 65 in February. Mr. Baker will continue to serve as chairman of the board for two years.

title: Family Money: A Home as Inflation Guard
description: THERE IS fresh evidence that buying a home is one of the best investments around. Over the long haul, owning a piece of residential real estate has proved to be a better hedge against inflation than United States Government bonds, Treasury bills, or common stocks.

title: First Alaskan Oil Arrives in. This Area
description: After a voyage of nearly 10,000 miles involving three oil tankers, the first shipment of Alaskan crude arrive in the New York area yesterday. The SS Erna Elizabeth, a 35,000ton tanker, docked at Chevron U.S.A.'s Perth Amboy, N.J., terminal to unload the cargo it picked up off the Panama Canal. The oil will be used for asphalt and boiler fuel. Capt. Gus Kukunas supervises the unloading. Alaskan oil production, which is intended to replace some imports, began last summer.

title: Department of Agriculture Sells Interest in Middle East Casino
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (AP)The Agriculture Department has finally posted a sold 'sign on its Middle East gambling casino in Beirut,Lebanon, selling out lock, stock and belly dancer.

title: U.S. Hardening AirFare Stand Against Britain
description: A source in the Carter Administration said yesterday that the White House was hardening its position in the airfare dispute with Britain and that the Administration was considering renouncing the BritishAmerican air pact signed last summer.

title: Rumor of Brazilian Curb on Soybean Oil Exports Spurs Futures Buying
description: CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)Rumors that Brazil had stopped issuing export licenses for soybean, oil touched off a flurry of speculative buying today that raised those futures to their highest levels since last summer.

description: WILMINGTON, OhioAt night, the weatherman stands in front of a huge, barely recognizable map of the country and bathes us in his passion for fronts and occlusions.

title: Emery Deal Collapse Poses Arbitrage Loss
description: Wall Street professionals, betting on a sure thing, stand to lose at least $5. million on a possible takeover of Emery Industries, the specialty chemical company, industry sources said yesterday.

description: A line of victims, all of whom went home sometime in the recent past to find something they had cherished gone, snaked across the waxed floors of Police Headquarters in New York yesterday on its way to a table made brilliant by precious, stolen possessions.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: EYE AND EAR: To learn the meaning of John Dowell's art  abstract lines and forms on white canvasesyou can listen to the painter at the piano as he leads the Visual Music Ensemble. The public is invited free tonight at 8 to the interpretive jazz concert introducing Mr. Dowell's new exhibition. It will run through April at the Dorsky Galleries, 4 West 57th Street.

title: I.M.F. GOLD AUCTIONED AT $181.13 TO $185.76 BID
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (Reuters)The International Monetary Fund today raised nearly $73 million to help finance a special trust fund for the world's poor nations at the 19th in its series of public ROM auctions.

title: AntiSonnoza Drive in Nicaragua Turns More. Violent
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 1Following the collapse of last month's businessmen's strike against the Government, the campaign to force the resignation of President Anastasio Somoza Debayle has turned increasingly violent as unrest spreads to Nicaragua's urban poor.

title: A Philippine Moslem Commander Surrenders With 140 of His, Men
description: ZAMBOANGA, Philippines, March 1 (Reuters)A commander of Moslem rebel forces surrendered with 140 of his men today after having fought. against Government troops for six years in the southern Philippines.

title: Va. Commonwealth 88, Georgetown 75
description: WASHINGTON, March. 1 (U131).4 Danny Kottak and Edmund Sherod, two freshmen, scored 29 and 26 points, respectively, to lead Virginia Commonwealth University to an 8875 upset of 14thranked Georgetown University in the E.C.A.C. southern regional game tonight.

title: Music: Adni on Piano
description: DANIEL ADNI, a young Israeli pianist who makes his home in London, made his New York debut a year ago as a winner. of the annual Young Concert Artists International Auditions. In a return recital at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on. Tuesday night, he played Beethoven's Moonlight Sonata, Liszt's Mephisto Waltz and Hungarian Rhapsodies Nos. 11 and 12 and Schubert's Sonata in B flat.

title: Abducted Italian Is Freed
description: BOLOGNA Italy, March 1 (AP)Abductors released the owner of a large shipping company here today after his family had reportedly paid a ransom of about $500,000. Giovanni Fagioli, .63 yeafi old, was freed in front of the railway station. He was,abducted Feb. &and was the first of, six persons abducted so far this year to be released. Abductors seized 72 persons in Italy last year.

title: Chicago Achieves Its Winter Record for Snowfall, but Only by a Wisp
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 27Somehow it was just not right. Chicago, the City of the Big Shoulders and all that, does things in a big way. And when a snowfall pushes the season's total past the record here, if it had any respect for the blustery history of the place it would come howling in off Lake Michigan on the icy haunches of a blizzard instead of whispering through the dark like a timid stranger from Sheboygan

title: Crowd in Islamabad Witnesses Flogging
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 1(AP) Several thousand people watched today as a 27-year-old man received 15 lashes as part punishment for having kidnapped and assaulted a 7-yearold girl.

title: Panel Is Set Up in Jersey, to Handle Complaints of High Lawyers Pees

description: TRENTON, March 1 (UPI)The Department of Insurance filed suit today against the Nationwide Insurance Company to prevent the concern from moving out of New Jersey.

title: Sound
description: TAPING MUSIC off the air has long been a, favorite, indoor sport and one of the main incentives for owning a tape deck. Countless collectors were tapping the musical reservoir of the sky to Make broadcast performances part of their personal musical hoard. But until recently, a whiff of felony clouded these cheerful doings, the question being a possible violation of copyright. Record companies understandably regard taping off the air as a form of stealing. They take the position that copying, their recordingsbroadcast or otherwisedeprives artists of their royalties and record concerns of potential revenue. Whatever the morals of the case, the law, at least, is finally clear. Under the new United States copyright law, effective since Jan. 1, taping off the air is in no way criminal as long as it is done strictly for private pleasure and with no commercial purpose.

title: The Riceman Cometh
description: SAN FRANCISCOLet us examine a curious connection between. two scandals: one, Koreagate, in which South Korean agents paid millions of dollars in cash bribes to members of the United States Congress; and two, the Marston affair, in which Congressman Joshua Eilberg induced President Carter to fire the prosecutor who was investigating him.

title: Infielder Energetic, Vocal at Practice
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1The new era of the New York Mets opened formally today with the first full workout of spring training and with a threeminute talk by Lenny Randle, who explained to his teammates his problems with the management.

title: Retiring Lefkowitz Looks Back on Fond Memories
description: With advice for his successor picked up in a halfcentury in New York politics and an affectionate look back at the clubhouse days of his youth, Louis J. Lefkowitz told a roomful of friends yesterday thatas some of them had said day earlierhe would not seek another term as Attorney General.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly indicated that Chinese forces were made up of 28 regular divisions and 18 local force divisions. Actually, these figures represent only the Chinese forces facing Taiwan. Total Chinese military strength exceeds 133 regular divisions and 70 local force divisions.

title: U.S. Envoy  Meets Sadat and Flies To Israel Again to Report Response
description: JERUSALEM, March 1 (Reuters)=-Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the special United States envoy in the Middle East, met in Egypt today with Foreign Minister Mohammed Ibrahim Kernel and President Anwar elSadat, then returned unexpectedly to Israel.

title: Carey Presents Proposals to Stiffen Fight on Crime
description: ALBANY, March 1Governor Carey today announced a tough new package of anticrime measures, including increased mandatory prison terms for persons convicted of certain violent crimes, life imprisonment for persistent violent offenders and sharp new limitations on pleabargaining by prosecutors.

title: Foyt Out of Coast Races
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 1 AP)1. Foyt, the defending champion, has withdrawn from this weekend's Datsun Twin 200 auto races because of injures he suffered during the Daytuna 500 last month. A.J. is simply hurtln. Lao much to race yet, his father said today.

description: Mayor Koch has chosen Axel Schupf, a Manhattan investment counselor and the president of the board of trustees of the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, to be the next president of the City Health and Hospitals Corporation, the $1billion semi autonomous agency that operates the 18 municipal hospitals.

title: Forgery Discussed By Robertson on TV
description: CLIFF ROBERTSON, the actor, yesterday made his first television appearances to tell the story about the forged check made out in his name that became the starting point of the scandal involving David Begelman, former president of the motion picture and television division at Columbia Pictures Industries Inc.

title: Engulfed by Yesterdays
description: I'M CLEANING out our attic, throwing out old useless things to make way for new useless things. The shuffle, Neer, tack and jib of taste call for constant revision, remorseless relegations. That piece we bought and showed with so muchpride first grew doubtful, then downright wrong. We've fallen out of love again: up to the attic with it.

title: 2 DIE IN COAST CRASH OF JET CARRYING 194
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1Two persons were killed and 50 were injured today when a jetliner ran off the end of a runway and burst into flames. But airport officials said that the skill of the 59-yearold pilot, on his last trip before beginning mandatory retirement on Friday, had saved scores of lives.

title: A Discreditable Tuition Bill
description: In approving a bill that would allow tax credits for tuition, the Senate Finance Committee seemed to be operating on the shabby theory that everybody loves a handout. Such an aimless distribution of billions of dollait would leave insufficient funds for higher education in the future. Worse, the extension of the tat credits students in private elementary and secondary schools would undermine the foundations of public education. President Carter, who has now given Congress his own package of greatly increased aid to education, is right warning that this nation cannot afford, and I will not accept bothhis student assistance program and the tax credits. It is the tax credits that should be abandoned.

title: Dance: Erica Meyers
description: ERICA MEYERS presented an evening of what she called erikinetics Tuesday at the Danspace of St. Mark's-inAheBowery. If one takes the first definition of kinetics as dynamics, or changes of motion produced by forces, Miss Meyers's tag was a sad misnomer. The five dances on the program were marked by a lack of any dynamic change, so that piece after piece swam together in one lowkeyed blur.

title: Suspected Drug Dealer Arrested
description: PENNSAUKEN, N.J., March 1 (UP1)A suspected drug dealer was arrested today on charges of handling $120,000 worth of pure heroin and cocaine. Ephraim Cintron, 22 years old, of Pennsau- ken, a roofer, was arrested in a 5 A.M. raid on his home by the Camden County narcotics strike force. The strike force said it acted after receiving a tip on its telephone hot line.

title: People in Sports . . .
description: When the Portland Trail Blazers meet the Knicks tonight in Madison Square Garden, they will play without Bill Walton. The allstar center stayed home to tend an ankle sprain he suffered Tuesday in his team's victory over Philadelphia. Coach Jack Ramsey said Walton had previously been playing with a sore right foot. . . . Arthur Ashe called the voluntary withdrawal by the South African tennis player, Ray Moore, from the Davis Cup series with the United States at Vanderbilt March 17 the best thing for Moore as a person. As for himself, Ashe said, he could not in good conscience play against South Africa if he were on the United States team. He said that he would Support the antiapartheid protests as long as they did not disrupt play. . . . The Newcastle United soccer team in England has earned $214,000 by exporting three players to the North American Soccer League. The latest was Ray Hudson, a midfielder for whom the Fort Lauderdale Strikers paid $87,750. Previous deals sent Paul Cannell, striker, to the Washington Diplomats and Graham Oates, utility

description: AMOVE to halt further distribution of the film The Man Who Would Be King was turned down by a Federal judge yesterday in a court battle that Sean Connery and Michael Caine have begun against the Allied Artists Pictures Corporation.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1A senior Justice Department attorney argued before the Supreme Court today that a Congressional investigator who committed burglary, or even murder, in uncovering relevant legislative information would probably enjoy immunity from civil or criminal legal action.

Rand Afrikaans Univprsity, where he endowed a chair for American studies with a $17,250 donation. title: A Federal Lever for Urban Jobs
description: There are two ways to assess the recent proposal by Commerce Secretary Kreps that more Federal procurement and construction contracts be set aside for minority business. It makes good, though limited, sense as a way to encourage such business. It makes much better sense as a way to spur economic growth in distressed urban areas. But, as so far presented, the Commerce plan focuses on too limited a segment of the business community. It cannot achieve the larger goal unless it broadened to tap more of Washington's enormous purchasing power.

title: Handcuffed in the Philippines
description: Perhaps because of Congress's tougher attitude toward aiding repressive governments, President Marcos of the Philippines has undertaken some small steps to relax the martial law he imposed five years ago. The most significant is the announcement of an election next month for an interim parliament, the first legislative electimi since martial law was imposed. Whether the exercise turns out to be a real step toward. democracy now depends on whether the opposition is free to conduct an active campaign. The latest signs are discouraging.

title: Pop: Roney Blakley
description: RONEE BLAKLEY'S perform-ance as Barbara Jean, the countrysingIng star in the film Nashville, has left a somewhat dubious Imprint on her image as a performer. She writes her own maternal, and much of it is in an assertive vein. But Barbara Jean was overwhelmed and eventually con,, sumed by her own creativity, and at times one almost expects Miss Blakley to burst into flames.
