Can I put polyurethane varnish on top o) the old varnish without it discoloring between the bare and varnished areas, or is there a light stain that can be applied on top of the old varnish and the bare wood before the polyurethane applied?1M., Glen Ridge, N.J.

title: CANADA EXPANDS RIGHTS ON PAY AND EMPLOYMENT
description: OTTAWA, March 1Under the new Human Rights Act, which took effect today, Canadians arc protected against discrimination in cer1an employment and provision- of services because of marital status and a range ether consideralions, and have the right to demand access to personal in on themselves in the Government's files.

title: Bossy: 2 Fast Hands That Inspire a Team
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 1Let's see those hands, his teammates demand. Fastest hands in the league.

title: Disks: Two by VillaLobos
description: HEITOR VILLALOBOS, the Brazilian composer who died in 1959 at the age of 72, wrote quantities of music that approach the voluminous output of Baroque figures such as Telemann and Vivaldi. He wrote live piano concertos in the last decade of his life, for example. The two works for piano and orchestra recorded here are actually relatively early products, but they are not well known.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods ended Dec.31 unless otherwise Indicated. (N) indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) overthecounter.

title: Hers
description: READERS TEND to snicker at newspaper stories with quotations attributed to taxi drivers, because the anonymous cab driver quote is a device much favored by reporters who are too lazy to ask any real people for their opinions. But I swear that the following story is an account of a real conversation with a real New York cabby.

title: Concert: Maurizio Pollini
description: PIANISTIC moths continue to flutter into the flame of the last Beethoven sonatas, and so do some of the eagles. Sometimes they emerge unscathed. Maurizio Pollini. last night in Carnegie. Hall, began the first of tworecitals devoted to the last six sonatas. He is doing them in chronological order, which means that on this occasion he played the E minor (Op. 90), the A major (Op. 101) and the B flat (Op. 106), the lastnamed of course being the Hammerklavier.

title: Advertising; American Motors Moves to Grey; Network TV in Crisis?; Harvard on 42d Street; Viasa's Umbrella to AH&R; Accounts; People
description: The American Motors Corporation is moving its passengercar business to Grey Advertising, a farmer Ford agency.

title: 10 Sites Bombed in Spain to Halt Construction of a Nuclear Plant
description: BILBAO, Spain, March 1 (Reuters)Tenoffices and installations of the Iberduero PElectric Company were bombed today, and Basque separatist guerrillos said they were responsible and that it was an attempt to stop, the construction of a nuclear power plant in the Basque town of Lemoniz.

title: Theft  Victims  Invited  to  a  Rich Loot   Showing
description: A line of victims, all of whom went home sometime in the recent past to find something they had cherished gone, snaked across the waxed floors of Police Headquarters in New York yesterday on its way to a table made brilliant by precious, stolen possessions.

title: Soviet Sharply Increases Prices of Gas and Coffee
description: MOSCOW, March 1The Soviet Union doubled the price of gasoline today, citing as a reason the growing cost and difficulty of developing the remote oilfields of Siberia.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Two major producersof copper, Marco Inc. and the Duval Corporation, cut the price of refined copper in a surprise move yesterday to 60 cents a pound, undercutting competitors that were simultaneously bringing their prices into line. at 61.5 cents a pound.

title: French Candidates Barbers Split Hairs in FiscalDebate
description: PARIS, March 1Raymond Barre, the conservative Prime Minister of France, and Georges Marchais, the ComMunist leader, may have little in common politically. But both have taken to consulting their barbers about the economic state of the country.

title: MurderSuicide Motive Is a Mystery
description: BEACON, N.Y., March 1An 18-yearold Beacon High School student who shot a 14-year-old neighbor to death and then killed himself yesterday evening apparently had no rational motive and was extremely disturbed at the time, the police said today.

title: Swiss Extend 10% Quarterly Levy To Central Banks Franc Deposits
description: GENEVA, March 1Switzerland took stall another drastic step today in an effOrt to clip the wings of its highflying franc by extending to foreign central flunks the 10 percent quarterly levy irn.Posed on foreign held Swiss franc deposits.

title: Met to Increase Season and Prices
description: FIVE new productions, a 30week seasonthree weeks longer than the current oneand higher ticket prices will be features of the Metropolitan Opera's 197879 season, which will open on Sept. 18 with Tannhauser. The Wagner work was the most successful critically of the new productions this season, and will be presented with Teresa ZylisGara, James McCracken, Bernd Weikl and Kurt Moll (debut), under the direction of James Levine, the company's music director.

title: A Show at the Met on What's Out of Fashion
description: DAN1SH modern, the style that dominated the popularity polls through most of the 1950's and into the 1960's, has long been. out of fashion. Much earlier, Swedish modern was in, then out. The exotic designs crafted by Carlo Bugatti, and the flamboyant, undulating chairs and settees sculptured by Antonio Gaudi and by Wendell Castel never were widely sought. Only maverick collectors found merit in them.

title: STABBED CHALLENGER STAYS IN  N.M.U. RACE
description: Louis Hale sat up in his bed at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan yesterday afternoon and, wincing a little from deep stab wound in his left thigh, replied, Absolutely, no, when asked if he would give up his race for the presidency of the National Maritime Union.

title: Norton Accepts Title Shot
description: Ken Norton accepted yesterday an insulting offer of $200,000 to fight Leon Spinks for the world heavyweight championship.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A threemonth lockout of 1,200 workers at the CurtissWright Corporation jet engine and ship parts plant in WoodRidge ended yesterday, with employees returning to their jobs after approving a threeyear contract.

title: Dane: Viola Farber Introduces Turf
description: AT HER WORST, Viola Farber creates dances that are either arid or coy, or sometimes both. At her best, she moves into cboreography that is totally unexpected in its movement shapes and that is controlled by a fine intelligence.

title: Bullets 125, Spurs 110
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 1 (AP)Kevin Grevey scored a career high 29 points and Bob Dandridge added 26 in leading the Washington Bullets to 125110 victory over the San Antonio Spurs tonight.

title: Reporter's Notebook Canal Stirs Real, if Not Always Great, Debate
description: WASHINGTON, March 1The Senate is really having a debate, about the Panama Canal treaties.

title: ES. STEEL CANCELS SUIT THAT ALLEGED JAPANESE DUMPING
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday withdrew a major antidumping suit against six Japanese steel producers, removing a possible stumbling block to the Carter Administration's effort to control the dumping of steel through a trigger price system.

title: Jazz: Joe Rigby And Quintet
Fleet Operators Shoe Readiness For Car Airbag
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Automobile fleet operators, including .the Federal Government, have expressed readiness to buy more than 60,000 cars a year equipped with airbag crash protection, according to the Department of Transportation.

title: Sanitation Agency Defends Its Action On Refuse Pickups
description: The Department of Sanitation said late yesterday that every part of New York City had had at least two garbage pickups since the snowstorm of Feb. 6. But a spokesman acknowledged that tons of garbage were still to be collected.

title: Cow Sidelines A Bears Center
description: CHICAGO, March 1 (AP)A kick by a cow on his Missouri farm has put the Chicago Bears center, Dan Peiffer, on the surgery list less than two months after he completed his first Na- tional Football League season. He suffered a torn ligament in his right knee and will be operated on this week at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. Afterward the knee will be in a cast for about six weeks.

title: Jazz: Miss Natal
description: ALTHOUGH the line between jazz singer and a pop singer is often rather vague, one identifying hallmark of the jazz singer is an ability to do scat chorusesvocalized, wordless lines in the manner of a saxophone or trumpet solo. Nanette Natal, who sings at the Tin Palace, Second Street at the Bowery, on Tuesday evenings, is an accomplished scat singer with a vocal range that allows her to execute adventurous ideas and to articulate complicated or demanding phrases with polish and assurance.

title: Pesign Notebook
description: HOME was never like this. Anyone who goes to see Image of the Home at the Institute for Architecture and Urban Studies (8 West 40th Street, through March 16) expecting anything resembling fashions in furnishing will be confused and disappointed. This ex- hibition of drawings by, Giuliano Fiorenzoli, .Nancy Goldring and Michael Webb, mounted with the aid of, a grant from the New York State Council on the Arts, deals with the furnishing of the mind. Its sources are Freud, Surrealism, SpaceTime, the technology of the future and remembrance of things pastnot the domestic styles that turn shelter into status and profit.

title: REP CHISHOLM IS OUT AS SCHOOLS NOMINEE
description: Representative Shirley Chisholm has withdrawn as one of Mayor Koch's choices for School Chancellor, apparently in response to City Hall's concern that key Republicans in the State Legislature would scuttle the Mayor's plan to restructure the Board of EdUcation if she became its chief executive officer.

title: Barry Neikrug Offers Mime Concert
description: THE PROGRAM for Barry geikrug's, solo performance Tuesday night at Alice. Tully Hall termed Mr. Neikrug a mime comique and called, his presentation A Clown in Concert. That seemed pretty fancy language to describe what was little more than a succession of harmless jokes.

title: Ac'cent Is on Music In Flavor. Campaign
description: Describing tastes with words is tough enough; imagine trying to do it with music.

title: $26,000-A-YEAR COST CITED FOR PRISONERS
description: It costs at least $26,000 a year to keep a prisoner in a New York City jail, the National Council on Crime and Delinquency said yesterday.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Outgoing

title: South African Convicted in Killings
description: KEMPTON PARK, South Africa, March 1 (AP)A court convicted a 24-year-old black man today on murder and terrorism charges stemming from a daylight assault last June in which two whites were killed in a Johannesburg warehouse. Solomon Mahlangu was found guilty of nine charges. He faces a possible death sentence.

title: Television
description: 4:59(2)The Jeanne Parr Show (R)

title: Rangers Top Wings; 2 Goals for Esposito
description: That old man of the New York Rangers, Phil Esposito, showed his younger teammates last night the value of never letting up in a game. Esposito, skating in his regular turn as well as on power plays and killing penalties, scored two goals to lead the Rangers to a 32 victory over the Detroit Red Wings et Madison Square Garden.,

title: Nets Turn Back Hawks As Williamson Gets 37
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. March 1Any game that, is still close in the final two minutes is usually decided in battle of strategies between the two coaches. Tonight, Coach Kevin Loughery had as much to do with the New Jersey Nets 9795 victory over the Atlanta Hawkg as John Williamson did with his gamehigh 37 points.

title: Maryland Wins in 3 Overtimes
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 1 (AP)Albert King, a freshman, scored 14 of his 21 points in overtime to lead Maryland to a 109108 tripleovertime upset of North Carolina State tonight in the first round of the Atlantic Coast Conference basketball tournament.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dialogue That Banishes Sleep
description: SOMETIMES it takes nothing more than a single line of dialogue to keep me tossing and turning in bed all night. The line may be a good one or a bum one or just one that's turned up in two different plays during the same week. Always has the same effect. keep running it through my head trying to read its implications. How did the author ever think of it? Whythese are the bum or repeated onesdid he bother?

title: No One Sings Happy Birthday For 200Mile Fishing Limit
description: GLOUCESTER, Mass., March 1The 200mile limit designed to protect American fishermen from the competition of mechanized foreign fishing fleets is one year old today, but no one here is celebrating.

title: Gasoline Mileage Ratings Raised
description: DETROIT, March 1 (AP)The Environsmental Protection Agency has raised some gasoline mileage ratings of the. Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon by two miles a gallon, according to Chrysler Corporation. Charles Heinen. director of fuel economy for Chrysler, told a meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers yesterday that the agency had given the cars a rating of 41 miles a gallon for highway driving and 32 for combined cityhighway driving if equipped with fourspeed manual transmission. The old ratings were 39 and 29. The city rating remained the same at 27.

title: Carter Plans Address At Press Club Today
description: President Carter is scheduled to address the National Press Club in Washington at noon today.

title: Capital Spending in West: Sluggish Prospect for 78; Leonard Silk; The Economic Scene; Worldwide Investment in Plantand Equipment The change In spending (measured in current United States dollars) by the 100 leading industrial companies in 13 selected countries.
description: The Western world appears destined to go on sluggishly through 1978or possibly to slide backwardif the major industrial. companies of each of the 13 most important industrial countries hold to their present investment plans. This gloomy conclution emerges from a survey of 100 leading companieg in each of the countries by the McGrawHill department of economics. As the accompanying chart shows, the survey found that these major companies are planning to increase their outlays on new plant and equipment by only 6.4 percent in 1978, measured in current dollars, compared with an increase of 6.8 percent in 1977.

title: Palestinian Reported Executed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 1 (Reuters)The Palestinian press agency, Wafa, reported today that a firing squad had executed a Palestinian for his part in the, killing of a Palestinian official in Paris, more than five years ago. The agency said that Salim Hussein Qasem Abu Sobh was shot yesterday after having confessed to cooperating with Israeli intelligence in the killing of Mahmoud al-Hamshari, director of the Palestine Liberation Organization office in Paris, in December 1972.

title: Indians Seeking To Play Cubans
description: No major league baseball team will play in Cuba this spring, but the major league executive council is considering a request by the Cleveland Indians to play three exhibition games next month in Arizona against a Cuban team.

title: HEAD OF WOMEN'S GROUP CRITCIZES MISSOURI SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, March 1Eleanor C. Smeal, president of the National Organization for Women, said today that an antitrust suit filed by Missouri's Attorney General was an attack on freedom of speech instigated by vested economic interests.

title: Sanderson Is Impressive in Comeback
description: KANSAS CITY, March 1Playing for free, before a Central Hockey League crowd of about 2,000, Derek Sanderson made an impressive return tonight.

title: Yank Drills Delight Young and Old
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.When Cliff Johnson drilled a battingpractice pitch over the leftfield fence, 5-yearold Michael Metz yelped in delight and 84-year-old Vernon Drape applauded politely.

title: CARTER TO ACT FAST IF COAL PACT FAILS
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 It coal Miners reject the tentative contract they are considering, President Carter will move immediately, perhaps as early as Monday, to reopen the coal mines, Secretam of Labor Ray Marshall said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: ALL THAT I KNOW of Chicago anymore lies inside O'Hare international Airport and it's adjoining Hiltonwhich is like judging the experience of breathing fitni the confines of an iron lung. But Bette. Howland offers an antidote in her collection of autobiographical sketches. Blue in Chicago.

title: Official Urges Teacher Evaluation
description: TRENTON, March 1The State Cornmissioner of Education, Fred G. Burke, recommended today that the state's 611 local school districts be required to evaluate the effectiveness of their teachers, including those with permanent contracts.

title: Nixon Gifts Accidentally Sent To San Clemente, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)About 30 gifts from foreign leaders have been found at former President Richard M. Nixon's San Clemente, Calif., home, and an official of the National Archives has concluded they were packed accidentally in the haste of Mr. Nixon's departure from the White House.

title: PANEL, 19 T018, BARS PAYROLL TAX CUTS FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 1By a vote of 19 to 18, the House Ways and Means Committee rejected today a proposal to reduce Social Security payroll taxes this year and make an offsetting cutback in the income tax reduction proposed by President Carter.

title: Only 34% in a Poll Know Who Case Is
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 1 (UPI) A public opinion poll by the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University shows that only 34 percent of the people polled could identify Clifford P. Case as the Republican Senator and that only 25 percent knew that Harrison A. Williams was the Democratic Senator.

title: California Legislators Seek Property Tax Relief
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1Members of the California Legislature have been frantically seeking a form of property tax relief that could stave off voter acceptance of a proposal on the June ballot that would radically change local governmentfinance.

title: CONSUELO KANAGA, PHOTOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Consuelo Kanaga, a pioneering photographer whose career ranged from the 1920's to the 1960's, died Tuesday at the Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. She was 84 years old and lived on Baptist Church Road, Yorktown Heights, N.Y.

title: Home Beat
description: MOST PEOPLE want their children to live; in the style to which the parents are accustomed. But it's not always possible to find nursery furniture with sophisticated airs.

title: Personal Beauty
description: When Christine Duval was growing up in France, she was strongly discouraged from taking an interest in her looks. She went to a boarding school where only a clean face and neat hair were acceptable with the school's navy uniform.

title: TV Ben  Vereen Stars In Special on ABC
description: BEN VEREEN possesses a very special taleht that has had trouble finding an outlet in television, On the stage, most potably in Jesus Christ, Superstar and Pippin, the song-and-dance man was immediately and distinctively dynamic, often electrifying. On television, especially on a short series of his own a couple of summersipgo, his riveting energy seemed to be dissipated in pointless efforts to be ingratiating. His projected, image wound up dangling somewhere bOtween Sammy, Davis. Jr. and Pearl Bailey at their cuddlesome worst.

title: About New  York
description: Last Saturday, after his retirement decision was made and celebrated over a family meal, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz took his two teenaged grandsons bowling. He enjoyed watching for a while, but, looking over the lanes of ordinary voters all around, the itch of a lifetime .returned and so he, began working the crowd. He went from lane to lane, shaking hands and hearing his name that special. familiar way from strangers: Louie!

description: SHAFTESBURY, England, Feb. 28No radio, no television, no newspapers. No toothpaste, no soap, no cosmetics. No electricity, no running water, no indoor topts. No cigarettes, no coffee, no tea.. w

title: Economic Scene: Capital Spending Plans
description: Continued From Page Dl be proceeding at a reasonably good lexel in 1978, the economic performances of these two countries do not look strong enough to serve as locoihotives for pulling. the lagging countries out of their slumps. Japan, which ;was supposed to have been the third locomotive, seems to be stalled itself.

title: STATE SETS UP PANEL ON HIGH LEGAL FEES
description: TRENTON, March 1 New Jersey residents who think they've been charged too much by their lwyers will be able to take their complaints to independent arbitration committees created today by the State Supreme Court.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (UPI)Vice President Mondale said today that he would visit Australia, New Zealand, Indonesia, Thailand and the Philippines next month. Mr. Mondale told reporters that he would leave April 6 and return April 16 after giving a major speech in Honolulu on American policy in the Pacific.

title: MACY SHOWS PROFIT OF 145% IN QUARTER
description: R. H. Macy & Company reported yesterday profit increases of 14.5 percent for the second fiscal quarter ended Jan. 28 and 16.9 percent for the half year period, despite three weeks of severe ice conditions followed by heavy snow storms and rain in January. The report yesterday noted that sales and earnings for both periods were the highest in the company's history.

He enjoyed watching for a while, but, looking over the lanes or ordinary voters au arouna, the itch of a lifetime returned and so he. began working the crowd. He went from lane to lane, shaking hands and hearing his name that special, familiar way from strangers: Louie!

The Pioneer will play in the E.C.A.C. Division IIIII. metropolitan tournament Saturday night at Trenton State against Kings, Point.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday incorrectly indicated that Chinese forces were made up of 28 regular divisions and 18 local force divisions. Actually, these figures represent only the Chinese forces facing Taiwan. Total Chinese military strength exceeds 133 regular divisions and 70 local force divisions.

description: PANAMA, March 1 (UPI)Moisds Torrijos Herrera, indicted in 1972 by a New York grand jury on charges of narcotics trafficking, is being replaced as Panama's Ambassador to Spain, the Panamanian Foreign Ministry said today.

title: SUPPLIES OF DISTILLATE OIL FALL 10.7 MILLION BARRELS
description: Supplies or distillate oil fell by 10.7 Million barrels during the week ended Feb. 24, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. Distillate oil, used for homeheating, dropped do supplies to 179.7 million barrels in the latest week compared to 190.4 million barrels in the preceding week and 131. 9 million barrels a year earlier.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: From its beginnings in 1961 as local diving and fishing club, the American Littoral Society has grown to an international organization whose members are dedicated to protecting and learning more about the highly productive, relatively shallow shore areas of the oceans.

title: Vida: My Feelings Don't Matter
description: MESA, Ariz., March 1After a winter of hibernation, Vida Blue was finally talking about what it's been like to he Vida Bltie. I didn'tthink about it, man,the Oakland A's lefthanded pitcher was saying. I went to out-of-the-way places to get away from it. But surely he thought about it, and now he couldn't get away from it any longer, even though he .had been reluctant to talk. I'm going to shoot pool, man, he had said Monday night. I don't want talk about Charley Finley and Bowie Kuhn, he had said yesterday. Talking about that, I might get a gun and be Son of Sam, man. I'm sorry I'm not Reggie Jackson, talk, talk, talk, but my life is not a soap opera. As he spoke yesterday, he stared at a package. I sent these George Benson tapes to a lady. and put my address on it instead of hers, he said. They came back to me.

title: Federal Indictments Expected Soon In East and Gull Coast Dock Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON. March 1After more than two years of investigation in Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports, Federal prosecutors in Miami are planning to seek about two dozen indictments ,charging a cross section of labor union and shipping industry officials with corruption, according to Government sources familiar with the case.

description: WASHINGTON, March 1 A few times in his life a newspaper reporter meets a political figure and senses authentic greatness: a magnetic external presence combined with a sense of inner serenity. That happened to me on June 9, 1975, in the South African mining town of Kimberley. I met Robert Sobukwe.

title: Bonn Confirms a Deal to Build  6 Submarines for Navy of Iran
description: BONN, March 1 (Reuters)West Germany confirmed today that it had apProved plans to build six 1,400ton submarines for Iran.

title: Leafs 3, Flyers 2

title: Anger Greets the Coal Pact in Ohio
description: DILLES BOTTOM, Ohio, March 1 Struggling. valiantly but, unsuccessfully. to disguise their disdain for the assignment, Floyd Lamb and a dozen other officials of the militant District 6 of the United Mine Workers tried to explain the details of their newly negotiated contract today to a smoldering audience in the auditorium of the local high school.

title: Film: 'Crossed Swords':Shades of Twain
description: "CROSSED SWORDS" has many things going for it. It's based on Mark Twain's classic, "The Prince and the Pauper," about the mad mix-up that ensues when a 10-year-old London beggar boy and his look-alike, Prince Edward, the son of Henry VIII, change places, the one to stand the court on its ear, the other to learn the bitter facts of life in Tudor England.The movie contains some stunning views of English palaces and country-sides, a lot of swordplay and its fair share of grandly fruity lines, such as the one spoken when Henry (Charlton Heston) finds the pauper hiding in his garden and steps on the boy's back. The boy cries out, "What?" bellows Henry. "Is the weight of England too heavy for you? I've carried it for these 5 and 30 years!"When I was two-and-eight, I loved this kind of dialogue, though I was puzzled. Why did kings always say, "these 5 and 30 years"? Why not "these 10 and 25 years," or even "these 17 and 18 years"? No matterstyle was the thing.Style is not something that "Crossed Swords" is exactly burdened with, though the movie comes to life every time Rex Harrison, as the fastidious, wiley, Roman Catholic Duke of Norfolk, makes his amused way across the screen, or when George C. Scott turns up briefly, but hilariously, as a snaggle-toothed bandit chief named the Ruffler, an ex-monk with a tendency to talk as if all speech were a Gregorian chant.The most notable thing about the filmand something that might guarantee its place in the history bookshas nothing to do with the esthetics of popular cinema, but with the fact it opens today at Radio City Music Hall and will probably be the last movie to play that most extraordinary of all picture palaces. The hall may well survive, but not as we've known it for the last 45 years."Crossed Swords" is not an inappropriate choice to receive this distinction. Though it is rated PG, it recalls the kind of romantic-adventure fiction that distinguished one of Hollywood's several golden ages and that served well the patrons of the Music Hall. I emphasize, however, that "Crossed Swords" only recalls those earlier times. It doesn't re-create them. It's a far cry from the sort of 1930's movie that starred Errol Flynn and presented great character actors such as Henry Stephenson, Halliwell Hobbes, Claude Rains and Montagu Love, who made the 1937 version of "The Prince and The Pauper" so entertaining."Crossed Swords" is vastly more elaborate and more expensive than that film, but it doesn't have its simplicity of spirit or even its know-how. Instead of the young Mauch brothers, the identical twins who played the title roles, it has an 18-year-old Mark Lester, who was such a steadfast little Oliver in "Oliver" 10 years ago, as both the prince and the pauper.I suppose the argument is that an older pair of heroes will attract a more sophisticated audience to "Crossed Swords," but Mr. Lester, now so long of limb as well as of tooth, simply looks silly in the roles. The readings are still those of a child actor and do not fit his physique. It's a comment on the age in which we live to be required to say of an 18-year-old actor: he hasn't aged especially well.As Miles Hendon, the soldier-of-fortune who befriends the prince on his travels around the kingdom, Oliver Reed makes every attempt to overwhelm the part and the movie. Mr. Reed's intensity as an actor is intended, I assume, to come across as character conviction, but the result is a kind of scary, humorless self-absorption. There's no sense of fun in the performance.There's somewhat more fun in the performance of Raquel Welch, as the woman Miles Hendon loves, if only because it's fun to see her in such costume spectacles as she exposes a perfectly straight face and a lot of well-tanned cleavage. Ernest Borgnine plays the pauper's vicious old dad as if Fatso Judson (of "From Here to Eternity") had awakened in Tudor London, which is not at all bad. There is also an attractive supporting performance by Lalla Ward as the self-possessed, opinionated little princess who later became Elizabeth I.Though the screenplay by George MacDonald Fraser seems to dawdle a lot, the direction of Richard Fleischer is much of the time paralyzed with indecision. Is "Crossed Swords" supposed to be funny or is it supposed to be an all-out adventure? The Old London sets are splendid, but the atmosphere is as tepid and unconvincing as that of a road-company operetta. When Mr. Fleischer cross-cuts between two lines of action, he has a unique way of cutting suspense in half instead of doubling it.There aren't so many costume films that one can easily dismiss "Crossed Swords." Yet one keeps wanting it to be better than it ever could be, given these circumstances."Crossed Swords," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), including some rough-and-tumble fight scenes, but nothing as blood-curdling as an average child's everyday nightmare.

title: Hard Sell on Nuclear Safety

The system was described as completely secure against efforts by terrorists or governments to extract weaponsgrade plutonium from nuclear facilities. It would thus permit, its advocates claim, worldwide expansion nuclear power without spreading the means to make weapons. If the claims hold up, the development would be a breakthrough in efforts to curb the proliferation of nuclear weapons: But the claims appear exaggerateda hard sell on behalf of rapid development of the next generation of nuclear reactors.

title: Notes on People
description: Paul Mellon, the art collector and horseman from Upperville, Va., recently bought. Thomas Gainsborough's famous por trait of ir Benjamin Truman, the British beer baron, and he'd dearly love to put the painting in the Yale Center for British Art. But two art galleries and a lot of plain citizens are raising a fund to keep the portrait in Britain. We feet passionately concerned about saving this masterpiece for the nation, said JohnHays, director of the National Portrait Gallery, which has given $20,000 to the fund. The Tate Gallery, which is supervising the campaign, has collected almost $560,000 toward the $780,000 needed, by law, to match the Mellon purchase price and keep the portrait in Britain. Thousands of Britons have - contributed small amounts to the fund. The Gainsborough portrait appears on the labels of Truman's beer, a popular brew.

A key element of the plan agreed to by the Governor and Democratic legislative leaders is a threetime loser provision, under which a person convicted for the third time of robbery, rape, arson, serious assault or serious burglary would automatically be sentenced to life in prison although with the possibility of parole after a dozen years or so.

title: Screen: Harvey Keitel in 'Fingers':Petulant Nuisance
description: JIMMY ANGELELLI, the hypersensitive hero of "Fingers," which opened yesterday at Cinema 2, is a man who has no frieends and who doesn't deserve any. For one thing, Jimmy is too busy pacing, brooding, pouncing, snarling and having inexplicable conniptions to have time for much of a social life. For another, he isn't the sort of fellow who'll allow anyone to get very close to him.We know this, and a lot of other things about Jimmy, courtesy of his portable tape deck, which he carries with him everywhere (because it puts up a kind of wall between him and the rest of the world), and which he uses to play both classical music and 50's rock-and-roll (Jimmy's is a divided nature). He even turns on the machine in restaurants, in scenes that mean to establish him as a desperately insecure figure but instead make him out to be a public nuisance."Fingers" marks the directional debut of the screenwriter James Toback ("The Gambler"), who exhibits a fatal fascination with Jimmy's every petulant quirk. Mr. Toback, having created a character whose intrinsic charm plus 50 cents would only barely get him onto the subway, seems incapable of putting his hero in any kind of dramatic perspective, and he is apparently unwilling to explore him in terms more intimate than those of an introductory psychology course. Jimmy's mother was a musician and his father is a boorish gangster; his mother resents him bitterly and his father wishes he'd strangled him in his crib. No wonder the kid's got a headache.Many of Jimmy's troubles revolve around sex, to which he devotes himself far too selflessly, according to his doctor (if this isn't the only movie to show someone having his prostate examined, it ought to be). Jimmy is obsessively entangled with a strange, elusive, mysterious girl (Tisa Farrow) who is so spitefully uncommunicative that one begins wanting, in the spirit of the movie, to give her a good belt. Jimmy's machismohe tries to castrate a rival, thinks women are sexier without birth controlis enough to make Tarzan blush.Mr. Toback favors a stiff, staccato, nervous style of direction that's heavy on the hocus-pocus and low on verisimilitude or insight. Aiming for a mood of nightmarish abstraction, he borders all too often on jumpy incompetence. Although the film's production credits are impressivethe cinematographer from "Taxi Driver," the production designer from "Three Days of the Condor," the costume designer for "Next Stop, Greenwich Village"and suggest that the film ought to have a good feeling for New York, it contains moments of surprising amateurishness. The sets look uninhabitable and the sound mixing is particularly appalling: A phone in the back of a restaurant rings at top volume, and the music sounds equally scratchy whether it's coming from a tape deck or a concert piano.Perhaps this should have been the movie to establish Harvey Keitel as a leading man of depth and versatility, but Mr. Keitel's performance as Jimmy only underscores Mr. Toback's skittishness. The screenplay draws Jimmy's character in such rudimentary terms that Mr. Keitel might have breathed a little healthy confusion into the role by playing against it. Instead, he does little more than illustrate Mr. Toback's points with a textbook tidiness, turning each scene into a virtual exercise. The part of Jimmy on which Mr. Keitel concentrates most avidly is, you guessed it, his fingers, whether Jimmy is working as a loan collector in his father's employ or a pianist in his mother's shadow. Not since Captain Queeg have a character's hands done so much restless wiggling and tapping.Mr. Keitel, as always, gives an impression of earnestness and dedication, but everyone else in the film appears to be in a big hurry to get to his or her lunch date. Miss Farrow is lovely to watch, but she gives a performance of such low wattage she barely seems plugged in; Marian Seldes and Michael V. Gazzo, as Jimmy's parents, suggest that Mr. Toback doesn't believe there's any such thing as overacting.Jim Brown, as the only real sex object in the movie (he's the only character who doesn't wear underwear), has the film's most, memorably silly moment, in which he smacks two women's heads together because they don't want to kiss each other. This episode, intended as a kind of taunt to Jimmy, is only one of many things in the film that only Mr. Toback could, or would want to, understand.

Which isn't surprising, considering it was taken from a ritual used by certain African tribes.

Or it's worn with no collar at all, just sitting there on bare neck instead of a necklace. Men are also playing games with ties. The bow tie so favored by history professors is now so tiny, one man says he uses a tweezer pull the loops.

title: Lopez Stops Rossrnan in Six Rounds

title: New Faces: A Guide to Fresh Talent in Town
description: The Age of Discovery never ends in New York. It begins daily at showtime when audiences thrill to the sight of something most of the world has yet to see: a new face, a new performer who has suddenly flowered in theater, movies, dance, music, cabaret, or television. It is an experience unlike any other, certainly unlike comparing the current work of a timetested veteran with his or her past record. It makes for the visceral reaction to a fresh per- sonality, an emotion that may not quite be love at first sight but can. approximate it. The new face is never absent from the New York scene. It comes from somewhere offstage, whether out-of-town or out of Manhattan, but has found its way to the spotlight. What will become of it? Will it prove to a seasonal phenomenon or a hardy perennial? No matter, the new face is here now and there's a special feeling in seeing it while it is as fresittlooking new snow.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Hustle and rhumba untilyou drop might be the theme of the 50hour Dance Marathon but it's in a good cause. The Student Activities Board of Ade1phi University has put together a weekendlong party to raise $25,000 for the Leukemia Society of America. There will be 12 bands of all musical persuasions including the Beatles soundalike Abbey Rhode. Among the guest entertainers will be comedian David Steinberg, the hypnotist Gil Eagles and a'covey of belly dancers. Twentyfive couples have paid $200 each to participate in the full marathon, from 6 P.M. tonight through Sunday at 8 P.M. Admission tonight is $4, tomorrow from 10:30 A.M. to 4 P.M. it is $1. for each child and adult; $4 after 7 P.M. Admission for the day on Sunday, from 8 to 8, is $2 for adults and $1 for children. Admission donations are tax deductible. For further information, call (516) .7461368.

title: Not Yoga or Therapy, but Music Lessons
description: In her daily life, Karon Cullen seems unalterably attached to the telephone receiver and the board room, and when her day is over the 31-year-ald chief operating officer of an international promotions firm is tense. Needlework did not do the trick, and yoga, although satisfying, somehow could not take care of all the kinks in a highpressure style that is belied by this executive's Southern drawl. Miss Cullen is not the sort for Eastern religion, and a change of pace was not cnly not feasible, it was understandable; she liked, her life, she only wanted a little oasis of inner peace in a week of business-as-usual. And she found it at the keybbard.

title: TV: More On Having  Babies
description: HIS week's ABC Friday Night Movie, beginning at 9 o'clock is Having Babies III, the Roman numeral merely indicating that there already have been two other TV movies of the same name. Obvious- ly, the ratings have been encouraging. And beginning next Tuesday, Having Babies will go into a limited run as .weekly onehous series. On paper, the programs aim at dramatizing the highly emotional experience of childbirth. In practice, they are bringing ,the dreariest aspects of daytime soap opera to prime time.

title: Music: Levine Conducts Beethoven
description: HEN Gyorgy Ligeti's Atmospheres made its appearance in 1961 at Donaueschingen, one of Europe's leading avantgarde festivals, most composers who thought of themselves as intellectuals and pioneers were still enthralled with the tightly serial works of Boulez and Stockhausen. But Ligeti's piece would have none of that. It was one of fhe first important breaks with serial technique, and as events have since demonstrated, only the beginning of the end of the style that had dominated the 1950's in contemporary composition.

title: Parenthood: Testing for the Job
description: It may be the only job in the world you can't quit. Becoming a parent is all too easy, human biology having provided neatly for the whole process but being a parent is another matter entirely. As the writer Jean Kerr once observed, The thing about childrenand I can't be the first to have noticed thisis that, after you have them, thereafter you HAVE THEM!

As might be expected, The Selected Works of Mao Tsetung is never out of stock. The Chairman's works are now up to Volume V in English, and his Little Red Book is the best seller.

title: The Round Jack Nicklaus Forgot
description: Jack Nicklaus's golf is better than his memory. When came charging home in the Inverrary Classic last weekend, picking up four strokes on Grier Jones, three on Jerry Pate and Andy Bean and two on Hale Irwin with five birdies the last five holes, he was asked whether he had ever put such a finish before..I can't imagine any other time, said. It was the most remarkable thing I've ever seen in my life, said Lee Trevino, comparing it with Reggie Jackson's three home runs in the last World Series game and Leon Spinks's victory over Muhammad Ali. Well, it was remarkable but it wasn't unprecedented.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: Britain's Reserves Off in February
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters)Britain's gold and foreign currency reserves fell $167 million in February to $20.7 billion, the Treasury announced today. It was the first drop since May 1977. Britain's reserves have shown a consistent rise since their December 1976 low of $4.13 billion.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Down 3.7%
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 14.7 billion tonmiles, down 3.7 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 386,470 cars, down 12 percent from last year. The American Trucking Association Inc. reported intercity truck tonnage rose 3.2 percent from a year ago.

title: Coal Miners Hear Contract Terms
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 2Thousands of members of the United Mine Workers met across the Appalachian and Middle Western coalfields today, gathering in cinderblock union halls and schoolhouses to hear their deeply divided officers explain the complex Dronosed contract.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: LOOKING FOR CLUES: A technician examining the damaged landing gear of the Continental DC10 that crashed Wednesday at Los Angeles International Airport after two tires blew out and caused the gear to collapse. Officials are trying to determine why the plane crashed and burst into flames during takeoff. Two persons were killed and 84 were injured. Coincidentally, a Continental DCI0 taking off from Honolulu Wednesday also had two of its tires blow out, but the pilot successfully aborted the flight. There were no injuries in the Honolulu flight.

title: Hot Lines Help Catch Welfare Cheats
description: NEW HAVEN, March 2Jilted lovers, neighborhood busybodies and.., irate taxpayers have become a key government weapon against welfare cheaters through the proliferation of special hot lines for turning in suspected cases of welfare fraud.

title: JUDGE WARNS OF JAIL FOR DEFIANCE BY F.B.I.
description: WASHINGTON, March 2A _Federal district judge in New York has warned the Justice Department that he will consider imprisoning officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation or other persons who defied a court order to disclose the names of informers, according to transcripts released today.

title: CARTER ACTS TO BACK $2 BILLION IN BONDS FOR NEW YORK CITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Carter put before Congress today what he called a very reasonable and very adequate rescue plan for New York City. It would provide Federal guarantees up to 15 years for as much as $2 billion in longterm bonds.

title: Senate and House TaxWriting Units Back Some Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Senate Finance Committee recommended today that Congress consider cutting taxes this year by up to $35 billion, or $10 billion more than the cut proposed by President Carter.

title: Anker Supersedes 2 Boards in Queens
description: Two community school boards, that have refused to collect ethnic data required for Federal aid were superseded yesterday by Irving Anker, the New York City School Chancellor.

title: At the Movies
description: ;ONCE you've made the picture, that's when you'd better know what you're doing, Frank Yablans was saying the other day, when, right on cue, the telephone rang.

title: Williamsburgh Bank Gets Status As Landmark After Loan Pledge
description: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday approved a landmark designation for the headquarters of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank after it pledged $10 million for new mortgages and home-improvement loans in Brooklyn.

title: Blazers, Missing Walton, Bow to Knicks by 128117
description: The Knicks halted the Portland Trail Blazers sixgame winning streak, 128117, last night at Madison Square Garden, and the focus was on the man who wasn't there.

description: WASHINGTON, March 2President Carter asked Congress today to reorganize the Civil Service System so as to reward merit and penalize incompetence in the Federal bureaucracy.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: There has been a rash of robberies of New York's banks, 46 percent more in 1977 than in 1976, and most of the trouble seems to be that the banks are just too friendly. The low, open counters are easily vaulted; lack of glass or grilles encourages the quick heist. The kind of monumental archi- tecture that used to suggest security, solidity and style has given way to people .banks that are as chummy as the laundromat and about as distinguished in design.

title: Corporation Affairs

title: Excerpts From Transcript of Interview With Tito in Advance of His Trip to the U.S.

title: Palmer Cards a 65, Gains Tie for Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 2 (AP)With an old, familiar hitch of the britches and a flash of the famous grin, Arnold Palmer quickstepped out of the past with a seven-under-par 65 and gained a share of the firstround lead today in the $200,000 Florida Citrus open golf tournament.

title: Bridge:
description: Winning titles in five consecutive tournaments might be considered the equivalent of hitting home runs in five straight baseball games. This feat, the bridge one that is, has been achieved by Julius Fields of New York in recent weekend tournaments of the American Bridge. Association, which provides primarily for black players.

title: Market Place
description: A sick stock market, a takeover boom and impressive asset values reported for the first time to the Securities and Exchange Commission have led to numerous takeover rumors resulting in share purchases by speculators who believe the rumors.

title: Vance Confirms Soviet Aides Presence
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance confirmed today that two Soviet generals were helping to direct Ethiopian and Cuban forces in the war with Somali troops. Mr. Vance also said in an appearance before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that there were 35,000 to 37,000 Cubans in Africa, including about 11,000 aiding Ethiopia.

title: Seton Hall., Iona Ousted In Playoffs
description: UNIONDALE, L.L, March 2Gary Winton came back after a leg injury.. and sparkedArmy to an 8179 over=time victory over Seton. Hall tonight in the first round of the Eastern College Athletic Conference Metropolitan area basketball playoffs.

title: Belgrade Conference To Issue a Statement Skirting Rights Issue
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 2 (AP) The Belgrade conference on EastWest cooperation reached agreement today on a closing statement that would make no mention of human rights. The accord, which ended a twomonth deadlock, came after the United States and its allies gave up all hope of winning any humanrights pledges.

title: Transcript of Questions and Answers at News Conference Held by the President
description: Following is a transcript of questions and President Carter's responses at a news conference yesterday at the National Press Club in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Carey Aides Leaning to a Rescue Of Failing MitchellLama Projects
description: Top officials of Governor Carey's administration are leaning toward a rescue program for financially troubled MitchellLama housing developments that would tie rent increases, or increases in maintenance charges at cooperatives, to tenants incomes.

title: 7 Blacks at Panasonic in Secaucus Charge Job Bias
description: NEWARK, March 2Seven black employees of the Panasonic in Secaucus, a division of Matsushita Electric Company of America, have filed a class action suit in Federal District Ccourt here charging racial discrimination.

title: Nigeria Reports 18 Dead in Crash Of Civilian and Military Planes
description: LONDON, March 2 (Reuters)Eighteen people were killed when a Nigerian Airways aircraft and a Nigerian Air Force plane collided in the air yesterday, the Lagos radio said today.

title: Czech Is Orbited With Russian for Salyut Rendezvous
description: MOSCOW, March 2A 29-year-old Czechoslovak military pilot rocketed into orbit with a Soviet colonel tonight and became the first man in. space from country other than the United States or the Soviet Union.

description: JERSEY CITYWith an assist from Federal community development money, housing officials here are working to bring about property preservation and improvement in a historic Jersey City neighborhood, the Hamilton Park area.

title: Woman, 37, Survives Fall From 20th Floor
description: MILWAUKEE, March 2 (UPI)A 37yearold woman accidentally tumbled out of a 20thfloor window at the Marc Plaza Hotel here today, but survived when she landed in a ventilation shaft on a sixthfloor roof, the police said.

title: Barwick Given Mrs. Spatt's Landmarks Job
description: Kent L. Barwick, long associated with historic preservation societies, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Koch as the $33,000-a-year chairman of the 11-member Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: For a Tibetan, Comfort in Disgrace
description: HONG KONG, March 2China offered some unusual evidence today of what happens to officials once they are purged. For the Panchen Lama, at least, once the secondnighest spiritual leader of Tibet, political purgatory seems to have been comfortable.

title: Concert: Ilan Rogoff
description: IN the intermittent appearances he has made in New York since his debut here in 1965, Ilan Rogoff has shown steady progress toward artistic maturity, and, playing a Chopin program at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. on Wednetday night, he

title: Art: Zoom Lens Canvases of Alex Katz
description: HE people in Alex Katz's paintings have skin as flawless as a fresh bolt of vinyl fabric. The shirts they wear are obviously fresh from the laundry, and there is a similar spotless look to the spaces they inhabit, whether living room, loft or the out-of-doors landscape. And their hair! It is less the hair of nature than the hair of the shampoo advertising industryso clean and silky and abundant, and with the sheen of damask under lamplight. And this atmosphere of the immaculate extends to nature too. The sky and the ocean that we see in a painting like Islesboro Ferryslip likewise have a freshly starched and laundered look. The world of Alex Katz's paintings is a preternaturally clean, welllighted place.

title: People and Business
description: Expressing fear that proposed tariff cuts averaging 40 percent would eventually damage the domestic chemical industry, William S. Sneath, chairman of the Union Carbide Corporation, told an industry meeting yesterday that major tariff reductions would probably adversely affect the industry's $5 billion trade surplus.

description: 14 A.M., WKCR Symphony Concertante,Kubik; Legend for Orchestra, Imbrie; Symphony No. 1, Van Vector.

title: Top Carter Aides Seen in Discord On How to React to Soviet Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The United States finds itself at a crucial juncture in relations with.the Soviet Union, uncertain about the Russians motivations and about how to deal with them on the arms issue, the EthiopianSomali war, and pending dissident trials.

title: N.B.A. Referee Suspended
description: Richie Powers, senior referee in the National Basketball Association was fined $2,500 and suspended for three Raines for allowing the Hawks and the Nets to use zone defenses Wednesday night. Page A18.

description: John Rockwell

title: A Peachy Suggestion For Avoiding Trouble
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 (UPI)President Carter suggested today that his top White House aide, Hamilton Jordan, stay out of trouble by switching from Amaretto and cream to peaches and cream.

title: Rise in Mandatory Retirement Age Is Approved by Congress Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 2House and Senate conferees today approved legislation that would permit many thousands of older Americans to remain on the job by raising from 65 to 70 the age at which employers may compel their workers to retire.

title: Young Unable to Attend Rites
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March (Reuters)Andrew Young, the United States representative here, will be unable to attend the funeral next week of his friend the black South African activist Robert Mangalisco Sobukwe, the United States Mission said here today. The United States will be represented at the funeral by its AmbassadortoSouthAfrica, William Bowdler. a spokesman for Mr. Young said. Three of Mr. Sobukwe's children l'ave been in Mr. Young's care in the United States.

title: On C.I.A. Secrecy, News Leaks and Censorship
description: ARLINGTON, Va.  The secrecy agreement all Central Intelligence Agency officials sign when they join the agency seems to be the most elastic thing since rubber bands. Last fall, the former Director of Central Intelligence, Richard Helms, stretched it to cover a lie he had previously fobbed off on Congress. (He explained to judge that he had been unable to tell the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the truth about C.I.A. involvement in Chile because of his oath to protect sources and methods.)

title: Bonn May Act Against Escapes From East Berlin
description: WEST BERLIN, March 2-On a dark ainy night not long ago a small truck tuned off the transit route linking this isolated city with West Germany and drove into a deserted treelined road. The driver, looking furtively around, stopped, opened the rear door and let three people limb aboard.

title: Restaurants
description: ROM the outside, Mr. Lee on the southeast corner of Third Avenue and 25th Street, suggests a dark and nondescript neighborhood bar. Inside, however, it summons up images of an enclosed, Spanish garden. Add to the contradic- tory images that the owner is Chinese, his Hawaiian wife is the chef, her first cook is Chinese, and the menu is Continental with strong French leanings and a few Oriental accents, and you'll begin to understand the mlange of influences at work on this seven-year-old restaurant.

title: Decision to Include Reds In Italian Coalition Hailed
description: ROME, March 2 (Reuters)An Italian Communist leader cautiously welcomed last night's decision by the Christian Democrats to accept a limited agreement with the Communists and four other parties as a way to end Italy's Government crisis.

title: Prof. Edward G. Begle, Chief Proponent of New Math
description: Prof. Edward G. Begle, the foremost proponent of new math, died yesterday at the/Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif. Professor Begle, who was 63 years old, shared a dual appointment. in the university's School of Education and its department of mathematics.

title: Notes on People
description: President Carter has filled two vacancies on the President's Council on Historic- Preservation, appointing to the Council a second cousin, Cliff Carter, a Tampa, Fla., insurance company executive, and Richard H. Jenrette, the chairman of the New York brokerage firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The two are amcng the 10 Presidential appointees on the Council, whose other members are all the Cabinet members, the head of the Smithsonian Institution and the head of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. Robert B. Garvey Jr., the executive director of the Council, said that Cliff Carter was a civic leader in Tampa active in historic preservation and the arts. Mr. Jenrette, a former member of the National Trust for Historic Preservation, has restored several buildings, and his avocation is the history of architecture.

title: C . A.B. Says Britain Broke the Air Accord And It Asks Reprisal
description: WASHINGTON, March 2The Civil Aeronautics Board today labeled Britain's blocking of lowfare service by Braniff Airways a fundamental and flagrant breach of the air agreement between Washington and London and called for retaliation.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 2, 1978

title: Begin Gets Sadat Note, First Contact in 10 Weeks
description: JERUSALEM, March 2Prime Minister Menachem Begin received a personal note today from President Anwar elSadat of Egypt in the first direct communication between the two leaders since they conferred Dec. 2526 in the Suez Canal town of Ismailia.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 3, 1978

title: Mr. Miller's Cloudy Victory
description: Now that he has won the overwhelming endorsement of the Senate Banking Committee, G. William Miller expected to gain. approval of the full Senate today and thus become the next chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. The haste is a little surprising. Just last week, the committee postponed a vote on Mr. Miller's nomination, calling for additional witnesses to appear and information. Now, apparently under heavy pressure from the White House, those plans have been abandoned and Mr. Miller's name has been sent to the Senate for confirmation.

title: Wake Forest 82, N. Carolina 77 Duke 81, Maryland 69
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 2 (AP)Leroy McDonald scored 21 points and Rod Griffin had 18 and they led Wake Forest from a 9point second half deficit to an 8277 upset victory over 10thranked North Carolina in the semifinals of the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament tonight.

title: A POLL OF CATHOLICS POINTS UP DIVERSITY
description: A major new study of Roman Catholics in the United States shows that those with college degrees are increasingly likely to reject church teachings on such issues as abortion but are less inclined than in the past to abandon Catholicism.

title: Tributes to a Songwriter
description: Even for the ubiquitous Charles Strouse, this is an uncommonly, busy tripartite weekend.

title: Jury Impaneled in Jascalevich Case
description: HACKENSACK, March 2A jury of 11 men and seven women was impaneled today in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the surgeon who charged with murdering five patients at Riverdell Hospital in Oradell in 196566.

title: Harris James Martin, 53, Headed Secret Service in New York City
description: Harris James Martin,. special agent in charge of the New York Field Office of the United States Secret Service, died Wednesday in Toms River (N.J.) Community Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 16 West Dewey Avenue, Wharton. N.J.

title: Food Stamps Are Returned
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 2 (AP)Dozens of people who said that their consciences were bothering them are returning the free food stamps they received after last month's blizzard. A social worker said, I'm afraid we were responsible for a lot of domestic turmoil. Officials said that the criteria for eligibility were unclear, and that some of the people who returned the stamps were entitled to them.

description: Fireman Thomas Miceli of Engine Company 47 was en his way to work yesterday evening when he saw smoke coming from a Harlem building at 126 West 116th Street. A twoalarm fire was in progress.

description: The stock market's modest rally continued yesterday as takeover situations dominated trading interest on Wall Street.

title: What I Saw of Graft in the Movies
description: An illuminating glimpse into some phases of this graft was given recently by Mrs. Rudolph Valentino, wife of the famous screen star. We take pleasure in presenting to our readers the views of Mrs. Valentino, who as a former art director, is in a position to speak authoritatively on the subject.EDITOR.

title: What Mrs. Gandhi Won
description: Hard at work on the political comeback trail, Indira Gandhi seems to be profiting handsomely from the Indian democracy that she tried so hard to suppress when she was Prime Minister just a year ago. That is the message from India's villages after elections held in five of that country's 22 states last weekend. The surprise is not that the Janata Party, which rules in New Delhi, did poorly in two large southern statesit was not expected to do wellbut that the regular Congress Party was crushed by the breakaway CongressI (I for Indira) Party that Mrs. Gandhi heads. She now has a new base of power in a part of India which, because of its distance from New Delhi, did not feel so sharply the impact the suspensions of civil liberties under the emergency she declared in 1975.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2Ellliott Maddox looked around at all the new faces in the training camp of the New York Mets today and said: I don't even know half these guysand I may not, until the AllStar break in July.

description: PRINCETON, March 2A Princeton University professor looking through the open stacks of the Fine Hall mathematics library today found a rare copy of a 100-year-old mathematics-and-physics text he estimated was worth $8,000 to $10,000.

title: Big Federal Inquiry Into Hollywood Is Denied by Movie Industry Head
description: LOS ANGELES, March 2 (Reuters)Jack Valenti, the president of the Motion Picture Association of America, today denied press reports that there was massive investigation by Government agencies into alleged corruption in the motion picture industry.

title: Five Californians Indicted in $1 Million Swindle
description: Three men and two women were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on Federal charges involving a sophisticated stock swindle that allegedly defrauded investors of $1 million.

title: Zambia Hints Rhodesia War May Force a Turn to Reds
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 1Zambia, until now one of the black African countries friendliest to the West, has begun warning that it may be forced to seek direct military assistance from the Soviet bloc if events in Rhodesia turn it into a battleground in the guerrilla struggle for control in Rhodesia.

title: Around the Nation
description: JACKSON, Mich., March 2 (UPI)--A laborer opened fire on fellow workers ,in the lunchroom of a forging plant today and wounded at least 18 persons.WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP)The House today approved a proposed constitutior.al amendment that would give the District of Columbia voting representation in the House and Senate.YOUNGSTOWN, Fla., March 2 (UPI)The police lifted the barricades late today around a 140-square-mile ared, allowing thousands of residents to return to their homes for the first time since last Sunday when a cloud of chlorine gas killed eight persons.

title: Tories Win HardFought Election
description: LONDON, Friday, March 3The Conservatives won a hardfought and closely followed byelection at Ilford North last night, but not by as wide a margin as some observers had predicted.

title: Commonwealth Oil Seeking Protection Under Chapter XI
description: The financially troubled Common; wealth Oil and Refining Company which has been fighting for months to stay out of bankruptcy proceedings, yesterday announced it had filed a petition for court protection under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in United States District Court for the western district of Texas.

description: Rita Hauser, a Manhattan lawyer, and State Senator Joseph R. Pisani of New Rochelle yesterday became the first Republicans to declare their candidacies to succeed State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, who has decided not to seek reelection after 21 years in office.

A memorial service will be held on Saturday, March 4, at 11 AM at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 80th St and Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Harvard Law School Fund, Cambridge, Mass., or the Nantucket Conservation Foundation, Inc., Nantucket, Mass.

title: Mrs. Gandhi: Again a Force
description: NEW DELHI, March 2  The crowds were adoring and exultant yesterday morning at Indira Gandhi's comfortable old colonial bungalow here, and those who used to help her run the government, notably including her son Sanjay, were proudly performing old News Analysis tasks. As photographers scrambled for pictures of the 60-year-old former Prime Minister and her aides bustled about importantly, one of her supporters proclaimed to a triena, This is just like old times.

title: ExIranian Official Says 3 at Bell Knew Of Khatemi's Role

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 2 Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black nationalist leaders based in Rhodesia announced agreement today on the details of an interim government that would aim at a transfer to black majority rule by the end of the year.

title: Art: Homage to a Bar in Spain
description: IT'S not every bar that gets an exhibition to itself at a great university. title: Broadway
description: YOU probably forgot that Vincent Price has made more than 100 movies, and possibly this is all right with Mr, Price because some of them were so awful that maybe he wants to forget them, too. You should not forget, however, that long before Mr. Price made some of those cele- orates clinkers he was on stage opposite Helen Hayes in Victoria Regina, and that now and again he returns to the theater. On April 12, he will open at the Eugene O'Neill in Diversions and Delights. This is a onecharacter production in which Mr. Price will play Oscar Wilde in the last year of his life, and Joseph Hardy, its director, says it is a real play. Every time a onecharacter production comes to Broadway, the people who are associated with it say it is a real play, even though quite often it is not. Mr. Hardy, however, is adamant.

title: ...And Snow
description: On Jan. 20, 1867, Edward 0. Guerrant, a student at Bellevue Hospital Medical College, wrote to his sweetheart, Mary Devault, in Jonesboro, Tenn., to tell her, among other things, about the snow here. A former captain in the Confederate Armyhe wore his uniform, shorn of military insignias, in medical school because he couldn't afford a suithe was graduated a few weeks later and returned to his home in Mt. Stirling, Ky., to practice medicine, and married Mary. Later, he became a Presbyterian minister. The letter, excerpted here, was sent to The New York!, Times by Charlotte Guerrant of Altadena, Calif., whose husbandalso Edward 0. Guerrantwas Dr. Guerrant's grandson.

title: The Swollen Crusade Against Cancer
description: In 1971 the Federal Government launched a war designed, in the hyperbole of a House resolution, accomplish the conquest of cancer . . by 1976 as an appropriate commendation of the 200th anniversary the independence of our country. Funds for cancer research skyrocketedfrom $233 million in fiscal 1971 to more than $800 million in fiscal 1977in the apparent belief that, if enough money were thrown at the problem, it would be solved. But the Bicentennial has come and gone and cancer is still with us, its conquest not much closer. Moreover, the cancer program itself may ailingthe victim of inept administration overwhelmed by the extent of the cancer crusade.
