description: Phyllis Read Mead, a farmer president of the Brooklyn Music School and noted translator of operas, died Wednesday in Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn. She was 79 years old and lived at 22 Willow Street, Brooklyn Heights.

title: The Lexington Is Offering Public a Voyage Into History at Bayonne
description: BAYONNS, March 3A lot of World War II history will be on display tomorrow and Sunday at the Military Ocean Terminal here when the aircraft carrier Lexington will be open to the public for tours from 1 P.M. to 4:40 P.M.

title: Appeals Court Says CBS Is Liable For Trespass in Mistral Filming
description: An appellate court in Manhattan has ruled that trespass was committed, making CBS accountable for damages, when a camera crew entered an exclusive midtown restaurant without permission and began filming..The restaurant, Le Mistral, had been accused of violating the city's health code.

title: France's Key Political Issue: Business and Labor's Gap
description: CLERMONTFERRAND, FranceBy all accounts, it was an unusual oceasion for the politicians, businessmen and labor leaders of this grimy industrial city.

title: Pentagon Asks Congress to End Ban on Women in Combat Units
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Defense Department has asked Congress to end the ban on women in combat, raising the prospect of women volunteers ultimately flying fighter planes, serving in infantry units and working aboard destroyers and aircraft carriers.

title: Aides Debated Baring Agnew Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)Before Spiro T. Agnew resigned in 1973, prosecutors struggled to keep from President Nixon the full details of the corruption case they had built up against the Vice President, newly disclosed documents revealed today.

title: U.S. REBUKES SOVIET ON BELGRADE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The White House rebuked the Soviet Union today for refusing to agree at the EastWest conference in Belgrade to a final communiqu that takes note of human rights concerns voices during the meeting.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Gaskin Markham Dance Concert
description: Kathleeh Gaskin and Dianne Markham joined forces on Thursday at the Theater of the Open Eye to present concert that was a model of its kind. was an evening of witty dance, well- conceived and beautifully performed.

title: Mugged in Moscow
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I was mugged in Moscow. A man grabbed my purse containing $70, 20 rubles (about $20) and a diamond brooch, while I was making a phone call in a crowded subway station and ran off with it. It all happened in a few seconds.

title: Some Elect to Remain in the Sun
description: PALM BEACH, FleNot all of the brokers who go to Florida to work do so for only the winter months. Some, like the man who came to dinner, decide to stay permanently.

title: Issue and Debate Cash vs. the Credit Card: Should There Be Discount?; Background; Cash Discount Proponents; The Case for Credit Cards; Outlook
description: Ah, take the cash and let the creditgo.

title: Mrs. King
description: KANSAS CITY, March 3 (UPI)Billy Jean King took off from a service ace in the third game, won nine straight games and upset secondseeded Evonne Goolagong, 62, 63, tonight in a quarterfinal match of the Kansas City. Tournament on the women's tennis tour.

title: Dayan Urges Israel Give SelfRule to West Bank.
description: TEL AVIV, March 3Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan suggested today that Israel put into effect parts of its peace plan granting administrative selfrule to the Arabs of the West Bank of the Jordan and in the Gaza Strip even if the negotiations with Egypt remained stalled.

title: A 4th Big Snow Hits New York; Traffic Snarled
description: The fourth big storm of the winter cloaked the New York metropolitan area in five to six inches of new snow yesterday, snarling highway traffic and delaying thousands of homebound commuters and other travelers despite early office closings and reshuffled bus and rail schedules.

title: Hospitals That Allow Visits
description: The following hospitals in the metropolitan area permit visits by young siblings to see the new baby: New York, Beth Israel, Roosevelt; University, St. Vincent's, St. Agnes in White Plains, St. John's Riverside in Yonkers and North Shore University in Manhasset.

title: Personal Investing
description: The portfolios of investment clubs have shown a change. While they include such familiar names as I.B.M., Texaco, Gulf, Minnesota Mining and A.T.&T., the new look is represented by such secondtier issues as Kaneb Services, American Family Corporation, Ameord, and Heublein. Page 29.

title: GOING OUT     Guide
description: LATER SHOWS When Lanford Wilson's Brontosaurus and John Bishop's Cabin 12 opened earlier this season in the Circle Repertory Company's neAr latenight series, both oneact plays won critical acclaim. Mel Gussow of The Times, reviewing Mr. Wilson's comedy of an antique dealer and a theology student, called it fiery, pungent and incisive. The reviewer also wrote that Mr. Bishop's drama of a family's reaction to death was quietly and gently affecting.

title: FEDERAL RESERVE VOTED TO LOWER MONEY GROWTH
description: The Federal Reserve System's Open Market Committee voted at its monthly meeting Jan. 17 to lower slightly the maximum growth rate target for the nation's basic money supply for January and February, the central bank disclosed yesterday.

title: JOHN F. MECK
description: HANOVER, N.H., March 3 (AP)John F. Meck, former vice president and chairman of the investment committee at Dartmouth College, died of a heart attack yesterday while skiing in Colorado, the college said today. He was 65 years old.

title: Princeton 68, Cornell 53
description: ITHACA, N. Y., March 3 (AY)Frank Sowinski scored 25 points and Bob Roma added 19 as they led Princeton to a 6353 victory over Cornell in an Ivy League game tonight. The victory improved Princeton's record to 169 over all and 103 in the league and kept the Tigers alive in the Ivy race.

title: Traditional Ban Falls as Children Visit Newborns in Hospitals
description: The reactions of children on seeing their newborn brothers or sisters for the first time in the hospital are often surprising. After all, there has been very little time for adults to learn just how children do react to seeing newborns in the hospital: traditionally youngsters have been prohibited from visiting.

title: Michael Balopoulos Dies in Prison; A Chief of Greek Junta in 67 Coup
description: ATHENS, March 3 (AP)Michael Balopoulos, a leader of the 1967 military coup who was serving a life term in prison, was found dead today in his prison cell, the police said. He was 57 years old.

title: The Blumenthal Loan Plan: Firm and Ambiguous
description: ALBANY, March 3In producing his .plan to keep New York City solvent, Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal has accepted the basic concept of what the city wanted by calling for Federal guarantees for longterm, as opposed to short- term, or seasonal, loans. But he has raised the possibility of imposing conditions that the city and its partners  particularly the publicemploye pension sys- ternsmight find difficult to meet.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Books of The Times
description: It turns out, says Anne Simon, that even Rachel Carson was wrong about the ocean, She saw it as beyond the reach of man's bad habits, as an indestructible resource. In her little tidal wave of a book, Miss Simon explains how our coasts, wetlands and estuaries form one immense, intricately interlocked system with the ocean and that we have, like a planetary Peck's Bad Boy, already damaged a considerable part of that system. The ocean is not immune to man; probably nothing is. If we put our minds to it, we may be able to destroy anything.

title: Rights for Handicapped Urged
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)Federal civil rights laws should be amended to cover people with mental and physical disabiities, the White House Conference on Handicapped Individuals recommends. t calls for amending the Civil Rights Act to include individuals with both physical and mental disabilities to provide protections comparable to those now afforded minorities, aged persons and women.

title: Brown Signs a Tax Cut Bill To Aid Owners and Renters
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 3(AP)Gov. Edmund Q. Brown Jr. signed a $1.4 billion propert tax cut bill todaythe biggest, he said, in the history of any stateand promised no income or sales tax increase while he is the Governor.

title: JACKSON REPORTS ACCORD IN PRINCIPLE ON PRICING OF GAS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Senator Henry M. Jackson, the chairman of the deadlocked Senate energy conferees, said today that key members had reached an agreement in principle on the hotly disputed issue of natural gas pricing.

title: Bilingualism Without English?
description: A recent segment on CBS's Sixty Minutes program touched on bilingual education in an East Harlem elementary school. It left the viewer with little to choose between unyielding opposition to the very concept bilingual education, voiced by a former high school principal, and uncritical support for the concept by a teacher even though it was evident that her colleague, a supposedly bilingual teacher, had come to his assignment with plainly inadequate English.

title: Suit by Oneida Indian Nation Bids New York Cede 6 Million Acres
description: UTICA, N.Y., March 3 (AP)  The Oneida Indian Nation, acting as its own attorney, filed suit in Federal Court here today to recover all state land in approximately six million acres of central and northern New York.

title: Rhodesia's Leader inTransition
description: Ian Douglas Smith, the tall, stonyfaced Prime Minister of Rhodesia, built a political career on a firm, unyielding policy of white supremacy.

title: A.M.C. Recalls 525,000 Vehicles
description: DETROIT, March 3 (AP)The American Motors Corporation today recalled about 525,000 cars and Jeeps because problems with ignitions and power steering. These vehicles, from the 1974, 1975 and 1976 model years, have a wire connector that could occasionally malfunction and interrupt the ignition, A.M.C. said.

title: Dividends
Trade Associations Flocking to Capital As U. S. Role Rises
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  For more than 40 years, the Aluminum Association kept its offices in New York City and held its annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. But then the association's executives realized that they were spending more and more of their time commuting to Washington, and last year they moved their headquarters to the capital.

title: Times Writer, Called as a Witness; Barred as Curare Trial Reporter
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 3A New York Times reporter who has written extensively on the case of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, accused of murdering five paitents at the Riverdell Hospital in Oradell in 196566, was barred todayat least temporarilyfrom covering the surgeon's trial because defense attorneys had subpoenaed him as a witness.

title: Speculum Musicae at Tully Hall
description: When it comes to devising programs of contemporary music, Speculum Musicae can generally be counted on for ingenuity as well as stimulating choices. The group's concert Thursday night in Alice Tully Hall was not only played with Speculum's customary virtuosity, but also it had its own satisfying archlike structure that set up a number of fascinating correspondences.

title: Corporation Affairs American Electric in Consent Pact On Violations of Securities Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPI)The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that a power company doing business in portions of seven Middle East states had violated Federal laws by requiring contractors to build allelectric homes and apartments since 1962.

title: Personal Investing
description: Back in 1972, when onedecision growth stocks were all the rage and International Business Machines wag trading at a record $340 a share, the little man was in the market with both feet.

title: News Summary
description: Four Rhodesian leaders signed an agreenient providing for majority rule by the end of the year. The accord was signed in Salisbury by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black nationalist leaders. The blacks were Bishop Abel Muzorewa, the Rev. Ndabaningi Sithole and Senator Jeremiah Chirau. Mr. Smith, who for years had insisted on contnued white control, spread his hands wide in a gesture of apparent resignation after he signed the agreement. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: Atherton in Jordan On Mideast Peace
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 3 (Reuters) Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the United States intermediary between Egypt and Israel, arrived here today to try to persuade Jordan to take part in preliminary Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Bullets 124, Pistons 108.
description: DETROIT, March 3 (UPI)Kevin Grevey, Bob Dandridge and Elvin Hayes totaled 78 points as the Wash- ington Bullets routed the Detroit Pistons, 124108, tonight. Grevey scored 32 points while Dandridge had 24 and Hayes 22 as the Bullets scored only their second road victory in their last 10 tries.

title: Article 4 -- No Title
description: Article 4 -- No Title

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTONA veteran inventor and licensor was awarded a patent this week for a molded plastic head protector. His helmet, which has a double shell and a foam interior, can be adapted for soccer, hockey, baseball, racing, industry or whatever. A chin strap, goggles or a face shield may be added.

title: Koch Favors Test Of Trash Pickups By Private Carter
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would favor contracting out some garbage collection to a private carter on an experimental basis to provide a yardstick against which to measure the efficiency of the Sanitation Department.

title: 17 More Counts in Shotgun Blast
description: JACKSON, Mich., March 3 (UPI)Leslie Torrey, a 21-year-old workman accused of spraying a crowded lunchroom with shotgun blasts that wounded 18 coworkers yesterday, was named today in 16 more counts of attempted murder and one count of assault with a dangerous weapon. Mr. Torrey refused to answer polico questions and stood mute at his first court arraignment on a charge of attempted murder. He was arraigned in District Court on the additional counts. Judge Robert Crary raised his bond from $35,000 to $50,000.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The State Division of TaXation advised New Jersey taxpayers yesterday not to claim the $1,000 deduction from their gross income for each child attending a nonpublic school when filing their state income taxes.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: School Aide in. Brooklyn Acquitted Of Filing a False Overtime Claim
description: William L. Carr, a 47-year-old employee of Community School District 23 in the Ocean HillBrownsville section of Brooklyn, was acquitted yesterday of charges that he defrauded the city of nearly $70,000 between 1970 and 1974 by filing false claims for overtime.

title: U.S. Women Rout British
description: LONDON, March 3 (UPI)The United States women's field hockey team beat Surrey, the English county champion, 40, today for its first victory on an 11match British tour.

title: La Salle 97,, Delaware 85
description: EASTON, Pa., March 3 (AP)Michael Brooks scored a gamehigh 32 points tonight to pace La Salle to a 9785 victory over Delaware in a semifinal game of the East Coast Conference nlavoffs.

title: Companies Report Earnings
Saratoga May Cancel City Ballet for Summer
description: The Saratoga Performing Arts Center has announced the possible cancellation of the New York City Ballet's annual summer season there because of a jurisdictional dispute between New York City Local 802 and Saratoga Springs Local 506 of the American Federation of Musicians.

title: It's Half Steam Ahead as L.I.R.R. Acts to Improve Its Diesel Cars
description: When the show starts to fall, as did yesterday, many Long Island Rail Road commuters change their routines and began their dash for home at the Hunters Point Avenue station in Long island City instead of at Pennsylvania Station.

title: Bayh Sees No Evidence Torrijos Dealt in Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Senator Birch Bayh, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, told the Senate in a transcript released today that there was no evidence, firsthand corroborated evidence to link the Panamanian leader with direct activity in narcotics trafficking.

title: Marcos Says He Will Yield His LawMaking Powers
description: MANILA, March 3 (Reuters)President Ferdinand E. Marcos has announced he will relinquish his legislative powers to an interim National Assembly being elected April 7.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh Move Against Chile Over Murder Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Topranking State and Justice Department officials have suggested that the United States recall its Ambassador in Chile if the Government of President Augusto Pinochet refuses to make two secret police agents available for questioning here in connection with the murder of former Ambassador Orlando Letelier, Administration sources said today.

title: $1 Billion IndustrialPark Plan Set For New York and 2 Jersey Cities
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will set in motion next week a $1 billion plan to develop industrial parks in New York City an in Jersey City and Newark that are designed to create 30,000 jobs and generate $90 million a year in tax revenue for the three cities within 10 years.

title: Man Held in Counterfeiting Case
description: An owner of a topless bar in midtown Manhattan was accused yesterday of selling $512,000 in counterfeit $100 bills, al legedly supplied by organizedcrime figures from New Jersey, to a Secret Service agent.

title: Carter's FiveYear $ 1 Billion Plan For Public Broadcasting Opposed
description: The Carter Administration's longrange bill for the financing of public broadcasting, which would authorize more than $1 billion in Federal support for a fiveyear period beginning in 1981, is encoun- tering significant opposition from some members of Congress. The opponents say that the system of noncommercial television and radio ought to be substantially redirected and reorganized first.

title: RHODESIAN LEADERS SIGN PACT PROVIDING FOR MAJORITY RULE
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 3Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black nationalist leaders gathered today under a portrait of Cecil Rhodes, the empirebuilder who established white dominiim here, and signed an agreement that is scheduled to install a blackmajority Government by the end of the year.

title: A BIT OF WORLD WAR II ON VIEW:
description: A BIT OF WORLD WAR II ON VIEW:

title: Firmer Dollar Helps Rise in Stocks
description: Stock prices continued to push slightly higher yesterday, with investor sentiment buoyed somewhat by a firming of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

title: 2. Perjury Charges Reinstated Against Police Inspector in Bronx
description: The office of John F. Keenan, the special state prosecutor, won reinstatement of two perjury charges against Inspector Robert H. Johnson, a top Bronx police official, who now faces three counts of perjury when he goes on trial in State Supreme Court Monday.

title: Marston 90% Sure He Will Enter Race for Governor of Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 3David W. Marston, whose .dismissal by the Carter Administration as United States Attorney here caused wide political controversy, is expected to announce Monday that he is a candidate for, the Republican nomination for Goirernor of Pennsylvania.

title: The Chicago Daily News Newsroom Busy as Ever, Publishes Its Last Issue
description: CHICAGO, March 3 (UPI)The Chicago Daily News, after 102 years, published its last newspaper today.

title: N.C.A.A. Ends Probe Of Oklahoma Football
description: NORMAN, Okla., March 3 (AP)The Na iona I Collegiate Athletic Association has closed its investigation of the University of Oklahoma.

title: John A. Lynch, Senator in Jersey; Mayor of New Brunswick, 195155
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3John A. Lynch, a former Mayor of New Brunswick and .o 22year veteran of the New Jersey Senate; died today at Whitestone Hospital in Queens. He was 69 years old, and had fought a losing battle with cancer for the last four years.

title: SENATE VOICE VOTE CONFIRMS MILLER AS RESERVE CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The Senate confirmed today the nomination of G. William Miller as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Of Salt...
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.The use of salt on roads for snow and ice removal has increased in the last 15 years. About nine million tons, more than 10 percent of all salt produced in the world, are applied annually to American highways in snowy states.

title: ATTACK ON CLINICS DENIED BY ANTIABORTION GROUPS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP)Antiabortion groups have disavowed a series of attacks on abortion clinics, saying clinic personnel, rivals or disgruntled relatives of women who had abortions could have been responsible.

title: Yankee Day: Absentee and an Ailment
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March ?? The Yankees experienced a routine day today: Mickey Rivers didn't show up for the workout and Don Gullett couldn't work out because of a sore shoulder.

title: Grubman Gains on 2 Mat Victories
description: PHILADELPHIA,March .3 Steve Grubman of Princeton extended his undefeated record this season to 24 victories in I42pound competition by winning twice today and gaining the semifinal round in the 74th Eastern Intercollegiate wrestling championships at the Palestra of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Snow Cancels Racing and Postpones Rangers
description: The snowstorm in the Northeast plus driving rains in Florida cut heavily into the nation's sport:, schedule yesterday,

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Car Sales Off 7.9% for Feb. 2128
description: DETROIT, March 3After a brief midmonth spurt, sales of new domestic car in the final third of February fell 7.9 percent below the sales rate in the comparable period a year earlier, according to statistics released here today by the nation's four major domestic car manufacturers.

title: Houston 70, Arkansas 69
description: HOUSTON, March 3 (AP)Cecile Rose made a 13foot jump shot with three seconds remaining to give Houston a 7069 victory over Arkansas in the semifinals of the Southwest Conference tournament.

title: Business Records
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT Friday, March 3, 1978 Petition filed by:

title: Carter at Camp David
description: THURMONT, Md., March 3 (AP)President Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, flew by helicopter today to Camp David, the Catocin Mountain retreat. Mr. Carter is expected to spend the weekend at the camp, and is scheduled to return to the White House on Sunday.

title: The Blumenthal Loan Plan: Firm and Ambiguous
description: ALBANY, March 3In producing his plan to help New York City, Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal has ac- cepted the basic concept of the city wanted by calling for Federal guarantees for long-term--as opposed to short term, or seasonalloans. But he has raised the possibility of imposing conditions that the city and its partners, particularly the public-employee pension systemsmight find difficult to meet.

title: Corena's Descent in Balloon Enlivens `L'Elisir at the Met.
description: Donizettis LElisir dAmore, frothy, tunefilled, opera that can scarcely fail to charm, was re. stored to the Metropolitan Operas active repertory Thursday night after an absence of four seasons.

title: Reno Discovers the Price of Prosperity
description: RENO, March 1On a clear, crisp winter morning, snowpacker mountains and broad valleys dominate the horizon here. And lately, so does the form of the nearly finished .MGM Grand Hotel.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA LASHED BY RAIN AGAIN
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3Another major rainstorm struck southern California tonight, causing fears of new flooding and mud slides in a region that has been battered by a series of storms since midDecember.

title: Villanova and West Virginia Gain Eastern 8 Final
description: PITTSBURGH, March 3 (AP)Rory Sparrow, a guard, made a 12foot jump shot with one second remaining to give Villanova a, 7270 victory over. Pittsburgh tonight in a semifinal game of the Eastern Eight college basketball tournament.

title: Scientists Skeptical About Book On Baby Created in Laboratory
description: A New York publishing house says that it will soon market a book purporting to be a firsthand account of the first successful cloning of a human being, feat of biological engineering that has previously been done in frogs to produce exact reproductions of adult frogs that have donated body cells.

title: DR. ALFRED MARROW, A PSYCHOLOGIST, 72
description: An Expert on Group Dynamics, He Was Picked by Mayor Wagner for IntergroupRelations Post

title: Special to The New Yank Times
description: SYRACUSE, March 3  Time, centuries of it, took more from the Onondaga than their land and their way of life; Lost as well, one by one from these rolling highlands west of the Adirondacks, were the Indians brothers in spirit: the bison, the bear, the wolf, the eagle.

title: Signs Growing That French Left Will Revive Its Electoral Alliance
description: PARIS, March 3Signs have multiplied here in the last few days that the French Communist Party has decided to restore its alliance with the Socialists through the decisive second round of national legislative elections of March 19 at the least.

title: New York Area Is Hit by the Year's 4th Snowstorm
description: Continued From Page 1 ran up to an hour on inbound flights and a halfhour on outbound flights at La Guardia Airport.

title: Houston Oil and Minerals Profits Rose by 43.5% in Fourth Quarter
description: Sharp increases in the production of oil and gas were the main reasons for o profit rise of 43.5 percent by the Houston Oil and Minerals Corporation in the fourth quarter and 71.6 percent for all of 1977, the conipany reported yesterday,

title: 15 Die as Caracas Plane Crashes Into Caribbean;: 32 Others Feared Lost
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 3 (AP)A Venezuelan airliner with 47 persons aboard crashed into the Caribbean Sea and burned tonight shortly after takeoff from Caracas International Airport.

title: Three Children Are Killed in Fire That Destroys House in Rockland
description: PIERMONT, N.Y., March 3A 6-yearold girl and her two younger brothers died in a fire in their family's firstfloor apartment last night in the center of this Rockland County village on the edge of the Hudson. A 7-year-old sister was seriously burned.

title: Carter's FiveYear $1 Billion Plan For Public Broadcasting Opposed
description: The Carter Administration's longrange bill for the financing of public broadcasting, which would authorize more than $1 billion in Federal support for a fiveyear period beginning in 1981, is encountering significant opposition from some members of Congress. The opponents say that the system of noncommercial television and radio ought to be substantially redirected and reorganized first.

title: PHILIP AHN, ACTOR IN CHARACTER ROLES
description: PHILIP ANN, ACTOR IN CHARACTER ROLES

title: Katherine Litz Dancers Revive Three Solos at Judson Church
description: Katherine ,Litz happily inhabits her own choreographic fantasy world. But Thursday nights program by the Katherine Litz Dance Company at Judson Memorial Church suggested that this world cannot be entered by every dancegoer.

title: 5 Years After Copier Deal, Bell Is a Big Factor in Iran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 3Six years ago, Bell Helicopter, a Texasbased subsidiary of Textron Inc., was barely visible as a company here, but today it runs the largest operation of any American enterprise in Iran, accounting for onequarter of the 38,000 American employees and dependents in the country.

title: George L. Rockwell Is Dead at 88; Comedian, Writer and Cartoonist
description: George L. Rockwell, the Dr. Rockwell of vaudeville and radio fame, died yesterday at the Brunswick Manor Nursing Home in Brunswick, Me. He was 88 years old.

title: BYRNE POCKET VETOES DEATH - PENALTY BILL
description: TRENTON, March 3Governor Byrne allowed to expire today a measure passed by the Legislature that would have restored capital punishment in New Jersey.

title: MINERS EARLY VOTE REJECTS PACT 2 TO 1
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Some of the nation's 160,000 striking coal miners began voting today on the proposed contract to settle their 88day walkout, and early returns tonight showed the agreement being turned down nearly 2 to 1 in regions where approval had been expected.

title: U.S. REBUKES SOVIET ON BELGRADE TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The White House rebuked the Soviet Union today for refusing to agree at the EastWest conference in Belgrade to a final communique that takes note of human rights concerns voiced during the meeting.

title: People and Business Palamara, No. 2 at Big Board, Plans to Rejoin Pittston in April
description: Francis J. Palamara, executive vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will rejoin the Pittston Company in April as executive vice president and member of the chairman's office, it was adnounced yesterday by N. T. Camicia, chairman and chief executive officer of the Greenwich, Conn., concarn.

title: Support in Congress Rated Good For Carter Civil Service Changes
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Civil Service Commissioner Alan K. Campbell said today that he believed chances were pretty good for enactment of President Carter's proposals to  reorganize the Civil Service system before the end of the year.

title: Stiffer E.P.A. Rules Set Huge Assessment For Chemical Spills
description: WASHINGTON,March 3 (AP)The linrsonmental Protection Agency today adopted regulations that could result in multimilliondollar assessments against those responsible for fouling the waterways with chemicals.

title: Whites in South Africa Barred From a Match
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 3 (AP)A Government board has barred white spectators from attending a multiracial soccer game in Soweto this weekend, M. P. Wilsnach, an official of the West Rand board, which administers black townships west of here, said Because of the lack of separate facilities at the grounds, it was not possible to allow any white spectators to attend the matches.

title: Soybean Futures Show a Sharp Rise; Wheat and Corn Up
description: CHICAGO, March 3 (AP)  Doubts about Brazil's soybean production this year caused heavy buying that increased soybean and soybean oil futures sharply on .the Chicago Board of Trade today.

title: Salyut Sets Record In Space as Two In Soyuz Link Up
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, March 4 (UPI)The Salyut 6 astronauts, Yuri Romanenko and Georgi Grechko, set a world record today for endurance in space, breaking a United States mark of 84 days.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut has asked President Carter and Secretary of Defense .Harold Brown to return the U. S. S. Nautilus, the first atomicpowered submarine, to Groton upon retirement from service in July 1979. Mrs. Grasso asked Mr. Carter to take all appropriate steps to have the submarine permanently moored there at the Marine Museum, which is operated by the Submarine Memorial Association. The Nautilus was built in the early 1950's at the Electric Boat Company shipyard in Groton. It would be put on display, Mrs. Grasso said, alongside the U. S. S. Croaker, a submarine that served in World War II and the Korean War.

title: A 4th Big Snow Hits New York; Traffic Snarled
description: The fourth big storm of the winter cloaked the New York metropolitan area in five to six inches of new snow yesterday, snarling highway traffic and delaying thousands of homebound commuters and other travelers despite early office closings and reshuffled bus and rail schedules.

title: Philadelphia Judge Fails To Get Blockade Accord
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 3 (UPI)At Court rehearing on a city request for permission to blockade the headquarters of the radical organization Move, a judge negotiated with the group by telephone to end their standoff with police.

title: COMMISSION REVOKES GALANTE'S PROBATION
description: Carmine Galante, described by law enforcement authorities as one of the nation's most powerful leaders of organized crime, must serve the remainder of prison term that expires in 1982, according to a decision disclosed yesterday by the United States Parole Commission.

title: Rhodesia at a Glance
description: GeographyRhodesia, a landlocked country of 150,800 square miles --, almost the ,size. of Californi is in the southern portion of Africa and is bortiered by Botswana, Mozambique, Zambia and South Africa.

title: Houston Ballet, Gwen Verdon
description: HOUSTON  .Everyone during this 10th anniversary season of the Houston Ballet will tell you that Thursday night's program at Jones Hall was not typical of the company.

title: PROTECTION DOUBTED BY WHISTLE BLOWER
description: WASHINGTON, March 3While President Carter said yesterday that he would seek legal protection for Federal whistle, blowers, the first whistleblower In his Administration expressed doubt that the action would extend to himself.

title: U.S. Said to Weigh Move Against Chile Over Murder Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 3Topranking State and Justice Department officials have suggested that the United States recall its Ambassador in Chile if the Government of President Augusto Pinochet refuses to make two secret police agents available for questioning here in connection with the murder of former Ambassador Orlando Letelier, Administration sources said today.

title: The New Westway Math
description: The Westway controversy is never dull. While the debate rages over the replacement of the not-so-noble ruin of the West Side Highway from the Battery to 42d Street, the section from 42d. to 57th is springing holes. But, as the highway crumbles and West Side rushhour traffic approaches immobility, the fiddling with figures continues: a city report issued under the aegis or the new Planning Commission chairman, Robert Wagner, presents still another arrangement of the arithmetic, and the battle about tradeIn benefits escalates, with Boston's roadway financing tactics now drawn into the controversy. Bashing Westway with numbers has become an intercity sport.

title: Ali to Give A Farewell Address
description: Muhammad All is expected to announce his retirement from boxing todayon live television, naturally. The former heavyweight champion of the world has scheduled a news conference, complete with TV cameras, for 5:30 P.M. at the CBS Broadcast Center.

title: Carter Says Talks With Brezhnev May Be Needed for Arms Accord
description: WASHINGTON, March 3President Carter said today that several difficult issues continued to block a Soviet-American strategic arms agreement and that a meeting with Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist Party leader and President, might be required to resolve them.

title: TRADE DEFICIT ROSE AGAIN IN JANUARY, 20TH MONTH IN ROW
description: WASHINGTON, March 3The American foreign trade deficit increased in January over December, reflecting both higher oil purchases brought on by the colder weather and the lingering effect of the OctoberNovember longshoremen's strike on the East and Gulf Coasts.

title: HARVEY P. HOOD
description: BEVERLY, Mass., March 3 (AP)Harvey P.. Hood, former board chairman and president of H. P. Hood & Sons and former trustee and benefactor of Dartmouth College, died, today at Beverly Hospital. He was 80 years old and resided in Manchester.

description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 3Cornell University will miss by more than year the deadline set by the Department of Health. Education and Welfare for achieving parity between men's and women's athletic programs.

title: The Toughest Courses for U.S. Schools: Money, Race
description: Across the country, cities large and small are wrestling with two often inseparable questions: How to desegregate their schools and how to pay for them. In California, as most states, schools are financed through property taxes, and an angry electorate is in revolt. Last week, the Legislature tried to head off a proposed constitutional amendment that would reduce levies drastically by passing its own package.

title: Dress, Skirt or Pants: The Word Is Options

description: LAUREL, Miss., March 4 (AP)A bus Carrying a junior college choir plunged down a 12foot ravine Today near ,here, injuring at leaSt 34 persons, the authorities said. Most of the injuries were minor, but one passenger underwent surgery, spokesman for the Jones County Community Hospital in Laurel said.

title: Many of Rhodesia's Blacks Fear Economic Disaster if Whites Flee
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 4After 18 years of working up from room boy to head waiter, John Martin was promoted recently to understudy the night manager at this city's most luxurious hotel. But Mr. Martin, who is black, is concerned that his prospects may wither if a black government hostile to whites takes power.

title: Headliners
description: Louis A. Lefkowitz was a spindly 23-year-old from New York's Lower East Side when he first went to Albany in 1927 as an unknown Republican member of the Assembly in a town dominated by the Democratic Governor, Alfred E. Smith. By the time he announced last week that he would not seek re-election as Attorney General, he had served in various offices under both Democratic and Republican administrations and was among the state's betterknown politicians. Mr. Lefkowitz first became Attorney General by appointment to succeed to Jacob K. Javits, who had been elected a United States Senator, but after nearly 22 years in the job the Lefkowitz name has become almost synonomous with the office. One reason for that was his close relationship with Nelson A. Rockefeller, starting from Mr. Rockefeller's first campaign for the governorship. He still says I'm predjudiced for Rockefeller. But equally important was his pursuit of his populist beliefs in a carefully cultivated nonpartisan fashion that won him the unofficial titles of grandfather of the consumerprotection movement and the people's lawyer. Mr. Lefkowitz will remain on the job until his successor is chosen and as in the past he intends to pursue his career vigorously. I'm still on the payroll, he said. I got to earn my pay for 10 months. I'll be here every morning at 8. But his decision, which had not been unexpected, is certain to quicken the pace of the previously muted campaigns of a number of wouldbe successors, both Democrat and

title: Marriage Announcement 2 -- No Title
description: Diane Kobisher and Gary Howard Abrams were married last night in the Plaza by Rabbi Irving Axel. The bride is an assistant buyer of women's dresses at Gimbels in New York. Her husband, president of Gary Stevens Designs Inc. of Brooklyn, manufacturer of women's handbags, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Abrams of Brooklyn.

title: Sanderson Pays His Way As Wings Tryout Nears
description: KANSAS CITYTwo million dollars innumerable.fifths of vodka and countless bottles of Valium later, Derek Sanderson is happy in a bar as he sits with a glass of seltzer and stirs the, slice of lime.

title: Readers Present the Case For Women's Liberation
description: When I read Annelies Lengers's article ['Do Women's Liberationists Play Destructive Role? Feb. 12] my immediate reaction to it was, What is this woman talking about? Her facts are incorrect, her point of view is twisted, her reasons and considerations are illogical. But then I read I'm terribly afraid of the feminist, and my distaste turned to compassion.

title: 66th Neediest Cases Fund Appeal Raised $1,045,182
description: The 66th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ended TUeSday with a total of $1,045,182.59 from 9.597 donors.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: THE scramble is on for slices of a new $1.2 billion Federal pie that has been cooked up by Congress and the Carter Administration to finance community development and rehabilitation projects in the nation's severely distressed cities over the next three years.

title: A High Court Ruling on Natural Gas
description: In 1976 the Federal Power Commission approved a tripling of the rates charged for natural gas produced by wells drilled after Jan. 1, 1973, or by earlier wells that had not produced before that date. The ruling added $1.5 billion to the nation's gas bills. Last week the Supreme Court, ruling on an attempt by consumers and municipalities to roll back the increase, declined without dissent to review a lower court decision upholding the rate schedule. The rate increase had been designed to cover costs of natural gas producers and provide a 15 percent return on investment.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Ten years ago a phenomenon and a shaman surfaced in Southern California  a state'and a state of mind that may or may not be all there. In this climate, ideal for drugs and demonology, there appeared a book that linked the counterculture with the credentials of academe.

title: Fire Critically Hurts Woman, 93
description: A fire in a Harlem apartment building Saturday felled two elderly victims who suffered severe smoke inhalation, Fire Department officials said. Bertha Rainford, 93, of 217 West 110th Street, was reported in critical condition at Harlem Hospital following the blaze. Also injured was George Dukes, 80 years old, who was in serious condition. The police said the fire was not suspicious in oriein.

title: New Meat Labeling Propose Delayed 90 Days for Comment
description: WASHINGTON, March 3 (UPD-Agriculture Department officials today announced a 90day delay in carrying out a controversial labeling proposal aimed at guaranteeing consumers all the meat and Poultry they pay for.

title: Katherine O'Hara Wed To Kevin Hickey of Time
description: Katherine Emily O'Hara and Kevin Gerard Hickey, consultant and production manager of Time Inc., in Teheran, Iran, were married yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception in IrvingtononHudson, N. Y. The ceremony was nerformed by the Rev. Peter Clark O'Donnell of the Bronx, the bridegroom's cousin, and Msgr. Thomas P. Leonard of Manhattan.

title: Swimming in Style: Like Mother, Like Daughter
description: WHO SAYS a child's swimsuit has to be dull? A little girl can get away with peekaboo cutouts, deep side openings and bare backs much more easily than many a big girl can. Somehow, rounded little tummies don't matter in the sandbox set.

title: GARDENING
description: MOST people have a favorite signal that tells them spring is on the way. This year it will be the thaw when the snow blanket finally disappears to reveal lawns, shrubs, patios and walks underneath.

title: Solution in Seattle
description: SEATTLE  This Pacific Northwest city is preparing voluntarily to integrate public schools this fall by mandatory transfers and busing students to schools outside their neighborhoods. Unique because no court or Federal agency has ordered the integration action and because it has broad community support, the Seattle Plan links white and nonwhite 'schools so that the combined student body generally. reflects the citywide school population. The Seattle District School Board ordered mandatory integration in December after 15 years voluntary student transfers and special magnet programs failed to get significant student participation above 10 percent. Linked schools submitted their proposed variations the basic Seattle Plan in February; last week, the school administration made its recommendations to the school board. It will vote Wednesday.

title: Angry Panther
description: AS Bobby Seale tells it, news of Malcolm X's assassination sent him on a brickthrowing hate rampage through the streets of Oakland, Calif. Whatever I do from now on, he cried as he pelted passing cars, it's this racist society's fault.

title: European Businessmen Don't Take Their Morality So Seriously
description: PARIS Foreign corporations are laughing behind their sleeves at the United States Senate these days. The dollar may be tumbling and world currency markets in unprecedented disarray. But the Senate took its time in letting G. William Miller pick up the untended reins of the Federal Reserve Board because Textron, Inc., the conglomerate he used head, may have made an improper payment to win a foreign contract several years ago and Mr. Miller says he didn't know anything about it. Once again, Congress seems bent on showing that next to nothing claims priority these days over its newfound desire to keep American corporations clean.

title: CELEBRATING THE NEW FREEDOM IN FASHION

But, in fact, they do apply to the way a woman looks and dresses today. For there has been a fashion revolution one so relatively unnoticed, so rapid, that even some of the participants are not totally aware of it.

title: TWO P'S IN A POD
description: The Two P's in Susan Terris's unsettling novel are lookalikes Pru, a sixthgrade social outcast, and Penny, the new kid in class who befriends her. Right away, Pru, a self-proclaimed follower, is dragged into manipulative Penny's schemes or strategies for becoming popular, the most malicious of which involves spreading wild rumors about a young male teacher and Martha, the class nerd. It takes supposedly perceptive Pru an awfully long time to see her friend for the bad penny she is. But Mrs. Terris doesn't shrink from showing how vicious kids at this age can sometimes be, and she delivers an accurate, unpretty picture of preteen life with all its attendant social Strong stuff.

title: Remember Seabrook? Battles Are Quieter Now
description: SEABROOK, N.H.  In this small seacoast town last May, 1,414 antinuclear demonstrators were arrested for trespassing during the nation's largest act of civil disobedience since the Vietnam War. Last week, 300 yards from the protest site, workmen sheltered from the snow and wind by fiberglass panels and canvas tarpaulins were pouring concrete and installing reinforcing rods in what will be the first of two. giant reactors, each designed to generate 1,150,000 kilowatts of electricity. The $2:3 billion nuclear energy plant called Seabrook Station is now 8 percent complete.

title: Correction
description: In an article on this page on Feb. 12, 1978, The Times through an editing error attributed statements to Ray Stark, the motion picture producer, that should have been attributed to Bob Evans, the former production chief at Paramount. Mr. Stark was inadvertently quoted as saying, The pressures are even worse now than when I was head of production at Columbia and as observing that the difference between the studio creation of a movie and the purchase of a package from an agent or producer could affect millions of dollars in profits. The Times rethe editing error.

title: Prose Fine and Foul

Life Line is a novella  a prose poem, if you will  of tremendous impact. It deals with elemental stuff; life, love and death, and does so with a savage intensity that crackles with excitement and superior writing on every page.

title: More Bore Than Brute

We've seen them in the movies. Young Laurence Olivier as the perfect Heathcliff  arrogant, brooding and dark; Orson Welles as Mr. Rochester, with fish eyes and a putty nose. He walks about in heavy coat, muttering, Jane, Jane, Jane.. . .

title: Oswald and the Russian Defector
description: IN January 1964, when all kinds of rumors about the real story behind the assassination of President Kennedy were first beginning to be heard, a highranking Soviet K.G.B. officer named Yuri Nosenko approached the C.I.A. in Geneva with some startling news. He had, he said, personally supervised the entire K.G.B. file on Lee Harvey Oswald and therefore knew everything there was to know about the alleged assassin's relationship with Soviet intelligence. He wanted to defect and he wanted to talk. The C.I.A. promptly brought him to the United States, where he has been ever since. Now, under a new name, Nosenko lives a life of affluence and influence in North Carolina, courtesy of the C.I.A. The agency bought him a house, found him a job and pays him an annual allowance of $30,000. In return, he keeps his mouth shut. He also acts as a consultant for the agency and the F.B.I. in counterintelligence matters relating to the Soviet Union. Some current but mostly former members of the C.I.A. consider this state of affairs a travesty and tragic. But, as Edward Jay Epstein tells it in this fascinating, alarming and perhaps enormously significant book, Nosenko has been a source of profound controversy within the Government for a long time.

No one in public life here talks about desegregation anymore, and questions about it are treated as boring and annoying reminders of an unproud past. title: Turner, a Racing Sailor, Will Ease Up This Year
description: NASSAU, Bahamas Ted Turner, America's foremost racing sailor, plans to ease up this summer, but watch his smoke in 1979 and 1980. Talking here last. week after the Southern Ocean Racing Circuit concluded, Turner made it evident that his No. 1 goal was to defend the America's Cup again in 1980 and he plans to do it once more in the yacht Courageous if he can get his hands on that vessel.

title: BRIDGE
description: A SIGN of the times in New England bridge tournaments nowadays is that some major pair events are in two divisions, one for smokers and one for nonsmokers. This makes one area more smokefilled than usual, leaves another area uncontaminated, and makes nearly everyone happy. The only problem arises for partnership including one smoker and one nonsmoker, who have to choose between deprivation for one player or asphyxiation for his partner.

title: The Rhodesian Contrivance
description: The American anu British Governments have thus far refrained from endorsing the Rhodesian internal settlement between Prime Minister Ian Smith and three black leaders. They are right to withhold support, and they should not give way in this week's debate of the issue In the United Nations Security Council. The deal is little more than a device for keeping real power in the hands of Rhodesia's small white minority and is rightly suspect in black African eyes.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WHAT happens to the great mass of poetry and I mean serious poetry, not the vanity stuff  that is now published year in and year out? Every season brings a few poets an*. their new books, usually fewer than half a dozen in al: into the limelight, and thus into generalinterest rr. view columns and the bookstores and perhaps even he hands of readers. But what happens to the rest of C'e poetry that gets published every year?

title: Around the Nation
description: EDINBURG, Tex., March 4Protesting farmers blocked traffic on the International Bridge in nearby Hidalgo for 2.0 minutes today to demonstrate their opposition to the importation of Mexican beef and agricultural products.The police watched from the banks of the Rio Grande but did not interfere with the demonstration, which was staged by a group estimated at from 1,000 to 2,000 members and supporters of the American Agriculture Movement.For the farmers, the blockade was both a show of strength and a triumphant return to the scene where scores were arrested for blocking the bridge three days ago. They dispersed peacefully today after their leaders said they had proved their point:The farmers asserted that the mass arrests that resulted from the confrontation Wednesday on the bridge had revitalized the farm movement by creating greater unity within their ranks and attracting widespread publicity. In that incident, some 200 farmers from Texas and other states blocked the bridge connecting Hidalgo with the Mexican city of Reynosa and were forcibly removed by the state and local police who used clubs and tear gas.

title: Only Three Aides of the First Importance

The residents of 10 Downing Street hhve never caught the empirebuilding virus that has afflicted every American President, to some degree, since Franklin Roosevelt. There are only three aides of the first importance. They form an inner ring around the Prime Minis- ter, and it appears to most British politicians that they have greater influence on him than anyone else, lending support Richard Neustadt's thesis that in bureaucratic politics, access is power.

title: SELECTION
description: ASTORY writer is more than happy to he read by students; the fact that these serious readers think and feel something in response to his work he finds lifegiving. At the same time he may not always be able to reply to their specific questions kind. I wondered if it might clarify something, for both the questioners and myself, if I set down a general reply to the question that comes to me most often the mail, from both students and their teachers, after some classroom discussion. The unrivaled favorite this: Is Phoenix Jackson's grandson really dead? refers to a short story I wrote yearS ago called A Worn Path, which tells of a day's journey an old woman makes on foot from deep in the country into town and into a doctor's office on behalf of her little grandson; he is at home, periodically ill, and periodically she comes for his medicine; they give it to her as usual, she receives it and starts the journey hack.

title: 'An Unmarried Woman,' Film With Jill Clayburgh:The Cast
description: What would you do if, after 15 years of what has seemed to be a happy marriage, you're walking down the street with your husband, making plans to rent a house on Fire Island for the summer, when he stops, looks suddenly bereft, and breaks into the sobs of childhood as he says he wants out? He confesses that he has another woman, another life he wants to go to, and he feels so miserable about everything he's shocked when you don't sympathize.In Paul Mazursky's new comedy, "An Unmarried Woman," about America's dangerously mobile, just-this-side-of-rootless middle class, Erica (Jill Clayburgh) gets bloody mad. She stalks off alone down the street, throws up in a trash basket and, when she at last lets the news sink in, starts to cry in fury, surprise, hurt and fear.As Miss Clayburgh plays this scene, one has a vision of all the immutable things that can be destroyed in less than a minute, from landscapes and ships and reputations to perfect marriages. The scene is beautifully written by Mr. Mazursky. It is high comedy of a sharp, bitter kind, and Michael Murphy is fine as the weasel husband named Martin, but Miss Clayburgh is nothing less than extraordinary in what is the performance of the year to date. In her we see intelligence battling feelingreason backed against the wall by pushy needs.In the succeeding weeks, Erica begins to cope. Daily routine helps. She has her job in a SoHo art gallery. She has her teen-age daughter and her women friends, some of whom are in worse shape than she is. One night she gets out of bed and systematically throws out Martin's shaving gear, golf clubs and Adidas sneakers. For a while Erica also has a woman therapist who makes her feel better by appearing serenely understanding (and a tiny bit smug) as she repeats to Erica truisms that can be very comforting to the deeply distressed."An Unmarried Woman," which opens today at the Beekman, Paramount and Murray Hill Theaters, is Mr. Mazursky's most ambitious movie so far, and the first film to put Miss Clayburgh's talents to full use. She was charming in "Semi-Tough," but otherwise she's had to wade around in things such as "The Silver Streak" and "Gable and Lombard," pretending that mud puddles are swimming pools.Mr. Mazursky has written a marvelous role for the actress, so I suppose it's not unfair of him to depend on her to carry the movie, which is ultimately not as tough and funny and critical as it is in individual moments. Because Mr. Mazursky has such a sharp eye for the essential props of a certain kind of American life, and because he has an ear for the way people talk, one expects him to be a more merciless social satirist than he has any intention of being.In his best films, "Blume in Love" and "Harry and Tonto," as in the supposedly elegiacal "Next Stop Greenwich Village," he inevitably chooses the sentimental over the satiric, which one could defend as his right if he weren't so effective in portraying the essential foolishness of a plastic society. It's as if he couldn't restrain his affection for people and thing that, as he shows them to us, aren't worth it. Specific scenes in "An Unmarried Woman" come across in sharp focus, but the overall view is as soft and fuzzy as something photographed through gauze.This is especially apparent in the new film after he has introduced us to Erica and her "problem," and after we witness her first desperate, comic attempts to liberate herself sexually (with an egocentric Village painter, nicely played by Cliff Gorman). Erica doesn't flounder for long. She meets Mr. Right in the form of an English artist (Alan Bates), who's so manly, wise, affectionate and dependable that he seems to be out of "The Sleeping Beauty."The final quarter of the movie gives the impression not of having been written, directed and acted, but of a tone poem that's been scored with slushv music and paced with swoony camera shots, thus to suggest an alternate title, "An Unmarried Man and A Woman."The way the film evolves should not be a complete surprise, I suppose, because in the earlier sequences one is always aware of the sort of romantic method by which scenes must begin with images as seen through mirrors, a device that is even more boring than the freeze-frame, which he also uses.Mr. Mazursky is a writer-director of such real abilities that we've the right to demand that he be better. He's fine with his actors (though Mr. Bates's role is no challenge to an exceptional actor) and he has the potential of a great satirst. It's as if he were afraid to let himself go because he wouldn't please enough people. He attempts to soothe when he should scratch.

description: For more than five years Joe L. Hensley has been vriting stories featuring Don :obak. Robak is a lawyer in a wwi in Ohio, and he is a good one. The Hensley books differ from the majority of courtroom dramas. For one thing, the author is a lawyer and his backgrounds have special authenticity. title: TYCOON; THE SAGA OF HENRY FORD II; The head of the Ford Motor Company is 60, and talks of retirement. A generation ago, he had to battle his grandfather for control of the family business. One man is the absolute master of this industrial universe. If you are in New York, you can walk down 43d Street and see the Ford Foundation Building, all glass and green plants, which houses bureaucrats dispensing millions of dollars a yearonce the creature of Dearborn but now, after bitter battles, beyond its control.

title: TOSHIKO HIGASHIKUNI

But as it turned out, West Germany and Japan had little taste for that solution. Now the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has a new idea.

title: IN BRIEF
description: Poor dollar. No one understands it. To hear President Carter tell the story, the greenback will be in good shape once the foreign exchange markets realize the attractiveness of investing in the United Statesnamely, the high interest rates, the gradual leveling off of American dependence on imported oil and the continued expansion of the economies of major United States trading partners, which should increase demand abroad for United States goods. The President's comments avoided any strengthening of official measures to shore up the value of the dollar even though West Germany has urged the Carter Administration to borrow marks and Swiss francs from private lenders to cover the United States balance-of-payments deficit. The currency markets were reluctant to take the President's remarks to heart: the dollar closed the week only slightly above the record lows it touched on Wednesday against the mark, though it did move higher against Swiss currency after the Swiss Government moved to restrict demand for its franc.

title: A Moderate New Notionist
description: THIS huge and important book is not a straight intellectual biography of Milton, though it con tains an elaborate account of his life and ideas. Its purpose is to set in a new light the relations between those ideas and the radical thought  political, moral and theological  of Milton's extremist contemporaries. For those men and women, most of them closer to the working class than Milton, no ethical religious notion seemed too wild, too difficult to justify. Christopher Hill is our foremost authority on their thinking, of which we have a much clearer idea since the publication of his book The World Turned Upside Down. In fact, as he tells us, Mr. Hill found in his study of these fascinating enthusiasts the starting point of his new book: I came to my version of Milton through a long period in the company of Seekers, Ranters, early Quakers and other new notionists the late sixteenforties and early fifties.

title: Ali, Frazier and Even Camelot
description: Dave Anderson's statement (The House That Joe Frazier Helped Build, Feb. 12) that Frazier was better in his prime than Muhammad Ali was in his is absurd. Frazier caught Ali after a threeyear enforced layoff, barely (but definitely) beating him in a fight thdt left Frazier's face looking as if he had washed it with a hand grenade. Had the fight taken place in 1968  when Frazier, according to Anderson, was already in his primeAli would have made Frazier into a slouchedover version of George Chuvalo.David B. Kanin, Brighton, Mass.

title: Another Hurdle.
description: ENGLEWOOD

title: The Enduring Fascination Of Dracula
description: JOHN J: O'CONNOR

title: Harold Danzig, new president of Waltham Watch, pins his hopes on a new product.
description: CHICAGO  Nicholas Datrla wanted to do a lot of things at the Waltham Watch Company. He wanted to buy dials and other components at a lower cost if he could get them. He wanted to develop an assembly line. He wanted to take greater advantage of cheap wage rates in such places as the Virgin Islands and the Far East.

title: When Vacationers Must Leave Aged Parents
description: A couple from Boston are planning sixweek vacation in the Orient. Both husband and wife are employed and in midcareer. By good fortune, they both have accrued leave and are able to take it together, provided that they do so before May. Perhaps never again before retirement will they have so much free time.

title: HEALTH AND BEAUTY: A MEDICAL VIEW
description: On even the bleakest of mornings, at least a halfdozen women of assorted shapes and sizes can be seen jogging along Manhattan's exclusive Sutton Place cement and asphalt turf. In the suburbs, husbands dedicated to their once-a-week racquet ball nights are doing babysitting and dishwasherloading routines while wives are taking their once-a-week ballet classes. Around the country, morning fitness classes at the Y., group lessons at the tennis club and field practice for women's soccer teams are replacing the kaffeeklatsch and bridge game. All are a part of the growing awareness among women that keeping fit is crucial to looking good and feeling good. When more and more women talk about slimming down to an efficient weight and energy level for marathonrunning instead of for dress size, it's clear that the female body in motion has become a new measure for beauty and health.

title: Susan H. Eiseman Planning to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William C. Eiseman of Darien, Conn., have announced the ehgagement of their daughter, Susan Haines Eiseman, to Russell Boynton MacPherson of Dover, Mass., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. MacPherson of Hingham, Mass., and Malden Island, Five Islands, Me.

title: Nassau and Suffolk Join Forces to Spur Industry
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 3In their latest effort to cooperate on common problems, the County Executives of Nassau and Suffolk Counties announced this week that agencies would be created on a twocounty basis to promote industry and tourism.

description: A woman's beauty newly defined by rich, tawny colors warming her face, gauzesheer fabric softly wrapping her body. Makeup from Les Contrastes by Christian Dior. Blouse, in cotton, by Carol Horn's Habitat. Earrings by Bonwillum. All, Bloomingdale's.

title: Gabe Paul Speaks
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 4Now the New York Yankees are both in front of him and behind him. As the Cleveland Indians new president, Gabe Paul has taken command here of a fifthplace team he doesn't yet know as well as the World Series champions that he constructed. Before his departure two months ago, Gabe Paul was considered the Yankees voice of reason as the mediator between George Steinbrenner, the Volatile principal owner, and Billy Martin, the volatile manager. He also made the big trades. His importance was apparent when the Yankees named two frontoffice executives, Al Rosen and Cedric Tallis, to replace him.

title: OHIND IRANIAN RIOTS, A WEB OF DISCONTENT
description: TABRIZ, Iran, March 4Religious-cultural conservatism and Moslem anger over the emancipation of women are, in the view of knowledgeable residents, at least as much to blame for last month's rioting here as Islamic Marxtsm, which the: central Government in Teheran cites as the cause.

title: Ties With Bonn HaveWeakened, U.S. Aides Say
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  United States relations with West Germany, its most powerful ally, have deteriorated in recent months, topranking Carter Administration officials remarked in a series of interviews over the last two weeks, although they insist that there is no crisis.

title: Carol S. Van Deusen Is Betrothed to William Happel
description: Mr. and Mrs. John F. Van Deusen Jr. of North Branford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Stroud Van Deusen, to William Ross Happel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry H. Happel of Yorktown, Tex. A fall wedding is planned in St. John's Episcopal Church in North Guilford, Conn.

title: Robert Prescott, ExFighter Pilot And Founder of Airline for Cargo
description: Robert W. Prescott, a World War II fighter pilot ace with the Flying Tigers who returned home and founded the Flying Tiger Line, the world's largest allcargo airline, died Friday of cancer at his home. He was 64 years old and lived in Palm Springs, Calif.

description: FREEPORT

title: HUSSEIN REBUFFS U.S. BID HE JOIN TALKS ON MIDEAST
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 4(AP)King Hussein refused today to join EgyptianIsraeli peace negotiations. despite urging by Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the United State intermediary in the Middle East.

title: POLITICS
description: BERGEN COUNTY Democrats are keeping a wary eye on their Democratic brethren from Hudson County these days to make sure that they don't try to steal the Ninth Congressional District nomination.

title: The Problem of Living Up to L'eggs
description: WINSTONSALEM, N.C.Robert E. Elberson, the 49-year-old president and chief executive of the Hanes Corporation, is one of those good ole Southern boys with a softspoken drawl and an easygoing affability. But beneath that veneer is a taut, controlled man who jogs a mile in eight minutes, whose life revolves around his Job.

title: Food; Quick Quenelles; Quenelles de veau (Veal quenelles); Sauce belle aurore
description: 1. Trim meat of all fat. (If using chicken, also trim off all tendons and skin.) Chill meat well. Cut the meat into oneinch cubes and add to the container of a food processor. With lid off, add salt and pepper to taste and the nutmeg.

title: The Ring is Square
description: Bob Biron, manager of Ken Norton, is as comfortably at home in boxing as an archbishop in a strip joint. He is a slender, graying man, conservative of dress and quiet of speech, who has never learned how to talk out of one side of his mouth, let alone both. He is a former executive vice president of General Dynamics and a for- mer vice chancellor for business and finance at the University of Southern California, San Diego, and is now prorni- nent in the La Jolla business community. He never had a fighter before Norton and will never have another. When it's all finished and write a book, he says, if I do, the title will be, The Only Thing Square Was The Ring. As Ken says, Boxing is a great sport and a dirtybusiness.

title: French Left Is Counting Heavily on Youth Vote
description: NANTERRE, France  Despite an outward air of political indifference in such former centers of foment as Nanterre University, where the catalytic 1968 studentworker demonstrations began, no one, least of all the politicians, is being misled about where the young citizens sympathies lie. For the Socialists and Communists gain power in national legislative elections scheduled later this month, it will be in large measure because of the disproportionate number of young voters who will be backing leftist candidates.

title: Ailing Soviet'Sail Flown to Coney Is.
description: A 25-year-old woman brew member who suffered an appendicitis attack on a Soviet fishing vessel, was remtedill , very good condition at ConeyIsland!, Hospital last night following an air,pea rescue by a Coast Guard helicopter dis patched to Ambrose Light Tower.

title: A Big Spender
description: SUNDAYS at 7 P.M.  Jack Benny time for years  families would huddle around the Philco to follow the comic misadventures of the stingiest man on earth and his partners in comedy: his wisecracking wife, Mary Livingstone; the boyishly eager-to-please Dennis Day ; the gravelvoiced, backtalking Rochester; Don Wilson; Phil Harris. For the television generation, the joys of radio may be difficult to comprehend. We did not have to see Benny to know exactly what he was doing  how his arms were folded and his look of almost angelic bemusement. His hesitation when a robber demanded, Your money or your life! was the most uproarious attenuated silence in comic history.

title: DINING OUT; A Unique Institution in Trenton; * BOSTON'S CAFE
description: FOR years, Boston's Cafe, one of the oldest restaurants in Trenton, was famous for keeping people out. Johnny Boston and his wife ran the place as a family affair and banished whomever they wanted, including notables like Richard J. Hughes, once Governor and now chief justice the State Supreme Court, provosts of Princeton University and wellknown writers like John McPhee.

title: Nancy Oppenheim Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Oppenheim of Hartsdale, N.Y., Have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Oppenheim, to David L. Schubert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Uriel . Schubert of White Plains. The wedding is planned
