description: MOSCOW, March 5At the age of 14, Aleksandr Mikhailov dropped out of school and began to hang around the streets and staircases of his neighborhood in Gorky, an industrial city 250 miles east of here.

title: Police Find 7 Precincts Brush Off Public Complaints About Officers
description: New York City police authorities say seven precinctssix in Manhattan and one in the Bronxhave ignored or disr coOraged civilian complaints against police officers.

title: 5 in California and 20 in Mexico Die in Fierce Pacific Coast Storm
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5 (UPI)At least five persons were dead in southern California and 20 more in northern Mexico today after an intense Pacific storm that lashed the Western part of the country. At least two persons were missing in California.

title: Credit Markets On Steady Path
description: The credit markets last week wavered up and down within narrow limits as the major influences on fixedincome security prices and yields stayed roughly in balance. Weakness of the dollar tended to depress prices, slow money growth helped raise prices and the two forces tended to offset each other.

title: Hockey: Islanders Tied, 33
description: PITTSBURGH, March 5'How many times do we have to bang our heads against the wall before we learn hurts? said Ed Westfall after a late letdown by the New York Islanders led to a :33 tie with the Pittsburgh Penguins today.

title: Global Slump Afflicts Ship Industry
description: Shipping industries in Western industrial nations and Japan are in deep trouble, caught by a lingering glut in global capacity that has idled a third of the world's tanker tonnage and cut the shipbuilding business.in half.

title: Bridge:
description: Nobody keeps statistics of margins of victory, so it is impossible to say whether winning a pairs event by margin of 7% boards is a record. But it must he a contender.

title: Bayh Defends Federal Juvenile Law
description: PRINCETON, March 4State Juvenile Justice officials are having problems with the recently amended Federal statutes sponsored by Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, an advocate of children's rights. The Senator explained today the philosophy behind his legislation at a conference on children's institutions and community care sponsored by the Child Service Association of Newark.

title: Knicks Trounced By Celtics
description: BOSTON, March 5The Knicks fivegame winning streak, their longest of the season, came to an end today in the worst and strangest of fashions.

title: Business Hurt Less By Winter This Year
description: Despite the severe winter and the long coal strike, business was less. affected last month by special factors than in February 1977, according to a survey by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Golf: M'Lendon Wins by 2
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 5 (AP)Mac McLendon, grimly concentrating on a putting lesson that turned his game around, held off a number of challengers with cards of 69 and 68 and scored his third PGA Tour victory today in the 36round windup of the $200,000 Citrus open golf tournament.

title: 2 Children Die of Smoke Inhalation And Mother Is Burned in Brooklyn
description: Two children died of smoke inhalation and their mother suffered serious burns last night in a fire that swept two apartments in a fourstory brick apartment building in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: Raise on High the Violet
description: IT is almost 10 years since New York University dropped intercollegiate basketball, and, as Jim Hester, the former president, foretold, both N.Y.U. and New York City have survived. New York has also survived the Rangers. teenage sex shows and even the West Side.

title: ExDean of Law School Is Named To SecondHighest Post at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, March 5 Abraham S. Goldstein, who served as dean of the Yale Law School from 1970 to 1975, was named today to the secondhighest post at Yale University.

title: M. Ali: Supplicant
description: THE spectacle of the former heavyweight champion of the world going on network television to beg for Ken Norton's shot at the title was embarrassing. Entreaty does not become Muhammad Ali. Never before in his professional life had he taken a step backward outside the ring, never had he truckled to public opinion. When his draft board, rejecting the recommendation of its own investigator, ordered him into the Army, Ali defied the law. A prison sentence did not bring him to heel. When boxing commissions drove him into exile because he did not satisfy their definition of patriotism, he did it his way. Now, with blessings and free air time from CBS, he was doing it Bob Arum's way. In the uncomfortable role of supplicant, he was imploring the public to let him and Arum and Leon Spinks break their promises to Norton.

title: MORATORIUM BACKED ON SOME US. LOANS TO POOREST NATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5The United States plans to join several other Western countries in offering to write off some of the outstanding official debt of the poorest countries, Administration sources say.

title: Carey Endorsement of Levitt Really Wasn't, Governor's Aides Say
description: Question: When is an endorsement not an endorsement? Answer: When Governor Carey endorses State Comptroller Arthur Levitt.

title: Wind Players In Selections Old and New
description: THE WIND ENSEMBLE from the University of Michigan School of Music blew into Alice Tully Hall Saturday night for a concert entitled Something OldSomething New. Just exactly what constitutes old or new in music sometimes debatable, but on this occasion the group's two opening selections, Scheidt's Canzona Battaglia and the Theme and Variations from Mozart's Serenade, K. 361, seemed to qUalify as old even though they still sound decidedly fresh and alive.

title: Ideas for Music Hall Weighed, Dismissed
description: THE many suggestions made to date to prevent the closing of the Radio City Music Hall on April 12 have very little value, according to Alton G. Marshall, president of Rockefeller Center Inc. and chairman and president of the Music Hall.

title: News Summary
description: China announced Hua Kuofeng's reappointment as Prime Minister. Mr. Hua, 59 years old, is chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. His reappointment was decided by the National People's Congress, China's nominal legislature, on the proposal of the party's Central Committee. He had orginally been picked as Prime Minister by the late Mao Tsetung in 1976, but recently his role has seemed circumscribed and somewhat ceremonial. The Congress also chose Marshal Yeh Chienying, who is 80, as chairman of its standing committee. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: Denver Shows Off New Concert Hall
description: DENVER, March 5America's newest concert hall, and its most unorthodox one, was inaugurated last night with a concert by the Denver Symphony Orchestra conducted by Brian Priestman. It is named Boettcher Concert Hall. it is part of the Performing Arts Center in downtown Denver and it is the first surround hall to be built in this country.

title: Letters: On HumphreyHawkins
description: To the Editor: I must take exception to your editorial which labeled the HumphreyHawkins Full Employment Act a cruel hoax [Feb. 21].

title: S.E.C. SUBPOENAS AUTOTRAIN PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (The Washington Star)The Securitiies and Exchange Commission is investigating possible kickbacks and political payoffs in its scrutiny of the Washingtonbased AutoTrain Corporation.

title: Deaths
description: HALPERNEsther R. (Strauss), of Englewood, N.J., on March 1, widow of Dr. Herman Halpern, mother of, Miriam Kaufman of Belmont, Mass., and Stanley N. Halpern of Strausstown, Pa. Sister of Max Strauss of Rego Park, L.I., Emanuel Strauss of Brooklyn, the late Irving Strauss of the Bronx, and the late Harry Howard of San Clemente, Calif. Private services were held on March 5. Remembrances may be made to the Englewood Hospital, Englewood, N.J.

title: Goldin Reports City Is Considering Earlier Collection of Certain Taxes
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that New York City was intensively exploring the possible acceleration of certain tax collections to reduce its seasonal cashflow needs.

title: News Summary
description: China announced Hua Kuofeng's reappointment as Prime Minister. Mr. Hua, 59 years old, is chairman of the Chinese Communist Party. His reappointment was decided by the National People's Congress, China's nominal legislature, on the proposal of the party's Central Committee. He had orginally been picked as Prime Minister by the late Mao Tsetung in 1976, but recently his role has seemed circumscribed and somewhat ceremonial. The Congress also chose Marshal Yell Chienying, who is 80 as chairman of its standing committee., [Page 1, Col. 2.]

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How does the scoring work in matchplay golf? That is, what does it mean when a player wins 3 and 2?

title: Figure Skating's Top Event
description: The world figure skating championships, at the Ottawa Civic Center, will start Tuesday. One hundred ten competitors from 19 countries are entered in the four categories: men's, ladies, pairs and dance.

title: Dollar at a Record Low In Early Tokyo Trading
description: TOKYO, Monday, March 6 (Reuters) The dollar dropped to another record low, of 236.50 yen, in early trading on the Tokyo foreign exchange market today.

title: JUSTIN GLICKSON
description: Justin Glickson, former director, general counsel and chairman of the executive committee of the Presidential Realty Corporation of White Plains, died Saturday at his home in Norwalk, Conn. He was 62 years old.

title: Deaths
description: McCONNELLAlbert Reynolds, age 86, of Jupiter Island, Hobe Sound, Florida, Passed away March 4 at his, home. He was born In Columbus, Wisconsin, grew up in Durango, Colorado, a graduate of Stamford University. He came to Jupiter Island in 1952 from GreenWich, Conn. Prior to, Ills retirement he was an executive with General Motors Corporation. Survived by two daughters, Mrs. Charles P. Williams of Tulsa, Oklahoma and Mrs. Edward R. Stehle of Lawrenceville, NJ and four grandchildren. A memorial funeral service will be held Tuesday, March 7 at 4:30PM at Christ Memorial Chapel, Jupiter Island. Donations to the donor's favorite charity.

title: Skiing: Pelen, 17, Triumphs
description: STRATTON, Vt., March 5With the petite 17yearold Perrine Pelen displaying the equanimity for which she is well known, France dominated the concluding phase of the fourday World Cuo ski meet today.

title: Southern Crescent Train Service Heads Toward Amtrak or Oblivion
description: WASHINGTON. March 5The Southern Crescent, the last major segment of rail passenger service in the nation still operated by a private railroad, is to. become Amtrakmanaged if details can be worked out here soon.

title: DISBARMENT INQUIRY ON 2 LAYERS ASKED
description: The chairman of the New Fork Legislature's Select Committee on Crime asked the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday to investigate and consider the disbarment of two lawyers who specialize in defending massage parlors and other sexindustry establishments in the city.

title: Is Linda Fratianne Too Shy for Stardom?
description: IT is 5:30 A.M., and Linda Fratianne is trying to pretend that the empty bleachers at the Pickwick Ice Arena in Burbank, Calif., are filled with spectators. Smile, she tells herself. Get excited. Warm up.

title: New Hunters of Missing Persons
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, March 5The states first countywide missingpersons bureau began working here this weekend under the direction of Sheriff Joseph A. De Marino. The bureau, which has a budget of $75,000, is being run by Capt. Frederick Clark of the sheriffs office wan the assistance or one woman ana three men sheriff's officers.

title: Connors Takse Indoor Title
description: MEMPHIS, March 5 (AP)Jimmy Connors defeated Tim Gullikson, 76, 63, today and won his fourth United States indoor tennis championship and his fourth tournament this year. The victory in the $225,000 event was worth $38,565 to the 25yearold lefthander.

title: New Anthem Adopted At Chinese Congress
description: HONG KONG, March 5 (UPI)China's Fifth National People's Congress adopted a new national anthera today, and the official press agency, Hsinhua, said that it had been collectively composed.

title: Miriam Barnes Is Bride
description: Miriam Barnes, an art director with the William Esty Company, an advertising agency, was married yesterday at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows, Queens, to Gerald H. Land, assistant administrator of the South Brooklyn Health Center. Rabbi Michael Rosen performed the ceremony. The parents of the couple are Mr. and Mrs. Jack Barnes of Whitestone, Queens, and Mr. and Mrs. Ancel Land of Wilmington, Mass. Mr. Barnes is United Nations correspondent and writer for The Associated Press.

title: Global Slump Afflicts Ship Industry
description: Shipping industries in Western industrial nations and :Japan are in deep trouble, caught by a lingering glut in global capacity that has idled a third of the world's tanker tonnage and cut the shipbuilding business in half.

title: Birthrights Up for Auction As Investments in London
description: LONDON, March 5A hush fell over the 25 soberlooking bidders gathered in an auction hall not far from St. Paul's Cathedral, and the auctioneer was soon matteroffactly putting up the day's first lot.

title: True Story of City Gang Life No Glittery West Side Story
description: JoAnn and Nellie Vega look foiward to the day they can once again see each other. But for now, the two sisters are at wartorn apart by their love for two members of rival Brooklyn gangs.

title: Ashkenazy, Perlman Perform Beethoven
description: THE COMPLETE CYCLE of Beethoven sonatas for violin and piano isn't offered quite as frequently as one might think. So the traversal of them begun Saturday night at Carnegie Hall by Itzhak Perlman and Vladimir Ashkenazy is a notable one, quite apart from the caliber of the players. (Subsequent dates in the cycle, which is sold out, are this Saturday and March 18.)

title: Sporting Gear
description: At last there is a new bicycle rack. The old slotpipe rack seems inadequate for today's expensive 10speeds: It isn't theftproof and doesn't accommodate so many bikes as it was designed for. Each stall in the new Rally Rack is a metal device shaped like an F, which slips over the chain stay bars and locks the back wheel. A cable on a spring can be pulled out to secure the front wheel, and the rack is adaptable to bicycle locks. There are five models, including one for mopeds and motorbikes. The racks also look attractive enough to stand in heavily traveled areas, further discouraging thieves. They are generally priced at $22 to $55, but there's a coinoperated model for $165. Orders can be placed with Rally Enterprises, Box 299, Sonoma, Calif. 95476.

title: HYMANADELSBERG,78,DIES; REALESTATE APPRAISER.
description: Hyman Adelsberg, a realestate appraiser who determined the value of many key properties for New York City,died Saturday at his home at 17321 Croydon Road in Jamaica Estates, Jamaica. Oueens. He was 78 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Negotiating Committee, Conference an Establishment of Industrial Development Organization as Specialized Agency10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: 161 Enthusiasts Cross Words at Puzzle Contest
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 5  What's a threeletter word that means the old West? Answer: Mae.

title: Miss Clarey Is New Mimi In Boheme
description: CYNTHIA CLAREY'S first Mimi in La Boheme with the New York City Opera, Saturday afternoon at the New York State. Theater, was pleasing without being really striking. Miss Clarey, who comes from North Carolina and studied at the Juilliard School, cuts a most attractive figure on stage, and she acted the part with charming sureness.

title: TAFTHARTLEY ACTION CALLED LIKELY CHOICE
description: WASHINGTON, March 5President Carter will announce tomorrow his choice of a Government action to reopen the coal mines, Administration officials said today, adding that the most likely choice would be invocation of the TaftHartley Act.

title: Miss Ramsey Keeps College Squash Title
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., March 5Gail Ramsey of Penn State won the women's squashracquets national intercollegiate championship for the second year in a row today. She fought hack a challenge by Liz Munson of Yale for a 1716, 1512, 1115, 155 triumph at Williams College.

title: HUN NAMED PREMIER BY CHINA'S ASSEMBLY; NO NEW JOB FOR TENG
description: HONG KONG, March 5Hua Kuofeng, the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, has been reappointed as Prime Minister, it was announced today, in move that seemed more an effort to preserve continuity in China than a reflection of the realities of power.

title: 4 Killed in California Air Crash
description: LOYALTON, Calif., March 5 (AP)Four people were found dead yesterday in the wreckage of a small plane that crashed and exploded Friday in mountains near the Nevada border north of Lake Tahoe, officials said. The dead were identified as Michael Mirk Jr., 34 years old, and his wife, Paula, age unknown, both of Los Gatos; Mr. Mirk's secretary, Cindy Macias, age unknown, and her 8yearold daughter, Karis, both of San Jose.

title: Spurs 98, Jazz 97
description: SAN ANTONIO. March 5 (AP)Mike Gale hit a jump shot with five seconds remaining to give the San Antonio Spurs a 9897 triumph over the Nev; Orleans Jazz today.

title: WHY IS GROWTH SLOW FOR MONEY SUPPLY?
description: Analysts, Seeking Answer, Suggest Acceleration May Come Soon.

title: Dance:AWhitmanPoem And Australian History
description: DANCE COLLECTIVE'S offerings Saturday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio ranged from an interpretation of a Walt Whitman poem to a history of Australia. Despite such thematic range, however, most of the dances were choreographically blurred.

title: TV: Desert Life And Heart Surgery
description: FANS of science documentaries have two outstanding productions available this evening: The Living Sands of Namib on public television, and The Red River on CBS. The only problem is that they are both being presented at 8 o'clock. Public television's National Geographic special, however, will doubtlessly be repeated on Channel 13 and also be shown on public UHF channels during the week. Total frustration is thus avoidable.

title: De Gustibus: When Paris Feasted on Odd Animals
description: In this column recently, a recipe was printed (in jest) for cooking an elephant. Several readers wrote to remind us that there was a time during the Siege of Paris when numerous animals that we do not ordinarily find in the kitchen sound themselves in stews, ragouts and a host of other preparations.

title: Market Place
description: Mandated bookkeeping entries on the balance sheets of leading retailers.. may soon change the perceptions of relative values in the group dramatically.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, March 5 (Reuters)  Prime Ministerdesignate Giulio Andreotti put the finishing touches today on a sixparty pact that is expected to end Italy's sixweekold government crisis.

title: Hockey Art On Exhibit
description: An exhibition of paintings, prints and sculpture, all depicting hockey themes, has just opened at the Spectrum Fine Art Gallery, 30 West 57th Street. Andy Warhol is among numerous artists represented. The exhibition continues Tuesdays through Saturdays, through April J. The hours are 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. by Gil Whitman

title: Beaths
description: RUBINHilda. Beloved wife of Carfdevoted mother of Barbara and Gerald, dear sister of Irwin, Ida, Arthur., Raymond, Leo, and Norman and cherished aunt. Services at ??? vard Park West 115 West 79th Street, Monday 11 A.M.

title: Commodities
description: Given the rising sound and fury over the dollar's struggle in foreignexchange markets, it is no surprise that speculators in commodity futures are turning increasingly to trading in currencies.

title: 3 Boats Catch Fire At 79th St. Marina; Family Flees in Cold
description: Two adults and two young children fled from their burning howeboat at the 79th Street Boat Basin early yesterday morning in a fire that dcqrcyed a second boat and damaged a third.

title: Hello, Dolly!. Is Back
description: The OPENING of Hello, Dolly! at the LuritFontanne Theater last night is not a revival but a return.

title: Rangers Lose to Leafs, 41
description: Perhaps the canceled game in Washington last,Friday night had nothing to do with it. but the New York Rangers certainly looked as if they had had a lost weekend.

title: Models With Shapes Like Thee and Me
description: The mannequins who slink down fashion runways are pretty much out of this world. Most of them are taller, have broader shoulders, are narrower through the rib cage and flatter at the bosom and hips than real women. Their attenuated elegance does a lot for a dress, which is why designers plan their display samples on them.

title: Survey Sees U.S. Leading Soviet in 15 Key Weapons
description: A Defense Department survey of the superpowers strength in 32 key nuclear and conventional weapons and in commandandcontrol systems found the United States ahead in 15 categories and the Soviet Union in 12, with leadership in the 5 others uncertain.

title: Gen. Yevgeny M. Gorbatyuk, 63, Deputy Soviet Air Force Chief
description: MOSCOW, March 5 (Reuters)Gen. Yevgeny M. Gorbatyuk, Deputy Commander in Chief of the Soviet Air Force, has died, the Defense Ministry newspaper Red Star reported today. He was 63 years old.

title: Man Wearing Mao's Mantle
description: Since his sudden emergence as one of China's most powerful leaders just over two years ago, Hua Kuofeng has become known as a man of compromisea politician and administrator who combines radical language with pragmatic action and thus has been able to mollify both the ideologues and the doers among the small and often factious group that that rules in Peking.

title: FitzGibbon, Irvine Win Platform Tennis
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 5Herb FitzGibbon of New York and Hank Irvine of Millburn, N.J., retained their nationa: platform tennis championship at the Fox Meadow Tennis Club today by defeating Clark Graebner of Westport, Conn., and Doug Russell of New York, 62, 63, 36. 61.

title: Philippine Leaders Hint C.I.A. Backs Election Foe
description: MANILA, March 5President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines and Defense Secretary Juan Ponce Enrile have charged that foreign factions are involved in the campaign for parliamentary elections April 7, hinting that the United States Central Intelligence Agency is backing a leading opposition candidate, Benieno S. Aquino Jr.

title: Mr. Blumenthal's Challenge to New Yorkers
description: Secretary of the Treasury Blumenthal has now made public the Carter Administration's program to keep New York City from dropping dead. He suggests that the Federal Government end the present program of temporary seasonal loans on schedule, but that Congress allow the Administration to guarantee the safety of up to $2 billion in longterm bonds which might be bought by the city and state employee pension funds. The Biumentnai program should give the city a chance to stay alive nancially for four years, provided  and it's a big proviso  that all the other participants contribute to the cure.

title: H. A. Hatch, Managerial Innovator
description: Harold Ames Hatch, a retired director and senior vice president of Deering, Milliken Inc., textile manufacturers, and originator of the Dutchess Plan for making employees partners, died Friday at his home in Sharon, Conn. He was 101 years old.

title: RISE IN POOR CHILDREN COSTS STATE MILLIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 4The number of children living in poverty in New Jersey increased by 38,000from 156,000 to 194,000between 1970 and 1975, the fourth highest gain among the 50 states, cording to Census Bureau calculations. As a result. New Jersey is losing at least $12 million this year in special reaerai school aid for disadvantaged children because the distribution formula is based on 1970 figures, a new study prepared for Congress shows.

title: Bloch, Bagger In 18Century Violin Program
description: ROBERT SAMSON BLOCH offered a program of 1Sthcentury violin music Sunday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall in collaboration with the harpsichordist Louis Barmen Given today's growing interest in performing old music on old instruments, it came as no surprise that Mr. Bloch, who teaches at the University of California, had brought along a Baroque violin.

title: FANNIE MAE CALLS H.U.D,PLAN A BURDEN
description: WASHINGTON, March 5Officials of the Federal National Mortgage Association,'the nation's largest source of funds to finance housing, have criticized a set of Carter Administration proposals as disruptive, burdensome and contrary to the will of Congress.

title: The Case of the Misplaced Americans
description: We learned from a recent OpEd article than an American citizen born in Tibet in 1943 is required by the United States to travel the world with a passport that lists his birthplace as China. A small matter, perhaps, but a nice demonstration of how, for more expediency, government can trample on the last shards of individuality. Because this particular citizen refused his passport, he could not travel at all, and was thus deprived of basic liberty.

title: Koch Seeking Court Order to Evict A DayCare Group in South Bronx
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that New York City would seek a court order to evict a group whose contract to operate a daycare center in the South Bronx expired last Friday.

title: Baseball's Farms Thriving Despite Free Agents
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA. ALTHOUGH there have been predictions of an imminent demise of baseball's farm systems since the appearance of the first free agent two years ago, the fears are proving unfounded.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Donizetti's L'Elisir d'Amore, 8.

title: Nicaragua, Reviewed
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua  Nicaragua has suffered through a trying period since the murder of Pedro Joaquin Chamorro and the general strike that ended on Feb. 6.

title: United Press International
description: Burgess Meredith, the actor, watching as volunteers attempted to save home from high tides in Malibu, Calif.

title: The Tactics of Peace?
description: WASHINGTON  American officials concerned with reviving the peace talks between Israel and Egypt are in a discouraged state. The reason is a position taken by Prime Minister Begin in private and now starting to emerge in public. Mr. Begin is arguing that the basic United Nations resolution on the Middle East, calling for Israeli withdrawal from occupied land, need not apply at all to the West Bank.

title: Alter 2 Dry Years, Most of Nation Has Abundant Supplies of Water
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 After two years of crippling drought in many regions, the nation has turned wet. Virtually every part of the country is reporting normal or abovenormal moisture supplies.

title: Tennis: Navratilova Wins
description: KANSAS CITY, March 5 (AP)Topseeded Martina Navratilova rebounded from a faulty second set and held off Billie Jean King to win, 75, 26, 63, today and record her seventh straight victory on the women's winter tennis tour.

title: A Word From Koch Soothes a Skittish Mum
description: Thirteenyearold Pam Stone and her 71yearold grandmother, Miriam Marauis of Sudbury, Mass., have decided to come to New York City after receiving personal assurances from Mayor Koch that the city is not a jungle.

title: Schools Take Up Study of Death
description: Nine high school students on an field trip gathered one day recently in the burnedout hulk of a church in Washington, D.C., to describe the kinds of funerals their parents had told them they wanted.

title: Aboard Carrier Lexington, 35 Years Later
description: Dawn over the South Pacific. On the flight deck of the American aircraft carrieLexington, about 60 Grumman Hellcat fighter planes are manned and ready. The air officer's voice bellows throueh the bullhorn.

title: By Our Bootstraps
description: Most people, including most of us New Yorkers, tend to think of our town in terms of giantism  the place where the Mobil Oils, the Exxons, the A.T.&T.'s, the I.T.T.'s, the Chase banks, the G.M.'s and the giants of Wall Street make their headquarters. But we. New Yorkers are not just bunch of corporate sophisticates, drinking our soontobebanned threemartini lunches. We are the veterinarian on Staten Island, the corner grocer in Brooklyn, the pizza purveyor in Queens. We work for 190,000 business firms, 98 percent of which employ 100. or fewer people apiece.

title: Conviction Rate and Sentences Up, 2Year Morgenthau Report Shows
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's office in 1975 and 1976 increased its conviction rate and the number of defendants sentenced to state prisim despite a desperate lack of funds that made those years a. period of crisis, a progress report said yesterday.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4) Perspective in Education 6:10 (2,7)News

title: The Female Candidate
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP)  The typical female candidate for Federal or state office in 1976 was a welleducated working mother who had limited previous officeholding experience, according to a survey released last week.

title: Santamaria Celebrates Grammy at Bottom Line
description: MONGO SANTAMARIA, who recently won a Grammy award for Latin Album of the Year, was at the Bottom Line celebrating on Saturday night. The award was a long overdue gesture of recognition for Mr. Santamaria, who performed with Tito Puente and Cal Tjader before making his first album in 1959, and was one of the pioneers in the adaption of traditional AfroCuban drumming to the demands of the jazz rhythm section.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: KEYBOARD CAVALCADE There's good news from across town at the Citicorp Center, where some of New York's top pianistsingers have been providing free entertainment in the early evenings in the atrium patio of the complex's Market. After a brief respite, the concerts saluting lounge and restaurant performers are resuming today.

title: A Latvian's Tent Diplomacy Gets Mother Back
description: Last year, Igor Dmitrowsky got tax refund of a few hundred dollars, enough to suit his design. He quit his job and bought a pup tent, a sleeping bag, a chair and some writing materials. He fashioned a large, crisply lettered placard that Eaid: Soviet Union Let My Mother Go!

title: 161 Enthusiasts Cross Words at Puzzle Contest
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 5What's a threeletter word that means the old West? Answer: Mae.

title: Of Dolphins, Japan And a Noxious Tide
description: To the Editor: As one who has been a devotee admirer of Japanese culture since training in the Japanese language fo service in World War II and one whc has lived in Japan on two occasion: for long periods of time, I must ex press outrage and horror at the cal lous, senseless and brutal slaughter about 1,000 dolphinssurely the moss unoffending of creaturesby Japanese fishermen. They were authorized do so by the chief of their prefecture because, it was alleged, the dolphins were feeding on the cuttle fish, a Japa nese delicacy.

title: FARMERS CARAVAN TAKES FOOD TO STRIKING MINERS
description: CAMPBELL, Mo., March 5 (UPI) A milelong caravan of trucks, vans and cars left for Kentucky today to deliver food donated by striking farmers to strikincr rnal miners.

title: RUA NAMED PREMIER BY CHINA'S ASSEMBLY; NO NEW JOB FOR TENG
description: HONG KONG, March 5Hua Kuofeng, the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party, has been reappointed as Prime Minister, it was announced today, in move that seemed more an effort to preserve continuity in China than a reflection of the realities of power.

title: Israeli Engineers Begin Strike
description: TEL AVIV, March 5 (Reuters)Some 10.000 Israeli communications engineers began a 24hour strike today, partially disabling the country's radio and television services. A spokesman for the workers said that they were striking because of the high rate of inflation. They declaed that pay increases had failed to make up for price rises.

title: Bulls 96, Warriors 95
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 5 (UPI)Artis Gilmore scored 26 points, 2 on free throws with six seconds left, to lead the Chicago Bulls to a 9695 victory over the Golden State Warriors today. The triumph snapped an eightgame losing streak on the road for Chicago and sent Golden State reeling to its eighth defeat in the last 10 games. The Bulls held a 9290 lead with 35 seconds remaining, and the Warriors missed a chance for a tie when Cliff Ray made only one of two freethrow attempts with 19 seconds remaining.

title: TaftHartley Act
description: With the coal settlement going down to defeat and supplies dwindling, President Carter's promised intervention considered most likely to take the form of invocation of the TaftHartley Act.

title: Judith A. Greenstone Is Wed to Jonathan Paul Miller
description: Judith A. Greenstone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Greenstone of Southfield, Mich., was married yesterday afternoon to Jonathan Paul Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert A. Miller of Birmingham, Mich., and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Robbers Posing as Policemen Take $300,000 in Antiques in Village
description: Gunmen posing as police officers took 8300,000 worth of Japanese antiques yesterday from the Greenwich Village apartment of an 80yearold dealercollector and his wife, the police renorteri.

title: Aquino to Reply to Charges
description: MANILA, March 5 (AP)President Marcos ordered Philippine television today to give Mr. Aquino time to reply to Government charges that he was C.I.A, agent and closely allied to Communist dissidents.

title: Miners Concern Focuses Now On What Might Happen Next
description: WARD, W. Va., March 5Even as they voted today on a proposed new contract, striking miners here (In Kelly's Creek and along the other water courses and hollows that thread the mountainous coal country around Charleston were looking ahead to its rejection and to future troubles.

title: Miners Concern Focuses Now On What might Happen Next
description: WARD, W. Va., March 5Even as they voted today on a proposed new contract, striking miners here nn Kelly's Creek and along the other water courses and hollows that thread the mountainous coal country around Charleston were looking ahead to its rejection and to future troubles.

title: Deaths
description: CONLONFrank E.. Of Hackettstown, N.J., on March 4th 1978, brother of John D., Catherine Clark, Margaret Neal. Funeral Wednesday March 8th, at 9 A.M. from Horgan Funeral Home, 301 60th Street, West New York, N.J. Mass 10 A.M. Saint Joseph's Church, West New York. Interment Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn. Visiting 24, 7.9 PM.

title: Schools Take Up Study of Death
description: Nine high school students on an field trip gathered one day recently in the burnedout hulk of a church in Washington, D.C., to describe the kinds of funerals their parents had told them they wanted.

title: Racing: Vigors, M'Hargue Click
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 5Darrel McHargue rallied Vigors from last in the 10horse field to a 21/2length victory in the $300,000 Santa Anita Handicap today. The nearly white horse came from 14 lengths behind.

title: Bullets 106, Rockets 88
description: LANDOVER, Md., March 5 (AP)Kevin Grevey scored 10 of his 22 points in the third quarter as the Washington Bullets broke open a tight game today and went on to defeat the Houston Rockets, 10688. Bob Dandridge helped the Bullets gain their fifth victory in the last six games by scoring 26 points. Calvin Murphy led the Rockets with 39 points. Houston led at halftime, 4847.

title: Shades of Fun City! Koch Holds Own as Comedian
description: Mayor Koch appeared as a standup comedian Saturday night, and proved he was his own man. As comics, other Mayors did shtiksJohn Lindsay with song and dance, and Abe Beame with oneline insults. Mr. Koch, however, practices the same comedic style in front of a crowd as he does at city Hall or in his own living room. He is a Catskills leprechaun.

title: A Word From Koch Soothes a Skittish Mum
description: Thirteenyearold Pam Stone and her 71yearold grandmother, Miriam Marouis of Sudbury, Mass., have decided to come to New York City after receiving personal assurances from Mayor Koch that the city is not a iunele. In a letter to the travel editor of The New York Times, which appeared yesterday, she said she wanted to take her granddaughter to New York, but needed some reassurance because her daughter and soninlaw said of New York: Mum, it's a jungle out there. The Times referred the letter to the Mayor, who responded that New York, far from being a jungle, had less crime than Phoenix.

title: A Long Way From Carolina
description: WHEN Bob McAdoo was in the seventh grade, and already elevating rapidly toward six feet in height, he was on the school basketball team and also played the alto sax in the school band. His coach told him that he had to decide between the team and the band, and McAdoo chose the band. He has not since mane a judgment error or similar magnitude.

title: Seizure of Mines
description: Presidents have seized all sorts of fa. cilitiescoal mines and steel plants, railroads and the Philadelphia transit system, once even a mailorder houseduring scores of disputes in the past.

title: Suzan Balk Wed To B. F. Friedman
description: Suzan Sandra Balk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Balk of New Milford, N.J., was married at noon yesterday to Barry A. Friedman, son of Nettie Friedman of New York and Hyman Friedman of Altamonte Springs, Fla. Rabbi Harold Halpern performed the ceremony in the Cotillion Room of the Pierre.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: The recent negotiations between the United Mine Workers and the coal industry graphically illustrate the harmful consequences of the exemption from the antitrust laws enjoyed by organized labor.

title: Walter Muir Whitehill Dies at 72; A Leading Boston Preservationist
description: Walter Muir Whitehill, the Boston historian and preservationist who was regarded as the city's leading cultural figure, died yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital. He was 72 years old and had been hospitalized since suffering a stroke on Feb. 16.

title: Szymanowski Program
description: THE newly formed American chapter of the Karol Szymanowski Society presented an allSzymanowski program Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, The nerformers were the baritone Andrzei Bachleda and the pianist DonnAlexandre Feder.

title: Dollar's Decline Bringing Hardship For G.I.'s and Families in Germany
description: BONN, March 5 (AP)The decline in the value of the United States dollar has had a devastating impact on the salaries and way of life of lowerranking American soldiers and their families stationed in West Germany. American commanders are urging landlords to lower rents, and military families that are better off are donating food.

title: Blazers 126, Bucks 88
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 5 (AP)Maurice Lucas scored 16 points in the first half today as the Portland Trail Blazers overcame an early 5point deficit and went on to take a 12688 victory over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: MINERS REJECT CONTRACT, 2 T01; CARTER TO ANNOUNCE PLAN TODAY FOR COMPELLING RETURN TO WORK
description: WASHINGTON, March 5In the 90th day of their walkout, the rank and file of the United Mine Workers today rejected by more than 2 to 1 the proposed strike settlement urged upon them by President Carter and their own leaders.

title: Federal Pay, on the Rise, Stirs Ire in Private Sector
description: WASHINGTON  Five years ago, John Morgan, a Hunter College graduate, quit $7,000ayear teaching job and joined a Federal agency at the same salary. Today, at age 30, he earns $21,883 a year.

title: When the Parent AbdicatesChildren Who Take on Adult Roles
description: Maria takes her maternal role very seriously. Constantly vigilant, she monitors the baby's every need: The moment she whimpers, Maria is right there to pick her up, feed her, comfort her. Maria carries the 18monthold child around with her wherever she goes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: AMERICAN MERCURY (Farrell). Matadi Aar. 19. Salle from Fruman St., Brooklyn.

title: Officials Fear Coal Pact Rejection Will Result in Widespread Layoffs
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 Federal officials said today that widespread layoffs and other adverse economic impacts were almost certain to follow quickly the rejection of the proposed settlement to the coal strike.

title: Deaths
description: JEFFRIES  Harry, of Berkeley Heights, NJ on March 3, 1978, busban of Marie Witthuhn Jet fries. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the service it the Brough Funeral Home, 535 Springfield Ave, corner Morris Ave, Summit, Monday at 8PM. Visitation Monday, 24 PM.

title: United Press International
description: ANNIVERSARY PASSES IN SILENCE: Soviet soldiers on guard duty marching by the grave of Stalin in Moscow yesterday. The 25th anniversary of the Soviet dictator's death went officially unacknowledged.

title: A Chilean Paper Says Suspect in Killing Of ExAllende Aide Is North American
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March, 5 (AP)One of two men wanted by the United States for questioning in the slaying of a former Chilean foreign minister is from North America and not Chile, the Chilean newspaper El Mercurio reported today.

title: Advertising
description: The board of directors of Doyle Dane Bernbach yesterday elected Neil R. Austrian president and chief operating officer, as expected, but unexpectedly also voted to restructure the corporation and to put Stephen Greyser of the Harvard Business School on the board.

title: MAYOR GIVES BADILLO CONTROL IN TAKEOVER OF MODEL CITIES AID
description: Mayor Koch reorganized the city's federally financed $34.3 million antipoverty Model Cities Program yesterday, moving the central administration to City Hall under Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo and ordering the dismissal of clerical help and the hiring of povertyarea residents.

title: Good Old American Don'tKnowHow
description: It was startling to hear that President Carter wants Congress to make it easier to fire incompetent bureaucrats. Firing incompetent Congresses might make some sort of sense, since they are as commonplace as ketchup stains in onearmed lunchroom, but incompetent bureaucrats?

title: Stocks Off 4.59 in Slower Trading Amid Concern Over Mine Outlook
description: Wall Street's concern that many of the coal miners won't heed the Government's order to go back to work sent the stock market lower yesterday in slower trading.

title: ExPostmaster Put on Probation For Throwing Out Federal Mail
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 6 (AP)A former Roxbury Postmaster, George C. White, received a oneyear suspended sentence and two years probation in Federal District Court today on a mailtampering charge.

title: Mrs. Gerard Is Hospitalized
description: Alice Gerard, the wife of the veterinarian who is under indictment for switching race horses, has been voluntarily committed to the Silver Hill Foundation at New Canaan, Conn., her psychiatrist said yesterday.

title: The Alinsky Theory of Protest, Its Application in Queens
description: Since the 1960's very little has been heard of Saul Alinsky, the radical organizer who died in 1972. The Industrial Areas Foundation, which he created in 1939 and which organized huge black and white civic protests in the 60's, seemed to have disappeared from sieht.

title: Penders Leaves Columbia to Coach Basketball at Fordham
description: Torn Penders, who built the Columbia basketball team into a contender for the Ivy League title during his four years there, signed a fouryear contract yesterday to coach Fordham.

title: Paralyzed Man Dies. in Fall
description: NEWNAN, Ga., March 6 (AP)A 21yearold man, paralyzed from the waist down, died of exposure over the weekend after his wheelchair fell into a ditch, the Coweta County authorities said today: Donald Millians, the county coroner, said Randy L. Butler of Fayetteville, whose body was discovered yesterday in a 9foot ditch near a trailer park in Palmetto, apparently lost control of his wheelchair and fell into the ditch. He was last seen Saturday near the trailer park.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets on Rhodesian question3:30 P.M.

title: Montreal Nearly Shut Out As Sabres Triumph, 24
description: BUFFALO, March 6 (AP)Ron Schock and Gary McAdam scored the goals and Don Edwards came within 16 seconds of shutting out the Montreal Canadiens as the Buffalo Sabres Hosted a 21 victory tonight.

title: Lusk Memorial Scheduled
description: A memorial service will be held next Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. at St. Mark's Church in New Canaan, Conn., for William T. Lusk, former president of Tiffany & Company, who died Sunday at the Norwalk Hospital. Mr. Lusk was 76 years old and lived in New Canaan. He was president of the leading jewelry and silverware concern from 1955 until 1967, when he retired but remained a director.

title: Associated Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Tito, who has led Yugoslavia on an often perilous path of independence and Marxism for morethan three decades, arrived here today.

title: Marine Corps General Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)Lieut. Gen. Robert H. Barrow was named today to become assistant commandant of the Marine Corps. General Barrow, who is 56 years old and a native of Baton Rouge, La., is now commanding general of the Atlantic Fleet Marine Force based in Norfolk, Va. Ho will be promoted_ to full general, subject to Senate confirmation, and replace Gen. Samuel Jaskilka, who is expected to leave the Marine's next July.

title: Deaths
description: AGNETAMargaret, on March 5, 1978, dear sister of Virginia Mitchell and Anthony, loving aunt of Catherine Hill and Maria Shaw. Reposing Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 8020 Roosevelt Ave. Jackson Hts. Mass of Christian Burial St. Joan of Arc R.C. Church, Wed, 11:15AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery. Visiting to 5, 7 to 9:30PM.

title: Two Lyricists Join Strouse In Y Series
description: After several seasons of presenting lyricists talking about and singing their lyrics, the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.ILA. is currently looking at lyric writing from a different angle by having composers discuss the lyricists with whom they have worked. However, on Sunday evening, in a presentation that was repeated last night, Charles Strouse, the composer of Annie, gave the series a new twist by bringing with him two of his lyricistsLee Adams, with whom he wrote Bye Bye Birdie, Applause and Golden Boy, and Martin Charnin, his lyricist on Annie.

title: Associated Press
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Tito, who has led Yugoslavia on an often perilous path of independence and Marxism for morethan three decades, arrived here today.

title: Larry Flynt, Owner Of Hustler, Is Shot Near Georgia Court
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., Alarch 6Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, who has been Involved in a number of obscenity and pornography cases around the country, was shot down and critically wounded on the street today shortly after spending the morning testifying at his trial here on an obscenity charge.

title: World News Briefs
description: NEW DELHI, March 6India and the Soviet Union reaffirmed their eternal friendship today and promised to work together in a wide range of economic and technical projects.

title: Atrocious Bungling Is Laid to New York In ReliefFraud Case
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice yesterday accused the Department of Social Services of unexcelled inefficiency and atrocious bungling, for failing to notify authorities that a woman accused of welfare fraud in 1969 had been restored to the welfare rollsand kept there for eight yearseven though she had failed to appear for arraignment on the 1969 charge and the police had been looking for her ever since.

title: Notre Dame Tops Loyola. For No. 20
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., March 6 (AP)Led by Dave Batton's 18 points and 10 rebounds, Notre Dame closed its regular basketball season tonight with an 8368 victory over Loyola of Chicogo.

title: Rhodesia Holds 2 in Bombings
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia March 6 (Reuters)Two young blacks, barefoot and dressed in loosefitting overalls, were ordered held today on charges of planting six bombs here. Five of the devices exploded on Saturday in mailboxes and garbage cans, but caused no casualties.

title: Sale of Airbus to Eastern Still Uncertain
description: Prospects for a $500 million sale of European widebody jets to Eastern Air Lines, already dimmed by technical problems, have been further clouded by emerging conflicts over financial terms.

title: Sports Today
description: Knicks vs. Houston Rockets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M.

title: LOANS SAID TO PERIL NEW YORK PENSIONS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen, chairman of a Senate Finance Committee panel on, pensions, contended today that trustees of New York City employee pension funds had placed in serious jeopardy the income of thousands of retired city Workers

title: Pieter Whitney Fosburgh, Founder Of State. Conservation Magazine
description: Pieter Whitney Fosburgh, a naturalist and conservationist, died Sunday at his home in Cherry Plain, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 63 years old.

title: CARTER IS SET TO USE U.S. FORCE IF NEEDED
description: WASHINGTON, March 6President Carter is prepared to use Federal power to repress violence in the coal fields connected with the backtowork order to the miners, Administration sources said today, although he expects state and local authorities to enforce the law.

title: Tangled Web In Industry,Too
description: WASHINGTON, March 6'You cannot run a factory that way and you certainly cannot run a Government that way, President Carter said last week when describing the rigidities of the Civil Service System and its inabilty to reward News Analysis.

title: African Nations Ask LION. to Condemn Rhodesia Pact
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 6African rations called on tie Security Council today to condemn the agreement on the future of Rhodesia reached in Salisbury last Friday between Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black leaders.

title: LANDMASS FRAGMENT LINKED TO ALIEN ROCK
description: A team of geologists, seeking to explain clues found in mountains from Oregon to Alaska, has concluded that a continental fragment formed far away across vanished ocean drifted against North America more than 100 million years ago.

title: Volunteers Help Patients as Nurses Strike in Norwalk Enters 3d Day
description: NORWALK, Conn., March 6Supervisory personnel at Norwalk Hospital, nurses from other hospitals, practical nurses and volunteers cared today for the 194 patients in the hospital as strike of registered nurses went into its third day.

title: Books of The Times Mad Dogs and Novelists
description: Just who does. Richard Adams think he is? The author of Watership Down and Shardik seems this time out to think he is a combination of Hannah Arendt and Sir Walter Scott, or JeanPaul Sartre and Anthony. Trollope, or B.F. Skinner and Hugh Walpole, or  enough.

title: Business Records
description: Petition flied by: MARGARET R. RIKER, 611. Ashford Ave., Ardslev, N.Y. Liabilities or assets, not listed at this lime.

title: Doctor Who Opposed LifeSupports Termed Suicide Victim With Wife
description: BOSTON, March 6 (UPI)The relatives of a prominent Boston cardiologist who opposed prolonging life by artificial means say he apparently took his own life, as did his wife, in accordance with his strong views on the suffering of terminally ill patients.

title: News Summary
description: China will abolish the revolutionary management committees formed during the Cultural Revolution in schools, factories and farm brigades. Prime Minister Hua Kuofeng announced the decision, which is a move toward restoration of a stable system of administration. The committees were ostensibly designed to allow students, workers and farmers to share administration authority, but professional administrators said the committees had been responsible for, a breakdown in discipline. School principals and economic managers will take over the work of the committees. [Page 1, Columns 45.1

title: And Why Mayor Koch Has Come to Terms
description: The Queens group that Mayor Koch walked out on last week walked into his City Hall office yesterday, at his invitation.

title: The Denver Offers Premiere
description: DENVER, March 6The second day of festivities at the Boettcher Concert Hall brought a world premiere. Yesterday afternoon Brian Priestman conducted the Denver Symphony Orchestra and a battalion or so of added forces in Mine Eyes Have Seen by John Green, better known as a writer of popular songs as Johnny Green.

title: Gold Futures Prices Climb to Record Highs as Traders Assess the Coal Strike Outlook
description: Doubts that invoking the TaftHartley Act will force coal miners back to work, coupled with inflationary implications. of the rejected strike settlement, lifted gold futures yesterday to record levels. Speculators rushed to buy precious metal contracts almost as. soon as he (President Carter) finished invoking the TaftHartley, said a trader.

title: Why Rostock Spurned Yanks, Mets
description: HOLTVILLE, Calif., March 6His name is Lyman Bostock and he hit. 336 last season. But not enough people knew his name because his Minnesota Twins teammate, Rod Carew, hit. 388. But then Lyman Bostock emerged as the first free agent chosen last November and people knew his name. He signed a sixyear $2.25 million contract as the Lailfornia Angels new center fielder. At age 27, he has a. 318 career average. Nolan Ryan, the Angels pitcher with four nohitters, calls Lyman Bostock one of the few natural hitters in the American League, up there with Rod Carew, with George Brett and Hal McRae of the Kansas City Royals, and with Mickey Rivers of the New York Yankees. The irony of that link to'Mickey Rivers is that if the Yankees had succeeded in their pursuit of Lyman Bostock, they would have installed him in center field and traded Mickey Rivers, probably for a starting pitcher. Or so Lyman Bostock believes. But he spurned the Yankees because I couldn't take all that controversy in the clubhouse. He also spurned a trade the Mets for Jerry Koosman midway through last season because I don't like to be manipulated. And now he's Angel with a tiny halo in his cap.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 6The Legislature today scheduled a March 17 vote on a proposal by Governor Byrne to speed the opening of the first gambling casino in Atlantic City. Passage of the measure seems almost assured since Republicans as well as Democrats have endorsed the plan.

title: Bibby of Indians Now Free Agent
description: TUCSON, Ariz., March 6 (AP)Jim Bibby, veteran Cleveland Indian pitcher, was declared a free agent today in a grievance he had filed over the late payment of an incentive bonus. The decision was made by an arbitrator.

title: Credit Markets Hold Their Ground Despite Coal Strikeand Performance of the Dollar
description: The credit markets yesterday studied the coal strike and the performance of the dollar, and they held their ground. Prices of fixedincome securities were little changed from Friday and trading activity continued light.

title: SitIn at Pennsylvania U. Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA March 6 (AP)A fourday sitin by students at the University of Pennsylvania ended early today after the school's president, Martin Meyerson, agreed to add student and faculty representatives to the board of trustees. The proposed oneyear experiment must be approved by the trustees.

title: Carter Is Forced to Consider Impact on U.S.Soviet Relations of a Failure to Reach New Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Moscow's growing military involvement in Africa and the nagging problems that still divide American and Soviet negotiators at the talks on stretegic arms are forcing the Carter Administration to confront a troubling question: What would be the impact of the failure to achieve a new agreement limiting strategic weapons?

title: Yank Battery Makes Pitch To Owner
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 6 Al Rosen stood in the doorway of the executive's,trailer outside Fort Lauderdale Stadium and. watched George Steinbrenner approach.

title: 3 Main Issues in Dispute
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Theissues in the dispute between the striking United Mine Workers and the coal companies do not include one customary bargaining point: wages. Both sides appear reconciled to the 37 percent increase in wages and fringe benefits over three years.

title: Japanese Action Possible
description: TOKYO, March 6 (AP)As the dollar fell to a record low here today, traders said there was a 5050 chance that Japan's monetary authorities would take come action to bolster the dollar beyond the central bank's Intervention in the market.

title: Legislature Changes Name of Willowbrook
description: ALBANY, March 6  Accepting arguments that no institution should bear the cross of a name that conjures up the past horror of Willowbrook, the State Senate voted 49 to tonight to change the name of the institution to the Staten Island Developmental Center.

title: NJAMINF.FEWDIES; D TOBACCO CONCERN
description: Benjamin Ferguson Few, a former director and president of the Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company, died Sunday of congestive heart failure at the Carolton Chronic and Convalescent Hospital, Fairfield, Conn. He was 83 years old and lived in Southport, Conn.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Leonard Silk says that G. William Miller is taking over as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board at a time of nervousness about the sinking dollar and the threat it poses for the United States and the world economy. Page 53.

title: The New Chairman of the Fed And Problems of Sinking Dollar
description: G. William Miller, confirmed by the Senate late last week, takes over as chairman of the Federal Reserve System at a time when normally calm people both within the central bank and the private financial community, who have every motivation for talking reassuringly, are freely admitting their nervousness about the sinking dollar and the threat it poses for the United States and the world Despair is the order of optimism is regarded as silliness. Eugene J. vice president of Merrill the day, and evidence of Sherman, senior Lynch International Bank Inc., rejecting all platitudes of hope, quotes an Italian Renaissance song, Io Non Compro Piu Speranza remain weak for the foreseeable future.

title: JACK A. ROSEN
description: Jack A. Rosen, a member of the law firm of Dugan & Rosen at 295 Madison Avenue in Manhattan for more than 20 years, died yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Kings Point, L. I.

title: Bohm Leads Philharmonic Benefit; Pollini Performs Mozart Concerto
description: The orchestra podium may be the only place in the modern world, outside of the United States Congress, where great age is regarded as an attribue to be cherished without question. Karl Btihm, at a mere 83 years old, is not yet to be counted among the gerontological wonders of the conducting world, but he is ripening nicely, as his concert last night at the helm of the New York Philharmonic showed.

title: Iranian Says His Nation Will Defend Somalia If Ethiopia Invades
description: TEHERAN, March 6A high official in the Shah's Government said today that Iran would go to the defense of Somalia if the Ethiopians and Cubans were so unwise as to push across its borders.

title: 3 Starters Typify Mets New Deal
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6 Joe McDonald, the man behind the massive rebuilding of the New York Mets, surveyed the training camp scene today and confessed with some wonder: It's incredible, even to me.

title: Famed Stanley Theater Faces Heavy Alterations
description: JERSEY CITY, March 6Unlike the hundreds of famous movies that have beamed from its giant screen over the last 50 years and are still enjoyed by television and filmfestival audiences, the Stanley Theater, the elegant Journal Square landmark, is facing a radical transformation.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times of Feb. 23 incorrectly stated that the United States last year had approved no military aid for Turkey for fiscal 1978. Turkey in fact is receiving $175 million in American military credits in fiscal 1978.

title: The Alinsky Theory of Protest, Its Application in Queens
description: Since the 1960's very little has been heard of Saul Alinsky, the radical organizer who died in 1972. The Industrial Areas Foundation, which he created in 1939 and which organized huge black and white civic protests in the 60's, seemed to have disappeared from sight.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The New York Times of Feb. 23'incorrectly stated that the United States last year had approved no military aid for Turkey for fiscal 1978. Turkey in fact is receiving $175 million in American military credits in fiscal 1978.

title: U.S. Reactor Makers' Recovery in Doubt After 4Year Market Dip
description: Over the last four years, American manufacturers of nuclear reactors have taken a painful drubbing on the international market. Foreign competition has badly cut into their oncecommanding position, and now the American suppliers are beginning to wonder whether they ; will ever reaain their lead.

title: Wenzel Adds To Family's Ski Renown
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., March 6Andreas Wenzel, whose 21yearold sister, Hanni, seems likely to bring Liechtenstein its first World Cup overall championship, brought more skiing glory to the small, Alpine principality today.

title: SitIn Group Demands Ouster of Directors of Puerto Rican Project
description: A sitin group led by City Councilman Gilberto GerenaValentin demanded yesterday that Mayor Koch's administration oust the board of directors of the citywide antipoverty Puerto Rican Community Development Project.

title: H. TERRY MORRISON, AT 81; CARGILL INC. EXOFFICER
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 6 (AP)H. Terry Morrison, former chairman of the board of Cargill Inc., died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: Dividends
description: IRREGULAR

title: EFFORT TO GET $8,000 LAID TO FLOOD EXAIDE
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The executive director of a research foundation that has come under fire in the investigation of Representative Daniel J. Flood, has charged that an aide to Mr. Flood tried to exact $8,000 from him for legal defense fees, according to a report made public today.

title: Defense Says Dr. X Was Framed In Curare Case by His Colleagues
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 6Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, charged with killing five hospital patients by injecting them with curare, was framed by colleagues trying to cover their own ineptness, the surgeon's lawyer said today. special to The New York Times

title: SOUTH KOREA AGAIN URGED TO LET EXENVOY TESTIFY
description: WASHINGTON, March 6Representative Allen E. Ertel, Democrat of Pennsylvania, renewed his demand today that South Korea make available Kim Dong Jo, the former Ambassador, to Congressional investigators seeking information on alleged Korean bribing of American Congressmen.

title: Constant Attacks Put Quebec's Leaders on Defensive
description: MONTREAL, March 3Under constant attack and handicapped in its ability to get its own message across, the government of Quebec appears to be having its most difficult moments since it was elected almost 16 months ago.

title: This Art Is For Wear
description: It was Robert Lee Morris's intention when he opened his small jewelry shop called Artwear six months ago that it resemble gallery. That's because he sells jewelry meant not just as decoration but as fine art that happens to be wearable.

title: OMAN DENIES SHIFT ON U.N. RESOLUTION
description: JERUSALEM, March 6Fcireign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that there was no contradiction between Prime Minister Menachem Begin's peace proposals and the United Nations resolution that calls for withdrawal from Arab lands seized in 1967. But Mr. Dayan said that of course, there are different interpretations of the document.

title: Matlack Assails Mets In Making Comparison With Pros on Rangers
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 6Jon Matlack, who was a New York Met for six years, has been a Texas Ranger for only three months, but that has been long enough for him to see a significant difference between the clubs.

title: Board of Inquiry: 3 Seasoned Arbitrators
description: WASHINGTON, March 6If a bit of sweetness at the factfinding table will help to ease the impasse in the coal strike, Eva Robbins is just the person to furnish it.

title: Transcript of Carter's Statement Invoking TaftHartley in Coal Strike
description: The majority of the United Mine Workers have now rejected the negotiated coal contract. I'm disappointed that this agreement was not approved, but I recognize that the United Mine Workers system of collective bargaining requires approval by union members before a contract can take effect.

title: And Why Mayor Koch Has Come to Terms
description: The Queens group that Mayor Koch walked out on last week walked into his City Hall office yesterday, at his invitation.

title: Steel Production for Week Rose By 0.7% to 2.42 Million Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended March 4 rose to 2.4 million tons up 0.7 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.403 million tons the week before.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, March 6The Supreme Court agreed today to pass on the constitutionality of another of the state laws enacted in the last five years in an effort, to limit the scope of the Court's 1973 abortion decision.

title: Shaun Cassidy Sings to CameraWielding Girls
description: Shaun Cassidy, who stars in the Hardy Boys television series and makes pop records, drew the largest crowd of camerawielding preteenage girls in recent. memory to the Nassau Colisum on Sunday. At times during his second show, the arena was brighter than noonday from the light of exploding:flash bulbs.

title: Programs for Syndicated TV Offer More Diversity
description: LOS ANGELES, March 6At one end of the cultural spectrum are frenzied entertainments with titles such as The Cheap Show and The $1.98 Beauty Contest, both inspired by the success of the boisterous and bizarre spoof of talent contests, The Gong Show.

title: Charity Ball Program Gets an Aeroflot Ad
description: Nothing quite embodies the spirit of offduty capitalism as much as the society charity ball.

title: Advantages of Optional Maturity Bonds
description: Stunned by sliding stock prices and slipping bond prices, many investors are searching for defensive issues with which to ride out the storm.

title: Colby Urges Limit on Prosecution Of Officials Who Leak Information
description: WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP)William E. Colby, the foimer Director of Central Intelligence, proposed today that sharp limits be imposed on the prosecution of Government officials who leak classified information to the press.

title: Goerner to Head Aramco
description: This Exxon Corporation confirmed yesterday the appointment of Hugh H. Goerner, a senior vice president of the Exxon Company U.S.A., as president of the Arabian American Oil Company. Mr. Goerner was nominated for the Aramco post last January. Aramco is 60 percent owned by the Saudi Arabian Government, which is expected to take over the remaining 40 percent of producing assets later this year.

title: Maxim's Is Dropped From the 1978 Michelin Guide
description: PARIS, March 6Maxim's, one of the world's most famous restaurants, was dropped from the Michelin guide today. At the same time, the bible of where to eat and sleep in France elevated L'Archestrate, a restaurant appreciated by gastronomes for its culinary daring, from two stars to the highest rating, three stars.

title: Gertrude R. Mansfield,. 66, an Aide With O.S.S. After World War II
description: Gertrude R. Mansfield, who served just after World War II as a personal assistant in the Office of Strategic Services to Gen. William J. Donovan, died of cancer yesterday in Mercy Catholic Medical Center, Philadelphia. She was, 66 years old and lived at 202 Dan:s Highway, New Canaan, Conn.

title: Puritan Fashions Expansion
description: The Puritan Fashions Corporation, a large apparel maker, announced yesterday that it would take over sales and manufacturing of the dress line of Diane Von Furstenberg Ltd. title: Crude Tools for Coal
description: Faced with the threat of widespread layoffs and production cutbacks, the President yesterday did what he had to do: He invoked the TaftHartley Act to order the coal miners back to work for an 80day coolingoff period. The injunction, which will probably be sought in court later this week, is a crude tool for settling the bitter coal strike. It probably will not work. But the President had no choice, The TaftHartley injunction Is the only remedy available to the President when labor and industry cannot resolve a collective bargaining dispute.

title: Film Triangle Gets a Twist In 'Furtivos'
description: There is a familiar-sounding romantic triangle in "Furtivos," involving a man, his sweetheart and his terribly chagrined old mother, but the Spanish director Jos Luis Borau chooses to present the situation in an exeedingly unfamiliar way.The mother lives quietly in an isolated cottage, where the woods are full of wolves and the provincial governor makes special visits just to sample her stew. But when her sad-eyed son comes home, madly in love with a thirtyish-looking woman who says she is a reform-school runaway, the mother's life is disrupted.In fact, the son is so bent on making his lover feel at home that one night he drags his mother from her own bed, screaming, so that he and his paramour can cuddle in comfort. The mother is so vexed by this, and so without effective recourse, that she stalks out to one of her wolf traps and takes out her rage on a hapless creature that has the ill fortune to be caught there.This episode takes place in the evening but many of the eeriest moments in "Furtivos," at the Cinema Studio, are set in brilliant sunlight and sparkle with disconcertingly deadpan humor; it's no wonder that the film has been advertised as a favorite of Luis Buuel.Mr. Borau, whose work has apparently been both popular and controversial in Spain (though it is new to American audiences), has a talent for shifting things ever so slightly askew, without sacrificing the air of oppressive normality that gives his best scenes a subversive vitality. In his most sharply successful moments, Mr. Borau manages to get things so wrong that they seem just right.So when the governor makes one of his periodic stew stops at this rude cottage in the forest, he brings a little chandelier as a bread-and-butter present. And when the runaway interrupts her truffle-gathering and dismisses her pig so she can seduce the sad-eyed son (now her sad-eyed husband) in the forest, who should appear on a motorcycle but her former boyfriend, a desperado who has come to find her.The newlyweds just stand there, as the desperado circles around and around and never quite seems to notice them. Rather than being irritated by the interruption, they seem quite impressed, even mystified, by the outlaw's peculiar timing.There is a marvelous spirit of mischief to Mr. Borau's work, and an unusual delicacy to his gift for making things seem daintily unhinged; the most enduring image presented by this handsome, impressively single-minded movie is that of an exquisitely serene autumnal forest with countless animal traps beneath the leaves.Mr. Borau, who begins the film with Franco's statement that "Spain is a peaceful forest," is better able to suggest subversion visually than he is through more pointedly political plot elements, such as the reformatory, the renegade, or the sad-eyed man's illegal poaching of the governor's game. And, in fact, the boldness of such ingredients tends to overwhelm the understated rebelliousness at which the film otherwise hints so ably."The climate of oppression that the film means to dramatize is important, but what makes Mr. Borau's American debut particularly auspicious is not his film's subject but its muted, idiosyncratic and altogether clear-eyed madness.

description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 6 (AP)Gerald Jordon was in no position to appreciate his luck. Jammed against the floorboard of his submerged car, he had to strain to kep his ace in a pocket of, air for an hour. But his rescuers say if his car had landed any differently, he would have drowned.

Mr. Pang is to be deported to Hong Kong upon his release from prison.
