The union says that it wants full restoration of health benefits curtailed because of the summer wildcat strikes, a limited right to strike over local issues and add:tional pay and vacation time.

title: PENNSYLVANIA MOVES AGAINST DRDE MARCO
description: HARRISBURG Pa., March 6An inde pendent hearing examiner found today that Dr. Peter T. DeMarco's patented socalled wonder drug, procaine PVP, is adulterated, misbranded end contraband and ordered the State Health Department to destroy all stocks of it immediately.

title: CAMPAIGNFUND CURB URGED BY DEMOCRATS
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  House Democrats proposed sharp reductions today in how much a political party can give a Congressional candidate.

title: Harrises Trial Set for July
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 6 (AP)A July 17 date was set today for the trial of William and Emily Harris on charges of kidnapping Patricia Hearst more than four years ago. Judge Stanley Golde of Superior Court also agreed to a new date of May 22 to hear pretrial motions, and he set May 15 to hear a defense motion to strike a portion of the indictments against the Harrises.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: TULSA, Okla., March 6 (AP)Settlerunt of a fiveyearold legal case between the International Business Machines Corporation and the Telex Corporation was disclosed today through United States District Court records. Details of the agreement were not shown, and the court clerk's office said the agreement was sealed.

title: MAYOR GIVES BADILLO CONTROL IN TAKEOVER OF MODEL CITIES AID
description: Mayor Koch reorganized the city's federally financed $34.3 million antipoverty Model Cities Program yesterday, moving the central administration to City Hall under Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo and ordering the dismissal of clerical help and the hiring of povertyarea residents.

title: Morgan Holds Off Omni Foreclosure As Talks Continue
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and Omni International Ltd. jointly announced yesterday that a sale of the Cmni International officeandhotel complex in Atlanta would not be held today as had been advertised.

title: Bruins 7, Blues 2
description: BOSTON, March 7 (AP)Peter McNab, in the midst of a scoring streak, notched his 32d and 33d goals and set up three others tonight as the Boston Bruins took sole possession of first place in the Adams Division with a 72 rout of the St. Louis Blues.

title: CREDIT MARKETS UP ON GAIN FOR DOLLAR
description: The credit markets rose slightly yesterday, inching toward higher prices and modestly iower interest rates as the dollar stabilized in foreignexchange trading.

title: Puerto Rico Asks Injunction to Halt Military Activities on Nearby Island
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 7Gov Carlos Romero Barcelo has asked the Federal District Court in San Juan for an injunction to stop the Navy and Marine Corps from further military activities on Vieques, a small island off Puerto Rico's east coast that is being used as a target area for naval maneuvers.

title: Theater: Wings, By Kopit, at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN WORDS are the legs of the mind; they bear it about, carry it from point to point, bed it down at night, it off the ground and out and mists. Arthur Kopit's and keep of marsh Wings is a remarkable attempt to dramatize the agony of a stroke victim. It presents a mind whose language has been knocked out from under it; one that struggles blindly, with alternating grace and terror, to regain its footing.

title: Troubled Portugal
description: Official Washington is a bit gloomy about Portugal these days. As one State Department functionary put bluntly the other day: It looks as Portugal is going down the drain. But it would be a pity to write off Lisbon's democratic experiment too soon.

title: GasPrice Accord Nearing in Senate, Conferees Believe
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Senate energy conferees said today that they had broken their threemonth impasse over natural gas pricing with a plan to end price controls in 1985 after allowing 62 percent price increase, plus inflation, in the interim.

title: Carter and Tito Are Said to Agree About Mideast and Horn of Africa
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter and President Tito of Yugoslavia discussed areas of conflict and tension in northeastern Africa and the Middle East today for more than an hour and found they disagreed very little in their assessments, official participants in the talks reported.

title: C.A.B. WITHDRAWS ORDER AGAINST CALEDONIAN AIR
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board, cornplying with a directive from President Carter on Monday, yesterday withdrew an order calling for retaliatory action against British Caledonia Airways Ltd., in a dispute over Braniff Airways service from Dallas to London.

title: Briton to Visit U.S. About U.N. Debate On Rhodesian Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Britain's Foreign Secretary, Dr. David Owen, will fly to Washington tomorrow to confer with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance as the United Nations Security Council continues its debate on an agreement for majority rule announced last week in Rhodesia.

title: Museum Mammoth Is a Metamorph
description: The most startling creature at the American Museum of Natural History has no fur, feather, hair, scales, or even bones. Nor will it be preserved for posterity. It is a lifesize replica of a Stegosaurus, an Early Cretaceous dinosaur sculptured entirely of snow.

title: Deaths
description: WALLACEMichael. Beloved husband of Diane. Devoted son of Charles and Anne Weinstein. Dear brother of Marjorie Scharff. Service Wednesday, March 8th, 11:45 A.M. The Riverside 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Good Medicine for Cuba
description: When the trade embargo against Cuba was proclaimed in 1962, medicines were specifically exempted on humanitarian grounds. But two years later this enlightened policy was abandoned; humanitarianism was redefined. Commercial shipments of drugs were forbidden; only strictly humanitarian shipments were allowed. The effect has been to hobble Cuban medicine. Recent visitors renort that drugs are often in short supply.

title: Rumanian Cabinet Reorganized; Party Official Is Given Promotion
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, March 7 (UPI) President Nicolae Ceausescu ordered reorganization of his Cabinet today, promoting a possible successor and shifting more than a dozen other ministers.

title: Palm Beach Company Ends Merger Talks
description: The Palm Beach Company, Cincinnatibased apparel producer, announced yesterday that it had terminated merger discussions with another company. Elmer L. Ward, Jr., president, declined to identify the company. Trading in Palm Beach stock was halted Monday, pending news on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 18thCentury Dining In Wild West Israel
description: BEERSHEBA, ISRAEL If BenGurion were alive this would kill him, the Israeli said. The line was a bit of a chestnut, but it conjured up a picture of the gruff old barechested man in khaki shorts, a tireless promoter of populating the Negev desert, confronted with an Israeli busboy dressed up like Marie Antoinette's footman.

title: Technology
description: Federal regulation of substances that people eat, drink and breathe continues to tighten amid a flood of warnings about chemicals in the environment that might cause cancer or birth defects. Standards for measuring mixtures of chemicals in food, drugs, air and water grow more exacting every year.

title: Cairo Orders a Halt In Work on Project
description: CAIRO, March 7 (UPI)Egyptian authorities today ordered a halt in work on a model pyramid that the Japanese had hoped to use to show how the ancient Egyptians had built the great monuments.

title: Jazz 84, Trail Blazers 82
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 7 (AP)Truck Robinson sank two free throws with 28 seconds left tonight as the New Orleans Jazz maintained its homecourt mastery of the Trail Blazers, 8482. Portland has never beaten the Jazz in New Orleans in eight attempts.

title: Rhodesia Attacks Guerrilla Base In Zambia and Reports Killing 38
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 7The Rhodesian Government announced tonight that its forces had crossed into Zambia and had killed at least 38 black guerrillas at a base belonging to the army of Joshua Nkomo, the exiled nationalist leader. The move could complicate efforts to win support for the majority rule agreement concluded here last week.

title: Judge Wright Finds Pity Is Not Repaid
description: Judge Bruce McM. Wright of Manhattan Criminal Court, whose reputation of being sympathetic to defendants, led the police to call him Turn em Loose Bruce, yesterday ordered the arrest of a parolee who allegedly had stolen a radio, a typewriter and a heater from the judge's chambers, the Manhattan District Attorney's Office reported.

description: Bolstered by higher profits from insurance, manufactured products and investments, net income of the Loews Corporation soared by more than 150 percent in the fourth quarter and 89.5 percent for all of last year, it was reported yesterday.

title: Police Pension Fund Orders 2,100 to File Report on Finances
description: Complying with a ruling from the city's II Corporation. Counsel, the trustees of the Police Pension Fund voted yesterday to require a monthly financial statement from about 2,100 people receiving disability pensions to make sure they are not earning more than allowed on another job.

description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Government reported today that a controversial effort to stimulate participation by minorities in a $4 billion public works program appeared headed for success.

title: Three Doctors Treated Spinks for a Rib Injury
description: Muhammad Ali managed yesterday to lend some credence to reports that Leon Spinks was suffering from a rib injury when he wrested the heavyweight title from Ali Feb. 15. And in Las Vegas, Nev., where the fight was held, three doctors lent more credibility to the report by confirming that they had examined Spinks and had treated him with pain killers before the fight.

title: Two Defiant SchOol Districts Yield
description: Two school districtsone in Brooklyn and one in Queensthat previously defied a Board of Education order to compile ethnic data on pupils required for Federal aid. now have agreed to provide such data.

title: New Leader of Airfreight Carriers
description: The Flying Tiger Line announced yesterday that it had passed Pan American World Airways as the largest airfreight carrier. According to figures made avail: able by the Civil Aeronautics Board, said Flying Tiger, its planes flew more than 990 million freight ton miles last year, while Pan Am flew 979 million. Freight ton miles are the tonnage, not including mail, carried, carried, multiplied by the miles flown.

title: Kerry Reid Gains in Tennis
description: DALLAS, Mrch 7 (AP)Kerry Reid gained a 62, 6.0 firstround victory today over Caroline Stoll of Livingston, N.J., in a $100,000 women's professional tennis tournament. In other matches, Helena Anliot of Sweden defeated Kathy Harter of Culver City, Calif.; Czechoslovakia's Regina Marsikova beat Florneza Mihai of Rumania and Australia's Lesley Hunt downed South Africa's Yvonne Vermaak.

Kaiser into the lobby of her apartment building at 860 United Nations Plaza early yesterday, the police said, drew a pistol and yanked a $500,000 diamond necklace from her neck.city. Nationally, last year one in eight births was by Caesarean  nearly three times the rate a decade ago  and in some hospitals as many as one in four babies are born via a surgical incision through the mother's abdomen.

In the 1970's the personnel has shifted and the band has waxed and waned; at one point a few years ago the group toured with a rather lavishly endowed hippieexotic dancer named Stacia, and the combination of her, a fairly ambitious light show. and band members general weirdness was pretty flashy.

It intends to develop a group of major industrial parks in the port region, each furnished with a powerhouse that generates electricity from municipal garbage. If it works, this scheme would surmount two major present obstacles to local industrial progressthe difficulties of assembling land and the high cost of electricity.

DePaul takes a 25.2 wonlost record into the National Collegiate tournament next Sunday against Creighton. Meyer's 36 teams at the Chicago school have won 569 games.

description: MOSCOW, March 7 (Reuters)Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today discussed with Soviet officials the result of meetings of Arab leaders who are opposed to Egypt's Middle East peace initiative, a Palestinian representative said today.

description: UTICA, N.Y., March 7 (AP)a man who was turned away by the Syracuse_ police yesterday when he tried to surrender on a murder charge was finally accepted as a prisoner by authorities here tonight.

title: Desai Deplores Annexation of Sikkim, but Says He Cannot Undo
description: NEW DELHI, March 7Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai said today that the government of his predecessor, Indira Gandhi, should not have annexed the tiny Himalayan kingdom of Sikkim in 1975. But, he said as he denounced the move, I cannot undo it now.

title: Film: 'A Little Night Music':Bergman-Inspired
description: INGMAR BERGMAN'S "Smiles of a Summer Night" is, next to his film version of "The Magic Flute," the most charming, most buoyant movie he's ever made. "A Little Night Music," the Broadway musical adaptation of the Bergman film, directed by Harold Prince, with music and lyrics by Stephen Sondheim at his best, sent one out of the theater feeling in top form.It's something more than a shock, then, that the film adaptation of the Broadway show not only fails to raise the spirits; it also tramples on them. The more kindly disposed will leave the theater depressed, a lot of others may be in a rage. Though it's possible to fail with intelligence and grace, the movie, which opens today at Columbia 1, pursues disaster in the manner of someone who, with mindless self-confidence, saws off the limb he's sittin on.Perhaps the movie's worst sin is to make the critic feel he must play the role of the piously aggrieved scoutmaster, who has to say a lot of boring, obvious thingsin this case about the difference between the stage and movies. These are things that Mr. Prince, who also directed the movie, and Hugh Wheeler, who wrote the screenplay from his own Broadway book, certainly know from experience that is more practical than most critics will ever have. The way they have made the movie, it looks like a publicly posted suicide pact. Such a succession of mistakes can't be accidental.The Broadway show, like the Bergman film, is a wickedly lyric rondel, a romantic, turn-of-the-century masquerade about three mismatched couples who, in the course of a limpid summer night, on a magnificent country estate, more or less stumble into perfect happiness.They are a beautiful, worldly actress of certain years (Elizabeth Taylor), her lover, a foolish hussar (Laurence Guittard), the hussar's jealous wife (Diana Rigg), the wife's school friend (Lesley-Ann Down), whose much older husband (Len Cariou) loves the actress and whose stepson (Christopher Guard) loves his stepmother.Looking on are the actress's ancient mother (Hermione Gingold), herself once a famous courtesan, and the actress's daughter (Chloe Franks), plus one lively, pretty maid (Lesley Dunlop), without whom no farce can be complete.The sum and substance of the show are not the characters but Mr. Sondheim's music and lyrics. They describe the awful and funny torments of hearts that rule minds of the size and consistency of baby peas. It's not exactly a problem play. It's Mozartean comedy in which stylized settings, costumes and even lighting create a world of sweet timelessness.Having elected to transform the Sondheim show into a film, Mr. Prince appears to have made every decision that could sabotage the music and the lyrics. He has cast the film with people who don't sing very well and then staged almost every number in such a way that we can't respond to the lyrics.He often photographs the singers in those blandly uninformative close-ups that force us to consider hairlines, necklines and lip-sync techniques.Mr. Sondheim's marvelous two-and three-part songs, in which characters, often in different settings, share their sentiments, work on the stage since the characters are enclosed by the same proscenium. In the movie, which is set in elegant but realistic locations, these numbers require all sorts of busy cross-cutting that upstages the music, which becomes as effectively fragmented as the images.It is, of course, possible to hear the songs, but in this movie it seems like-work. "Send in the Clowns" will survive Miss Taylor's game way with a lyric, and so will "You Must Meet My Wife" (Miss Taylor and Mr. Cariou), but "A Little Night Music" shouldn't be a matter of survival. It should be ebullient and fun. It isn't. It often seems to be mean-tempered.There's no reason why Miss Taylor should be photographed so unflatteringly (unless she gave the orders), or that Lesley-Ann Down and Diana Rigg should appear at times in flesh colors of grayish-green (at least in the print I saw).Someone should also have had the decency to blip out a word in one of the lyrics that gets a cruel laugh in the way it refers to Miss Taylor, who is an actress of more wit and character than "A Little Night Music" ever allows.So are Miss Down and Miss Rigg, though they, and Miss Taylor and Mr. Cariou do have one very funny scene. It's a dinner table scene in which everything goes wrong and no one is required to sing.Of the actors, Mr. Cariou is the only one who registers as a character. The others are animated mannequins. Hermione Gingold, re-creating her Broadway role, gets short shrift from the film, which even nips off her last scene, though that may be just as well. It's become increasingly apparent that less of Miss Gingold is moreand sometimes too much."A Little Night Music," which has been rated PG A "Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a couple of love scenes that are less heated than jurious in the way of farce.

title: News Summary
description: A new Israeli Government dispute was disclosed. Ezer Weizman, the Defense Minister, told Prime Minister. Menachem Begin by telephone Monday that he would cut short his mission to the United States, return to Israel and resign if work was begun against his orders on a new civilian settlement in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River. However, Mr.. Weizman told newsmen that he spoke again with Mr. Begin yesterday and it was agreed that all expansion of Israeli settlements in occupied Arab lands would halt until after Mr. Begin confers with President Carter next week. description: JERUSALEM, March 7The coalition Cabinet of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is becoming increasingly divided at a time of growing debate over the way the country should be responding to the peace gestures of President Anwar elSadat, which began with a sense of historic drama in November and are now stalled over the details.

Jersey healthcare company. Such action, the oil company said, would be an abuse of S.E.C. authority in that it would represent an attempt by the S.E.C. to write new law rather than enforce existing law.

description: THE title character in Anne Cornmire's Shay, marvelously played by Marge Redmond (at Playwrights Horizon), is a compulsive, selfwounding clown, forced and unwilling  to act the role of adult and mother. Pregnant at 15 and a highschool dropout, she has spent tne sunsequent years strapped to her familyand, as we watch, she is sinking. Her jokes are symptomatic of her collapse. To her middleclass Michigan family, she is merely an eccentric, strewing her home with notes to herself and to them, refusing to go out of the house, and craving isolation.

title: James M. Kahn, ExSports Editor Of The Sun Who Covered Yankees
description: James M. Kahn, former sports editor of The New York Sun and managing editor of The Brooklyn Eagle, died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday of stomach cancer. He was 75 years old and resided in Manhattan.

title: 2 Albany Panels Pass a DeathPenalty Bill
description: ALBANY, March 7A sweeping capitalpunishment bill permitting the execution of those convicted of intentional murder was approved in committee today and sent to the floor cf the Legislature, where action was scheduled for next week.

title: Islanders Set Back Canucks
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 7The New York Islanders easily defeated the Vancouver Canucks tonight, 52, too easily for a team in need of honing before the playoffs.

title: Japan Sees Yen's Rise as Threat to Economic Goals
description: TOKYO, March 7Japanese governmental, business and financial leaders expressed mounting concern here today that the yen's sharp rise this week, to a record value of 235 to the dollar, poses an increasing threat to the national economic growth targets to which Prime Minister Takeo Fukuda has committed his Government.

title: $400 Million Surplus Spurs Wisconsin Political Debate
description: MILWAUKEE, March 7It appears to be a politician's dream: There is more money in the Wisconsin state treasury than anyone expected, and all a candidate need do is to propose state expenditures that appeal to the voters.

title: Best Buys
description: WINTER recoiled last week from its almost relentless siege against the family food budget, as the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City dropped by 2.6 percent, or $2.07.

title: Suns 126, Nuggets 112
description: DENVER, March 7 (AP)Walter Davis, a rookie, scored 34 points. and Paul Westphal keyed a fourthquarter rally as the Phoenix Suns scored 126112 victory tonight over the Denver Nuggets.

title: Council to Hear Guerrillas
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 7The Security Council, meeting on Rhodesia, agreed today to hear the two leaders of the Patriotic Front guerrilla organization. Joshuo Nkomo and Robert Mugabe, the leaders of the Front, are scheduled to speak tomorrow.

title: Ends of Power Sold to Dell Paperback
description: After an auction that was conducted from last Wednesday to last Friday, the paperback rights to H. R. Haldeman's The Ends of Power, published in hardcover by Times Books, have been acquired by the Dell Publishing Company.

title: Private Lives
description: WHEN THE NEWS came last week that the English novelist Paul Scott had died, I was sorting books, I should have begun sorting my books  categorizing, alphabetizing, in some cases burning  20 years ago, but I've pretended instead to subscribe to a principle of serendipity. That is, if I didn't know where find the particular book, a book I hadn't thought of. This principle of serendipity is opposed to the principle of the study of ablations. An ablation a tumor or diseased organ, removed by surgery. Scientists study ablations, and try to draw conclusions about boring health from the evidence of ex travagant disease. (Only in his sickness does man become interesting, said Nietzsche, who ought to have known.) Many people organize and study their books in the same way, pathologically; they know exactly where to go to pull down an inky ablation of modernism or totalitarian politics or erotic poetry.

title: Judge Overrules the Assignment of Teachers by Race
description: The agreement between the New York City Board of Education and the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare to assign teachers by race was declared invalid yesterday by Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: CARTER IS AGAINST A BILL ON DISCLOSURE OF PAPERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)President Carter thinks that immediate public access to his Presidential papers once he is out of office could have a chilling effect in the meantime on forthright advice from his aides, the General Services Administrator said today.

title: KATHARINE P. M'KEE
description: Katharine Pillsbury McKee, who was active for years in the Boys Club of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and long a civic leader in Annapolis, Md., died last Friday at her home in Annapolis after a long illness. She was 72 years old.

title: Busch Stadium Is Rolling Up the Rugand Selling
description: ST. LOUIS, March 7The managers of Busch Stadium here are holding gigantic carpet closeout salecarpet that has been spiked and trampled by ballolavers for eight years.

title: LEGISLATOR CLEARED OF PADDING PAYROLL
description: ALBANY, March 7  Assemblyman Thomas R. Fortune was cleared of payroll padding charges late yesterday by judge who contended that the evidence was weak and that no show jobs had been standard procedure in Albany at the time of the alleged padding.

title: Tax Me, I'm British
description: LONDONA friend of mine recently wanted to rewire his house in Bracknell (a large London dormitory town). My friend received two estimates for his wiring job. One was a regular quote for payment by check. The other was for not much more than half the amountnothing said, nothing written, you understand, payment strictly in cash.

title: Hawks 123, Pistons 109
description: ATLANTA, March 7 (UPI)  John Drew scored 19 points tonight and led the Atlanta Hawks to a 123109 Victory over the Detroit Pistons. The triumph moved Atlanta into a tie with idle Cleveland far third place in the Central Division in the race for an Eastern Conference playoff spot.

title: United Press International
description: PLANT EXPLOSION FORCES EVACUATIONS: Smoke billowed from explosion and fire at Vicksburg Chemical Company hi Vicksburg, Miss., yesterday. The accident injured four people and sent a cloud of pesticide gas drifting across the Mississippi River into towns in Louisiana. People in area were moved from homes and businesses.

title: The New York Times/Paul Hosetros
description: WASHINGTON, March 7President Carter and President Tito of Yugoslavia discussed areas of conflict and tension in northeastern Africa and the Middle East today for more than an hour and found they disagreed very little in their assessments, official participants in the talks reported.

title: U.S. Firm on Shcharansky Case Despite Roommate's C.I.A. Link
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  United States officials said today that they still regarded the pending trial of Anatoly Shcharansky, a Soviet Jewish dissident, as a test of SovietAmerican relations, despite the confirmation that a former roommate of his had worked for the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Business Records
description: Chapter XI Petition For An Arrangement By: YOUNG IN FIGURE INC., In care of Robert E. Michael, 53 Wall 51., N.Y. Liabilities, $1,523,243; assets, $3,000,000. Ownership in real property In Westchester County N.Y. Emily W. Levey Is president.

title: About Real Estate
description: Fashion models were strolling around the sixth floor of One Penn Plaza yesterday, showing buyers the latest European fashions. It was Emile. Tubiana's European Fashion Fair, which used to hold forth at the StatlerHilton Hotel. But Mr. Tubiana, A French citizen who lives in West Germany, leased one full floor with 68,000 square feet In One Penn Plaza last January for his AmericanEuropean Trade and Exhibition Center. The first show is in full swing.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 7 (AP)The city today was granted permission to blockade a fortified house where a group of more than 20 armed radicals has been staying since a confrontation with the police last May.

title: Humphrey Property Left to Wife Value of His Estate NOt Known
description: BUFFALO, Minn., March 7 (UPI)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey left the bulk of his personal property to his wife, Muriel, and four shotguns to his three sons and 11;s soninlaw, but the value of his estate is uncertain, records show.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, March 7 (UPI) Bjorn Borg ended a 16month professional boycott of his country today by appearing in the $60,000 Scandinavian Cup tennis tournament. He defeated Sandy Mayer of the United States, 76, 6.3, in the opening round.

title: Sampling the New Exotics
description: Captain William Bligh's crew hated breadfruit so much it reportedly triggered the famous mutiny on the Bounty. When Captain Cook encountered the bumpyskinned tropical fruit in Tahiti he found it disagreeable as a pickled olive.

title: Deaths
description: CASOLAAlfred S. Reverend (V.F.), Pastor Sacred Heart RC church, North Merrick. LI on March 7, 1978. Beloved son of the late Mary, and the late Ralph. Loving and devoted brother of Albert, Lucy Madden, Armand and Sue Emmon. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, cousins, grandnieces and grandnephews. Reposing Sacred Heart RC Rectory 1921 Old Mill Road, North Merrick, Wednesday 1PM to 5PM and 7PM to 10PM and Thursday IPM to 5PM. Thence, transferral to Church at 7:30PM where Concelebrated Mass of Transferral will be celebrated by Rev. Witham F. Costello, Pastor, Cure of Ars RC Church at RPM. Concelebrated Mass of Christ the High Priest will celebrated by Most Reverend John R. McGann (Bishop of Rockville Centre Diocese) on Friday, 11AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers family requests Mass Cards preferred.

title: Bridge:
description: Just as some barroom political clashes can be settled only by physical sombat, so some postmortem arguments about bridge bidding have to be decided on another battlefield by fighting out what might have happened in the play.

title: City Won't Alter Old Bank
description: New York City has abandoned plans to alter the main banking hall of the old Emigrant Savings Bank at 51 Chambers Street, Mayor Koch has announced. The city, which owns the building and uses the upper floors for offices, had been planning a drastic renovation of the room, considered one of the finest BeauxArts banking halls in the city, to accommodate the Parking Violations Bureau.

title: U.S., in U.N. Rights Body, Charges Soviet Harasses Religious Believers
description: GENEVA, March 8The United States told the United Nations Human Rights Commission today that it should be deeply troubled by reports that Soviet citizens were being persecuted for their reiiginus beliefs.

title: Deaths
description: GODSOL, Beatrice H. March 5. In Pain) Springs, California. Interment Ptivate.

title: FRENCH JOURNALISTS SEE VIETNAM BATTLE
description: THUONG PHUOC, Vietnam, March 4 Tell the artillery to open fire, ordered the Vietnamese officer commanding the detachment that accompanied us to the front line near the border beween Cambodia and Vietnam.

title: Japanese Pyramid Rises in Egypt
description: CAIRO, March 7The Japanese, who mastered the art of the compact automobile and the transistor television set, have now tried their hand at the Egyptian pyramid. They learned less about the ancient pharaonic secrets than they did about frustrations of modern Egypt.

title: Police PensiOn Fund Orders 2,100 to File Report on Finances
description: Complying with a ruling from the city's Corporation Counsel, the trustees of the Police Pension Fund voted yesterday to require a monthly financial statement from about 2,100 people receiving disability pensions to make sure they are not earning more than allowed on another job.

title: 3 Scientists Will Demand U. S. Data on Cloning and Genetic Engineering
description: Three scientists said yesterday that they would demand information from the National Institutes of Health and other Federal agencies about any Government support of research related to cloning and genetic engineering.

title: Parsley Gets Star Billing
description: IF PARSLEY were as scarce as sturgeon eggs and as rare as truffles, it would conceivably be one of the world's most soughtafter herbs. Happily, it is almost as abundant as meadow grass, taken for granted In most kitchens throughout the world as salt ana pepper. un any given asy, IL is tossed, in one form or another, into countless soups and stews and assorted ragouts. Without parsley sprigs what would airline chefs resort to as they garnish those plastic trays?

title: Futures Prices Soar For Precious Metals And Farm Products
description: Prices of precious metals and basic farm produce futures exploded yesterday in what brokers described as a burst of demand from both domestic and overseas buyers. But most were unable to explain whv.

title: Rhodesia Attacks Guerrilla Base In Zambia and Reports Killing 38
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 7The Rhodesian Government announced tonight that its forces had crossed into Zambia and had killed at least 38 black guerrillas at a base belonging to the army of Joshua Nkomo, the exiled nationalist leader. The move could complicate efforts to win support for the majority rule agreement concluded here last week.

title: Alabama Policemen Dismissed
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 7 (AP)Two white policemen were discharged and another was suspended today after they were accused of shooting into the home of a black family mhile off duty in a marked police car.

title: Knicks Win
description: The Knicks beat the Houston Rockets, 112101, last night but a seething Willis Reed watched the closing minutes of the victory on cable television.

title: Suit by Physician In Police Beating Wins $1.2 Million
description: Damages of $1.2 million were awarded last night by a Federal jury in Brooklyn to a Long Island physician who said two Long Island State Parkway officers had severely beaten him two years ago after stopping his car and falsely accusing him of drunken driving.

title: Miss Morerod Captures World Cup Giant Slalom
description: WATERVILLE VALLEY, N.H., March 7Switzerland's LiseMarie Morerod won the giant slalom, Liechtenstein's Hanni Wenzel won her first women's overall title and America's skiers won the. plaudits of the crowd at the World Cup competition today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOUCH OF GLASS 70 rare examples of paperweights from the classic period Of their manufacture, during the mid19th century, mainly in France, England and Bohemia. will be on view at Steuben Glass, Fifth Avenue at 5Gth Street, today through April 1. Drawn from international private collections and museums, the paperweight array is a benefit for the New York Public Library. Admission is $2, and $1 for students an the elderly; visiting hours are 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., except Sunday.

title: Ads in Film Houses Resisted
description: Los ANGELES IT IS 8 O'CLOCK on a Monday night at the Westwood Village Theater in suburban Los Angeles. On the movie screen, a chubby youne man drives down a country lane. Ten seconds later, he arrives at recording studio in London. For the next three minutes, the man, Alan Price, accompanies himself on a guitar and sings.,His song, I Wanna Dance, ends to scattered applause from an audience that has come to see Saturday Night Fever. Only wheh an album jacket from Jet Records appears on the screen does the audience realize it has been watching a commercial. There is a moment of embarrassed laughter.

title: Deaths
description: CASOLAAlf red S. Reverend (V.F.). Pastor Sacred Heart RC church, North Merrick, LI on March 7, 1978. Beloved son of the late Mary, and the late Ralph. Loving and devoted brother of Albert, Lucy Madden, Armand and Sue Emmon. Also survived by many loving nieces, nephews, cousins, grandnieces and grandnephews. Reposing Sacred Heart RC Rectory 1921 Old Mill Road, North Merrick, Wednesday 1PM to 5PM and 7PM to 10PM and Thursday 1PM to 5PM. Thence, transferral, to Church at 7:30PM where Concelebrated Mass of Transferral will be celebrated by Rev. William F. Costello, Pastor, Cure of Ars RC Church at 8PM. Concelebrated Mass of Christ the High Priest will celebrated by Most Reverend John R. McGann (Bishop of Ror.kville Centre Diocese) on Friday, 11AM. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village. In lieu of flowers lamily requests Mass Cardspref erred.

title: Wine Talk
description: IN 1865 pollsters In England and Germany set out to probe people's likes and dislikes. According to David Resnick, an assistant professor of government at Cornell Universtiy, two of the people who replied were Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.

title: Providence Six Advances Ousting Cornell, 85
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 7 (AP)Steve O'Neil had three goals and two assists, including the gamewinning goal tonight as Providence defeated Cornell, 85, in the Eastern College Athletic Conference hockey quarterfinals.

title: Clues From Wine Cellar
description: One of the more esoteric products of the current Tutankhamen revival is a large format color paperback volume entitled King Tut's Wine Cellar, by Leonard H. Lesko, a University of California Egvatolo2ist.

title: Gerulaitis Heads Davis Cup Team
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, Harold Solomon, Sherwood Stewart and Fred McNair were named yesterday to represent the United States in the threeoffivematch Davis Cup tennis competition against South Africa March 17 indoors at Vanderbilt University in Nashville.

title: Experts Find City Pension Funds Losing Ability to Rescue New York
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The ability of municipal employee pension funds to play a vital role in New York City's financial recovery plan is in jeopardy, threatening bankruptcy for the city, according to experts who testified at Congressional hearings today.

title: Queens College ExStudent Admits Doctoring Grades
description: A former Queens College student who worked in a computer center on the Flushing campus has admitted changing the grades of about a dozen students and getting an unmerited Phi Beta Kappa key for himself, according to City University and Queens College officials.

title: Deaths
description: ADELSBERGHyman. Cornell Chapter and Alumni, Alpha Epsilon Pi Fraternity sorrowfully mourn the loss of Hyman Adelsberg (Beta 21). A devoted Chapter advisor for many years; builder of a wonderful new Chapter House; highly respected; an outstanding man greatly admired by everyone. Condolences to his family.

title: G.O.P. Stalls Burstein Appointment
description: ALBANY, March 7In an attempt to widen their majority, leaders of the Republicancontrolled State Senate have decided to delay the confirmation of Karen S. Burstein's appointment to the State Public Service Commission until April 1the last date to call a special election to fill the vacancy created by the Nassau County Democrat's departure.

title: Judge Says U.S.New York Accord Was Reached Without Hearings
description: The agreement between the New York City Board of Education and the Federal Department of Health, Education and Welfare to assign teachers by race was declared invalid yesterday by Judge Jack B. Weinstein in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Moses, at 89, Has Not Lost His Talent for Speaking Out
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Robert Moses, at the age of 89 still the inimitable Peck's Bad Boy of autocrats, gave his views on an entire spectrum of subjects to an invited audience at the National Portrait Gallery last night, proving himself unmellowed by the nassaze of time.

title: Dispute and Strain in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, March 7The coalition Cabinet of Prime Minister Menachem Begin is becoming increasingly divided at a time of growing debate over the way the country should be resporlding to the News Analysis peace gestures or rresiaent Anwar elSadat, which began with a sense of historic drama in November and are now stalled over the details.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Drafts a Plan To Reopen the Tombs

title: U.S. MAY STILL SEEK SPECIAL LEGISLATION TO SEIZE COAL MINES
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Carter Administration is still planning to ask Congress for special legislation to seize the struck coal mines if the TaftHartley remedies now in motion do not work, officials here said today.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 8, 1978

title: G. O.P. Urges Carey To Increase Budget For Mental Health
description: ALBANY, March 7Senate Repu'blitional in Governor Carey's mental health budget and for restoring $4.6 million that ads whvec haraa

title: Affidavit Says Philadelphia F.B.I. Urged That Marston Be Retained
description: WASHINGTON, March 7As. early as last September, Neil Welch, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in Philadelphia, warned a top Justice Department official that the city was a cesspool of political corruption and urged that David W. Marston be kept there as United States Attorney, documents made public today showed.

title: Pollution Curbs Called Threat to State Industry
description: TRENTON, March 7A labor and business coalition urged the Byrne administration today to go slow in implementing Federal clean air standards or risk stampede of business from the state.

title: TV: Captain Nemo Is Back
description: SPOOKY! WEIRD! the two Navy sea divers assure us as they swim toward a strange ship wedged in a Pacific coral reef. Actually, what follows turns out to be merely ludicrous. The ship Is the Nautilus, and the man in a glass cylinder is Captain Nemo, preserved for 100 years and now ready to resume his search for Atlantis. But sir, says one of the helpful sailors, Captain Nemo is a fictional character out of a book by Jules Verne. That much established, television proceeds to perform its normal damage.

title: To Their Manners Born
description: THAT superior view of social standing was common in the 19th century. Etiquette dictated intricate rules, delicate observances, sensible cautions and stifling demands. Woe to the parvenu who challenged what authorities called the power of Tittles.

title: Museum Mammoth Is a Metamorph
description: The most startling creature at the American Museum of Natural History has no fur fdather, hair, scales, or even bones. Nor will it be preserved for posterity. It is a lifesize replica of a Stegosaurus, an Early Cretaceous dinosaur sculptured entirely of snow.

title: U.S. Mobile Missile Project Faces New Delays
description: The Air Force's program to develop the mobile intercontinental ballistic missile, already slowed by the Carter Administration, faces further delays and possible scrapping because of uncertainties about the missile's ability to survive an attack.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in some editions of The Times yesterday that Benjamin J. Few, a former director and president of Liggett & Myers who died Thursday, was one of 13 tobacco company executives who were convicted in 1941 of monopoly and pricefixing. Mr. Few was acquitted in that case.

title: China Issues Charter Expanding Rights of Citizens and Legislature
description: PEKING, March 7 (Reuters)China published today its new Constitution, ostensibly strengthening the rights of citizens to speak out and increasing the powers of the cbuntry's parliament in relation to the Community Party.

title: Sadat Appoints Writer
description: CAIRO, March 7 (AP)  President Anwar elSadat appointed a prominent leftist writer today as secretary general of the AfroAsian Peoples Solidarity Organization to replace Yousef elSebai, who was assassinated last month in Cyprus by three Arab gunmen.

title: Cases of Fraud Found in Testing Drugs on Humans
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Officials of the Food and Drug Administration said today that they had found isolated cases of fraud in the testing of new drugs on humans.

title: Key Question in LongTerm Funds
description: A large question in New York City's longterm financing plan is what effect large purchases of New York City bonds by the city and state pension funds might have on the funds taxexempt status.

title: 71 JERSEY INSURERS HELD OVERCHARGING
description: TRENTON, March 7James J. Sheeran. the State Commissioner of Insurance, said today that 71 private health and accident insurance companies had been overcharging New Jerseyans and that he had ordered them to stop selling 133 kinds of policies in the state.

title: James M.Aahn, ExSports Editor Of The Sun Who Covered Yankees
description: James M. Kahn. former sports editor of The New York Sun and managing editor of The Brooklyn Eagle, died at Bellevue Hospital yesterday of stomach cancer. He was 75 years old and resided in Manhattan.

title: New Governor For Arizona
description: PHOENIX, March 7Although Bruce Babbitt has been Governor of Arizona for only three days, newsmen here have already given his Administration a nickname. They call it the Gray Suit Administration. It refers not only to the dress but also to the official style of the 39yearold Democrat. an affinity for sport shirts and Westernstyle string ties called bolos. But it is hard to imagine Mr. Babbitt showing up for work at the Statehouse in anything but a basic business suit, a, tie, and a clean white shirt.

title: Notes on People
description: THE retired Roman Catholic Archbishop of Washington, Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, has withdrawn as a sponsor of the capital's St. Patrick's Day Parade because the Irish Northern Aid Committee is going to be allowed to participate in it. The committee, suspecte d ofsupporting the Irish Republican Army, has been described as anathema to our party and our Government by John Lynch, Prime Minister of Ireland. The committee's part in the parade was brought to the attention of Cardinal O'Boyle by the Rev Michael Hamilton, a Protestant native of Belfast who is cannon of the Episcopal Washington Cathedral. Although the Cardinal has asked that his name be removed from the list of parade sponsors, remaining on the list are the names of Senator Edward M. Kennedy and Representative Michael Harrington, Democrats of Massachusetts.

title: Soviet Allows an AvantGarde Show, Partly Censored
description: MOSCOW, March 7  An officially. sanctioned exhibition of 20 Soviet avantgarde painters opened today after the authorities had removed a score of paintings for ideological reasons.

title: LIQUOR STORES CHARGED WITH TAKING KICKBACKS
description: The New York State Liquor Authority has charged 28 stores in the metropolitan area with accepting illegal kickbacks rorn the National Distillers & Chemical Corporation.

title: Closed End Funds
description: Unaudited net asset values of closedend Investment fund shares, reported by the companies as of Friday, Feb. 24, 1978. Also shown is the closing listed market price or dealertodealer asked price of each fund's shares, with the percentage of difference.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: It was incorrectly reported in some editions of The Times yesterday that Benjamin J. Few, a former director and president of Liggett & Myers who died Thursday, was one of 13 tobacco cornpany executives who were convicted in 1941 of monopoly and pricefixing. Mr. Few was acquitted in that case.

title: Police in Virginia Arrest Man in Shooting of Larry Flynt and His Lawyer
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 7 (AP)A young man was arrested in Norfolk tonight and held on Georgia fugitive warrants charging him with the attempted murder of the owner of Hustler magazine, Larry Flynt, and his lawyer, the police said.

title: BANKERS URGE STEPS TO PROTECT DOLLAR AS DROP CONTINUES
description: The dollar weakened yesterday in late trading on the foreign exchange market in New York, after several prominent bankers called for urgent measures to curb the American currency's decline.

title: Boston University Six Wins
description: BOSTON, March 7 (UPI)Bob Voileau scored at 7:21 of an overtime period tonight to lift topseeded Boston University to a 65 victory over the University of New Hampshire in the quarterfinals of the Eastern College Athletic Conference tournament. Voileau slipped in the rebound of a slapshot by Bill LeBlond.

title: Two Defiant School Districts Yield
description: Two school districtsone in Brooklyn and one in Queensthat previously defied a Board of Education order to compile ethnic data on pupils required for Federal aid now have agreed to provide such data.

title: Fastest OldTimer in Town
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7In this land of sunshine and senior citizens, the oldest baseball player in town today was Louis Clark Brock of the St. Louis Cardinals. He will be 39 years old in June, he has stolen 900 bases in summers and nobody else in history has stolen more, but has one more goal before calling it quits: 3,000 hits in the major leagues. Old people and young baseball players are everywhere in Florida and Arizona these days, and for tile same reason: the sun shines. There are even some young people who are old baseball players, but accomplished ones. Willie McCovey of the San Francisco Giants just turned 40 after hitting 28 home runs. Gaylord Perry of the San Diego Padres turned 39 after pitching 238 innings and winning 15 games. But no senior citizen and no other baseball player any age anywhere has an act like Lou Brock's.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: NOBODY EVER gives eavesdropping its proper due. When surveys of leisuretime activities are made, the statistics always show that Americans are watching television, running off to baseball games in record numbers, staying diome from football games in unprecedented hordes, taking up boating on manmade lakes in the desert, tuning in on the mystique of crosscountry skiing, flocking to tennis courts, discovering the joys of running, finding new things to stuff into the Cuisinart, buying new athletic shoes, meditating and even engaging in sex.

title: About Education
description: For hundreds of thousands of schoolchildren in the metropolitan area, many of those schooldays lost because of snowstorms will have to be made up with terms extended into the summer vacation.

title: A Coeducational West Point Examines Fraternization
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., March 6First ere was the busing of women into est Point for Saturday night dances. len they began to come in their lofts cars, often alone, for a weekend ite.

title: Partisan Clash on Jobs Bill
description: WASHINGTON. March 7The fight in Congress over the HumphreyHawkins full employment bill is sounding increasingly like an opening skirmish in this year's oolitical camvaign.

title: Illinois Town Suspends Its Police Amid Accusations of Corruption
description: ROBBINS, III., March 7The entire 15 member police department of this Chicago suburb has been suspended as a result of charges that some policemen committed burglaries, extortions and assaults and stole narcotics before they could be used as evidence in criminal cases.

title: Books of The Times
description: WOULDN'T it be uplifting if Leslie Fiedler were right when he argues in his new book Freaks that we of the 20th century have changed our attitudes toward nature's experiments, because instead of being interested in freaks for their alien otherness, as people were in the 19th century, we have come to identify with them as expressions of our secret selves?

title: Atlanta's Police Director Is Relieved of Command
description: ATLANTA, March 7Reginald Eaves, Atlanta's Public Safety Commissioner, was relieved tonight of command of the city's police department, pending the conclusion of a controversial, racially sensitive investigation into a promotion scandal.

title: Officials of F.B.I. Fund Say Dues Were Not Misused
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Officials of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Recreation Association have sent form letters to all the group's members telling them that, despite a Justice Department report that concluded that some former F.B.I. officials had misused the association's funds, none of their dues had been used for improper purposes.

title: Film: A Doll's House, '73Vintage Jane Fonda
description: DAVID MERCER'S adaptation of the Ibsen play, directed by oseph Losey, has been fattened with feeble lines and even short scenes that the old genius didn't write. Also, some passages, such A Doll's House was shown at the 1973 New York Film Festival. It was also shown on ABCTV Dec. 23, 1973. The following are excerpts from the review written by Nora Sayre and published in The Times on Oct. 2, 1973. The film opens today at the Thalia Theater, 95th Street and Broadway, and will play through next Tuesday. as Kristine Linde's reunion with Krogstad and Nora's tarantella, have been intercut. So the dramatic momentum is butchered. Although we can sympathize with a film maker's urge to escape one single indoor setting, and it's always nice to have an excuse for shots of snowespecially if you can sling in a sleigh or twomost of these tricks merely weaken a tightly written play.

title: Philadelphians Play Ivan the Terrible
description: PROKOFIEV composed the score of Ivan the Terrible in 1944 for Sergei Eisenstein's film of that name. But he never got around to abstracting the music for concert performance, as he had done with several of his film scores, notably Lt. Kije and Alexander Nevsky.

title: Deaths
description: REDMONDMichael. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Michael Redmond, associated with The Times from June 1, 1946 until retiring in 1968.

title: Deaths
description: DeNOOY E RLeonardOn March 4, 1978. Beloved husband of Ellen. Devoted father of Leonard, Ellen and Alice. Dear son of Martiena DeNoover. Services Friday 11 AM it Purchase Friends Meeting House Route 170, Purchase, N.Y. Interment Purchase Meeting Burial Grounds. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Westchester Heart Association 15 Ridge Plaza, Port Chester, N.Y. would be appreciated.

title: Careers
description: Go West or go South, young nurse, is the message that will be brought to New York this week by 70 nurse recruiters from many parts of the country. They have more than 3,000 fobs to fill.

title: Jersey Trooper Settle Civil Suit On Beating of a Driver on Turnpike
description: NEWARK, March 7 (AP)A New Jersey state trooper has settled a police brutality civil suit by agreeing to pay $17,500 and accept a transfer to a nonpublic contact iob.

title: TEMPORARY LICENSES BACKED FOR CASINOS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 7The Casino Control Commission said today that unanimously backed a proposal by Governor Byrne that would speed the opening of gambling casinos here by allowing temporary operating permits while investigation of applications for permanent licenses continued.

title: Carter Signs Appropriations Bill; Will Close Clinch River Project
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (UPI)President Carter signed the $7.3 billion supplemental appropriations bill today. contained $80 million for the Clinch River Breeder Reactor, which he opposes, so the President said he would use the money to close the program.

title: EMPLOYEES OF HUGHES VIEW HIS SPRUCE GOOSE
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 7 (APWith security guards as escorts, 70 guests got a look today at Howard Hughes most mysterious possession, The Spruce Goose, the enormous flying boat that he flew only once.

title: Foreigners Taking Over Businesses In U.S. at Bargain Basement Prices
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)Foreigners are grabbing up small and mediumsize United States businesses at bargainbasement prices because of a sharp drop in investment by Americans, the chairman of the American Stock Exchange said today.

title: Easter Seal Society
description: For somone on crutches or in a wheelchair, a flight of stairs can be a devastating barrier. It can keep that person out of a school building, a place of employment, a museum, a theater. The list is endless.

title: Sancho Is Favored for Garcia's Seat
description: Robert Sancho, a 32yearold Manhattan school official, emerged yesterday as the frontrunner for the State Senate seat vacated by Robert Garcia when he won election to Congress from the South Bronx last month

title: Experts Unclear About the Extent Of Coal Shortage
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Although Administration and private economists have said repeatedly that the prolonged coal strike would soon cause power cutbacks and largescale layoffs, the actual extent of the coal shortage is unclear so far.

title: Deaths
description: GODSOL, Beatrice H. March 5. In Palm Springs, California: Interment Private.

title: U.S. MAY STILL SEEK SPECIAL LEGISLATION TO SEIZE COAL MINES
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Carter Administration is still planning to ask Congress for special legislation to seize the struck coal mines if the TaftHartley remedies now in motion do not work. officials here said today.

title: Humphrey Property Left.to Wife; Value'of His Estate Not Knowiti
description: BUFFALO, Ivlinn., March (uri)Senator Hubert H. Humphrey left the bulk of his personal property to his wife, Muriel, and four shotguns to his three sons and his soninlaw, but the value of his estate is uncertain, records show.

title: People and Business
description: Robert Tarnmero, senior vice president of finance for Abraham & Straus, is expected to be named president todAy of the Brooklynbased chain of 10 department stores in the metropolitan area, trade sources reported yesterday.

title: SENATE UNIT BACKS MEASURE FOR AUDITS OF 3 BANK AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 7The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee approved today legislation to require for the first time Federal audits of the nation's three bank regulatory agencies.

title: State Says  Dr. X Tried to Discredit Colleagues by Killing T heir Patients
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 7Over strenuous objections by the defense, the prosecution began building its case today linking what it called Dr. Mario E, Jascalevich's murder of five patients at Riverdell Hospital with attempts to gain more power as chief of surgery at the hospital.

title: ISRAEL DEFENSE CHIEF THREATENS TO RESIGN IN SETTLEMENTS RIFT
description: WASHINGTON, March 7Ezer Weizman, Israel's Defense Minister, told Prime Minister Menachem Begin by telephone yesterday that he would cut short his official visit to the United States, return to Israel and resign if work was startedin defiance of his orderson a new civilian settleinent in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Coastal States Gas Corporation announced yesterday that a Federal bankruptcy judge in San Antonio had issued an order that effectively assures continued payment to a Coastal States subsidiary for delivery of feedstocks to the Commonwealth Oil and Refining Company's Puerto Rican refinery complex.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: New Jerseyans confidence in the Federal Government, the mass media and educational institutions increased during the last four years, according to a poll taken by the Rutgers University Eagleton Institute of Politics.

title: FRENCH LEFT COUNTS ON THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: PARIS, March 7Large segments of the French middle classwhich constitutes a majority of the nation and, has been the backbone of 20 years of conservative governmentare behaving out of character and leaning to the left.

title: Puerto Rican Group Is Ordered to End SitIn at a Project
description: A group sitting in at the citywide antipoverty Puerto Rican Community Development Project was ordered by State Supreme Court justice to let. workers back in and services resume yesterday.

title: Japanese Pyramid Rises in Egypt
description: CAIRO, March 6The Japanese, who mastered the art of the compact automobile and the transistor television set, have now tried their hand at the Egyptian pyramid. They learned less about the ancient pharaonic secrets than they did about frustrations of modern Egypt.

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: OR ANYONE who cares about new experiences in eating, one of the more obvious pleasures of travel is the sampling of dishes not altogether common in one's own kitchen or milieu. On a recent trip to Italy, particularly in Tuscany, we dined several times on various birds stuffed with a blend of prosciutto and rosemary, a most agreeable combination flavors and certainly not common in the French repertory.

title: Rutgers Fights Order It Admit a Bankrupt
description: MORRISTOWN, March 7Attorneys for Rutgers University said today they would appeal a Federal Court ruling that the university had to readmit a student who had become bankrupt and had defaulted on a student loan.

title: 2 Men Take $500,000 Necklace From Kaiser Widow
description: A man followed the widow of the industrialist Henry J. Kaiser into the lobby of her apartment building at 860 United Nations Plaza early yesterday, the police said, drew a pistol and yanked a $500,000 diamond necklace from her neck.

title: Taming Civil Service
description: The many Americans who think Federal employees are underworked and overpaid and enjoy excessive benefits sometimes have a point. The Civil Service bureaucracy, always spawning regulations for others to live by, has difficulty living by its own; agencies are poorly managed, hiring policies have little logic, and inefficiency tolerated because it takes too long to fire the inefficient.

title: Girl Pitches 2 Innings For High School on Coast
description: SOUTH SAN FRANCISCO, March (UPI)Robin Petrini pitched two innings in a high school varsity baseball game with Capuchino High of San Bruno yesterday. Local coaches said it was the first time a female pitcher had been used in an interschool varsity name.

title: Developing Trend by States Toward Balancing Budgets
description: At the same time that the Federal Government has been strugglingwithout successto bring its budget back toward balance, the experience in almost all of the 50 state capitals has been just the opposite. There has been a dramatic turnabout in the condition of their financial ledgers during the last three years for a variety of reasms but chiefly because of the recovery in the national economy, which has pushed their revenues to new peaks in many cases. In the 197576 fiscal year, 24 of the 50 states ran deficits in their generalfund accounts, but in the current fiscal year, only six states will show redink figures, according to Leon J. Karvelis Jr., vlc,:> president in charge of municipal credit analysis for Citibank.

title: DR.X TRIED TO BUILD POWER, STATE SAYS
description: Prosecutor Charges That Physician Accused of Murder Tried to Make Colleagues Look Incompetent

title: S.E.C. PICKS MENDELSOHN AS INVESTING UNIT CHIEF
description: Washington, March 7The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the appointment of Sydney H. Mendelsohn as director of the agency's division of investment management.

title: LEONARD LEVIN
description: Leonard Levin of Great Neck, L. 1., public information officer for the State Racing and Wagering Board, died yesterday at St. Mary's Nursing Home in West Hartford, Conn. He was 63 years old.Mr. Levin, who held a similar position with the. State Harness Racing Commission before it was incorporated into the racing board, was a past president of the New York Chapter of the Harness Writers Association. He also was a Past Deputy Grand Chancellor of Rex Lodge, Knights of Pythias.

title: Deaths
description: DeNOOYERLeonardOn March 1978. Beloved husband of Ellen. Devoted father 01 Leonard, Ellen and Alice. Dear son of Martiena DeNoover. Services Friday 11 AM at Purchase Friends Meeting House Route 120, Purchase, N.Y. Interment Purchase Meeting Burial Grounds. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Westchester Heart Association 15 Ridge Plaza, Port Chester. N.Y. would be appreciated.

title: Boat Owners Urge End to 79th St. Marina Concession
description: Angry owners of boats kept at the west 79th Street marina met yesterday with Gordon Davis, the New York City Parks Commissioner, to demand that he immediately end the city's agreement with Nichols Yacht Yards Inc., which operates the marina.

title: Stevens Head Leaving Bank Under Pressure
description: GREENVILLE, S.C., March 7James D. Finley, chairman of J.P. Stevens & Company, which is locked in a bitter struggle with organized labor, said today that he was being forced to leave the the board of New York's Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, a bank that holds more than $1 billion in union trust and pension funds.

title: Associated Press
description: THIS RAILROAD ACCIDENT took place Monday night near Hesperia, Calif., when four locomotives and 20 freight carsmany carrying new automobiles derailed and caught fire. Two persons were reported missing and two others were injured. It was assumed that heavy rains in the area had undermined the tracks, causing the derailment.

title: Auto Workers Union to Contribute $2 Million to Miners Relief Fund
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP)The United Automobile Workers union will contribute $2 million to a relief fund to help the families of striking coal miners and pensioners, Douglas A. Fraser, the union president, said today.

title: Russian Takes Lead in World Figure Skating
description: OTTAWA. March 7 (AP)Vladimir Kovalev of the Soviet Union, the world champion, took a slim lead in the disciplined compulsory figures of the men's competition in today's opening day of the world figure skating championships.

title: Winds of Change Ruffle Charlestown, R.I
description: CHARLESTOWN, R.I., March 7No one who came into the Cross Mills general store for a bolt or a saw o a gallon of gasoline wanted to talk about Indians today.. Normally, no one here ever wants to talk about Indians.

title: Market Place
description: Howard Johnson, son of the founder of the motel and restaurant concern of the same name, says he is not talking merger with anyone and adds that the company simply is not for sale.

title: Sovereignty: Bulwark Against Statism's Utopia
description: In a recent letter, Benjamin Ferencz blamed national sovereignty for the rising level of chaos and hostility between countries, many of which dismiss cruelty to their own citizens behind the notion of noninterference in internal affairs. He envisions the deliberate withholding of surplus foodstuffs and fuel oils by nations ready instead. to export international blackmail and even Armageddon, all in the name of selfish national sovereignty (i.e., the insistence by each nation on pursuing its own wellbeing).

title: Suit by Physician In Police Beating Wins $1.2 Million
description: Damages of $1.2 million were awarded last night by a Federal jury in Brooklyn to a Long Island physician who said two Long Island State Parkway officers had severely beaten him two years ago after stopping his car and falsely accusing him of drunken driving.

title: Steve Bilko, 1st Baseman; Batted 248, Hit 76 Homers
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 7 (AP)Steve Bilko, a former major league first baseman, died today at Mercy Hospital here. He was 49 years old.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods ended Dee. 31 unless Otherwise Indicated. (N) Indicates. stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, (A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) otterthecounter

title: Chinese Style
description: If you've mastered cooking in a wok and eating with chopsticks, the next step might be a set of prepackaged tableware designed to make serving a Chinese meal more authentic. Imported from China and pack.

title: The Grandeur That Still Is Little Italy
description: IHAD LIVED in New York for a number of years before being absolutely certain where Little Italy was. For a time I thought it was that part of Greenwich Village surrounding the appropriatelynamed Church of Our Lady of Pompeii. Then one day I crossed Houston Street and walked down Mott Streetsimply because of the lyric, What street compares with Mott Street?and there it was: five and sixstory red brick buildings festooned with fire escapes and signs proclaiming Grotto Azzurra, Cafe Luna, Ferrara's. Italian words crossed my ears; the aromas of Italian cooking delighted my nose.

title: Andreotti Gets Accord On Forming Cabinet
description: SPecial to The New York TimesROME, March 8Prime Ministerdesignate Giulio Andreotti obtained agreement in principle today from the Communists and three smaller political parties to form a new eovernment.

title: Senators BidforDocuments Widens Marston Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The Senate Judiciary Committee today agreed to ask the Justice Department for documents that would significantly broaden the committee's inquiry into the dismissal of David W. Marston as United States Attorney in Philadelphia.

title: The Unending Human Rights Review
description: Two and a half years ago, the United States, the Soviet Union and 33 other states endorsed the celebrated Helsinki Final Act. It ratified the territorial changes wrought in Europe by World War H, abjured the use of force for settling disputes, and committed the signers to a variety of measures to protect the human rights of their citizens. They also undertook to meet again at Belgrade two years later to assess what they had doneand not doneto make good on their commitments.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENCharles J., on March 7, 1978 of Tenafly, N.J. Beloved husband of Lillian (nee Gleichauf 1. Devoted father of Dr. Ronald Allen of Wood. cliff Lake, N.J. Dear brother of Arthur of Rochester, N.Y. Also survived by 5 grandchildren and 1 great grandchild. Reposing Barrett Funeral Home. 118 Dean Drive. Tenafly, N.J. on Thursday 2.4 and 7.9. Funeral Mass Friday 10AM MICannel Church, Tenafly. Interment Mt.Carmel Cemetery.

title: TRANSIT SYSTEM WINS MIAMI AREA BACKING
description: MIAMI, March 8Forty years after New York City began dismantling its elevated railway lines, Miami area voters have given the goahead to the construction of a highspeed transit system dependent on elevated tracks.

title: GORDON E. COX OF CANADA, CAREER DIPLOMAT WAS 60
description: VIENNA, March 8 (Reuters)Gordon Edwin Cox, Canadian Ambassador to the EastWest troop reduction talks here, died today after having been struck by a streetcar, the police said.

title: H.E.W. WARNS ABOUT BIAS IN PUNISHING OF TEACHERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)  A school that believes two teachers are having an affair could lose Federal funds if only one of them was punished, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare says.

title: Anker to Suspend Queens Board Unless ItGives Racial Data to U.S.
description: The New York City School Chancellor, Irving Anker, said last night that he would suspend Community School Board 26 in Queens tomorrow if the board continued. to refuse to submit an ethnic breakdown of its students and faculty members.

title: Republicans to Break A 25Year Pattern
description: It has been so long that party leaders cannot remember offhand just how long, but when the Republican Party holds its state convention in New York City next June, it will be the first time here in at least 25 years.

title: Built for Healthy Living: A Loft With Splash
description: THE FOCAL point of Adri Stecking's spacious new home is not a fireplace, a painting or a cozy seating arrangement. It's an eightfootsquare Jacuzzi whirlpool bath that accommodates 10 people, is set into a white tile platform reached by eight steps, and is equipped with a cat board should any of the two resident felines fall into the pool.

title: Rhode Island Aides Vote to Strike
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 8 (UPI) Rhode Island officials today braced for a threatened strike next week by two, thirds of the state government work force but hoped a walkout could be averted through new contract talks. Leaders of qouncil 94 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees voted 22 to 5 last night to strike at 6:30 A.M. Monday in a wagereopener dispute from a contract that expires next October. The council represents 12,000 state employees.

title: A Dulles Allefies 900 ErrorsinDulles
description: A storm of recriminations and press releases is being churned up as a result of a new biography, Dulles, by Leonard Mosley, published by James Wade/The Dial Press.

title: Waiting
description: Has anyone seen a harbinger lately? Or heard one? No snowdrops have come up on the lawn yet and no daffodil peddlers have shown up at the subway station. There hasn't been a chirp from a robin looking for an early worm or a tune from a street musician fiddling for his supper. The lunchtime picniclers on the library steps huddle in their parkas under lee of a lion and the fat buds on the magnolia trees keep their coats tight around the flowers inside. The sun, of course, follows its usual schedule as it moves toward the equinox but does nothing to warm us up for that vernal occasion. Like the impatient poet who asked the wind to forecast the season, we have a wishful question: Can spring really cometif its heralds are so far behind?

title: Hers
description: TEN years ago, in quite separate circumstances, I knew a man and a woman who each suffered acutely from what might loosely be termed the imposition of the powerful will.

title: TV Cartoons Face Dim Future
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8Tens of millions of dollars worth of animated cartoon programs face losing. their market, and consequently their value, if the Federal Trade Commission should adopt a rule to eliminate all commercials from television programs directed at preschool children.

title: Potential Juror With a Problem
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 8  Thomas F. Busacca, who has been subpoenaed for jury duty in State Supreme Court in Mineola, would be delighted to carry out his civic duty, his lawyer says,. but there are problems.

title: Spicks Picks All as Next Foe; Blacks Oppose South Africa Site
description: While Leon Spinks announced yesterday he would fight Muhammad Ali and not Ken Norton, plans for that $14 million world heavyweight title rematch, to be held in Bophuthatswana, met with strong opposition from antiapartheid groups in the United States.

title: Somalis Abandoning North Ogaden
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 8Under heavy attack from planes, artillery and infantry, Somali force have abandoned positions in Ethiopia's northern Ogaden region and are straggling back to Somalia.

title: Mets vs. Mets: Hitters Star as Hurlers Flop
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8In a howling wind under black skies, the New York Mets tested their rebuilding program in a baseball game today and after nine innings it seemed apparent that the team had indeed gained some punch but had indeed sacrificed some pitching to get it.

title: Rhodesian Guerrillas Bar Talk With Internal Blacks
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 8Rhodesian guerrilla leaders reaffirmed today their refuSal to meet with the domestic nationalists who signed an agreement last week with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith on transition to a black majority government.

title: High Dudgeon Over High Taxes
description: Righteous wrathor high dudgeonclears the head but muddies the water. The Community Service Society, one of New York City's oldest social welfare agencies, succumbed to this emotion last week when it issued a press release calling the city's real property valuation system racist. One result was that practically no one bothered to discuss the substance of the report about the administration of the real property tax in New York City, which the press release introduced.

title: Civiletti's CoverUp
description: WASHINGTON, March 8A fairly serious charge was leveled in this space two months ago: that President Carter's order to fire David Marston, the United States Attorney in Philadelphiadelivered at the request or a Congressman who was being investigated by Mr. Marstongave us reason to suspect that the President may have been drawn into an obstruction of justice.

title: Dance: Laura Dean Premiere
description: LAURA DEAN Dancers and Musicians, as Miss Dean now calls her performing group, never fails to come up with some of the most interesting experimental choreography around at this time.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter should state his terms for breaking the diplomatic stalemate in the Middle East, President Anwar elSadat said in an interview at his home beside the Nile. The Egyptian leader, appearing apprehensive about next week's meeting in Washington between Mr. Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, said the time has come for the United States to risk its responsibility as a partner and not a mediator in the negotiations. Mr. Sadat suggested that Mr. Carter apply his espousal of human rights, nonacquisition of land by force and mutual security. [Page A1, Col. 11

title: About New York
description: The winter home of the Big Apple Circus is the church synod building on the grounds of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, an anachronistically soaring compound amid the roughhewn reality of Harlem. There the silvery aerialiit rigging crisscrosses under the high roof like spaceage liturgical instruments, and Gregory Fedin, a circus teacher from Russia, scampers without a net along 38foothigh beams above the twinkle of the church chandeliers.

title: Youth, 18, Admits He Killed Couple
description: An 18yearold youth on trial for murder confessed yesterday to killing an elderly lawyer and his wife in their luxury East Side apartment and to taking $2,800 from them because he did not like his grandmother working as a maid for white Caucasians.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: WHO's ON VERSE? Two young poets who recently received national awards are reading tonight at 6:30 in the free Academy of American Poets program at the New York Public Library's Donnell Center, 20 West 53d Street (opposite the Museum of Modern Art). The guests are Larry. Levis, winner of the Lamont Poetry Selection, and Stan Rice, recipient of the Edgar Allan Poe Award.

title: Home Beat
description: SOME people are discovered in Hollywood soda fountains. Fame found Karen Nymanin a wallpaper store. Seven years ago Mrs. Nyman (who was 27 years old at the time, a Philadelphia housewife, mother of two young children and a former math teacher) hung some wallpaper, herself, in a bathroom. It was a fabricbacked foilthe hardest of all papers to hang, especially for a beginner. She did such a good job that the man who sold her the paper told her she ought to go into business. Three years later, after she had hung paper in her husband's office and in the homes of innumerable friendsshe went to work three days a week for Penn Wallpapers.

title: State Assails New York City's Care of Mentally Ill
description: ALBANY, March 8  The State Department of Mental Hygiene has accused New York City of consistently failing to meet its commitments to improve care for the mentally ill, particularly. children and the chronically disturbed..

title: COMSAT GENERAL AWARDED A CONTRACT BY ARABSAT
description: Arabsat, an organization of 21 Arab League nations planning to operate its own communications satellite network in the early 1980's, has awarded a technical design and services contract worth $16 million to $21 million to the Comsat General Corporation.

title: 76ers 108, Hawks 97
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (UPI)Doug Collins scored all 14 of his points in the first half tonight as the Philadelphia 76ers posted a 10897 triumph over the Atlanta Hawks. The victory was the 76ers 17th straight at home.

title: Family Money
description: THRIFT institutions are being drained of deposits as alert savers in search of higher yields shift their money elsewhere. The lowrisk alternatives are plentiful.

title: Bridge:
description: Very few American players will have the opportunity to compete in the World Bidding Contest organized by the Inteivational Bridge Academy, the only world event played at club level.

title: 2 Ship Concerns Accused on Rebates
