description: WASHINGTON. March 8 (AP)Two shipping companies have been indicted by a grand jury in Cleveland on chvrpes that they paid kickbacks to an official of an import company in return for its exclusive use of the companies ships.

title: Democrat to Replace U.S. Attorney
description: David G. Trager, United States Attorney for the rostem District of New, YorkBrookly, Queens,, Staten Island and Long Island  will be replaced by a Democrat when his term expires in May.

title: Events Today
description: RUNAWAYS, conceived by Liz Swados; at the MartInson Hall/Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, produced by Joseph Papo, 8.

title: Court Indefinitely Stays an Order To Blockade Radicals House
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 8 (UPI)  The State Supreme Court late today stayed indefinitely an order that would have allowed the city to set up a blockade aimed at cutting off food and other supplies to the barricaded headquarters of the radical backtonature group Move.

title: Severe Cold Blunted the Expansion Of Consumers Credit in January
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (UPI) Americans expanded their use of credit by a modest $2.42 billion in January as severe winter weather in some sections of the country apparently forced consumers to postpone planned purhases, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Jazz: Art Ensemble
description: NEW YORK's newest jazz club is a glorious contradiction to the stereotype of the smoky, lowceilinged rooms in which jazz is theoretically supposed to be played. It is the Cabaret on the third floor of the Public Theater building at 425 Lafayette Streeta room that seats 200 at long, narrow tables under high, curved skylight ceiling that gives it an air of great openness and spaciousness.

title: Books of The Times
description: PHYLLIS CHESLER, the author of Women and Madness and professor of psychology at the City University of New York, has written a brave, sad, disorderly, sometimes selfindulgent, often infuriating, always provocative hook. The disorderliness and the selfindulgence are its biggest problems. It lacks the coherence and control of, say, Susan Brownmiller's Against Our Will. flails and keens. It seems somehow hasty, or slapped arbitrarily together, variously composed of grim reminiscence, literary snippets, newspaper clippings, interviews with men, art reproductions with critical captions, and prose meditations tortured almost but not quite to the point of poetry. I'm reminded, unfortunately and inappropriately, of Norman Mailer when the vapors take him.

title: Nets 123, Kings 121
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 8 (UPI) John Williamson and Bernard King combined for 68 points tonight to lift New Jersey to a 123121 victory over the Kansas City Kings and snap the Nets 15game road losing streak.

title: U.S. to Bolster Davis Cup Efforts
description: A plan for reorganizing America's Davis Cup program will be initiated soon by the United States Tennis Association regardless of the outcome of next weekend's. controversial match with South Africa.

title: Future Peril a Key Factor in TaftHartley Actions
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Although most Americans outside the areas immediately affected by the coal shortage could see no signs of crisis, President Carter invoked the national emergency nrovisions of the TaftHartley Act this. week to order striking miners back to work. While News announcing that he would Analysis ask for an injunction to reopen the coal mines, the

title: In Interview Egyptian Urges U.S. to Become a Partner in Talks
description: CAIRO, March 8Appearing anxious about next week's meeting in Washington between President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that he thought the time has come for President Carter to state his terms for breaking the diplomatic stalemate in the Middle East.

title: Soviet Grants France Airbus Landing Right
description: PARIS, March 8Soviet authorities following negotiations opened in 1975 have granted landing rights in Moscow to the FrenchGerman Airbus passenger transport plane.

title: Borg Wins, 64, 16, 63, From Gerulaitis in Final
description: GOTHENBURG, Sweden, March (UPI)Bjorn Borg defeated Vitas Gerulaitis today, 64, 16, 63, and captured the $33,000 first prize in the twoday, fourman $60,000 Scandinavian Cup.

title: Miller Takes Helm at Fed
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)G. William Miller, industrialist, was installed today as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board. and Arthur F. Burns, outgoing chairman, received a standing ovation at the White House ceremony.

title: New Jersey Leads in Race For Offshore Oil Benefits
description: TRENTONNew Jersey, after losing out to Rhode Island for most of the initial onshore economic benefits from offshore drilling for oil and gas, has become the favorite in the competition to capture the longterm benefits of a major oil strike offshore.

title: Weak Dollar Abroad Lifts Prices Of Imports Stirring U.S. Inflation
description: The American consumer is beginning to pay the price of the falling dollar abroad.

title: SENATORS PRESENT NATURAL GAS PLAN TO HOUSE. LEADERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Senate energy conferees today presented their newlyreached tentative agreement on natural gas pricing to House leaders who said it would take them several days to evaluate it.

title: Money
description: Prime rate: 8.

title: NORMAN EASTON BORDEN JR.
description: Norman Easton Borden Jr., a career officer in the Air Force, an aeronautical engineer with the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Corporation and an author, died Feb. 27 in St. Petersburg, Fla., after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: ExAide Says Rep. Flood Expected $50,000 Kickback
description: LOS ANGELES, March 3When Representative Daniel J. Flood pushed through a $14.5 million appropriation for Philadelphia's Hahnemann Hospital in 1975, he expected to receive $50,000 payment from Representative Joshua Eilberg's law firm, according to Mr. Flood's former Congressional assistant.

title: GARDENING
description: THIS is the kynd of winter that has most people looking forward to a summer visit to the seashore. The same can't be said for plants, however. Many of the regulars used in landscaping at home simply do not like the salt mist that inundates seashore locations, even they adapt themselves to the sandy soil, which in itself poses problems. But if you want a seashore gardenand with the past months storms much replanting will be needed all along the Eastern'Seaboardthere area number of plants that take to this kind of life.

title: Loew's Valencia in Queens From Movie House to House of God
description: The old rugged cross is the main. attraction these days at the old Loew's Valencia theater, which in its heydaywas the most lavish movie house in Queens, one that immersed the visitor in a wondrous gilded world as soon as he walked from beneath the drab Jamaica Avenue elevated and past the box office:

title: Penney Net Jumps 48.9% in Quarter
description: Reflecting the best sales gain for a comparable period in more than 30 years, the J. C. Penney Company Inc. reported yesterday a 48.9 percent jump in net income for the fourth quarter of 1977 and a 29.4 percent gain for the year.

title: Bucks Defeat Knicks In 2d Overtime, 12712 5
description: MILWAUKEE, March 8The fans here might have felt cheated tonight. The Knicks and the Milwaukee Bucks played only two overtime periods before the Bucks won. 127125.

title: Soviet Jewish Dissidents Believe K. G.B. Duped C.I.A. With Agent
description: MOSCOW, March 8Jewish dissidents voiced the belief today that the Central Intelligence Agency had been tricked by the Soviet security police, the K.G..B, into enlisting a doctor who was close to Anatoly Shcharansky, the Jewish activist. They said the effort was made so that the doctor could then use his credentials as an American agent to accuse Mr. Shcharansky and others in the human rights movement of espionage.

title: March of Dimes Ending Role on Birth Defects
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)The March of Dimes is phasing out its support or programs that can diagnose major birth defects amid pressure from antiabortion groups that say parents have no right to decide whether a deformed child should be born.

title: Deaths
description: POSNERRenee (nee Bruckenthal). beloved wife of James. mother of Jennifer & David, sister of Mar. Rudy. She died March A, 1978. She was strong in heart & a brave woman. Funeral services Friday, March 10, 1:30PM, Schwartz Brothers Funeral Home, Queens Blvd & 76th Rd, Forest Hills. @QUELERNatalie(Samdperil), March 7, 1978. Residence 36 Stadium.

title: New Yorker Has Debut On Cosmos
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 8 The Cosmos added a native New Yorker to their international cast today by signing Ron Atanasio, their No. 1 draft choice.

title: A lion Says Begin Stand on U.N.'s Resolution Perils Peace Effort
description: JERUSALEM, March 8Yigal Allon, the former Foreign Minister, charged today that. Prime Minister Menachem Begin's controversial interpretation of a United Nations resolution calling for Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab lands was impeding peace negotiations and damaging. Israel's credibility.

title: Discotheque Burns in Jersey
description: OLD BRIDGE, N.J., March 8 (UPI)Your Suzy's Place, a discotheque near here on Route 35, was destroyed by fire today. Firemen said the blaze broke out in the basement at 4 A.M., shortly after the discotheque closed, The fire raged through the twostory building for two hours before firemen brought it under control.

title: Carter Economies Turn Elliot Richardson to Art
description: WASHINGTON, March 8If Elliot L. Richardson ever decides that he does not like his portrait that was unveiled today at the Department of Commerce, he has only himself to blame. He painted it..

title: Business Records
description: Wednesday, March 8, 1978

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Corporation Affairs Asarco, Duval Bring Copper Price in Line
description: Less than a week after they reduced the price of copper to 60 cents a pound, undercutting competitors, Asarco Inc. and the Duval Corporation yesterday raised their prices by 1.5 cents, putting them in line with the rest of the industry.

title: Minor Quake Jolts Anaheim Area
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 8 (UPI)minor earthquake jolted the Anaheim area at 6:49 A.M. today, prompting about 20 telephone calls to the police department but causing no apparent damage. The quake registered 3.2 on the Richter scale and was centered seven miles east of Anaheim.

title: Q&A
description: Qour house was built 20  years ago, the basement walls were coated around the outside with a waterproofing substance. Now, when we have a heavy rain, some water seeps through the concrete in several places. Is there any preparation I can apply to the inside of these walls to prevent this seepage?S.F.B., Stony Brook, L. I.

title: Tension Between Jctscalevich and Hospital Recalled
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 8  Growing tension between osteopathic doctors who ran Riverdell Hospital and Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a medical doctor who accused of murdering five patients there, was described today at Dr. Jascalevich's trial in Bergen County Superior Court.

title: From One Energy Hurdle to Another
description: Just before Christmas, the Carter Administration's energy plan disappeared under a Congressional snowdrift. Senate conferees were locked in seemingly endless stalemate over natural gas prices. Now, suddenly, the freeze seems to have lifted. The Senators have achieved a compromise solution. It is fragile, vulnerable to, among other things, new demands from tne House conferees. But if the compromise holds, it would represent an important step toward an effective national energy policy.

title: Republican Suggests U.S. Help New York City for Only Year or. Two
description: WASHINGTON, March8  The ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee suggested today that Federal, financing assistance to New York City might be limited to a oneor twoyear extension of the seasonal loan program, which expires June 30.

title: Murdoch's 3 Goals Help Rangers Defeat Barons
description: His name is Don Murdoch, but he was JohnnyontheSpot last night in Madison Square Garden as. the New York Rangers trounced the Cleveland Barons, 61, in a National Hockey League contest.

title: New Rail Project Dramatizes Soviet Power
description: BAIKAL TUNNEL, U.S.S.R.Beneath the remote, forested mountains of Siberia, small teams of tunnelers work in dim light against a gray face of granite.

title: Man Who Held Up 2 Garages Shot to Death by Police Officer
description: A man who allegedly held up two East Side underground garages, stealing a car from each of them, was shot and killed by a police officer on foot patrol last night at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue, the police said.

title: Charles J. Allen, 73, Retired As Executive of. Sinclair Oil Corp.
description: Charles J. Allen, a retired Sinclair Oil Corporation executive, died Tuesday ??? Pascack Valley Hospital, Westwood, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Television
description: 6:00(4)Parspective in Education

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city's Transit Authority said yesterday that it planned to purchase 500 standard urban buses, 100 minibuses, 10 doubledeck buses and 40 articulated buses. The purchase would be the first time the city added mini and articulated buses to its fleet.

title: STABILITY IN DOLLAR AIDS CREDIT MARKET
description: Prices continued to inch higher in the credit markets yesterday, encouraged by the dollar's greater stability in foreignexchange dealings this week.

title: Music: Stoltzman Plays With Beaux Arts Trio
description: PERHAPS not wanting to overdo a cliche, Richard Stolzman and friends began a series of three concerts at the 92d Street Y.N1.y.W.H.A. Tuesday night without designating it as such. The program was listed merely as being by the clarinetist and the Beaux Arts Trio. On april 3 his colleagues will be the Amadeus String Quartet, and on May 9 he will be joined by the pianist Peter Serkin.

title: aldheim Chooses. Ghanaian Diplomat For No. 2 U.N. Job
description: UNITED NATIONS;.. March 8Secretary General Kurt Waldheim has chosen a Ghanaian diplomat for the secondranking United Nations post of Director General for Economic Develoment.

title: POLICE MUST CUT OUT UP T0 1,000 POSITIONS IN NEXT FISCAL YEAR
description: The Koch administration has told the Police Department it, will have to lose up to 1,000 police positions through attrition in the fiscal year that starts July 1 as part of the overall effort to close a $174 million city budget gap.

title: Sound
description: AT a recent conference on new developments in recording tape, a physicist in charge of formulating the mix of magnetic particles for a leading manufacturer was fondly introduced as our brewmaster. Considering how things have been going lately in the tape industry, this title seems altogether fitting. Just as competing brands of beer are basically similar but slightly different, so different tapes have slightly variant sonic flavors. One might sound more brilliant while. another has greater sonic warmthdifferences that might well be compared to the fine distinctions between, say, Lowenbrau and Heineken. Yet such divergences, perhaps just because of their subtlety, seem to inspire fierce partisanship and fervent loyalty among tape fans as well as beer drinkers.

title: Backgammon:
description: Every game of backgammon ultimately becomes a race. In a pure racing game, in which no contact is possible between the opposing sides, high numbers. are, of course, favorable. However, the outcome of many games is determined by which player most effectively blocks his opponent and prevents hint from racing. In such cases, high numbers may be quite disadvantageous.

title: Jewish Leaders Seeking 50,000 in Skokie Protest
description: CHICAGO, March 8, (Reuters)Jewish leaders today pledged a big demonstration to confront an American Nazi march through Skokie, a predominantly Jewish suburb of Chicago that is home to many survivors of Hitler's death camps.

title: 2 Gangs Slug It Out In a Crowded Lobby At Court in Brooklyn
description: Flashing knives and swinging chains and lead pipes, members of two rival Brooklyn gangs  the Unknown Bikers and the Dirty Ones  had a brief but savage rumble early yesterday afternoon in the crowded lobby of the Brooklyn Criminal Court Building, at 120 Schermerhorn Street.

title: WEST VIRGINIA AREAS MADE TO CUT POWER
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 8Businesses in the industrial northern areas of West Virginia and the less industrialized eastern section began turning down lights and thermostats and trimming work schedules today to comply with the state's newly imposed emergency energy plan.

title: HENRY WRISTON DIES, BROWN HEAD, 193755
description: Dr. Henry M. Wriston, president of Brown University from 1937 to 1955 and a principal in the reorganization of the nation's Foreign Service in 1954, died yesterday morning at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 88 years old, and lived at 12 Beekman Place in Manhattan and Marstons Mills, Mass.

title: Credit Growth Blunted
description: The Federal Reserve reported that cold weather was a factor in holding the growth of credit to a modest $2,42 billion in January. Page D12.

title: Dance: Lazarus, a Multimedia Event
description: IF A MAN sits at a table and eats a corned beef sandwich, no one watching him necessarily thinks, How strange. Tables, sandwiches and hungry men are all perfectly ordinary. But if that man eating that sandwich might just conceivably be Lazarus returned from the dead, one may think, How very strange. The perfectly ordinary has been transformed by his presence.

title: U.S. and Britain Call Their Rhodesia Plan Yardstick
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The United States and Britain said today that their joint proposal remained the yardstick for a Rhodesian solution and that much about the settlement that was announced by the white Government and three black leaders in Salisbury last week was still unclear.

title: Court Hears Both Sides in a DayCare SitIn in Bronx
description: A Bronx sitin group whose pressure tactics Mayor Koch had decried contended in State Supreme Court in the Bronx yesterday that its daycare program was supported by 80 percent, not more, of the parents of the 160 children enrolled in the program.

title: Gold and Silver Stocks Advance; I.B.M. Gain Helps Dow Rise 4.08
description: Gold and silver issues, reflecting higher prices for precious metals, moved ahead yesterday while the general market also improved in late trading.

title: 3 IN GUATEMALA RACE DISPUTE VOTE COUNT
description: GUATEMALA, March 8  A fierce power struggle has erupted among congervative military and civilian groups here over the results of the presidential elections last Sunday, although most Guatemalans seem surprisingly indifferent about the outcome.

title: EXAIDE CHALLENGES C.IA'S SECRECY SUIT
description: Author of Vietnam Book Says Bid to Bar Speaking About Agency Violates First Amendment.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONEmergency legislation that would pay grain and cotton farmers to set aside additional land and pump $2.3 billion more into the farm economy was introduced yesterday by the Democratic chairman and the ranking Republican of the Senate Agriculture Committee.

title: TOWER REMOVES HIMSELF FROM THE KOREA INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Senator John G. Tower, a member of the Senate Select Committee on Ethics, has taken himself out of the committee's Korean investigation because he has come under scrutiny, a spokesman,for the committee chairman said today.

title: Bratigi
description: HAMMETTHanl (nee Weiss) of 121 West End Avenue, Summit, NJ., on March 3, 1978. Survived by Jay Rutter Gross and daughters Stephanie Rosenbaum and Amy Crownover. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the research fund of the American Cancer Society.

title: 2 Harvard Professors Win Bancroft Prizes
description: The Bancroft Prizes, given annually for books of exceptional merit and distinction in American history and diplomacy have been awarded to two Harvard professors.

title: Carter Hawley Hale In. Tentative Accord To Buy Wanamaker
description: Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, which withdrew Feb. 23 from a bitterlyopposed effort to take over Marshall Field Company, announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement in principle to acquire the 15store John. Wanamaker chain. The transaction, totaling about $45 million, involves an exchange of stock and $12.6 million in cash.

title: Bucks Defeat Knicks
description: The Bucks heat the New York Knicks after two overtime periods at Milwaukee last night, 127125. The score was tied at 106106 after regulation time and at 116116. after the first. overtime. Page D18.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH STATISTICS indicate that more than 9 percent of all home fires are detected by occupants while the fire is still in its earliest stages, the vast majority of homes and apartments still do not contain even one portable fire extinguisher. An ex',inguisher of good quality, close at hand, can save property and prevent disaster.

title: FAREIGH INCREASES TUITION RATES AGAIN
description: RUTHERFORD, March 8The trustees of Fairleigh Dickinson University today raised the university's tuition and room and board for the fifth consecutive year, amid sign of student opposition to the increased costs.

title: Neutron Bomb Opposed By Dutch Parliament
description: THE HAGUE, March 8 (AP)The Dutch Parliament adopted a resolution today opposing production of the neutron bomb and calling on the Government to notify the United States and other allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization of its action.

title: Anker to Suspend School Board Without Ethnic Data
description: The New York City School Chancellor, Irving Anker, said last night that he would suspend Community School Board 26 in Queens tomorrow if the board continued to refuse to submit an ethnic breakdown of its students and faculty members.

title: SENATOR HITS LABELING OF STUDENT AS TERRORIST
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Senator James Abourezk, Democrat of South Dakota, demanded at today's meeting of the Senate Judiciary Committee to know why the Federal Bureau of Investigation had relayed information to the authorities in Israel that an American graduate student had trained as a terrorist.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: The New York Times/Neal Boenzl, Gary Settle

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Scientist to Study Mainmoth Sample For Clues to Life
description: A tiny specimen of frozen mammoth flesh, flown here yesterday from Moscow, will be tested to determine whether its proteins and nucleic acids are intact.

title: Deaths
description: CASSIDYCatherine D. Of South Nyack, NY, on Tues., Mar 7. Sister of the late Msgr. William A. Cassidy. Sisterinlaw of Mrs. Joseph X. Cassidy, of Piermont, three nieces Mrs Frances Daly of Tappan, Mrs. Betty Sedlack of Piermont and Mrs. Anne diFrancesca of Piermont. Mass of Christian Burial at St Johns Church. Piermont NY, Fri, March 10, at 11 am. Interment Rockland Cemetery, Sparkill, NY. Friends may call at the Stevenson Funeral Home, 790 Piermont Ave, Piermont. NY from 2.4, 79pm.

title: Prudential Rebuts Charge by State That Some of Its Rates Are High
description: TRENTON, March 8The Prudential Insurance Company of America took issue yesterday with charges by the state's Commissioner of Insurance that it charged excessive rates for health and accident insurance.

title: Doctors Vote to End Hunterdon Plan Restrictions
description: FLEMINGTON, March 8Physicians voteed overwhelmingly here today to end a 25yearold healthcare system that sought to eliminate competition among them and to cut medical costs by prevering specialists from maintaining private practices in Hunterdon County.

title: Consultative Body Ends Peking Session
description: HONG KONG, March 8 (UPI)The Chinese People's Political and Consultative Conference ended the first session of its fifth national committee meeting today by naming Teng Hsaioping, China's First Deputy Prime Minister as its chairman.

title: Author in Controversy on Cloning Asserts That He's Seen Lab Child
description: The author who says that he helped arrange the first cloning of a human being insisted yesterday, in his most extensive comments on the matter to date, that the reproduction was really accomplished. But he still offered no corroborative evidence to sunnort the assertion.

title: Notes on People
description: FOR the first time, a United States Chief of Naval Operations will visit Egypt and Israel. A Navy spokesman said in Washington yesterday that Adm. James L. Holloway would spend March 2528 in Egypt and the next three days in Israel. When the admiral's Egyptian and Israeli counterparts recently visited this country, the Navy spokesman said, the admiral accepted their invitations to visit their countries and discuss matters of mutual interest. He added that it would be a mistake to read any special significance into the trip.

title: ARTHUR BATCHELLER
description: Arthur Batcheller, chief engineer in charge of the Federal Communications Commission's Northeast district, died Tuesday night in Framingham, Mass., his retirement home. He was 90 years old.

title: New Rail Project Dramatizes Soviet Power
description: BAIKAL TUNNEL, U.S.S.R. Beneath the remote, forested mountains of Siberia, small teams of tunnelers work in dim light against a gray face of granite.

title: Going Solarfor $1,000
description: WORD GOT AROUND, largely through an article in the Nantucket Inquirer and Mirror, that we were building a solarheated house, the first on the island as far as anybody knew. For weeks thereafter, my wife and I repeatedly put down levels, hammers, crowbars and try. squares to guide an intermittent parade of curious visitors. After the first handful, however, I sensed unfulfillment, as though something valuable had been lost, but the visitor wasn't quite sure what or even if he were searching for it in the right county. Where are the collector plates? an M.I.T. graduate student asked at one point, and it finally dawned on us that our inspectors, and perhaps most other people as well, harbored Sundaysupplemented expectations that solar heating required a wondrous, Rube Goldberg array of shiny surfaces, pipes, motors God knows what else to extract heat out of the mere stuff that suntans come from.

title: Judge Orders 4 Towns in Jersey To Change Snob Zoning Speedily
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 8 (AP)Judge Mary Ellen Talbott of Superior Court has criticized four Camden County municipalities for snob zoning and ordered them to amend their laws to permit more affordable housing.

title: In Interview Egyptian Urges U.S. to Become a Partner in Talks
description: CAIRO, March 8Appearing anxious about next week's meeting in Washington between President Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt said today that he thought the time has come for President Carter to state his terms for breaking the diplomatic stalemate in the Middle East.

title: Affirmed, Cauthen Up, Scores by 4 Lengths
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 8 (AP) Affirmed, thoroughbred racing's champion 2yearold last year, won his first 1978 outing today by four lengths in $30,000 allowance race at Santa Anita.

title: Callaway Ski Resort Plan Backed by Forest Service
description: CRESTED BUTTE, Colo., March 8 (AP) The United States Forest Service has given tentative approval for the second time to the expansion on public land of a ski resort owned in part by former Army Secretary Howard H. Callaway.

title: Lance Hearing Asked By Financial General
description: WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP)Attorneys for a major bank holding company today asked a Federal court to find Bert Lance, President Carter's former Budget Director, in contempt of court for allegedly walking out on courtordered interrogation.

title: Jersey Doctors Vote to Eliminate Hospital's Private Practice Curb
description: FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 8  Physicians voted overwhelmingly, here today to end a 25yearold healthcare system that sought to eliminate competition among them and to cut medical costs by preventing specialidts from maintaining private practices in Hunterdon County.

title: Document That Omits Rights Is Adopted at Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 8 The Belgrade conference on European security and cooperation wound Up five months of bitter debate today by adopting a summary document that did not mention human rights or other major issues that divide East and West.

description: ANNOUNCEMENTS OF DEATHS MAY BE TELEPHONED TO 354.3900 UNTIL 5:30 P.M. FOR WEEKDAY EDITIONS. UNTIL 2:30 P.M. ON SATURDAY FOR SUNDAY EDITION. IN REGIONAL OFFICES 9.00 A.M. TO 4:30 P.M. (516) 669.1800; CONNECTICUT (203) 348.7767.

title: Head of Deliverers Says a Strike Is Possible at 3 Papers March 30
description: Douglas LaChance, president of the Newspaper Deliverers Union, warned yesterday of the possibility of a strike at midnight March 30 when the current contracts with The Daily News, The New York Post and The New York Times expire.

title: Elrati10
description: WALKERClare Edward, Attorney. Beloved husband of Karin, dear father of Anne, Clare, Jr. and Wanda. Funeral service Friday 2 PM, at Guido Funeral Home, 440 Clinton St. Bklyn. Memorial service Sunday 2 PM at The First Unitarian Church, 50 Monroe Place, Bklyn.

title: Carter Liaison Aide W ith Jews to Quit White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 8Mark A. Siegel, the White House assistant who has served as the Administration's liaison with the American Jewish community, has decided to resign from the Presidential staff because of his disagreements with President Carter's Middle East policy.

title: Scienceand Prudencein Cancer Prevention
description: WASHINGTONThe Carter Administration is now preparing to move aggressively against cancercausing chemicals in the home, the workplace and the general environment. Today cancer is our second leading killer, and a concerted, Governmentwide attack on the substances that cause much of it is essential.

title: Deaths
description: ELEFANTEJean Harris of New Providence, NJ, on Mar 7, 1978, wife of Michael A. Elefante, mother of Michael Barrett, Jeffrey Paul and Carl Elelante, daughter of Gwen Harris. Also survived by 7 grandchildren. Memorial service at St Andrew's Episcopal Church, 419 South St, Murray Hill, NJ, on Friday, March 10, at 12:30pm. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Summit YWCA would be appreciated.

title: JOHN MARSHALL PRICE
description: John Marshall Price, former cable editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died Tuesday night at Nyack Hospital after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter should state his terms for breaking the diplomatic stalemate in the Middle East, President Anwar elSadat said in an interview at his home beside the Nile. The Egyptian leader, appearing apprehensive about next week's meeting in Washington between Mr. Carter and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel, said the time has come for the United States to risk its responsibility as a partner and not a mediator in the negotiations. Mr. Sadatsuggested that Mr. Carter apply his espousal of human rights, nonacquisition of land by force and mutual security. [Page A1, Col. 1.]

title: BuddyBuzzers Aid Aged Living Alone
description: SIXTYSEVEN years old, living alone in a firstfloor apartment in a Bronx neighborhood that she says isn't getting any better, and moving only with the ponderous clumping of a walking aid, Mrs. C. is particularly vulnerable to crime and illness.

title: Secrets of the C.I.A.
description: BOSTON, March 8  As Director of Central Intelligence, William E. Colby put great emphasis on the need to protect intelligence secrets. He helped develop a legal strategy for secrecy, and he repeatedly asked Congress for a law to restrain leakers.

title: NAT BRANDWYNNE
description: Nat Brandwynne of Las Vegas, Nev., a pianist and orchestra leader who conducted or played for many major vocalists, including Frank Sinatra, Perry Como, Kate Smith and Ella Fitzgerald, died there Tuesday in the Desert Springs Hospital of a heart attack. He was 67 years old. His hand played in the WaldorfAstoria's Empire Room for 25 years and for the last 12 years in the Circus Maximus room of Caesars Palace in Las Vegas.

title: U.S. PLANS UPGRADING OF PROJECT IN BRONX
description: A block of South Bronx apartment buildings rehabilitated between 1969 and 1972 at a cost of $4 million, but once more decaying and partly abandoned would be rehabilitated again under a Federal plan to salvage the project, a Government official said yesterday.

title: Lingering Snow Bringing Cheer to Stowe's Skiers
description: STOWE, Vt., March 8 I don't believe it, said Clarence Hayford of Mount Mansfield's ski patrol, setting out today on his weekly inspection of the snow. It's 25 degrees above out. Considering we've had mostly zero weather lately, this is like Indian summer.

title: Film: Six Shorts on Working
description: THE six short films in the Working program at the Film Forum show people with widely varying degrees of selfconsciousness about what they do.

title: Zambia Reports Border Gunfire
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 8 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Siteke Mwale said today that exchanges of fire were continuing across the Zambezi River border with Rhodesia after a major incursion by Rhodesian forces.

title: REGINA WALLACE, ACTRESS FOR STAGE, FILMS AND TV
description: Regina Wallace, an actress whose 50year career took her from the Broadway stage to movies and then into television, died Feb. 13 at the Inglemoor Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J., after a stroke. She was 86 years old and lived at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood.

title: Hanoi Renews Demand That U.S. Provide Aid for Reconstruction
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 8 (Reuters) Vietnam today renewed its demand that the United States provide economic aid for its postwar reconstruction.

title: Advertising
description: Sevenyearold Keenan & McLaughlin has merged with the New York office of the 55yearold Ketchum, MacLeod & Grove, Pittsburgh, to create Keenan McLaughlin Ketchum, with each partner bringing about $20 million in billings to the wedding.

title: Enough Monkeys Likely For Polio Vaccine Testing
description: Federal health officials say they will bd able to obtain enogh rhesus monkeys to conduct this year's polio vaccine testing even if India refuses to lift its export embargo, according to United Press International.

title: Indianians Are Getting Suspicious About Utility Shortage Warnings
description: EVANSVILLE, Ind., March 7To conserve electric energy as a result of the nation's longeSt coal strike, Mayor Russell G. Lloyd has been relying on the sun to light his small office here for several weeks. And in the reception area nearly half the lights are off.

title: TeenAgers Who Don't Mind Housework
description: JILL Singleton, 15 years old, and Gina Gonzalez, 14, were in a quandary last fall about how to earn spending money. Christmas loomed ahead, too, with all those gifts to buy.

title: Two Potato Futures Traders Suspended and Fined in Default
description: PRESQUE ISLE, Me., March 8 (AP)Two major traders in potatoes and contracts for future delivery of potatoes have been given substantial suspensions and fines in connection with a default on the Maine potato futures contract in 1976.

title: GOLD PRICE SURGES NEARLY $4 TO $190 IN BULLION CENTERS
description: PARIS, March 8The price of gold leaped nearly $. an ounce in active trading on European markets today, reaching $190 an ounce at the afternoon fixing in London and Zurich, compared with $186.25 an ounce at yesterday's final. Lon. don fixing.

title: Power in San Diego Out for 4 Hours After Plant Blast
description: SAN DIEGO, March 8 (AP)An explosion at a power plant left a wide area of San Diego County without power for four and a half hours today, trapping dozens of persons in stalled elevators and slowing evening rush hour traffic.

title: Assembly Votes Bill for Transfer Of Realty Development Rights
description: ALBANY, March 8  The Assembly passed and sent to the Senate today bill making it easier for local governments to use a new concept in landuse management designed, to encourage the preservation of historic, agricultural or environmentallyvaluable areas.

title: BACKTOWORK ORDER TO MINERS DUE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The United Mine Workers today bitterly denounced the Carter Administration's resort to the TaftHartley Act's compulsory backtowork, procedure, and spokesmen for the coal Industry regretted it. But a Federal courtinjunction commanding the 160,000 striking miners to return to the pits nonetheless became more a certainty, perhaps by tomorrow afternotin.

title: Soybean Futures Climb in Price
description: Suspicions of severe drought damage to Brazil's soybean crop spurred another flurry of buying yesterday that sharply increased futures prices in the soybean and soybean product pits.

title: Defiant Rhodesian Guerrilla Leader
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 8In the aftermath of the agreement in Salisbury last week providing for majority rule, the key to Rhodesia's future peace or warrests with Joshua Nkomo more than with any other figMan in the News ure. For Mr. Nkomo, who is credited with having founded the black nationalist movement and with having dominated it for much of the last 25 years, the role is a familiar one.

title: Allon Says Begin Stand on U.N.'s Resolution Perils Peace Effort
description: JERUSALEM, March 8Yigal Alton, the former Foreign Minister, charged today that Prime Minister Menachem Begin's controversial interpretation of United Nations resolution calling for Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab lands was impeding peace negotiations and damaging Israel's credibility.

title: Concern Ends Work On Parking Meters In Dispute Over Pay
description: A Queens concern that repairs parking meters under a twoyear $8 million city contract, laid off its 100 employees yesterday and shut its doors, contending that the city had refused to pay for services rendered.

title: Wealthy Businessman Kidnapped in Belgium
description: ANTWERP, Belgium, March 8 (UPI) The police reported today the kidnapping of Baron Charles Bracht, a 63yearold diplomat and wealthy businessman with worldwide financial interests, but officials said they had yet to hear from his captors.

title: Market Place

description: THE COSY event that is known in Germany as a liederabendan evening of songsis not easy to come by nowadays. More often than would be permitted in an ideal world, !leder recitals are now given in halls of outlandish size by singers whose reputations have been made in the opera house, for audiences that know and admire their work there.

title: I.R.S. May Toughen Stance On Rules for Bearer Bonds
description: Bank certificates of deposit, known as bearer bonds, are rapidly gaining popularity among small investorswho apparently were quick to recognize the certificates potential for tax evasionbut their heyday may already be drawing to a close.

title: Miss Rodnina Ties World Skate Mark
description: OTTAWA; March 8Linda Fratianne faces an uphill struggle to retain her crown, but Irina Rodnina wrote her name into the record _books tonight during the world figure skating chamnimishins. title: Ford High Five Advances In C.H.S.A.A. Tourney
description: Bishop Ford High School gave a basketball shooting display last night that Tolentine will not soon forget. The Brooklyn school won its Catholic High Schools Athletic Association quarterfinal playoff game, 7057, shooting 67 percent on its field goals and 85 percent from the freethrow line.

title: Bicycling To Wisdom
description: ONE OF THE first life decisions I ever made, at an age when admittedly causal connections between life and decisions were pretty foggy in my mind, was to switch my college major from English to philosophy. Philosophy! yelled my father over the telephone. What kind of a job are you going to be able to get with a philosophy major?

title: Tito W ants Red Aid For Ethiopia to End if Peace Is Reached
description: WASHINGTON, March 8President Tito said today that Soviet and Cuban military units should be withdrawn from Ethiopia as soon as a peace settlement between Ethiopia and Somalia was reached.

title: Police Free Susvect in Flynt Shooting
description: NORFOLK Va., March 8 (UPI)A young man arrested as a suspect in the shooting of Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, in Georgia on Monday was in Virginia at the time of the shooting and has been released from custody, a police official said today.

title: OPEC Talks Planned On Decline of Dollar
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, March 8 (AP)The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will hold an informal meeting in Geneva April 3, the official Iraq news agency reported today.

title: New Bond Issues
description: *New on List. Source: First Boston Coro.

title: Cultist Seized in Killing Of Utah Polygamy Leader
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 8 (UPI) -Policemen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation today arrested another religious cultist charged in the assassination last May of a Utah polygamist leader.

title: Penthouse Acquires Site for Casino On the Boardwalk Near Playboy's
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 8Penthouse Ineelciational acquired a multimilliondollar gambling casino site on the Boardwalk today a block from a casino site !planned by its publishing rival, Playboy Enterprises.

title: Order on Disclosing Of Finances Upheld By Top Jersey Court
description: TRENTON, March 8  The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld Governor Byrne's right to require hundreds of highranking state officials to disclose their personal finances.

title: POLICE MUST CUT OUT UP TO 1,000 POSITIONS IN NEXT FISCAL YEAR
description: The Koch administration has told the Police Department it will have to lose up to 1,000 police positions through attrition in the fiscal year that starts July 1 as part of the overall effort to close a $174 million city budget gap.

title: Nebraska 67, Utah State 66
description: LINCOLN, Neb., March 8 (UPI)Andre Smith, a freshman, came off the bench tonight and scored 18 points, including two crucial free throws with 42 seconas left, to lead Nebraska to a 6766 victory over Utah State.

title: NEW RATES TO EUROPE REQUESTED BY BRANIFF
description: Braniff Airways, whose new service between London and Dallas has been postponed by a fare dispute with the British Government, asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday for emergency authority to provide nonstop service from Dallas to Paris, Frankfurt, Amsterdam and Madrid.

title: Rockefeller, Out of Politics, Focuses on Art and His Family
description: On a clear day, from his unpreten tious office on the 56th floor. of Rockefeller Center's tallest building, Nelson A. Rockefeller can see his life with considerable detachment. There, in a philosophical mood on a recent afternoon, the former Vice President sipped a cup of tea, ate an Oreo cookie, reflected about his current activities and laced his conversation with intimations of mortality.

title: Loew's Valencia in Queens. Goes From Movie House to House of God
description: The old rugged cross is the main attraction these days at the old Loew's Valencia theater, which in its heydaywas the most lavish movie house in Queens, one that immersed the visitor in a wondrous gilded world as soon as he walked from beneath the drab Jamaica Avenue elevated and past the box office.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Opening day of the trout fishing season in states throughout the Northeast will fall sometime in April, and with that anglers should Lle looking now to their equipment.

title: Georgetown Ousts Virginia in N.I.T.
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., March UPI)Mike Riley and Craig Shelton sank two foul shots each in the final 35 seconds of overtime tonight to lead Georgetown to a 7068 victory over Virginia in the first round of the National Inivitation Tournament.

title: Weak Dollar Abroad Lifts Prices Of Imports, Stirring U.S. Inflation
description: The American consumer is beginning to pay the price of the falling dollar abroad.

title: New Rochelle Civilian Aides Free Police to Tackle Serious Crimes
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.Phil Banks threaded his metallicblue emergency through the narrow streets of a residential secion of New Rochelle while he waited and listened for those calls that are the bane of a policeman's daily duties a barking dog, a fallen tree or a blockd driveway.

title: Row Levin Set Deathtrap
description: WHEN the curtain in Ira Levin's mind went up on Deathtrap a halfdozen years ago, he thought of the comedythriller story as a book but somehow it wouldn't sit still between covers and kept making itself into play.

title: Radio
description: 6.9 A.M., WKCR. War Requiem; Cello Symphony, Britten.

title: Sports Today
description: Rutgers vs. Army, National Invitation Tournament, at Rutgers gymnasium, Piscataway, N..T., 7:30 P.M. (RadioWRSU, 7:25 P.M.)

title: Design Notebook
description: WE ARE accustomed to thinking of the historic preservation business as something of a lost cause in New York. Penn Station is gone, the Savoy Plaza is gone, nothing remains of midtown Park Avenue save for the Waldorf, and so on. To hear, a New Yorker say that nothing is left of the city he knew a decade ago is so common by now as to provoke no response except a nod and a sigh.

title: Weizman Meets Brown on Arms
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman of Israel met with Defense Secretary Harold Brown today and discussed at length Israel's request for about $15 billion in American military equipment over the next decade.

title: Jersey High Court Upholds Order For Officials to Disclose Finances
description: TRENTON, March 8The New Jersey Supreme Court today upheld Governor Byrne's right to require hundreds of highranking state officials to disclose their personal finances.

title: Career News Parley On at 3 P.M. Today
description: The three television networks and their local stations, Channels 2, 4 and 7, have scheduled live telecasts at P.M. today of President Carter's news conference. Radio stations WCBSAM, WINS and WMCA will broadcast the news conference.

title: Letters
description: To THE HOME SECTION:

title: Raw North Makes Some Wives Pine for Moscow
description: GOUDZHEKIT, U.S.S.R.  Tanya Yakimenko and Lidiya Bessolov have left their small children with their mothers and followed their husbands to Siberia, where they have been struggling with their new roles as modern pioneers.

title: Politics in Peking: A Great Leap Backward to the 1950's
description: HONG KONG, March 8An old Chinese adage holds that in a wellordered state, The minister runs the government, the emperor performs the ceremonies. Unless most analysts. of Chinese affairs are fundamentally mistaken, something like this seems to be happening in Peking now.

title: JAPANESE CAR CURB ROILS BRITISH GROUP
description: LONDON, March 8 Distributors of Japanese cars responded angrily here Joday to an agreement limiting imports or Datsuns and other makes to Britain for one year, the first such agreement involving the. Japanese Government in the growing dispute over the British market.

title: Tension Between Jascalevich and Hospital Recalled
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., March 8Growing tension between osteopathic doctors who ran Riverdell Hospital and Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a medical doctor who is accused of murdering five patients there, was described today at Dr. Jascalevich's trial in Bergen County Superior Court.

title: Rockefeller, Out of Politics, Focuses on Art and His Family
description: On a clear day, from his unpretentious office on the 56th floor of Rockefeller Center's tallest building, Nelson A. Rockefeller can see his life with considerable detachment. There, in a philosophical mood on a recent afternoon, the former Vice President sipped a cup of tea, ate an Oreo cookie, reflected about his current activities and laced his conversation with intimations of mortality.

title: Yanks to Put Holtzman in Showcase
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 8 Hey, man, Sparky Lyle said to Ken Holtzman in the Yankee clubhouse today, congratulations.

title: Copters Fly Aid to Tribe Isolated by Snow and Mud
description: BLACK MESA, Ariz., March 7The helicopter's first stop was the Badone'0;family's camp, where a diabetic urgently needed insulin. Moments later bewildered horses and dogs fled the thunder and wind of the Chinook as it dropped out of the sky to deposit sacks of food beside a sodroofed hogan that has been a home to the Yuazzio family of Navajo Indians for more than a century.

title: BACKTOWORK ORDER TO MINERS DUE TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, March 8The United Mine Workers today bitterly denounced the Carter Administration's resort to the TaftHartley Act's compulsory backtowork procedure, and spokesmen for the coal industry regretted it. But a Federal court injunction commanding the 160,000 striking miners to return to the pits nonetheless became more a certainty, perhaps by tomorrow afternoon.

title: Savitt Won't Disclose Data on Its Billings
description: Advertising Age, the weekly trade paper, once a year used to rank advertising agencies according to their billingsthat is the amount of advertising money moving through. Much of the information came from the agencies themselves.

title: Leonard Silk Coal Strike: How Big a Blow to Economy?
description: The economic impact of the strike of the United Mine Workers, which has cut the national rate of coal production roughly in half, is coming in stages. The first stage, during which electric utilities and other coal users. The Economic Scene could live off stocks, with slight effect on jobs and production, has lasted longer than was originally expected. Three weeks ago, the sixstate region of the most coaldependent statesMichigan, Indiana, Ohio, Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Kentuckywas estimated by Data Resources Inc., the nation's largest private forecasting firm, to be down to a 35day supply. Within the succeeding 30 days, Data Resources said, it expected 750,000 jobs and $2 billion of output to be lost.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: U.S. DollarStabilization Sales Of Foreign Currencies at Record
description: The United States sold a record $1.5 billion in foreign currencies, mostly West German marks, in the three months through January in an attempt to stabilize the severely sliding market for dollars, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

title: Stage: Soviet Promise
description: ALEKSEI. ARBUZOV'S The Promise, which the Roundabout is reviving on its Stage Two theater, is set in Leningrad during the great siege of World War II and in the years thereafter. References to the siege and the great suffering that derived from it abound: Mention is made of corpses, bombings, ration cards, of furniture broken for firewood, and there, are such apostrophes'es How many thousands died that we may live. These references to a world in upheaval are obviously designed to add dimensions to a domestic drama of much smaller scale being acted in a tiny room, in the heart of the beleaguered city.

title: Dividends
description: PeHod Pate Stk. of nayrecord able

title: The TV Squeeze on Leon Spinks
description: GILMAN HOT SPRINGS, Calif., March 8On the. roadside marquee at the Massacre Canyon Inn, red letters announce, Welcome Ken Norton The Champ. Ken Norton not the world heavyweight champion; he is merely the No. contender. But on dignity, he deserves the championship. now. In the confusion, if not corruption, that surrounds Leon Spinks's first defense of the title he detached from Muhammad All three weeks ago, Ken Norton is the only boxer behaving like a champion. Leon Spinks has turned into a pawn for Bob Arum, the devious Top Rank promoter, and the CBS network. Muhammad All has turned into a panhandler for a rematch, the first multimilliondollar panhandler in captivity, but a panhandler nevertheless. Muhammad All likes to boast that, I'm bigger than boxing, but he's getting smaller and smaller. The more Muhammad Ali whines about a rematch and the more Bob Arum snarls about Leon Spinks's alleged rib injury, the more Ken Norton will emerge as the new champion of the people, at least the people who believe a boxer's signed agreement should be as nonnegotiable as the rule that a round last three minutes. And the people in the Congress and the Justice Department should consider investigating what is happening in boxing now, notably how Leon Spinks is being squeezed by two corporate boa constrictors, Top Rank and CBS.

title: California County Votes, 2 to 1, to Bar Nuclear. Plant
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8 Residents of southern California's rural Kern County, in an advisory referendum, voted by margin of more than 2 to 1 yesterday against construction In the county of what might have been the world's largest nuclear power plant.

title: Unmistakable Zandra
description: LONDON. ZANDRA RHODES'S home is unmistakable. In the center of a decaying block of identical white town houses it casts a peachy glow on its decrepit neighbors. The surrounding wroughtiron fence is baby blue with gilt gingerbread. Zandra Rhodes is aso unmistakable. Her current hairdo is red, green and black. Her current makeup includes a long, thick black line stretching from the outer edge of her right. (obiterated) eyebrow to the midpoint of the left, followed by two shorter lines. Above, a black square. Her fingernails are red with lavender tips.

title: Rock: Return of NRBQ
description: BACK in the late 1960's, when rock was dominated by ipsychedelia and English blues clicMs, a Pew stubborn souls insisted that the only music worth listening to was 1950's rock-and-roll and contemporary avantgarde jazz. They were night, for though almost nobody can listen seriously to period psychedekia or English blues excesses anymore, Fats Domino and Ornette Coleman have stood the test of time.

title: KOCH OFFERS APOLOGY ON QUEENS REMARKS
description: In the latest flareup over Mayor Koch's walkout at a Queens civic meeting, the Mayor apologized yesterday for comparing the civic meeting to a Stalin trial of Jewish doctors.

title: Trial of Baader-Meinhof Lawyer Delayed Over Security Checks
description: STUTTGART, West Germany, March 9 (Reuters)The trial of Klaus Croissant, former attorney for leaders of the BaaderMeinhof urban guerrilla group, adjourned after a brief opening session today when defense lawyers refused to submit to security checks.

title: EDWARD S. WALLY
description: Dr. Edward S. Wally, clinical assistant professor at the New York University School of Medicine, died Wednesday the university's Medical Center Hospital. Dr. Wally was 68 years old and lived at 20 East Ninth Street.

title: E.P.A. PERMITS PESTICIDE FOR FIGHT ON FIRE ANTS
description: , WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The Environmental Protection Agency will permit the controversial pesticide ferriamicide to be used in the South to kill fire ants.

title: Citizens Group Opposes Koch Plan to Let Big Apple Circus Use a Park All Summer
description: A dispute reminiscent of the early days of John V. Lindsay's mayoralty, when public events were staged in grassy areas of New York City parks that had not previously been used so vigorously, has cropped up in the Koch administration.

title: Notes on People
description: Carterpuri, the village in India that changed its name in honor of President Carter after he visited it briefly on Jan. 3, yesterday welcomed Robert P. Goheen, the Ambassador to India, who pe'rsonally delivered a thankyou note from the President. Mr. Goheen, who was born in India, was told tnat mr Carter's visit to Carterpuri, meaning Carter place, had been a great help to the village, formerly called Daulatpur Nasirabad. Many banks have come forward to help the village, said Ma Seem Humid, a magistrate. There have also been offers of help for develop ment projects. In a tour of the village, Mr. Goheen got a chance to skow off some of his Indian vocabulary. Pointing tO a brick-and-mortar chicken coop and a villager's home, he said, The chick ens get a 4pucca house and he gets a kacha house. Pucca means solid and kacha means mudwalled.

title: AMER AND BOARD 26 SEEK TO END DISPUTE
description: Community School Board 26 in Queens plans to meet today with Chancellor Irving Anker in an effort to reach an agreement and head off its suspension because of its continued refusal to submit ethnic data on pupils and faculty members.

title: Soviet, at Geneva Parley Asks Neutron Bomb Ban
description: GENEVA, March 9The Soviet Union submitted to the disarmament conference todayl the draft of a treaty that would nntlaw the neutron bomb.

title: Changes in Model Cities Program More a PhasingOut Than Revision
description: The restructuring of the Model Cities program announced by the administration of Mayor Koch this week signals the beginning of the end in New York City of that remnant of President Lyndon B..Johnson's Great Society program, according to Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo.

title: Dance: Miss Keen Presents New Work
description: WEDNESDAY night's performance by the Elizabeth Keen Dance Company at the Entermedia Theater suggested that Miss Keen is a cheerful eclectic willing to try out anything in a dance. She also likes to mix disparate styles in a single work and stir them up until she has produced a savory choreozranhic stew.

title: Ford Recalls 15,433 Vehicles
description: DETROIT, March 9 (AP)The Ford Motor Company recalled 15,433 cars and trucks today to correct problems with seat belts. The recalls involve 12,000 197278 model L series heavy trucks, 1,800 trucks in Canada and 33 trucks In other countries, and 1,600 Mustang II, Pinto and Bobcat passenger cars in the United States from the current model year. On the recalls involving trucks, Ford stays owners in the United States, Canada and foreign countries should return them to dealerships for inspection and replacement of seatbelt assemblies on the driver's side.

title: Dispute on Releasing Hospital data Interrupts Trial of Dr. Jascalevich
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 9The trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, charged with murdering five patients in Riverdell Hospital in 1965 and 1966, was interrupted unexpectedly today when those now in control of the hospital in Oradell balked at releasing records sought by the defense.

title: Special Rules for GeneSplicing Patents Rejected
description: Inventions arising from Governmentsupported research in genesplicing should be patentable under rules that already apply to such biological inventions as vaccines, the National Institutes of Health has decided after a yearlong study.

title: Events and Openings
description: EL CENSO (THE CENSUS) by Emilio Carballido, and CIEN VECES NO DEBO (One Hundred Times Shouldn't) by Richard Talesnik; directed by Elfore Perattat Presented by Gilberto Za!diver's Spanish Repertory Company; et the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, 8.

title: At the Movies
description: LOOKING more like an enchanted child than the sensuous star of Dona Flor and Her Two Husbands, Sonia Braga gazed out the window of Orsini's and watched last week's snow fall gently into 56th Street.

title: Richard Wheelwright, the Founder Of a FurnitureMaking Company
description: Richard Wheelwright, a manufacturer of reproduction antique furniture, died Sunday at the Fairfield Medical Center in Montego Bay, Jamaica, of a respiratory illness. He was 73 years old and lived in Vero Beach. Fla.

description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From the Court Order
description: WASINGTON, March 9 (AP)Following are excerpts from the temporary restraining order issued today in the coal miners strike by Federal Disrict Judge Aubrey E. Robinson Jr.

title: Will Beat the Yankees?; Sports of The Times; Don' t Break the Furniture; Their Own Worst Enemy
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9Baseball doesn't own any Rhodes scholars at the moment, like football's Pat Haden or basketball's Bill Bradley. But in all those training camps from Miami to Yuma, the best intellects in the business are gathering their brains for one grand exercise: clobbering the New York Yankees.

title: New Fed Chief Sees Expansion At a Calm Pace
description: WASHINGTON, March 9G. William Miller made his Congressional debuttoday as the nation's new monetary chief. He predicted further economic expansion at a moderate pace this year, but he, warned that inflation remains disturb ingly high and that getting it under control requires stronger Federal policies.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
description: Article 1 -- No Title

title: Exchanges Ask S.E.C. to Approve 5Way National Electronic Hookup
description: Five leading securities exchangesin an important step to create an electronic stock marketasked the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday to approve a national electronic hookup to link the five exchanges.

title: AirPiracy Suspects Are Delayed in Cuba
description: Arrangements for the return of six alleged hijackers from Cuba to the United States went awry on an undisclosed technicality last night, but a State Department spokesman said that the problem had been overcome and that the group was rescheduled to fly to New York today to face airpiracy charges.

title: Move Follows Weeks of Diplomacy by U.S. to End the Fighting
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter announced today that Somalia had agreed to withdraw its forces from the Ogaden region of Ethiopia where they have been fighting since last July ostensibly in support of an insurrection by ethnic Somalis.

title: U.S. Court Orders Coal Miners Back to Work for 80Day Period
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Carter Administration today obtained a court order under the TaftHartley Act that is intended to begin an 80day hack-to-work coolingoff period in the nation's coal mines, closed in a strike by the United Mine Workers for 94 days.

title: Women Who Kill Their Spouses: The Causes, the Legal Defenses
description: It Is aphenomenon that has confirmed some men's worst notions about the women's movement and caused the legal profession to take a long look at the definition of selfdefense. The phenomenon is domestic violence, the violence that. ends in a woman killing her mate because he has battered her one time too many. Dozens of such cases have been tried in recent months. More important and, to some, more shocking, is that many of them have ended in dismissals, acquittals or light sentences.

title: ROYAL DUTCHSHELL REPORTS PROFIT OFF
description: The Royal DutchShell Group of cornpanies, second largest international oil company, reported yesterday a 42.6 percent decline in fourthquarter net income, but said it ended 1977 with a gain of 8.84 nerrent

title: Can Spring Be Far Behind?
description: There's nothing like an arrangement of spring flowers to give a lift to the spirits after the long, hard winter. It could be the fragrant bunch of freshcut parrot tulips, delphiniums, spider mums, daffodils, ranunculuses and heather. that subscribers to Dhuanne Tansill's Bouquets Unlimited service received this week. Or it could be Mrs.

title: Opera: Cilea's Adriana
description: CILEA'S Adriana Lecouvreur, an opera that apparently appeals to public if not to critical taste, had its fifth performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera Wednesday night. (There will be five more before the season is out.)

title: TV Trade Voted Again
description: In a 5-to-2 vote, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday approved for the, second time an exchange of television stations between Washington Star Communications and Combined Communications Corporation of Oklahoma City. After first granting approval last January, the commission had decided to reconsider its action after Joe L. Allbritton, owner of The Washington Star and station WJLATV in the capital, sold the newspaper to Time Inc. last month without having informed the commission that the sale was in the offing.

title: ISRAEL IS CAUTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter said today that any refusal by Israel to comply with a key United Nations resolution calling for the return of occupied Arab territories, including the West Bank of the Jordan, would be a very serious blow to the prospects of peace and. a complete reversal of the policy of the Israel Government.

title: Stage: Inspired Runaways
description: ELIZABETH SWADOS'S 'Runaways, which opened last night at Joseph Papp's. Public Theater Cabaret, is an inspired musical collages about the hopes, dreams, fears, frustrations, loneliness, hum6r and, perhaps most of all, the anger, of young people who are es:, tranged from their families and are cparchinv for themselves. There are moment; of joyfulness ,and youthful, exuberance, but:basically this is, a serious, contemplative Musical with something important, to say about society today.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Down 3.3%
description: Special to The New York Times

title: `Orderly Marketing Pacts And Restriction of Imports
description: WASHINGTONThere was a definite sense of satisfaction in Government circles here this week over the degree of success being claimed for the orderly marketing arrangements now in force to restrict imports of. textiles, shoes, and color television sets into the American market. The jury is still out, however, on the latest importrestricting program the one covering foreign steelbecause of its newness and complexity.

title: Risdon Will Halt Manufacture Of Aerosol Valves Used in Cans
description: NAUGATUCK, Conn.,March 9 (UPI)The Risdon Manufacturing Company announced today that it would discontinue the manufacture of aerosol valves for products packed under pressure in cans. The company said it would sell or phase out its aerosolvalve operations.

title: Auschwitz and Peace
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Menachem Begin is negotiating with the Egyptians not merely as an Israeli but as a Jew. He culls his politics from history: a firm politics from a grim history. The past that exercises him is not so much the biblical bliss of Jewish sovereignty but rather the lachrymose history of the Jews in exile. Above all, he feels accountable to Auschwitz.

title: Spain,With Its Economy in Crisis, Finds Itself Torn Politically, Too
description: MADRID, March 9Spain is caught in what is considered its gravest economic crisis since the civil war, and the country's newly democratic politics are taking on a sharper edge, with growing signs of polarization between the left and right.

title: Islanders Beat Blues
description: Mike Bossy and Denis Potvin scored two goals each as the New York Islanders downed the Blues, 6.3, last night in St. Louis, Page A22.

title: Reporter'sNotebook:FrenchVoting Hoopla
description: PARIS, March 9Almost everyone who is or has ever been involved in French politics has been whooping up in the press, on television and radio, and on the speaker's platforms in the current election campaign. Even Fran- coise Sagan, the novelist and . playwright, provided .a long article for Le

title: Carter Is Backed On Withholding Data on Imports
description: For the first time in his 14 months office, President Carter invoked executive privilege yesterday to prevent more than 20 White House documents from being made public in a suit challenging United States quotas on imports of nonrubber sneakers from Korea and Taiwan.

title: PROJECT ANNOUNCEDFOR HUDSON PARKWAY
description: $45 Million Program Is Scheduled to Improve Road Between 72d St and George Washington Bridge

title: Richard P. (Red) Smith, Executive; Played Pro Baseball and Football
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, March 9Richard P. (Red) Smith, a former professional football and baseball player and a brewing industry executive, died yesterday in Flower Hosiptial at 73 years of age. He was dubbed Toledo's Red Smith to distinguish him from a Notre Dame classmate, Red Smith, the nationally syndicated New Ycrk Times sports columnist, who once kiddingly called him an imposter.

title: U.S. Protests Seizure by Soviet Of Clippings From Correspondent
description: MOSCOW, March 8 (Reuters)The United States Embassy here protested today to the Foreign Ministry over the confiscation of press Western clippings and research reports from an American correspondent by Soviet customs agents. The customs officers also seized reporti issued by the Soviet Government agency Tass.

title: Somali Leader, A Military Man
description: President of Somalia, born in 1919, a military man . . . Served as chief inspector in the Somali police force . Became a major general in 1966 and also Commander in Chief of the armed forces . . . Led a successful coup in October 1969 and has ruled the country since then despite promise to restore civilian rule . . . Brought in the Russians as major foreign bacxer on coming to power, and espoused a Maolike scientific socialism and made the Russians his arms suppliers and builders of big naval bases in the strategic Horn of Africa . . . Joined the Arab League in mid1974, although Somalis are non-Arabic-speaking people . . Signed friendship treaty with Moscow in July 1974. After start of war with Ethiopia in mid1977 in Ogaden region of Ethiopia, he switched ties from Moscow to Washington . . . Was offered American military assistance in July . . . Expelled all Soviet advisers on Nov. 13, 1977, halting Soviet use of bases . . . As recently as Feb. 22, described a United States call for Somali forces to withdraw from Ogaden unmisinformed.

title: Gutenberg Bible Brings $1.8 Million
description: A Gutenberg Bible,.the most coveted of all books and one of the rarest in the world, has been sold by Hans P., Kraus, the New York book dealer, for $1.8 million to the Gutenberg Museum in Mainz. West Germany.

title: FOY SEES PRESSURES FOR STEEL PRICE RISE
description: Lewis W. Foy, chairman of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's secondlargest steel company, warned yesterday that pressures were building for another steel price increase because of rising costs from the existing contract with steelworkers and future settlement of the coal strike.

title: Night Life ThrivesAgain In New York
description: BEYOND the rhythmic din of the discotheques there is a vibrant night life in New York that filled with singers, comedians, rock groups and jazz bands. In fact, at the moment there is almost a sense of stability and solidity about what is usually a very ephemeral business. The visitor is the true beneficiary of this; there is something for every taste available on any weekend in the city.

title: Auctions
description: THEIR eyes are wide with wonder, their cheeks are puffy, and frame perpetual smiles. In the parade of 250 wax and chinahead dolls up for auction today at 10 A.M. at the Richard A. Bourne Company in Byannis, Mass., virtually, all the miniature mannequins have chubby fingers, tiny feet and an abundance of golden  or ravenblack  curls. The collection represents a century or tasnionsgowns stitched of laces, brocades, organdies and taffetas, cut full in the sleeves, tight in the waistsand so much more. Thesp are dolls many children have loved, dolls dating from the 1880's to the 1940's, dolls wearing boots, ribbontied slippers, highheel pumps, dolls that summon up images of the Civil War, the Gay Nineties and even the Depression of the 1930's, when Shirley Temple reigned supreme in the affections of millions of tots.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, March 9The 4,000 or so players, including perhaps 100 from New York, who will play here in the North American Championships during the next 10 days will have a wide choice of events.

title: Rutgers Stops Winton, Beats Army in N.I.T.
description: PISCATAWAY. N.J., March 9Rutgers barely made it through the first round of the 41st annual National Invitation Tournament tonight by holding on and beating Army, 72.70, in what the Cadets coach, Mike Krzyzewski, called, a hell of a college basketball game.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: HUSBANDS, WIVES AND LOVERS, a new weekly series premiering on CBS tonight, has Joan Rivers serving as executive .story consultant, and offers the hilarious hastles, foibles and frivolities of five couples living in the suburbs of Los Angeles. Hilarious isn't quite the word.

title: Restaurants; Stopping by Woods on a winter evening.; Woods
description: Mimi Sheraton

title: McCall's Comeback Effort Livens Race in Oregon
description: PORTLAND, Ore., March 3With Tom McCall coming out of retirement to run for a third fouryear term as Governor, Oregon voters can expect to be presented with choices that they have faced twice before.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Tennis buffs and antiques enthusiasts take note. The Park Avenue Antiques Fair at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and .67th Street, will have a special cachet this year. Among the 100 or so exhibitors of glass, porcelain, furniture, silver, painting and prints are some of the important dealers missing- from January's winter Antiques Show. And the collection of the National Tennis Hall of Fame will leave its home at Newport Casino ,for the first time in 25 years for exhibition at the show. Among the memorabilia are tennis fashions from the 1870's, antique tennis rackets and trophies and films of 1920's tennis stars. The show is open from 12:30 to 9:30 P.M. today and Saturday, and from noon to six P.M. on Sunday: Admission is $3.50. For information, call 6826300.

title: Parking Policy Means Streets Will StayDirty

Firemen said the blaze broke out in the basement at 4 A.M., shortly after the discotheque closed. The fire raged through the twostory building for two hours before firemen brought it under control.

title: From Finance To Health

He has made a lot of money here by advising others how to increase theirs. He has dined in Man in the News most of the city's nest restaurants, reveled in its arts and theaters, and risen every morning just before dawn to run along its deserted streets and empty parks.

description: WASHINGTON, March 9The House Armed Services Committee has approved funds for a $2.13 billion nuclearpowered aircraft carrier and a $1.7 billion nuclearpowered guided missile cruiser that were not included in the Carter Administration's defense budget.

title: In Remote Siberia, a Buddhist Center
description: IVOLGINSK, U.S.S.R.  Beneath a large and brightly painted Buddha, the temple was filled with aged faces, eyes dimmed and deepened by long years. Cho lamas, in dull orange and brown robes, heads shaved, sat before leaves of handdrawn manuscripts and chanted. Worshipers dressed in the rough clothing of the Siberian countryside worked beads.

title: New Operatic Farce Uptown
description: For all its status as a clAsiic 19C11century French farce, 1'N Italian Straw Hat by Eugene Lnblche and MarcMichel has not turned up, in New York very often. In 1935, Oryort Welles, then the Wunderkind of the theater, subjected it to his brilliant ytaging for the Federal Theater and called it Horse Eats Hat. In 1957, jit ran Drier, ly as a play with music by Jacques Ibert and lyrics by Mitchell Parish. Rene Clair's famous silentfilth version pops up from time to time. This weekend the play appears as an opera by Nino Rota, presented by the Manhattan School of Music.

title: The Nuclear Winds of Windscale
description: Britain is about to undermine President Carter's campaign to curb the spread of nuclear technologies that can be used to make bombs. A British judge has recommended construction of a nuclear fuel reprocessing plant at Windscale, on England's northwest coast. The issue will be referred to Parliament for further debate, but close observers believe final approval of the controversial plant is certain. That would be unfortunate. The Plant would use precisely the technology that Mr. Carter trying to discourage. Moreover, the British decision comes at a particularly bad timejust as an international study designed to find safer technology is midpoint. Yet the Carter Administration, which could greatly influence the Windscale debate, has been curiously reluctant to intervene.

title: MARCH, OF: DIMES DENIES IT'SENDING GENETICS WORK
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 9 (UPI)The National FoundationMarch of Dimes today denied reports that its genetic research and genetic counseling programs were being cut back in response to pressures from antiabortion groups.

description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter announced today that Somalia had agreed to withdraw its forces from the Ogaden region of Ethiopia where they have been fighting since last July ostensibly in support of an insurrection by ethnic Somalis.

title: Cabaret: Jack Gilford as Clown
description: IT would scarcely be accurate to call Jack Gilford the last of the silent clowns, to use Walter Kerr's apt term for the great knockabout mimes of the early movies. Mr. Gilford arrived much too late to be part of that company. But he spent his childhood in the balconies of various Brooklyn theaters studying them to such good effect that he can be considered a postscript to the silent clowns.

title: Bucking Up the Dollar
description: The continued battering of the dollar in foreign money markets is troublesome. Worse, however, is the remedy advocated by a growing chorus of experts: slower economic growth in the United States. That might, indeed, shrink the nation's trade deficit and thus satisfy the gnomes of Zurich, or elsewhere, who trade in foreign currencies. But slow growth would force the nation to pay dearly in rising unemployment. It would also backfire on our allies and on the lessdeveloped countries, dependent on growing American markets. A better way to holster the dollar would be to fight inflation, something the Carter Administration has yet to do seriously.

title: Broadway
description: A FEW weeks ago it was said herewith great authoritythat big musicals do not open on Broadway in the middle of summer. Ho! Ho! Ho! Alice opens at the Minskoff on July 27. This is the show with a book by Vinnette Carroll, who will also direct, and music and lyrics by Micki Grant. The choreographer is Talley Beatty, and the producers are Mike Nichols and Lewis Allen. Debbie Allen (not related to Lewis Allen), who called herself Deborah when she was in Raisin, and who was in the much applauded 3 Girls 3 on television, will play Alice. Alice Ghostley will play the White Queen. The people who will play the Mad Hatter, the March Hare and so on have not yet been signed. By now you have guessed that Alice is based on the works of Lewis Carroll.

description: The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday challenged a gag order imposed on a former deputy marshal who contended that he had become romantically involved with a female juror during the campaignabuse trial of Nelson G. Gross, the former state Republican chairman.
