With a hit single in Margaritaville and a hit album in Changes in Latitudes. Changes in Attitudes, he began to sell records at last in the quantity that his enthusiastic audiences in most parts of the country might have led one to expect he'd. been doing all along.

title: Art People

The artists, who include the wellknown sculptor Mark di Suvero, want to stay in the seedy but lowrent 18thcentury and 19thcentury digs that some have occupied for close to 20 years. But the state which bought the block from the city in 1974 and plans to restore it as a maritime museum, says the artists will have to gothough it will help to relocate them.

title: Rhodesian Rebels Speak at U.N.

title: Screen: Wounded Sub:Gray Lady Down
description: "GRAY LADY DOWN," which opens today at the Cinerama 2 and other theaters, is this year's model of your standard peacetime submarine melodrama which is not about a confrontation between navies but about one with the element through which the submarine moves.In the first scene of "Gray Lady Down," the nuclear-powered United States Navy submarine Neptune surfaces in a fog off Cape Cod and is immediately rammed by a Norwegian freighter. The damaged Neptune sinks to a precarious position on a sea shelf 1,400 feet below, and for the next 100 or so minutes we are asked to wonder whether Charlton Heston, the skipper, and his ethnically balanced crew are going to be saved.The fact that "Gray Lady Down" was made with the enthusiastic cooperation of the Navy may give you a clue. The Navy seldom looks on the dark side of things, especiallly itself. "Gray Lady Down" has about it a sort of capitalistic sunniness, best summed up when, just after the wounded sub has come to rest on the ocean bottom, a scared sailor says, "Thank God." Says Chuck Heston, "Thank God and General Dynamics."The movie also takes care to reassure us that even though the tremendous sea pressure may eventually crush the ship's hull. There's absolutely no danger that the ship's nuclear power-pack will pollute the seas. In a world where all is change, it's reassuring to know that one thing will last forever."Gray Lady Down" is somewhat less enduring, though it seems endless. It's been composed with its crises so evenly spaced that you ache for a station break bracketed by commercials. Will that bulkhead hold? Mercy me, it's starting to leak! The oxygen supply is giving out. Will Captain Bennett (Stacy Keach), the man in charge of the rescue (and an old friend of Chuck's), get the undersea rescue vessel to the doomed sub before the crew has the fatal vapors? Do you doubt it?The people who appear in movies like that don't act. They display various cuts of resolve and steadfastness as if they were male models. The Navy is so particular about the men it lets into the sub service, you may also rest assured that when the Neptune's executive officer, played by Ronny Cox, has a brief, neurotic temper tantrum, he will recoup his reputation by making the sacrifice sometimes called supreme. David Carradine attemptsand failsto give some individuality to his role, that of a idiosyncratic officer who has invented an experimental undersea craft.The screenplay, which is terrible, was directed by David Greene, who directed the first segment of "Roots" and other television shows. Considering the material, he seems to be an efficient fellow."Gray Lady Down," (which has been rated PG ("Parental Guildance Suggested"), contains some mildly vulgar language.

title: News Summary

He said that President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia had informed him of the decision Wednesday night, and he expressed the hope that the Somali withdrawal would lead to a pullout of the Cuban and Soviet forces that have been supporting Ethiopia in the fight over control of the Ogaden region. The announcement culminated weeks of urgent private diplomacy, in which ending the fighting in Ogaden and an improvement in deteriorating AmericanSoviet relations were the objectives. A retreat will make it possible for African as well as Western nations to press for the removal of most of the outside forces.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, March 9Because today's scheduled game in Pompano Beach against the Texas Rangers was rained out, the Yankees will open their exhibition season here tomorrow night against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

description: Shouting We need space and other slogans, more than 500 students and teachers at Hostos Community College blocked traffic in the South Bronx for more than two hours yesterday to demand that the city release funds needed to complete their longdelayed annex.

title: No Strings, Please
description: As our thoughts turn to Federal incometax time, many businesses find that this is an occasion to review corporategiving policies and to allocate funds vital to the survival of America's educational institutions. Corporate philanthropy, which totaled $1.35 billion in 1977, is. one of the few remaining large sources of funds available to meet the financial needs of higher education.

title: Sanderson Stays in Minors; Wings Say He's Not Ready
description: Derek Sanderson's dramatic return from nearsuicide, drinking and drugtaking stopped just short yesterday of his putting on a National Hockey League uniform for the first time in a year.

title: SIR ROY HARROD, ADVISER ON ECONOMICS TO I.M.F.
description: HOLT, England, March 9 (AP)Sir Roy Harrod, one of Britain's leading economists and a former economic adviser to the International Monetary Fund, died early today. He was 78 years old. No cause of death was reported.

title: About Real Estate
description: FORT LEE, N.J.Construction activity in this community hugging the George Washington Bridge awakened from its recession slumber only last year, when excavations started for two office buildings. The current year promises a pickup, though not necessarily in the highrise apartments that mushroomed in Fort Lee in the 1960's. (Do you know anywhere where they're building apartments today? asked Mayor Richard A. Nest.)

title: For Children
description: CONCERT FOR YOUNG PEOPLE, with an allStravinsky program, by the New Little Orchestra, directed by Thomas K. Scherman, at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M. on Saturday at Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center. Tickets, ,trom S3 to $5. Reservations: 757-3460.

title: Renault's Success a French Election Issue
description: PARIS; March 8Renault, the French stateowned automobile manufacturer, is that rare phenomenon on the European business scenea nationalized company that makes money.

title: Fire Destroys Row of Proud Homes in East New York
description: A fouralarm fire raged out of control for two hours in the East New York seaton of Brooklyn yeserday . morning, destroying most of a blocklong row of private homes on one of the few solid, wellkept blocks remaining in the troubled neighborhood.

title: Brunch Dancing Is Back and at The Stork Club
description: SUNDAY at 1 P.M. It is a time when some night owls are just rolling out of bed. It is a time when the devout are just getting out of church. It is a time when joggers are jogging, strollers are strolling, and sports addicts are clicking on their television sets. In other words, the same old Sunday stuff.

title: Most Stocks Edge Up in a Mood Of Caution as the Dow Dips 0.87
description: Most stock prices edged higher yesterday in cautious trading as investors weighed conflicting.economic developments. Advancing issues outnumbered declining stocks by more than 8 to 5.

title: Vance Gets Complaint On Remark by Young
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 9Ambassador Peter Jay of Britain called Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance last night to object to a remark by Andrew Young, the delegate to the United Nations, that suggested that Britain might walk away from the Rhodesia problem.

title: Television
description: 11:30 P.M. (5) The Sea Hawk (1940). Errol Flynn, Flora Rob son, Claude Rains. Real color and sweep.

title: Robbery Suspect Arrested
description: NEWARK, March 9 (AP)Larry Johnson of Newark, wanted on armed robbery charges in Columbia, S.C., was arrested Tuesday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on a Federal warrant from South Carolina charging him with the armed robbery of the First Citizens Bank and Trust Company, Rosewood Branch, in Columbia, the F.B.I. said. Arraigned yesterday before United States Magistrate William J. Hunt, Mr. Johnson was remanded to the custody of the Federal marshal.

title: SUPPLIES OF DISTILLATE OIL OFF BY 11.7 MILLION BARRELS
description: The country's supplies of distillate oil fell sharply by 11.7 million barrels to 167.7 million in the week ended March 3, from 179.4 million barrels in the preceding week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: 2 Council Leaders Reject Koch's Report on Agencies Productivity
description: Two New York City Council leaders rejected Mayor Koch's management report on productivity and goals of city agencies yesterday, with one of the leaders calling it useless.

title: Swiss Skier Captures CrossCountry Race
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., March 9 (UPI)  John Kreuzer, a member of the Swiss national team, today won the men's 15kilometer race at the North American crosscountry ski championships at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Bitr Tax Evasion On Bearer Bond Certificates
description: WASHINGTON, March 9The Internal Revenue Service, as expected, proposed regulations today that would virtually destroy the attractiveness of a new type of bank deposit that has proliferated because of the tax evasion opportunity offers small investors.

title: Metals Futures In Broad Decline
description: Prices of precious metals futures sagged on a broad front yesterday in expectation that President Carter would announce moves to bolster the dollar at his afternoon news conference. He didn't.

title: CELESTINE G. FITZPATRICK
description: The Rev. Celestine Gerard Fitzpatrick, formerly of New York City, died Wednesday in St. Joseph's Manor, a retirement residence in Trumbull, Conn., where he had been a chaplain. He was 71 years old and lived at the manor.

title: ISRAEL IS CAUTIONED
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter said today that any refusal by Israel to comply with a key United Nations resolution calling for the return of occupied Arab territories, including the West Bank of the Jordan, would be a very serious blow to the prospects of peace and. a complete reversal of the policy of the Israel Government.

title: Experts Call 2 Dams Upstate Unsafe; Toccoa Dam Collapse Recalled; (Inspectors Call 2 Dams in Orange County Unsafe; A Definition of Terms; Five Dams Inspected
description: WARWICK, N.Y.It was below freezing, and the air was cold and crisp, with bright sunlight pouring out of a blue sky over. the clean snow that covered the groundexcept in one spot.

title: All the Juicy Details About LateNight Burgers
description: In France, the wellknown antidote to an evening of drinking and other hangoverprovoking merriment is a big thick crock of onion soup, golden and fragrant under a bubbling mantle of toasted cheese. To the Italians, a similar preventive measure is pasta agliooliosteaming spaghetti bathed in garlicperfumed olive oil and touched off by fiery hot redpepper flakes. paprika bright goulash soup, thick with beef and potatoes, is said by citizens of Munich to ward off a morningafter katzenjammer.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS BACKING FOR YUGOSLAV UNITY
description: WASHINGTON, March 9President Carter, in a statement issued jointly with President Tito at the end of the Yugoslav leader's visit here, strengthened American backing for Yugoslav national security today by declaring that his Administration supported the unity of Yugoslavia, a country of many nationalities.

title: Koch Appoints Badillo Protege Head of Model Cities
description: Richard J. Aniero an official regarded at City Hall as a protegd of Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo, was put incharge of the restructured Model Cities Office yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
description: (Millions of dollars) Daily Averages for the weeks ended:

title: School Board in Yonkers Approves a Modified Pact With Teacher Federation
description: YONKERS, March 9After months of renegotiation between the Yonkers Federation of Teachers and the Board of Education, the board tonight approved, 6 to 3, a modified version of a collectivebargaining agreement that ended a 15day teachers strike last fall.

title: David Owen's Star, After Fa,st A.,scent, Now Seems in Peril
description: LONDON, March 9Just over a year ago, David Owen, an obscure and very junior member of the British Cabinet, was named Foreign Secretary. At 38 years of age, he was the youngest man since Anthony Eden to hold the job, with its inescapable echoes of Palmerston and Curzon.

title: AliSpinks Rematch Sails to a New Port
description: Bophuthatswana, , the black homeland recently set up by the South African Government and acknowledged so far only by South Africa and Top Rank Inc., lost half its worldwide recognition yesterday when the boxing promoter shifted the planned Muhammad AliLeon Spinks rematch to Mauritius, an independent island nation in the Indian Ocean.

title: Charges Against Cadet Dropped In West Point Fraternizing Case
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 9Army lawyers, in an unusual move, agreed tonight to drop all charges against Cadet Kevin Downey, who had been accused of fraternizing with a female plebe at West Point and then lying about their relationship.

title: Ski Conditions
description: The following reports were tiled by ski operators at 11 A.M. March 9. Ski surfaces are subject to change because of weather and skiers traffic.

title: Vineyard Curlew Report Draws Flock of watchers
description: MENEMSHA, Mass., March 9Reports that a lone Eurasian curlew has taken refuge in the tidal flats here have touched off a flurry of excitement in the birdwatching world and here on Martha's Vineyard, where things get quiet once the ice coats the marshlands, snowpatches dot the beaches and the cold wind blows in off the ocean.

title: Guatemalans, Awaiting Election Results 4 Days, Hear Rumors of a Coup
description: GUATEMALA, March 9Four days after Guatemala's presidential elections, the final results had still not been announced today. Rumors spread that the army was preparing to intervene in the dispute between the two main military contenders for Dower.

title: Textron Is Ordered to Yield Documents to the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, March 9In a significant victory for the Securities and Exchange Commission, a Federal district court judge today ordered Textron Inc. to turn over company documents to the agency without a special court order protecting their confidentiality.

title: CANAL HOLDOUTS FIND PRESSURE MOUNTING
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 - Senator Wendell H. Ford was lectured In newspaper advertisements bought by an old friend, Senator Edward W. Brooke went to see President Carter today, Senator Dennis DeConcini is working on amendments to facilitate military base rights. Senator Edward Zorinsky is having his constituents polled. Senator Jennings Randolph met with a woman who drove 175 miles through a snowstorm.

title: Dispute on Hospital Records Interrupts Trial of Dr. X
description: HACKENSACK, March 9The trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, charged with murdering five patients in Riverdell Hospital in 1965 and 1966, was interrupted unexpectedly today when those now in control of the hospital in Oradell balked at: releasing records sought by the defense.

title: Advance Album to Push `Thank God It's Friday
description: LOS ANGELES, March 9In a reversal of usual Hollywood form, Casablanca Records is releasing its twoand-a-half-record album of Thank God' It's Friday six weeks in advance of the picture of the same name. The

title: Chilean Chief Announces Lifting of State of Siege, In Force Since 1973 Coup
description: This is not a threat, but I am testing how the people will behave, the President said in announcing the end of the state of siege.

title: SchoolCrossing Guard Painting Smiles on His World at Age 82
description: ENGLEWOOD, March 8  Dam Benau is a schoolcrossing guard at St. Cecilia. He also paints bright, cheerful primitive works, which are currently on exhibition at the Englewood Community Health Center.

title: Weiskopf Still Forgoing Golf for Bighorn Sheep
description: MIAMI, March 9About this time a year ago Tom Weiskopf shook the Professional Golfers Association by announcing he would not play in the Ryder Cup matches against Britain and Ireland in September because he preferred to hunt bighorn sheep in the Canadian Rockies.

title: Plan to Soften Abortion Dispute Collapses
description: CLEVELAND, March 9Hopes for an unusual step toward cooperation between right-to-life groups and advocates of abortion rights, raised at a meeting here two weeks ago between officials of the Roman Catholic Church and William R. Baird, the abortion activist, collapsed in confusion this week as plans for a followup meeting fell apart.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission voted today to begin an investigation into whether Western Union slioqld continue its 35-year-old monopoly over the nation's telegraph business. The action was the result of an application by Graphnet Systems Inc. to interconnect with the international carriers to deliver messages from them to inland locations within the United States.

title: Hardee's Conducting Merger Discussions
description: Hardee's Food Systems Inc., the nation's thirdlargest hamburger chain after McDonald's and Burger King, said yesterday that it was holding merger talks but that no agreement had yet been reached.

title: Psychiatrist Now Calls Mrs. Gay Insane
description: CAMDEN, March 9A psychiatrist testifying for the prosecution at the trial of Roxanne Gay today reversed his earlier opinion and said that Mrs. Gay was insane when she killed her husband in 1976 and that she was still insane.

title: Apples Trade Virginia Wade to Gaters
description: The longstanding plan to break up the Apples was achieved yesterday by World Team Tennis with the formal announcement that Virginia Wade was being traded by New York to the Golden Gaters. In a threeway deal that also involved Seattle, JoAnne Russell will join the Apples as a teammate of Billie Jean King.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: OCEANIC (Home). Left Port au Prince Mar. 7; due 8 A.M. at W. 55th Street.

title: Italy Begins Trial of Terrorists After 2Year Delay
description: ROME, March 9The founding members of the Red Brigades, a major urban guerrilla organization, went on trial in `Turin today after two years of delay and in spite of a systematic campaign of intimidation by terrorists 'still at large to block the trial.

title: Two Bodies Found in Train Wreck
description: HESPERIA, Calif., March 8 (UPI)The bodies of two Santa Fe crewmen deadheading on a freight train that derailed have been found at the bottom of tons of jumbled and burned railroad oars. Rescue workers reached them last night while sifting through the wreckage. The victims were not immediately Identified.

title: Somoza's Top Army Aide Murdered by Guerrillas In Attempt at Kidnapping
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, March 9 (AP)Leftist guerrillas murdered the chief military aide to President Anastasio Somoza Debayle in a kidnapping attempt in Managua, the police reported today.

title: The Rev. Hugh Morley, 69, Leader Of the Catholic International Press
description: The Rev. Hugh Morley, a Capuchin Franciscan priest who served as representative of the International Catholic Union of the Press at the United Nations, died Wednesday at St. Clare's Hospital in New York City. He was 69 years old and lived in the city.

title: Cape Cod Environmentalists Sue Over Air Force Base Radar Unit
description: SANDWICH, Mass., March 9A group of Cape Cod environmental groups has filed suit in Federal District Court in Boston seeking a preliminary injunction to compel the Air Force to prepare a statement on the environmental impact of the Pave Paws radar facility under construction at Otis Air Force Base here.

title: Publishing: 25 Years For a Modern Classic
description: WHEN Eric F. Goldman's Rendezvous With Destiny: A History of Modern American Reform came out a quarter of a century ago, Jimmy Carter was a 28-year-old officer aboard the submarine Seawolf. In a new preface for the 25th anniversary edition of this modern classic, recently published by Vintage Books/Random House, Dr. Goldman, who is Rollins

title: Market Place
description: Ten Kennecott Copper Corporation, which has been regarded by some as a takeover candidate ever since the company sold its Peabody Coal Company subsidiary for $1.2 billion, is in the spotlight again.

title: Concert: Lynn Harrell
description: THE repertory for cello and orchestra being as limited as is, soloists cast around in all directions. That is one reason why Lynn, Harrell played Prokoffev's SymphonyConerto last night in Avery Fisher Hall, with the New York Phil. harmonic conducted by James Levine.

title: Brazilian Gets Tryout On Cosmos
description: SOUTHAMPTON, Bermuda, March A Brazilian who plays soccer for Santos slipped into the Cosmos camp today at the strong recommendation of a Brazilian who use to play soccer for Santosand the Cosmos.

title: Stretching the Coal Supply Has Meant a Fast Pace at Ohio Utility); Doubts Voiced by Public; Alabama Imposes Power Cutback
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 9As James P. Fenstermaker and Fred V. Stine, two top officials of the Columbus and Southem Ohio Electric Company, ported over charts on coal supply and fuel managemerit this morning at the company'ss headquarters here, Mr. Fenstermaer moved a hand across one of the charts and said in a relieved tone, Today would have been zero day.

title: CHINA IS SEEN EASING ATTITUDE ON RELIGION
description: (HONG KONG, March 7China appears to be allowing some Christian churches that have been closed to Chinese for over a decade to reopen and may be returning to a policy of greater religious tolerance.

title: Blaze Destroys a Row of Proud Homes in East New York and Routs 100
description: FIRE DESTROYS ROW OF HOMES IN BROOKLYN: An aerial view of a blaze that raged out of control for two hours in East New York, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, destroying most of a blocklong row of private houses one of the few wellkept blocks remaining in the troubled neighborhood. There were about 12 injuries. Page A25.

title: Court Action Barred in Nun's Case
description: PROVIDENCE, RI, March 9 (AP)Federal Magistrate Jacob Hagopian, saying that under the First Amendment he could not get involved in church matters, has refused to rule on the dismissal of a nun from a religious order after 25 years of service. Sister Therese Nadeau, 51 years old, charges that the Religious Order of Jesus and Mary broke its con= tract with her when she was dismissed in 1972. The reason for her dismissal was not given in court yesterday.

title: Art: Napoleon in Rhode Island
description: NAPOLEON IN RHODE ISLAND just has to be this season's most provocative title. Many years ago there was a novel by G. K. Chesterton called 'The Napoleon of Notting Hill, but on the face of it Napoleon in Rhode Island makes no sense at all.

title: DOLLAR GAINS HERE BUT FALLS IN TOKYO
description: The dollar fell to a new low against the yen in Tokyo but rebounded later yesterday both in Europe and New York, the Associated Press reported.

title: Blaze Destroys a Row of Proud Homes in East New York and Routs 100
description: FIRE DESTROYS ROW OF HOMES IN BROOKLYN: An aerial view of a blaze that raged out of control for two hours in East New York, Brooklyn, yesterday morning, destroying most of a blocklong row of private houses on one of the few wellkept blocks remaining in the troubled neighborhood. There were about 12 injuries. Page B3.

title: Newark Likely to Go Bankrupt, And That Is Good, Expert Says
description: NEWARK, March 9A Rutgers University specialist in urban affairs believes that Newark is headed for bankruptcy and that the result would be a good thing.

title: Jet Engine Failure Laid to Engineer
description: National Airlines said yesterday that an error by the flight engineer in managing the flow of fuel probably caused the brief failure of all three engines on a Boeing 727 flying off the Florida coast Jan 27.

title: South Africa Releases 10 Blacks, Including Qoboza, Leading Editor
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 10  The South African Government, apparently confident that the upsurge of black resistance to its rule has subsided, released today 10 of the blacks it seized in crackdown on dissenters last year, including the country's foremost black editor, Percy Qoboza.

title: 54 Calves Die on a Flight To Iran and Are Returned And Buried in Newburgh
description: Fiftyfour calves that died on a flight from Lincoln, Neb., to Iran last Monday were flown back to this country and finally buried at Stewart Field in Newburgh, N.Y., Thursday night under supervision of Department of Agriculture authorities.

title: Miss Austin Ends Navratilova Streak
description: DALLAS, March 10 (UPI) Tracy Austin, the 15-year-old from California, ended Martina Navratilova's 37match winning streak tonight, taking the last point of a thirdset tiebreaker for a 63; 26, 76 victory in the quarter, finals of the Maureen Connolly Brinker tournament.

title: MOSCOW SAID TO LINK PULLOUTS BY CUBANS, SOMALIS IN ETHIOPIA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Soviet Union has informed the United States that Cuban military forces in Ethiopia will be substantially reduced once Somali troops are Withdrawn from the Ogaden area and fighting stops, reporters at the State Department were told this evening.

title: United Brands Loss In 4th Quarter Cuts Net for 1977 by 54%
description: The United Brands Company operated at a loss of $5.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1977 in contrast to a profit of $3.1 million, or 23 cents a share, in the 1976 final quarter,

title: Consumer Notes
description: One of the major opticians in the state is challenging a proposed regulation by the State Board of Optometrists that would prevent consumers from obtaining a copy of a prescription for contact lenses and taking it to an optician to be filled.

title: Trial of Dr. X Hears of the Death of 4-Year-Old Girl
description: HACKENSACK, March 10A Riverdell Hospital doctor testified today how one of his patientsa 4-year-old girlsuddenly died after apparently recovering from surgery. The testimony came as the trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich began to deal directly with the first of five patients Dr. Jascalevich is charged with murdering at the hospital in Oradell.

title: KOCH ACTS TO REDUCE CITY PAYROLL BY 6,345
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday to let the city's work force shrink. by 6,345 jobs by July 1, 1979, in a move that he said would help close a $457 million budget gap with no layoffs and no significant cuts in services.

title: DOLLAR UP SHARPLY AS U.S.GERMAN TALKS SPUR HOPES OF AID
description: PARIS, March 10The dollar rallied sharply on money markets across Europe today and the price of gold eased, on the strength of expectations that the Carter Administration and the West German Government would be planning new measures this weekend to bolster the battered United States currency.

title: Police Aide Is Killed in Turin, Site of Guerrillas Trial
description: ROME, March 10A police official noted for his fight against terrorists was shot and killed in Turin this morning as a trial of 15 leading urban guerrillas went into its second day there.

title: New York Council Panel Puts Off Action on Market Beneath Bridge
description: A New York City Council committee yesterday held up approval of the proposed Bridgemarket complex of food shops and restaurants beneath the Manhattan end of the Queensboro Bridge because of questions on the background nf t,he developer. Harley Baldwin.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The Honda Motor Company of Japan announced that it has established wholly owned subsidiary in Ohio to handle its planned manufacture of motorcycles in the United States. Honda is the world's largest manufacturer of motorcycles and Japan's fifth biggest auto producer.

title: French End Bitter Election Drive For a Day's Respite Before Voting
description: PARIS, March 10France's long and bitter election campaign officially ended tonight with strong indications that the opposition Socialists and Communists could win a majority of votes in the first round Sunday, and, possibly enough Assembly seats in the final round on Sunday, March 19, to claim the right to form the next Government.

title: Going out Guide
description: HEADY MIXTURE Both classical and popular music artists have joined the roster for a downtown concert tomorrow afternoon at 3, with proceeds going to benefit the Village Nursing Home in Greenwich Village. The place is the auditorium of the New School, 66 West 12th Street.

title: Unemployment Rate Fell to 6.1.% For February, Lowest in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Despite the coal strike and bad weather, the unemployment rate fell to 6.1 percent last month, the lowest since October 1974, the Labor Department reported today.

title: ExGeneral Loses Soviet Citizenship
description: MOSCOW, March 10 (Reuters)The Soviet Government announced today that it had abrogated the citizenship of Pyotr G. Grigorenko, a leading Soviet dissident who is now on a visit in the United States. The effect of the Soviet decision was to commit the former major general to exile.

title: Purtzer Leads Indian Golf
description: CALCUTTA, India, March 10 (AP)Paul Purtzer of the United States shot a 71 today and took a twostroke lead over Stewart Ginn of Australia at the halfway mark of the Indian open, the fourth leg of the Asian golf championship,

Gibson Disputes Dean's Prediction Of Bankruptcy for Newark by 82
description: NEWARK, March 10Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson disputed today a contention by a Rutgers dean that Newark, the' state's largest city, faced bankruptcy within four years.

title: Treacy,Campbell Set N.C.A.A.Meet Marks
description: DETROIT, March 10Ian Campbell of Washington State (and Australia) and John Treaty of Providence College (and Ireland) set imposing meet records in the triple jump and threemile run tonight at the National Collegiate indoor track and field championships at Cobo Arena.

title: Koch's Offbeat Style
description: Mayor Koch's quick and open off-thecuff responses to various situations are creating a growing controversy, even within his own inner circle, and raising the question among many politicians over whether his flamboyant and off- beat style might be overshadowing and detracting from the substantive achievements of his administration. Some politicians contend that Mr. Koch's style comes across as arrogant and acerbic and tends to heighten and prolong controversies such as his walkout at a Queens civic meeting 11 days ago. But others argue that the Mayor is merely being open and frank, and call it a refreshing contrast to his cautious and circumspect predecessor.

title: The Alcoholic Nurse: Facing the Problem
description: Mary, a thin, blond nurse with musical Irish accent, stood up before group of 100 fellow nurses yesterday and nervously told them about her years as an alcoholic.

title: Cabaret
Newcombe's Comeback Thwarted by Connors
description: NEW HAVEN, March 10In prepar ing for his tennis match against Jimmy Connors in the World Cup tournament here tonight, John Newcombe of Australia went all week without a beer.

title: Archimede's Mirrors: Some New Reflections
description: Like many ancient legends, the one about Archimedes setting fire to an attacking Roman fleet using sunlight concentrated by mirrors has its doubters, and they have touched off a lively controversy among scientists and historians.

title: Census Finds Blacks Are Moving From Northeast at a Faster Rate
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Census Bureau reported today that the migration of blacks away from the Northeast, first tentatively detected during the early 1970's, appeared to have accelerated since 1975.

title: REILLY CASE WITNESS TELLS OF CONFESSION
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 10  A young woman who told authorities that a man had confessed to her that he murdered Barbara Gibbons, the mother of Peter A. Reilly, has been placed in protective custody, the state police said today.

title: New Cunningham Work Is Danced
description: AMHERST, Mass., March 10Merce Cunningham's new dance work, Inlets is a knockout. It is a major collaboration with the painter Morris Graves and the Cunningham company's longtime music director, John Cage.

title: KOCH ACTS TO REDUCE CITY PAYROLL BY 6,345
description: Mayor Koch proposed yesterday to let the city's work force shrink by 6,345 jobs by July 1, 1979, in a move that he said would help close a $457 .million budget gap with no layoffs and no significant cuts in services.

title: Mayor of Atlanta Suspends Police Head, Giving the City's Image a Blow
description: ATLANTA, March 10In an effort to end a drawnout, racially sensitive police promotion scandal, Mayor Maynard Jackson suspended Atlanta's Public Safety Commissioner today, charging that he had committed serious errors in judgment that had resulted in severe damage to the city's reputation.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LOANS BARRED BY CITIBANK
description: In a reversal of its longstanding public policy, Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, has decided not to make loans to the South African Government or to Governmentowned manufacturing and utility enterprises.

title: Pan Am Affirms Wiser Will Resign In May After 2 Years as President
description: Pan American World Airways, the country's largest international air carrier, confirmed yesterday that its president, Forwood C. Wiser Jr., 57 years old, would resign in May after only two years at the controls.

title: EVIDENCE IS SOUGHT FOR INQUIRY ON CETA
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 10Robert 13. Fiske, the United States Attorney in Manhattan, said today that he would cooperate in an investigation of possible fraud in Westchester County's Comprehensive Employment and Training Act program, but not until evidence of major wrongdoing was uncovered.

title: Fratianne Second in Skating
description: OTTAWA, March 10Linda Fratitume came out fighting tonight, but still lost a close decision to Anett Poetzsch of East Germany for the ladies singles title at the word figure skating championships.

title: New York City's February Job Increase Is the First in 9 Years
description: The number of jobs in New York City in February rose for the first time in nine years, the United States Department of Labor said yesterday.

title: Around the Nation
description: ST. LOUIS, March 10 (UPI)A judge who said he was repulsed by the philosophy of the Nazi Party refused today to block a march by the party planned for tomorrow. The judge was bound by the law to let the Nazis parade.

Russian flu outbreaks continue to spread, attacking high school and college age groups, the center said.

description: An alleged multimilliondollar drug ring that reportedly provided Rutgers University students with marijuana, LSD, hashish, opium and other drugs was broken yesterday with the arrest of 37 persons. authorities said

title: Knockouts Pace Card At Garden
description: Knockouts by Ronald Huston in the lightheavyweight class, William Costello in the 135pound class, and Robert Vinas, featherweight, highlighted the 52d annual Golden Gloves boxing tournament at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Jailed Foe of Marcos Allowed to Speak on Television
description: MANILA, March 10In an unusual spectacle, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., President Ferdinand E. Marcos's chief political rival who has been in prison for over five years, was allowed to appear on television here tonight to answer Governent charges that he had worked for the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Jazz Subdue Nets, 10599; Pacers Overcome Knicks
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J. March 10The New Orleans Jazz registered its third National Basketball Association victory of the season over the New Jersey Nets by scoring a 10599 victory tonight before a crowd of 4,823.

title: COURT RULES WOMAN WAS INSANE IN KILLING
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 10Roxanne Gay was ruled insane today and acquitted in the fatal stabbing in 1976 of her husband, Blenda, a professional football nlaver for the Philadelphia Eagles. Judge I.V. DiMartino ruled in Camden County Superior Court, after a fourday sanity hearing, that Mrs. Gay, 26 years old, was suffering from delusions of per. secution and was legally insane when she killed her 27-year-old husband while he slept in their Gloucester Township apartment on Dec. 20, 1976.

title: Carter Cautioned By House Group On Jets for Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, March 10A majority of the members of a key House committee told President Carter today that they opposed his decision to link the sale of advanced planes to Israel to similar sales to Saudi Arabia and Egypt,

title: People and Business
description: The overseas operations of the General Motors Corporation have been reorganized, effective April 1, Thomas A. Murphy, chairman, announced yesterday in Detroit.

title: Ballet: Repertory Troupe Opens
description: Ballet Repertory Company opened its first New York season on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church with a wellbalanced program of contemporary abstract, dramatic and traditional ballet. The group, a second company that feeds into American Ballet Theater, is composed of young dancers chosen both for their talent and promise. Its 20 members have had the benefit of thoughtful and imaginative training and extensive touring experience. And embryo performers often have a special vitality. But the evening was disappointingly bland.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart of the Index of Finished Goods Prices in The Times yesterday was inaccurate in some respects. A corrected chart appears today on page 31.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
Patents
description: WASHINGTONEngineers of Bell Telephone Laboratories in Atlanta have invented a highlysuccessful communications cable for light waves. A mileand-a-half of the cable is now carrying voice, video and data signals in evaluation operations under the streets of Chicago.

title: Unemployment Rate Fell to  6.1% For February, Lowest in 3 Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Despite the coal strike and bad weather, the unemployment rate fell to 6.1 percent last month, the lowest since October 1974, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Butch Lee's Road Winds to the Pros
description: Four years ago, as a senior at DeWitt Clinton High School, he stuffed shoe boxes with mail from colleges that wanted him. Now Butch Lee is completing his Marquette University basketball career, and, unlike so many playground superstars, he'll take another sten UM into the pros.

title: Sprayed Marijuana Called Peril
description: The Government yesterday warned that permanent lung damage could result from regular or heavy smoking of marijuana that is taintd with paraquat, a highly toxic herbicide that Mexico is spraying on its marijuana fields, supported by United States Government funds.

title: U.S. MAY SEEK DEAL WITH SOVIET ON ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Secretary of Defense Harold Brown said today that the United States might use the controversial neutron bomb as a bargaining chip in exchange for Soviet weapons restraint.

title: Movie Colony Fights Surf and the State
description: MALIBU, Calif., March 10Juggling huge boulders as if they were basketballs, big yellow skiploaders snorted along the sands of California's Gold Coast today, trying to bulwark homes of the rich and famous against further devastating assaults by stormdriven Pacific surfs.

title: Don Giovanni Is Sung at Met; Many Performers Make Debuts
description: Don Giovanni, bespeckled with new figures, came to the Metropolitan Opera last night for the first time this season. Joan Sutheiland, of course, was familiar. But Julia Varady ano John Brecknock made their debuts as Elvira and Ottavio, and Hugdette Tourangeau and Allan Monk sane their first Zerlina and Massetto at the house. Richard Bonynge, the conductor, had never before led the Mozart opera here, and Gabriel Bacquier, the Leporello, was still another appearing in this role for the first time at the Metropolitan.

title: N. Car. St. 82, S. Carolina 70
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 10 (AP)Kendal (Tiny) Pinder scored 18 points to lead a balanced attack as North Carolina State defeated South Carolina, 82.70, tonight in the first round of the N. I. T.

title: Dow Climbs 8.58 to 758.58 in Strongest Rally of Year
description: The stock market staged its broadest rally of 1978 yesterday, responding with enthusiasm to a strengthening of the dollar abroad and to a surprise drop in the jobless rate at home.

title: U.S.SEEKING TO LEARN NOW TIMES GOT DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Justice, Department is conducting an investigation here and in New York in an attempt to learn how The New York Times obtained a copy of a classified report that said that Cuban espionage agents in the late 1960's and early 1970's provided limited aid to antiwar radicals in this country, a department spokesman confirmed today

title: Indiana St. 73, Illinois St. 71
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., March 10 (UPI) Howie Johnson's 20foot baseline jumper with 2:12 left gave Indiana State the lead and the Sycamores held on to score a 7371 firstround triumph tonight over Illinois State in the N. I. T.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Dorazetti's La Favorite, 2; CIlea's Adrlana Lecouvreur, 8

title: AIRLINE BALKS AT RETURN OF HIJACKERS FROM CUBA
description: HAVANA, March 10 (Reuters)United States officials here grappled today with the problem of how to get six American hijackers home from Cuba to stand trial.

title: 2 Under North Sea Are Rescued Unhurt
description: LERWICK, Shetland Islands, March10 (AP)Two offshore oilfield workers were rescued unharmed today from the North Sea after being trapped 355 feet under water for nearly 24 hours in small submersible.

title: Two Former Federal Agents Convicted in Drug Case
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 10Two former agents of the Federal Drug Eniforcement Administration were convicted here today of conspiring to steal and sell Information from the agency's master computer and to smuggle drugs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 11, 1978

title: Cloning Becomes a Publishers Experiment
description: The publishing world is surprised, sk4ptical and yet willing to get on the cloning bandwagon if the new magical word about the laboratory creation of a human being captures the public's fancy.

title: Business and Labor Urged to Back Health Maintenance Organizations
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Carter Administration called business and labor leaders together today and urged them to support health maintenance organizations as a means of cutting down on workers'and the nation'sskyrocketing health costs.

title: ISRAEL SAYS RELIGIOUS LAW WON'T CURTAIL CHRISTIANS
description: The Israeli Government, reacting to a complaint from American Jewish leaders, offered assurances yesterday that a new and controversial law on religious conversions would not be used to restrict relieious freedom of Christians.

title: Cosmos 993 Goes Into Orbit
description: MOSCOW, March 10 (UPI)The Soviet Union fired another of its Cosmos series satellites into orbit today, No. 993. It circles the earth every 89.7 minutes and its orbit takes it 202.8 miles out at the greatest distance and to 109.2 miles from the earth at its closest point.

title: London Blacks GrowUneasy As the Race Issue Heats Up
description: LONDON, March 7The greengrocer, his face tilted in the Cockney posture of fixed amazement, smiled at his customer over a bank of plantains, red beans and yams. Caribbean music drifted through the market from a record shop in a converted Victorian house.

title: South Africa Releases 10 Blacks, Including Qoboza, Leading Editor
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 10  The South African Government, apparently confident that the upsurge of black resistance to its rule has subsided, released today 10 of the blacks it seized in crackdown on dissenters last year, including the country's foremost black editor, Percy Qoboza.

title: P.B.A.'s New Negotiator
description: MINEOLA, L. I.It is 7:45 on a Friday evening and the law offices that surround the courts here have long since let most employees off for their weekends. But at Hartman, Morganstern & Lerner on Old Country Road Man in the News lawyers, secretaries and clerks, about 80 in all, attend to their duties as if it were 10 A.M. on a weekday morning. The following morning at 7:45 it is the samea blur of. activity.

title: Malnutrition Needs More Than a Green Revolution
description: Worldwide fammewhich seemed imminent as recently as 1972is considered unlikely today. Nevertheless, the numbers of malnourished remain much as they have for decades, even though reports of food surplus have replaced stories of crop failure and drought in the news.

title: Lolich, Allen Spring Eternal
description: YUMA, Ariz., March 10In the spring an old player's fancy turns to hanging on, as Dick Allen hopes to do with the Oakland A's, or to coming back, as Mickey Lolich hopes to do with the San Diego Padres after one year in retirement as a softball first baseman and manufacturer's salesman.

title: Schubert Dance Given Premiere
description: The Murray Louis Dance Company opened a twoweek season Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and looked as sprightly as ever. A virtuoso performer, Mr. Louis has developed his style out of the body's capacity to be quick and nimble.

title: Publicly Traded Funds
description: Friday, March 10, 1978

title: Books of The Times
description: This is the meticulously detailed account of the transformation of a small, saucy Democratic daily into one of the most influential newspapers in America. It is also a trip through the lookingglass. A look not only at the mirror that The Post has been holding up to Washington all these years, but also at those who hold the mirror and who all so often become an inextricable part of what the mirror is reflecting.

title: Mr. Koch Takes the, Reins on Poverty
description: Mayor Koch is moving in on New York City's embattled $75 million antipoverty effort, including the Model Cities programs in Harlem, the South Bronx and central Brooklyn. Some black and Puerto Rican leaders have responded with predictable hostility, charging that the Mayor's centralization plan would reduce services to lowincome areas of the city. But the Mayor's action is necessary to distribute the program's resources more fairly and to coordinate the delivery of services. The plan should also help to correct the mismanagement that up to now has marred even some of the best antipoverty efforts.

title: Housing Construction in 1977 In New York State Best in 5 Years
description: New York State officials yesterday reported the first significant upturn irf the rate of housing construction in the state in five years.

title: Weather Helps Fiori Retain Doral Lead
description: MIAMI, March 10Every tournament on the PGA Tour has its morning glory, an unknown rookie who leads the first round and then vanishes on the second day with a 78 or so. Ed Fiori may turn out to be one of them, but he has lasted two days because of a pair of perverse days of the kind that Floridians call spring weather.

title: Personal Investing
description: Speculative flurries are few and far between on the Big Board these days, but lowpriced realestate investment trusts and other real estateoriented issues have suddenly become all the rage.

title: Wallace Says Utility Misled Him on Supply
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 10 (AP) Gov. George C. Wallace has withdrawn his mandatory power cutback proposal, which included rotating blackoutS in nesidential areas, saying than the Alabama Power Company m'isl'ed him about the severity of the itility's coal shortage.

title: A COUNSEL IS SOUGHT FOR ETHICS INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The House ethics committee is planning to appoint a special counsel to investigate allegations of wrongdoing recently leveled against Representatives Joshua Eilberg and Daniel J. Flood, Democrats of Pennsylvania, senior Congressional sources said today.

title: Dodgers, 143 Days Later, Top Yanks
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 10 One hundred fortythree day after the teams last played each other in the World Series, the Los Angeles Dodgers finally devised a way to get Reggie Jackson out and to beat the New York Yankees.

title: Centrist Candidate Is Apparent Victor In Guatemalan Vote
description: GUATEMALA, March 10Gen. Romeo., Lucas Garcia, a taciturn 53-year-old for mer Defense Minister, emerged today as the apparent victor in last Sunday's presidential elections, though his two opponents continued to charge fraud in the votecounting.

title: Rhodesian Bishop Blocked at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 10African countries appear to have succeeded in blocking a hearing before the Security Council for a Rhodesian black nationalist leader who signed a majorityrule agreement last week with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: U.S.OfficialVoices Optimism for Accord In GATT Meetings
description: Alonzo L. McDonald, the deputy special negotiator for the United States in the multinational trade negotiations under way in Geneva, said yesterday he believed that there was better than a 5050 chance that the 96nation conference would produce a respectable international agreement.

title: Dividends
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 10, 1978

title: Comedies at No Smoking
description: F. Murray Abraham demonstrated his comic agility and malleability in two Broadway comedies by Terrence McNally. In Bad Habits, Mr. Abraham was a selfadmiring, starry - eyed actor, perpetually reading for roles and burnishing his suntan. In The Ritz, he was a wildly antic homosexual.

title: Tank Cars Back on Track
description: FLORENCE, N. J., March 10 (UPI)Conrail put back on the tracks today the last two of four tank cars that derailed here yesterday while carrying the chemical vinyl chloride to the Hooker Chemical plant from Texas. The police said that none of the chemical escaped and the cars were not damaged.

title: SOUTH AFRICA LOANS BARRED BY CITIBANK
description: In a reversal of its longstanding public policy, Citibank, the nation's secondlargest bank, has decided not to make loans to the South African Government or to Governmentowned manufacturing and utility enterprises.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart of the Index of Finished Goods Prices in The Times yesterday was inaccurate in some respects. A corrected chart appears today on page 31.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, March 10Two major national championships began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. New York is strongly represented in the 244 pairs in the men's pair championship and the 384 pairs in the women's pairs.

title: Spiess of Austria Posts First World Cup Victory
description: LAAX, Switzerland, March 10 (AP)Ulrich Spiess of Austria scored one of the biggest upsets of the ski season today when he raced to his first World Cup victory in the downhill event.

title: Alaskan Pipeline to Buy Natural Gas in Canada To Be Consumed in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Northwest Alaskan Pipeline Company, which is building a 4,800mile pipeline to carry natural gas from Alaska to the United States mainland, announced today that it would purchase more than 1 billion

title: Tune Sought to Help Do Away With Litter
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 10 (AP)  This city is in the market for tunesmiths. Officials here say New Brunswick needs a song, and it is sponsoring a contest to come up with a tune to help combat litter problems.

title: Efforts to Shield Money From Inflation Spurs Futures Buying Spree
description: Speculators scrambled to buy almost anything that would protect their money froni inflation this week, starting an explosion in futures markets ranging from precious metals to agricultural products, The Associated Press mooned.

description: ARRIVING TODAY, Mar. 11

title: Opera Buf fa Italian Straw Hat By Rota at the Manhattan Schoo
description: Rossini, Offenbach, Gilbert and Sullivan, Leharthese were some of the composers whose names kept recurring in the mind during the New York premiere of Nino Rota's opera buffa The Italian Straw Hat, which was presented by the John Brownlee Opera Theater of the Manhattan School of Music on Thursday night. (It will be repeated tonight and tomorrow afternoon.)

description: Handled Legal Aspects of Major Projects of New York Authority

title: Pursuing the Letelier Killers
description: At long last there are signs of progress, both in this country and in Chile, in the effort to bring to justice the murderers of Orlando Letelier, who was Foreign Minister in the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens. Mr. Letelier and an American assistant died in Washington in September 1976, when their car was destroyed by plastic explosives. Two weeks before his death he naa been ostentatiously stripped of his citizenship by the Chilean junta that overthrew and killed Mr. Allende. Mr. Letelier was one of the most prominent and effective critics of the junta.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSJeanne, loving wife of the late Albert. Beloved mother of Iris Llbresco. and grandmother of Joshua, Nicole and Andrea. Sister of Rose Moses, Lillian Lipner and Aaron Orenstein. Services Sunday, March 12; 12:30PM in The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Proxmire Sees Conflict of Interest
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, charged the Treasury Department today with an apparent conflict of interest in awarding

title: City Ballet Musicians Agree to Saratoga Pact
description: The New York City Ballet will perform as scheduled next summer at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. A jurisdictional dispute between New York City Local 802 and Saratoga Springs Local 506 of the American Federation of Musicians had threatened to cancel the company's 13th annual summer season, scheduled to run for three weeks, from July 5.

title: DESAI DEFENDS CRITICISM OF SIKKIM'S ANNEXATION
description: NEW DELHI, March 10Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai bluntly told the opposition in Parliament today that he still believed that the manner in which Sikkim's merger with India was carried out was a wrone step.

title: UNIONS BOLT TALKS WITH NEW YORK CITY
description: Municipal unions abruptly broke otf contract negotiations with New York City yesterday, complaining that they could not continue unless the administration of Mayor Koch withdrew what they called its outrageous and retrogressive demands for contract rollbacks.

title: Opening of Talks With Greece Called Positive by Turkish Leader
description: MONTREAUX, Switzerland, March 10 Prime Ministers Constantine CaramanHs of Greece and Bulent Ecevit of Turkey faced each other for the first time here today and vowed objective approaches to solving some of the problems that have brought their countries to the brink of war.

title: Answers to Weekly Quiz
description: 1.Resolution 242, which was drafted to guide peace efforts after the 1967 war, between Israel and the Arabs, called for Israeli withdrawal from occupied Arab territories. Prime iMnister menachim Begin of Israel contends that the resolution does not apply to the Gaza Strip and the West Bank; the United Stalin says it does.

title: Wisconsin Wins U.S. Curling
description: UTICA, N.Y., March 10 (UPI)A Wisconsin rink, skipped by Bob Nichols, cinched the United States men's curling championships today with its tenth straight victory. Wisconsin next will compete in Winnipeg, Manitoba, March 25 in the world championships. Teams from ten countries will participate.

title: REBEL SCHOOL BOARD SUSPENDED BY ANKER OVER QUEENS DISPUTE
description: School Chancellor lrying Anker yesterday suspended the board of Community School District 26 in Queens, because has refused his request for an ethnic breakdown of its students and faculty members.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP)The senate voted today to amend the Panama Canal treaties to insure that the United States could intervene militarily if any nation sought to block the waterway.

title: Archimedes Mirrors: Some New Reflections
description: Like many ancient legends, the one about Archimedes setting fire to an attacking Roman fleet using sunlight concentrated by mirrors has its doubters, and they have touched off a lively controversy among scientists and historians.

description: A speculative flurry of investor interest in realestate stocks is apparently keyed to a turnaround in the malty market. Page 31.

title: Study Finds Use of Alcohol At Colleges Is Up Sharply
description: BOSTON, March 10The use of alcohol by college students has substantially increased in the last 25 years, especially among women, and most students establish their drinking patterns while still in high school, according to a study published today by the Medical Foundation.

title: Handicapped Maintain a Maryland Town
description: ST. CHARLES, Md.  On a snowrimmed, muddy road in this 8,000acre new town an hour from Washington, six people were at work clearing away the debris of a throwaway culture with the thoroughness of harvesters stripping a Kansas wheat field.

description: Of Cannibals and Mr. Cuervo

title: Ethiopian Diplomat Calls Soviet and Cuban Troops A Nonnegotiable Subject
description: ROME, March 10 (UPI)A spokesman for the Ethiopian Embassy said today that the presence of Cuban and Soviet troops in Ethiopia was not subject to negotiation in the Ogaden conflict.

title: Porter's Gay Divorce Revived by E.L.T.
description: Even after more than 40 years, Cole Porter's 1932 The Gay Divorce carries memories that have lasted, memories that have been supplemented and renewed by television showings of the screen version, The Gay DivorceeNight and Day, Fred Astaire, Eric Blore's meticulous but fuzzy mouthings and Erik Rhodes's narcissistic professional divorce co-respondent.

title: Loretta LeVeck Watson Wed to W.C. Weitzel Jr.
description: Loretta LeVeck Watson and William Conrad Weitzel Jr., general counsel of Texaco Inc., in White Plains, were married yesterday in St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Frederick T., Bender performed the ceremonv.

title: Levitt Thinks That 24 Years is Enough, But That Doesn't Mean He's Quitting
description: ALBANY, March 9State Comptroller Arthur Levitt says it is time for him to retire from the post he has held for 24 yearsbut he adds an if that makes it hard to tell whether or not he will be running for reelection once azain come November.

title: Against Oil and Gas Price Controls
description: NORTHBROOK, Ill.Energy remains our country's most urgent problem, but there's been no agreement on a sound national energy policy.

title: Notes on People
description: United Airlines newest pilot is Gail Gorski, who was chosen Queen of the Kentucky Derby in 1972, Miss Gorski received her wings yesterday at the United Airlines Flight Training Center in Denver. She's a veteran pilot with 1,730 hours at the controls, has worked as a corporate pilot and as a flight instructor and for a time was a flight inspector for the Federal Aviation Administration In Atlanta.

title: U.S. MinorityHiring Plan Assailed
description: Proposed Federal Labor Department regulations would severely curtail efforts to require the hiring of blacks and other minorities on federally financed construction pobs in New York and other large cities, according to city and state affirmativeaction officials.

title: MIXUP SNAGS EFFORT TO OPEN COAL MINES
description: WASHINGTON, March 10Amid confusion over the Governments competence in enforcing the TaftHartley 80day back-to-work order that the Carter Administration obtained yesterday against the nation's 160,000 striking miners, renewed bargaining for a negotiated settlement recessed tonight, with new talks scheduled tomorrow at 10 A.M.

description: MOSCOW, March 10 (AP)A Soviets and a Czechoslovak astronaut returned to Earth today from the Soviet Salyut 6 space station, leaving two other Soviet astronauts aboard, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

description: Reports that the first human clone is now in existence and well on his way to becoming a taxpayer have raised many questions about cloning. Here are some of the answers:

title: Psychologist Studies the Storms That Come With the Changing Seasons of Life
description: The professor was struggling through his early 40's, and his life seethed with changes. After 16 years at Harvard, he was contemplating a move to Yale. His father died, and he, an only child with close ties to his parents, was plunged into a painful period of adjustment. His wife, a fellow psychologist who had often worked with him in the past, wanted to strike out on her own. And, like most people confronting middle age, he found himself beset with anxieties about the aging process and how it was transforming his selfimage.

title: COURT RULES WOMAN WAS INSANE IN KILLING
description: CAMDEN, March 10Roxanne Gay was ruled insane today and acquitted in the fatal stabbing in 1976 of her husband, Blenda, a professional football player for the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: SAIJI HASEGAWA
description: TOKYO, March 10 (AP)Saiji Hasegawa, president of Japan's Jiji news service from its founding in 1945 until 1972, died today of a heart attack, hospital officials said. He was 74 years old. In 1945, the

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal District Court judge ruled that Bole:days Maikovskis, a 73-yearold retired carpenter from Mineola, Li., must. testify in a deportation hearing on an accusation that he concealed a record of wartime atrocities in his native Latvia when he entered the United States in 1951.

title: Train Achieves 187 M.P.H.
description: TOKYO, March 10 (AP)Japanese railway engineers announced today that an electric rail car had attained a speed of 187 miles per hour in a test run and that they plan to pass 300 m.p.h. next year. In operation, the experimental 10ton ML500 is magnetically lifted five inches above the rails to cut friction.

title: South Africa Ties to Fight Are Scored
description: Plans to shift a proposed Leon SpinksMuhammad Ali rematch to the island nation of Mauritius in the Indian Ocean were met yesterday with stiffening opposition from groups objecting to South African financing of the $14 million bout. Top Rank Inc., promoter of the heavyweight title fight projected for sometime in September, bowed Thursday to antiapartheid pressure and shifted the site from Bophuthatswana, a black homeland recently set up by the South African Government.

title: MOSCOW SAID TO LINK PULLOUTS BY CUBANS, SOMALIS IN ETHIOPIA
description: WASHINGTON, March 10The Soviet Union has informed the United States that Cuban military forces in Ethiopia will be substantially reduced once Somali troops are withdrawn from the Ogaden area and fighting stops, reporters at the State Department were told this evening.

And What's Better Than a Real Irish Paddy for the Big Parade?; A Trying Day for Patrick; In the Beginning; A Rousing Reception; Kidnapped at the Plaza
description: JERSEY CITY, March 10When Patrick J. Kenny, a Dublin policeman, marched in this city's first St. Patrick's Day parade in 1963, the city's taverns ran out of beer.

title: Quashing the District 26 Rebellion
description: Irving Anker, Chancellor of New York City's schools, has suspended the District 26 Community School Board in Queens for refusing to submit an ethnic survey of its students and faculty, data needed to qualify for $6.2 million in Federal funds. The Chancellor has appointed a trustee to carry out his mandate. Mr.. Anker's strong action was necessary; the district board had failed to discharge its responsibilities.

description: WASHINGTON, March 10The time has come in the life of the Carter Administration when the tidy facade of harmonious collaboration has begun to crack and the Government is speaking with conflicting voices.

title: Combined Is Holding Merger Discussions
description: The Combiged Communications Corporation, owner of The Cincinnati Inquirer as well as broad radio, television and outdoor advertising interests, disclosed in Phoenix yesterday that it was holding merger talks with a larger, unidentified company.

description: MOSCOW, March 10 (AP)A Soviets and a Czechoslovak astronaut returned to Earth today from the Soviet Salyut 6 space station, leaving two other Soviet astronauts aboard, Tass, the Soviet news agency, reported.

description: The National Marine Fisheries Service has closed down the surfclamming industry until April 1 because harvesters have exceeded their quotas for the first three months of 1978.

description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Securities and Exchange Commission has broCight its first court action under the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the new law that prohibits bribery of foreign officials by United States companies.

title: International Talents Show Their Style
description: Sooner or later everybody who has anything to do with the business of making clothes shows up in New York with his wares. The lures are the big stores, the fashion shows staged for an honorable charity, the chance to widen the circle of customers. So in the past week, there were French, Italian and German visitors, with the local talent making some noise of its own.

title: Man With a Long Police Record Charged With the Murder of a Follower of Sun Myung Moon Last Month
description: A 31-year-old man with a long record of arrests for violent crimes was charged yesterday with the Feb. 24 slaying of woman follower of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon in East Harlem, where she had gone to distribute copies of a newspaper associated with the evangelist's Unification Church.

title: FATAH ADMITS RAID
description: TEL AVIV, Sunday, March 12Between 20 and 30 Israeli civilians were killed yesterday when Palestinian terrorists landed by boat, seized a bus and fought with policemen, the Israeli radio said. About 70 other civilians were wounded in the incident, in which the bus burst into flames during a gunfight between the terrorists and the police on the outskirts of Tel Aviv.

title: Sports Today
description: N.C.A.A. playoffs, Midwest Regional doubleheader: St. John's vs. Louisville and Noire Dame vs. Houston, at Tulsa. Okla.. (TelevisionChannel 4, 2 and 4 P.M., respectively.)

title: Hans Koning's Gezellig Amsterdam
description: Nothing is more dangerous, I suppose, than to try to sum up the individuality of a city in a single word. But if I had to settle for one adjective that distills Amsterdam's peculiar genius, it would be the Dutch word gezellig. Attempts at pre- cise translation are likely to spawn a series of nearmisses; but in essence, gezellig means both cozy and convivial, both intimate and sociable. The blend of these various shades of meaning adds up to an aspect of character that is more pronounced in Amsterdammers than in other inhabitants of Hollandand surely more pronounced than in city dwellers of other lands. If it werent for Amsterdam, in fact, one might logically assume that bigcity life and gezelligheidthe noun for this bent of personality and preference justdo not mix.

title: Emmylou Harris-Her Heart Is Still in Country Music
description: Emmylou Harris-country rock recording star and member of the Studio City, Calif. P. T. A.was home the other day, resting up between finishing a month of recording with Linda Ronstadt and Dolly Parton and setting out on a fiveweek European tour. If she hasn't been home as much as she would like lately, she's still been there a lot more than she ever was before. the new house she shares with her husband and producer Brian Ahern, her eight-year-old daughter.Hallie and 10-year-old stepdaughter Shannon, is the first permanent address she's had in years. At age 30, she has just bought her first livingroom sofa (also her first pool cue), and is learning how to cook.

title: State Labor Department Rebuts Allegations of Westchester Aides About CETA Plan
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 11The State Labor Department took issue today. wrath assertions by Westchester County leaders that it had failed to certify applicants adequately for Comprehensive Employment and Training Act jobs that are now under investigation.

title: South Africa and the Davis Cup: What the Issue Really
description: The biggest protest since the 1960's is in prospect foE the Davis Cup tennis matches at Nashville, Tenn., starting Friday between the United States and South Africa. There were similar demonstrations at tennis events at the Spectrum in Philadelphia; Eastbourne. England; Newport Beach, Calif., and Forest Hills in Queens.

title: Motor Sports Calendar
description: TodayRaritan Valley Sports Car Club noviceoriented T.S.D. rally; start at Somerset Shopping Center (behind Sears), junction of Routes202, 206 and 28, Somerville, N.J. Registration: noon; first car off 1:01 P.M.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Lou Feintuch of Wood. mere, N.Y. announce the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl, io Mr. Andrew Mark Drazan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Drazan of Rock. ville Centre, New York.

title: Teleprompter to Offer New PayTV Channel
description: Teleprompter Manhattan Cable TV will begin Monday to offer its subscribers a new local paytelevision channel on which, for a monthly fee of $3.95, viewers will be able to receive entertainment specials and motion pictures in their original form and without commercials.

title: One Battle Is Left for a Judge, Now Dead, Who Faced Job Loss
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1When Judge Willis W. Ritter ct the Utah Federal District Court died a week ago in Salt Lake City, some people may have assumed that his years in the center of controversy were ended, his voice stilled.

title: Coal Supplies Reported by Energy Dept.to Have Evened Out for Midwest Utilities Affected by Strike
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The distri bution of available coal supplies among utilities in the Middle West that are most affected by the miners strike has been substantially evened out over the last three weeks, according to Energy Department officials.

title: Deaths
description: ADAMSJeanne, loving wife of the late Albert. Beloved mother of Iris Libresco. and grandmother of Joshua, Nicole and Andrea. Sister of Rose Moses, Lillian Lipner and Aaron Orenstein. Services Sunday, March 12, 12:30PM in The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Long Beach: Hope in a City in Transition
description: LONG BEACH LIKE a grayhaired woman sitting at the window of faded seaside hotel and waiting to be warmed by the winter sun, the City of Long Beach, its boardwalk and buildings silvered by nearly a century hard weather and use, is hoping that gambling casinos, which have been proposed, may bring a new, golden era.

title: Jamaica's Humor Engages a Visitor
description: For a warm, gloomdefying sense of humor you cannot beat Jamaica. Even in lean times, in late spring and summer, when tourists glide in from the skies less frequently, people face life with some oil of ribbing and kidding and verbal byplay. A visitor is always in- cluded. The contrast between the high spirits and the setting of a lowincome tropical island yields some surrealistic episodes.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Housework is really very boring, a friend mine once said in what amounted to a longdelayed consciousness breakthrough. House work is boring, but somebody has to do it unless you can adapt to living in garbage. One of the repeated criticisms made by women seeking raise the consciousness of movie makers not long ago was that most roles offered to actresses were of women as ad- juncts to menwives, mistresses, whores, homemakers, sex objects, dishivashing machines. Now that we've apparently entered an era when women in movies can be seen having careers (The Turning Point,, Julia) and friendships (Julia and 3 Women), giving expression to sexual needs (Coming. Home, Looking for Mr. Goodbar, The End the World in Our Usual Bed on a Night Full of Rain), or making serious decisions about living as themselves, without men as emotional crutches (An Unmarried Woman), I keep wondering who's doing the housework for them.

title: The Panama Canal From the Sky Deck
description: It is 6:30 A.M. Our ship moves cautiously through curtains of mist toward the Atlantic end of the Panama Canal. We are in the bay of Limon, where, I remember from my reading, Columbus coasted along the shoreline on Christmas Day, 1502, vainly looking for an opening seaway to what he thought was Asia, not far beyond.

title: MOOD OF CONFIDENCE MARKS REVIVED TALKS ON STRIKE BY MINERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 11Voluntary bargaining to settle the 96-day-old coal miners strike took on a new atmosphere of confidence today, with both sides fearing that three decades of industrywide negotiations would end if no settlement was reached this weekend.

title: Niceties of Eating Affect Obesity, Tests Show
description: The kinds of amenities that many people enjoy at the dinner tablean attractive goblet, a bit of candlelighthave been used in an experiment to show the degree to which the eating habits of obese people are controlled by influences beyond their physiological needs.

title: Garden Allies by Mail
description: From now until planting time , a lot of funny things will ar- rive in my mailbox: earthwo rms, praying mantis egg cases and ladybugs. When I put out my seeds, I like to put

title: Jonathan HenningBauer Weds- Susan A. Zetkov
description: The marriage of Susan Anne Zetkov to Jonathan HenningBauer took place yesterday at the Palm Beach, Fla., home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Edward Zetkov, who also live in Briarcliff Manor, N. Y. Mr. and Mrs. Richarl Joseph Bauer of Newburrrh N Y are the bridegroom's parents. The Rev. Charles Schaum, Presbyterian minister from Newburgh, performed the ceremony.

title: Suspension of Queens Board Linked to Koch's Policy
description: A high official of the New York City Board of Education said yesterday the suspension of a Queens community school board that refused to submit ethnic data was in accord with the Koch administration's effort to gain greater control over the city's school system.

title: Living Simply: Americans in Spain
description: Getting there is not half the fun. Not when you're going to Agua Amarga, small village on the southern coast of Spain in the area between the Costa del SOl and the Costa Blancawhat we came to call the Costa de Nada.

title: TURIN REACTS ANGRILY TO OFFICER'S MURDER
description: TURIN, Italy, March IITurin burled its latest victim todaya police officer whose death has shaken the city from its lethargic response to terrorism Into a heated debate on how to deal with urban guerrillas who have chosen the city Its one of their main targets.

title: Winter Drove More Waterfowl South This Year
description: ALBANYWhere have all the waterfowl gone?

title: Miss Costanza Loses Some Duties
description: MILWAUKEE, March 11 (AP)Miss Costanza said today that responsibility for liaison with business and trade representatives would be removed from her office under a reorganization of the White House staff.

title: Of Vietnam and Gold and the Cauldron of 68
description: The rancor over Vietnam was at a peak. Who cared about gold and the dol- lar?

title: FOUNDATION WOES THE SAGA OF HENRY FORD II: PART TWO
description: THE story of Henry Ford 2d is oneneatly enoughof victor) and defeat. When he was 26 he came back from the Navy, fought for the control of a nearly bankrupt company and in 10 years rebuilt it into one of the largest industrial corporations in Ilw world. In 1949, he controlled what was to become the largest foundation in the world. But by 1976, he admitted defeat and abandoned the foundation to forces he had come to regard as hostile to everything he believed in.

title: Opposition Claims 31 Votes
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The Carter Administration and its Senate allies, worried about a crucial vote Thursday on one of two Panama Canal treaties, have sought to influence undecided Senators by agreeing to a reservation to the act that would make it easier to keep United States troops in Panama after the year 1999.

title: 18 Fire Companies and 3 Fireboats Subdue a Blaze on Jersey City Pier
description: A multiple alarm fire on an unoccupied Jersey City pier was brought under control late last night after 18 fire companies as well as three New York City and Coast Guard fireboats arrived to battle the .spectacular blaze, fire officials said.

description: BRADLEY BEACH SOMEONE once estimated that there were 15 inches sand along the New Jersey oceanfront for every man, woman and child in the state. On some busy July 4th weekends in the past, it often appeared that just about everyone had arrived to stake a claim.

title: Parents Miss Chance to Aid Children's Sexual Growth
description: AFEW years ago, as a nurse in a Planned Parenthood clinic. I would sometimes be counseling young teenagers when my mind would somersault to my own 14-year-old at home alone, and I'd feel a sudden apprehension as I realized she could, just maybe, be one of these, the millions of young people in need of or seeking help.

title: The Show Must Go On
description: I wonder how many ballet companies landed in the wrong country because of blizzards, or how many musicians refused to play in unheated halls, carrying their delicate instruments along icy paths?

description: AIR infiltration through small cracks and other openings in exterior walls, or around the edges of loosefitting doors and windows, can account for a surprisingly large amount of wasted energy both in the winter, when the house is heated, and in the summer, when it is air-conditioned. Some experts feel that caulking and weatherstripping can save as much energy as insulation.

title: 473 Homeowners on L.I. Decide To Let the Sun Heat Their Water
description: Spurred by a Federal program that pays a portion of the cost for a solar heating system, 473 Long Island homeowners have decided to let the sun provide for ???? notwater needs.

title: Florida Court Says Birth Begins After Infant Leaves the Mother
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 11 (AP)Birth under Florida law does not occur until an infant's body is separated from the mother, says a sharply divided Florida Supreme Court, ruling in a wrongfuldeath suit.

title: Joan Lombardi's 3 New Dances Display WideRanging Themes
description: It came as no surprise that a program of dance by Joan Lombardi at the American Theater Laboratory on Friday was one of taste and wit. But Miss Lombardi has grown, and, on the strength of that concert, she seems to be one or the most literate choreographers around. Hers is a literacy founded on a sure sense of her craft and the special visual clarity Miss Lombardi, a graphic designer as well as a former member of the Paul Sanasardo and Anna Sokolow companies, brings to dance.

description: Some of the worst pictures painted anywhere and at any time are of flowers.
