description: The marquee at the Palladium advertised Angel, Judas Priest, and the Godz on Friday night. Was the show, perhaps, a religious festival? A convocation of Jesus rock bands? Well, no. If anything was being worshipped, it was the dark forces, but as it turned out the program did not offer anything that was even seriously sinister.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: pOSSIBLY onethird of the population is affiliated with fundamentalistevangelical sects, and there has been a rapid growth over the past 10 years of religious publishers and bookstores catering to these bornagain Christians. Herewith a quick survey of the evangelical field.

description: GENEVA, March 11The northsouth dialogue between the rich and poor nations was given new life today when the developing countries settled for a pledge that solutions to their debt problems would be sought by the industrialized countries.

description: There were sounds of a struggle backstage at the Music Box Theaterchairs being overturned, muffled cries, fallingbody thumps. Upstairs in his dressing room, John Wood nodded his satisfaction and smile creased his bony face. Mr. Wood is the star and chief troublemaker of Ira Levin's new thriller, Deathtrap, and the sounds of murder most foul are music to his ears.

description: AMERICAN public education continues to be the target of state and Federal politicians as competencyproficiency legislation spreads throughout the nation. Dissatisfaction with the general level of the high school graduate appears to be a major concern. As of January, 26 states had enacted some form of competencyproficiency standards.

description: MONTREUX, Switzerland, March 11A conference of the leaders of Greece and Turkey ended here today with an attack against the Carter Administration by the Turkish Prime Minister, Bulent Ecevit.

description: Sara Fifield Morey and Dale Richard Floody will be married May 13 in Princeton, N.J.

Newspapers were carrying advertisements in which a woman was shown standing over a. toilet bowl urging people to vote yes lest their drinking water be polluted by sewage.

title: Suit to Bar Nuclear Reactor Cites Terrorist Risk
description: Danger from urban terrorists and sabotage is being- cited by New York City in a legal argument seeking to establish through Federal Court a local right to control location of nuclear reactors because of pEculiar local considerations.

title: Modernists Make Brooklyn A New Home
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music opened in 1908 with an operatic recital by Ernestine SchumannHeink and a production of Faust starring Geraldine Farrar and Enrico Caruso. Although Vaslav Nijinsky was an early attraction and Rudolf Nureyev made his American debut there, the Academy had no strong tradition of dance until its current president, Harvey Lichtenstein, assumed direction.

title: State Is Keeping An Eye on Doctors
description: TRENTON NEW JERSEY has become pacesetter in protecting the public health by disciplining physicians guilty of malpractice and other professional misdeeds, according to Alfred J. Schuster of the state's Board of Medical Examiners.

title: Guide for Parents Suggests Ways To Avoid Sexist ChildRearing
description: When you say to parents: Would you like to raise your girl to be feminine and your boy to be masculine? they always say, Yes! Yes!

title: Horn of Africa Likely to RemainConflict Zone
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 11Despite Somalia's agreement to retreat from Ethiopia's Ogaden area and United States appeals for the withdrawal of Soviet and Cuban forces that have been supporting Ethiopia, diplomats here feel that the region will not quickly return to peaceful obscurity.

title: At Home: Fire Company
description: Each of us sees different things. watch my friends faces grow thoughtful as the fire absorbs their vacant eyes. Some of them look melancholy, as they are reflecting on the fact that all life is only a burning up of energy, that, in a sense, we all go down in flames. For others, the fire is like a Rorschach test: They see in it whatever is uppermost in their minds.

title: Headliners
description: Last year, Hustler magazine's creator and publisher, Larry Flynt, announced his conversion to bornagain Christianity and later, at a rally in Waterloo, Iowa, proclaimed his conviction that he was willing to die for his God. Last week, Mr. Flynt and his lawyer, Gene Reeves Jr., barely escaped death when they were shot as they walked down a street in Lawrenceville, S.C., where local authorities were trying to obtain another conviction for Mr. Flynt - in this case, on charges distributing obscene material. After three operations, Mr. Flynt now lies in what doctors called satisfactory condition in Atlanta's Emory University Hospital, where he has been visited by Ruth Stapleton, President Carter's sister, who knew him before his conversion. But the surgeon who removed a bullet from Mr. Flynt's lower back on Thursday said the shooting had caused severe damage to a mass of nerves near the spinal column, and that there was less than a 50 percent chance complete regeneration. Mr. Flynt may never walk again. Mr. Reeves was also reported in satisfactory condition.

title: Italy Forms Cabinet Aided by Communists
description: ROME, March 11 (AP)Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti formed today Cabinet of Christian Democrats that lie said would be supported in Parliament by the Commun'sts, Italy's second largest party.

title: Stephen Davoust Fiance Of MaryEileen Lohr
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph B. Lohr of Wayne, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, MaryEileen Lohr, to Stephen G. Davoust, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Davoust of Cortlandt Manor, N. Y. The wedding is planned for May 20.

title: Carey Reports Savings in Medicaid:
description: ALBANY, March 10Governor C:rey hns released a report heralding savings of more than $97 million in state Medicaid and welfare costs in this fiscal year, resulting from his continuing drive to reduce and control such expenditures.

title: Judith Rockefeller Engaged
description: Mrs. Hugh C. Wallace of Greenville. Del., and Godfrey A. Rockefeller of Gibson Island, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Judith Stillman Rockefeller, to Raphael J. de la Gueronniere, son of Mrs. Longer de la Gueronniere and Joseph Daum, both of New Orleans,

title: Sparkling Future Is Seen For Diamond Cutter, 16, With Growing Reputation
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va. (AP)At the age of 16, Don Goffaux had a solid start on his ambition in life. 'I want to cut the perfect stone, said the studious, slightly built high school sophomore.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: IN New Jersey, 89 percent of its residents live in urban areas, according to Governor Byrne. It is not surprising, therefore, that he wants the Carter Administration's new na- tional urban policy to provide tax incentives to private industries to locate and expand in urban locations, especially as a means of revitalizing decaying old cities.

title: Sheriff Greets Burglars
description: LA MESA, Calif. (UPI)Robert Kerns, deputy shriff, said that he saw two men and a woman acting suspiciously outside his home. He watched while they cased the house and waited patiently for them to finish breaking in the front door. When they did, he arrested them.

title: MANNERS MATTER
description: We are in a state of absolute anarchy as far as the manners and courtesy of today's children and teenagers are concerned. No, it's not some relic of the Victorian era sneaking, it's the very model of a modern psychologist. Dr. Fitzhugh Dodson to be precise. Dr. Dodson, a worldrenowned authority and author of several books on child raising, wants to see a return to the 14th century dictum of William of Wykeham that manners maketh man. After all, as he says, one of the reasons good manners exist is to make society move smoothly, and the sooner a child realizes this, the easier his path through life will be.

title: World Health Organization Has Identified Them
description: One of the major phenomena of recent decades has been the explosion in the number of drugs marketed throughout the world. Thousands of products have become available, and there is a growing recognition that drugs are not always used to their full potential, nor according to guidelines espoused by experts in pharmacology. At the same time, governments of industrialized and developing countries are becoming increasingly concerned about the rising costs of pharmaceutical products.

title: Elizabeth L. Barbato Will Be Wed in June To Mark Harrington
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Barbato of Plandome, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Leslie Barbato, to Mark Garland Harrington of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Hampton Harrington of San Antonio. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Feldman Offers Sonatas For the Cello
description: Cello sonatas by Bach, Dmitri Kabalevsky, Samuel Barber and Franck occupied Marion Feldman's attention in Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night. With four such stylistically dissimilar composers on the program, musical diversity was assured, and on the whole Miss Feldman, together with her admirable partner at the piano, Gena Raps, rose to the occasion with four sensitively conceived and technically polished performances.

title: Years of Wrangling Have Ended in a Single Sentence, Fraught With Meaning
description: WASHINGTON - The settlement of one of the bitterest feuds on Capitol Hill was announced early this month in one brief sentence in the Congressional Record. Under the heading Technology Assessment Board, the item stated: The board held a closed business meeting where it authorized the Director of O.T.A. to appoint, supervise, and discharge em. ployees, including contractors of and consultants to the O.T.A.

title: Pitney Bowes, a Munchkin Among the Copier Giants
description: The tricks of no-holds-barred competi- tion are hard to learn when a company. is accustomed to resting on mammoth market shares. Pitney Bowes Inc., whose name is synonymous with post- age meters, learned that the hard way. Its first major diversification attempt a foray into the electronic cash register business - lasted only four years and cost the Stamford, Conn., based corporation $81 million.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: SNOWBLIND, by Robert Sabbag. (Avon, $2.25.) How a wellborn, welleducated Manhattan advertising man drifted into a second career - the smuggling of drugs from Mexico and Colombia but was finally arrested at his Amagansett, L.I., beach house. mostly engrossing, mostly convincing report on the ways of the international underworld and its ties to New York's beautiful people.

title: Carter Drops Opposition to House Vote on Postal Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 11The White House has unexpectedly dropped its opposition to a House vote on a pending postal bill that would provide More Federal subsidies. The bill would also give the President authority to appoint the Postmaster General.

title: Man Thrown From Fourth Floor By Robber Who Used Toy Gun
description: A 29-year-old man was seriously injured yesterday when he was thrown out of a window of his fourthfloor hotel room at 273 West 38th Street in Manhattan by a robber.

title: Then Came the Oil Search And Dreams of Riches
description: FINCHVILLE, N.Y.In this small community, 65 miles northwest of midtown Manhattan, the Gulf Oil Corporation's flag, white and orange with blue lettering, snaps smartly in the breeze beside a milliondollar (and counting) hole in the ground.

title: Puzzling Kipling
description: ONE of the more grotesque falsifications taste, and it is usually propounded in schools, is the pious belief that a work of literature must be morally pure and rightminded before it can wholly satisfy us. No villain can enthrall us, the argu- ment runs; no villainy or repulsive opinion can persuade or inspire. And yet if this were so, half of literature would be lost to us in our selfdenying refusal to see, as Angus Wilson puts it in this superb critical biography of Rudyard Kipling, the difficult truth that aesthetic satisfaction is not one with ethical satisfaction. There are morally disgusting stories that one reads with absolute enchantment and, from the Jacobeans onward, villains who are truer and vastly more enjoyable than saintly heroes who never put foot wrong.

title: Jane Loraine Koehn Betrothed to David T. Nutt Jr.
description: Jane Loraine Koehn, a technical service representative with Reynolds & Reynolds in Los Angeles, plans to be married April 15 in Cincinnati to David Tysen Nutt Jr. cf Los Angeles, an assistant to the director and dialogue coach on the NBCTV series Chico and the Man.

title: F. Ray Marshall Saw It Coming Long Ago
description: WASHINGTQN  It was a slightly raw winter's day on Dec. 28,1976, when Presidentelect Jimmy Carter summoned his designated Cabinet Secretaries to St. Simons Island, Ga. for a review of difficulties likely to arise during the first year of his Administration.

title: Religious Best Sellers
description: The accompanying three lists of bestselling religious books of 1977 are based on a representative national sampling of the 2,500 bookstores affiliated with the Christian Booksellers Association. The King James Version of the Bible, a perennial best seller, is not included in the list of Bibles and guides. Books sold in religious bookstores cover a wide range of subjects: for example, from Christ and His Gospel as Preached by Billy James Hargis to Shall We Give Away the Panama Canal?  by Dr. Jose Hernandez, both published by the Christian Crusade in Tulsa, Okla.

title: A Long Ago Day When a Haircut Was Just That
description: I wasn't the only one who disliked them. The other kids on my block, almost every kid I knew for that matter, couldn't (stand them either. To our parents, who Insisted we visit them so regularly, they were a necessity, like clean clothes and shined shoes, vital to our appearance and respectability.

title: MARKETS
description: The stock market was a study in contrasts last week. It started out in the doldrums and wound up with a rousing rally on Friday that put the Dow Jones industrial average ahead by 11.27 points for the week. The bluechip indicator finished at 758.58.

title: Carter Economic Policies, Laudable in Intent, Aren't Helping

title: AUDIT SHOWS AGENCY HID ITS CONSULTANTS

Two consultants were paid $465 a day, more than three times what the law allows.

title: The Hudson: Too Much to Swallow
description: THE Army Corps of Engineers is designing a $4.6 billion system to import Hudson River water to New York City and Nassau County, at a potential cost to Nassau taxpayers of $800 million. Aside from the expense, there are serious hydrological and publichealth flaws in the plan.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 10 (AP) Mark I. Frizell, a 23-year-old Rutgers University alumnus who was partially blinded by a fraternity fireworks duel, has accepted a $90,000 settlement.

title: Segregation Found To Persist in State
description: This finding was offered to the commission orally by representatives of the Regional Planning Association, a private organization assisting TriState in developing programs for the populous area. It was not known whether the association would issue a printed report. The conclusions were given to the commission's Committee on Housing, Community Development and Social Services.

title: Connecticut/ThisWeek

title: LETTER TO   THE  EDITOR;
description: Because of my firm belief in the twoparty system, and despite the fact that I am solidly a Democrat, I support and respect the efforts of the Republicans to make a political comeback (The Republicans Try to Get Their Act Together by Tom Wicker, Feb. 12). However, I find some of their tactics a little disconcerting. Most offensive is their attempt not to win the black vote but to get just enough of it in order to make possible some crucial Republican victories. It is obvious that in order to win over a necessary minority group the Republicans will employ all sorts of schemes, none with any real intention of helping

But Long Island anglers will be benefiting at the expense of commercial cod fisher men, who now are feeling the long arm of the National Marine Fisheries Serv- ice.

title: Lutheran Council Votes to Accept, Group Created in Split of Synod

Now, equivocation by the Department of Justice about obeying court orders in the case raises unsettling questions About the Government's devotion to law in the present.

title: Owolabi, Double Victor, Sets State Track Mark
description: ITHACA, N.Y., March 11Sanya Owolabi of Sleepy Hollow High School set a state record in the triple jump v..:Lh a leap of .50 feet 61 inches and also won the long jump today at the New York State.public high school indoor track and field championships in Barton Hail on the campus of Cornell University.

title: TV VIEW
description: After officially closing a couple of weeks ago, the play Paul Robeson is back on Broadway, due largely to the efforts of Joseph Papp, the produc- er, and, in what must be a unique twist, to a series of reports carried on a local television news nro2ram. WNBC's NewsCenter 4 provided a forum. The reportercommentator was Carl Stokes, formerly coanchorman for WNBC's news and, before that, the first black mayor of Cleveland. As an anchorman, Mr. Stokes was amiable and attractive but somewhat halting. He does not read the news exceptionally well. But as the dominant personality of a special news segment called Urban Journal, he has developed into a firstrate investigative journalist, justifiably respected for his quiet forcefulness and unusual tenacity in following through on a story.

title: Fat Times in New Haven
description: NEW HAVEN

title: 7,500 Hit by Delays on the L.I.R.R.
description: More than 7,500 Long Island Rail Road riders encountered delays of up to tWo hours yesterday when a power failure affecting signal and switching equipment forced a shut down of service in both directions between Penn Station in Mal. haltan and Jamaica, Queens.

title: Future of A's and Giants Getting Test on Coast
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 11A final effort to remove the A's from Oakland to Denver and leave the Bay Area to the San Francisco Giants, who would play games in both cities, will face a major test Monday when the San Francisco Board of Supervisors considers the matter at a formal meeting.

title: ROUGH, TOUGH KIDS STUFF
description: Once upon a time, everything made for children was special. From changing tables in the nursery to miniature easels in the playroom, they were -practical for only their brief moment in time. But now there are industrial products that, used with a little imagination, can be adapted for children and will grow with them. The ones shown here will be longlived and will remain useful as the child grows.

title: Eastern Treasure
description: AHARMLESS enjoyment of life, a minor art form in the community in which I reside, is t he ability to speak knowledgeably about someone, preferably of importance, of whom your audience has never heard. For all so inclined, as well as others better scholarly tone, these three volumes are nearly ideal. Outside of a narrow specialist world, Ananda K. Coomaraswamy is adequately unknown. His contributions to the history of art, to the sources of traditional crafts and numerous other subjects in the first half this century were varied and, subject to some dispute, of high interest.

title: SELECTION
description: THE British Embassy in Bonn, where I was working as a junior diplomat in the early 60's, not on the face of it conducive to literary creation, though it produces untold quantities of written matter. I described its appearance later in A Small Town in Germany: a grey, sprawling, unlovable, cementrendered barracks, indistinguishable from the Mercedes factory, the Coca-Cola factory or the German ministerial buildings which are its neighbors. It was there, nevertheless, behind white-barred windows, in lunch hours, in the early mornings, in the witching hour between office shut-down and the beginning of the Bad Godesberg cocktail round, that I put together The Spy Who Came in From the Cold, the story of Alec Leamas and the girl Liz Gold. I wrote it in three months or so, by hand, as I write this now, and the original version came out.at about a quarter of a million words, though I don't think all of them reached the typing stage: I had already laid the axe to them by then. As I approached the end, the story took me over, as stories usually do, and I was climbing out of bed at three or four in the morning in order to get back to work and find out what was going to happen to everybody.

title: CRIIKE
description: There is nothing very original about FREEWAY by Deanne Barkley (Macmillan, $7.95). The ingredients are familiar, and there are no surprises. But considering that this is Mr. Barkley's first novel, it shows an unusual degree of promise. The writing is assured, the characters are well realized, and there is a completely unsentimental view of life and people.

title: Barbara Allen Engaged To Brendon P. Bernard
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Allen of Wheelock, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Marjorie Hooker Allen, to Brendon Paul Bernard of London. He is a son of Major

title: Those Other Fire Islanders: The YearRounders
description: For most New Yorkers, Fire Island a nearby escape from the. summertime heat and grit of civilization. The narrow boardwalks and the absence of automobiles make its 32 miles of beach seem more remote than it actually is. But for about100 families, Fire Island is a yearround home, and the concerns of these people make them closer in spirit to the Aran Islanders than to their Suffolk County neighbors.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: It is disconcerting to be told that certain photographs are historically important and then go on to see them and find out that they are small, dim and not nearly so im- pressive as the pictures in modern magazines, but this is the kind of experience viewers are likely to have when they go to see the photographs of John Thomson at the Daniel Wolf Gallery, 30 West 57th Street, in a snow running through April 1. With a few exceptions, Thomson's pictures really look antique, and it takes an effort of the imagination grasp their significance.

title: Boy, 15, Gets Life in Slaying
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., March 11 (UPI)James Alan Conner, 15 years old, who had pleaded guilty to firstdegree murder, was sentenced to life imprisonment today after a jury became deadlocked, 84, on whether to send him to prison or the gas chamber. Under state law, if the jury verdict in a capital case is not unanimous, the defendant must be sentenced to life. The boy had pleaded guilty to firstdegree murder in the slaying of Boyd Funderburk, 78, shot in the hack at the home of his son.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IWASN'T the only one who disliked them. The other kids on my block, almost every kid I knew for that matter. couldn't stand them either.

title: Lure of the Woods Captures State's Trappers
description: LIKE his father and grandfather before him, Steve Bergenty is a trapper  one of perhaps 1,000 who earn money by setting traps throughout the state's woodlands and marshes for such valuable animals as beaver, mink and muskrat.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: One wonders just how far to trust a book that argues for an accurate systematic approach research on dance and then comes up with this statement: One of the reigning ballerinas the Imperial Ballet of Moscow, she (Mathilde Kchessinska) reigned as well as the mistress Czar Nicholas II before he ascended the throne. Afterward, she became the wife of Nicholas cousin, the Grand Duke Andre. Unlike many of her friends and patrons, she remained a power after the Revolution. Lenin gave his first public speech from her balcony.

It was a journey that many people believed could not be made. After all, direct travel between Greece and Turkey has been extremely limited since the two countries broke off relations in 1975. Air service is restricted (Sabena, the Belgian airline, flies three times a week between Athens and Istanbul), travel by sea has been heavily curtailed and the train between Athens and Istanbul runs only once a day in each direction,

title: Dave Kingman Is Comfortable Now
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - Like someone who has searched the real estate market, Dave Kingman has found the right home at the right price. As the Chicago Cubs new leftfielder, he will be swinging for home runs in Wrigley Field where he has what he calls a comfortable feeling. His price will be $1.375 million over five years, an- other comfortable feeling, especially after the discomfort of existing on a pinball machine last season, bouncing from the New York Mets to the San Diego Padres to the California Angels to the New York Yankees before he emerged as a free agent. Some baseball people believe that Dave Kingman is now comfortable enough to challenge Roger Maris's major league record of 61 homers, set in 1961 for the Yankees, or surely to threaten the National League mark of 56 homers, set in 1930 by Hack Wilson, another Cubs outfielder. Those people include Dave Kingman himself, who hit home run in each of the Cubs first two exhibition games.

title: Leafless Trees Show Off Their Bark

Although this merit alone should not be the criterion for choice, fascinating texture and pattern do offer a special dimension, especially during the bleak winter months. While waiting out the snowstorms and cold weather, I had an opportunity to observe some of the patterns of tree bark, around suburbia and in the woodlands. It was a challenge to identify the trees by their bark without leaves or flowers to guide me. How many trees can you identify from the phntographs shown? Many are fine landscape specimens Worthy of a place at home.

title: Screen: Gunnel Lindblom's 'Summer Paradise'
description: The weather is perfect, the wild flowers are in bloom, and the old house is so spacious that everyone has his or her own prettily wallpapered room, but all is not right in the film "Summer Paradise"or at least it's not supposed to be. The middle-class extended family that spends its yearly vacations at this idyllic retreat is meant to seem much too complacent for its own good and for anyone else's.As the director Gunnel Lindblom sees it, the ills of the world don't intrude enough to spoil these merry Swedes' good time, and whenever anyone has a bad dream, Grandma, who is a physician, merely prescribes sleeping pills. The family takes its greatest satisfactions in the lake, the flowerbeds and the freshly baked bread.Naturally enough, there are a few termites in the woodwork: The women are lonely, the men are weaklings, and the children are growing up without proper supervision. These things are pointed out by great-grandpa and by grandma's social-worker friend, older people who are wise enough to realize that subsequent generations have gotten further and further out of line. "It's a disgrace to be a human being today, woman," says the social worker at last, in a rather blunt and unconvinicing moment of pique.Miss Lindblom, an actress who worked with Ingmar Bergman in films such as "The Seventh Seal" and "Wild Strawberries." fills "Summer Paradise" with hints of trouble and indications that a great deal is being swept under the rug. However, she never manages to suggest that the family genuinely gives a hoot about any of this, and the film's glimpses of bourgeois guilt are singularly unaffecting. When unrest finally does burst forth at the end of the story, it comes as a bolt out of the much-too-blue sky.Miss Lindblom's point may very well be that people who live life too comfortably aren't even capable of intelligent or moving regret, but that's a poor premise on which to construct a drama; she winds up with two hours' worth of ripples in the water and not a single wave.She also has a tendency to undercut her own points through overemphasis: A lower class mother and son, very conspicuous brunettes in a sea of blondes, are treated with wildly exaggerated rudeness by the others. When, at the end of the film, the little boy sits dejectedly on the lawn, Miss Lindblom photographs him in the foreground of a larger shot, then makes the point in the closeup, and then in even closer closeup than that.Miss Lindblom gets some vivid characterizations out of a distinguished Swedish cast, and she is particularly successful in presenting scenes between lovers with an equal appreciation of male and female sensuality.But there is no sense of real darkness beneath the film's patently artificial light, and the viewer is finally swamped by those very same middle-class amenities that Miss Lindblom means to deplore. One does wind up feeling sick to death of nice-looking people with nicely manageable problems, but that's apparently only half of what Miss Lindblom had in mind.

title: Shame Is the Key
description: FORTY years after it was written, this classic social study has finally been translated from its original German into English. Norbert Elias's The Civilizing Process was the first psychohistory, probably the greatest, and unlike the books of that eenre we have since come to know. The Civilizine Process could also be labeled a great work of historical sociology, challenging both the method and the ideas of Max Weber. Simply as history, the book is radical departure from the goods produced in the academic mills.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Having given us Carl Maria von Weber's Oberon, Eve Queler and the Opera Orchestra of New York will now turn their attention to Rossini's Tancredi, on Tuesday in Carnegie Hall. There's a real rarity for you. Immensely popular during 50 or so years after its premiere in 1813, Tancredi all but dropped out of sight in the latter part of the century. It never was staged by the Metropolitan Opera. It was largely ignored during the belcanto revival of the 1950's, except for one revival in 1952, Florence, with Giulietta Simionato. Until just a few months ago there were no recordings.

title: Sculpture That Starts With Spark Plugs
description: NISSEQUOGUE AFTER spending his day with legal intricacies, Richard Scheyer doffs his lawyer's suit, puts on a pair of mismatched conductor's gloves and a light safari jacket and approaches another bench (in his basement) to get to work on his favorite of many hobbies, metal sculpture.

title: Good Books
description: IT all depends on what you mean by translation. Some years ago I had the task of rendering T.S. Eliot's The Waste Land into Indonesian and, after 10 lines, saw how hopeless it was. Forgetful snow became thalji yang herlupa - impossible, because an inanimate substance could not, to my intended readers, forget  or remember. And thalji, a Persian borrowing anyway, has no referent to the tropics, except for the incrustations of a neglected refrigerator. It couldn't be done. Ever since, I have been prepared to accept as a translation anything that, however freely, conveys the most general sense and feeling of an original. Job Speaks expresses, in contemporary urban terms, the pain of a human being deprived, anguished, alienated. Let the day perish wherein I was born, cries King James's Job, but Rosenberg's:

title: MUSIC
description: IT takes time to build a company that functions as a unit, instead of as a collection of individuals, however talented, and the Gilbert and Sullivan Troupe of the MidWestchester Y. M. & Y. W. H. A. has been at its appointed task for about 17 years.

title: ANTIQUES
description: The revivals of interest in Art Nouveau and the Arts and Crafts movement have sparked numerous exhibitions and more than a score of books. Although both movements emerged at the turn or tne century and were rooted in William Morris's efforts to reestablish handicrafts and standards of excellence in the decorative arts, the esthetics of these styles differ dramatically: Art Nouveau is basically baroque and characterized by whiplash curves, whereas the Arts and Crafts style is neomedieval and architectural in its orientation.

title: JESSIE BRYAN TREFETHEN
description: PORTLAND, Me., March 11Jessie Eryan. Trefethen, a watercolorist, teacher and Professor emeritus of fine arts at Oberlin College, died Thursday in a nursing home here. She was 95 years old. Miss Trefethen, a native of Peaks Island in Portland Harbor, received'a bachelor's degree in art history from Mount Holyoke College in Massachusetts and later spent three years at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. She was awarded a Cresson Scholarship for European travel and study.

title: Balancing Act
description: NADAV SAFRAN may well be the unluckiest and the luckiest, the most foolhardy and the most courageous of our leading students of the ArabIsraeli conflict. In 1965, he began to work on his From War to War. After completing five chapters based on the assumption that a deliberate war was ruled out for many years ahead, the war broke out in June 1967. He had finished twothirds of a book that needed only three more chapters to explain why the war had actually taken place. A less foolhardy author might have tried to hide the signs of disharmony. Not Professor Safran. He courageously told the reader expect five chapters written from one historical perspective and three chapters from another. Still, despite the handicap he had given himself, he produced one of the better books on the first 20 years of the ArabIsraeli conflict.

description: 0 UR first conversational impulses exhausted, our minds and bodies lulled by food and drink, we gazed, my guests and I, into the fire. Each of us sees different things.

title: Mexico City's Streets: Pleasures and Perils
description: Among the promises held out by any visit to a new city are the simple pleasures and complex perils of getting from one place to another. Mexico City's area may not be as remarkable as its altitude of 7,349 feet, but this capital is among the biggest and most spreadout of the world's cities, with sights to be seen in all directions. Only an obsessive walker with boundless energy, bunionless toes and endless time would attempt to navigate the metropolis on foot. Happily, alternatives exist, offering not just transport but that precious illusion for the tourist of doing as the natives do. (Unlike natives, the tourist would do well to get a good street map$3 at the hotel shop, half the price elsewhere.)

title: A Talk With The Third Anna Karenina
description: The first Anna Karenina on the screen was, of course, Greta Garbo. Then came Vivien Leighand now there is the television Anna Karenina of Nicola Pagett. Miss Paeett is an English actress who was only sketchily known in the United States until the BBC's 10hour version of Tolstoy's novelabout a married woman's love affair with a cavalry officerbegan its epic journey Feb. 5 on public television's Masterpiece Theater. She was in New York recently to publicize the series, which is now approaching its tragic climax (the sixth episode will be shown tonight at 9 on WNET / 13).

title: Eastwood Scores an Ace On Way to 65 in Doral
description: MIAMI, March 11One of these days Bob Eastwood is due to win an automobile by bagging a hole-in-one. Few players on the PGA tour have come closer.

title: Attention Turning to New
description: TRENTON - In the three years since the Mount Laurel decision struck down exclusionary zoning New Jersey, very little has happened to open up the state's suburbs to the poor. Efforts to persuade the suburbs to voluntarily make room for the less welloff have mostly failed, and a threat by Governor Byrne cut off state aid to those towns which refused to do so has so far proved ineffective, although his threat may be revived. While New Jersey courts have reaffirmed on several occasions that it is a violation of the State Constitution for stillgrowing municipalities to cater only to the affluent (through such zoning techniques as prohibiting lowcost apartment houses), the courts have yet to enforce any of these rulings. They are all pending in various stages of study or litigation.

title: HELP FOR PRISONERS SET IN EAST HARLEM
description: An East Harlem antipoverty agency has been seeking out inmates in New York State prisons who come from the area to return them to their neighborhood to share in a variety of services designed to help them stay away from new offenses.

Just before Mr. Begin's nowpostponed third visit to Washington, Administration officials admitted to perplexity about the man whom one Israeli recently dubbed as the last Mohican of the grand old Zionist generation.

This will be a historical occasion, for it will mark the first time that exploratory drilling for gas and oil has been conducted off the East Coast. Other companies that have leased tracts in the Baltimore Canyon area of the Outer Continental Shelf plan to follow soon.

As he works at his new novel, he seems oblivious to the cries of birds wheeling over his head and to the hooting of ships on the river. He is oblivious to the noise: When he wants the pleasures of a view without distractions he wears earplugs.

title: ART VIEW
description: No one with a wide knowledge of contemporary art any longer doubts that Realism is now firmly established as a viable creative enterprise. True, its very existence remains something of a bugbear to diehard partisans of the modernist movement for whom any form of Realism but the parodistic is a betrayal of sacred principles. But this linger- ing resistanceoften indistinguishable from outright nostalgia for the heroic vanguard days of yesteryearis itself only another measure of the position Realism has won on the contemporary scene. The remnants of various avantgarde traditions continue to command a large and eager following, of course, but they are no longer able to exert the old authoritvthe authority of the absolute. For they, too, now speak the name of tradition and are as dependent on recognized precedents and established conventions as Realism itself. Acolytes worshipping at the shrine of Duchamp or Malevich are not wellplaced to cast aspersions on the pieties of painters working in the tradition of Courbet or Corot.

title: The House, Live
description: The House of Representatives may have the chance this spring to give its constituents an uncensored television view of the way it works. It should jump at the chance. After years of talk. the House finally seems willing to tolerate filmed coverage. But it remains fixed on the idea that only House einployees should manage the cameras. The House Rules Committee, in a recent report on alternative proposals for televising the proceedirigs, predictably favored a censor'seye view of the proceedings. One member attributes the attitude to the Honie's obVious paranoia?

title: Fire Island YearRound: 4 Generations
description: FOR most New Yorkers, Fire Is- land is a nearby escape from the summertime heat and grit of civilization. The narrow board- walks and the absence of automobiles make its 32 miles of beach seem more remote than it actually is. But for about 100 families, Fire Island is a yearround home, and the concerns of these people make them closer in spirit to the Aran Islanders than to their Suffolk County neighbors.

title: :That's Doing in PHILADELPHIA
description: PENN'S TOWN - Philadelphia, which is approaching its tricentennial, is a lovely old city made for strolling. The central section (Center City), less than 30 blocks wide, was laid out by Wil liam Penn in 1682. Orientation is easy because the northsouth streets are numbered, running westward from Front Street (instead of First Street) near the Delaware River to the Schuyl: kill River around 30th Street. Broad Street (the equivalent of 14th Street) I forms the main stem in the center of town, crossing the main eastwest thoroughfare, Market Street, on the site of City Hall. Many of the eastwest streets bisecting the numbered streets are named for trees, from Lombard on the southern edge of Center City to Cherry on the north. An old rhyme pinpoints the main streets north and south of Market: Market, Arch, Race and Vine Chestnut, Walnut, Spruce and Pine.

title: Defending Quintet Loses in Overtime Providence Out
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 11Miami University of Oxford, Ohio, the beneficiary of an official's controversial ruling, rallied to register one of the major upsets in National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament history today by beating Marquette, last year's champion, 8481, in overtime of a firstround game.

title: On Broadway, The Spectacle's the Thing
description: Agleaming, Art Deco fullscale mockup of the 20th Century Limited train (it cost $196,500) surges on stage and zooms away in the course of the new musical On the Twentieth Century. The train assembles and disassembles and switches from silvery exteriors to posh interiors, wowing audiences who clap for it as if for a star. In Timbuktu! the billowing orange, magenta and purple silken robes and mockAfrican giraffe masks (all of which cost $148,900) get a hand as high and hearty as Eartha Kitt does. In Dracula there is spontaneous applause for Edward Goreys mockmacabre, castle interior (cost: $84,000) and an allout ovation for the plays mockbatswhich seem to fly (those with other special effects, cost $14,000). Boxoffice grosses are surging, too. Should this season's headline be Starringthe costumes and sets?

title: ART
description: CROTONON-HUDSON ELEGANCE can be a dirty word in some art circles but when it is applied to the sculptures of Mario Nardin, now on view at the Fine Art Gallery at Gallimaufry. takes on a markedly positive significance. Elegance in these works does not by any means diminish their expressive impact or turn them into powerlessly decorative constructionson the contrary, it endows them with expression and power.
