description: The artist guided the small boys hands along the smooth surface of the sculptured bronze bust.

title: States Primaries, Starting Next Week, Likely to Test Carter and G.O.P. Rebuilding
description: WASHINGTON, March 12With the nation's first primary nine days away, the 1978 elections seem likely to test President Carter's standing in the country and the Republican Party's efforts to rebuild itself.

title: Bill Brask Wins Indian Golf Tourney
description: CALCUTTA, India, March 12 (AP)Bill Brask of Eden Prairie, Minn., shot a 67. the lowest score of the final round, and gained a fourstroke victory today in the Indian open golf tournament. The 31-year-old Brask wound up at 284. The phrase players who were tied for the lead going into the final round Kuo Chie Hsiung of Taiwan, and Brian Jones and Stewart Ginn of Australiaal shot 76's for 288.

title: Bishop Moore Criticizes City Policy on Children And Voluntary Agencies
description: With 500 disadvantaged children present, Bishop Paul Moore Jr. of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, yesterday sharply criticized the city's policy toward children and toward the voluntary agencies that serve them.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Bottom of the ninth inning, score 22, bases full. The batter hits a home run over the fence. Since the game ends as soon as the winning run scores, does the hit count as home run? Is the final score 32 or 62?

title: MILTON C. ZAIDENBERG
description: Milton C. Zaidenberg, who specialized in the selling of major blocks of securities in the financial market, died Saturday at his home at 19 East 80th Street. He was 77 years old.

title: The ShapeUp on Piers Gives may to `Show- Up
description: It is dark and cold before 7 in the morning when the longshoremen begin to gather in the lower Manhattan hiring hall.

title: Prospects for Primary Contests In New York G.O. P. Are Fading
description: Although the Republicans are not the incumbents, the broad outlines of their state ticket are already dear  indeed so dear that the prospects of a primary fight for any of the four major nominations are fading every day.

title: Nice People On TV
description: TELEVISION isn't especially fond of nice people. A show such as The Waltons is an exception. The entertainment norm veers more toward abrasively hostile types (Archie Bunker or Maude) or juvenile goofiness (everything from Happy Days to Three's Company). Just plain nice tends to be overwhelmed by highpowered commercials.

title: Woman in the Reilly Case Released
description: STAMFORD, Conn., March 12  A woman who had feared for her safety after she had implicated two men in the murder of the mother of Peter A. Reilly has been released from protective custody. and relocated.

title: Commodities
description: The longignored market in hamburger futures is an exciting one for the handful of those who trade in the raw material for America's most popular meat products. Page D3.

title: Duryea Asserts He Has Sewn Up G.O.P. Designation for. Governor
description: The New York State Assembly minority leader, Perry B. Duryea, claimed enough support yesterday on the Republican State Committee to insure his designation for the party's gubernatorial nomination.

title: Gold Rises as Dollar Tumbles
description: PARIS, March 13The dollar tumbled again today on European currency markets after a strong showing earuy in the day as dealers and bankers expressed disappointment with the new joint support measures for the dollar.

title: Companies Report Earnings
description: For periods as Indicated. (N) Indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) over-thscounter.

title: Equal Taxi Opportunity
description: Hailing a taxi in New York City would seem to be simple matter; for blacks, however, it can be a humiliating or risky experience. Imagine standing on a curb midManhattan, waving furiously but futilely as empty cabs pass, only to see one stop a few steps away to pick up whites.

title: Deaths
description: JENERALAnthony J The Association of ExMembers of Aircraft Engineering Sauadron M, U.S. Marine Corp Air Station Cherry Point N.C. during W.W. II records with deepest sorrow the loss of their valued and devoted colleague Tony Jeneral at Westfield, Mass on March 12, 1978. Deepest sympathy to his wife Dorothy. their 3 sons Anthony J. Jr., James and Eugene and to the Marine Carp League

title: Market Place
description: Eastman Kodak, which had been core holding in virtually every institutional portfolio until it fell from favor with growth stocks generally, has taken a bigger pounding than most such shares.

title: Syndication Cuts Into Major TV Networks RtimeTime Programs
description: The invigorated and expanding field of television syndication is encroaching on the time periods normally reserved for network fare and threatens to complicate the feverish competition for audience ratings among the ABCTV, CBSTV and I NBCTV networks.

title: JOHN CAZALE, ACTOR ON STAGE AND SCREEN
description: John Cazale, the actor perhaps best known as Al Pacino's weak, elder brother in the film The Godfather and its sequel, The Godfather, Part II, died Sunday night of cancer at the SloanKettering Memorial Hospital. He was 42 years old.

title: Tenzing Namgyal, Prince of Sikkim
description: The Crown Piince of Sikkim. Tenzing Kunzang Jigme Namgyal, was killed in an automobile accident Saturday in the Sikkimese capital of Gangtok. He would have been 26 years old yesterday.

description: New York, March 2, 1978 The writer was chairman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights from 1960 to 1965.

title: Conference on Infants Studies The First Experiences of Life
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 13When do Apfants first hear, see and touch, am!. when do they first begin experiencinc emotions?

title: These Knights Are Queens of the Court
description: Even the New York Stae Legislature has congratulated the Queens College women's basketball team on its season of 29 victories in 31 games. Assemblyman Alan G. Hevest delivered the proclamation to his alma mater last week- end while the seventhranked Knights were beating Providence College, 7364, and Southern Connecticut State College 7362, to advance to the first round of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women national tournament.

title: Home Is Where the Hearth Is
description: WILTON, Conn.What a beauty, said Steven Curtis, staring down the flue of a triplethroated 190-year-old chimney. These are the kind that tempt you to go right down inside. Then he did just that, swinging his brush before him and lowering himself into the sooty brick chamber until only his black top hat was showing.

title: Deaths
description: GANNONRev. Robert I., S.J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York expresses deep sorrow on the death of its beloved and distinguished honorary member.

title: S.E.C. Says ESystems Made Questionable. Payments to Seoul Official
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that an official of the South Korean Embasy had received more than $1 million in questionable commission fees in connection with the sale of electronic equipment to the South Korean Government.

title: Navy Protests Limitation of Its LongTerm Mission
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Navy, protesting a limitation of Its role under Defense Secretary Harold Brown's policies, has said that they represent a fundamental change in national strategy, conceding the Norwegian Sea to the Soviet Union and placing control over the Mediterranean in serious doubt

title: A HIJACKER GIVES UP AT AIRPORT IN DENVER
description: DENVER, March 13 (AP)A United Airlines 727 was hijacked today from California to Denver, where the hijacker surrendered after three crewmen jumped from a cockpit window about an hour after the plane landed here for refueling.

title: U.S. Tries to End Rift With Turkey
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Carter Administration tried to extricate itself today from an embroglio with Turkey that stemmed from an impromptu candid statement by Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance last week on policy toward the Ankara Government.

title: CONGRESS RESISTING PLANS FOR AGENCIES
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Members of the House, the Senate and the White House are engaged in a struggle over tho independent regulatory agencies.

title: Security for Bergland Tightened
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)Security for Agriculture Secretary Bob Bergland was tightened today after telephoned threats to his life and plans for a threeday demonstration here by thousands of farmers. An informed source said about a dozen phone calls were received last week that were interpreted as threats against Mr. Bergland and top aide. The source said some of the anonymous callers associated them'selves with the farm strike movement by the protest group American Agriculture.

title: Track Meet Women Of AllAges
description: A crowd of more than 13,500 relatives, friends and fans of the participants turned out at Madison Square Garden last night to watch 201 track and field finalists compete in the fourth Women's Games.

title: Stoneware and Old Wisdom
description: What is unusual about our company is that we still do so much by hand in our dinnerware, said Nancy Lamb, who runs Old Mountain Stoneware Laurel Bloomery, Tenn. The route Mrs. Lamb took to get to Laurel Bloomery is also unusual.

title: PLAN IS ANNOUNCED BY U.S AND GERMANY TO STABILIZE DOLLAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The United States and West Germany announced series of joint actions today to stabilize the value of the dollar and to demonstrate greater agreement on basic economic policy.

title: Iranian Students, in Texas Court Over Sitin, Renew Their Protest
description: BEEVILLE, Tex., March 13More than 100 Iranian students, many of them linked to groups that oppose Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi, pled not guilty today to charges of criminal trespas arising from a demonstration at the community college in this small south Texas town.

title: U.S. Oil Imports Starting to Fall; Analysts See Drop as Temporary
description: While Congrersional conferees have been struggling, to shape some form of energy legislrtion that would reduce America dependence on forcirl oil, little noticed yet encouraging development has emerged: Oil imports hive started to drop on their own.

title: Around the Nation
description: NORFOLK, Va., March 13 (AP)A protest to President Carter from Puerto Rico has forced the cancellation of a 30,000man military exercise that that had been set to begin on May 5.

title: Taxes & Accounting; Which Divorced Parent Gets Exemptions?; Taxes & Accounting: Which Divorced Parent Will Claim Children as Dependents?
description: When couples with children divorce or separate, fights over tax questions can be among the most bitter. Often the focal point is which parent will claim the children as dependents. Not surprisingly, the warfare often escalates around this time of year, as the due date for tax returns approaches.

title: Parseghian Named Trustee
description: COLUMBUS, .Ohio, March 13 (UPI) Gov. James A. Rhodes appointed Ara Parseghian to a nineyear term on the board of trustees of Miami University, Oxford, Ohio, today. The former Notre Dame football coach succeeds Paul Brown, general manager of the Cincinnati Bengals. Both are graduates of Miami and Parseghian also coached football there.

title: How Central Banks Use Swap Accord
description: In 1962, the Federal Reserve set up its first swap agreement with the Bank of France forby today's standardsa mere $50 million. Since then, 13 other nations have become involved in the swap accords, or shortterm credit agreements between nations to exchange currencies, and the lines total more than $22.2 billion.

title: How. Busy to Be Mister Carter
description: Good morning, President Carter. Here is your agenda for the day: 66:30 A.M.Calisthenics shave, breakfast, make bed.

title: Democratic Legislators Split Over Naming of Regent
description: ALBANY, March 13An agreement between the Democratic leaders of the State Senate and the Assembly over who should be named to the State Board of Regents broke down at the last minute tonight over issues involving regional representation, racial balance and the right of the Senate's Democrats to play a major role in the selection process.

title: 19 Mares in Kentucky Have Symptoms of Disease
description: The possibility that two horses imported from France have spread the contagious equine venereal disease metritis has almost halted the multimillion dollar horse breeding season in Central Kentucky.

title: White House Woos Holdouts on Canal
description: WASHINGTON. March 13The White House quietly changed its position today on the $2.3 billion emergency farm bill to conform to the wishes of a Senator 1 whose vote it is wooing on the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Matthew Josephson, Biographer and Muckraker, Dies
description: Matthew Josephson, the Brooklynborn biographer whose writings ranged from French literary figures to American capitalists, died yesterday at Community Hospital in Santa Cruz, Calif. He was 79 years old and had suffered from asthma.

title: Aquarium Transfers Fish in Breathtaking Maneuver
description: BOSTON, March 13The New England Aquarium began transferring all 284 occupants from its 250,000gallon tank today in preparation for draining the tank and replacing a damaged window. On New Year's Day, the outer layer of the four laminated sheets that make up the window shattered mysteriously, but the inside layers remained intact.

description: DratII5

title: SOME PALESTINIANS ARE PROUD OF ATTACK
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon. March l3Some Palestinians interviewed here expressed pride today over last Saturday's daylight guerrilla raid in Israel, and a spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization warned of more raids to come.

description: HANS AXEL WALLEEN

title: Crime, Punishment and Insanity
description: In advising Governor Carey to seek a law to abolish the insanity defense, the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene has had the first word in the renewed debate over how to judge criminal responsibility. should not be the last. The department's report has many virtues, notably the calmness with which it addresses an issue that so often triggers demagoguery. But the report is inadequate as a basis for legislative action.

title: Lafleur,Gets 3 Goals
description: Guy Lafleur of the Montreal CatiadiPns scored three goals in the first period last night against the Minnesota North Stars and raised his National Hockey Leagueleading totals to 54 ;.;oals and 116 points. It is the fourth season Lafleur has exceeded 50 goals, second only to Phil Esposito of the New York Rangers, with five. Canadiens won, 52. Details on page 44.

description: TUESDAY, MARCH 14, 1978

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 7Year Marijuana Term Upheld
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., March 13 (AP) The Missouri Supreme. Court today upheld a sevenyear prison sentence given to a Missouri man for selling 11 grams of marijuana. The state's highest court turned down Jerry Mitchell's argument that the sentence was cruel and unusual punishment. Mr. Mitchell pleaded guilty in 1975 to selling the drug, less than onethird of an ounce, for $5.

title: People and Business
description: Gerhard D. Bleicken, chairman and chief executive officer of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company, announced yesterday that he will retire on Dec. 31. He will be succeeded by J. Edwin Matz, now vice chairman, president and chief operations officer.

title: Cauthen Suspension Stayed
description: ARCADIA, Calif., March 13Steve Cauthen, the jockey, won a Superior Court injunction today, staying his suspension at Santa Anita and apparently enabling him to ride Affirmed Saturday in the San Felipe Handicap.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: One Missing in Swiss Avalanche
description: COL DA MOSSES, Switzerland, March 13 (UPI)The Swiss police reported today that only one skier was still unaccounted for following an avalanche that roared across a packed ski slope yesterday afternoon. Hundreds of other skiers

title: Yields on Treasury Bills Decline
description: Yields declined on Treasury bills in the weekly auction yesterday in both the 91day and 182clay maturities.

title: New York a Strain for Wives of Japanese Businessmen
description: Every morning after her husband leaves for work in Manhattan, Sachiko Watanabe begins another long, lonely day in her apartment in Hartsdale in Westchester County. With luck she might see her husband arbund midnight. Meanwhile. she will spend a good part of the day confined to her modern apartment, staring at the Japanese scrolls on the wall and dreaming of home.

title: Lafleur Scores 3 as Canadiep,s Win
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., March 13 (UPI)Guy Lafleur, tha. National Ho'key League's leading scorer, scored three goals within a 6-minute-10-second span of the first period tonight to spark the Montreal Canadiens to a 52 victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

title: LARRY FLYNT OF HUSTLER NOW DEVELOPS PNEUMONIA
description: ATLANTA, March 13 (AP)Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, has contracted pneumonia and is getting blood transfusions to overcome internal bleeding, a medical advisory from Emory University Hospital said today.

title: Aquarium Transfers Fish in Breathtaking Maneuver
description: BOSTON, March 13The New England Aquarium began transferring all 284 occupants from its 250,000gallon tank today in preparation for draining the tank and replacing a damaged window. On New Year's Day, the outer layer of the four laminated sheets that make up the window shattered mysteriously, but the inside layers remained intact.

title: Ethnic Data Refused by Board in Queens Taken to Washington by Staff Workers
description: The ethnic census data that were needed for Federal aid and that the local board of School District 26 in Queens had refused to supply were gathered by staff workers of the district and taken to Washington yesterday to meet Fedetal deadlines.

title: Lafleur Player of Week
description: Guy Lafleur of the Montreal Canadiens, who leads the National Hockey League in scoring, has been named the player of the week for March 612 by the Professional Hockey Writers Association. Lafleur scored four goals and had a total of 6 points in four . games, raising his season total to 113. His three goals last night against the North Stars increased the total to 116.

title: Miners, AfterUnion Meeting, Vow No Contract, NoWork
description: JOHNSTON CITY, Ill., March 13Claude Phelps, the mountainous washer boss at Orient No. 4, .an underground mine a few miles south of here, sat slumped in his chair in an office shack today, his face blackened with coal dust except for the white circles left by pair of goggles.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 14. 1978

title: City Opera Brings Back Tosca
description: Tosca neyer disappears from the repertory of any company for long and sure enough, Puccini's melodrama returned to the City Opera Sunday night after a ,few seasons absence. The performance was, on the whole, a smooth one, tolerably well sung and respectably acted.

title: France After the FirstRound Vote: The Left, Hopes Shaken, Now Faces an Uphill Battle
description: PARIS; March 13  The voters of France divided their favors even more closely than opinion polls and politicians had foreseen in the first round of legislative elections yesterday.

title: Steel Output Increased by 2.1% In the Week to 2.47 Million Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended March 11 rose to 2.47 million tons, up 2.1 percent from the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry produced 2.42 million tons the week before.

title: Obituary 2 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: French Leftists, Set Back in Vote, To Join Forces
description: PARIS, March 13After falling short of the showing they expected in the first legislative election round, France's quarreling leftist opposition parties tonight worked out an agreement to run common candidates in the final round next Sunday.

title: Carey Proposes Life Without Parole for Murderers
description: ALBANY, March 13Governor Carey today submitted longawaited legislation authorizing life imprisonment without parole for convicted murderersa step plainly aimed at blocking the drive for the death penalty this week.

title: Assad, in Interview, Voices Doubt Of Gain in Any CarterBegin Talk
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 11President Hafez alAssad says that even Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel and President Carter reach an agreement at a future meeting, they cannot possibly solve the Middle East problem.

title: Increase in World Trade In First Half of 78 Seen As Modest in GATT Study
description: GENEVA, March 13The volume of world trade can be expected to show only a modest increase in the first half of 1978, after an already relatively small rate of expansion recorded in 1977, according to a staff study of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

title: 37 Malians Are Held in Plot
description: BAMAKO, Mali, March 13 (Reuters)Mali authorities said today that they had arrested 37 people, including government ministers and senior military and police officers, in connection with a plot to overthrow President Moussa Traore. A statement from the ruling Military Committee for National Liberation, published today, said 33 police, air force and army officers had been arrested in addition to four former government ministers, already in custody, who are accused of being the chief plotters.

title: Iran to Free 1,200 Prisoners
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 13 (UPI) -Iranian officials announced today that it would release of more than 1,200 prisoners, including 261 convicted of treason and subersion, under a new law passed by the Iranian pariament.

title: Carter Bitterly Criticized
description: DILLES BOTTOM, Ohio, March 13Officials of one of the largest districts of the United Mine Workers issued a statement today bitterly attacking President Carter for invoking the back-to-work authority of the TaftHartley Act in trying to end the coal strike.

title: Duran Has New Opponent
description: Adolfo Viruet of Puerto Rico will replace Wilfredo Benitez in a 10round nontitle fight against the lightweight champion, Roberto Duran, in Madison Square Garden April 27, it was announced today. The unbeaten Benitez, also of Puerto Rico, had to withdraw because of hepatitis.

title: Carlon Price Increases
description: The Carlon division of Indian Head Inc. announced a 6 percent increase on all conduit, duct, large - diameter pipe, sewer pipe, fittings and accessories, effective March 20. . . Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., announced a price increase averaging 10 percent, effective April 1, on its liquid hydrogen and bulk quantities of gaseous hydrogen.

title: Advertising
description: When Frank S. Berger, president of the Seagram Distillers Company, tells you he only sleeps from 1 A.M. to 4:30 A.M. and. works from 6 A.M. until 11 P.M., you've got two choices: Believe him or stay up with him.

title: Resolution Proposed at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 13A resolution was proposed here today by seven thirdworld countries asking all governments not to recognizt any agree: ment on the future of Rhodesia made by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's illegal regime.

title: Activist Is Arrested on Gun Charge
description: Vincente Alba, a Puerto Rican nationalwas held in $25,000 ,bail in Bronx. Criminal Court yesterday on dangerous charges of illegal possession of a dangerous weapona loaded .38 pistol from which, the serial number allegedly had been removed.

title: TELEPHONE OF SAKHAROV DISCONNECTED IN SOVIET
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (UPI)Andrei D. Sakharov, the physicist and civil rights advocate, said today ,that the Soviet authorities had cut off his telephone service for the first time.

title: Dispute Over Cost May Halt Work In Groton on Nuclear Submarines
description: The General Dynamics Corporation announced yesterday that it would halt work next month on 16 nuclearpowered attack submarines at its Electric Boat Division in Groton, Conn., as a result of dispute with the Navy over design changes and cost overruns of more than $544 million.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: WALTER GOODMAN

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times on Sunday that New York City would begin accepting applications yesterday for federally financed summer jobs for young people. According to the Em- ployment Department, applications are being taken only from companies and organizations willing to sponsor such jobs: Application forms for youths will be available in April on a date to be announced.

title: Adm. John Hall Jr., a DDay Leader
description: Adm. John Lesslie Hall Jr., who commanded the 11th Amphibious Force in the Omaha Beach assault during the Normandy invasion in 1944, died last Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was $6 years old.

title: Quebec Poll Against Independence
description: MONTREAL, March 13 (Reuters)Que, bec voters would overwhelmingly reject separation from Canada if a vote were held today, the Frenchlanguage tabloid Dimanche Matin has reported. A survey commissioned by the paper showed that 58.3 percent would reject the separatist Quebec Government's option of independence and only 24.8 percent would vote in favor. The newspaper said 16.9 per cent were undecided.

title: California Attorney General Accused of Using Post in Governor's Race
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13Two revan actions by Attorney General Evelle J. Younger have drawn accusations that he uses his office's legal authority to further his campaign for the Republican nomination for Governor of California.

title: Begin Vows to Cut Off Evil Arm Of Group Responsible for Raid
description: JERUSALEM, March 13Prime Minister Menachem Begin vowed today that Israel would cut off the evil arm of the Palestinian guerrilla organization responsible for the weekend raid that took the lives of more than 30 civilians.

title: SMALL GAINS SHOWN IN PRICES OF BONDS
description: The credit markets shrugged off the Federal Government's latest move to stem the dollar's decline in foreign ex change trading, and most fixedincome se, curity prices closed yesterday little changed drom their final levels last Friday_

title: US. AGAIN STRESSES CONCERN ON REPRISAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The State Department expressed again today the Administration's concern that Israel's expected retaliation for Saturday's raid by Palestinians might ruin chances for Middle East peace negotiations.

title: Landlords Resisting City Mandate For Window Guards for Children
description: Landlords throughout the city, including the Nciw York City HousingAuthority, are seriously concerned about a littleknown Hapth Code regulation that requires guad bars on the windows of all apartment whose tenants include children 10 years old or younger.

title: About New York
description: I used to keep the radio on during sex so I could hear the race results, one man said. That's a compulsive eambler.

title: HONEYWELL DROPPING POWERFUL COMPUTER
description: Honeywell Inc. announced yesterday that it would not market a computer it introduced more than a year ago as the, largest and most powerful machine in the company's history. Honeywell said there was no demand for it.

title: Company Calls Casino Plan Drastic
description: TRENTON, March 13Officials of Resorts International testified today that proposed legislation permitting temporary licensing of gambling casinos in Atlantic City provided controls that were too drastic.

title: AIRLINE FARE PACT IS REACHED BY U.S. AND NETHERLANDS
description: British Airways Weighs Extension of New York-London Budget Plans to 7 U.S. Cities

title: The First Round In France
description: Although inconclusive as to the makeup of the next government of France, the, first round of that country's parliamentary elections produced some interesting resultsnot the least of which was that, in one regard. European democracy showed itself healthier than the American variety.

title: Euthanasia Pact Described
description: LONDON. March 13 (AP)Jean Humphry knew she was dying of cancer. Dreading a slow, painful death in a hospital ward, she made a pact with her husband to help her commit suicide so she could die quietly at home.

title: CURARE VIALS LINKED TO LOCKER OF DR. X
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 13A director of Riverdell Hospital testified today that after months of puzzling over why there were so many unexplained deaths, at the.Oradell hospital during 1966 he and other directors secretly opened the locker of Dr. Marjo E. Jascalevich and found vials of curare, a powerful muscle relaxant.

title: For Springy, Nonconformity Is Back in Fashion
description: At this point in time, fashion is operating on the laissezfaire principle. Not so many years ago (remember the midi?) fashion designers were accused of being dictators. Today they would no sooner mandate the length of heinline than they would insist on the shape of a dress.

title: EARLY CLUES HINTED IN HAHNEMANN CASE
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Documents released today provided further evidence that lowerlevel Justice Department officials knew as early as last summer of links between the law firm of Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania, and allegations of wrongdoing in the construction of Hahnemann Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: Accord Near on A's Move, Giants Use of Two Parks
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13Legal technicalities concerning the bonds that financed both stadiums emerged today as the one remaining serious roadblock to moving the A's from Oakland to Denver and having the San Francisco Giants split their home schedule between Candlestick Park and the Oakland Coliseum.

title: A Gasoline Leak Threatens Water In Provincetown
description: PROVINCETOWN, Mass., March 13Provincetown has declared a state of emergency because a major part of the town's water supply is threatened with contamination from gasoline that leaked out of an underground tank in a service station near its primary municipal water source.

title: SOVIET, IN SHIFT, GIVES U.S. SOME ARMS DATA
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Soviet Union in recent weeks has begun to provide sensitive information on the size and composition of its strategic missile arsenal to American negotiators at the Geneva talks, Government officials said today.

title: Mehta Plans Barber Premiere To Open Philharmonic Season
description: Zubin Mehta, who will be the new music director of the New York Philharmonic when it begins its 197879 season, will conduct 16 of the 32 weeks of its subscription concerts. He will open the season on Sept. 14. conducting the premiere of a work by Samuel Barber, commissioned by the Merlin Foundation and called The Ambiguities (after Melville), and Mahler's First Symphony. The final concert, also in Mr. Menta's hands, will be on May 5, 1979.

title: U.S. Oil Imports Starting to Fall; Analysts See Drop as Temporary
description: While Congressional conferees have been struggling to shape some form of energy legislation that would reduce America's dependence on foreign oil, little noticed yet encouraging development has emerged: Oil imports have started to drop on their own.

title: Withdrawals Plague Europe - U.S. Meet.
description: MILAN, Italy, March 13The EuropeUnited States indoor track meet scheduled here tomorrow night lost some luster today when the squads were named and a few of the biggest stars were not included.

title: ADOLPH D. STORCH,  HEADED JERSEY DRUG CONCERN
description: Adolph D. Storch, president and board chairman of the Purepac Laboratories Corporation, a pharmaceuticals and homeproducts concern, in Elizabeth, N. J., died Sunday in New York Hospital after long illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Arms Research Lab Ordered to Tighten Safety Procedures
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13Amid rising employee concern about toxic materials where they work, the Lawrence Livermore Laboratory has been directed by the Department of Energy to tighten Its system of hazard control.

description: SAILING TODAY) TramAtlantIc

title: Delmonica Hanover Sold
description: Delmonica Hanover, a trotter who twice won the Roosevelt International, has been sold for $400,000, a record price for a standardbred mare. The announcement of the sale was made yesterdaythe same day she presented foal, sired by Super Bowl, to her new owner, Hanley Dawson Jr. of Chicago. The sellers were Ed Ryan of Pittsburgh and Dorothy Hardy of EightyFour, Pa., who purchased the mare in 1974 for a then record of $300,000. Delpionica Hanover originally was purchased for $5,000 by Del Miller, her trainerdriver.

title: Radio
description: 14 A.M., WKCR. Four Seasons, Haydn.

title: U.M.W. Defiance Is Consistent
description: The refusal of the nation's coal ininerb to return to work over the weekend, defying an injunction issued under the TaftHartley Act, is consistent with the United Mine Workers implacable opposition to the law since it was enacted in June 1947.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated in The Times on Sunday that New York City would begin accepting applications yesterday for federally financed summer jobs for young people. According to the Employment Department, applications are being taken only from companies and organizations willing to sponsor such jobs. Application forms for youths will be available in April on a date to be announced.

title: French Leftists, Set Back in Vote, To Join Forces
description: PARIS, March 13After falling short of the showing they expected in the first legislative election round, France's quarreling leftist opposition parties tonight worked out an agreement to run common candidates in the final round next Sunday.

title: Deaths
description: SPORCHAdolph D. The Carlton Group, New York Section National Council of Jewish Women, extends deepest sympathy to our devoted board member & past chairman, Horty Storch, on the,death of her beloved husband, Adolph.

title: Stocks, Reacting Warily to Pact On Dollar, Close With Small Gain
description: The stock market managed to finish with only a slight gain yesterday after investors skepticism over the agreement between the United States and West Germany to support the dollar in the foreign exchange market eroded much of the early advance.

title: Carey Proposes Life Without Parole for Murderers
description: ALBANY, March 13Governor Carey today submitted longawaited legislation authorizing life imprisonment without parole for convicted murderersa step plainly aimed at blocking the drive for the death penalty this week.

title: Colby Says His Dismissal as C.I.A. Chief Arose From His Cooperation in Domestic Spying Inquiries
description: William E. Colby says in a memoir to be published in May that he believes President Ford removed him as Director of Central Intelligence in late 1975 because he chose not to stonewall but to cooperate with the Congressional and executive inquiries that year into wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Dresden Treasures to Tour U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  An agreement that will bring 7C0 treasures from the museums of Dresden, East Germanypaintings, rose diamonds, armor and Meissen porcelain, among other itemsfor a year's exhibition at three United States museums was announced today at the National Galley, where the show will open next June.

title: COAL MINERS IGNORE TAFTIIARTLEY ORDER; PACT REPORTED NEAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Union coal miners ignored 1he Government's TaftHartley Act back-to-work order today as negotiators for the United Mine Workers and the coal industry marked time here, reportedly nearer agreement on a new settlement proposal to be formally put forward tomorrow.

title: Landlords Resisting City Mandate For Window Guards for Children
description: Landlords throughout the city, includ1 ing the Nciw York City HousingAuthority, are seriously concerned about a littleknown Hapth Code regulation that requires guad bars on the windows of all apartment whose tenants include children 10 years old or younger. ,.

title: Deaths
description: FINKLeo. The Employees of Barney's express deepest sorrow on the sudden loss of their longtime friend. As a coemployee he befriended all who knew him and served with utmost devotion and will so be remembered. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife, Sylvia and his family.

title: Cimcert:NielsenbyCincinnatians
description: The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra dedicated its concert in Carnegie Hall last night to the memory of Thomas Schippers. Mr. Schippers had been the group's music director for seven years until his death last December at the age of 47.

title: New Lawyer Named For Italian Guerrillas
description: TURIN, Italy, March 13 (Reuters)The president of an Italian lawyers association, whose predecessor who shot to death five days before a trial of urban guerrillas, was called upon today to defend those guerrillas.

title: Law and Religion Intermingled In Suit on Abortion Ban
description: For many long days since last July, Judge John F. Dooling Jr. has been listening to a case brought by Cora McRae, Jane Doe, Mary Doe, Susan Roe, Ann Moe and others that represents a major constitutional challenge to current law restricting the use of Federal funds to pay for abortions. The women, who are from New York, Connecticut and Minnesota, and are single and married; aged 15 to 25, with up to four children, never appear to hear the arguments before Judge Dooling in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Blazers Go for Big Double In Rich N.B.A. Playoff Pool
description: The 11 Portland players and Ron Culp, their trainer, can earn almost $28,000 each if the Trail Blazers become the first team since the 1969 Boston Celtics to win successive National Basketball Association championships.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Edgar B. Speer, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, is telling stockholders that the nation's largest steel company will direct new capital spending to nonsteel operations until the Government acts to change the investment climate for the steel business.

title: Top Role Is Sought By Transport Dept. On U.S. Air Policy
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Transportation Secretary Brock Adams sent memorandum last week to President Carter asking that his department,- rather than the State Department, be given the major authority in establishing international air transportation policy, according to Department of Transportation sources.

title: Guerrilla Version of Israel Raid Is Reported in Soviet Newspaper
description: MOSCOW, March 13 (Reuters)The Soviet Union publicized today the Palestinian version of what happened in the raid in Israel Saturday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Dutchess County grand jury yesterday indicted Sheriff Lawrence J. Quinlan on two felony and five misdemeanor counts involving the possession and sale of handguns.

Dooling Jr. has been listening to a case brought by Cora McRae, Jane Doe, Mary Doe, Susan Roe, Ann Moe and others that represents a major constitutional challenge to current law restricting the use of Federal funds to pay for abortions. The women, who are from New York, Connecticut and Minnesota, and are single and married; aged 15 to 25, with up to four children, never appear to hear the arguments before Judge Dooling in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Police Can't Resolve Gracie Mansion Case Involving 3 Guards
description: The Police Department said yesterday that an investigation had found insufficient evidence to clearly prove or disprove allegations that three police officers who were temporarily assigned to guard Gracie Mansion has got drunk on duty pn beer and wine .taken from the Mayor's official residence.

title: Spring Training, Japanese Style; Dave Anderson; Sports of The Times; Is Gamble Worth $2.8 Million?; One American's Assessment of Oh
description: YUMA, Ariz.When the Swallows come back to Yuma next year, they'll bring their own noodles again. These aren't the swallows who come back to Capistrano each year. These are the Yakult Swallows of the Japanese Central League who nested here with the San Diego Padres for mine training. They brought their own noodles andthey prepared their own rice, making it mushier than Americans like it. Other than that, they thrived on American food, especIally ham and eggs for breakfast, at the Stailust Motel where they already have made reservations for next year. They also thrived on long workouts. They usually were on the field at Desert Stadium at 9 o'clock in the morning and they didn't depart until 4 in the afternoon, whereas the Padres perspired from 10 to 2 until their exhibition games began last week. After two victories and two losses against major league opposition, the Swallows are en route to Japan now but whenever they had a dull moment here, many took films of the Padres hitting, pitching and fielding. In other moments, some talked of Joe Pepitone, once of the New York Yankees and briefly with the Swallows once upon a time.

title: Allstate Assails Release Of State's Interim Report On Its RateRise Request
description: TRENTON, March 13The Allstate Insurance Company has filed a legal brief with the State Insurance Department criticizing the release of an interim report of a hearing on the company's last rate increase, describing the new rates as substantially higher than they should be.

description: Leonard Mosley's Dulles is the 19th book on contemporary history by the inexhaustible former chief war correspondent for the London Sunday Times. (He has also written five

title: ALBANY ACTS TO AID UTILITY CUSTOMERS
description: ALBANY, March 13In response to the exigencies of the harsh winter, the Senate today passed legislation giving the Public Service Commission the authority to order gas or electric utility companeis to refund excess profits to consumers.

title: Florida Inmate a Suspect in Killings of 36 Women, but Police Lack Decisive Evidence
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 11For several weeks now the police in this southern capital have held in an armorplated jail cell a man who is either victim of unusual circumstances oras the police in several states suspectthe killer of at least 36 women.

title: F.T.C. CHARGES FRUEHAUF VIOLATED ANTITRUST LAW
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)--The Federal Trade Commission said today the Fruehauf Corporation's 1973 acquisition of the KelseyHayes Company violated antitrust law. Fruehauf is the nation's largest truck trailer manufacturer and KelseyHayes is a leading maker of automotive components, including two that are needed in the production of truck trailers Fruehauf announced immediately that it would appeal the F.T.C.'s ruling.

title: TV: Perfect Gentlemen, a Movie About Women
description: On paper, Perfect Gentlemen shows promise. Written by Nora Ephron, the critic, the television movie stars Lauren !scan, Sandy Dennis, Ruth Gordon and Lisa Pelikan. But as produced and directed by Jackie Cooper, the film, which is on CBSTV tonight at 9, fizzles into a selfconscious romp in which A busy music track is offered as a substitute for style.

title: Rhodesian Rebels in London Talks
description: LONDON, March 13 (Reuters)British and American diplomats met with Rhodesian guerrilla leaders here tonight to discuss the possibility of their holding talks with black nationalist leaders wso signed a majorityrule agreement March 3 with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith.

title: Pacification Chief inVietnam Now a Top Pentagon Adviser
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  He was called Blowtorch in Saigon, and he (revels in the nickname. It's still my name around here, Rbbert W. Komer says with a laugh. It's my job. I have to keep pushing everybody.

title: B. Preston Schoyer, 66, Novelist And Author of Articles on China
description: B. Preston Schoyer, author of four highly prailed novels and many articles on China, died yesterday of cancer at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 66 Mears old and lived in Riverside, Conn.

title: Change in Bank Secrecy Act Asked
description: The Treasury Department yesterday proposed an amendment to the Bank Secrecy Act that would require banks to keep records on the persons or businesses that purchase and redeem all certificates of deposit and capital notes.

title: Aquarium Transfers Fish in Breathtaking Maneuver
description: BOSTON, March 13The New England Aquarium began transferring all 284 occupants from its 250,000gallon tank today in preparation for draining the tank and replacing a damaged window. On New Year's Day, the outer layer of the four laminated sheets that make up the window shattered mysteriously, but the inside layers remained intact.

title: Talks Today To Air Status Of Music Hall
description: Led by Lien;. Goy. Mary Anne Krupsak, a galaxy of pro-preservationist forces ranging from the Rockettes to Henry Geldzahler, the city's Cultural Commircioner, will turn out today to testify at a pubPc hearing that may determ'ne landmark status for Radio City Music Hall.

title: Prosecutor Calls In Begelman
description: LOS ANGELES, March 13David BegelEan, ousted president of Columbia Pictures, has a date with the Los Angeles district attorney to discuss his alleged embezzlement of $61,008 of the company's funds. He also has a new Columbia contract that should bring him a minimum of $300,000 a year.

title: Health Council Officer Urges PublicSmoking Ban
description: TRENTON, March 13A cigarettesmoking state hearing officer, Judge Sidney Goldmann, today found a proposed ban on smoking in most public places in New Jersey to be in order.

title: U.S.WILL INVESTIGATE CETA IN WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 13Federal Labor Department officials stepped in today to investigatethe operation of the Comprehensive Employment and Training Act in Westchester County, an operation that the State Labor Department criticized last week.

title: Gotbaum Is Criticized by DeMilia For Comment on P.B.A. Demands
description: Samuel DeMilia, president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, yesterday criticized Victor Gotbaum, the head of the largest municipal union, for suggesting that police officers would not be able to get a better contract settlement than other New York City unions barzainine as a coalition.

title: Guide GOING OUT
description: VOICE OF EXPERIENCE The public is invited today at 6 P.M. to hear a lecture on Japan and the United States: Today and Tomorrow by Jun Eto, Japan's foremost literary critic, at Japan House, 333 East 47th Street; between. First and Second Avenues. The free event will focus on recent tensions. in AmericanJapanese diplomatic, political and economic relations.

title: Da, an Irish Memory Play, Opens
description: Like its central character, Hugh Leonard's Da is loquacious, exasperating, persistent and finally not far from irresistible.

title: Mailers Union Authorizes Strike Against New York Newspapers
description: The Mailers Union voted 79 to 2 last night to authorize a strike against New York City's three major daily newspapers if a new contract has not been agreed Linen by March 30.

title: Managing, Compared
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.As Edward I. Koch and other new mayors choose administrators to run government agencies, many of us wonder how we should judge the managers. Inevitably. we measure the performance of public officials against that of the private sector, in spite of the late political scientist Wallace Sayre's warning that business and government administration are alike in all unimportant iespects.

title: Palermo Retracts Bid for License
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 13 (AP) Frank (Blinky) Palermo, a former boxing manager and convicted extortionist, gave up his bid to return to ringside today, charging what his lawyer called harassment by the awesome power of the press.

title: PLAN IS ANNOUNCED BY U.S. AND GERMANY TO STABILIZE DOLLAR
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Ilnited States and West Germany announeel series of joint actions today to stabilise the value of the dollar and to demonstrate greater agreement on basic economic policy.

description: With his aggressive theatricality, his role as defender, of the underdog and his involvement in many of our most critical judicial cases, Clarence Darrow is a natural magnet for the Americah actor. Orson Welles, Henry Fonda,

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 13 (Reuters)Hungary, the world water polo champion, was the unbeaten victor in the fourday Can-Am-Mex series which ended last night.

title: Notes on People
description: When Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, showed up Sunday near St. Anthony, Newfoundland, where the annual slaughter of baby harp seals for their hides began, he received an angry tonguelashing from John Lundrigan, Minister of Industrial and Rural Development for the province. Mr. Ryan was sponsor of a resolution passed by Congress last year condemning the seal hunts. After his helicopter landed at the hunt site, Mr. Lundrigan confronted Mr. Ryan and said: It's just a cheap political trick. You're a cheap bloody politician. You're the cheapest kind of politician. You've taken your stand. You've already clobbered us, so now you're back to find out the fadts. Is that American? Mr. Lundrigan also suggested to Mr. Ryan and other United States observers at the seal hunt that they should go back to your own bloody country and get it straightened out a little bit.

title: Laos's Need: U. S. Rice
description: WASHINGTONAs a result of widespread drought last year, Laos. faces food,ishortages and, in many areas, the likelihood of famineTo try to stave off the impending disaster, the Laotian Government has appealed to the World for aid, and in early January made, direct request to the Carter Administration. But the State Department Wand the Administration have refused to respond.

title: Begin Vows to Cut Off Evil Arm Of Group Responsible for Raid
description: JERUSALEM, March 13Prime Minister Menachem Begin vowed today that Israel would cut off the evil arm of the Palestinian guerrilla organization responsible for the weekend raid that took the lives of more than 30 civilians.

description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 13 They used words like vicious and fear, but'they weren't talking about the Frankenstein monster or Jack the Ripper. His teammates were talking about Rich Gossage, the relief pitcher whose rocketlike pitches make weaker men ask, Why am I standing here at the plate subjecting myself to such cruel and unusual punishment?

title: Cutler-Hammer Charges Dismissed
description: CutlerHammer Inc., Milwaukee, announced yesterday that charges brought against its internal auditor, George Thomas, last year by the Securities and Exchange Commission had been dismissed by the United States Distriot Court in Los Angeles. In April 1911 the S.E.C. alleged that Mr. Thomas and the Macrodata Corporation had conspired to misstate Macrodata's 1975 financial results. Macrodata, now wholly owned by CutlerHammer, was at that time 62 percent owned by the Milwaukee concern. i Both Mr. Thomas and CutlerHammer had denied any wrongdoing on the part of Mr. Thomas.

title: Furlough of Mitchell Is Extended For Testimony in Korean Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, March 13 (AP)John N. Mitchell's furlough from prison was extended for a third time today so that the former Attorney General can testify on what the Nixon Administration knew about secret South Korean efforts to influence Congressmen.

title: Dispute May Halt Work in Groton On 16 Navy Nuclear Submarines
description: The Ceneral Dynan ins Corporation announced yesterday that it would halt work next month on 16 nuclearpowered attack submarines at it Electric Boat Division in Groton, Conn., as a result of a dispute with the Navy over design !changes and cost overruns of more than $544 million.

title: But Red Sox Scout Fails to AppearShortstop Angry
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 13With the deadline for interleague trades only two days off, the New York Mets tried to showcase Bud Harrelson for the Boston Red Sox today. But no Boston scout appeared at the ball park for the audition, and so the rebuilding Mets were left dangling on the immediate future of the man who has been their shortstop for the last 11 summers.

title: Exiled Soviet General Denounces Moscow, Demands Right to Return and Stand Trial
description: Pyotr G. Grigorenko. the former .Soviet major general stripped of citi- zenship last Friday and denied the right, to return home, angrily accused the Soviet Government yesterday, of a vile act and hypocrisy and called on world leaders to support him in his determination to go home. `'.

description: JERUSALEM, March 13Prime Minister Menachem Begin vowed today that Israel would cut off the evil arm of the Palestinian guerrilla organization responsible for the weekend raid that took the lives of more than 30 civilians.

description: The New York Stock Exchange yesterday named 11 stocks to be used in pilot operation of its Intermarket Trading Systeman electronic hookup of the New York, American, Boston, Philadelphia and Pacific stock exchanges. The stocks are Atlantic Richfield, Chrysler, Cluett Peabody; General Instrument; Johnson & Johnson; Kraft; Marathon; J. Ray McDermott; Merck, NCR and Standard Oil of Indiana.

title: Sanderson Joins Penguins Tonight
description: Derek Sanderson, retired since last November, will return to National Hockey League action tonight with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

description: The Shadow Open Market Committee, a selfappointed group of rcademic and business economists who gather every six months to evaluate Government monetary and fiscal poiicy, warned yesterday that the dollar could not be expected to stabilize in the foreign exchange market if large Frdeiai budget deficits, nignty VaTlaDIC mane. tary policies, growing restrictions th trade and misguided policies on onot gy Continue.

title: CURARE VIALS LINKED TO LOCKER OF DR. X
description: HACKENSACK, March 13A director of Riverdell Hospital testified today that after months of puzzling over why there were so many unexplained deaths at the Oradell hospital during 1966 he and other directors secretly opened the locker of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich and found vials of curare, a powerful muscle relaxant.

title: ASIAN GUNMEN SEIZE 72 IN DUTCH KOK
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, March 13South Asian nationalist gunmen stormed a threestory government building on the 1 outskirts of this northern Dutch town today, seizing 72 hostages and demand ing the release of comrades in Dutch jails I and a plane to fly all of them out of the country.

description: TUESDAY, MARCH 14, 1978

title: DOLLAR WEAK AGAIN AS TRADERS DISCOUNT AGREEMENT TO AID IT
description: Economists and Bankers Say They See Nothing New in Plan and Urge U.S. Fight on Inflation

title: N.C.A.A. Is Warned On Reprisals
description: WASHINGTON, March 13Representative John E. Moss, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Oversight  and Investigation,warned the National Collegiate Athletic Association today that any attempt to threaten witnesses before his subcommittee could result in action by the Justice Department against the N.C.A.A. and its officers.

title: To Break the Cycle of Hate
description: It is not enough to condemn the senseless terror against Israel. It is not enough to warn that if the negotiations falter now, the Fatah guerrillas will have won again, destroying not the lives of dozens but the peace of millions. It is not enough to recognize that the terror, born in Palestinian hate, also threatens the interests of other Arab nations, notably Egypt. None of this is enough because in their torment Israelis also hate.

title: Letdown Over Dollar Pact Spurs FuturesPrice Surge In Grains and Soybeans
description: The dollar's relapse . despite a joint United StatesWest German plan to bolster the currency spurred huge advances yesterday in soybean and grain futures prices, The Associated Press reported.

title: Acquisition for Witco Chemical
description: The Witco Chemical Corporation has purchased for cash the operating assets of the North American Chemical Corporation, Paterson, N.J. Witco's Ultra division will assume responsibility for operating the acquired assets, according to William Wishnick, chairman of the company.

title: World News Briefs
description: ROME, March 13Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti's new Cabinet consisting entirely of Christian Democrats was sworn in today in a short ceremony by President Giovanni Leone.

title: LANDLORDS BALKING AT WINDOW GUARDS
description: Landlords throughout the city, including the New York City Housing Authority, are seriously concerned about a littleknown Health Code regulation that requires guard bars on the windows of all apartments whose tenants include children 10 years old or younger.

title: Charge of Welfare Waste Assailed In New York City Council Hearing
description: A report by the State Welfare Inspector General charging that the city was losing up to a quarter of a billion dollars year in fraudulent or incorrect welfare payments was criticized at a City Council hearing yesterday, not only by city officials, but by another state welfare official as well.

title: Federal Spending $8.7 Billion Below Carter Budget
description: WASHINGTON, March 13The Government reported today that once again Federal spending was running below estimated levels and would impart less stimulus to the economy than had been antitiDated.

title: Bronx Group Carter Visited Gets Grant
description: A South Bronx housing-rehabilitation group to which President Carter paid a surprise visit last October has been granted $500,000 by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development to put 75 neighborhood youths to work on improvement projects in the MelroseMorrisania section, Thomas Appleby, the regional administrator for the department reported yesterday.

title: Chicagoans Visit Meadowlands
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, March 13A debegation of 18 Chicago officials, led by Mayor Michael A. Bilandic and former Gov. Richard Ogilvie of Illinois, toured the Meadowlands Sports Complex today looking for ideas on how to construct and operate a similar athletics facility in their city.

title: A New Method For Converting Coal to Liquids
description: A simplified method for converting coal yesterday at the national meeting of the other petroleum products was disclosed yesterday at the national meeting of the American Chemical Society in Anaheim, Calif.

title: Energy Department Presses Plan To Convert Waste to Electricity
description: NEWARK, March 13The New Jersey Department of Energy recommended today a program for converting the state's daily accumulation of 17,000 tons of municipal solid waste into fivebillion kilowatt hours of electricity a year.

title: Questionable Commissions
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged that more than $1 million in questionable commission fees were paid to an official of the South Korean Embassy in connection with the sale by ESystems Inc. of electronic equipment to .the Korean Government. The company neither confirmed nor denied the charges and has consented to a permanent injunction against securitieslaw violations. Page 49.

title: Queens Party Leader and Broker Are Reported Named in Indictment
description: As a result of an extensive investigation into allegations of corruption in the Queens Democratic Party organization, the office of the special state prosecutor, has filed sealed indictments charging a Queens Democratic district leader and a politically active insurance broker with arson, according to persons close to the, investigation.

title: The Family of Onions: A Good Bunch
description: rROM the grassy chives with their fragrant springtime flavor to the lusty leek, from the tiniest crystal white pearl onions to the giant zlobes of Spanish onions that lend a pungent sting to salads, herrings and hamburgers, the onion and all of its odoriferous relatives make up the world's most widely used vegetable family, and one of the oldest known to man. A species of the lily and amaryllis, the onion has been used as food for at least 4,000 years; the Egyptian pyramids, it has been said, owe their existence to onions that sustained the builders. The Egyptians also regarded the onion as a symbol of eternity because of its layer within layer formation. Our name for it derived from the Latin unio, meaning united, because of the way dividing onion bulbs remain clustered.

title: Quake Aftershock Felt on Coast
description: LA HABRA, Calif., March 14 (AP)----A small earthquake aftershock was felt in this eastern Los Angeles County community today, but aside from one cracked window, no damage was reported. The tremor was an aftershock to yesterday's quake here, which registered 3.4 on the Richter scale but caused minimal damage,

title: BELL ASKS FOR CONTROL OF GOVERNMENT LAWYERS
description: Attorney General Griffin B. Bell proposed yesterday that the Attorney General's office be given authority over Government lawyers outside the Justice Department, according to the Associated Press.

title: Fire Kills Refinery Worker
description: CHALMETTE, La., March 14 (AP)A flash fire killed one man today at a Tenneco Oil Company refinery, the site of an explosion that killed 13 persons in 1976. The fire brokeout in a unit where gasoline components are blended, according to the plant manager, Charles Kilgore, and was extinguished by employees. The dead man, a Tenneco employee, was not immediately identified.

title: Britain Bows to U.S. in Dispute Over TransAtlantic Air Fares
description: Britain has yielded in Its dispute with the United States over low transAtlantic air fares, sources close to Government negotiations over the issue said yesterday. The sources predicted that an increased volume of lowcost tickets soon would be available on most major scheduled routes between this country and Europe.

title: F.B.I. Is Destroying Criminal Files On Cases Closed for Five Years
description: WASHINGTON, March 14The Federal Bureau of Investigation, over the objections of some of its agents but with the consent of the National Archives, has begun to destroy the inactive criminal files in its field offices of cases that have been closed for five years.

title: Villard Interiors Go Into Storage
description: Workmen in the Villard Houses began the painstaking task of dismantling the fine interiors of the Manhattan landmark town houses, to be, stored during construction of the 51story Palace Hotel. The rooms will be reassembled and incorporated into hotel structure.

title: Dr. X's Accuser Compliments Him
description: HACKENSACK, N. .J., March 14Dr. MarioE. Jascalevieh, on trial for murdering five patents at Kiverdell Hospital by giving them lethal doses of curare, was described today as a hrilliant and excellent'surgeon by the doctor who accused him of the murders.

title: Dayan Tells the Israelis That Egypt Does Not Require That Jordan Join in the Peace Talks
description: JERUSALEM, March 14The Israeli press and radio carried reports today citing a political source in Jerusalem as having said that Egypt was no longer insisting that Jordan participate in Middle East peace negotiations.

title: GoodPitch, NoPunch Mets Win
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 14The New York Mets, who traded pitching to get punch, continued their strange spring today when they defeated the Minnesota Twins, 10, for their second shutout in three days.

title: Ruth O'Neill, Executive In Concert Management, Secretary to Stokotvski
description: Ruth O'Neill, formerly a leading executive in concert management, died Saturday of pneumonia in a hospital in Tucson, Ariz. She was 87 years old.

title: Stocks, Cheered by a Settlement Of Coal Strike, Post Small Gain
description: News that a settlement had been reached in the coal strike helped the stock market yesterday to post a modest gain in active trading.

title: Britain Reports a Trade Surplus Of $350 Million During February
description: LONDON, March 14The Government, in a, report with farreaching economic and political implications, reported today that Britain registered a $350 million trade surplus last month following two monthly deficits including a big and unexnected one in January,

title: John L.'s Legacy
description: He was an old man when I met him. We grew to know one another, cautiously, from the time he was 84 until his death, in 1969, in his 90th year. Early during those years I mar- tied into the family, once large and proud and strong, then reduced to few, almost all now gone. The first evening I met him I was apprehensive. He scrutinized me with those clear, clear, Welsh blue eyes, a gaze that felt as though it went through me and found a focal point about a foot behind my head. He was not a giant, to my surprise, but a broad man, diminished by age to little taller than myself. Through the next years the white hair thinned more, the body hunched and faltered. The voice was often quiet, the thoughts away in time. The eyebrows, his trademark, whitened, but remained thick and fierce.

title: Film: De Palma Mixes Genres in 'Fury':Psyching a Spy
description: "TELEPATHY," someone says solemnly in "The Fury" is a timeless form of communication to which Woody Allen (were he around) might add with equal solemnity, "and far cheaper than Western Union.""The Fury," which opens today at the National, Cine and other theaters, was directed by Brian De Palma in what appears to have been an all-out effort to transform the small-scale, Grand Guignol comedy of his "Carrie" into an international horror/spy/occult mind-blower of a movie. He didn't concentrate hard enough, though. "The Fury" is bigger than "Carrie," more elaborate, much more expensive and far sillier. Let's face itit's the De Palma "1900"a movie that somehow got out of hand.It's also, in fits and starts, the kind of mindless fun that only a horror movie that so seriously pretends to be about the mind can be. Mr. De Palma seems to have been less interested in the overall movie than in pulling off a couple of spectacular set-pieces, which he does. He leaves the rest of "The Fury" to take care of itself.The John Farris screenplay, though based on a published novel, has the air of something that hasn't been thought clearly through, or at least thought through to the point where basic plot questions don't distract us from enjoying a line like, "I'm just a receiver and Robin sends me pictures."The girl who says this is one of the two doomed young people who possess the power, like that of the heroine of "Carrie," to move objects through force of will. They also are able to communicate, telepathically, to share memories with someone unknown, to detonate things and to bring on cerebral hemorrhages at random. The film's pathology is as confused as the story, so one spends most of "The Fury" impatiently anticipating the next demonstration of something that one keeps hoping will be unspeakable but never is.In particular, "The Fury" is about Peter Sanza (Kirk Douglas), an American superagent whose son, a fellow with psychic powers, is abducted from an Israeli beach by one of Peter's colleagues, apparently for the exclusive use of the United States Government.For most of the film, Peter searches vainly for the young man (why he had to be abducted is never made clear), the trail eventually taking him to Chicago and to a mysterious "institute" where the psychically gifted are studied. There Peter finds not his son, but a young woman named Gillian (Amy Irving) who is in thought communication with the son.The story is too witless to bear more scrutiny than that. The things that keep one sitting through "The Fury" when one's mind knows better are the occasional action sequences (including a fine, funny automobile chase through Chicago) and the special effects that finally bring the movie to an end that recalls "Zabriski Point," on a more personal level.When a screenplay is so bad, there truly isn't much that actors can do except behave themselves, which is more or less what happens. In addition to Mr. Douglas and Miss Irving, the most prominent members of the cast are John Cassavetes as the Government kidnapper, Andrew Stevens (Stella's boy) as the son, and Charles Durning as the head of the mysterious institute.The most peculiar thing about the movie is why Carrie Snodgress, who retired after receiving an Oscar nomination for "Diary of a Mad Housewife," should have elected to use it as her comeback film. It's a nothing rolethat of a psychiatric instructor who helps Mr. Douglas locate his son. She's efficient and so invisible it's as if she never left home.

Her able leadership extended to the National Organization where she served as State Regional President, Chairwoman of various national committees and National Historian. As a leader, Director. title: Film: Winner's Version of 'Big Sleep':Showroom Piece
description: HOWARD HAWKS directed the 1946 version of "The Big Sleep" in black and white, so it's conceivable that Mr. Hawks didn't furnish Philip Marlowe's bedroom with color-coordinated sheets and blankets merely because he wasn't able to. However, it's also conceivable that Mr. Hawks chose deliberately to depict Marlowe as something other than an immaculately appointed fellow with a decorating flair. Michael Winner's new film version of the Raymond Chandler novel concentrates so heavily on the dapper side of Marlowe that it makes the first version look like an unmade bedwhich may be what it was meant to look like, after all.There are no shadows in this senselessly gaudy remake; there isn't much nighttime, either, and there isn't any rain. There isn't any Los Angeles, because Mr. Winner, pretending to switch the story's setting to London for no intelligible reason, seems actually to have transferred it to a succession of furniture-store showrooms. Not a single prop looks used, not even the dainty china cups put of which Marlowe drinks his morning coffee.The name of Lew Grade, the British entrepreneur who "presents" this new versionhe has also sponsored "The Cassandra Crossing" and "Voyage of the Damned"has come to denote too many stars and not enough savvy. Sure enough, "The Big Sleep" is overloaded with big names, and in this case the net effect of an all-star cast is to make an already confusing mystery even harder to follow.Oliver Reed is hilariously foppish as the gangster Eddie Mars and Richard Boone is almost as delightful a villain here as he as in "The Shootist." But Joan Collins, Edward Fox, John Mills and even James Stewart get lost in the shuffle, reeling off plot details that will seem confusing to anyone who hasn't seen Mr. Hawks's version or read Mr. Chandler's, and numbingly familiar to anyone who has.As the insinuatingly sensual Charlotte Sternwood, in a role first played by Lauren Bacall, Sarah Miles is at least twice as lewd as the screenplay requires her to be, and nowhere near as electrifying. Candy Clark, as Miss Miles's mad younger sister, winds up in desperate trouble Under Mr. Winner's dependably off-base direction, Miss Clark skips and giggles and foams at the mouth, frantically overplaying the most unsalvageable kook role of her kook-ridden career. It would be lovely to find her playing someone who made sense once in a while.Mr. Winner, who wrote the screenplay as well as directed it, approaches Mr. Chandler's material with the same depth and delicacy he brought to "Death Wish." It's hard to imagine a director less suited to the subtleties of this kind of story, but then subtleties aren't anything Mr. Winner even tries for. Instead of struggling with the seediness implicit in this story's layer upon of layer of corruption. Mr. Winner substitutes a high-priced vulgarity that wipes out every last touch of evil. The villains in this version aren't wicked, and they aren't even particularly villainous. They just manage to do everything in stultifyingly bad taste.If Robert Mitchum seemed to be an effective Marlowe in the 1975 "Farewell, My Lovely," that had as much to do with Dick Richards's carefully evocative direction as it did with the actor's performance.Mr. Mitchum's world-weariness and his unflappable calm simply don't, on their own, add up to the suspicious, swaggering style that the character and the overall movie require. Taking the strong, silent route once again, Mr. Mitchum gives a performance meant to blend in with the kind of lurid and evocative backdrop Mr. Richards's film provided. But Mr. Winner strips away the neon colors, the 40's costumes and the pulp-novel paraphernalia, substituting sunny skies and a lot of green lawn. With only that to work against, the best Mr. Mitchum can do, figuratively speaking, is to play croquet.

title: MOSCOW COURT IMPRISONS BROTHER OF A DISSIDENT
description: MOSCOW, March 14 (Reuters)A Moscow court today sentenced the brother of an active dissident to two and half years imprisonment on charges of illegally possessing a firearm and ammunition.

title: She Joined the Navy, but Hates the Tug
description: GROTON, Conn.'This is hell on water; I hate boats, I can't swim; since Day One I've been trying to get off this thing, said Brenda McLeod, a sea- man apprentice aboard YTB (Yard Tug Big) 834, which daily chugs up and down the Thames River, pushing and hauling Navy vessels with her all-female deck crew.

title: Seat on C.M.E. Sold For Record $190,000
description: A record $190,000 was paid yesterday for a seat on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the nation's second biggest commodity market. The new asking price is $250.000. The previous record sale was $172,500, effected last Feb. 9.

title: Dutch Marines Free All Hostages And Capture 3 Asian Terrorists
description: ASSEN, the Netherlands, March 14A special team of 60 antiterrorist Dutch marines charged into a local government building here today and after a brief exchange of fire freed 70 hostages held since yesterday by three Asian gunmen.

title: China Publishes Einstein Work
description: HONG KONG, March 14 (Reuters)China has produced a threevolume translation of Einstein's works, Hsinhua, the official news agency, reported today. Chou Peiyuan, vice president of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, was quoted as saying in an introduction to the 133,000character edition, that the physicist's cultural and scientific heritage would have a positive effect on the development of sciences in China.

title: N.F.L. Adds Official, Receivers Get Help

title: Tancree Is Revived
description: real operatic rarity, Rossini's Tancredi, was given a concert performance by the Opera Orchestra of New York last night in Carnegie Hall. Even in the great days of the bel canto revival there was only one major revival, in Florence, 1952. Most of the music in Tancredi is altogether unfamiliar. There are some forgotten operas known by one or two arias, but even the most famous aria in Tancredi forgotten. Di tanti palpitihas been virtually This was the 10th of Rossini's 39 operas, and it had its premiere in 1813. The plot? Divorced from its ramifications, it has to do with the love between Tancrdi (sung by a mezzo-soprano) and Amenaide. Only Tancredi thinks she has deceived him by going over to the enemy, and not until he dying of wounds received in a battle against the Saracens are they united. It is pretty weak, even by the standards of the day.
