title: Screen: 'House Calls':Divorcee's Love Story
description: WANTED: Personable actress, mid-30's or older, to play a wry divorce with romantic leanings, a consumer advocate who gets most of her information from Reader's Digest, and avid reader of nothing but best sellers, and perhaps the first movie heroine to make her living by baking since Mildred Pierce. Divorce will meet and fall for a surgeon, now an eligible widower, to be played by a gruff, lovable actor who never stands up straight. Eventually, they will jog together and romp in the sand. Presumably, this will be love.If all of this makes perfect sense to you, consider the fact that the sweethearts of "House Calls" are played by Glenda Jackson and Walter Matthau, an odd couple if ever there was one. Mr. Matthau is no problem: He has been gruff but lovable before, and he never stands up straight anyway.But Mr. Matthau and Miss Jackson don't particularly set off fireworks together, and Miss Jackson is way too steely to play the kind of woman who'd sit up all night watching the candles burn down if Dr. Right didn't arrive for dinner on schedule, or who would hope to bag that special guy by whipping up that special cheese-cake.Howard Zieff, who also directed "Slither" and the frequently funny "Hearts of the West," swivels nervously among enough plot points for three and a half different movies. One of them, the love story, could be "Pete 'n' Tillie"in fact, it already has been. The second thread is about the workings of a poorly administered hospital, run by a sneakily senile doctor (played by Art Carney) with an amusingly selective memory.The third and most interesting element has to do with the indignities to which the young submit the middle-aged (Mr. Matthau, after attending a rock concert with a nurse he's dating, has to sit in a beanbag chair in her apartment), and to which the middle-aged submit the old.The half movie is an affectionate comedy about a married man who begins to regard himself as a ladykiller when he becomes a bachelor again, and perhaps it should have been a whole movie. But Mr. Matthau's career as a swinger is cut short soon after Miss Jackson blazes a trail to his heart by way of his stomach.Mr. Zieff, who directed commercials before he came to movies, is as crisp and economical with brief comic vignettes as he is overwhelmed by the demands of a sustained plot; "House Calls" continuously juggles fast, flashy jokes with nagging inconsistencies. The early portion of the movie is quite promising, especially sincebecause the doctor meets the divorce when the rewires her broken jaw, and she doesn't get to talk until later onit takes a while to realize how seriously Miss Jackson has been miscast.Once it becomes apparent that this droll, tough-minded actress is playing a tomato who wants little more from life than a few trash novels and a jogging partner, confusion set in."House Calls" tries to seem stern and modern in establishing the divorce's independence, and her superiority to the bimbos the doctor regularly courts, but it turns too sentimental too soon. One minute these lovers are talking good, solid horse sense about their relationship; the next minute they're mired in mush.Mr. Zieff seems never to have determined what sort of romance he wanted to show, and as a result the movie is constantly contradicting itself.Mr. Matthau, Miss Jackson and Mr. Carney are as pleasant and plausible as a jumpy screenplay and Mr. Zieff's wandering directorial attention will allow Richard Benjamin is less unctuous here than he's been in years, and Candice Azzara, in something like a Judy Holliday role, offers the kind of quick caricature that Mr. Zieff often uses to fill his movies with types rather than people.Among the questions the film inadvertently raises are: How does Mr. Matthau manage to charm a rich widow into reconsidering her lawsuit against the hospital merely by mentioning Brooklyn? Has there ever been a clumsier seduction scene than the the main one presented here? And how come Mr. Matthau, after Miss Jackson steals his clothes and hides them in her freezer, manages to find in her closet a boa-trimmed bathrobe that fits him better than it fits her."House Calls" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested") because Mr. Matthau spends part of the movie as a swinger and because he and Miss Jackson evidently become more than good friends.

title: Groton Takes Threat of Layoffs in Stride

title: A Converted Barn
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. UESTS may occasionally be tempted to say that the horses once stabled at what is now the Crawford home here would hardly recognize the place. In fact that bit of wit is not entirely accurate. Anne and George Crawford have indeed converted a centuriesold barn into a justso retreat for themselves and their four children, and a showcase for some unusual and idiosyncratic pieces of early American and contemporary art. But in many ways, the house remains a barn, with barn siding, old brick barn floors, a barn roof, and even, in the master bedroom, a secondstory square barn door once used for loading hay into the area where two of the Crawford children now sleep.

description: TEL AVIV, March 15 (AP)The defense in the trial of Sami Esmail, an American of Palestinian descent accused of belonging to a Palestinian guerrilla organization, challenged the validity of Mr. Esmail's confession today.

title: Complex Fight Over City Pay
description: The bargaining between New York City and its unions is just beginning but already it is setting a mark for contrariness. The employers list of demands longer than the workers proposals despite the city's retraction of 10 demands on Tuesday. Vie bestKnown labor leaders talk about restraint, and the liveliest slugging exchange comes between two union leaders.

title: News Summary
description: Israel routed Palestinian guerrillas from at least seven strategic strongholds in southern Lebanon all along Israel's northern frontier. Prime Minister Menachem Begin said the Israelis would remain until assured of border security. The land, sea and air operations continued as Israel acquired what a military leader called a security belt 63 miles long and up to six miles into Lebanese territory. Defense Minister Ezer Weizman told reporters, We shall continue to clear the areaprevent the area from being attack positions against us as long as we find necessary. The offensive, the biggest Israel has ever launched against the Palestine Liberation Organization, also involved air strikes at Palestinian camps far north of the Israeli border, including at least two near Beirut. An army spokesman said that one base was used by Arab raiders who entered Israel Saturday and killed more than 30 Israeli civilians. [Page Col. 6.1

title: 4 Killed in Minnesota Fire
description: BAUDETTE, Minn., March 15 (UPI)Three children and their grandmother were killed today in a fire that swept through a lumberjack's home near the Canadian border. The dead were the chil- dren of Martin and Margaret RambegScott, 5 years old; Shelley, 3, and Sandy, IS months, and Mrs. Ramberg's mother, Mrs. Floyd Olson. Mrs. Ramberg and another son, Shawn, II, escaped through window when awakened by the barking of the family dog.

title: Independent Inquiry Is Requested In Gas Allotments to Billy Carter
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)Two Democratic Representatives said today that they had asked Attorney General Griffin B. Bell for an independent investigation of allegations that President Carter's brother, Billy, and other politically wellconnected Georgians had got emergency gasoline allotments they had not deserved.

title: E.P.A. Proposes Rules to Reduce The Noise Level of Motorcycles
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPI)The roar of motorcycles would be somewhat muffled starting in 1980 under an Environmental Protection Agency regulation proposed today.

title: Music: Tancredi Revived in Concert
description: Areal operatic rarity, Rossini's Tancredi. was given a concert performance by the Opera Orchestra of New York Tuesday night in Carnegia Hall. Even in the great days of the bel canto revival there was only one major revival, in Florence in 1952. Most of the music in Tancredi is altogether unfamiliar. There are some forgotten operas known by one or two arias, but even the most famous aria in Tancredi 'Di tanti palpitihas been virtually forgotten.

title: Deaths
description: FREEBORNBeatrice Dwight on March 14, 1978 In NYC. Wife of the late James Livingston Freeborn of NYC and Germantown, NY. Survived by two daughters Mrs. G. Edward Stamm of NYC and Beatrice Livingston Freeborn of Rome, NY. Funeral Service and burial St. PauIs Church, Tivoli, New York on Friday, March 17th at 12 noon. Memorial service Church of the incarnation Madison Avenue at 35th St Thursday, March 23rd at 11AM. Contributions to House of the Holy Comforter 2751 Grand Concourse, Bronx will be appreciated.

title: 6 Guilty in Attack At Washington Sq
description: Six of nine young men charged with taking part in a 1976 rampage in Washington Square Park that left one man dead and 13 persons injured were found guilty yesterdaythree of manslaughter and three of lesser charges.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Living Section yesterday erroneously identified The Royal Victorians as a BBC television series. Actually, it was produced for Britain's commercial network by LeW. Grade's ATV company.

title: Finally, the Panama Canal Vote
description: So, after six months of debate it comes down to handful of uncommitted Senators. That is the drama today's Senate vote on the first of the two Panama Canal treaties signed last September, the agreement providing for the canal's permanent neutrality and acknowl- edging permanent right of the United States to defend The second treaty, which turns over to Panama ownership of the canal and operating responsibility by the end of the century, will come up for a vote in April.

title: Witness in D X Trial Concedes Faulty Diagnosis

Jascalevich that, contrary to Dr. Jascalevich's recommendation, he had made a mistaken diagnosis in suggesting an operation on a patient who died suddenly after that operation.

title: WILLIAM GORDON DIKE
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 15 (UPI)William Gordon Dike, a physicist who helped the United States develop the atom bomb in World War II, died Sunday in Methodist Hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: City Bar Group Is Investigating 2 Lawyers Over Links to Sex Business
description: A controversial aide to a New York State Senator who accused two lawyers of unethical behavior has been appointed special counsel in a disciplinary investigation of the lawyers, who specialize in representing sexoriented businesses.

title: Eastwick, Sad as a Red, Relieved to Be a Yankee
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 15This was life for Rawly Eastwick with Cincinnati last year: Dick Wagner [Reds vice president] told me I wasn't as good as I thought I was. That tends to break your commence. Atter a wnite. ra go out cn the mount and wonder what would happen next. I couldn't conand do my job because I couldn't concentrate. I was going out on the mound thinking about too many things, about all the problems I had with Cincinnati, the contract and other things.

title: People and Business
description: Robert A. Baker, who has served since October 1976 as trustee for the reorganization of the Equity Funding Corporation of America, has been named fiscal agent for the Commonwealth Oil Refining Company.

title: Divided Lebanon Again Becomes A Battlefield
description: With the invasiqn of Lebanon by thousands of Israeli troops, the tiny country, still recovering from 19 months of virulent civil war, has once again become a major battlefield.

title: And Who Would Say Neigh?
description: TRENTON, March 15 (AP)  New Jersey has named a committee to plan construction of a $7 million diagnostic and research center to serve its multimilliondollar horse industry. The facility was recommended after a study showed that horseowners had to leave the state for treatment, lab work and surgery on their animals.

title: MILTON PERLMUTTER, HEAD OF STORE GROUP
description: Milton Perlmutter, president and chief executive officer of the Supermarkets General Corporation, died yesterday at his home in Short Hills, N. J. He was 50 years old.

title: Events/Sports
Puerto Rico Utility Sale Effort Ends
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, March 15 (UPI)The Puerto Rican Government today gave up its efforts to sell the island telephone company back to private en- terprise. J. Raymond Watson, president of the Puerto Rico Telephone Company, urged the island legislature to repeal the law authorizing the sale of the public utility. At a news conference, Mr. Watson said the repeal of the law is necessary for the floating of new bonds.

title: DEATN-PBNALTY BILL IS PUT OFF IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, March 15Deadlocked by a dispute on the selection of new members to the Board of Regents, the Democraticcontrolled Assembly set aside its plans to take up the death penalty today and nut the issue off until next Monday.

title: Convicted Pennsylvania Official Wins $10,925-a-Year State Pension
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., March 15 (UFO)Former State Senator Henry J. Cianfranl, now serving a Federal prison term for extortion, income tax evasion and mail fraud, won authorization today for a $10,925-a-year state pension.

description: LOS ANGELES

description: SECAUCUS, March 15Hartz Mountain Industries suffered a minor setback today in its battle to win land rights to build a $100 million shopping center in the Hackensack Meadowlands here.

title: Piano: Mark Zeltser
description: MARK ZELTSER is a 30-yearold pianist who emigrated from the Soviet Union to the United States, via Italy, two years ago. After his arrival here, word went around that he was exceptional, even in an era that has spawned so many gifted young virtuosos. He was engaged to appear with the New York Philharmonic, where he made his debut, and his recital debut, which took place last night in Alice Tully Hall, was made a part of the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series.

His new venture is to be financed by CBs.

It is a fair request, particularly after Yasir Arafat took pride in the brutal assault on Israeli civilians last weekend and promised more of the same.

description: WEST FRANKFORT, Ill., March 15The prevailing attitude among miners here in southern Illinois today was one of cautious and often skeptical appraisal as details reached them of a new contract nronosal to settle their longest strike.

title: Sound
description: LOST in the maze of the new United States Copyright Law, apparently missed a point when I said that toping off the air (or copying phonograph records) was permissible if done for private enjoyment and not commercial purpose. For anyone who has followed the history of this law, a bit of confusion seems it order. All alone it had been the ex pressed intent of Congress to put no restraint on home rz.scord.ng when not done for profit. As one observer remarked, most Congressmen's children are taping radio programs, and the legislators don't want to have criminals in the family. But curiously, the special sanction for home recording was knocked out of the bill at the last minute. so taping off the air or copying records, even if done for private use only, must be considered an actionable infringement.

But Mr. Wagoner's own cherubic presence and easy, expansive way of moving and his evocation of the downhome courtesies of another time and place temper that eccentricity, as was the case on Tuesday, when Dan Wagoner and Dancers appeared in the Dance Umbrella festival at the Entennedia Theater.

description: WASHINGTON, March 15 - Three years ago, Thomas J. Downey nervously took his seat in the House of Representatives. At 25, he was the youngest member of the new Congress and eagerly sought an assignment on one of the influential committees.

title: NEW &
description: Bronze Foo dogs for $8,000 a pair . . porcelain wanton spoons for $15 each . . . a tablesize screen inlaid with jade and amethyst stones for $3,100 . . . a porcelain Buddha for $75 . . and much, much more can be found these days on the fifth floor at Abraham & Straus. The store has mounted an exhibition and sale of more than $300,000 worth. of Ch'ing Dynasty treasures imported from the People's Republic of China by Michael Srednick Company of Los Angeles. Although there are scores of examples of the blue and white porcelain vases and bowls that one would expect to see, there are also such delights as roof tiles in the shape of fish (symbolizing freedom) ar parrots (a reminder tolvives to be faithful the parrot would talk) and a collection of jewelry ranging from glass bracelets at $10 to elaborate necklaces. silver and colored stones for $350. Pieces of antique embroidery suitable for framing are $20 to $75, and there is even a wall hanging embellished with the Forbidden Stitch (socalled because working on such tiny stitches led to blindnest, and the stitch was finally banned) for $2,800. Most of the wares are 19th century, but there are also some modern Chinese watercolors on silk paper ($15 to $25). The show will be at the Brooklyn store until Sunday, and at the Abraham and Straus stores in Manhasset, and Center from 6 16.

title: SCHOOL BOARD HEAD IS CALLED BY GOLDIN
description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin yesterday subpoenaed Stephen R. Aiello, president of the Board of Education, to appear Friday in the Comptroller's office to testify under oath and supply records concerning the city's vocational schools.

description: Maggie McNamara, the diminutive actress who starred in the controversial 1953 film, The Moon Is Blue, died from an overdose of pills on Feb. 18 in New York. She was 48 years old.

title: The Rhodesian Tangle
description: BOSTON. March 15The internal settlement reached by Ian Smith and three black leaders in Rhodesia is at tracting significant support in Britain and the United States. A number of editorial voices have praised it. and businesses interested in Rhodesian Minerals are starting to lobby hard for it in Congress. The Carter Administration is likely to face increasing pressure to endorse the settlement.

title: Kim Trial Opens in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (UPDHancho C. Kim, charged with conspiring to pass $600,000 to members of Congress on behalf of the Korean Government, today became the first person to stand trial in connection with the influencebuying case.

description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission voted unanimously today to find out what it could do to halt the proliferation of unwanted funk phone calls.

title: Hers.
description: EDITH WHARTON and Henry James are often discussed as a pair of writers whose similarity of idiom makes comparison irresistible (both came out of the same world, both Were endlessly preoccupied with the trapped quality of that world, and both endowed it with metaphoric meaning). A favorite amusement of JamesWharton readers is to describe an appropriate tale and then ask: Which of the two would have written this? Recently, I.observed an incident in a contemporary iversidk. at the WhartonJames world which brought :this game bidlt to my mind.

title: Ski Areas Undaunted By Recent Rainstorm

Those reauirements will be difficult to meet. The im- portance of economic development was emphasized by Mayor Beame's raising the position to the rank of Deputy Mayor, a distinction continued by Mayor Koch.

title: Soviet Dissident Is Said to Reject Court-Appointed Defense Lawyer

title: Book Awards Again Stir Controversy

In the past, most disputes surged around the winners, This year, one surfaced even betore tne nominations were announced, when Roger Straus, head of Farrar, Straus & Giroux, learned that Edmund Wilson's Letters on Literature and Politics, 19121972, edited by Elena Wilson, which he had published, was regarded as ineligible.

description: WASHINGON, March 15The director of the Federation of American Scientists said today that new observations supported his thesis that links flights of the supersonic Concorde to many of the mysterious booms heard along the East Coast in recent months.

title: ATOM PLANT DANGERS AT SEA HELD GREATER
description: TRENTON, March 15A new study by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission being circulated here finds that a major accident at a floating nuclear power plant nronosed off Atlantic City. while very improbable, could contaminate sea and fish with radioactivity, close long stretches of beach for months and cause cancer.

title: DEFENSE CHIEF CRITICIZES VETERAN JOB PREFERENCE
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 (AP)Laws giving veterans preference for Federal jobs have become a perpetual entitlement rather than a bridge from military to civilian life, according to Defense Secretary Harold Brown.

title: GARDENING
description: TOMORROW, St. Patrick will turn the warm side of the stones uppermost and new potatoes can be planted. According to tradition, his feast day is also the proper time to sow grain and plant peas.

title: Mixed Results of Integration Typified in Louisville School
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., March 13When Central High was an allblack school in the heart of the Louisville ghetto, the yard was full of weeds and junk. Just before it was integrated in 1975, the yard was converted into a running track with all the latest equipment.

title: Humidifiers: Airing the Pros and Cons

At its best, a humidifier adds moisture to the airprotecting art, furniture, plants and the human body from drying out. But a humidifier, if not kept cleaned, can also add bacterial growths to the air, causing allergic reactions in some people.

title: U.S. Expects No Permanent Disposal of Nuclear Waste Before 1988
description: WASHINGTON, March 15Permanent disposal of nuclear wastes, a central element of President Carter's plan to encourage use of atomic power, cannot be achieved before 1988, three years later than was estimated six months ago, and may not be achieved then, Federal officials said today.

title: Notes on People

Yes. it was the George Wash- ington, and under the terms of the posthumous promotion, the commander of the Continental Army in the American Revolution and the nation's first President was promoted to the newly created rank of General of the Armies of the United States. Congress authorized the new title two years ago to make it absolutely clear that Washington is the Army's senior general.

title: SADAT AFFIRMS GOAL IS PEACE IN MIDEAST
description: CAIRO, March 16President Anwar elSadat said today that he wanted to continue his Middle East peace efforts, which have been shaken by the new Middle East fighting, but he underlined that these efforts would depend on what Israel did next in Lebanon.

title: Screen: 'American Hot Wax':Brooklyn Rocks
description: THERE'S the seed of an interesting movie inside "American Hot Wax," but it never gets a chance to sprout. The picturesque aspects of the 50's reach way beyond cinch belts and finny Cadillacs, and the flap surrounding the birth of rock-and-roll is evidence that style can be as important as substance in initiating social change. But "American Hot Wax," which has a plot so thin you could thread a needle with it, chooses to see the era strictly in terms of the B-movie melodramas it produced."Look," says the disk jockey Alan Freed, as the police try to muscle in on a concert he is sponsoring, "you can close the show. You can stop me. But you never can stop rock-and-roll, don't you know that?" Of course they know it, and we know it, tooas the title of one song performed at this same concert puts it, "Rock-and-Roll Is Here to Stay." The suspenseful elements of the movie, and its stabs at poignancy, are strictly old news.Alan Freed, played gently and reservedly by Tim McIntire, is less the movie's focus than its storm center. Freed, who pointedly applied the name "rock-and-roll" to what had once been called "race music," and who regularly played records other white disk jockeys were afraid to go near, is never clearly established as a renegade, a fan, a fanatic or even a character.Instead, he's merely someone who marches from his crowded office through his bustling lobby and out to his encircled limousine, giving the camera a chance to glimpse the throngs of fans and musical aspirants who dogged his footsteps. The flurry of activity looks exciting for a while, but sooner or later an audience is bound to grow accustomed to the clutter, and unhappily aware that the movie has nowhere to go.Art Linson, who also produced "Car Wash," seems to subscribe to the notion that a completely amorphous movie can be a lively movie if everyone just keeps on jiving along and the viewer is never given a chance to think. So "Car Wash" was sloppy, and "American Hot Wax"which also manages to seem strangely anachronistic in applying disco-movie methods to the 50'sis even sloppier.The plot holes are as big as potholes, particularly when it comes to Mr. Freed's payola problems, and to his ambitions as an entrepreneur (in one scene, we watch him trying to buy a huge, very-California mansion that's supposed to be just outside of New York, but we never find out why he wants it or whether the sale is actually made).Mr. Freed's office is full of eager young singers who audition for him, some of them singing songs that were already hits in 1959, when the movie is setare these the people who went on to have the hit records, or are they merely imitating the most popular numbers of the day? Why are some hits attributed to the people who actually sang them, and others attributed to fictitious singers? Is Laraine Newman, of "Saturday Night Live," really plausible as an enormously gifted young songwriter, the kind of girl who later grew up to become Carole King?The movie's cast includes some of the world's oldest teen-agers, like Chuck Berry and Jerry Lee Lewis, old favorites who unfortunately perform their material as if they had been performing it for 20 years. (They have been.) It also includes the record producer Richard Perry, featured in a rousing little sequence that shows him making up the arrangement for "Come and Go With Me" right there in the studio, just by adding the proper set of dom-dom-dom-dom-dom's.And there is a wonderful, unexpectedly delicate scene between Freed and a young boy (Moosie Drier), who is president of the Buddy Holly fan club and who begins to cry as he tries to explain to Freed's listeners why he loved the late Holly so much. On this boy's face, there is more passion, more hopefulness, more understanding of what rock-and-roll meant to those who were most powerfully influenced by it than there is anywhere else in the movie.Some of the music is expertly repdered, particularly by the four blae male singers who play a fictitious group called The Chesterfields, and some of the concert numbers, like one by three women in spangled turquoise dresses, make a strongly evocative visual impression. A feeling of nostalgia does come through, powerfully at times. But there should have been a lot more to "American Hot Wax" than memories.

title: Trustee for Board 26 Is Taunted As His Ouster Is Sought at Hearing
description: The trustee appointed to take control of Community School Board 26 in Queens was loudly jeered last night as he held the first public hearing since the elected board was ousted last week.

title: Hanoi Charges Cambodians Seize Vietnamese Border Area on Coast
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 16 (AP)The Hanoi radio said today that Cambodian troops crossed the Vietnamese border on the Gulf of Siam Tuesday and occupied a tiny strip along the frontier.

title: TWO EXHUGHES AIDES CITED IN DRUGS CASE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16Two longtime associates of the late Howard it Hughes were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Las Vegas today on the charge that they conspired to provide Mr. Hughes with illegally obtained supplies of codeine.

title: Controversial New Landing System Approved for Westchester Airport
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 16The Westchester County Board of Acquisition and Contracts today unanimously approved the installation of a controversial second instrument landing system at the County Airport.

title: VESCO MUST STAND TRIAL, COSTA RICA COURT RULES
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, March 16 (Reuters)A Costa Rican court rued today that Robert Vesco must stand trial here on charges of fraud brought by Costa Rican citizen.

title: Carter Urban Policy: Blacks Concerned and Skeptical
description: A recent luncheon discussion among veteran black urbanologists at a meeting of the executive committee of the National Urban Coalition demonstrated the close attention that knowledgeable blacks are paying to the development of the urban

title: F.C.C. Censures CBS Over Sports
description: Culminating a 10month inquiry into irregularities by CBS Sports in its presentation of four tennis matches that were billed as The World Heavyweight Championship of Tennis. the Federal Communications Commission yesterday found that the network deceived the public and also violated commission rules concerning sponsorship identification and payola.

title: Spain May Admit Foreign Banking
description: MADRID, March 16  Spain's new democratic Government says it wants to lift the bah against foreign bank operations here, and some 20 banks, including most of the leading United States banks, have shown interest in setting up shop.

title: Mr. Carter, the Palestinians and Israel
description: WASHINGTON  The 16th of March occupies a special place in Middle East developments. Just year ago, President Carter told Clinton, Mass., audience that the Palestinians have a right to a homeland.

title: James P. Roach, the Sports Editor Of The Times F rom 58 to  73 , Dies
description: James P. Roach, retired sports editor of The New York Times, died early yesterday morning at New York Hospital. He was 70 years old, and had been suffering from a bonemarrow cancer. Mr. Roach was sports editor from 1958 until his retirement in 1973.

title: New Senator Gives Decisive 67th Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 16At 12:53 P.M. today Senator Paul G. Hatfield stood on the Senate floor and, his hands trembling slightly, announced his support of the Panama Canal treaty that would be voted on three hours later.

title: ,Israeli Immigrant Is 100 Years Old
description: TEL AVIV, March 16 (Reuters)Esther Tragman arrived in Israel from the Soviet Union today to begin a new life at 100 years old. Mrs. Tragman, who celebrated her birthday last Friday, was accompanied by her daughter, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren. Her eldest son, who is 67, came to Israel several years ago.

title: Market Place
description: Buyers of call options have been a most unhappy lot, by and large, since last year, thanks to the nearsteady decline in the prices of many leading stocks. Call options, which bowed into trading nearly five years ago, give their owners the right to buy an underlying stock at a specific price during the life of a contract.

title: DEMOCRATS PUT OFF SHOWDOWN ON RULES
description: WSHINGTON, March 16National Democratic leaders set the stage today for an orderly retreat from some of the more controversial proposals for change in the way Presidential candidates are chosen.

title: Bank Overseers Split On Insider Privileges
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Federal bank regulators disagreed today about whether the special privileges many banks give insiders are necessarily improper or unfair to the public.

title: CASTRO ASSERTS SOMALIA BROKE VOW WITH INVASION
description: HAVANA, March 16 (Reuters)President Fidel Castro said last night that Cuban officials held a secret meeting with Somali and Ethiopian leaders in Aden last March during which Somalia Pledged not to invade Ethiopia.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Play: Two Brothers
description: NEW HAVENIn the best tradition of institutional theaters, the Long Wharf Theater has grown organically: Need precedes capital construction. Recently, the company opened a second stage, Stage II, with a production of Conrad Bromberg's Two Brothers.

title: U.S. Text on Middle East Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, March 16-Following is the text of the American statement on the Israeli attach in southern Lebanon as read by Nodding Carter 3d, the State Department spokesman.

title: Art People
description: IN GENERAL, and with one or two significant exceptions, art dealing is a highvisibility profession. To be seen, to be known, to be talked aboutall these are almost mandatory.

title: Profile in Courage: Jim Roach
description: Jim Roach was the dearest of friends, he was the best newspaper men and he was the bravest man I have known. Death released him early yesterday from imprisonment in body tortured by almost intolerable pain for most of the last five years. Those who love him are desolate; and thankful for his deliverance.

title: Hometown Lions Honor Citizen Flood
description: WILKESBARRE, Pa., March 16Although Representative Daniel J. Flood being investigated in Washington for alleged misuse of his power in Congress, the 73-year-old Democrat was hailed tonight in one of his hometown's St. Patrick's Day celebrations as if he were Celt who drove the snakes out of WilkesBarre.

title: Car Owners Bemoan Return of StreetParking Rules
description: Eric Ross who hadn't even thought about his car for 62 dayswhen there were no alternateside parking regulationsgeared up yesterday to move it from where it had stood motionless on West End Avenue.

title: Mets Beat Blue Jays, 62, for 5th in Row
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 16Oh ye, of little faith. The New York Mets, scorned by their public and quoted at 100 to 1 by the smart money at Las Vegas, rolled to their fifth straight victory of the exhibition season today by beating the Toronto Blue Jays again, 62.

title: Small Coal Companies Are Hardest Hit by Strike
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., March 15As the strike by members of the United Mine Workers union continues in its fourth month, coal mine operators are not exactly having a picnic. That is especially true for familyowned and closely held companies that have no other sources of income on which to fall back when coal sales sag.

title: House Panel to Back Plan on Gas Impasse
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The House energy conferees said today that they would accept the substance of a Senate proposal to end the natural gas pricing impasse, although they asked that some changes be made.

title: Spinks May Counter In Court if W.B.C. Acts
description: In the latest round of Leon Spinks vs. the World Boxing Council, the heavyweight champion's lawyer and promoter were preparing yesterday what could be multimilliondollar counterpunches against the threatened withdrawal of title recognition by the sanctioning body.

title: Two Die in Vermont Air Crash
description: MANCHESTER, Vt., March 16 (AP)Two persons were killed in the crash of a singleengine plane near Bear Mountain here, officials said. Two other passengers survived, but their conditions were not immediately known, they said. The dead are Spencer Hall Jr., a Philadephia lawyer, and a companion, Peter Bensen, family spokesman said.

title: Goldin Lists Cost to Other States If New York City Went Bankrupt
description: If New York City were to go bankrupt, companies in 40 states would find themselves with hard-to-collect bills for purchases by the city totaling $418 million, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday.

The text of the treaty was published Sept. 7 1977, by The New York Times.

description: KEYPORT, March 15 Although $300,000 in Federal funds was made available to the state more than a year :ago to establish shelters for battered .wives and their children, none is in operation.

description: Like January, February new product introductions fell below the levels of those months last year, according to the DancerFitzgeraldSample New Product News. There were 81, compared to 97.

description: A free program of Chinese regional dances will be offered tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 P.M. at the New York Public Library's Donnell Library Center, 20 West 53d Street. Presented by the Young People's Chinese. Cultural Center, the program will include dances of the Han, Tibetan, Yai, Yi, Mongolian, Sinkiang and Korean peoples and will be followed by a discussion.

title: Irish in Savannah Looking for a Big Day
description: SAVANNAH, Ga., March 16Pop! Toby Buttimer stripped away the tab on a can of Pabst Blue Ribbon last night and prepared himself for the taunts of Timothy O'Keefe, the bartender. On the next stool at Pinky Master's Bar, Michael J. Curran sipped whisky from a cup with an air of amusement.

title: 3 Tied for Lead at 71
description: SAN DIEGO, March 16 (AP)Penny Pulz, Amy Alcott and Silvia Bertolaccini all carded 1-u'der-par 71's today and tied for the firstround lead in the $165,000 Kathryn Crosby golf tournament.

title: Indicted L.I . Doctor Now Accused Of a $ 1 .8 Millon Kickback Scheme
description: Dr. Anton Notey, a Long Island physician under indictment in an alleged $1.6 million nursinghome kickback scheme, was indicted again yesterday, this time in connection with an alleged $1.8 million kickback and theft operation at private hospital he owns in Hauppauge.

title: A Big Mistake in Small Claims . .
description: An orderly at a Bronx nursing home who allegedly lent two coworkers $300 each at 66 percent interest for 10 weeks and then sued them in Small Claims Court after they defaulted was arrested yesterday on usury charges.

title: Israelis Mop Up in Lebanon, Meet Some Resistance
description: MERJ UYUN, Lebanon, March 16Israeli military forces engaged in moppingup operations in southern Lebanon today, encountering some pockets of resistance by Palestinians in the wake of the land, sea and air offensive into the area yesterday morning.

title: Cabaret: DeJohnette
description: JACK DE JOHNETTE, who made an important. but often overlooked contribution to the rhythmic direction of contemporary jazz through his work as drummer with Charles Lloyd and Miles Davis, has put together the most ambitious group of his career for an engagement this week at Joseph Papp's Public Theater Cabaret. He has called all his bands Directions, but this one really does spin off along a number of different paths.

title: Nicaragua: To Practice What We Preach
description: After dominating Nicaragua for more than 40 years, the Somoza family has had its hold shaken by two months of almost continuous protests. United States Governments have, at times, been quick to intervene in such situations in Latin America. This time, the Carter Administration has wisely taken a relatively neutral position, disappointing both President Anastasio Somoza Debayle and his liberal opposition.

title: Management
description: People problems on the shop floor, in maintenance crews and in groups of clerical workers are the areas where many American companies seek solutions to help increase productivity, according to PA International.

title: Mahaffey, in Comeback, Has to Relearn His Golf
description: PONTE VEDRA, Fla., March 16John Mahaffey, one of those young Texans who looks as is he were churned out of a mold that specializes in blond golf professionals, is walking proof these days that golf is a humbling game, not only for the weekend hacker, but also for the established star. He has learned it is even more humbling when the star is in a protracted slump.

title: 3 Boston Students Are Injured In Scuffle Over Tuition Rise
description: BOSTON, March 16Three studelps suffered minor injuries today when, rally of 1,000 students at Boston University to protest a recent tuition rise culminated in a scuffle between students, the police and university administrators.

description: CERTAIN strange words suit certain strange people. One such word is energumen, and one of the people it suits is S. W. Hayter, who in 1927 founded a print workshop called Atelier 17 that is still in existence in Paris.

title: Giants to Be Allowed 40 Games in Oakland
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 16 (AP)The San Francisco Giants received the city's permission today to play 40 National League home games this season in Oakland, making it virtually certain the American League's Oakland A's will be moving to Denver.

title: Keeping Step With the Irish On Their Day
description: WHEN the clock in front of 522 Fifth Avenue strikes noon today, Police Officer Patrick Skelly from County Caven will blow a whistle,  the 26th United States Army Band will strike up the Irish marching song Garryowen, and the 1978 St. Patrick's Day Parade will be off and stepping.

title: Police Inspector Johnson Is Acquitted in Bribery Case
description: Police Inspector Robert H. Johnson was found not guilty last night of lying to a grand jury by denying he shared in bribe money from gambling or other illegal interests in Harlem.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Tonight's fashion show at Philipsburg Manor, part of the Sleepy- Hollow Restorations in Tarrytown, N.Y., won't he a trend setter. Instead, it's going to show trends from the pastformal and informal clothes worn by Americans from 1720 to 1860. The evening's title, Whalebone and Willowreed, was inspired by the whalebone stays, corsets, caned petticoats and other underpinningsfigureflattering but not especially comfortablethat yesteryear's woman endured.

title: City Corporation Counsel Supports Goldin s Audit Of the Vocational Schools
description: New York City's Corporation Counsel told the Board of Education yesterday that Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin had the law on his side in conducting a performance audit of the vocational high schools and would be represented by the city's lawyers if the matter went to court.

title: SouthJerseyansWinU U.S. Hearing On Banning Atomic W aste Storage
description: HANCOCKS BRIDGE, March 16South Jersey residents who fear that Salem County will become a major storage center for highly radioactive nuclear fuel wastes expressed gratification today that they had won their battle for a public hearing on the issue.

title: Cabaret: Carleton Carpenter Returns
description: CARLETON CARPENTER, who made a rather uncertain nightclub debut a year and a half ago at Brothers and Sisters, is back in a club again, this time at Reno Sweeney through tomorrow, with much more positive and welldeveloped performance.

title: Deaths
description: DAVID - MorrisThe Sephardie Temple, Congregation Emeth Ve Shalom in Cedarhurst, Long Island, wishes to record with profound regret, the passing of Morris David, the dear and devoted brother of Hy David, the distinguished Vice President of our Temple. Morris David was a Founder of our Temple and supported with great dedication the ideals of Sephardic Synagogue life and communal unity. A pioneer in the apparel industry and in the world of finance, he lead our community to philanthropic endeavor. Condolences to his brother, Hy David; to his children. Stella, Ronald and Larry, and to the entire family. May his cherished memory serve as an everlasting inspiration. Funeral services, Sunday, March 19, 12 noon, Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam

title: Drive to Isolate J.P. Stevens Is Renewed
description: The Amalgamated Clothing and Textile Workers Union has initiated a new campaign to pressure several corporate and financial institutions into severing their boarthcom ties with J..P Stevens & Company, the big textile manufacturer.

title: Turner Sailing Victor
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 16 (AP) Five Congressional Cup skippers, including Ted Turner of the. New York Yacht Club, finished today's first day of competition with perfect scores because only one race was run. Two other races were scheduled, but a lack of wind prevented them. Turner defeated Noel Robins of the Sun City (Australia) Yacht Club by 2 minutes 35 seconds.

title: Film: Matthau in 'Casey's Shadow':The Big Race
description: "CASEY'S SHADOW" is not exactly an offbeat horse movie, but it is so decently tempered and its principal characters so surprising at important moments that, in the world of horse movies it seems rare indeed. Having said that, I should admit I've never been a particular fan of movies about horses, not since I was very young and a pony I was feeding made a serious if unsuccessful attempt to take a few fingers too. I've nothing against horses, but I let them go their way while I go mine."Casey's Shadow," which opens today at the Loews State 2 and Baronet Theaters, is much more reliable than your average, mean-spirited pony. It's about a splendidly fast 2-year-old quarter horse named Casey's Shadow, about the big race (the All-American Futurity at Ruidoso, N. M.) he is expected to win, and about the little boy named Casey who loves him. It's also about Lloyd Bourdelle (Walter Matthau), Casey's dad, a kindly, tobacco-chewing slob who trains quarter horses on a run-down Louisiana farm, and about Casey's oldest brother Buddy (Andrew A. Rubin), who acts as an assistant trainer and as the conscience of the family, in the absence of a mother who has fled for what appear to have been good reasons. Among other things, they're born losers.With the exception of a tendency to overorchestrate the movie in the manner of television commercials, Martin Ritt, the director, has made such an easygoing, understated film, one of such good feelings, that it seems almost rude to fault it for clichssuch as the big raceit cannot avoid, though it attempts to play them down. In the case of the race, this is done by showing us the race entirely in slow motion, which has the odd, not entirely unpleasant, effect of completely dissipating the tension.More important to the total effect of the film are the performances, especially those of Mr. Matthau, who plays the father with an unusual mixture of intelligence and comic wilfullness; Alexis Smith, as a rich, very classy owner of quarter horses, a person with both scruples and humor, and Mr. Rubin, as the son who must forever pick up after his father.The principal supporting roles are handled by Stephan Burns, as the Bourdelle son who doubles as the family jockey; Michael Hershewe, as Casey, the youngest son who has the tough job of attempting to be both lovable and, on occasion, stupid, and Murray Hamilton and Robert Webber, who are as close to villains as the film contains.The screenplay by Carol Sobieski, based on a John McPhee story, manages to touch almost all of the bases one expects in a horse movie, but it does so without condescension. The screenplay even has the temerity to suggest that the racing of 2-year-old quarter horses, whose leg bones have not yet matured, may be a much more cruel sport than anyone in the film, with the exception of a veterinarian, cares to acknowledge. I'm not sure this is true but it's nice to know that Ray Stark, the producer, has taken the matter under consideration."Casey's Shadow," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggesed"), contains an explicitly photographed foaling sequence, which might be perfectly harmless facts-of-life material except that the mare dies in the process. It thus may raise more questions in the minds of the very young than it answers.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDSTEINJoseph C. March 15, 1978 Husband of Rose. Father of Leonard Gaines. Brother of Mel, and Jean Loewenthal. Devoted grandfather. Services were private.

title: JOHN M. BUTLER, 80; 1YITARTHY SUPPORTER
description: Former Senator Jahn Marshall Butler of Maryland, a supporter of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy who played a significant role in the turmoil of the 1950's over alleged Communist influence in the Government. died of a heart attack in North Carolina yesterday. He was 80 years old, and was returning with his wife from a vacation on St. Simons Island, Ga., when he was stricken.

title: N.C.A.A., A.A.U. at Odds
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 16 (AP). A Federal judge declined today to issue a temporary restraining order requested by the National Collegiate Athletic Association after the N.C.A.A. filed an antitrust suit United States District Court, charging the Amateur Athletic Union with abuse of monopoly power.

description: WASHINGTON, March 16The United States said today that it expected Israel to withdraw from the six-mile-deep cordon it seized yesterday in southern Lebanon and said that new arrangementssuch as an international peacekeeping forceshould replace the Israelis on the Lebanese side of the border.

Through the centuries, these dark days have exercised the imaginations of thoughtful arists and led to the creation of some of the greatest monuments of Western art

title: Extremist Red Brigades Seek to Destroy the Italian State and Society
description: ROME, March 16At the forefront of the political violence that has been sweeping Italy are several hundred mostly welleducated, middleclass men and women whom the police have called political mystics. They call themselves Red Brigades, and to Italians in general they are the nation's most feared terrorist group.

title: Panamanians Reluctantly Indicate. They Accept Pact's Reservations
description: PANAMA CITY, March 16With evident reluctance, the Panamanian Government indicated tonight that it would accept the lastminute reservations attached to the new Panama Canal Neutrality Treaty before it was approved by the United States Senate today.

title: For Philippine Women, Success Despite Stereotypes
description: MANILAThere is no women's liberation movement in the Philippines. Philippine women are perhaps best known abroad for winning beauty contests. And as a strongly Roman Catholic country that was under Spanish colonial rule for nearly four centuries, the Philippines still does not permit divorce.

title: 2 Soviet Astronauts Return Safely After Man's Longest Space Flight
description: MOSCOW, March 16The longest manned mission so far in the history of space flight ended today as two Soviet astronauts rode their Soyuz 27 capsule to a perfect landing in poldery snow on the steppes of Central Asia. They had spent a record 96 days orbiting the earth.

description: The woman had entered the City Hospital Center at Elmhurst, Queens, with congestive heart failure, chronic bronchitis and emphysema. She was 75 years old and was given little chance of leaving alive.

title: The City Tries a Clean Sweep as New Snow Threatens to Delay Work
description: A light but persistent snow threatened yesterday to complicate further the lodgdelayed cleanup of New York City but, with the alternate-side-of-the-street parking rule ban after a 62day suspension, .the Sanitation Department sent 13D mechanical brooms out to start sweeping their way through the five boroughs.

title: World News Briefs
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, March 16 (Reuters) A military tribunal today sentenced 19 persons to death for plotting the overthrow of President Mobutu Sese Seko. Ten were military people, including woman.

title: LEFTISTS KIDNAP ITALIAN LEADER; 5 GUARDS KILLED
description: ROME, March 16Aldo Moro, one of Italy's most influential politicians, was kidnapped this morning by leftwing urban guerrillas who killed all five of his bodyguards in a bloody street ambush.

title: AN ALTERNATIVE PLAN ON BREEDER REACTOR IS BEING NEGOTIATED
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Department of Energy and a key House committee are currently negotiating an accord to end the impasse over the Clinch River breeder reactor by moving toward construction of another, larger nuclear breeder facility using different technology, according to Administration and ConRressional sources.

title: LANDES IS REPORTED CLEARED IN TAX CASE
description: State Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes reportedly has been absolved of criminal wrongdoing in failing to file state incometax returns in 1974. 1975 and 1976.

title: World Cup Skiing Postponed
description: AROSA, Switzerland, March 16 (AP) Strong winds today caused a 24hour postponement of a women's World Cup giant slalom race here. The men's giant slalom, originally scheduled for tomorrow, will he held Saturday, with the men's and women's parallel slalom races set for Sunday.

title: Iran Legislator Calls for Censure Of Regime Over Handling of Riots
description: TEHERAN, Iran, March 16 (Reuters)A motion censuring the Iranian Government for its handling of riots in Tabriz last month was introduced in Parliament today.

title: C.I.A. Reportedly Recruited Blacks For Surveillance of Panther Party
description: The Central Intelligence Agency recruited American blacks in the late 1960's and early 1970's to spy on members of the Black Panther Party both in the United States and in Afriaa, according to former highlevel officials of the agency who have firsthand knowledge of the operations.

title: Police Block a Philadelphia House Held by Anarchists
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 16 (AP)Riotequipped policemen blockaded a threestory house today in an effort to starve out more than 20 armed anarchists holed up since last spring, when they taunted the police with automatic rifles.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: For those who believe it Is the right of any woman to choose to have an abortion during the early months of pregnancy, the news these days is grim. The Supreme Court affirmed this right in 1973. Since then, however, it has been eroded, under heavy attack by those who seek to impose their philosophy of life on everyone else.

title: Around the Nation
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 16 (AP)The Kentucky House of Representatives voted 61 to 28 today to rescind ratification of the equal ights amendment to the Constitution, making Kentucky the fourth state to rescind approval of the amendment.

title: Clinton S. Lutkins, 92, Ex-Officer Of the Allied Chemical Corporation
description: Clinlon S. Lutkins, a former vice president and director of Allied Chemical Corporation, died Wednesday at his residence in the Carlyle Hotel. He was 92 years old.

title: GUILD ASKS STRIKE VOTE AT 2 NEW YORK PAPERS
description: Strike votes will be held by the Newspaper Guild of New York against The New York Times and The Daily News in response to what was termed the newspapers demand for retrogressive proposals in the current contract talks, spokesman for the union said last night.

title: U.S. AND STATE REACH A NUCLEAR STANDOFF
description: ALBANY, March 16A Federal Government report, apparently linking takeover by Washington of a nuclear facility in New York to the state's willingness to receive nuclear waste from outside, today set off a series of charges, denials, expressions of relief and further doubts about exactly what the Federal Government had in mind.

title: Willimantic Hails Arrest of 54 Pupils In Marijuana Case
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., March 16Residents of this small bluecollar town hailed their local police today follow???? yesterday's arrest of 54 schoolchildrenMx of whom are only 9 years oldon charges of possessing and selling marijuana.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 17, 1978

title: Auctions
description: THE American paintings market has grown in depth and scope over the last five years, thanks to the scores of gallery and museum shows that have explored the works of artists from the mid18th century through the mid20th century.

title: MurderTrial Witness Says Curare Was Widely Available at Hospital
description: HACKENSACK, March 16A witnesses in the trial of Dr. Mario E, JascaleVich testified today that curare was commonly used at Riverdale Hospital, where the doctor is accused of murdering five patinets with lethal doses of the drug. The testimony contradicted a statement by the chairman of the hospital's board, as recorded in the minutes of a 1966 board meeting, that curare had never been used at Riverdell.

title: 3 Boston Students Are Injured In Scuffle Over Tuition Rise
description: BOSTON, March 16Three students suffered minor injuries today when rally of 1,000 students at Boston University to protest a recent tuition rise culminated in a scuffle between students, the police and university administrators.

title: Gains Made in Production And Housing Last Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Government reported today that industrial production and housing starts gained in February in spite of heavy snows across much of the country and the impact of the coal strike.

title: Deaths
description: ABITANTERose, Beloved mother of Mary, Delia Williams, Stella Bettini & Joseph Jr. Reposing at Vanelia's Chapels 29 Madison St until Monday 9:45AM.

title: 73 Killed in Bulgarian Plane Crash
description: VIENNA, March 16 (Reuters)A But. garian airliner crashed today shortly after takeoff from Sofia, the capital, killine all 73 persons on board.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 17. 1978

title: Very Old People in the Andes Are Found to Be Merely Old
description: For those who had hoped that residents of the village of Vilcabamba in the Andes had found the secret of extreme longevity, the news is not good.

title: DeLury Retiring As Union Chief After 40 Years
description: John J. DeLury, who has been president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association since the late 1930's, announced yesterday that he planned to retire on May 1.

title: Senate RollCall Vote Approving Canal Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (AP)-Following is the 68-to-32 rollcall vote by the Senate today approving the first of two Panama Canal treaties:

title: About Real Estate Nassau Homes on School Land
description: ROSLYN, substantial part of the housing production in Nassau County over the next few years is expected to come about on property where obsolete schools now stand. The redevelopment process has already begun.

title: Deaths
description: SCHWARTZMilton. D.D.S. The Association of the Attending Staff of The Mount Sinai Hospital records with sorrow the death of an es. teemed colleague. Dr. Milton Schwartz, a member of the dental staff, served the hospital and its patients for over 10 years. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. DAVID C.C. STARK. M.O., Pres. DAVID H. SCHONHOLZ, M.D., Secy

title: Deaths
description: ROACHJames P. The New York Times records with dens sorrow the Passing of James Roach, associated with The Times from 1931 until retirIna in 1973.

title: Palestinians Fleeing the Israelis Crowd Into Saida; Lebanese Port City Fears It Will Be Next Target
description: SAIDA, Lebanon, March 16 - Several Israeli gunboats were seen last night off Saida and planes flew overhead this morning, leading many here to believe that this port city might be next in Israel's operation in southern Lebanon.

title: Fuchsberg Censured for Trading 1 n1Vew York Notes During Appeals
description: Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg of the New York Court of Appeals was officially censured yesterday for his trading in city and state securities when crucial appeals on the city's finances were regularly coming before that court.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE case of Melanie Safkaknown to her fans simply as Melanieis curious and a little sad, too. Melanie emerged in the late 1960's as a vulnerable, mystical flower ohild, and although her music and that image won her some tangible success, most notably the single Brand New Key in 1971, it also limited her as the 1970's matured.

title: LEFTISTS KIDNAP ITALIAN LEADER;
description: ROME, March 16Aldo Moro, one of - Italy's most influential politicians, was kidnapped this morning by leftwing urban guerrillas who killed all five of his bodyguards in a bloody street ambush.

title: SENATE, 6832, APPROVES FIRST OF 2 PANAMA PACTS; CARTER HAILS COURAGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Senate voted 68 to 32 today to approve the Panama Canal neutrality treaty, giving the Carter Administration and the Senate leadership a crucial victory.

title: St. Patrick's Day Guide to the Best Irish Coffee Spas
description: When the St. Patrick's Day parade is drawing to a close, what better way to cap it off than with an Irish ccffee? With its chill crown of freshly whipped cream creating a thin moustache as its robust, heartwarming liquid crosses one's lips, an Irish coffee is a special occasion it itself.

title: Louise Helms Beck, Widow of the Producer And a Founder of American Theater Wing
description: Louise Heims Beck, the widow of Martin Beck, the theatrical producer, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 89 years old.

title: SENATE, 6832, APPROVES FIRST OF 2 PANAMA PACTS; CARTER HAILS COURAGE
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Senate voted 68 to 32 today to approve the Panama Canal neutrality treaty, giving the Carter Administration and the Senate leadership a crucial victory.

title: Moro a Master of Elusive Phrase
description: Although Aldo Moro has never officially announced his candidacy, the 61yearold Christian Democratic Party leader who was kidnapped by terrorists in Rome yesterday has been considered the frontrunner in the race for a new President when Italians vote in December.

title: DOLLAR DOWN AGAIN AS SUPPORT EFFORTS HAVE LITTLE EFFECT
description: PARIS, March 16The dollar fell back sharply again on world markets today, showing that the Carter Administration's latest support efforts are still having little effect on the ailing American currency.

title: Concert:HenrykSzeryng
description: CONCERTGOERS who favor Sibelius's Violin Concerto should - consider themselves lucky just now. Henryk Szeryng is soloist with the New York Philharmonic this weekend, and his performance of the work at Avery Fisher Hall last night was a model of smoothness, musicai authority and tonal suavity. This was the first of the four concerts he and Andrew Davis, guest conductor, will be sharing with the Philharmonic this weekend and next Tuesday.

title: OTB, Tracks Work Toward Reaching Racing Peace
description: New York's warring ontrack and offtrack betting interests are negotiating a peace settlement that could produce a major legislative restructuring of the state's horseracing operations.

title: Willimantic Hails Arrest of 54 Pupils In Marijuana Case
description: WILLIMANTIC, Conn., March 16Residents of this small bluecollar town hailed their local police today tollowing yesterday's arrest of 54 schoolchildrensix of whom are only 9 years cldcn charges of possessing and selling marijuana.

title: JERSEY AUTO DIVISION CRITICIZED BY INQUIRY
description: TRENTON, March 16The New Jersey Public Advocate, Stanley C. Van Ness, reported today that a yearlong investigation had found that- citizen complaints about rudeness and inefficiency in the Division of Motor Vehicles were justified.

title: Publishing: More Books From European Houses
description: AAMERICAN readers will soon have a greater opportunity to select titles from Britain and the rest of Europe because of recent changes in the lineup of transAtlantic publishing. European houses are investing here at the same time that American houses are improving their marketing around the world. Readers everywhere are bound to benefit.

title: Broadway
description: 'RUNAWAYS, the musical by Elizabeth Swados, which opened to generally glorious reviews at the Public Theater. will move into the Plymouth Theater on May 6. The Water Engine. the play by David Mamet that opened to generally glorious reviews at the Plymouth after it had played the Public Theater, will close Sunday. Between the closing of Water Engine and the opening of Runaways at the Plymouth, it is likely that there will be a couple weeks of the Eliot Feld Ballet.

title: Dance: A New Solomons
description: GUS SOLOMONS Jr., whose dance company is called the Solomons Company / Dance, presented some rather unusual works Wednesday night at the Entermedia Theater.

title: Study by Assembly Unit Finds Lag in Home Care for the Needy
description: The oftencriticized management of New York City's pionering home-attendant program for the sick or disabled poor has become worse, the chairman of the Assembly Committee on Cities charged yesterday.

title: Easter Music Season Debuts Tomorrow
description: Drawing by Malls Mclu

title: Sabres Down Flyers
description: BUFFALO, March 16 (UPI)Gil Perreault scored his 40th goal of the season and assisted on another tonight to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 31 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: Bernard Wehrmann, 55; Chief of New York Office Of Justice Dept. Division
description: Bernard Wehrmann, chief of the New York office of the antitrust division of the United States Department of Justice, covering New England, New York and New Jersey, died Wednesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 7040 Juno Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Troops Shot 2 I.R.A. Suspects After Soldier Is Hurt in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 16 (Reuters)Two suspected members of the provisional Irish Republican Army were shot and seriously wounded here today by British troops in the heart of the Roman Catholic Anderstown district.

title: Carey Reported to Bar Koch Plea For Use of Guard in T ransit Strike
description: ALBANY, March 16The Koch administration asked Governor Carey to make National Guard troops availablt to operate buses in New York City if there is a transit strike, officials familiar with the situation said today, but the Governor said no.

title: Australia Taking More Refugees
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 16This country, which until recently followed strict policy of prohibiting nonwhites from settling permanently, will accept 2,000 more Indochinese refugees by June, bringing to 9,000 the number who have come since the fall of the Saigon Government in April 1975.

title: Administration Unveils Its Plan To Revise Pharmaceutical Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Carter Administration today unveiled its longawaited plan to overhaul the pharmaceutical laws, and it immediately ran into the opposition of the drug industry.

title: People and Business Grand Union Reorganizes Management
description: The Grand Union Company announced major management changes yesterday that are designed to effect an orderly transition of responsibilities within the major supermarket chain. Among the appointments announced by James Wood, president and chief executive officer, were the following:

title: Shipment Ban Set by Kentucky
description: A 30day ban against the shipment of thoroughbred breeding stock out of Kentucky went into effect yesterday in that state.

title: Spring Couture Draws Fans Even in a Winter Storm
description: Winter played a rerun yesterday, thereby defeating the plans of many women to show up at Bergdorf's Paris couture show in their new spring finery. Boots and furs were the order of the day, as they have been for many months. Like Marjorie Reed and Jan Chipman, most women in the audience settled for blouses and skirts underneath their furs, as they inspected the couture regalia for warm weather.

title: Yankee May Be Out for Season
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 16Andy Messersmith of the Yankees, who has encountered one disabling injury after another since becoming a celebrated free agent two years ago, suffered shoulder separation today that could sideline him for the entire season.

title: Corporation Affairs Guardian Set to Acquire Assets Of GAF PhotoFinishing Unit
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., March 16 (UPI) Texaco Inc. notified the Government today that it intended to contest a record $228,700 fine levied by the United States Occupational Safety and Health Administration. OSHA delivered to Texaco on March 1 a 52page citation alleging 137 violations of labor safety regulations, the result of a fiveweek inspection of Texaco's Port Arthur plant.

title: The Death Penalty Resurrected
description: The death penalty bill now before the New York State Legislature faces certain veto by Governor Carey, his second veto of the effort to bring back capital punishment. The Senate passed the bill Tuesday, by a majority just one vote short of the twothirds margin that would be needed to override the Governor. The Assembly votes on Monday; there, too, passage is sure but the majority may not reach the 100 votes needed for an override. Given the emotional steam behind the measure, the question now is whether enough legislators who are known personally to oppose capital punishment will match the courage of the Governor and sustain his veto.

title: Theater. A Farce Of Classic Form
description: The classic French farce is not merely written in a foreign language; it is a foreign language. This being so, the Circle-intheSquare production of Georges Feydeau's Monsieur Chasse, adapted and translated under the title 13 Rue de 1'Amour is a real accomplishment. It has some beautifully springy and agile performances, a wellmanaged direction, and quite enough fun in it to be thoroughly worth seeing.

title: Art: Rare Glimpse Of Nijinsky's Faun
description: r,. EW histories of the field accord the photographs of Baron Adolphe de Meyer (186919,16) a significant place among the superior artistic achievements of the medium. Yet ho turns out to be a figure we have underrated, and on at least one occasionwhen he photographed Nijinsky and the Diaghilev dancers in The Afternoon of a Faun in 1912he produced a body of work that is undoubtedly a classic.

title: Municipal Unions Drop Two Proposals Costing Half Billion
description: The coalition of unions bargaining with New York City for new contracts yesterday withdrew two economic proposals that the city said would have cost nearly $500 million if granted.

title: Music: Collard Debut
description: IT WASN'T until the final number in his New York debut recital, at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H. last night, that JeanPhilippe Collard gave some indication of why he had been preceded here by a considerable reputation. Much of that reputation had been based on the release here of numerous recordings, some of which had won awards. The 29-year-old French pianist had also been a prize winner in international contests.

title: Israelis Mop Up in Lebanon, Meet Some Resistance
description: MERJ UYUN, Lebanon, March 16Israeli military forces engaged in moppingup operations in southern Lebanon today, encountering some pockets of resistance by Palestinians in the wake of the land, sea and air offensive into the area yesterday morning.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Mayor Lay.rence F. Kramer of Paterson announced yesterday that he would tun for a fourth term.

title: RAID IN ISRAEL WENT AWRY, PALESTINIAN AIDE ASSERTS
description: VIENNA, March 16 (Reuters)The Palestinian guerrilla raid into Israel last Saturday did not go according to plan, spokesman for the Palestine Liberation Organization said today.

title: Investors Diversified Services
description: Investors Diversified Services Inc. reported a fourthquarter net loss of $8.6 million, in contrast to a net income in the 1976 final quarter of $7.6 million, or $1.06 a share, on the Class A stock. The loss was after an extraordinary charge of $3.1 million.

title: For Children
description: THE LITTLEST WILD WEST FIGHTER, a new musical by Lawrence J. Pellegrini and John Kennedy Shirley, about a little girl who wants to be a cowboy, I P.M. on Saturday and Sunday, and Snow White, a musical version by Mark Katzman, at 3 P.M. on Saturday, at the 13th Street Theater, 50 West 13th Street. lickets, $2. Reservations: 924.9785.

title: Restaurants
description: THIS is a tale of two restaurants, one new, the other wellestablished, both Swiss and under the same management. The newer effort of Hans Egg and Robert Keller is the Auberge Suisse in the Citicorp complex. Their popular and older restaurant is Dezaley, on 58th Street between Madison and Park Avenues.

title: Savings Banks Report Decline for Deposits
description: Mutual savings banks posted a net deposit inflow in time and savings accounts of $150 million in February, the lowest for that month since 1962, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

title: Rocks Identified Free Sunday at Museum
description: Everyone who has a rock, mineral or fossil of unknown origin is invited to bring it to the New York Paleontological Society's meeting on Sunday for a free identification. A dozen scientists will be on hand to examine specimens, from noon to 4:30 P.M. in the Education Hall of the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street.

title: For Oil Pricing, a Basket Of Currencies in Offing?; Pricing of Crude Oil; A Buyer's Oil Market
description: The continuing slide of the dollar has revived talk among oilproducing nations of raising their prices or abandoning the buffeted American currency as the basis for pricing oil.

description: Morning

title: Arkansas Turns Back U.C.L.A
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., March 16 (AP)Marvin Delph and Sidney Moncrief sparked Arkansas to a 16point lead during the first half tonight, then the Razorbacks held off a secondhalf rally by the University of California, Los Angeles, for a 7470 victory in semifinal game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association West regional basketball tourney.

title: Plant Sanctuary in Bronx Reopens
description: An ivy elephant waves his trunk in greeting at the , hippopotamus, who merely yawns and exposes a mouthful of carefully trimmed, dark crimson coleus leays. A giraffe and camel, similarly attired in neat green ivy, stand at attention, much as they might have done centuries ago in the Roman gardens of Pliny the Younger.

title: U.S. Plans Rules to Help Trace Guns Used in Crimes
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Treasury Department today proposed a series of regulations designed to help it more quickly identify firearms used in crimes and to monitor more effectively the 10 million to 12 million sale of pistols, shotguns and rifles that it estimates take place in the United States each year.

title: Precious Metals Show Price Rise On a Late Rally; Interest Rate Futures M??ed; Forest Products Dull
description: A late.and sharp rally lifted prices of preciousMetals futures yesterday. Brokers attributed the rally to a.wire service report quoting a Palestine Liberation Organization spokesman as saying the Israeli incursion into Lebanon would provoke another Arab oil embargo.

title: Plane With French ExMinister Reported Missing in West Germany
description: FREIBURG, West Germany, March 16 (AP)A small plane carrying a former French cabinet minister was reported missing today. The police said they searched this Black Forest region fort three hours but failed to locate it The search was called off at nightfall and was to resume at dawn tomorrow.

title: Sanderson Breaks the Ice: Tallies 200th Career Goal
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia, March 16 (AP)Derek Sanderson had two reasons to save the puck he scored with in last night's Pittsburgh-Vancouver National Hockey League game.

description: 2 under parVic Regalado, Ben Crenshaw, Gary Groh, John Schroeder, Jack Nicklaus, Bobby Wadkins, Gibby Gilbert.

title: Kentucky 91, Miami (Ohio) 69 Mich. State 90, W. Kentucky 69
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 16 (AP)Mike Phillips scored 24 points to lead Kentucky to a 9169 triumph tonight over Miami of Ohio and into the final of the Mideast regional tournament.

title: View From Beirut: Battle Seems Contained
description: BEIRUT, March 16As Israeli forces consolidated positions in southern Lebanon today, it became possible for the first time to assess the impact of the Israeli military actio non the future of the Middle East.

title: At the Movies
description: ANY actor who. happens to be strong and stocky, has red hair, an Irish name, and a native New Yorker, is likely to find himself referred to, once he gets to Hollywood, as a Cagney type.

title: Wight and the Music and Arthur Schwartz at Y
description: Arthur Schwartz, who composed Dancing in the Dark, You and the Night and the Music,'r Hammacher Sehlenuner, I Love You and almost 30 other songs, most of them for Broadway musicals, arrived here last week on his 99th transAtlantic trip since he moved to London in 1969.

title: Minnie Tybo
description: ELKO, Nev., March 16 (AP)Minnie Tyho, Nevada's oldest resident, died yesterday. She was 112 years old. Mrs. Tyho was honored in 1975 by the North Las Vegas Chamber of Commerce as the oldest living native of Nevada. She served as grand marshal in the city's annual Christmas parade that year and also was made an honorary constable.

title: Witness in the Jascalevich Murder Trial Says Curare Was Widely Available at Hospital
description: Late in 1966, at a meeting hastily called by tho Riverdell directors, Dr, Jascalevich was asked to explain why curare had been found in his locker at the hospital in ORADELL.

title: Syria Relies on World Pressure to Handle Israelis
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 16The Government of President Hafez alAssad appeared today to be relying on international pressure to counter the invasion of Lebanon by a powerful Israeli force, which so far has not clashed with the 30.000 Syrian peacekeeping troops stationed in Lebanon.

title: Seven Players Traded to A's
description: PHOENIX, March 16 (UPI)Beating the midnight interleague trading deadline by five minutes, the San Francisco Giants obtained Vida Blue from the orossbay rival Oakland A's last night. Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said later he would not block the trade.

title: The View From Riyadh
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 16Saudi Arabia is using its influence for the moment to keep Syria out of the fighting in the Lebanon. Iti quiet diplomacy should not be underestimated. It is a principal financial sup- porter of President Hafez alAssad's Government in Damascus and officials here seem reasonably confident that their urgent appeals to avoid any accidental clash between the Syrian and Israeli Air Forces will be heard.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses the rekindled debate on the need for an incomes policy to battle the pressures of increasing inflation. Page D3.

title: Advertising
description: The A & W Distrihtlt;ng Company and its agency, Humphrey Browning MacDougall, both have headquarters in Boston, but, boy. do they have our number. They know that we cocky New Yorkers think our town's got it all.

description: State Assemblyman Irwin J. Landes reportedly has been absolved of criminal wrongdoing in failing to file state inconetax returns in 1974, 1975 and 1976.

title: N.Y.U. and Notre Dame Gain in N.C.A.A. Fencing
description: KENOSHA, Wis., March 16Notre Dame, the defending champion, and New York University, the 1977 runnerup, qualified in all three weapons today at the 34th National Collegiate Athletic Association fencing championships, which were held at the University of Wisconsin at Parkside.

title: ELM.W. Seeks Support for Pact; Judge Delays TaftHartley Order
description: WASHINGTON, March 16 (UPI) Leaders of the United Mine Workers began drumming up support today for proposed new contract to end the 101day coal strike, and a Federal judge put off for .a day a decision under the TaftHartley Law.

title: U.S. ADVISES ISRAEL IT EXPECTS TROOPS TO LEAVE LEBANON
description: WASHINGTON, March.16The United States said today that it expected Israel to withdraw from the six-mile-deep cordon it seized yesterday in southern Lebanon and said that new arrangementssuch as an international peacekeeping forceshould replace the Israelis on the Lebanese side of the border.
