title: HumphreyHawkins Bill Is Voted In House by Tally of 257 to 152
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The House of Representatives today approved the HumphreyHawkins bill, which would establish as national policy the right to a job for every American willing, able and seeking to work.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 16 (UPI) The Kansas City Kings have filed suit in Jackson County Circuit Court, seeking $25,000 allegedly owed by the New Jersey Nets in the Nate Archibald deal of 1976. The Kings, who filed the suit earlier this month, allege the money was to be paid in monthly installments from Dec. 1, 1977, to April 1, 1978. Similar payments totaling $25,000 were made from 1976 to 1977.

title: Stock Prices Gain Despite Worries over Middle East and Weak Dollar
description: The stock market .reg.stereu a mode.ate advance yesterday uesp:te investors continued wariness over Middle Last developments and the decline of the dollar in foreign exchange markets.

title: Rossetti Coup Gives Albany Nomination To Rival of Sancho
description: A political coup by Frank G. Rossetti, who surrendered the Manhattan Democratic leadership when Mayor Koch took office, resulted yesterday in the nomination of an East Harlem district leader, Olga A. Mendez, for the State Senate seat vacated by Robert Garcia when he was elected to the House of Representatives last month.

title: Deaths
description: MAC MAHONMyles T. of West Orange, N. J., on March 15, 1971. husband of Lynn. father of Lillian T., brother of Lillian Cope. Miriam Kearney, Anna MacMahon and Paul MacMahon. Funeral mass In St Joseph's Church. West Orange. N. J. Saturday 10AM. Visiting in the Prout Funeral Home, 370 Bloomfield Ave. Verona, N. 124 and 79PM

title: Memorial Meeting Is Held for U.S Victim of P.L.O. Attack on Israel
description: The body of Gail Rubin, the American freelance photographer who was the first victim of the terrorist attack on Israel last Saturday, was returned to the United States yesterday on an El Al jetliner.

title: Music: Fritz Jahoda
description: rRITZ JAHODA, a musician who , taught at City College until his retirement two years ago and who, over the years, has occasionally come into a midtown concert hall to play a piano program, returned to Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night to play Brahms's Piano Sonata in Fsharp minor (Op. 2), Janacek's In the Mist andwith a chamber orchestra of young people Mozart's Piano Concerto in E flat (K.271).

title: AARON BERG, 74, LAWYER; COLUMBIA ALUMNI LEADER
description: Aaron W. Berg, a retired lawyer, who was a former president of the Columbia University Alumni Association and chairman of the Columbia College Fund Committee, died Wednesday of a heart attack while vacationing in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 74 years old and lived at 1125 Park Avenue and in Long Branch, N.J.

title: British. Petroleum Net Is. Cut 10% By an Overseas Tax Item for 77
description: The British Petroleum Company reported yesterday that a nonrecurring extraordinary item for overseas tax reduced net inccme for 1977 by 10 percent.

title: WILLIAM R. LOVETT, GROCERY CHAIN CHIEF
description: JACKSONVILLE. Fla., March 16-William R. Lovett, who turned a $10,000 investment into a $100 million supermaret and snipping empire, died at St. Vinewes Medical Center yesterday. He was 87 years old and lived in Jacksonville.

title: Organized Crime Specialty Of the F.B.I. Chief in Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 16Thomas J. Emery, who took over this .week as Federal Bureau of In'estigation's special agent for New Jersey, brings to the post a strong background in cornbatting organized crime and white-collar crime.

title: News Summary
description: A Panama neutrality treaty was approved by the Senate. Noting that the 68-to-32 vote had reached the constitutionally required twothirds majority with just one vote to spare, opponents of the canal treaties, largely from the South and West and largely Republican, vowed to continue their fight against ratification of the second treaty, which would give Panama control of the canal by the year 2000. [age Al, Column 6.]

title: Himalayan Team at Halfway Point
description: KATMANDU, Nepal, March 16 (AP)A Colorado climbing team making an attempt on Manaslu in the Himalayas reported today that it had established a base camp almost halfway up the 26.760 foot mountain, the world's seventh high- est. The 11member team left here last month for the camp with 250 porters and six tons of equipment. Five porters were killed and 32 injured when a truck overturned 30 miles north of Katmandu.

title: Reserve Report
Notes on People
description: A lawyer for Caroline Kennedy is expected to have her plead guilty today to a reduced traffic violation charge and, under a pleabargaining arrangement, she will be permitted to keep her driver's license. The 20-year-old Miss Kennedy, a student at Radcliffe College in Boston, will not have to appear in Suffolk County Court in Hauppauge, L.I. She was given a speeding ticket last July 4 for driving 86 miles an hour on the Long Island Expressway, near Yaphank, in a 55-mile-anhour zone. Her lawyer, Thomas McVann Jr, said that the District Attorney's office would allow her to plead guilty to driving at 70 miles per hour, thus avoiding the rule that requires revocation of a driver's license when an offender is found guilty of driving more than 25 miles an hour over the limit. Mr. McVann said that Miss Kennedy ticket was for a first offense, and a spokesman for the District Attorney's office said that she was not given any preferential treatment. She does face fine of $100.

title: Police Inspector Johnson Is Acquitted in Bribery Case
description: Police Inspector Robert H. Johnson was found not guilty last night of lying to a grand jury by denying he shared in bribe money from gambling or other illegal interests in Harlem.

title: France's Extreme Left May Hold Key in Election Runoff Sunday
description: PARIS. March 16France's extremeleft splinter groups, which received combined 3.3 percent of the vote in last Sunday's first round of legislative elections, could make the difference in this Sunday's runoff because the contest will be so close.

title: With Inflatibn Surging Ahead, New Debate on Incomes Policy
description: Whenever inflationary forces or expectations surge upward, interest inevitably rekindled in some kind of incomes policy to battle the pressures. Just as surely, the foes of controls warn of the dangers and inequities that such programs have created in the past. The discussion was revived when the Administration disclosed its budget for the 1979 fiscal year, projecting a second year of $60 billion deficits, and was intensified by the return of the price indexes to doubledigit annual rate increases this winter.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Down 5.4%
description: WASHINGTON, March 16The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.4 billion tonmiles, down 5.4 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 404,130 cars, down 13.9 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 3 percent from a year ago.

title: Agents Search Lockheed Offices For Documents on South Korea
description: WASHINGTON. March 16 (AP)-Federal agents searched offices of the Lockheed Corporation in California and in Washington this week for documents showing that the aerospace concern planned to provide rocket propellants to South Korea.

description: CAPE TOWN, March 16 (Reuters)Charges were dropped today against leading church figure, the Rev. Theo Kotze, who was accused of breaking his banning order by preaching last Nov. 6.

description: There was no waiting in an obstetrician's office, no lying immobilized and draped on a table with feet in stirrups, no easy dismissal of questions. Even an hour's discussion with the physician would have seemed superficial to the familieS in a new selfcare program conducted at the Maternity Center Association.

description: Dr. J. Wallace Hurff, who retired in 1969 after a medical practice in Newark, For more than 50 years, died Wednesday while on vacation in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 88 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: Notes on People
description: Like it or not. and he didn't like it at all, L. Ewing Scott was evicted yesterday from San Quentin Prison in California, ending 17 years behind bars in which he had refused to accept pardons or paroles. Mr. Scott had refused to budge all those years because, he maintained, accepting a pardon or parole would have implied an admission that he killed his wife, an act he has denied. Mr. Scott, now 82 years old, was convicted of murder after the disappearance of his wife from their Los Angeles home in 1955. No body was ever found. The California Community Release Board has been trying to parole or to pardon him for years because of his age, but it wasn't until yesterday that officials decided to forcibly remove him from the prison. He'll stay with friends in San Jose, Calif.

title: New Policy Allows Homes to Be Rebuilt In FloodProne Sites

title: Pigeon Extermination Backed
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, March 17 (AP)A Youngstown judge has ruled that pigeons have no rights under the Constitution. That frees the Youngstown Board of Health to go ahead with its pigeon extermination program. Judge Sidney Rigglehaupt of Mahoning County Common Pleas Court said yesterday that the Constitution guarantees life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness for citizens, but I find no such constitutional protection for pigeons.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: WARMUP Last year's lively spring celebration by the Village Singers, who specialize in Classical chorus singalongs, drew a packed house, so partygoers are advised to arrive well before 8 o'clock for tonight's concert, foodaridwine reception and dancing at Greenwich House at 27 Barrow Street, a block below Sheridan Square. The concert portion will include music of Schubert, Mozart, Copland and Rossini; the group's Sunday Brunch Company will also render a poetry session, and the dance band this year is reportedly a good one. The door tab is $5.

title: TV: Big Band Bash Recalls Swing Era Magic
description: Halfway into WNET's Big Band Bash, a threehour special devoted to bigband music that will be shown tonight on channel 13 beginning at P.M., comes a vintage film clip of the Duke Ellington orchestra playing Take the A Train. It's over in less than minute, but what a minute it is! Ellington swivels around on the piano bench as if it were just a little too hot, conducting the band with body English. Ray Nance dances, Cat Anderson growls, Johnny Hodges serenely leads the saxaphone section. The Hollywood set simulates a moving. train, but the performance overcomes its stagy ambiance. It works both as entertainment and as art.

description: The dollar plunged three yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange yesterday to hit a new low, but improved in trading in Europe and New York, The Associated Press reported.

Burrell, an administrative assistant to Representative Andrew Jacobs Jr., Democrat of Indiana, was married at the Woman's National Democratic Club in Washineton last evening to Ivanhoe Donaldson, manager of the mayoral campaign of City Councilman Marion Barry in Washington. title: Mr. Moro's Fate, and Italy's
description: It is easy to overdramatize the terrorist kidnapping of former Italian Prime Minister Aldo Moro and the killing of his five bodyguards as an attack on the heart of the state, as the leftist perpetrators of the outrage have described it. It is considerably less than that, despite the human tragedy for Mr. Moro, his family and his close friends in the new Andreotti Government, who must now take decisions affecting his survival. The Red Brigades have indeed demonstrated the ability of handful of armed extremists to seize center stage and dominate the attention of the country. But they are still a handful, a few hundred at most, divided into factions and capable only of hitandrun assaults.

Mr. Baryshnikov, a guest principal dancer with the American Ballet Theater, appeared in the film The Turning Point. His new setting of Don Quixote, his second ballet for Ballet Theater, will be seen during the company's spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: New York Negotiates With a Difference

If so it will be in part because of a novel element in the bargaining, which has appeared also in the national coal negotiations and other recent contract talks: Employers have been coming to bargain not only against union demands but with demands of their own.

title: Canvases by Benny Andrews Shown at LernerHeller Gallery
description: Taste in color seems to be rooted In an early awareness of what goes best with one's own complexion. Naturally, it is encouragedor warpedby the same pressures that work on all the other faculties. Extremely versatile as a tool, color can induce a state of mind as well as expressing one; it can dramatize, tranquilize and, when used to gussy up cheap design, deceive. In art it can be as good as a signature:. a Prussiantype blue next to an acid lemon can evoke Tiepolo, while a jollier yellow beside ultramarine suggests the Blaue Reiter School.

Poverty is purity; a writer who has rich style is taking words out of poor people's mouths.

title: Trinkets and Cloth for Vida
description: . In one of his last official acts as the Oakland A's distributor of talent, Charles 0. Finley finally figured out how to slip Vida Blue past Bowie Kuhntrade the lefthanded pitcher to the San Francisco Giants for John, Dave and Gary along with another Gary, an Alan, a Phil, an estimated total of $400,000 in cash and a resin bag to be named later. The players full names are John Johnson, Dave Heaverlo, tiary Thomasson, Gary Alexander, Alan Wirth and Phil Huffman, but none are household names. Of the six, only Gary Thomas son, a 26yearold outfielder, is an established major leaguer. In his sixth season last year, he hit .246 with 17 homers and 71 runs batted in. Gary Alexander hit .303 last year as the ailrookie catcher. Those two apparently can play and Dave Heav erlo apparently can pitch. He had a 51 wonlost record and a 2.55 earnedrun average last season in 56 games out of the bul pen. The three others are pitching prospects up from the minors. But if all six suddenly were put on the freeagent market, it's unlikely their cumulative value would be $1.75 million, the amount that Charles 0. Finley was forbidden by Bowie Kuhn to accept from the Cincinnati Reds two months ago along with the muscles of a first baseman named Dave Revering, whom the A's later acquired in a separate deal. The commissioner also voided the 1976 sale of Vida Blue the New York Yankees.

title: Reagan Rallies Foes of Canal Pact

title: Couple Held Liable in Rock Slide
description: WEEHAWKEN, March 17Last New Year's Eve, several tons of basalt rock tumbled out from under the backyard of a house that sits on a promontory in this Hudson County community and crashed onto Boulevard East, a heavily traveled county road 150 feet below.

title: 'Straight Time' a Film of Grim Wit
description: "Max," says the parole officer, "I think you have a serious attitude problem." Just how serious is the dramatic substance of "Straight Time," the grimly witty account of the decline of Max Dembo (Dustin Hoffman), an ex-con (six years for armed robbery) who would say that he pursues success though he measures his life in small failures and the treacheries of others. He knows the world is crooked and he behaves accordingly. Like millions of other people who live on the right side of the law, Max never questions the system. He simply tries to beat it in his own half-baked way.Max is the sort of fellow who automatically lies when someone asks him how much rent he pays. It would make no difference if he told the truth, but Max has to keep in practice. The only time he can look someone in the eye with ease is when he stares, through the slits in a face maskduring a holdup.Max is shrewd, self-absorbed, tough in superficial ways, and doomed. He defines the meaning of recidivism. In real life you wouldn't trust him to hang up your coat. In "Straight Time," in the person of Dustin Hoffman, he's a fascinating character, made romantic only to the extent that an actor of such stature invests him with importance that is otherwise denied. Max is strictly small-time.Even though "Straight Time," which opens today at the Coronet Theater, has been tailored to Max's dimensions it's not a small-time movie. Ulu Grosbard, the director, and Alvin Sargent. Edward Bunker and Jeffrey Boam, who wrote the screenplay, have succeeded in making an uncommonly interesting film about a fellow whose significance is entirely negative. It's almost as if the real subject of the movie were all the things Max isn't.This may be to invest "Straight Time" with more purpose than was ever intended, but it is such a leanly constructed, vividly staged film that one seeks to justify the way it compels the attention. The first words we hear in the movie are those of the guards as Max is getting out of prison"Open the gates"while the rest of the film is the detailed case history of a man doing his unconscious best to get back in.The movie makes no attempt to explain Max. It simply says that this is the way he is. It requires us to fill in the gaps, and it's the measure of the film that we want to. In the meantime, we watch as Max has his early run-ins with his Los Angeles parole officer, a sadistic, patronizing redneck, marvelously well-played by M. Emmet Walsh, and accept as inevitable his return to life as a holdup man.The film's most surprising and involving sequences are the series of heists that Max carries out, at first solo, then in the company of an old associate, a fellow named Jerry Schue (Harry Dean Stanton), an ex-con, now a paint contractor apparently happily married, who is going out of his mind with the boredom of a settled life that involves a backyard swimming pool and barbecue pit."Straight Time" makes a concession to convention in the casting of Theresa Russell as the young woman who has a brief affair with Max. Miss Russell, who was so good in "The Last Tycoon," is an extremely appealing actress, with a kind of contemporary authority, but she looks so classy, so understated-chic, that she suggests an upper-class girl whose path would cross Max's only at the beach, or maybe at a singles bar. The two really belong in different movies.The film is beautifully acted by everyone, but especially by Mr. Hoffman, Mr. Walsh, Mr. Stanton and Gary Busey, who plays a junkie friend of Max who cops out at the last minute of a crucial job. "Straight Time" is not a movie to raise the spirits. It is so cool it would leave a chill were it not done with such precision and control that we remain fascinated by a rat, in spite of ourselves.

title: The UnBeautiful People
description: Despite all the advantages of good looks, social scientists insist there's no proven correlation between selfesteem and appearance. But the lessthanravish ing sometimes have a hard time believing it.

description: KARLSRUHE, West GermanyAt the Singer Company's plant here, sewing machines are being built and tested by small groups of workers, responsible for their own output, instead of by line of assembly workers.

title: New Air Force Jet Passes Test
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., March 17 (AP)A new highly maneuverable Air Force jet, the F16 fighter, has completed its 1,000th flying hour in a long test that proved successful, its pilot says. It's a major milestone and we did it on another very productive flight test mission, Col. James G. Rider said after a flight of two hours and 45 minutes yesterday.

title: Italy Holds Off on Reply to Terrorist Murder Threat in Moro Abduction
description: ROME, March 17The Government of Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti did not reply today to leftwing terrorists who abducted former Prime Minister Aldo Mom yesterday and apparently threatened to execute him if 15 of their comrades were not released by tomorrow.

description: NASHVILLE,March 17Four hundred demonstrators protesting against South Africa's participation in the Davis Cup tennis matches marched in front of Vanderbilt University's gymnasium tonight, shouting at those entering and accusing them of supporting racism and murder.

title: Patrice Regnier's Dancers Look at Growing Up
description: Patrice Regnier's student years at the Juilliard School left her a competent dancer. But judging from a program of four dances performed by her group, the Rush Dance Company, at American Theater Laboratory on Thursday, she is a far less persuasive choreographer. The dances were tasteful. Several were based on interesting ideas. Neither the ideas nor the movement, however, developed further than initial statements. Her dancers never traveled across the stage in any directed way but seemed pulled toward the center or broke into isolated little bursts of activity on the periphery. It was as if Miss Regnier had dropped a choreographer's pebble into a still pool.

title: When You y Goodbye To a Job in the City
description: WHEN the corporation that employs my husband announced it would move its international headquarters from New York City to a Westchester location just a few minutes from our home, we popped the cork on a bottle of champagne. Then during construction of the mammoth building, we nosed about thesite almost weekly, quite willing, if we had been asked, to dig, shovel, or pound something ourselves to hasten the completion.

title: Indiana State Gymnasts Win

title: Wallace Stevens: A Daughter's Memory
description: WHEN Wallace Stevens, one of America's greatest poets, died in 1955, he left almost no manuscripts in his Own hand and few records. According to Holly Stevens, the poet's only child, the manuscripts were not lost or destroyed posthumously, as those of other writers often are. Apart from short notes that he jotted down, she said, he seldom actually put his poems on paper. He thought them out and then dictated the completed verses to his secretary at the Hartford Accident and Indemnity Company. Stevens worked most of his adult life as a Hartford insurance man and published no books until he was 44 years old.

title: Tag Sales Are Everybody's Business
description: LI SAVED so many things in this attic thinking that my children would want them, a tagsale seller said. This was my grandfather's blackthorn cane, and this marble washstand belonged to my mother. And now the children are scattered. The ones in Northern Canada don't want any possessions and the ones in the Air Force move far too often to accumulate possessions. So now that we're moving to Florida, we're having a tag sale.

title: Kathryn Hayes Feakins Wed to Carl A. Carbone

Carbone of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Mr. Carbone, were married yesterday in Morristown, N.J., at the home of the bride's parents. Judge Charles M. title: Jewish Group PuOlishes Guide on Countering Efforts of Evangelists

title: SINGING SCHUBERT'S PRAISES
description: In 1827, the year before his death, Franz Schubert composed the last and greatest of his song cyclesDie Winterrelse. The last song in the cycle, Der Leiermann, is about an organ grinder, and it is all December: snow, quiet, physical and emotional death. The organ grinder cranks away, but nobody cares. Nobody listens. His plate remains empty, dogs snarl at his feet. Yet he keeps on making music. Mysterious old man, the song ends, shall I go with you? Will you crank your hurdygurdy to my songs?

title: Late TV Listings

title: Amid Bad News, Mitterrand Goes To the Offensive
description: PARIS, March 18  It was the last rally of the long legislative campaign for Francois Mitterrand, the leader of the Socialist Party and the most probable prime minister in the event of an upset victory by the French leftists in the final round of the elections tomorrow.

title: Begin Due in Washington This Week
description: WASHINGTON  Four short months ago, President Anwar elSadat of Egypt dared to defy the political laws of gravity in the Middle East, and ever since his visit to Jerusalem there has been an eerie suspension of the terrible dynamics of violence and death between Arabs and Israelis.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN the finish on a table top gets severely stained, scratched or discolored it is almost impossible to get by with merely polishing or touching up. Refinishing, on the other hand, is not only a tedious chore, it often requires that the entire table be refinished  not just the top. In many cases a simpler and more permanent solution lies in covering the top with a plastic laminate. This provides a permanently stainproof surface that will be almost maintenancefree. Sold in all lumber yards, these plastic veneers come in a wide range of woodtone colors that will match or blend with most finishes.

title: MARY M'PHERSON NAMED PRESIDENT OF BRYN MAWR
description: BRYN MAWR, Pa., March 18Bryn Mawr College today announced the selection of Mary Patterson McPherson to be its sixth President, replacing Harris Wofford, who had held the post for eight years.

title: N.F.L. Rule Changes Stir Controversy
description: A set of playingrule changes intended to encourage passing, increase offense and open up the game have been adopted by the National Football League. There was little disagreement that such a result would be desirable for the sport that tries harder than any other to feel the public pulse from moment to moment. But there was considerable disagreement about the true effect of the changes.

title: Simone SignoretFrom Sultry Sirens to a Faded Floozy
description: PARIS here were several reasons why Simone Signoret didn't want to play the title role in Moshe Mizrahi's film Madame Rosa, [which opens today at the Plaza Theater.] An important one was that her husband, Yves Montand, urged her not to portray the ailing, frowsy, frizzlehaired old whore.

title: Dwarf Dahlias Need a Head Start Indoors
description: Few flowers are as colorful for summer gardens as dwarf bedding dahlias. Beginning to bloom in early summer and continuing until frost, each bushy plant is covered with a profusion of single or double flowers in bright clear shades of red, salmon, rose, pink, white and purple.

description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, March 18A State Department delegation arrived here today for critical talks affecting AmericanSomali relations, including a commitment by Washington to supply Somalia with defensive weapons.

title: Running In Kenya: A Quest
description: In the highlands of equatorial East Africa, under strange new stars, the realization came to me that the European or American traveler has lived his life unaccustomed to mortal fear, protected by allegiances both grand and mundane that are the fabric of civilized society.

title: With Moro Abduction, Italian Terrorists Achieve Goal of Shaking the State
description: ROME, March 18Italy's political terrorists have now achieved what they wanted for so long. With the abduction of Aldo Moro, one of the most outstanding figures in the political establishment, they have managed to shake the foundation Of the Italian state, instead of just nibbling at it.

title: Ein Volk, Ein Reich

Not long ago, I went back to Mod ling. I had spent my childhood there. It was early evening and I walked up the street until I came to the bank building across from the town hall. The town had changed little.

February marked the opening of an artist-in-residence program in Hackensack, this month has seen the premiere production by a professional acting company in Englewood and April will see a new orchestra presenting its first concert.

The 72hole World Cup will begin Wednesday, July 5, and will conclude on Saturday, July 8.

title: GARDENING

Those who have particularly wide interests find that there are just not enough leisure hours left over from the businessman's or homemaker's day to squeeze in the lighter activities. Everylooks for shortcuts.

The bride's father retired as vice president and general counsel of Field Enterprises and was formerly a partner in the New York law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison.

title: A Day at Royal Ascot &
description: Let me say straight away that l am no expert on the sport of kings. I think went to the track once as a cub reporter for United Press International, and lost my $10 stake betting UPI selections for want of any better system. Since then have managed to resist media importunings to join The New York Bets at my local OTB parlor. So it was quite by chance that I found myself at the opening day of the Royal Ascot race meeting outside London.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)Airports are making only halfhearted efforts to reduce the threat of collisions between airplanes and birds, a spokesman for the National Wildlife Federation said today.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Brand Names. When the paperbounders of Publishers Row get together these late winter days, their talk often drifts to the subject of Big Brand Names  those wellestablished writers whose mere name on a new book's cover will turn it into a best seller. Somebody's figured out that the average age of the BBN's is now a bit beyond 60. Where will the next generation of BBN's come from? What can a publisher do to help his authors qualify for the golden circle?

title: Ideas &
description: It's not quite the fountain of youth, but a lot of very old people have suddenly become much younger, thanks to anthropological detective work. In the mountain village of Vilcabamba, Ecuador, persistent reports have stated that many inhabitants live to extraordinary ages, some as much as 140 or 150, with nine centenarians in a population of 819, according to a 1971 census. A study presented at the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md., now indicates that no one in Vilcabamba is older than 96.

title: A Year's Delay Possible For Early Out
description: STATE education officials are considering a delay in the start of the controversial early out diploma program for high school students wishing to leave at age 16.

The executive vice president of Union Carbide complained of socalled high 'school- graduates who could not read. The president of Republic Steel mentioned the monstrous growth of Government regulation in urban affairs, and the chairman of McGrawHill brought up the everrising taxes and utility costs in New York City.

description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (Alli)Th. Federal Communications Commission says its rules for citizens band broadcasters will be written in plain English as of. Aug. 1. But Commissioner Joseph R. Fogarty decided one last fling of bureaucratize was in order.

Max Frisch, the internationally known author of such plays as The Fire Raisers and Andorra, and the powerful, gripping novels I'm Not Stiller, Homo Faber, the Sketchbooks and Montauk, was working on a new play. But I asked him first about his fiction.

title: Side Issues Delay Bill to Create New U.S. Judgeships

description: Badillo Says More Time Is Needed for Mandated Reorganization of Foreclosure Procedure

title: The U.S. Is Both Chief Consumer and Principal Worrier
description: CARTAGENA, Colombia Three centuries ago, incalculable wealth in gold, emeralds, pearls and silver traveled on the annual treasure fleet from the Spanish. Main to Europe from fortresses that still stand in this balmy Caribbean port. But that great treasure was small compared with the hundreds of millions of dollars in illicit cocaine flowing now from Cartagena. It is the most important staging point for Colombianproduced cocaine, which accounts for almost threequarters of the amount consumed In a United States market that is worth several billion dollars a year and growing. Authorities in the two countries have succeeded in stopping no more than 10 percent of the annual shipments, estimated at 20 to 40 million tons.

title: CONGRESSMAN TO OPPOSE CAMPAIGN FUNDS PROPOSAL
description: WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI)Bowing to Republican demanus, Representative Frank Thompson Jr. of the House Administration Committee, said today that he would try to kill a proposal that would reduce the amount of campaign money political parties may give House candidates.

description: MONMOUTH JUNCTION IN the summer, Zoltan Borhely installs redwood swimming pools manufactured by his own company. In the winter, he makes Hun garian sausages from hogs he has slaughtered and butchered himself.

title: Prospects Bright for Lower Air Fares
description: The head-to-head confrontation between Washitigton and London over tiansAtlantic air fares Was resolved last week. Britain blinked. The accord lollowed an announcement that the United States and the Netherlands had reached d lowfare agreement. The prospects for more charter flights and reduced prices were never brighter.

title: BEIRUT FEARS CHAOS AS REFUGEES POUR IN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 18As Israeli forces continued military action in southern Lebanon today, authorities here feated a social explosion as a result of the tens of thousands .of refugees fleeing toward this capital.

title: An Improved Diagnosis
description: The American economy is emerging from a tough winter with some obvious scars but apparently without permanent damage and probably with lesser wounds than many business diognosticians had originally feared. The major reservation on that assessment is the question about the ultimate inflationary impact from all the domestic troubles of recent months and, especially, from the recurrent attacks on the value of the dollar in the currency markets.

title: Chants, Oracles, BodyRhythms
description: ALLEN GINSBERG's poems of the 1970's are a marvel, his new book, Mind Breaths, presenting a half dozen poems, probably more, that are firstrate Ginsberg. The fact that they are as good as anything he has ever written delights me (and, I hope, many others), because I feel that his poems of the 1960's in The Fall of America were generally not so good, too full of random, unassimilated political rage; neither were his experiments with consciously composed blues a few years ago, as I remarked at the time.

title: State Acts to Cope With Toxic Cargoes
description: TRENTON THE state government, disturbed by two recent accidents involving freight trains transporting hazardous chemical materials, is reviewing its plans to deal with rail and truck mishaps that threaten life and oronerty.

title: GARDENING
description: SOME landscape plantings just seem to happen, but others are well planned. It is the latter that most often continue to provide beauty and utility year after year. They are the ones that increase in attractiveness rather than become unsightly and overcrowded or develop problems that require high maintenance at maturity.

title: TRAPEZE
description: In a dingy allnight theater on 42d Street in New York, at 4 o'clock one morning in 1962, a Mexican family started watching a sixyearold movie called Trapeze. Side by side sat Tito Gaona, 14, his sister, Chela, 15, and their big brother, Armando, 17the three members of a circus trampoline act called The Titosand their father and teacher, Victor Gaona, a 38yearold acrobatic clown who had been many things in the circus but never yet a star.

title: Levitt Assails Reduction in Welfare Investigators
description: State Comptroller Arthur Levitt, urging stronger efforts against welfare cheats in New York City, has decried the city's recent reductions in its investigating staff and has proposed civil suits to recover overpayments when district attorneys fail to Dress criminal prosecutions.

And the assembly is expected to do the same tomorrow, with more than 90 yes votes anticipated in the 150member chamber.

title: For Coops, Penny Pinching Is the Vogue
description: There was a time when cooperative apartments were almost syn onymous with a lobby full of Whitegloved attendants smiling solicitously, running elevators, opening doors, summoning taxicabs, carrying packages, watching children, walking dogs, and generally being cheerful and supportive to a group of affluent New Yorkers who never for a moment thought of themselves as pampered. There was, in the better buildings, an effortless quality to the daily routine: Necessities appeared, things got done, as if by magic.

Mr. Zeitlin's main ambition, however, is to be a conductor.

title: Pounds Then, Dollars Now
description: To someone who spent the 1960's in England, the decline of the dollar is like coming home. Memories of an English girlhood: life in a continuing currency crisis. As in the United States today, each morning brought bulletins from the international money markets. The balance of payments was as familiar as the breakfast marmalade. Our leaders spoke sternly, as President Carter nGw does, of disorderly market circumstances, in which the value of the pound was not being adequately assessed.

title: The Hot Topic: South Africa
description: A yellow looseleaf binder more than on inch thick will confront the. live members of the proxy committee representing the Teachers Insurance anti Annuity Asst icia ion and the College Retirement Equities %ellen they sit clown to study this year's shareholder resolutions. The file is on one subject: South Africa.

title: Quiet Help for Prisoners of Conscience
description: FOLLOWING an aborted coup in Indonesia in 1965, more than a half million people were killed and 100,000 were detained. The vast majority of these prisoners were never charged or tried. One of them was Suhasi Suwardi's husband. In August of 1969, Mrs. Suwardi, a simple market woman about 48 or 49 years old, sought out police officials to ask about her husband's health and whereabouts. Her questions prompted her arrest. She was also never charged or tried. Was she clothed? Fed adequately? Did she need medical attention? When would she be released? No one would answer.

title: Baking Bread: It's Such Fun
description: BERNICE and Morton Hunt are a writing team that has become a breadbaking team. It began when Mrs. Hunt was working on a book about bread. Great Bread! exclaims its subject with enthusiasm, accurately reflecting Mrs. Hunt's attitude toward the art of creating the risen loaf.

title: Invasion Focuses Attention on Censorship in Israel

title: Headliners
description: Since 1848, the Uncle Sam, so to speak, of France has been Marianne, a young woman in a Phrygian liberty cap who symbolizes the Republic. Since 1971, when sculptor Alain Asian chose her for his Marianne model, the face of Brigitte Bardot has graced the town halls and schoolrooms of that fortunate land. But now Mr. Asian has sculpted another Marianne, and this time the model is Mireille Mathieu, the singer. Miss Bardot is 43 now; Miss Mathieu, 31. Times change, and it's never the same thing.

title: David M. Warburg And Chaye Lamm Set Summer Bridal
description: Dr. Norman Lamm, president of Yeshiva University, and Mrs. Lamm of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Chaye Lamm, to David M. Warburg. Mr. Warburg is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Warburg of Monsey, N. Y. A summer wedding is planned.

title: A Friend of Strauss Returns to the Met With Die Frau
description: When Karl Biihm raises his baton Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera, his eye may well travel to the top page of the score be fore him on the conductor's desk. There, inked in florid German lettering, is an inscription that reads, In remembrance of a wonderful performance of Die Frau ohne Schatten, Dresden, June 15, 1939; with much gratitude, Dr. Richard Strauss. Dr. Biihm's downbeat will then begin the Met's own much admired Frau ohne Schatten production. For the next four hours, the audience may be sure of hearing an interpretation of Strauss opera blessed by the composer himself.

title: David Dent Is Fiance Of Karen A. Hessing

title: TV VIEW

Actually the program, produced by WNET/ 13's Jack Sameth, is only about 90 minutes long. It will be interrupted at least twice for fund raising as public television's Festival 78 campaign is brought to a conclusion with a 30hour marathon after 15 consecutive nights of onair money appeals between programs. It seems some enterprising executive discovered that the first station in the present system was established Houston in 1953, and the anniversary hoopla was put into orbit.

Coccaro of Brooklyn, and the late Dr. Coccaro, was married yestherday to Dr. Charles Francis Barbiere, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Barbiere of Brooklyn. The Rev. Christian Cochini performed the ceremcny at the main altar in St. Patrick's Cathedral

title: Legend With Buttons
description: WHAT we persist in ignoring about Emerson is that his work was an answer, a response to the America in which he found himself and to Western culture, not an essence distilled from Concord's woods. When he first worried about the question of being an individual in the rather newly united states he had two concerns: property and its effects upon us, and the deadening foreign influences that hampered American cultural development. The latter concern was to decrease, but the former would become more intense. He had no entangling alliances with American institutions. In his first book, Nature (1836), he said that one could make one's own world through perceptions of a reality lying wholly outside social arrangements. This outraged some and was happily received by a growing number.

title: Fairfield County Is a Land of Plenty for Women Realtors
description: HOW can you run an office where there's no man to make the decisions? woman client asked Mary Mills, a partner of New Canaan's Village Realty, one of Fairfield County's allfemale realestate offices.

The tourists climb up the bare stony hills to photograph the old abandoned refugee camps near the bridge and the flourishing new town of Jericho, full of green orange groves and irrigated Pastures.

description: SYRACUSEJohn F, Mates did not become a professional flier after World War II, when he had the chance. He once studied to become an agriculture agent, but he decided against that, too. Both times. he chose instead to milk cows.

Woodfin Camp Jr. of Amarillo, Tex. The wedding will take place on May 13 in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church.

title: Hart Island Full of Possibilitiesand Not Much Else
description: Somehow, it doesn't seem quite fair. On one hand, virtually everybody speaks well of the place, even if many people do pronounce its name incorrectly. They say how beautiful it is. what an excellent location it has and how many wonderful things could be done there. And yet, when it comes time to deciding what precisely is to be done with it, Hart Islandnot Hart's always seems to be relegated to the role of human dumping ground.

title: A Marxist Look at the Dollar Crisis
description: The current crisis of the United States dollar is often explained by the large dependence of the United States on imported oil, by relatively high rates of internal price inflation and by faster growth of the American economy in recent years as compared with the performance of other developed market economies.

title: Gasoline Spill Vanishes
description: WATCH HILL, R.I., March 17 (AP)Owners of the Ocean 250, which ran aground off Watch Hill lighthouse, said today that the vessel had spilled 682,458 gallons of gasoline into Fishers Island and Block Island Sounds. That clissifies it as a major spill, Chief Dale Puckett, a Coast Guard spokesman said. He said Coast Guard officials had flown over Fishers Island Sound today, but had found no traces of the spilled gasoline. It apparently evaporated and never reached shore, he said.

title: Jane Wales, Robert Blaze Plan Nuptials
description: Jane MacGregor Keep Wales, associate director of the Office of Public Liaison st the White House, and Robert Scott Blaze, a lawyer with the litigation division of the Office of General Counsel in the Federal Maritime Administration, plan to be married in New York on April 15. The ceremony will take place at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration (Little Church Around the Corner).

title: Syria Says Its Borders Are Open For Arabs to Go Fight in Lebanon
description: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 18 (Reuters)  President Hafez alAssad declared today that the land ind skies of Syria were open to all Arabs who wanted to pass through to fight against Israeli forces in southern. Lebanon. He said that the same privilege applied to the movement of military equipment.

description: WASHINGTON  Because of what some people still call fringe benefits, coal miners have been on strike for more than 100 days, rejecting one proposed contract settlement, defying a court order to go back to work and preoccupying the Carter Administration for weeks.

description: PHOENIX, March 18 (AP)  More than half the members of the National Wildlife Federation who answered questions in a poll rated President Carter's environmental record as fair.

title: Early Fowles
description: WHATEVER one's opinion of The Magus, no one ever wished it any longer. Except John Fowles, evidently, because this revised version not only exceeds the original (1965) by 70some pages but includes a foreword explaining the somewhat unusual course he has taken. We are used to the frequent changes made by an Auden or a Lowell in the text of their poems; but for a novelist, even 13 years after the event, quite thoroughly to rewrite and republish a large novel that is also a cult book for many younger readers  this is worth some explanation. In his foreword Mr. Fowles is typically urbane and disarming, conceding that the most popula of his books is also the one he's been least satisfied with, and that even with this substantial revision it will remain a novel of adolescence written by a retarded adolescent. Charmed by such modest candor, assured by its author that his book has no more significance than a Rorschach test  which at least for this reader means no significance at all  we begin

description: BELGRADE. Yugoslavia, March 18 (Reuters)Prime Minister Pot Pot of Cambodia, a figure about whom little is known, has disclosed details about his life in an interview, the press agency Tanyug reports from Phnom Penh.

The sensiized metal and glass plates used in those early days were excruciatingly slow, so that exposures ran into n tn ut es, or at least many seconds. In the 1860's emulsions were fast enough to lermit 1/50second exposures in bright but with hand-

description: By its very nature, real estate has been a local business.

title: A Revolution in the Puppet World
description: YONKERS Atalking scallop shell ushers the curious visitors into the 18thcentury drawing room. George Washington glowers at the Brit ish insignia cast in the fireplace. And upstairs Frederick Philipse paces the Moor boards with anxiety at his impending imprisonment. These dramatic figures are part of an unusual new puppet program created recently by members of the Philipse Manor staff in Yonkers to teach children American history.

title: A Busing Proposal Divides Yonkers
description: YONKERS APROPOSAL to reorganize the city's school system to meet the problems of a steadily declining enrollment and spiraling costs and, at the same time, desegregate schools, has embroiled black and white residents here in a bitter controversy over the value of busing children to achieve a quality integrated education.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: Americans love to play house. They do not, course, have a monopoly of this pastime, but they bring to it an unselfconscious abandon that theirs alone. The great archetype for that abandon may well be the scene in Modern Times, when Chaplin and Paulette Goddard make a palace out of a few scraps of wood, and perhaps it is not a coincidence that Alyce Aycock should remember that scene quite particularly.

title: Richter Plays Bflat Sonata By Schubert
description: Schubert's Sonata in B flat is a towering challenge for any pianist. Like Beethoven's Hammerklavier, it is a work so complexily profound that virtually any interpretation is likely to seem a compromise from which aspects of the music are missing.

title: French Joblessness Rises
description: PARIS, March 18 (Reuters)  The French Labor Ministry said today that unemployment in February stood at 1,042,000, an increase of 19,000 over the previous month. Labor unions contest the figures and generally say that unemployment is closer to 1.5 million.

title: Tuition at Penn to Riso
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (UPI)The University of Pennsylvania has announced a tuition increase of $375 for the 197879 academic year that begins in September. The increase in tuition and fees to $4,825 was announced yesterday by the president, Martin Meyerson. The rate for the current academic year is $4,450 and it was $4,125 in the 197677 year.

description: Red Smith

title: Desire and Memory
description: EARLY in this silky new guesswho novel, Billy Ikehorn, incalculably rich and beautiful and powerful and newly widowed, strews the ashes of her beloved husband over the family vineyard and goes to bed with the pilot of the Beechcraft Bonanza. But it's not really so disloyal. Billy's husband was incapacitated by a stroke years ago, and everybody agreed that she needed some sex, the most-recommended remedy for feelings of loss or emptiness in Scruples. Scruples, the name of Billy's jazzy Beverly Hills boutique, are what Billy got rid of during her Cinderella emergence from being fat and poor and Bostonian to being thin and powerful. Power is what this book is all about, and the fascination with power is why it is (like The Users, The Other Side of Midnight, and others of the genre) hard to put down. Like porn, power hypnotizes by its apparent ability to exist apart from emotionality; that its price is the ability to feel doesn't become apparent until later, when those who have it wonder why there is still something wrong.

title: To Provide for Those Who Cannot Affoid It
description: WASHINGTON  This country suffers from not having an acute housing problem, says Anthony Downs, a student housing issues at the Brookings Institution. He means that a nation in which 65 percent of families own their own homes, the millions crammed into Brownsville tenements, into miner's patches in Appalachia, into shacks provided for migrant farm workers in Georgia, does not impinge on the political or social consciences of most Americans.

Anil behind the rickety bicycles. their rusting handlebar baskets stuffed with a perishable commodity, looms a vast'computerized industry: the Japanese newspa- per business  a clannish but competitive group of commercial fiefdoms whose total number of employees equals the population of Buffalo.

description: Over the past 20 years, mental health care in the United States has been revolutionized as the idea of deinstitutionalization  returning patients to the community and caring for them in the least restrictive setting possible  became the gospel. The revolution has created a whole new set of difficulties. Out on the street, many victims of chronic mental illness simply cannot provide for their own basic needs: food, shelter, work, money, friends, medicine.

title: Notes: Signs of Spring In a Bounty of Events
description: As the equinox occurs at the ruins of Chichen Itza in the Yucatan tomorrow, the sun casts shadows in the form of a serpent. In Mayan lore this solar phenomenon, which draws crowds each year, represents the descent of the god Kukulcan to earth and the beginning of spring. Though travelers elsewhere may not encounter quite so curious harbinger, they will find a host of special events to encourage them to seek out spring's phenomenal beauty.

title: Businesses Unite To Aid Local Arts
description: HACK EIZISACK FOR John J. Slattery, one of the most rewarding aspects of his new job as president of the Business Arts Foundation is that the organization gives back to the community 95 percent of the funds it raises for cultural programs in New Jersey.

title: The Siamese Connection
description: THE surgical separation of Siamese twins, usually carried out in infancy, nowadays can be accomplished even when vital organs are linked. This was not the case when Chang and Eng were born in a riverside village in Thailand in 1811. When the midwife saw that the otherwise perfectly formed male babies were joined at the base of the breastbone by a band of flesh more than an inch thick and a couple of inches long, she fled in terror. Fortunetellers who learned of the birth predicted imminent plagues, earthquakes and other calamities.

title: Barrera Takes a joy Ride
description: In what he described as a joy ride Ruben Hernandez guided Harbor View Farm's favored Barrera to the easiest stakes victory of the Aqueduct season yesterday. His margin of victory was 9 lengths.

title: Poodles Continue to Lead In Popularity
description: Doberman pinschers have nosed out German shepherds for second place in the canine popularity polls across the country, but they are still far back of the poodles, who retain a margin of about 33,000.

title: A Bird Astray
description: In eager coveys, bird watchers have been rushing to Martha's Vineyard to see a feathered rarity called the Eurasian curlewand have been properly wonderstruck.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ALL right, friends, let's hear it for spring. Lets rejoice in the trees, with their new lightgreen foliage. Let's get up from our desks, walk out the front door and take two turns around the building. Let's leave the dishes and stroll in the garden, or down the street to the store, and let the season give lie to the fact that all is not well in our private or public worlds.

It was the third straight loss for the Knicks and the fifth in the last six games.

title: The Moro Kidnapping Last Week Only
description: The kidnapping of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro by terrorists of the ultraleft Red Brigades in Rome Thursday came after several weeks of public debate about who should. control the Italian police and how their questionable effectiveness could be enhanced. But with Mr. Moro's abduction and the killing of his bodyguards in a meticulously organized ambush, the questions raised by Italians and outsiders are more pointed: Have Italy's law enforcement agencies cornnletelv lost control? Is there any way of curbing the violence?

title: Market For All Seasons
description: There are reasons to go to Philadelphia. There's Elfreth's Alley, that residential street of 1690, and Independence Hall, the Betsy Ross House, the Liberty Bellthe many famous attractions of an historic city. Then that palls. On the whole, I'd rather be in the Italian market.

title: AL SANTORO

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN the finish on a table top gets severely stained, scratched or discolored it is almost impossible to get by with merely polishing or touching up. Refinishing, on the other hand, is not only a tedious chore, it often requires that the entire table be refinished  not just the top. In many cases a simpler and more permanent solution lies in covering the top with a plastic laminate. This provides a permanently stainproof surface that will be almost maintenancefree. Sold in all lumber yards, these plastic veneers come in a wide range of woodtone colors that will match or blend with most finishes.

title: ONE NIGHT IN LENINGRAD
description: It was the winter of 1934 when my mother and her two sisters talked my grandmother, who was famous in the family for her compulsion to save a little here and save a little there and for questioning every want with an imperious What do you need it for? You already have a DOOR, Into pluming Stalingrad to say hello to her younger sister. The two sisters had not seen each other since that night in December 1917 when my grand- mother, then in her teens, and two of her brothers packed snugly under fur rugs on the floor of a dug cart, driven by an unknown driver, with bags of bagels and a few gold coins  began the twomonth trip across frozen rivers and through foreign forests, across several borders and an ocean, that would eventually bring them to Brooklyn. (Stricken with typhoid, my grandmother's younger sister was unable to leave; by the time she recovered, the political climate had harshened, and escape was risky and too expensive.)

title: Around the Nation
description: SEATTLE, March 18 (UPI)The Department of Labor has filed an age discrimination suit against the Boeing Company over dismissal of a number of engineers ranging in age from 45 to 60 years.

title: The Rise of
description: No one thinks it unusual if a dance work, be it narrative or abstract, classical or contemporary, contains an ensemble composed entirely of women. Nor is any one really astonished if the entire cast of a dance is female, as the casts of dances have often been from the early works of Martha Graham to the early works of Twyla Tharp. Maledominated ensembles, however, remain uncommon, and the mere production of an allmale work often sets dancegoers debating innumerable artistic and social issues.

In many cases a simpler and more permanent solution lies in covering the top with a plastic laminate.

description: When I travel I want more than the comforts of home from a hotel. I want the tingly feeling that tells me, You're in San Francisco. Or Denver. Or Boston.

description: UNIONDALE, L.I., March 18Confusion, nonphysical play and a general lack of gusto characterized the New York Islanders tonight and resulted in a 52 loss to the Atlanta Flames, marking the first time in nearly two years that New York lost to its expansion twin.

title: Dianne Morse Wed To Gilbert Smith 3d
description: Dianne Elinor Morse, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Gordon Morse of Forest Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Gilbert Elliott Smith 3d, sen of Mr. and Mrs. Smith of Scotia, N. Y.

title: Women Officials Swap Experiences
description: SCARSDALE ANEW style of kitchen cabinet has emerged in Westchester, but it gathers at a village hall and its 21 members support one another rather than one party's elected official. In fact, the group is composed entirely of elected officials.

title: Ski Trip Is a Lesson for Grandfather
description: When I went skiing for the first time, I was not under the tutelage of a tall, blond, thinlipped ski instructor. Mr. instructor was short, bald and fat. He was my grandfather.

title: The Sweet Smell of Success in Milford
description: MILFORD

title: No Music in Nashville
description: NASHVILLE, March 18  Music is more than a melody here, it's an industry. Country music. The Grand Ole Opry. Guitars and amplifiers and singers. Tennessee Ernie Ford, Dolly Parton. Charley Pride. Loretta Lynn.

title: An Exercise In Perception
description: NEW CANAAN

title: Kathleen McShane Is Wed to Robert T. Burke
description: Kathlecn Elizabeth McShane, daughter of Mrs. Laurence Edward McShane of Chappaqua, N.Y., and the late Mr. McShane, was married yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y. to Robert Thaddeus Burke, scn of Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Gerard Burke of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. John Patrick Meehan performed the Roman Catha:ic ceremony in the Butler Memorial Chapel at the Marymount Convent.

title: Oil From W recked Tanker Pollutes 70Mile Stretch of Brittany's Coast
description: PORTSALL, France, March 18Some 80,000 tons of oil from a wrecked supertanker fouled beaches, harbors and fishing grounds along 70 miles of the Brittany coast today in one of the worst oil spills on record.

title: POLITICAL POWER AND AMERICAN AMBIVALENCE
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt had it and Harry Truman picked it up on one bounce. Richard M. Nixon threw it away while Richard J. Daley clutched it tightly until the day he died. Gerald Ford seemed genuinely confused and Eugene McCarthy merely bemused by it. Lyndon Johnson loved it almost sensuously, having learned its tricks from another Texas master, Sam Rayburn. Beneath the Zen sleight of hand, Jerry Brown has an oldfashioned grasp on it. Seed of the Devil, gift of the gods, a smoky essence stronger than sex, political power beckons and repels Americans.

title: Developer of the Neutron Bomb Defends the Weapon Against Critics
description: Samuel T. Cohen, whose 1958 study led to the development of. the neutron weapon, defends the.. controversial new weapon as a major step toward a more credible defense position for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS Continued Grammer
description: In the Times Literary .Supplement, where learned controversies appear weekly, the current furor hangs upon a. hyphen. In the Colorado state legislature, a region generally resistant to erudition, last week's dispute descended from an apostrophe. In fact, on both sides of the ocean, punctuation is all the rage.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Last Week's Tally for the Metropolitan Area Senate

title: Preserving the Victorian Look
description: PRINCETON JUST as the state's preservation efforts were about to be worn to a nub, with countless fingers pointing to yet another home- stead where Washington might have slept or piece of land where Indians might have encamped, three new groups have come along within the last three years, each with a refreshing new goal.

title: Series of Factors Made L.I. an Antiabortion Stronghold
description: The question you Ask yourself Is whether you can live with yourself you let other people kill people, said Ann Robinson, a leader in the antiabortion movement.

title: Notre Dame's Fencers Retain Title in N.C.A.A.
description: KENOSHA, Wis., March 18Notre Dame retained its National Collegiate fencing championship today at the University of Wisconsin, Parkside. The

title: Nazi Leader Indicted in Missouri On Charges of Hitting Police Chief
description: CLAYTON. Mo.. March 18 (AP)Frank Collin, director of the National Socialist Party of America, has been indicted on a charge of striking the police chief of Florissant, Mo., at a Nazi demonstration outside Florissant City Hail.

title: BRIDGE
description: In one unusual form of the game of bridge, not recommended except perhaps on New Year's Eve when the wine is flowing freely, an element of poker is introduced. Bonus points of increasing amounts are introduced for winning a trick containing a pair, two pairs, three of a kind and four of a kind. This adds another dimension, since players try to create such combinations when they are about to win a trick and to avoid them in the contrary situation. The declarer suddenly finds that the choice of plays from acekingqueen in the dummy may be significant.

title: Onondaga County Deputy Indicted On Soliciting of Campaign Funds
description: SYRACUSE, March 18Peter D. Andreoli. a special state prosecutor, announced this week the indictment of deputy in the Onondaga Sheriff's Department an charges of unlawful solicitation of campaign contributions.

title: Facility in Queens Threatens to Cloie Kidney
description: A dispute over the enforcement of Federal regulation intended to control soaring medical costs has threatened to close the country's secondlargest blood dialysis center, a Queens facility where 250 people receive lifesustaining treatment three times weekly.

title: Obituary 6 -- No Title

title: Film Junkets for Journalists Raising Divisive Questions
description: LOS ANGELES, March 18By the end of the seventh race at Santa Anita, Walter Matthau was broke. He had lost the $250 Columbia Pictures had given him to bet on the horses. He had also blown $3,000 of his own.

title: Williams Favors Solar Energy
description: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON

title: Clare Villari is Married
description: Clare Villari, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Villeri of Brooklyn, and David Michael Walsh, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Walsh of Boca Ratan, Fla., were married yesterday. The Rev. John Boylan performed the ceremony in Our Lady Hz1p of Christians Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. Mrs. Walsh, a graduate of Brooklyn College, was until last week, an assistant buyer of fine jewelry for R. H. Macy's. Her father is an engineer with Stone & Webster, Inc. in New York. The bridegroom expects to graduate from the University of Oregon's School of Architecture in June.

title: Groton Lives By the Sword And Under It
description: GROTON THE scare over the future of 12,000 jobs tied to the construction of 16 attack submarines at Electric Boat here was caused by a vote of the Board of Directors of General Dynamics Corporation, in St. Louis. The first reaction was in Hartford, where the Governor got on a plane to rush to the scene of the dispute  not Groton, but Washington. wruie tne question 01 wno will pay tor tne cost overruns on the SSN688 nuclearpowered submarines has not been decided, the state's public officials are determined that construction will not stop on Apri112, as General Dynamics has threatened. But the incident dramatizes a situation of which Groton is aware but so far has been unable to change: the fate of the town, and the whole region, is in the hands of faraway businessmen and bureaucrats who have other priorities on their minds.

title: A Shameful Story
description: THE great fear, like the threat of upheaval and expropriation that inspires it, David Caute oddly writes in the first sentence of his introduction, has been a recurrent phenomenon in the history of the bourgeoisie since the French Revolution.

title: Campus Crime Spurs Tighter Security
description: COLLEGE campus policemen, regarded as a symbol of oppression by many students of the 1960's, have become reassuring allies to most of today's students on the Island. Apprehension over campus ?? line has contributed to this reversal of student attitudes.

title: To Frustrate the Terror
description: It was not a heartening week in the Middle East. A handful of fanatics ripped open the scars of fear in Israel, provoked a massive Israeli response and left the principally concerned governments tangled in issues that do not directly bear on the prospects for peace. if Presi- dent Carter and Prime Minister Begin spend most their talks this week on the conditions for an Israeli withdrawal from Lebanon, they will move back the clock of diplomacy by quite a few years. It is up to them, and President Sadat, to see that this does not happen.

title: Nicklaus, With 73214, Is Golf Leader by Shot
description: PONTE VEDRA, Fla., March 18It was what Jack Nicklaus called a typical T.P.C. day. It was cold and windy, and the best golf scores were determined by making the smallest number of mistakes. And so Nicklaus, with fewer errors than anyone else, shot a windblown 73 today to take the lead in the third round of the Tournament Players Championship.

title: New Fodor Pilot Holds a Steady Course
description: There's a new chief at Fodor's Modem Guides. Or perhaps not exactly new; Robert C. Fisher is 47 years old and has spent 18 years in apprenticeship to Eugene Fodor, who last year retired to his home in Litchfield, Conn. Who is Robert C. Fisher, and what is he up to at Fodor's?

title: Models of Their Kind
description: IN the cramped unpromising world of the short book review, the late Stanley Edgar Hyman (191970) packed about as much electricity as the form .. will allow. If he were reviewing this collection him- self, he would undoubtedly find at least a dozen major things wrong with it but wind up pronouncing it a very important book, in a crackle of jests and policy statements. As a teacher he always did his obligatory scolding, but as an enthusiast he scavenged equally hard for virtue. And it's the enthusiasm that still makes him worth talking about.

title: Fire in Apartment Kills 4
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 18 (UP)A smoldering apartment fire generating heavy smoke and fumes today killed a mother and her three children. The Fire Department said efforts to revive Mary McDaniel Andrews, 22 years old, and her children, Malcolm 3, Tony 2, and Vernon 1, were in vain.

title: Kindrachuk of Flyers Out
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 18 (AP)Orest Kindrachuk of the Philadelphia Flyers had his spreained right ankle put in a cast yesterday, and he will he out of action at least through Monday. The Flyers said Kindrachuk had also reinjured his right knee on Thursday night at Buffalo in a 1 loss to the Sabres.

title: Catholic Faction
description: Calls for Unity

title: Political Theology
description: HENRY FAIRLIE, a waspish British journalist now resident here, has some novel theories about party politics in this country. For example, he attributes Gerald R. Ford's defeat in 1976 to Wendell L. Willkie's campaign against Franklin D. Roosevelt 36 years earlier. It is not, he writes, from the New Deal that the Republican Party has not recovered but from the nomination in 1990 of one of the most preposterous figures ever to lead a major party. And some of the difficulties the Democrats now face can be traced to the nomination of Adlai E. Stevenson in 1952. Stevenson simply was not fit to be the national leader of a great party. What made Willkie preposterous is not altogether clear, though one part of the indictment seems to be that he was the creature of a movement outside the structure of his party (Mr. Fairlie distinguishes harshly between movements and parties, the former tending to be ideological and undisciplined, the latter being cohesive and capable of governing, as distinct from preaching.) What made Stevenson unfit to lead was his essential conservativism and his distaste for electioneering.

title: David Bevan Jr. Plans to Marry Miss McIntosh

And, the Government's economic indicators totanirnously pointed top. The Coninwrce Departrnent reported that last month's retail sales gamed of I percent in the month atter .lantiarv's revised iti percrill Aide -- I ?? elan ?? ?? at just ed annual rate of $R.2 billion dollars or 0.5 percent and that luiusinp, starts inched ahead during February by 2.1 percent. The nation's industries reversed a January drop and raised output by fivetenths of 1 percent according to the Federal Reserve.

description: WASHINGTON  The story of the Senate vote to approve the Panama Canal neutrality treaty is less story of great victory achieved by masterly strategy than a story of missed opportunities for disaster, cavernous potholes avoided  not simply for President Carter but less dramatically, for the ambitions of the Senate minority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr.

title: Fishermen and Conservationists Are Bracing for Test Drilling for Oil Off Coast of Long Island
description: Als the oil industry prepares to begin test drilling in the Baltimore Canyon, Long Island fishermen and conservationists are bracing for what some fear is the final affrontto one of the most se verely polluted areas of coastal waters, the wedge of the Atlantic between the Island and the Jersey Shore known as the New York Bight.

title: Librarians Gain A Fighting Spirit
description: IBRARIANS are leaving behind their old image of invisibility and quiet service to the public. They are speaking out to legislators, to city officials and to mayors and governors about the importance of libraries to everyone in these years of expiuding knowledge on the one hand and the mad rush for survival in the cities on the other. At every town meeting or open forum librarians will be there in the front row inquiring about library support and legislation.

description: TRENTON FOR at least five years, New Jersey nonsmokers have been pushing for a state law that would save them from having to breathe other people's tobacco smoke.

title: Everyone Kept Busy
description: AS Daniel Rodgers demonstrates in this elegant exercise in intellectual history, the traditional American devotion to the work ethic has usually been coupled with a fear that universal devotion to work would result in material abundance that would in turn produce moral and social decay. As early as 1819, John Adams put these sharp questions to his constant correspondent Thomas Jefferson: Will you tell me how to prevent riches from becoming the effects of temperance and industry? Will you tell me how to prevent riches from producing luxury? Will you tell me how to prevent luxury from producing effeminacy, intoxication, extravagance, vice and fol ly? Adams worried over the moral fiber of the upper classes.

title: Plane Racing: Its Revival Is Still Up in the Air
description: Jack Hall is an airline pilot who not only flies Boeing 747's around the world but also takes other pilots up regularly to check their performance for the Federal Aviation Administration. When it comes to his work, he is such a perfectionist that he remembers vividly the one time he bounced an airliner during a landing.

title: Crowds Beat a Path to Paradise
description: Eager to meet an ivy elephant, to scale a skywalk to the trees or simply, at long last, to step inside the spectacular glass structure, thousands gathered at the Bronx Botanical Garden yesterday for the reopening of the Crystal Palace, the landmark conservatory.

Bruce Edwards accepted a pastorate the following June with the Makakilo Baptist Church in Honolulu. Mr. Edwards had left Plains following a bitter congregational split over what some members considered his liberal views on racial integration.

title: WHITE HOUSE EASING STAND ON FARM AID
description: WASHINGTON, March 18The Carter Administration's resistance to any increase in aid for grain and cotton farmers has been eroding. under the weight of politics and pressures from farm state Congressmen.

And that lovely country place of your family's, is it really in Normandy? Uh, can you call it fiction, if it's so true to life?

Since Israeli troops and armor thrust into Lebanon early Wednesday, most of Tyre's 35,000 residents seem to have bolted their doors, shuttered their shops and joined the pellmell exodus of refugees toward Beirut.

Tone, direc for of commuterservice contracts for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. Mr. Tone said that it could be months before a final decision was made by Federal authorities on the M.T.A.'s request, submitted early this month, seeking to determine whether the $30 milavailable.

title: Kristin Ann Goffredo Engaged to Maurice R. Mathis

title: ART
description: WATCHING a recent television profile of Helen Frankenthaler, I was struck by the subtlety of high art's entanglement with the techniques of mass diversion. Here was this imposing and accomplished artist, who from some angles resembles England's Queen Elizabeth, supervising the instal.: lation of a retrospective at the Andre Emmerich Gallery in New York. The catalyst in the formation of the Color Field school of painting, she spoke with candor and assurance, noting her debts to Picasso and Jackson Pollock.

title: A Catch 22 For the Aged
description: THE New Jersey Legislature has created a Catch22 for some of the state's senior citizens. It's difficult to be elderly in our society, worse to be elderly and ill and, worst of all, to be a victim of a catch.

title: ART VIEW
description: For almost as long as I can remember, people have been denouncing the phenomenon of fashion in the artsmere fashion, as they usually say, thereby consigning all despised and unexpected changes of taste in the arts to some assumed periphery of our culture where true seriousness and stability no longer act as a brake against opportunism and frivolity. Alas, I suspect that I have myself probably contributed more than my fair share to this ongoing chorus of complaint about fashion. The very concept of fashion implies something temporary, superficial and distracting, and there is never any shortage of new art events answering to this description. It is with good reason, therefore, that we look askance at the socalled trends that nowadays arrive on our doorstep almost as regularly as die morning mail, and with good reason, too, that we tend to regard tireless professional cheerleaders of the new as slightly comical characters.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE LIFE OF RAYMOND CHANDLER, by Frank MacShane. (Penguin, $3.50.) A careful, analytical look at the career and works of Raymond Chandler (18881959), California businessman who in midlife turned to the writing of such yarns as The Big Sleep and Farewell, My Lovely, works that remain classics of the hardboiled privateeye genre.

description: EVEN though winter is approaching its end, the word for northern New Jersey gardeners is still wait. Yes, I know that is the last word that impatient gardeners want to hear, and I always feel obscurely guilty when it is the only advice I have to offer.

Joseph Garrahy to study Rhode Island's economy has endorsed the construction of Interstate 84 in the state. The Governor said he was waiting to receive an environmental. impact statement before deciding whether to support the controversial highway, which would link Hartford and Providence.

title: Constructive Construction
description: THIS is a big complicated subject, in a big complicated country writes indefatigable journalist Martin Mayer of housing. But with reams of research and a healthy skepticism, he has mastered it. The Builders is a penetrating, provocative look at the nation's largest, most complex industry and a service to those who wonder how the roof over their heads got there, what it cost and why it leaks.

title: Hopewell: Soup's On

It serves the kind that makes a cold winter day feel warm, the kind that Grandma used to make out of bones and meat and vegetables, the kind that could never come out of a can.

description: Short Cut

title: IDEAS AND TRENDS Continued Psychiatry
description: The scene is the emergency room of a large city hospital. Mrs. Jones is frantically begging the psychiatrist on duty to do something for her husband. She tells the doctor that for weeks Mr. Jones has been acting tense, nervous and suspicious. Finally last week he announced that he was quitting his job. He told her that he was convinced certain people were reading his mind, that he heard voices accusing him of things too awful to describe and that he could no longer face his colleagues at work be. cause they were in on the whole thing. Since then he has re mained at home, increasingly agitated and inaccessible to her and the children. Having already interviewed Mr. Jones, the psychiatrist has every reason to believe that the husband has a serious mental illness, paranoid schizophrenia, and the wife's story confirms his diagnosis. But Mr. Jones has adamantly refused treatment, and the psychiatrist explains to the incredulous woman that under the new civil commitment laws in their state he can do nothing.

title: Southampton Library Is Planning Comfortable Cubicles for Writers
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I.John Steinbeck, the Nobel Prize novelist who rived and worked in nearby Sag Harbor until his death in 1968, will be memociaNzed in a writers enclave to be opened late this fall in the library of Southampton College.
