title: Golda Meir Remains in Hospital
description: TEL AVIV, March 18 (Reuters)Doctors examined tonight results of medical tests on former Prime Minister Golds Meir of Israel to see if she had suffered a minor heart attack. Mrs. Meir, 79 years old, was hospitalized Tuesday. Doctors said she was in an intensivecare unit and in good condition.

title: Food
description: It has long been our contention that, in the ultimate sense, good food knows no calendar. On the other hand, there are certain dishes that are tailormade for the vagaries of climate and temperature and equinoxes. One of the great winter dishes, which is also perfect for a blustery day in March, is a traditional French boiled beef  boeuf bouilli made with seasonal vegetables and richtextured beef with bone. One of the best selections of beef for this venerable cold weather creation is a sizable shin of beef. In France, when this cut is used, the dish is sometimes referred to as boeuf bouilli a la jambe de bois. When the meat is cooked, the bone is exposed and it does bear some resemblance to Long John Silver's artificial limb.

title: ANTIQUES

description: TRENTON, March 18 (AP)Nationw:Aie Mutual Insurance Companies has agreed to renew. commercial fire and casualty insurance in New Jersey until June 30, 1979, according to the State Insurance DOpartment.

title: Stuyvesant's Town
description: THR EE hundred and fiftythree years ago, in the spring of 1625, New York's local history began. William Verhulst, commissary of New Netherland for the West India Company, arrived in the harbor with orders to lay out the first six farms on Manhattan Island, and began to do so. Till then, Manhat- tan nao peen uses only as a watering place tor snips and a hunting ground for Indians. Countless explorers and their ships crews had seen and admired the handsome, wellwatered place, but until the first six Dutch farmers began to plow the eastern side of the southern tip of Manhattan, no one had stayed there except to visit, and, in the Indians case, to hunt.

title: A Jaundiced View of the Budget Deficit
description: The American economy Is entering the fourth year of recovery, when by every rule of economics and common sense the Government should be tapering off its spending. In fact, the federal deficit increased last year by $17 billion, and President Carter's proposed budget for the fiscal year starting in, October makes no significant trim in that deficit. Indeed, if the financing required for Federally guaranteed borrowings is included, the socalled offbudget entities, the proposed Federal budget deficit will rise by $3 billion.

title: Screen: Moishe Mizrahi's 'Rosa'
description: Israeli films, even the best, are specialized entertainments for most American audiences. They tend to deal in sentiment of an intensity that strikes us as almost rude. In our popular literature, as defined by the sitcoms of television, we take close family relationships for granted and move on to other matters: Will dad allow the kids to go on that camping trip? Otherwise, we treat family relationships as subjects for psychoanalytical scrutiny because we know that nothingcertainly not lovecan be trusted to be exactly what it seems. Just beyond one's love of mom is the raging desire to carry her off to the nearest honeymoon motel.In Israeli films, family relationships are fundamental and secure, even if the film happens to be about changing attitudes toward them. One result is that Israeli films often seem too simple and sunny for sophisticated American audiences. What we fail to detect in the intensity of these feelings is an element that is far from sentimental, but is, rather, dark, obsessivethe need to establish continuity in the face of chaos.These thoughts are prompted by "Madame Rosa," which is not an Israeli film at all. It is, in fact, France's nominee for the Oscar as the best foreign-language film of 1977, but it was directed (beautifully) by Moishe Mizrahi, the Egyptian-born Israeli director best known in this country for his Israeli films, "I Love You, Rosa" and "The House on Chelouche Street."Though it's not an Israeli movie, "Madame Rosa" makes profoundly moving the kind of emotions that have earlier been involved rather than effectively demonstrated by Mr. Mizrahi in even "The House on Chelouche Street." "Madame Rosa," which opens today at the Plaza Theater, is sweet and tough in conventional ways, but it also acknowledges something you don't often see except in the films of directors like Renoir and Truffaut, that the greatest courage may often be the will to go on, to continue, in the conviction that there is nothing but darkness beyond.Such a character is Madame Rosa, born and raised a French Jew, self-described agnostic, a once-gaudy whore who was the toast of a few streets of Paris, but who has been inactive since her release from Auschwitz at the end of World War II. To make ends meet, Madame Rosa now runs a kind of makeshift boarding house in her cramped, sixth-floor flat in Paris's Belleville quarter, a working-class district where Algerians, black Africans, Jews and gentiles live in a harmony dictated by necessity. Her boarders are the off-spring of her friends and former associates in "the life," some of whom take their parental duties as seriously as busy film stars who make it a point to see their children once a week, while others leave them and vanish.As played by Simone Signoret, Madame Rosa is a tremendous character, an overwhelming mountain of worn-out flesh whose arteries are hardening, whose ankles are weak, and whose lungs are less dependable than a couple of ancient innertubes. Madame Rosa is tired. She's in the process of dying and she's afraid, not because of what comes after deathshe's tough enough to face that, except sometimes in the middle of the nightbut because of what will happen to her last boarder, a solemn, old-for-his-years, Arab boy named Momo (Samy Ben Youb).Momo is one of her abandoned boarders. As, little by little, the other children are picked up by their mothers and placed in other refuges, Momo stays on because he has no place else to go. He's both attached to Madame Rosa and furious. One day he steals a dog from a pet shop, cares for it lovingly and then, in an act he can't explain, sells the dog to a passerby and drops the 500 francs thus earned into the sewer. Madame Rosa thinks he may be losing his mind. Actually he's passing through puberty."Madame Rosa," which Mr. Mizrahi has adapted from the 1975 Prix Goncourt novel by Emile Ajar, is a story of love and especially of mutual need and appreciation that will, I suppose, be read as some kind of parable about the Near East, though that is to freight it with a kind of political significance it doesn't have to depend on. It's a clear-eyed, often very funny film about two brave, complex, immensely appealing characters as they discover resources within themselves that are as surprising to them as to us.Miss Signoret has her best role in years, one that uses the extraordinary physical presence she has become without exploiting it. As Momo, Samy Ben Youb  slight, large-eyed, solemn  matches her performance perfectly. Claude Dauphin has several very effective moments as Madame Rosa's old doctor, a fellow who is understandably somewhat shocked when Momo, with the best of intentions and the most careful tact, tries to talk the doctor in putting the old lady out of her misery. Costa Gavras, the director of "Z" and other films, makes a sort of token appearance as the father of the family Momo will probably move in with.There are sentimental moments in "Madame Rosa," but they are the shadows, not the substance, of a very good, very firm movie.

title: Fashion
description: Perhaps it's inevitable. Just as women are getting used to big, fullblown clothes, designers are starting to think about closing in on the body again. The indications are visible in the summer collections of many of America's designers a narrow, fannyhugging skirt here, skintight pants there, a slither of a crepe-de-chine dress somewhere else  all straws in the wind that point the way to a shift in silhouette that will be stronger by next fall. There are reasons, of course, for such things. Many women have had a hard time adjusting to the voluminous freeflowing look. Designer Bill Blass says, American women have worked hard to keep their good figures and want to show them. Perry Ellis who made his reputation designing oversized clothes for young women  now asks, How much bigger can clothes get? And Calvin Klein has always contended that American women like the comfort of loose clothes but don't want them too big. What's interesting  and good  about these new clothes is that they are not copies of the 1950's pinchedin plastered-to-the-body look. They do show a woman's curves, but are cut to move with her body, not constrict it. One note of caution: These curvingcloser clothes are one more manifestation of the present fashion for a beautiful body. So woe to the woman who has let her own shape expand with the fullblown fashion.

title: CRIME
description: When Brian Freeborn's Good Luck, Mister Cain was published in 1976, it was greeted here and elsewhere with yelps of joy. One of the best first mystery novels of that or any other year, it had Harry Grant as its hero. Grant was on the wrong side of the law, living off his wits, but there was something likable about him. He had a nimble mind and was willing to take a chance. Not an admirable character, really, but rakish and fastspoken. In addition, the book was a crash course in British underworld argot, used by the author in a flip but naturalsounding manner. There were also elements of Damon Runyan, with one difference: Runyan was sentimental, and Freeborn never was.

title: Can Drama and Music Be Equal in Opera?
description: Ithink just about every actor I've ever met has wanted to sing, while not every singer has wanted to act. Instead of melding these arts he has been encouraged to place the vocal cart before the theatrical horse, in the belief that if one possesses a voice, nothing else matters. Inevitably the stage director has inherited the results and finds himself in the hapless role of Svengali.

title: In Defeat, the President Has Discerned an Honorable Victory
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Mogadishu, in defeat, is much the same as it was in victory six months agoundemonstrative and inscrutable. Behind the pink and white crenelations that fend off the gentle breeze from the Indian Ocean, the children gambol on rockpiles, the men crowd the sweltering coffee houses at dusk and women cloaked in thick black veils lug the clay's purchases in tiny brown sacks. There seems to be little talk of the war that ended last week. Aside from the of graffiti on the walls  Freedom, like the rising sun, cannot be halted, and Down with Russian imperialism  a visitor would have little way of knowing that the nation had just suffered the most disastrous defeat in its 18year history and the annihilation of a dream called greater Somalia.

title: The Bee Gees Are Getting as Big As the Beatles
description: As anyone who pays the most cursory attention to popular culture must know, this is the time of the Bee Gees. The Australian popdisco trio dominates the sound track of the topgrossing movie of the moment, Saturday Night Fever. The soundtrack album, a twodisk set largely but not exclusively consisting of old and new songs by them, or written and produced by them for others, is a solid, longterm No. 1 on the album sales charts. Most astonishingly, three of their new songs from the album are high on the singles charts, and two morecomposed and produced by Bee Gees members for Andy Gibb and Samantha Sangare up there, too. In some charts the Bee Gees as composers, performers and /or producershave four of the top five singles and five of the top 10. It's a dominance unprecedented since the acme of the Beatles's first success in 1964, made all the more remarkable by the fact that Andy Gibb is the younger brother of the three brothers Gibb who make up the Bee Gees: Barry, Robin and Maurice.

title: YANKEE PLAYERS DENY CUNNINGHAM DEALINGS

Like the. best blues guitarists, he can take the simplest musical materials- two pitches and one chord; sayand through the creative use of varied inflections and splitsf end timing get more musk: out ot them than most rock guitarists can extract from the entire chromatic scale.

title: GIACOMO CARDINAL VIOLARDO
description: ROME, March 18 (UPI)Giacomo Cardinal Violardo, one of the Roman Catholic Church's leading law experts, died today, Vatican officials said. He was 79 years old. Cardinal Violardo, a law professor at Pontifical Lateran University, served for 22 years on the Supreme Tribunal of the Apostolic Signatura, the Vatican's ccurt of appeals, of which he became secretary in 1963. Pope Paul VI appointed him a cardinal in 1969. His death reduced the number of cardinals to 130.

title: Panama: Two Cheers, One Reservation
description: The vote (6832) on the first Panama Canal treaty yielded a margin so close to the required twothirds that the months of intensive lobbying and the lastminute compromises must be marked down as justified. We are disturbed by the escape clause written into the neutrality treaty in the closing days of the battle and no one should be complacent about next month's vote on the second treaty that actually transfers control over the waterway. But neither must all the maneuvering be allowed to cloud the achievement: The United Stafes on the verge of eliminating a major irritant in relations with Latin America, removing the last trappings of hemisphere colonialism in a way that still assures American access to the .canal.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: THE relationship between public television and books in this country has largely been a mutually beneficial one. In its latest literary venture, the Public Broadcasting System will present a series of programs on the life and work of eight American authors. The series is called The Originals: The Writer in America, and the first one will be shown nationally on March 20 (in the New York area, the program will air on March 23 at 8:30 P.M. on Channel 13). The premiere show features Janet Flanner, who for over 50 years wrote the Letter From Paris in The New Yorker. In the following weeks, halfhour programs will be devoted to poet Robert Duncan, novelist John Gardner, poet Muriel Rukeyser, and novelists Ross Macdonald, Wright Morris, Toni Morrison and Eudora Welty, in that order. The series originated at WNETTV, with a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. We recently saw four of the halfhour programs and found them to be imaginative and sensitive, if abbreviated, video portraits of the writers and their worlds.

description: TodayJanSu Stables, Oak View Highway, East Hampton, L.I. Special and children's working hunters, special and novice jumpers, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: The President
description: WASHINGTON  Before the Inauguration, when the Presidentelect was putting together his Cabinet, Robert S. Strauss, then as now one of Mr. Carter's chief political advisers, had a bit of sage advice: If you pick Joe Califano he'll irritate you every single day, but at the end of the day you'll look back and see that he's been a Rreat asset.

title: Of Special Interest
description: Moliere in Spite of Himself, a translation and adaptation of a play by Mikhail Bulgakov written in 1929, recently opened at the Colonnades Theater Lab. Ostensibly about the difficulties that Moliere and his troupe of players encountered in the court of Louis XIV, the play is a study as well of the relationship between art and power, and reflects Bulgakov's view of Stalin. The Times's Richard Eder responded with an accolade: A collection of beautifully schooled and styled performances. They are put together in a production whose every element ... is a stroke of shining craftsmanship. The piece runs through April 22 and thereafter will enter the repertory. (See Theater)

title: Kidnappers End Silence, Releasing a Photo of Moro and a Statement
description: ROME, March 18The kidnappers of Aldo Moro broke a tense 48hour silence abOlit his fate today, releasing a photograph of the former Prime Minister sitting beneath their banner and a statement declaring war on the state.

title: Beaths
description: ALEXANDEREthel Newsome, on March 18, 1978, beloved wife of the late Thomas McKenzie Alexander, devoted mother of the late Elizabeth Alexander Stent and Jessica Ann Alexander. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, Madison Ave at 81 St, Sunday, 3 to 7PM. Funeral Mass Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Ave & 84 St, Monday, 11AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN the finish on a table top gets severely stained, scratched or discolored it is almost impossible to get by with merely polishing or touching up. Refinishing, on the other hand, is not only a tedious chore, it often requires that the entire table be refinished  not just the top. In many cases a simpler and more permanent solution lies in covering the top with a plastic laminate. This provides a permanently stainproof surface that will be almost maintenancefree. Sold in all lumber yards, these plastic veneers come in a wide range of woodtone colors that will match or blend with most finishes.

title: Wrestling Title to Iowa
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., March 18 (AP) Iowa's only two finalists lost, but the Hawkeyes clung to a slender lead built in the consolation round and edged the defending champion. Iowa Stale, by onehalf point for the National Collegiate wrestling championship tonight at Cole Field House of the University of Maryland:

title: A North Fork Rite of Spring
description: SOUTHOLD IT'S 5:30 A.M., the sun is just beginning to streak the skies over the North Fork, and from Mattituck to Orient, a special Saturday has begun for many people. This is the day that George Conway is slaughtering pigs and that, as it has been on the Conway farm for the last 60 years, is the occasion for a ritual rite of spring.

title: Barbara Ann Krasa Bride of Brian Kelly
description: Barbara Ann Krasa, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Krasa of Jackson Heights, Queens, was married yesterday afternoon to Brian Christopher Kelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher G. Kelly of Fair Haven, N. J. The Rev. John G. Donohue performed the ceremony in Holy Family Roman Catholic Church.

title: POLITICS
description: HARTFORD

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In Denver, the other week, Christopher Jaffe was talking about concert halls then and now. Mr. Jaffe, a heavyset, squareshaped man with thinning hair and a permanently quizzical look, is the acoustician of the Boettcher Concert Hall, which opened to great applause on the evening of March 4. He is something of a maverick among acousticians, always asking questions, refusing to take anything for granted. One of the things he refuses to admit is the necessity for concert, halls to follow the established pattern.

title: GARDENING
description: ROOFTOP GARDENING

description: Pamela Ann Winthers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Robert Winthers of Morristown, N.J., was married yesterday to Robert Armstrong Matthews, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Dunbar Matthews of Wantagh, L.I.

title: N.C. State, Texas Win in N.I.T.
description: North Carolina State and the University of Texas will meet in the final of the National Invitation Tournament tomorrow night at Madison Square Garden, after scoring semifinal victories last night in contrasting styles.

title: Boston's Trolleys Now Seem on the Right Track
description: BOSTONFor a while, Boston thought it was stuck with the little engine that couldn't.

title: Bhutto's Lawyer Urges World Pressure to Save Him
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 19The lawyer representing Zulfikar All Bhutto made an appeal today for an interimtional campaign of pressure to prevent the execution of the former Prime Minister, who was sentenced to death yesterday after being convicted of a murder conspiracy.

title: Relief Is Felt in U.S. Over Election Result
description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (Reuters) American officials greeted the victory of the French Government today with apparent relief, and one analyst suggested that the victory might have a favorable effect on the volatile Italian parliamentary situation..

title: Chrysler Plans to Ask Approval For Its First Preferred Shares
description: DETROIT. March 19In a move to raise funds to finance an ambitious capitalimprovement program over the next five years, the Chrysler Corporation will ask shareholders this spring to approve the issuance of 20 million shares of preferred stock and 90 million shares of common stock.

title: Automat, a Down-to-Earth Windows on the World, a Shadow of Old Self
description: The Automat, that gleaming chrome and glass marvel that so many once thought was the restaurant of the future, is slipping into New York City's oast.

title: PETER R. HART
description: Peter R. Hart, the portfolio manager and a vice president of the Hartford National Bank, died Saturday of cancer at the Hartford Hospital. He was 32 years old and lived at 13 Nodbrook Drive in Simsbury, Conn.

title: Moscow Denies Only Itself
description: Soviet art and thought are bleeding, hemorrhaging, in fact. The stream westward of distinguished artists and intellectuals in the past decade can be compared only with the flow from Nazioccupied Europe 40 years ago. So if settling in freedom without losing interest in the affairs of the homeland is truly unpatriotic activity, there is plenty more work for the Soviet bureaucrats who last week erased the traces of citizenship from Mstislav Rostropovich, the cellist; his wife, Galina Vishnevskaya, the soprano; and Pyotr Grigorenko, a former general.

title: Investor Said to Be Interested In Building Trade Center Hotel
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has found a private investor interested in building a hotel at the World Trade Center, the authority's chairman. Alan Sagner, said yesterday.

title: 150,000 Rhodesian Blacks Hail Muzorewa at Rally
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 19Some 150,000 blacks crowded into a muddy athletic field here today to acclaim Bishop Abel Muzorewa, one of three black leaders who earlier this month signed an agreement with Prime Minister lan D. Smith aiming at black majority rule by the end of this year. The accord has met with widespread skepticism internationally because major facKjow of blacks were not represented.

title: Fire in Bird's Nest
description: BOURNEMOUTH, England, March 19 (Reuters)Firemen extinguished a fire in a bird's nest under the eaves of a building here during the night. We think the bird picked up a lighted cigarette stub to use for nestbuilding, said the fire station chief, Philip Miller.

description: The telephone pollof residents of School District 26 in Queens was conducted from March 13 through March 15. There were 573 respondents in this sampling of households in the district.

title: DESPITE KIDNAPPING, ITALY WILL CONTINUE TRIAL OF TERRORISTS
description: ROME, March 19Italian authorities have decided to continue the trial of leading members of the Red Brigades tomorrow, despite the fact that Aldo Moro, the former prime minister, is still being held hostage by terrorists belonging to that organization.

title: How to Get Into Shape for a Season's Play
description: For those who have been playing tennis, squash or racquetball two or three times a week during the winter, there is usually no need to engage in extensive physical exercises before forsaking the indoor arenas for the outdoor tennis courts. But for thosebuffs who have led a sedentary life since last fall and have not prepared themselves physically, the possibility of damaging muscles or joints during the first spring outing is a very real one.

title: The Stakes in Rhodesia
description: The United States and four other Western members of the United Nations Security Council were right to abstain last week on a resolution to condemn Rhodesia's internal settlement between Prime Minister Ian Smith and three black leaders. The West could not defend a plan for supposed majority rule that in fact leaves great power with Rhodesia's 4 percent white minority. But to vote against the plan would have closed the door on new negotiations to bring the competing black factions together.

title: Issue and Debate Stabilizing the Ailing Dollar-- Active and Passive Aspects

title: Thoughts At 33
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.I was reared in a sevenroom ranch house with two full baths, a twocar garage and central airconditioning. My mother was especially proud of the house and the community, an ailment SUDUM of Newark,. N.J. I was somewhat embarrassed by it all. We seemed to have so much and Newarkers seemed to have so little. My high school English teacher said I was blessed with an active social conscience.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MASTER WORK One of New York's sterling contemporarymusic series is ending its season tonight at 8 with a special program at Alice Tully Hall. The concert, presented by the Performers Committee for 20th-Century Music, is the first in a number of events saluting the 70th birthday of Olivier Messiaen, France's senior cornposer.

title: Bert I'm Proud of You
description: WASHINGTON  After promising the Senate under oath that he would not engage in banking activities, and after taxing the oath of office as Jimmy Carter's most powerful Cabinet memoer, Bert Lance broke his promise and dishonored his oath: He met two men in the Metropolitan Club in Washington, D.C., last spring to discuss the takeover of a company that owned a dozen banks in Washington and New York.

title: Poll Finds 70% of Residents Back Ousted Queens Board
description: Seventy percent of the residents of Community School District 26 in Queens support the refusal of their community school board to supply the Federal Governmrat with ethnic information in the schools, according to a poll conducted by The New York Times.

description: Burlgars stole $150,000 in jewelry yesterday from a Forest Hills, Queens, store after chopping through a wall from an adjoining camera store, which they also burglarized.

title: U.S.Arab Interests Form Banking Unit
description: A group of businessmen from the rut ing family of Kuwait and from merchant families in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have joined with Anierican executives to form an investment banking venture in the United States to recycle petrodollars into investments here- and abroad.

title: Sally Little Wins; SAN DIEGO, Calif., March 19 (UPI)Sally Little carded a par at the first suddendeath hole today and beat Nancy Lopez for first place in the $165,000 Kathryn Crosby golf classic.
description: Miss Lopez, who was trying for her third straight Ladies Professional Golfers Association victory, left a 15foot par putt an inch short on the playoff hole. Miss Little, by chipping to within two feet, and holing out from there, picked up the first prize check of S22,500.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19 (UPI)Senator Robert C. Byrd said today that he knew of no deal by the Administration to gain votes for the Panama Canal neutrality treaty.

description: Federal authorities in New York City ire investigating allegations of massive bankruptcy fraud involving a national warehousing company that has been in eceivership since 1973.

title: AIR ACCORDS DILUTE ROLE OF NEW YORK IN ATLANTIC TRAVEL
description: The opening of 11 new American cities to direct international air traffic and the spread of discount air fares to existing gateway cities are likely to bring New York down another notch in its dominance of transAtlantic air travel, according to aviation analysts.

title: Justice Burger Urges Judges to Help Preserve Role of State Courts
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., March 19Speaking of the need to restore the state Courts as the basic system of justice, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger urged state court judges today to take the lead in halting the expansion of the jurisdiction of the Federal court system.

description: Seventy percent of the residents of Community School District 26 in Queens support the refusal of their community school hoard to supply the Federal Goyernment with ethnic information in the schools according to a poll conducted by The New York Times.

title: Payments to Informers Extended
description: OMAHA, March 19 (AP)An experimental program in which the police buy information about robberies and burglaries with money from the Nebraska and Omaha Food Retailers Association has been extended. The retailers, mostly Omahaarea grocers, have put up an additional $2,500. The police said that the association had already gathered $1,500 which has helped the recovery of about $35,000 in stolen property and the arrests of 40 persons in felony cases.

title: NEW YORK WOMAN IS SLAIN IN HOTEL ROOM IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, Monday, March 20 (AP)A hotel busboy has been charged with murder in the killing of a New York City woman who was found strangled in her room.

title: Song: Montserrat Caballe Gives Recital
description: NOT EVERYBODY loves Montserrat Caballe. There are those who find her lapses from the score lamentable, her mushy declamation an offense and her reliance on halfvoiced cooing little more than a mannerism.

title: Triumph Of Hate?
description: BOSTON, March 19Prime Minister Begin comes to Washington this week with an emotional mantle of approval for his response to Palestinian terrorists. Internal Israeli criticism of his peace policy has been damped down. Many American supporters of Israel sympathize with its military action in Lebanon. The New York Times says` the massive retaliation was justified.

description: THERE WERE two debuts at the Saturday matinee of Carmen with the New York City Opera at the New York State Theater, one in a major role and one in smaller part.

description: Hundreds of teenagers bearing rifles, sabers and colorful flags invaded Madison Square Garden Saturday for an allday competition to see who could swirl, twirl march and dazzle the best.

title: Neutron Bomb Protested
description: AMSTERDAM, March 19 (Reuters)About 50,000 people marched through the center of Amsterdam today to protest against plans by the United States to develop a neutron bomb.

title: TEXAS FREIGHT RATE MAY BECOME TEST OF CARTER PROGRAM
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 19Texas energy consumers, who already pay some of the highest rates in the nation, are facing an estimated increase of at least $250 million a year by 1985 if the Government agrees to a proposed increase in the price for delivering coal from Wyoming.

description: LEXINGTON. Ky.. March 19This is normally the gladdest time of year here in the heart of Kentucky's bluegrass regionthoroughbred country.

description: Comptroller Harrison 3. Goldin said yesterday that he would scrutinize the large maintenance costs at Yankee Stadium that have enabled the New York Yankees, with soaring baseball revenues in 1976 and 1977, to pay a rent to the city that is only a small fraction of the amount ordinarily required by the lease between the city and the Yankees.

title: Duke Routs Villanova In Eastern Final, 9072
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19Duke gained such an easy 9072 victory over Villanova today in the East Regional finaL of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament that the game, which was settled in the first seven minutes of play, amounted to an embarrassment for the Wildcats from Philadelphia's Main Line.

title: Montclair Quintet Gains East Title
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 19Carol Blazejowski, the rangy shooter with fingertip control, established a women's intercollegiate scoring record this afternoon in leading Montclair State to a 7560 triumph over Queens College.

title: Poland Advances
description: WARSAW, March 19 (UPI)Poland won the final two singles matches today to defeat Iran, 4I, in the European zone eliminations. Wojtek Fiback beat Mansur Bahraini, 63, 61, 62, and Czeslaw Dobrowolski routed Maharani Khodaj, 61, 60, 64, in the final two matches of the series.

title: French Hint Dispute May Have Caused Oil Spill by Tanker
description: BREST, France, March 19A quarrel over salvage money and delays in informing the French Navy that the vessel was in trouble may have led to the world's worst oiltanker spill, according to French officials.

title: Skiing: Mahre Edges Stenmark
description: AROSA, Switzerland, March 19 (AP) Phil Mahre of White Pass, Wash., won the men's parallel slalom race today, narrowly beating the overall World Cup champion, Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden, in the final event of the World Cup skiing season.

description: JADRA, Lebanon, March 19The old man slumped against the cleated tire of his McCormick tractor and emitted a piercing moan that rose above the sound of the hurrying traffic of other refugees.

description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Nuclear Regulatory Commission confirmed today that Federal agents were investigating attempts by European commodities traders to sell 239 pounds of highly enriched uranium to the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

description: ALBANY, N.Y., March 19 (OPI)A 29-year-old Connecticut man, John Vitali, outlastcd almost 700 other runners today to capture the national amateur athletic union 30kilometer championship run between Schenectady and Albany.

description: ABOARD THE VIKING PIPER BARGE, in the North SeaEddie Lemoine sometimes hears a gull scream when he wakes up in the morning. It is not the same as waking to the song of a mockingbird or the bray of a lonesome alliator.

description: PAMINE OLIVEROS is a remarkable American composer, and her Rose Moon, a ritual choral work commissioned and performed by Neely Bruce's Wesleyan Singers, is a fascinating piece. Whether it works quite as well as it might is another matter.

title: Golf: Nicklaus Triumphs by Shot
description: PONTE VEDRA, Fla., March 19Jack Nicklaus finished the Tournament Players Championship today in fewer strokes than anyone else, but he did not consider himself the winner. Nicklaus said the Sawgrass golf course, with its extraordinary wind, slow greens and severe pin placements, had been the real winner, while he was the sole survivor. He could not remember winning a tournament with a lastday, nobirdies 75, as he did today.

title: Future Stars Of Tennis
description: The Easter Bowl. a junior tennis tournament that in the past has included Jimmy Connors, Dick Stockton and Tracy Austin, will be held Wednesday through Sunday at the East River Tennis Club, near the 59th Street Bridge in the Long Island City section of Queens. This year's field includes players named Evert (John) and Solomon (Shelley), who have older siblings somewhat more famous. Admission to the 9 A.M.-to-9 P.M. event costs $2 daily, but $1 for those 18 years and under.

title: Indictments Shock Florida Town, Inured to Vice Reports
description: LAKE CITY, Fla.Corruption was way of life for so long in Lake City that the community began to lose sight of the difference between fixing a speeding ticket and letting criminals escape justice for a once.

title: Man Shot in Apartment
description: A Washington Heights man identified as Emanuel Fredericks, 24 years old, of 616 West 165th Street, was in critical condition last night after being shot in the head and chest in the lobby of the apartment house where he lives according to the police. His wife said he had been summoned downstairs by an unidentified ingi and had been shot twice for an unkribwn reason.

title: Miss Ruvinska At the Piano
description: PAULINA RUVINSKA, who pcrformed Saturday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall, is no newcomer. Her New York debut took place over 40 years ago, and she once appeared here with some frequency. Saturday's was her first lotal concert in many years, howeVer.

title: De Gustibus: The Shrimp Newberg Issue
description: A brief while ago my colleague, Pierre Franey, offered a recipe for shrimp Newberg (sic), accompanied by an anecdote concerning the origin of the dish about which he expressed some mild skepticism. Briefly, gastronomic lore has it that a gentleman named BenWenberg frequented the old Delmonico Restaurant in Manhattan in Its heydey and was much respected by the management.

title: Captured Arab Describes Bus Raid
description: TEL AVIV, March 19 (Reuters)  A teenage Palestinian guerrilla who was captured in the terrorist raid on Israel eight days ago said today that his band set out from the Lebanese port of Tyre aboard a mother ship on March 8 and, after casting off in rubber boats the next day, lost its way at sea.

title: Spinks: Traffic Charge
description: ST. LOUIS, March 19 (AP)An already bad weekend was climaxed early this morning for Leon Spinks, the heavyweight boxer, when he was detained after being stopped by traffic police here in his hometown. Earlier Spinks had been stripped of his world championship crown by the World Boxing Council and had been sued by his landlord in Philadelphia for nonpayment of rent.

title: Canadian Issue: School Language
description: MONTREAL, March 19An Englishspeaking or Frenchspeaking child has a right to be educated in his or her own language, according to the 10 provincial premiers of Canada, but it is up to each province to apply the right as it wishes.

title: State Directs Bergen Pines to End Overcrowding in Psychiatric Ward
description: PARAMUS, March 17State health officials are sharply critical of the Bergen Pines County Hospital here for allowing chronic overcrowding in a locked psychiatric ward where emotionally ill teenagers coexist with criminals, psychopaths and mentally unstable old men alcoholics.

title: Cheyney State 47, Wis.Green Bay 40

J., March 19Clark Graebner of Greens Farm, Conn., a former high ranking tennis star, and Doug Russell of New York City won the biggest money prize in platform tennis history today by taking first place in the men's division of the $50,000 classic at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

title: Palestinians Report an Israeli Drive Toward Tyre

title: Colson Assails Haldeman Book

title: Ice Age Tools Put to the Test

Sister of Mrs Esther Bromley, 11 grandchildren, 1 great grandchild also survive. A memorial service will be held on Thursday at 11 AM, in the United Methodist Church, of Norwalk, Ct. title: THE REV. JAMES SUGIOKA
description: INDIANAPOLIS, March 19 (UPI)The Rev. James Sugioka, a veteran activist for the civil rights of JapaneseAmericans, died last night after his car fell on him while he was doing repair work. He was 71 years old.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Suddenly (at 6:34 P.M.) It's Spring
description: Spring arrives today at 6:34 P.M., when the sun crosses the equator, making night and day of equal duration in all parts of the earth. In the New York metropolitan area, the National Weather Service forecast called for a sunny day, with temperatures in the upper 40's, and a partly cloudy evening with a low about 40 degrees. A chance of showers was predicted foriomorrow.

title: Parkchester Hospital in the Bronx, A Subject of Inquiry, Closes Doors
description: The Parkchester General Hospital, a private 208bed facility in the Grand Concourse section of the Bronx, closed yesterday, discharging the last of its 140 patients, most of whom were moved to neighboring hospitals over the weekend.

title: DOROTHY OPALACH
description: Dorothy Opalach, president of the WNCN Listeners Guild, an organization devoted to helping the New York City FM radio station present classical music, was killed in an automobile accident Friday. She was 50 years old and lived at 393 West End Avenue.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, March 19Thanks to a whining decision in a difficult slam contract on the last deal a semifinal match in the early hours of this morning a quartet of Chicago experts headed hy Marine Walters reached the final of the women's knockout team championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here today'.

title: Multistate Banking Makes Financial General a Rarity
description: Financial General Bankshares Inc., the prospective subject of a courtordered tender offer by wealthy Arab associates of Bert Lance, former director of the Office of Management and budget, is a rarity in bankinga bank holding company with operationg in more than one state,

title: Auto Racing: Atlanta 500 to Bobby Allison; HAMPTON, Ga., March 19 (AP)lobby Allison, driving a Thunderbird, crasted to a onelap victory today in he 19th Atlanta 500 stock car race.
description: Allison led the last 197 laps of the 128lap event, taking the checkered lag under caution, the fourth of the lay, following a threecar spin four aps from the finish.

title: Knicks Drop 4th in Row, 125118
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 19  The Knicks lasted a little longer today than they did last night, but the result was the samea loss to the Philadelphia 76ers. The 76ers triumphed, 125118, before a crowd of 17,138 at the Spectrum.

title: Pressmen Reach a Tentative Pact With Newspaper in Tacoma, Wash.
description: TACOMA, Wash., March 19 (AP)One of two striking unions has reached a tentative contract agreement with negotiators for the. 102,000circulation Tacoma News Tribune, which was shut down by walkouts on March 10.

title: Deaf Boy, 13, Is Slain by Landlord On Failing to Heed Shout to Stop
description: A 13-year-old deaf boy was shot to death yesterday in lower Manhattan by the owner of a building who said he surprised two boys as they ran into a vacant upstairs apartment and escaped out a rear window, the police reported.

title: Jazzwomen Jam First Festival
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 19Kansas City, a seedbed of jazz in the 1920's and 30's when Count Basie, Lester Young, Ben Webster, Mary Lou Williams and Charlie Parker were playing there, is in the jazz spotlight again this weekend. Women jazz musicians from all parts of the country nave converged on the city to learn at clinics, to play in jam sessions and to listen to such jazz stars as Marian McPartland, Mary Osborne, Betty Carter, Toshiko Akiyoshi and Miss Williams at the first Women's Jazz Festival.

title: Dance: 3  Women On an Afternoom Off
description: WHAT do dancers do on their afternoons off? Dance, of course, and on Saturday at the Enterme:. dii Theater Peggy Lyman, Elisa Monte and Diane Gray got together in the last- new program of this season's Dance Umbrella series. There was a fitting sense of the timeless and the new to the afternoon. .

title: Dyson's Nomination Still Periled Despite Apology on Mask Incident
description: ALBANY, March 19  The state's Commerce Commissioner, John S. Dyson, continues to attract as much controversy as business.

description: Spring means good news for tennis players in the metropolitan area who prefer outdoor to indoor competition. Next Monday, for instance, the City of New York will begin issuing permits for its outdoor courts. These will not open until

title: Swallows Are Back In Capistrano on Time
description: SAN JUAN CAPISTRANO, Calif., March 19 (AP)The swallows came back to Capistrano today, on schedule.

title: Jersey Criticizes a Hospital Ward
description: PARAMUS, N.J., March 17New Jersey health officials are sharply critical of the Bergen Pines County Hospital here for allowing chronic overcrowding in a locked psychiatric ward where emotionally ill teenagers coexist with criminal prisoners, psychopaths and mentally unstable old men and alcoholics.

title: Ice Age Tools Put to the Test
description: FRONT ROYAL, Va.It was almost a scene from the Pleistocene epoch. On a snowy hilltop near this Shenandoah Valley town, a shaggyfaced man, playing the role of an Ice Age hunter, plunged his flint knife into the carcass of an elephant representing a mammoth,

title: JULIAN BOND PLANS TO GIVE UP POLITICS
description: NASHVILLE, March 19State Senator Julian Bond of Georgia, the civil rights activist who 10 years ago was the first black ever offered as a possible VicePresidential candidate for a major political party, now finds himself politically isolated and plans to leave elective politics altogether.

title: Dance: Julie Maloney
description: Too MUCH of Julie Maloney's choreog,raphy resembles wall paper. Wallpaper patterns certainly fill space neatly. But usually they are so Innocuous as to be almost unnoticeable: Or if they do call attention to themselves, they may seem nointlesslv bizarre.

title: BLACK CIVIC GROUP SHAPING NEW ROLE
description: A grassroots civic organization for blacks in Brooklyn to act as watchdog of all agencies and officials that affect the community was formed yesterday at the end of a threeday convention in Brooklyn.

title: Gottfried Triumphs; WASHINGTON, March 1R (AP)Brian Gottfried defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 75, 76, today in the final of a $125,000 tennis tournament.
description: Gottfried, who did not lose a scL during the tournament, won $21,250. He defeated Arthur Ashe, Phil Dent and Manuel Orantes on the way to the final.

title: Notre Dame, Duke Win Regional Titles
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., March 19In an athletic tradition as rich as Notre Dame's it is hard to find a way to reach new heights, but its basketball team took a large step in that direction today by beating DePaul, 8464, to wrap up the Midwest Regional phase of the 32team National Collegiate Athletic Association championship tournament.

title: Officials of a Large Union District Predict Ratification of Coal Pact
description: DILLES BOTTOM, Ohio, MarCh 19Officials of one of the United Mine Workers largest districts grudgingly predicted today that a majority of the national union's 160,000 striking members would vote yes on Friday to ratify a new proposed contract and end the work stoppace now in its fourth month.

title: BERLE OUTLINES PLAN. SAVING STATE WATER
description: ALBANY, March 19New York State's Environmental Conservation Commissioner, Peter A. A. Berle, today outlined his department's legislative program for water conservation and coupled it with a request that the Federal Government change its water policies to benefit the industrial Northeast.

title: Independence 62, Niagara 61
description: HUTCHINSON, Kan., March 19 (UPI) Independence, Kan., won its second consecutive National Junior College Athletic Association championship last night with a 6261 victory over Niagara of New York. Thomas Louden scored the deciding point on a free throw.

title: Foaling Time a Sad One in Kentucky
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 19This is normally the gladdest time of year here in the heart of Kentucky's bluegrass regionthoroughbred country.

title: $9 Million Wastage On City U. Project Charged in Audit
description: A deficient design for the construction of a new Bronx Community Colege campus above a subway yard, wasted $9 million, and the eventual costs of the design deficiencies could amount to $54 million, according to a state audit.

title: NURSINGHOME AUDITS FIND OVERPAYMENTS
description: Audits of the books of 245 proprietary nursing homes in New York State indicate that 210 have collected a total of $50 million in Medicaid overpayments since 1970, Charles J. Hynes, the special state nursinghome prosecutor, reported yesterday.

title: Unionists Resigned to Terms, With Fiery Exceptions
description: NEW STANTON, Pa., March 19Local union officials representing 9,000 western Pennsylvania coal miners cheered today as cne of their number burned a copy of the proposed contract that, if ratified, would end the  105day United Mine Workers strike.

title: TV Tunes In Sex as Crime Fades
description: Los ANGELES

title: The New York Times/Garr Settle
description: RESCUE DRILL: Greg Toffic holding a duck in demonstration of the hands on technique of cleaning waterfowl soiled in an oil spill. The Essex County Park Commission program is providing training for 26 volunteers.

title: In Hunt for Moro, Italian Police Seem Outmatched
description: Helicopters whir over Rome and the countryside. Police cars scream through the streets on their way to follow up leads. Using scanners and police dogs, police are checking traffic at roadblocks at most points leading in and out of the city.

title: 150,000 Rhodesian Blacks Hail Muzorewa at Rally
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 19Some 150,000 blacks crowded into a muddy athletic field here today to acclaim Bishop Abel Muzorewa, one of three black leaders who earlier this month signed an agreement with Prime Minister Ian D. Smith aiming at black maiority rule by the end of this year. The accord has met with widespread skepticism internationally because major factions of blacks were not represented.

title: Tennis Gear
description: A Pair of Practice Aids

title: Rosberg Victor
description: SILVERSTONE, England, March 19 (AP)Keke Rosberg of Finland won the rainplagued $190,000 International Trophy auto race at Silverstone today in a time of 1:12:49.02. Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil finished less than two seconds behind the winner for second place. Tony Trimmer of England was third and Brett Lunger of Wilmington, Del., fourth in the 117.28mile race.

title: Tones Is Golf Victor; KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia (UPI)Brian Jones of Australia shot a twounderpar 70 today and won the Malaysian open golf championship with score of 276.
description: Tied for second six strokes behind tones were the defending champion, Stewart. Ohm of Austrialia, lien Arda of the Philippines, and Mike Krantz of the United States. Arda closed with a 67, Krantz with a 73 and Ginn with a 75.

description: TEL AVIV, March 19The Israel Army swiftly took control of practically all of Lebanon south of the Litani River today, moving beyond what the Government had at one time said would be a sixmile security belt.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
Three Faces of CETA
description: It is only four years old, but in that brief span, CETA the Federal Government's Comprehensive Employment and Training Acthas been different things to different people. It has been a form of Federal help for financially beset cities, enabling them to rehire civil servants to maintain municipal services. It has offered tideover employment to laidoff workers. And CETA has meant, at last, federally created public service jobs for poor, chronically unemployed workers. Which is CETA's right role?

title: French Hint Dispute May Have Caused Tanker's Grounding
description: BREST, France, March 19A quarrel over salvage money and delays in informing the French Navy that the vessel was in trouble may have led to the world's worst oiltanker spill, according to French officials.

title: DESPITE KIDNAPPING, ITALY WILL CONTINUE TRIAL OF TERRORISTS
description: ROME, March 19Italian authorities have decideno continue the trial of leading members of the Red Brigades tomorrow, despite the fact that Aldo Moro, the former prime minister, is still being held hostage by terrorists belonging to that organization.

title: Around the Nation
description: ONTARIO, Calif., March 19 (UPI) California Jam H, an allstar outdoor rock concert that drew a quartermillion young people, ended yesterday, but about 8,000 stragglers were still scattered over the parking lots, nearly two dozen concert goers were in jail and 75 were hospitalized.

title: Deaths
description: FUCHS-Isabel. Congregation Kne. seth Israel mourns the passing of Its esteemed Sisterhood CoPresident, beloved wife of our officer, Bernard. May the Almighty comfort the entire family among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: Women's Basketball Arrives
description: MAR? MacLELLAN, a portly presence in the firstrow bleachers at center court, was swinging a plastic bag of chocolatechip cookies. Among her 14 children is Eileen, a Queens College basketball player, and Mrs. MacLellan was calling out the players names and pointing to the bag. They know, she said, if they win they get the cookies. Only if they win.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LON( BEACH, March 19 (AP) Dick Deaver of the Los Angeles Yacht Club captured the threeday Congressional. Cup competition that was comp:eted late last n'ght.

title: $750 Million in Canadian Bonds Dominates Credit Market's Week
description: Canada, a country with more inflation, more unemployment and a weaker dollar than the United States, will dominate the American capital markets this week as borrows $750 million, the largest financing ever arranged here by another nation.

title: Gypsy Cabs in City Using Haverstraw Addresses to Cut Insurance
description: HAVERSTRAW, N.Y.A crude sign over the door of a shabby storefront in town says Public Car Service. The door is locked and the place looks empty. Down the street, a sign says Haverstraw Livery Service. In the window is a homemade cardboard sign with the names of a halfdozen car and livery corporations. That door, too, is locked, and no one is inside.

That door, too, is locked, and no one is inside.

title: Sports Guide
description: The National Hockey League's television, network offers en exceptionally good game this week, pitting the two teams ting for first place in the Patrick Division. Few people push the Flyerpsround as the Islanders have in winning the most recent two contests betWeen these clubs. Combined score: New York 10, Philadelphia 1 This season, in fact, the Flyers show only two ties in four games against the New Yorkers. All the more incentive for the erstwhile Broad Street Bullies. Tonight's game, at the Spectrum in Philadelphia, can be seen here Channel 9, starting at 8 o'clock.

title: Residential Aid for Elderly Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, March 18With the ncouragement of the Carter Administraon, Representative Millicent H. Fenwick, republican of Bernardsville, N.J., is inroducing legislation that would allow naxty thousands of elderly people to void being sent to nursing homes and hat would also allow others already in iursing homes to return to their own omes or to those of relatives.

title: ZAMBIA IS STRUGGLING TO GET CRUCIAL LOAN
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, March 18Zambia, which devalued its currency by 10 percent and announced a series of austerity moves this week, has apparently met the tough and painful terms set by the International Monetary Fund as conditions for a $390 million loan to shore up its badly buffeted and sagging economy.

title: Braths
description: TERWILLIGER-James H., of Englewood, NJ, on March 17,1978, beloved husband of Anne (Chamberlain) Terwilliger, devoted father of James R. Terwilliger and Joan C. Tervilillger (daughter-In-law), brother of Mrs H. Pratt Tobev of Green Village, NJ and Mrs Richard B. Lamsche of Tuckerton, NJ. Memorial service Mohday, March 27, 11AM at Brookside Chapel, Engle Street, Enolewood. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Englewood Hospital Building Fund would be appreciated.

title: Gary Mayor's Lessons in Racial Hostility, Urban Woes and Keeping Faith
description: GARY, Ind., March 19  This is the gritty seat of the United States Steel Corporation's most productive Industrial plant. It Is also the home of Richard 1). Hatcher, who has been in office longer than any other black Mayor of a major

title: Books of The Times
description: THERE are the mountains, huge and mysterious. Here is John Jerome, his mind amazed. John Jerome loves the mountains, has done so ever since he came as a teenager from the flatlands of Hous- ton, north to Colorado and beheldwords fail him--all those little mountain cliches. (But I was in them, for the first time. . . . I vaguely recall flopping onto my belly on the pine needles for a while.) Still, for all his love, There was a frustration involved that I think is peculiarly American: I couldn't find anything to do with mountains. I didn't hunt or fish (I'd done that, and didn't want to anymore). Climbing wasn't for me (that's another long story). Camping seemed silly, par ticularly with small childrencomplex efforts to get into an uncomfortable environment in order to test one's skill at reducing that discomfort. I couldn't find any logical way to use the mountains. Which meant I didn't seem to be able to get at them.

title: Federal Paperwork: A SmallBusiness Man's Nightmare
description: MAPLE HEIGHTS, OhioEd Richard, president of Magnetics International Inc., a small manufacturer of motors, magnets and generators, glared at the mound of Government forms on his desk. It's become a nightmare, he said. We're spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to keep the Washinaton bureaucrats happy.

title: FRANK DOYLE IS RESIGNING AS CITY FIRE SPOKESMAN
description: An assistant New York City fire commissioner, Frank D. Doyle, yesterday announced his resignation as his department's press officer after more than 32 years of public service. Mr. Doyle, who will be 70 years old later this month, said he would open his own office in Manhattan soon to continue working in the publicrelations field. His resignation is effective Anril 1.

title: LEADER OF DISABLED ISSUES A CHALLENGE
description: The president of an organization for the disabled: charging that every other minority has been given more consideration by the Koch administration, challenged five city officials yesterday to spend two days working in wheelchairs to experience the problems of the disabled firsthand.

title: BEGIN ARRIVES IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Adminis, ration officials said today that they expected President Carter to have .extremely blunt talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin in coming days on the profound disagreements that have developed between the United Stites and Israel on important Middle East issues.

title: School Basketball: Mater Christi Wins
description: Mater Christi, the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association chainpion, jumped off to a 122 lead yesterday and then coasted to a 7249 victory ovr Benjamin Cardozo in the second annual Catholic vs. Public School Athletic League city championship basketball game.

title: Vaughan Deering, Fordham Professor Of Tkeater,87,Dies
description: Vaughan Deering, a professor emeritus of theater at Fordham University, died yesterday at Calvary Hospital, in the, Bronx. He was 87 years old and lived at 120 West 44th Street.

title: OFFICIALS OPTIMISTIC ON CASINO OPENING
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 19The tone of a panel discussion here on casino operations was decidedly optimistic as participants heard that obstacles to the opening before Memorial Day of the first casino, to be operated by Resorts International, would most likely be overcome and that the operator could conceivably net substantially more than $20 million during the first year.

title: A Treasure Hunter in Florida Seems to Have Won Ship's Booty
description: MIAMI, March 19Mel Fisher, the best known and most controversial treasure hunter in Florida, may have won his fight with the Government over possession of treasure aboard the sunken Spanish galleon Nuestra Senora de Mocha.

title: LEAGUE OF WOMEN VOTERS BACKS GAS DEREGULATION
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The League of Women Voters today announced its support of phased deregulation of oil and natural gas prices coupled with taxes on windfall profits.

title: TitleMinded Reds Top Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19The New York Mets got their first look of 1978 at the Cincinnati Reds today and found some clues to this question: Can the Reds regain their ranking as the best team in the National League and dethrone the Yankees as the best the business?

title: Koch Victorious
description: BRUNFLO, Sweden, March 19 (AP)Biil Koch, the silver medalist in the 30kilometer event at the 1976 Olympics, beat a fellow American Stan Dunklee, by 19 seconds today to score his first international crosscountry victory of the season.

title: Grossman Conducts, Frank Is Soloist
description: HERE are pianists around whip can play the Beethoven C minor Concerto With a bit more finesse than Claude Frank did Saturday evening at Alice Tully,Hall, but there cannot be very many who can play it with such intelligence, authority and riveting conviction.

title: Commodities
description: After meandering between $4 and $5 an ounce for almost four years, the price of silver futures appears to have broken opt on the upside ofthe market charts.

title: 11th Arrondissement: French Voting in Microcosm
description: PARIS, March 19The Basfroi Bar, a few blocks from lite Bastille in the largely working class 11th Arrondissement, was open as usual today.

title: 3,000 Russian Jews in City Find Purim Is a Little Early This Year
description: Mothers clutched babies to their bosoms and danced; fathers toasted old friends, old times and the future, and a fivepiece combo played joyous tunes yesterday as 3,000 Russian Jews, many of them newly arrived, celebrated the festival of Purim, many for the first time.

title: Hockey: Rangers in 77 Tie
description: When the firing was over, the teams were tied, 77. Although it was a freeshooting contest, there was a lack of hitting, forechecking and backchecking. Only 6,801 fans bothered to show up at Met Center, but they got all the scoring any fan could want.

title: Sweden in 50 Rout
description: DUBLIN, March 19 (UPI)  Bjorn Borg, the Wimbledon champion, crushed Sean Sorenseon, 60, 62, 60, today and Kjell Johansson routed Kevin Menton, 60, 60, 60, to complete a 50 victory for Sweden over Ireland in a thirdround European zone match.

title: Marshall Defends HisTactics In Handling Strike by Miners
description: WASHINGTON, March 19From where Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall sits, which is in a large office with a picturepostcard view of the Capitol, he and the Carter Administration are doing a good job of handling the coal strike.

title: Spoleto Festival U.S.A. Gets New Williams Play
description: Creve Coeur,. a new play by Tennessee Williams, will have its world premiere on June 1 at the Dock Street Theater in Charleston, S.C., as part of the second Spoleto Festival U.S.A.

title: Jazz: Leo Smith's Horns
description: WHEN a number of Chicago's brightest young jazz players banded together to form the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians in the mid60's, one requirement for membership was the ability to present a coherent and convincing solo concert. The result was a multitude of approaches, with each musician contributing something of his own personality to the art of unaccompanied playing while learning from his peers.

title: Tennis: A Loss For Miss Evert
description: BOSTON, March 19Tennis coaches were breathing easier today. When Evonne Goolagong captured her second straight tournament this afternoon by beating Chris Evert, 4.6, 61, 64, in the final, the Australian helped to disprove the theory that all play and no work can nroduce a champion.

title: Sale of Permits Begins Next Week
description: The sale of permits for the city's 535 outdoor municipal tennis courts starts next Monday at borough offices of the Department of Parks and Recreation. The courts open April 8. The price of permits is $27.50 for adults, $6 for juniors (16 years and under) and $15 for the elderly (62 and over).

title: U.S. Aides Say Warning to Soviet Also Aimed at Domestic Critics
description: ST. SIMONS ISLAND, Ga., March 19President Carter's strongly worded warnling to the Soviet Union last Friday resultled as much from the dictates of domestic American politics as from the needs of international diplomacy, aides to the President acknowledged privately today.

title: Ancients, Moderns
description: WASHINGTONThe debate about the economic and social problems of the industrialized world, like the (rather more sterile) philosophical dispute at the University of Paris in the 15th century, has its ancients and moderns.

title: BEGIN ARRIVES IN U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 19Administration officials said today that they expected President Carter to have extremely blunt talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin in coming days on the profound disagreements that have developed between the United States and Israel on Important Middle East issues.

title: Strike in Seville
description: SEVILLE, Spain, March 19 (Reuters)About 6,000 hotel, bar and restaurant employees went on strike for 24 hours today at the start of Seville's traditional Easter Holy Week celebrations.

title: Minsk Computer Proves a Failure
description: MOSCOW, March 19 (UPI)The Byelorussia Power Engineering Construction Department, complaining that modern technology is more trouble than its worth, has put its computer up for sale.

title: Advertising
description: This week Lorillard's True brand be comes the first cigarette to be a New York basic bus advertiser. The concept, introduced eight years ago, allows a single advertiser or produet to take over all advertising on a number of buses. Lorillard is taking 100 for two months.

title: For Want of a Shave, a Look
description: Perry Ellis, a designer, calls it breaking through a psychological barrier; Peter Jaeger, a manufacturer, likens it to girding up to face the day; Arthur Kretchmer, an editorial director, says that it's his way of declaring, Hey, life doesn't really have to be so rieid.

title: For Matlack, Reawakening
description: Red Smith

title: POPE MAKES AN APPEAL FOR RELEASE OF MORO
description: ROME, March 19 (AP)Pope Paul VI, speaking firmly though still suffering from a bout of flu, appealed today for the release of Aldo Moro, the former prime minister of Italy, who was kidnapped on Thursday.

title: Bond Markets Turn Stagnant
description: The bond market last week stayed as flat as a pancake, and fixedincome analysts last Friday were reluctant to predict that it might break out of this uninteresting stalemate at any time soon.

title: COTICIL VOTE IS 120
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19The Security Council approved a reFolution today calling on Israel to withdraw its military forces immediately from south;rn Lebanon and agreed to set up United Nations peace force to take over In the area.

title: North Park 69, Widener 57; ROCK ISLAND, III., March 19 (AP)Michael Thomas, a freshman, pumped in 19 points and Michael Harper and Toni Florentine scored 17 each in leading North Park to a 6957 victory over Widener and to the N.C.A.A. Division 111 basketball championship last night. The team from the North Side of Chicago never trailed. In the thirdplace game, Albion of Michigan defeated stony Brook of New York, 8778.
BUDGET OFFICE TO ACT ON GRIEVANCE METHOD
description: WASHINGTON, March 19The Office of Management and Budget will begin an intensive review this week of a Justice Department proposal that, for the first time, would give citizens a formal mechanism for seeking the administrative discipline of Federal agents who have allegedly misused their powers.

title: Commodities
description: Silver futures prices have apparently broken through the $5-an-ounce upward barrier for the 13th time in four years and once again traders ponder the permanency of the trend. Page D4.

title: GOVERNMENT PARTIES WIN AS FRENCH VOTERS REJECT LEFTISTS
description: PARIS, Monday, March 20  French voters solidly rejected yesterday the bid of the Socialists and Communists for power and retained the existing centerright Government coalition with a comfortable majority.

title: Text of U.N. Council's Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 19 (UPI)Following is the text of the United States resolution, adopted by the Security Council today, dealing with the Israeli occupation of southern Lebanon.

title: A Single Highway Remains Open To Link Tyre to Rest of Lebanon
description: Special to The New York Times TYRE, Lebanon, March 20Israeli troops, continuing their advance in southern Lebanon, took hilltop positions two to three miles from here, according to Palestinian sources, today virtually encircling this port city as Israeli gunboats and planes attacked Palestinian guerrilla positions to the north and south.

title: NEW YORK ASSEMBLY VOTES TO RESTORE THE DEATH PENALTY
description: ALBANY, March 20A. DlI ?? the death penalty in New York State was approved tonight after nearly six hours of debate by a fractious and emotional Assembly, but the 94-to-51 vote fell short as it did in the Senate last weekof the twothirds margin that would necessary to override Governor Carey's expected veto.

title: Cage Music Dance Event
description: Sometimes Merce Cunningham's Events seem so rarefied that, despite their pleasant moments, one nevertheless fears that by devoting his energies to them Mr. Cunning- ham is working his way up an artistic blind alley. Then there may occur an Event so remarkable that one understands why Mr. Cunningham remains preoccupied with the form. Such an occasion was Event 210, presented Sunday afternoon by Merce Cunningham and Dance Company at the Roundabout Theater.

title: Insurers
description: LONDON, March 20The breakup of the supertanker Amoco Cadiz off the coast of France is likely to inflict only a small loss on London's insurance market it anneared today.

title: Harcourt Shakes Up Trade Division
description: In a massive shakeup of its trade division, a move Harocurt Brace Jovanovich called in a press release, a reorganization; six key persons were dismissed yesterday. William Jovanovich; chairman and chief executive of the corporation, assumed direction of the division.

title: Bridge:
description: HOUSTON, March 20  Two major titles were decided when the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals concluded here last night.

title: Pop: Roche Sisters Are Now a Trio
description: In 1975, under Paul Simon's auspices, Columbia Records released an album by Maggie and Terre Roche, sisters from Park Ridge, N.J., who lived in New York and wrote songs in a folkish, softrock idiom. It was a lovely disk, and received as such by several writers.

title: REGENT STEPS ASIDE, EASING VOTE DISPUTE
description: ALBANY, March 20A bitter dispute among the Legislature's Democrats over who should be named to the state's Board of Regents took a large step toward resolution today when Regent Alexander 3.

title: Soviet Reports China Has Rebuffed a New Overture
description: MOSCOW, March 20The Soviet Union disclosed today that it had been rebuffed by China in a new offer last month proposing talks that would lead to imnroved relations.

title: CAPITAL GETS NEW SYSTEM FOR LONGDISTANCE CALLS
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)The Bell System said today that it had installed here a super switcher that can handle longdistance calls four times faster than the old system.

title: SALLY PHIPPS, 67, STAR OF THE SILENTMOVIE ERA
description: Sally Phipps, who was a star in silent movies of the 1920's, died last Friday at Long Island College Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn.

title: Pope Cancels Holy Week Activities
description: ROME, March 20Pope Paul VI has canceled his heavy schedule of Holy Week activities for health reasons, but may celebrate mass in St. Peter's Basilica and preside at ceremonies on Easter Sunday, a Vatican spokesman announced today.

title: Bank of Japan Supports Dollar
description: TOKYO, .March 20 (AP)The Bank of Japan supported the currency of the United States today by buying an estimated $400 million. Foot trade totaled an unusually heavy $673 million. A trader said, Customers wanted to sell at any price  that was 230 yen or better. The dollar ended the day unchanged at 230.025 yen a record low.

title: Gales Delay Unloading of Oil From Stricken Tanker
description: BREST, France, March 20Galeforce winds and mountainous seas today haiv. pared plans to unload the large amount of oil still in the hull of the tanker Amoco Cadiz, aground on the North Brittany coast near here, which is already responsible for the biggest oil spill in history.

title: Major British Bank in Hong Kong Wants to Invest in Marine Midland
description: The Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, a major British hank in Asia, announced yesterday that it was holding exploratory talks with Marine Midland Banks Inc. about buying a significant equity position in the Buffalobased bank holding company.

title: Corporation Affairs Wheeling Steel and Pennsylvania Agree on a Plan to Curb Pollution
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation and the State of Pennsylvania have reached an agreement on a plan to clean up wheeling's steelmaking facilities, removing a major impediment to the ailing steel company's efforts to obtain about $100 million in governmentguaranteed loans to help it survive.

title: Around the Nation
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., March 20 (AP)-Lieut. Gov, Thelma Stovall of Kentucky today vetoed a resolution rescinding ti! Slate Legislature's ratification in 1972 of the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: T.W.U. Asking a $51-a-Week Raise To Make Up for 4 Years of Inflation
description: As the pace of negotiations quickened in an effort to reach agreement before the tnicinight deadline on March 31, the Transport Workers Union presented its case ,to the Transit Authority yesterday for substantial raises for the city's 33,000 bus and subway workers.

title: The Almost Total Class
description: Possibly the most important political current flowing just now is the anger of the middle class. From Queens to California, news accounts speak of a middle class seething against a system it perceives as increasingly indifferent, if not hostile, to middleclass interests. what is curious in tills Is tne aosence of any clear idea of what the middle class is. The old notion that it was the whitecollar and storekeeping branch of society, recognizable through comfortable but not splashy income and faith in the status quo, is no longer useful.

title: Bikini Natives to Be Resettled
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The Interior Department is seeking $15 million to resettle Bikini Island natives because new studies have found that radiation from atomic tests in the late 1940's and 1950's is at an unsafe level, A letter from Under Secretary James Joseph to Vice President Mondale said that well water could not be used for human consumption and that restrictions had been placed on the amount of locally grown produce that natives could eat.

title: JUSTICES WILL DECIDE PRESS FREEDOM CASE

title: Court Refuses to Act in Church of Scientology Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, March 20The Supreme Court today turned aside a protest by the Church of Scientology that a raid on its headquarters here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation last July had violated the constitutional ban on unreasonable search and seizure.

title: Notes on People
description: Among 16 life peers created yesterday by Queen Elizabeth II of Britain was Sir Christopher Soames, a son-inlaw of Sir Winston Churchill. Sir Christopher served as Ambassador to France from 1968 to 1972. As a life peer, Sir Christopher, a former Conservative Cabinet member who lost his seat in Parliament in 1966, will no longer be able to be a member of the House of Commons. If the Conservatives return to power, however, it is assumed that he would become a party leader in the House of Lords. The 57yearold Sir Christopher was married in 1947 to Churchill's daughter Mary.

title: Bhutto's Fate and Pakistan's Future
description: Even in prison and in disgrace, Pakistan's former Prime Minister, Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, remains the chief issue in his country's politics. It was Mr. Bhutto's alleged rigging of Pakistan's parliamentary elections last March that led his opponents to demonstrate against him. It was his effort to suppress the ensuing riots by force that led Gen. Mohammad Zia ulHaq. the Army chief of staff, to remove him from office last July and declare what he hoped would be temporary martial law. And now it is Mr. Bhutto's conviction and sentence to deathfor ordering the murder of a political opponentthat has introduced new turmoil.

title: KOREAN CHIEF LINKED TO INFLUENCEBUYING
description: WASHINGTON, March 20A former offiter of the Korean Central Intelligence Agency testified in court today that he had been told that President Park Chung Hee had personally approved a covert operation in which a KoreanAmerican agent was to spend up to $1 million to influence Congress.

description: PHILADELPHIA, March 20  The Philadelphia Flyers put on a kick in their race with the New York Islanders for first place in the Patrick Division; beating their rivals tonight, 42.

description: DETROIT, March 20 (AP)The Detroit News, the nation's largest evening circulation newspaper, announced today that it would publish a morning edition for newsstand sales beginning April 3.

title: Worker Falls, Causing Blackout
description: HONOLULU, March 20 (AP)An electric company employee fell from a ladder into a 46,000volt transmission line today and was critically burned. The accident left much of downtown Honolulu, including television and radio stations and the newspapers and news services, without electricity for 57 minutes.

title: News Summary

title: TV : Michener's Personal and Loving. Look at Spain
description: Spain: The Land and the Legend finally veers in the format direction that the documentary series James Michener's World should have been taking from the start. Produced in countries associated with Mr. Michener's books'Hawaii, Israel from The Source, and now Iberia'the programs began with Mr. Michener simply reading, rather woodenly, Albert Waller scripts on appropriate locations. The results weren't dreadful, but there didn't seem to be anything very distinctive about Mr. Michener's world.

description: Leonard Silk

title: Commodity Trading Soars 22.7%
description: The volume of commodity futures soared 22.7 percent last month from the level in February 1977, according to statistics furnished by the Futures Industry Association yesterday. For the first two months of 1978, the volume climbed 16.5 percent above the 1977 level. In January, thy gain was 11 percent above 1977.

title: High Court Won't Act In Suit by Gulf Unit
description: WASHINGTON. March 20 (AP)The Supreme Court today refused to interfere in a billion dollar uranium lawsuit. Gulf Oil subsidiary in a New Mexico state court.
