title: Companies Report Earnings
CLASH ON DEATH DATA AT JASCALEVICH TRIAL
description: HACKENSACK, March 20Figures on the sharp rise in surgical death rates at Riverdell Hospital were brought out today by both the prosecution and defense to support conflicting theories in the trial of Pr, Mario E. Jascalevich, who is accused of murdering five patients at the Oradell hospital with lethal doses of the drug curare in 1965 and 1966.

title: 2 AT Q.T.T. ACCUSED OF PERJURY ON CHILE
description: WASHINGTON, March. 20The Justice I Department today charged two officials of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with a total of 12 felony offenses, all of them stemming from their testimony to a Senate subcommittee about the company's involvement in the 1970 presidential election in Chile.

title: NEW YORK ASSEMBLY VOTES TO RESTORE THE DEATH PENALTY
description: ALBANY march 2GA bill to restore the death penalty in New York State was approved tonight after nearly six hours of debate by a fractious and emotional Assembly, but the 94-to-5l vote fell short as it did in the Senate last weekof the twothirds margin that would he necessary to override Governor Carey's expected veto.

title: Tiuner Tells Employees of C.I.A. Dismissals Will Be Limited to 50
description: This will be less than a quarter of the 225 employees the agency had expected to let go by Oct. 1 in a reduction in the division responsible for clandestine, or undercover, operations.

title: Controlling Connecticut's Coast
description: Connecticut's coast comprises 270 miles of decaying industrial ports, sandy beaches, offshore islands and quaint seaport villages. Coastal recreation facilities are strained beyond capacity and pollution threatens them further. Over half the state's tidal wetlands have been destroyed. Some 500 Federal, state and local agencies vie for jurisdiction over planning and zoning, road construction, fish management and channel dredging. The Connecticut General Assembly is now considering area management legislation to bring some order to this coast.

title: Singing Out for an Opera Job
description: The New York Times/Edward Hausner

title: Salt on the Wounds of Snow
description: The arrival of spring cannot, alas, melt away one of the hidden costs of winterdamage from the enormous amounts of salt spread on the nation's roadways. The New York Transportation Department estimates that it will have used 374,000 tons of the stuff, an alltime high. Local jurisdictions have dumped their own huge quantities. The purpose of this massive outpouring of salt is to reduce the hazards of driving. Unfortunately, it also corrodes and contaminates.

title: Brzezinski, Foreign Policy Adviser, Sees Role as Stiffening U.S. Position
description: WASHINGTON, March 20Not long ago. Zbigniew Brzezinski sat alone in his White House office drawing up a list of the pluses and minuses of his first year as Jimmy Carter's national security ndvispr.

title: Precious Metals FutuFes Drop After French Election
description: All precious metals futures prices came under heavy selling on both sides of the Atlantic yesterday, reflecting the French Government's strong victory at the polls Sunday.

title: French Elections Strengthen Franc
description: LONDON, March 20 (AP)The French franc, aided by yesterday's election results, advanced strongly in European currency markets today. Meanwhile, the dollar made marginal gains but dropped in relation to the franc:

title: BRITISH LEYLAND POSTS A LOSS OF $99.1 MILLION
description: Reflecting extraordinary charges of the equivalent of $83.8 million for plant closings and other special expenditures, British Leyland Ltd. reported yesterday that it lost $99.1 million last year.

title: U.S. Indictments Tell Of Swimmers and Ships And Murder for Cocaine
description: Carlos (Pepo) Riascos, a 24year010 native of Buenaventura, Colombia, stowed away on a freighter bound for New York in 1973 to get rich or die. He died.

title: Humor Is Just a Mathema ical Plot to. One Scientist
description: Perhaps only a mathematician could regard a joke. as .a catastrophe, but one of them has sugge,Aed that just such a view of humor might yield new insight into the nature of artistic and scientific creation.

title: Advertising
description: The Continental Insurance companies, which uses a picture of a Continental soldier as a symbol, is about to start a new television ad campaign to highlight corporate identity. And it is starting with a bang, not a whimner.

title: CLOSING OF HOSPITAL IS PUT OFF BY JUDGE
description: Bankruptcy Court Hears Reports of Continuing Corruption at Logan in Harlem

title: U. of Miami Elevates Saban
description: MIAMI, March 20 (AP)Lou Saban, former coach of the Buffalo Bills who look over as the University of Miami's football coach last year, was named athletic director today. He will continue as coach.

title: Florida High Court Upholds Right Of Homosexuals to Practice Law
description: March 20The Flririda Supreme Court ruled today that a homosexual could not be denied admission to the state bar because of sexual preference.

title: U.S. Said to Urge Chile to Question 2 In Letelier Slaying
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, March 20Eugene Propper, an assistant United States attorney, showed Chilean officials evidence today identifying two suspects in the assass;na don in Washington of Orlando I etclier, a former Chilean foreign minister.

title: United Press International, Associated Prase
description: TURIN, Italy, March 20Shouting threats against former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, whom their comrades kidnapped last Thursday, leaders of the Red Brigades terrorist band threw their trial into pandemonium today almost as soon as it had resumed.

title: But at Benefit, Spring Is Stillthe Star.
description: There were a lot of flowers around Macy's Sunday night. Some of them will be there until this weekend; others bloomed for only a few hours and disappeared into the balmy spring air. They'll appear again, but who knows when and where.

title: Lemons Leads Texas Into Final
description: Abe Lemons, the Texas basketball coach who is noted for his humor, played true to form at yesterday's news conference in Madison Square Garden. His team opposes North Carolina State in the final of tonight's National Invitation Tournament at S P.M,

title: World News Briefs
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 20 (Reuters) Supporters of former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto, angered by his conviction in al murder case, fought with policemen in several cities in Pakistan today.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 21, 1978

title: Obituary 1 -- No Title
description: JOHN PARKERSON

title: Holiday Ham: No Pig in a Poke
description: IT IS far easier to limn the pagan origins of Easter than divine why ham is so thoroughly accepted in America as the holiday dish. In an estimable work titled Easter Garland, by Priscilla Sawyer Lord and Daniel J. Foley (Chilton Books, 1963), the authors point out that the name Easter refers to the season of the rising sun, or the dawn. This meaning long antedates the Christian era and was adopted as appropriate for the Resurrection, tne r east En LUC New Life.

title: People and Business
description: Wells Fargo & Company announced yesterday a major management restructuring in which Carl E. Reichardt was named president of its major subsidiary, the Wells Fargo Bank of San Francisco.

title: Carry Flynt Off Respirator
description: ATLANTA, March 21 (AP)Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, 1 has spent a full day off a mechanical respirator after having a comfortable night, a spokesman at Emory Univerpity Hospital said today. Mr. Flynt, who was shot March 6 in Lawrenceville, Ga., at a break in his trial on charges of distributing obscene material, was listed in serious condition.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)The House voted today, 391-to-6, to raise the minimum mandatory retirement age from 65 to 70 in most private industry and remove such restrictions altogether for nearly all Federal employees.

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 21, 1978

title: Evans Joins Staff of Rams
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21 (UPI)George Allen, the coach of the Los Angeles Rams, announced today the hiring of his 1 1 th assistant, Clyde Evans, who will be in cargo of conitioning the players. Evans, 34 years old, was with the San Diego Chargers in a similar capacity the ]sat four years.

title: TALK CALLED SERIOUS
description: WASHINGTON, March 21President Carter told Prime Minister Menachem Begin today that historic decisions were needed to break the impasse,in the Middle East negotiations, but the Israeli leader appeared to remain firm throughout the day on most of the issues that have produced differences with the United States.

title: Padres: Dark Out, Craig In
description: YUMA, Ariz., March 21 (UPI)The San Diego Padres dismissed Alvin Dark as manaer today because of his inability to communicate effectively with his players, coaching staff and management.

title: Chess:
description: BUGOJNO, Yugoslavia, March 17The world champion, Anatly Karpov, and a former world champion, Boris Spassky, both of the Soviet Union, shared first prize in the Bugojno International Tournament, each finishing with .105.

title: The Circus Is in Town, With Elephants, Lions And the Old Hoopla
description: The arena at Madison Square Garden was mostly deserted yesterday morning. On the floor, a few players prac- ticed for the evening's National Invitation Tournament finale. Up in the stands, nine chambermaids mopped the floors.

title: Opera: John Alexander's 33d Rolec
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's undernourished production of La Favorita, with its staid staging and skimpy sets, had at least become musically well coordinat- ed in its seventh performance this season on Monday night. This despite an announcement that Shirley Verrett, in the title role, was indisposed but would sing anyway, and the fact that the leading tenor role of Fernando was being sung for the first time by John Alexander. It was his 33d role with the company.

title: Farm Safety Week Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)Presi dent Carter today designated the week beginning July 25 as National Farm Safety Week and called on farmers to regard safety as an integral, part of all their activities.

title: Prices of Precious Metals Futures Recover From Big Monday Selloff
description: Prices of precious metals futures recovered somewhat yesterday from Monday's sharp selloff. However, the best gains were made by the close of trading. Brokers described the early buying as bargain hunting.

title: BRITAIN GIVES PLAN TO USE OIL REVENUES TO UPLIFT INDUSTRY
description: LONDON, March 21Britain's Labor Government, releasing its longdelayed plan for using North Sea oil revenues, said today that it would give top priority to rejuvenating the country's aging industrial plant.

title: Sadness in Jerusalem
description: JERUSALEMFor a few brief weeks, it appeared that Easter Week, with its eternal message of hope, might really be a time of general rejoicing in Jerusalem this year, but it hasn't worked out that way.

title: Careers
description: Standing somewhere between legal secretaries and lawyers, there is a relatively new type of professional called the paralegal, who can be described as a trained person working under the direct sunervision of a lawyer.

title: Choosing a Pet From an Easter Menagerie
description: The mound of black and white fur that the woman was stroking in her lap was neither canine nor feline. It was a rab- bit, and with the approacn of haster, rabbits come naturally to mind. This particular rabbit was part of a family comprising parents, two small children, a dog, a cat and a hamster. It seemed to enjoy being petted.

title: ANKER ACTS TO RAISE DIPLOMA STANDARDS
description: Proposals to upgrade substantially the requirements for graduation from a New York City high school, including a recommendation that a student read at least at the ninthgrade level, are expected to be announced today by bcnool Lnancenor Irving Anker.

title: Anderson Wins in Illinois Primary; Other Campaigns Pull Few Votes
description: CHICAGO, Wednesday, March 22,RPpreFentative John B.. Anderson, the thirdranking Republican in the United States House of Representatives. fought  off a hard challenge and was renominated for his 10th term in yesterday's primary election in Illinois.

title: Carey and Albany Leaders Agree To Reduce Taxes by $750 Million
description: ALBANY, March 21Governor Carey and the legislative leaders reached agreement late tonight on a $750 million package of permanent tax reductions that would lower the maximum tax rate on salary income from 15 percent to 12 percent.

title: Texas Wins Final In N.I.T. by 10193
description: Texas had things its own way offensively and defensively last night and overwhelmed a bigger and stronger North Carolina State team, 10193, in the final of the National Invitation Tournament before a crowd of 11,323 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sal Mineo Murder Trial Set
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21 (UPI)The accused killer of actor Sal Mineo was ordered yesterday to stand trial on May 25. Lionel Raymond Williams, 21 years old, was held on $500,000 bail. He will face trial before Superior Court Judge! Edward A. Heinz Jr. Mr. Mineo was fatally stabbed, outside his West Hollywood apartment on Feb. 12, 1976.

title: Parents in Connecticut Fight Ban On Pupils Needing Rubella Shots
description: HARTFORD, March 21Peter tirucien's two children have been barred from their elementary school in Rocky Hill for three weeks because, on the advice of their , npriiatrician he has refused to let them

title: CurtissWright Enjoined on Kennecott Bid
description: The rapidly escalating battle for control of the Kennecott Copper Corporation took a new turn yesterday as Utah State', Judge David K. Winder enjoined the CurtissWright Corporation from making any overt step to wage a proxy war against Kennecott.

title: Deaths
description: STOLZFreda B., age 65, passed away March 20, 1978. Beloved wife of Samuel S. Adored mother of Margritt, Robert & Jamie. Darling mother-in-law of Roger Bernstein & Marlene Nadel Stolz. Revered sister Chita Fried, Fannie Eckstein & Nat Bagdan. After a long illness. Services Weds, Mar 22, 11:30AM The Riverside 76 St &Amsterdam Ave

title: New Train From Chicago No 20th Century Limited
description: CHICAGO, March 21At least the Amtrak people are honest enough about it.

title: Britain Plans to Use Oil Revenues Mostly for Modernizing Industry
description: LONDON, March 21Britain's Labor Government, releasing its longdelayed plan for using North Sea oil revenues, said today that it would give top priority to rejuvenating the country's aging industrial plant.

title: Dance: Theatre du Silence
description: SOMETHING really new breezed into town last nighta French dance company with absolutely no pretensions to saving the world or upholding centuries of tradition.

title: Bhutto, in a Statement From Cell on Death Row, Attacks Pakistan Regime
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 21Former Prime Minister Zulfikar All Bhutto, in his first public statement since his conviction Saturday in a murder conspiracy case, vigorously denied the charge tonight, and attacked the Government for prosecuting him.

title: Jesse Jackson Will Renew Activist Drive in South
description: ATLANTA, Warch 21The Rev. JPqFe L. Jackson, one of the South's leading Civil rights activists of the 1960's who has for the past six years worked primarily in the North. plans to renew his efforts in the South in a major way,- beginning next month in South Carolina.

title: Bus Driver Is Accused of Slaying Passenger in Brooklyn Argument
description: A New York State Supreme Court officer who was working as a bus driver in violation of court rulesshot a passenger early yesterday morning in an arffument over the fare, then sped away, refusing to let the two remaining riders get off, as the fatally wounded man lay bleeding on the sidewalk, at a Brooklyn bus stop, the police said.

title: U.N. Force Adds More Contingents
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. March 21The new 4,000man United Nations peacekeeping force for southern Lebanon began to take shape today with the acceptance of troop offers from Nepal, Norway and France.

title: The U.N. Today
description: MARCH 22, 1978

title: More Food for Thought: A Barmecidal Feast
description: A numbir of letters have suggested, none too gently, that in an article I wrote earlier this year (January 4) I may have bitten off more than I could chew in dealing with matters both edible and linguistic. I own the soft impeachment. Perhaps the following will stick in the craw of fewer  or at least different etymological epicures.

title: Moynihan Apologizes For Senate Remarks
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)Senator Daniel P. Moynihan, Democrat of New York, publicly apologized today for a personal attack he made yesterday on Senator Malcolm Wallop after the Wyoming Republican had proposed an amendment to one of the Panama treaties.

title: About Real Estate
description: When last heard from in Wall Street real estate activities, the American International Group was buying the distinguished Cities Service buitlding at 70 Pine Street. It has renamed that 66story Art Deco edifice the American International Building and has been moving in for two years, expanding from two buildings on Maiden Lane.

description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 21When he arrived at Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's office today for his first meeting as a coleader of Rhodesia's transitional government, Bishop Abel Muzorewa was a chaneed man. In place

title: ROBERT POTTER, 73, A WRITER ON SCIENCE
description: Robert D. Potter, science writer, editor and retired executive director of the Medical Society of the County of New York, died last Saturday in a nursing home in Miami after a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Amex Short Interest Up in Month
description: Amex Short Interest Up in Month

title: 60Minute Gourmet
description: IT IS THE understatement of the decade to say that American cooking habits have undergone mindboggling changes within recent memory. Home.cooks have traditionally never been noticeably keen about deepfrying in the kitchen but, if the sale of electrically operated deepfrying units is any indication; then that technique is gaining widespread currency from the East Coast to the West.

title: SENATE VOTES RISE IN FARMER SUBSIDIES FOR GRAIN AND COTTON
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Senate today quickly approved amendments to the farm law that would increase subsidies and price support loans on grains and cotton and push up the market prices of those commodities. The sponsor of one of the provisions estimated that it alone would cost the taxpayers $2 billion more this year.

title: British. Panel Calls for Tight Curb On Asian and African Immigrants
description: LONDON, March 21A bipartisan Select Committee of the House of Commons called in a report published today for a virtual end of major immigration of Asians and Africans to Britain and the introduction of close checks on immigrants already here.

title: World News Briefs
description: DARES SALAAM, Tanzania, March 21 (UPI)Andrew Young, the chief United States representative at the United Nations, had two hours of extremely friendly talks today with President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania and was praised for United.States restraint in the war in the Horn of Africa between Soinalia and Ethiopia.

title: The Circus Is in Town, With Elephants, Lions And the Old Hoopla
description: The arena at Madison Square Garden was mostly deserted yesterday morning. On the floor, a few players practiced for the evening's National Invi- tation Tournament finale. Up in the stands, nine chambermaids mopped the floors.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Community School Board lb in Queens filed an appeal with the central Board of Education to overturn its suspension. The community board was suspended by Chancellor Irving Anker earlier this month because it refused to submit an ethnic census of its students and faculty members. .

title: Egypt Feels Violence Shows Need for P.L.O. Peace Role
description: CAIRO, March 21Egyptian officials, evaluating the damage done to Cairo's peace initiative, are hoping that the fighting in Lebanon has dramatized the necessity of bringing the Palestine Liberation Organization, or its tacit representatives, into future neace talks with Israel.

title: India Sets Food Records but Millions Are Still Hungry
description: RANDOOR. India  Sushin Ram, a !sinewy 32-year-old farmer, grows highiquality wheat on his fertile oneacre plot !here, yet his five children are improperly ;nourished most of the time.

title: Bateman Eichler, Regional Firm, Accused of Stock Manipulation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange yesterday charged Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., a large Los Angelesbased brokerage company, with stock manipulations.

title: Easter Beyond the Egg
description: EASTER is for eggs, as we all know. But from that point on, inspiration fades. We have to be of Russian origin and particularly tenacious in nostalgia to have strong views as to what should be eaten on Easter Day and no other time in the year. Thanksgiving has its ritual menu, English Christmas has its plum pudding, and even tne rrencn break down to the point of proffering at the appropriate time that repulsive specialty, the buche de Noel, or Christmas log. But Easter is for eggs. Thereafter, it's every man for himself. Easter Day in gastronomical terms is an unfocused festival.

title: Corporation Affairs Seoul Drafts $1 Billion Order To Westinghouse for Reactors
description: SEOUL. South Korea, March 21 (AP) South Korea has decided to go ahead with a $1 billion order for American nuclear reactors as originally planned, the Korean Electric Company said today. A spokesman said that the staterun utility was drafting a contract with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

title: Deaths
description: BRUNOHarry. Air Service Post 501 American Legion records with deepest sorrow the passing of its chairman emeritus Harry Bruno, who for over 68 years lead the way with great vigor and accomplishment with a career as an aviation pioneer, leading aviation public relationist, and a confidant to all the legendary giants of the aviation and aerospace world. Recepient of our highest honor, the Frank Hawks Memorial Award, he inspired us all with his leadership and achievement.

title: Open Interest
description: TUESDAY, MARCH 21, 1978

title: Mets
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 21With only two weeks left in spring training, the New York Mets intensified their auditions for pitching tonight while breaking a fourgame losing streak that had cast doubt on the caliber of the entire staff.

title: Another Yankee Sellout
description: The Yankees jumped ahead of the Royals, 109, with three runs in the too of the ninth. Mickey Klutts, who also had two singles, fled the game with a tworun double, then scored on Al Hrabosky's wild pitch and Porter's wild pickoff throw.

title: Bill on Homosexual Rights Advances in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21The growing political power of homosexuals here and their coexistence with many others in this historically tolerant city were demonstrated last night when the Board of Supervisors approved a homo- sexual rights ordinance that many here consider the most stringent and encompassing in the nation.

title: House Votes 4Month Extension For Ceiling on National Debt
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (UPI)The House voted today to extend the $752 billion national debt ceiling four months past March 31, when the Government's borrowing power is scheduled to expire.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: NEW YORK is a polyglot city, but unlike Copenhagen and Amsterdam, few of its natives are bilingual. Still, hardly a soul lives here for long without picking up a few words from this language and that, the result being a city full of people who are jacks of all languages and masters of none.

title: Rebecca Gertner Bride Of Rabbi Arthur Blech
description: Rebecca Gertner, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yehude Gertner of Caracas, Venezuela, was married yesterday to Rabbi Arthur Blech, son of Mrs. Hersch Blech of Brooklyn and the late Rabbi Bloch.

title: BOND RATES STEADY DESPITE BIG VOLUME
description: Interest rates held steady and even declined in certain instances yesterday despite a large volume of new bonds that came to market. Many issues sold rapidly, and bond prices rose slightly in secondary market trading.

title: EASTLAND WON'T SEEK NEV TERM IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, March 21James 0. Eastland, who has been considered a segregationist power in the Sente for decades, will retire next January at the end of his term. His retirement clears the way for Edward M. Kennedy, a liberal who was only 9 years old when Mr .Eastland cameto the Senate, to become chair. man of the Senate Judiciary Committee. An aiee in Mississippi announced Mr. Eastland's retirement plans today after reports circulated throughout the state and the Capitol here.

title: Easter: Memoiies Of a Rite of Spring
description: Each year in my parochial grammar school it was impressed upon us that Easter was the more important of our two treat religious holidays. For years I thought that we were being taught that ;Christmas had gone commercial: too much Santa Claus, too many presents had whittled away the significance of the parish crche with its lifesize Mary, Joseph, attendant shepherds and plaster lambs.

title: BANK MANAGER HELD HOSTAGE FIVE HOURS
description: A gunman held a b?nk manager hostage for several hours in a bank in Deptford Township, N. J., yesterday, then surrendered to an F.B.I. agent he had allowed into the bank, the authorities reported.

title: Deaths
description: ANDERSENJane Forbes. On March 19, 1978 at Fairfax, Virginia, beloved wife of the late Arne K., devoted mother of Roy and Dorothy A. Skelton; also survived by 9 grandchild. ren, dear sister of Daniel McKay, Anne Allen and Nancy Carney. Visiting today 2 to 5 PM at Edw. C. Halvorsen Chapels, 5310 8th Ave. Bklyn, NY. Thence to Christ United Methodist Church, 7th Ave at 45 St. Bklyn where services will be held at 8PM. Funeral Thurs.10AM.

title: ALBANY PSYCHIATRIST FAVORED AS REGENT
description: ALBANY; March 21Dr. Arlene B. ReedDelaney, an Albany psychiatrist, appeared favored today for election to the New York State Board of Regents. mit Democratic sources said the selection process might again be postponea necause of an early exodus from Albany for the holiday weekend.

title: Best Buys
description: RISING temperatures, falling prices and sales calculated to marshal a preEaster parade. What more could anyone ask?

title: Three Rhodesian Blacks Sworn In To Share Leadership With Smith
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 21The formal transition to majority rule in Rhodesia began today when three black leaders gathered in the dining room of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's residence to be sworn in as coleaders of tne provisional government that will prepare for a fully black government by Dec. 31.

title: F.T.C. Head Assails DoctorGuided Blue Shield Plans
description: WASHINGTON, March 21Physician domination of Blue Shield plans, the nonprofit insurance groups that pay doctors bills, may be creating conflicts of interest, reducing competition and inflating fees, Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today.

title: Technology
description: Laws to reduce pollution and increase worker safety, along with increases in dishonesty and crime, have sharply retarded increases in business productivity in the United States in the last decade, according to Edward F. Denison, a senior fellow of the Brookings Institution.

title: Giscard Considers Changes in Cabinet; Talks With Premier
description: PARIS., March 21In the aftermath of the French legislative elections, President valery Giscard d'Estaing was weighing today chrries in his Government, includins; the question of reappointment or replacement of his Prime Minister, Ray mond Barre.

title: Municipal Unions Demand Settlement On Prior Contracts
description: A coalition of 50 municipal lanor unions said yesterday at an acrimonious meeting of the Emergency Financial Control Board that they would refuse to continue collective bargaining with New York City until all outstanding issues trom ow cuutractsincluding deferred cost-of-living paymentshad been resolved.

title: Deaths

Heubner, Endicott, NY Funeral services from the Wenk Funeral Home, Chatham, NY, March 21 at 9pm. Spring Interment, Canaan Cemetery. title: Q&A
description: When you are passing a food, casserole for example, to allow guests to serve themselves when seated at table, do you serve from the left or right? And at the end of each course do you remove the dishes from the right or left?

title: The Rangers
description: From the moment the Rangers offered the two Swedishborn stars of the Winnipeg Jets twoyear contracts worth a million dollars apiece, Bill Jennings. the Ranger president, knew he had them.

title: Theater: Madwoman Pilled With Paradox
description: JEAN GIRAUDOUX's entrancing play The Madwoman of Chaillot, now running at the CSC Repertory, combines two antithetical elements: a romantic yearning for a rural France, Out expresseu in nonromantic language that is precise, pithy and full of paradox. The reasoning of his characters is often crackbrained, but their logic is rigorous. Giraudoux's antiurban posture stands for something more than a distaste for the modern corporatiOn and its buttoneddown leadership. He seems to regard them as everything base and destructive in French national life. There are no ambiguities in The Madwoman. No one will doubt where the Playwright stands.

title: Bridge
description: For entirely different reasons, the two winners of the national open pairs that concluded the Spring Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League in Houston Sunday had particular cause for satisfaction with the result.

title: ANKER ACTS TO RAISE DIPLOMA STANDARDS; Plan Requiring at. Least 9thGrade Reading Level Is Expected Today
description: Proposals to upgrade substantially the requirements for graduation from a New York City high school, including a recommendation that a student read at least at the ninthgrade level, are expected to he announced today by School Chancellor Irving Anker.

title: CITIZENS BAND OPERATOR HINDERED HIJACKING TALKS
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 21 UPI)A citizens ,band operator using powerful, illegal equipment interrupted sensitive radio negotiations with .a hijacker at Oakland International Airport and nearly caused a disaster, the Government said yesterday.

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP)Louis Cottrell Jr., a veteran band leader of the Golden Age of Dixieland who charmed audiences with his mellow clarinet, died nu! av at his home. He was 67 years old.

title: EarlyOut
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21California's earlyout plan, an attempt to address the problems of restless high school students that may serve as one of the models for a similar plan in Connecticut. has worked well for some students in the two years since it began but has had a negligible impact upon the schools, according to a recent study.

title: SENATE VOTES RISE IN FARMER SUBSIDIES FOR GRAIN AND COTTON; MUSKIE FEARS PRICE IMPACT Challenge Posed to Carter by Move to Aid South and Wheat States House Panel Due to Meet
description: WASHINGTON, March 21The Senate today quickly approved amendments to the farm law that would increase subsidies and price support loans on grains and cotton and push up the market prices of those commodities. The sponsor of one of the provisions estimated that it alone would cost the taxpayers $2 billion more this year.

description: A DAY TO TAKE YOUR SHOES OFF: As the thermometer hovered near 60 degrees yesterday, the first full day of spring, a woman could not resist the urge to pause from shopping and catch some sun at cart scnurz Park on Manhattan's East Side. Forecast is for more of the same today with temperatures ranging from 41 to 59.

title: Wine Talk
description: ONE WAY to make sense out of the complex subject of wine is to break it down into components. Bordeaux, for example, would be comnonent of the wines of France. The Meacic would be a component of Bordeaux and St. Julien say, would be a component of the Medoc. Disassembled that way, the subject begins to make sense. Italy has always been a tougher nut to crack becauSe the geographical breakdown does not work as well. The regions are not as well known and there are some wines whose names, while famous, have nothing whatever to do with geography. Barolo, for example, is the name of a village; barbera is the name of graPe.

title: WINIFRED WESTOVER HART
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21 (UPI)Winifred Westover Hart, former silentscreen actress and former wife of the western movie star William S. Hart, died Sunday. She was 78 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, March 21The House of Representatives today killed any chance that House elections this fall would be financed by public funds.

title: A Haven in the City for the StageStruck
description: New York,is a very big and oppressing and terrifying place. You don't know a soul, you can't afford to live here, and suddenly you're taken into this safe, friendly place where everybody has the same ambitions you do. They show you the ropes, for $55 a week you've got room and two good meals a day and youre within walking distance of every casting director and agent in town.

title: Private Lives
description: IS PARTURITION. contagious? He is on the living-room floor again, listening to the house be empty. Part of his family has gone, and part has vet to arrive. In two hours he will go to the air- port. He spends more time in airports than he does in bathrooms. He occasionally feels like an airport; the announcements over his publicaddress system are in Twi or Tagalog. He ought to be thinking about the weekend, because the weekend will require all his cunning. He is thinking instead about parturition, because everybody seems to be pregnant.

title: Critic's Notebook: Pleasant Surprises
description: FROM the poverty of the theater come its surprises. Except in a few cases, there simply is no money for much advance fanfare. Broadway does lay out some- thing here and there on preopening publicity, but this is modesty itself compared with the promotional budgets for motion pictures.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: The sentimental will listen with nostalgia, the sophisticated with laughter, and the young with amazement. Imagine, just, imagine, an anthology of 77 segments of the soap operas of yesteryear. Two hours of One Man's Family, Backstage Wife, Valiant Lady, Road of Life, David Rerun], Amanda of Honeymoon Hill, John's Other Wife and Life Can Be Beautiful. That, of course, is just a sampling. For the real thing, a tworecord set called Bubbles in the Air, The Radio Yesteryear Scrapbook of Soap Operas, the price is $8.95 plus $1.05 postage and handling, and the place to write is Radio Yesteryear, Box C, Sandy Hook, Conn. 06982.

title: EXSECURITY CHIEF QUITS CHILEAN ARMY

This beloved and esteemed colleague will be missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to his family.

description: ATHENS, March 21Ever since Xenophon led 10,000 Greek mercenaries to sell their military skills to the King of Persia in 401 B.C., Greeks have been going to the Middle East in large numbers to seek their fortune.

title: Three Rhodesian Blacks Sworn In To Share Leadership With Smith

Smith's residence to be sworn in as coleaders of the provisional government that will prepare for a fully black government by Dec. 31.

description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21 (AP)Rich Kell'y scored a careerhigh 33 points, grabbed 17 rebounds and blocked six shots to lead the New Orleans Jazz to a 117.114 victory over the New Jersey Nets in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: Crocus Locus
description: ASIGH? No more: a yellow or white rupture of the cold silent Winter ground, the exclamation of such effort. Yet unaccompanied by the echoing multitudes that hope surveys; one only, and whether an accident or an example, too important In its uniqueness to be considered important for its meaning. 0, spring will come, and one time it will not, but what we are to know we will know from all the various emblems crying out of the grass, vivace asset, and waving in the soft wind, 0 Mort. One swallow of water makes no summer of earth. One drop of darkness is no sign of wine. One flower points to nothing but itself, a signboard bravely hung outside the signpainter's. The crocus of all points lying along the river that speak for themselves is but one point of saffron or of snow. A sign? 0, more.

title: FORD FOUNDATION PLANS COAL STUDY SPONSORSHIP
description: The Ford Foundation, whose studics on energy have had a sinificant influence on the Carter Administration's positions on toe subject, is to sponsor y;l. another major energy study, this ere comparing coal with other energy options available to the United States over the next 20 years.

title: The Bock Tradition, A Beer Drinker's Spring Toast
description: Long ago, in the days before tradition died easy, a special beer  brewed in the late autumn or in the early days of winter  was consigned for storage to the chill embrace of streams in the countryside that was to become Germany.

title: GmaTOUT
description: CELEBRATION A free concert telling the Purim story in word and song, and featuring Shlomo Carlebach, the Hasidic folk singer and composer, is scheduled for 8:45 tonight at Temple B'nai Jeshurun, 88th Street, west of Broadway. The musician will be joined by Rabbi William Berkowitz, director of the Institute of Adult Jewish Studies, sponsor of the concert, to the accompaniment of the Neginah Orchestra, in evoking the biblical background of the Jewish holiday.

description: Edward Marzeski, the 55-year-old Mayor of Richfield Springs in Central New York State, won reelection yesterday while being held on arson and murder charges in the Otsego County Jail.

title: NIXON AIDES WARNED BY HOOVER ON KOREA

title: Personal Health
description: WAS only 8 when my grandmother, who could not read English, mixed up the two blue bottles of milky fluid in the pantry and took two teaspoong of cleaning fluid instead of milk of magnesia. The horror of that moment and its aftermath  despite her uneventful recovery  left me with pronounced fear of accidental poisoning.

title: WorkStudy Program At. Irvington High Wins a Competition
description: IRVINGTON, March 21Irvington High School has finished first in statewide competition among schools with a federally financed program that enables seniors to attend classes in morning and get on-the-job experience the rest of the day.

title: Overseeing, Not Just Overhearing
description: Washington has long been tormented by a dilemma over electronic surveillance. Does using wiretaps and bugs turn the Federal Government into Big Brother? Does failing to use them against criminals and spies make it a weak sister? The most frequently used taps and bugs, in criminal investigations, were brought unaer judicial supervision in 1968. But in cases assertedly involving national security, surveillance has continued to raise disquieting questions. The tapping of officials, journalists and others in the name of national security accounted for no small part of the specter called Watergate. Now, because of commendable cooperation between the Justice Department and Congress, there is reason to hope that the dilemma may be finally and fully resolved.

title: PlowDown
description: SPRINGFIELD, Colo., March 21 (UPI)Striking farmers began a nationwide plow-down today, to protest low farm prices by turning under 2,000 acres of wheat in Baca County, spokesmen for the American Agriculture Movement said.

title: The President's Friend
description: The career of Bert Lance is becoming an object of concern for many Americansif not yet for the President. Mr. Lance speeds in and out of foreign airports using his special diplomatic passport. He asks top business executives to luncheon, describing himself in the invitation as Special Envoy of the President, returning here directly for this meeting from a 10nation European visit with Heads of State. He enjoys easy access to the White House, which may explain why wealthy Arabs have hired him to help invest their oil fortunes in the United States.

title: 55 Hurt in Greek Student Protest
description: PATRAS, Greece, March 21 (ReutersFiftyfive persons were injured today in clashes between the police and students demanding changes in educational poll ties at Patras University, a police official reported. The police used clubs and water hoses to disperse the demonstrators and the students pelted the police with stones and pieces of wood, the spokesman added.

title: New Orders Climb For Durable Goods By 2.5% in Month
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP) Spurred by gains in the automobile and aircraft industries, new orders for durable goods rose 2.5 percent in February, the Commerce Department reported today. Orders were up $1.5 billion to a total of $63.8 billion.

title: Notes on People
description: ALTHOUGH a Federal court suit has been filed to prevent it, Gov. Meldrlm Thomson Jr. of New Hampshire said yesterday that he intended to have all American flags on state buildings lowered in observance of Good Friday. He did it in 1976 and 1977, but this year three Unitarian ministers, an Episcopal priest and a rabbi have filed suit, maintaining that the Governor's order violated the Constitution. Mr. Thomson called the clergymen's suit a nuisance action and said, It is hypocritical to drive from public office any evidence of religion and the Christian faith. He added that he would go to the Supreme Court if necessary to fight the clergymen's suit.

title: RECORDING IS PLAYED AT PROVENZANO TRIAL

title: No. No. Race, Not Class, Is Still at the Wheel.
description: The theory that racial distinctions are less important than class distinctions in American life is being revived. It is especially disturbing now because it suggests unprecedented tensions between middleclass and underclass blacks. These new tensions, the theory slates, are byproducts of the last two decades of racial progress In the United States. But the theory is premature. In spite of some signs of progress.

title: Newark School Head to Run System as a Business
description: NEWARK, March 21Alonzo W. Kittrels, the new Executive Superintendent of Schools in the state's largest city, says he is trying to run the 68,000student public school system, with its 8,500 employees and $130 million annual budget, as a business.

title: 40% of Auto Repair Costs Called a Waste
description: WASHINGTON, March 21 (AP)The average car owner spends more than $150 a year on inadequate, incompetent, unnecessary or fraudulent auto repairs, the Federal auto safety agency said today.

title: Music: Salute to Messiaen at 70

It was a fascinating program, ery well performed. But first one should say a word about the Performers Committee's move to Alice Tully Hall this season, since Monday's concert was the third and last of the group's performances there after more than a decade at Columbia University's McMillin Theater.

title: Film: A Wagner Memoir:Aggressive Candor.
description: IF YOU STILL have doubts about the ability of the motion-picture camera to reveal the profound complexities and contradictions within the human character, you shouldn't miss "The Confessions of Winifred Wagner," the 104-minute, German, with English subtitles, documentary that opens today at the Film Forum.The film has been edited from five hours of footage made three years ago in a series of interviews with Winifred Wagner, then 78, the English-born daughter-in-law of Richard and Cosima Wagner, the widow of Siegfried, for decades the keeper of the Wagner flame at Bayreuth and, today, still loyal to the memory of her dear friend Hitler, nicknamed Wolf.The documentary is the work of Hans-Jurgen Syberberg, who was helped in obtaining the Interview by the intercession of Gottfried Wagner, the son of the Bayreuth festival's current director, Wolfgang, and the grandson of Winifred. The method of the film is so self-effacing as to be no method at all, a series of close-ups and medium close-ups of this extraordinary, shrewd, amazingly vigorous old woman as she answers questions put to her by the film maker."The Confessions of Winifred Wagner" is ironically titled in that Winifred Wagner tells everything but confesses nothing. With the kind of candor that is so aggressive that it puts her listeners on the defensive, she talks about her early meetings with Hitler, and of their shared love of the music of Richard Wagner that became the basis of a friendship that lasted from 1922 until Hitler's death in 1945.She also talks about family squabbles, about her early decision to put her husband and his work with the Bayreuth Festival ahead of her children"There were always people to take care of them"about great musicians she's known, about the rise of National Socialism and the devastating war; but always what fascinates us is the manner in which she resolutely refuses to turn her back on Hitler.Winifred Wagner professes to believe that she was always "unpolitical," that the Hitler she knew was a kind and gentle man, and, when she is pressed, that he really wasn't responsible for the Final Solution. Both she and Hitler, she says rather airily, were sad about the bombing of London, but by that time she considered herself to be completely German. There were no feelings of divided loyalties."The Confessions of Winifred Wagner" is much more than the self-serving memoir it might initially appear to be, largely because Winifred Wagner is too honest in her own way to be concerned with the minor disturbances of reputation. What we see on the screen is one manifestation of a singular family, as well as of an entire European cultural tradition, captured simply, cleanly, by a film maker who understands that by deferring to its subject, the camera is most often victorious."The Confessions of Winifred Wagner," will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 P.M., and repeated there next week, Thursday through Sunday, at the same time.

title: Q&A
description: Q We have lived in our house for six  months and although we had no problem during the summer, after the recent heavy rains and snow we have had water seepage through the. basement floor. title: The Bed That Jumps Over the Moon
description: D LANE VON FURSTENBERG is sleeping an Eclipse. That's what her new bed called. A work of art, it was a gift from her mother. The bed is oversized, and some peo- pie might say it was overpriced for a bed. Dakota Jackson, the artist who designed and made it, wouldn't quote the price  but he did say the bed was in a very serious privee range. One source said that the bed cost $12,000. The headboard; covered in pink satin and lighted from behind like an eclipse, is 12 feet wide. The footboard is nine feet wide, but the mattress is a standard king. Mr. Jackson's name is popping up more and more lately. The son of a magician, he started out making sleight-of-hand furniture. One desk in his oeuvre had drawers that opened when you passed your hand over them in a special way. NoW Mr. Jackson has started a design development workshop with a number of master craftsmen at 20S West 29th Street (6953092), and he is designing everything from a new bottle for Miss von Furstenberg's new cosmetics to special effects for rock-and-roll groups. All his clients should be as happy as the princess. She tells people she likes the bed so much she wants to he buried in it.

title: Wallenda Is Killed In Fall From Wire
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 22Karl Wallcnda, patriarch of the most .amous troupe of highwire walkers in circus history, plunged to his death today when wind gusts apparently caused him to lose his balance as he tried to walk a'ong a 750-foot-long cable strung between beachfront hotels.

description: ALBANY, March 22Leaders of the Legislature sought unsuccessfully today to resolve their differences on education aid, mentalhygiene funds, state aid for abortion and other issues remaining on the budget for the state fiscal year that begins April 1. The attempt followed iatenight agreement on the outline of permanent $750 million tax reduction.

title: OPEC Ministers to Meet in April
description: VIENNA, March 22 (AP)Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries Will hold an informal meeting on April 3 in Geneva, OPEC spokesman Hamd Zaheri confirmed today. He said he could not disclose. details of the agenda for the meeting, but in earlier discussions of the sessions, it was reported that the group would discuss the weakening of the dollar.

title: Midwest Exchange in New System
description: CHICAGO, March 22 (UPI)The Midwest Stock Exchange intends to join five other securities exchanges in the Intermarket Trading System, scheduled to begin operation in April. Midwest plans to scrap its Regional Market System that links it with three other exchanges at the end of April, clearing the way for the Midwest to join I.T.S. I.T.S. and R.M.S. provide an electronic link among marketplaces so that stock orders pending on one floor can be transmitted for execution to another floor when a better price is available there.

title: Sound
description: THE EUPHORIA you felt on having bought your new stereo system may slide down somewhere between mild beWilder, mem and utter confusion after you lug it home, open the cartons and face the task of putting it all together. Take comfort: You. are not alone in tnis; which is why some of the fancier audio salons will dispatch a technician to help their clients set up their sound gear. So, if you are timid about wires and other electrical matters, it may be worthwhile to seek out a shop that provides such service. The Yellow Pages may aid your search, especially if the dealer ads display the emblem of the Institute of MO Fidelity.or the Society oil Audio CUISUitants, organizations that accredit some of the better shops. But., like doctors house calls, home visits by audio installers are getting hard to come by from discount outlets.. Lacking competent personnel, these quickturnover shopS just. hand you your purchase and from then on, you're on your own.

title: Claims Court Chief Judge Named
description: WASHINGTON, March 22 (AP)President Carter announced today that he would nominate Daniel M. Friedman, the, First Deputy Solicitor General, to be chief judge of the United States Court of Clainis, succeeding Wilson Cowen, who has retired. Mr. Carter also said he would nominate Harold H. Greene to be a district judge in the District of Columbia, succeeding John J. Sirica, who has retired. Mr. Greene is chief judge of the District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: Cattle, Hog and Pork Bellies Soar to Limits
description: All cattle, hog and pork bellies futures contracts soared to their respective limits in frenetic trading yesterday. Prices were locked into limits early and caused the pools Of unsatisfied buy orders to climb into the thousands of contracts by the close.

title: U.S. to Back Up Steel Aid Loans Of $550 Million
description: WASHINGTON, March 22The Economic Development Administration issued guidelines today for a program under which the agency could guarantee up to $550 million in loans to ailing steel companies. And Robert T. Hall, who heads the agency, promised that the program would not be used to prop up ailing companies for a few years just.to save some lobs.

description: FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., March 22 (AP)More than 5,000 civilian employees scheduled to receive reassignment notices yesterday.as part of an Army Electronic Command rorganization here were granted a onemonth extension because of procedural problems. Harry Conover, an Army spokesman, said the reassignment process was being reworKed because tne Civil Service Commission indicated some assignments. might not be proper. Under the reassignment, most of the workers will be offered a similar job at the same salary scale.

title: Stanley Johnson, 57 , A . P . Correspondent Who Covered Soviet
description: Stanley J. F. Johnson, an Associated Press reporter who was a correspondent in the Moscow bureau in the postStalin years, died yesterday in University Hospital. He was 57 years old. During the middle 1950's and early 1960's, Mr. Johnson was one of the small group of Western reporters from whom most of the newspapers and broadcasters of the United States got news of the Soviet Union.

title: Rock: Long John Baldry Returns
description: LONG JOHN BALDRY was power in English rock during the 1960's. At one time, both Rod Stewart and Julie Driscoll were his proteges, and out of his touring groups came a host of future bandleaders and sidemen. But despite some American exposure, culminating in Warner Brothers album in the early 70's, Mr. Baldry never caught on here. Nevertheless, he was back on Tuesday night, playing at the Bottom Line with a strong backup unit.

title: Notes on People
description: WHILE her fifthgrade classmates spend .their Easter holidays next week inmore prosaic ways, Amy Carter will accompany President and Mrs. Carter on their trip to Liberia, Nigeria, Venezuela, and Brazil. It's a great eaucational experience, said Mary Finch Hoyt, an aide to Rosalynn Carter. The 10-year-old Amy is a very self-sufficient young lady, said Mrs. Hoyt, and so it won't be necessary for a member of the Carters personal staff to be along on the trip to care for her. It will be Amy's first trip abroad.

description: MADRID, March 22 (Reuters)Three youths shot to death the director general of the Spanish prison system today in what appeared to be revenge for the death of an anarchist prisoner.

title: Care and Feeding Of Rosa Rugosas
description: Roses are more vulnerable than most shrubs to root competition from neighboring plants. The Rosa rugosa is tough enough to eliminate its competition, and it will do even better given a fightfree existence. That's one reason it thrives as a tUbbea terrace plant. Anotner is simply that it requires very little care on the rooftop compared to its highstrung hybrids. It is tolerant of the wind and even the breeziest terraces are rarely a hindrance to its prolific growth.. A last point in its faVor is that the wild rose is ex- tremely winterhardy, and winter decimation is. after all, probably the greatest cause of the city garden's demise.

title: British Steel Faces Severe Cutbacks To Curtail Losses
description: LONDON, March 22, (Reuters)Brilain's Labor Government today published plans for cutting down production, laying off thousands of. workers and slashing investment in an attempt to curtail the huge losses of the stateowned steel industry.

title: People and Business Chrysler Says Cuts in Bonuses Halved Executives Pay in 1977
description: The Chrysler Corporation, which posted a $50 million losS for its 1977 fourth quarter, said yesterday that despite a salary raise for its top executives last year, they received on average less than half their 1976 compensation because of a sharp cut in bonuses.

title: Treasury Notes Go at 7.56% Rate; Most. of Canadian Bonds Are Sold
description: While a move toward lower 'shortterm interest, rates earlier this week lost its drive yesterday, the Treasury sold $3 billion of twoyear notes at an average rate of 7.56 percent, down from 7.70 percent in a similar financing in February.

title: Topics
description: Still stewing about President Carter's choice of Braniff for the valuable DallasLondon route, Pan Am now blames some of its bad luck, and politics, on New Yorkers. It has decided that the President's perfidy was achieved by the ferocity of the Texas Congressional lobby and that New York's representatives, apparently ungrateful for the 12,000 Pan Am jobs in New York City, are lamentably indifferent to the needs of state enterprises. Maybe, reckons Pan Am, it ought to move deep into the heartland of the enemy; if you can't lick em, join em Houston.

description: The Koch administration said yesterday that School Chancellor Irving Anker's plan to upgrade the requirements for high school graduation was a step in the right direction, but did not go far enough.

description: LONDON, March 22 (Reuters)Twenty people died when a boat capsized on the flooded Zambezi River in the Pinda district of Mozambique, the Mozambique radio reported today. Thousands were made homeless by flooding.

title: Wild Roses Make a Comeback
description: FEW FLOWERS have had as much energy.and time lavished on their development as the rose. There ate roses cultivated for deep red luster  Masterpiece and Eutin; for instance. There are the more modehi, classic apricothued roses such as Antigua and Tropicana. There are lavishly white, yellow, pink and now even lavender specimens. There are ,roses grown as much for their fragrance as for their color, and roses that are superlative climbers to cover and cling to splitwood fences and formal trellises. There are even miniatures for Lilliputian gardens. But what about the wild rose, Rosa rugosa, the'rose that started it all?

title: Nothing Works Anymore: A Consumer's Tale
description: HAVING enjoyed a Revere whistling teakettle for years, I recently decided to treat myself to a new one. Not that the old one didn't work well. I just thought it would be nice to have one that wasn't scratched and dulled by a dozen years of use; so I bought another just like it, same brand, at a wellknown city department store. I took it home, filled it with water and waited until it boiled. No whistle. I got in the car and drove 20 miles to the suburban branch, where I got to see the assistant department manager. She graciously changed my kettle for another in sealed carton. Home again, another test. No whistle. I took back. For all I know, the assistant department manager told me, none of them whistle. She gave me a refund. I'm still using my old, scratched pot. It may look shabby, but will probably whistle long after I'm gone.

title: To Old Fans, Spring Recalls Many Seasons
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.Frank Shimsky is staying in Hallandale, going to the race track every day and hating the Yankees whenever they play. He has hated them ever since he can remember, going back to his days on 103d Street in Manhattan. Every summer he goes to Yankee Stadium 20 or 30 times and hates them even more.

title: Senate Sends Carter a. Bill Raising Mandatory Retirement Age to 70
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP)The Senate today passed and sent to the White House a bill that would raise the mandatory retirement age to 70 for most Americans and eliminate it completely for Federal employees.

title: Art: A Marriage of Freedom and Form
description: THE new drawings that Sonia. Gechtoff is currently showing at the Gloria. Cortella Gallery, 41 East 57th Street (through April 12), are at once a highly charged summary or tne GISLIIICLIVe imagery sae has lately brought to this medium, and an extension into something new. The extraordinary control that the artist brings into her drawingsa medium she virtually reinvented for her own purposesremains the same. She does the almost dreamlike evocation of light and shadow that is their special magical province. Only now there is in the latest of these drawings a new note of fluency and openness. The windows that have mainly concentrated on abstract distillations of urban twilightand still do have also been opened to the freer,, unbroken space of landscape and skyscape.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: The Two Worlds of Japanese Art the sacred and the secularmake up the new show at the Newark Museum. On the sacred side of the exhibition, which begins in the 10th century and ends 900 years later, are objects relating to Buddhismwooden statues, brush paintings, priests shawls and temple altar covers. Secular life is represented by screens, hanging scrolls, porcelains, lacquerware and, wood and metal objects used in daily life during the. 18th and 19th centuries. The exhibition, mostly display of the museum's own collections, also includes five kimonos, made of brocade or decorated with intricate embroidery, worn in the 18th and 19th centuries. Hours: noon to 5 P.M. daily (through Sept. 17). No admission charge. From New York take PATH to Newark and then the No. 23 or No. 44 bus to the museum, 49 Washington Street. Information: (201) 7336600.

In recent months, however, as auctions nave proliferated and the competition for buyers has intensified, the focus of specialization has narrowed even more.

That her birthday coin- tides with Easter this time around has nothing to do with it, nor does the fact that she must fly to Denmark on Sunday to get there in time for performances in Copenhagen next week.

title: GYULA ORTUTAY
description: BUDAPEST, March 23 (AP)Gyula Ortutay, an authority on folk tales who was Hungarian Minister of Culture from 1947 to 1950, died today, He was 68 years old.

title: Broadway
description: 'THE BIKO INQUEST, a dramatization of the death of Stephen Biko, who died a South African prison, will open at Theater Four on West 55th Street, on May 10. Mr. Biko died on Sept. 12, 1977. The inquest, which took place a month later, exonerates the south African police, despite what seemed to be a substantial amount of evidence that Mr. Biko had been severely beaten. The Biko Inquest, which is by Norman Fenton and Jon Blair, who will also direct the production, is taken word for word from the minutes of the inquest. Fritz Weaver will play Sidney Kentridge, the lawyer who represented Mr. Biko's family at the inquest.

title: Film: What Happened After 'The Other Side':In Love With a Trucker
description: AT THE END of "The Other Side of the Mountain," the 1975 movie based on the life of Jill Kinmont, Jill (Marilyn Hassett), the radiantly pretty championship skier who'd been paralyzed in a downhill accident, was coping quite beautifully with her paraplegia, with the loss of her fianc in a plane accident and with the loss of her fatherheart attack, I think. She was finding a new life as a teacher.At the start of "The Other Side of the Mountain, Part II," which opens at the Guild and other theaters today, Jill Kinmont, still played by Miss Hassett, continues not simply to cope, but to achieve. Very early on she's named Los Angeles's Woman of the Year and almost immediately meets and falls in love with handsome, sensitive John Boothe (Timothy Bottoms), a long-distance trucker who comes from her hometown of Bishop, Calif.The fact that a lot of us already know that in real life Miss Kinmont and Mr. Boothe got married creates certain difficulties for Douglas Day Stewart, who wrote the screenplay for this sequel to the extremely popular first film. The problem with "Part II" is that there is no problem.The ones that Mr. Stewart has attempted to dramatize are lugubriously unbelievable. Jill supposedly thinks of herself as a bad-luck charm"everyone I've ever loved has died"and so she puts off John. Then she tries to convince us that though they love each other, they are incompatible. "He's not interested in anything I am," she says, "not books or plays or concerts," though the Jill we see is hardly a culture-nut.The first film, directed by Larry Peerce, who also directed the spinoff, was a slickly prefabricated bathtub of movie sentimentality, at the heart of which was a gallant young woman facing real handicaps. "Part II' is really a 30-minute postscript to that story, blown up to feature-length by artificial plot problems and so many flashbacks to the first movie that the second becomes a sort of reverse trailer, a coming attraction for something that's already gone.All of the characters are so relentlessly genial that the movie comes to look like the smile on a billboard. I suppose that some interest is generated by our curiosity about the sexual lives of paraplegics, but this subject is so discreetly attended to that it seems to be another one of the film's nonproblems.Mr. Peerce's direction suggests a certain amount of desperation. You can almost hear him asking, "What can I do to make things interesting?" Sometimes characters talk to each other's backs, but mostly they just look cheery. In moments of emotional crescendo, he puts his camera on a helicopter so that it can slowly pull away from the scene in a grand manner that may or may not indicate God is taking care of things."The Other Side of the Mountain, Part II," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), indicates that before their marriage Miss Kinmont and Mr. Boothe went off on a trial honeymoon, during which they sometimes shared the some bed.

title: Deaths
description: MAZERCeil. In deepest sorrow, the American Friends of the Hebrew university expresses the shock of its officers and trustees over the death of our beloved Cell Mazer, wife of our esteemed Vice President Joseph M.Mazer and, in her own right, leader of our organization. Sharing her husband's dedication to Israel and the Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Ceil Mazer's warm personality and generous spirit brought a special note of joy and good feeling to our councils and public occasions. To our dear friend Joseph M. Mazer, and to the entire Mazer family, we extend our profound sympathy in the hope that this may provide a Medcomfort.
