title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday erroneously described the terms of merger agreement between the Security Pacific Corporation and American Finance System Inc. If the merger takes place, holders of American Finance common stock would receive $10 in market value of Security Pacific common shares. Holders of American Finance percent preferred stock would receive $25.25 a share in cash and holders of American Finance $6.75 preferred stock would receive approximately $104 share in cash. Shareholders of both classes of preferred would also receive accrued dividends. The total value of the transaction would be more than $64 million.

title: Tentative  Agreement Averts Bus Strike; Vote Due Next Week
description: MAPLEWOOD, March 23'The buses will continue to roll, Anthony Grazioso, a spokesman for Transport of New Jersey, said today as the company and the Amalgamated Transit union announced a tentative settlement on a new contract to replace one that expires at midnight tomorrow.

title: Bill Kenny, Last Surviving Member Of the Original lnkspots Group, 63
description: NEW WESTMINSTER, British Columbia, March 23 (Reuters)Bill Kenny, the last surviving member of the orginal Inkspots singing group, died today of a respiratory illness. He was 63 years old.

title: The Act Cuts Mondays
description: The Act, the Liza Minnelli musical at the Majestic Theater, will offer seven performances a week instead of the customary eight, beginning next week. Miss Minnelli requested the change be cause of the demanding nature of her role

title: Uranium Offered to Westinghouse Is Believed Useless for Weapons
description: WASHINGTON. March 23Theuranium that Was offered to he Westinghouse Electric Corporation last summer by European businessman for $288 million was apparently a form of uranium with little commercial value and with no use as an atomic weapon.

title: $76.8 Million Loss Is Shown by Conrail As Deficits Continue
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation continued to show deficits with a fourth quarter loss of $76.8 million, bringing the loss for all of 1977 to $366.6 million. In reporting its results yesterday Conrail said it did not expect an improvement in its financial performance this year.

title: Nominee for Marston's Post
description: WASHINGTON, March 23For nearly two months, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell has been gingerly trying to find a United States Attorney for Philadelphia who would not provoke another Political donnybrook. Today, after sev- eral days of speculation in the press, Mr. Bell announced that he would nominate Peter Francis Vaira, an expert on organized crime prosecution and a 10year veteran of the Department of Justice, to replace David W. Marston.

title: Deaths
description: MAZERCeil. The Officers and Staff of the National United Jewish Appeal express their profound sorrow at the untimely death of Ceil Mazer, beloved wife of our Honorary General Chairman Joseph H. Mazer. A deeply compassionate human being she always gave generously of her time and energy to help others. In her fireless efforts on behalf of the Jewish people, she helped make possible the rescue and resettlement of thousands of ws thruout the years. Always conceied with the human needs of Israel's people and with the education of Jewish youths there and here at home, she devoted her life to helping Jews around the corner and around the world. Our heartfelt condolences go to her husband Joseph and her bereaved family. We have lost a close and valued friend. Humanity has lost a wonderful human

title: Multinational Seeks Projects in Vietnam
description: BANGKOK, March 17The Eisenberg Group, a Western multinational organiza, tion specializing in investment and trading projects in developing nations, is in the advance talking stages in negotitiOns with Vietnam for a number of projects valued at $600,million.

title: Miners to Vote  Today on New Pact; Union Denies Withholding Relief
description: WASHINGTON, March 23As 160,000 striking miners prepared to vote tomorrow on the coal industry's third proposed contract, United Mine Workers officers at union headquarters here made another lastminute defense of the leadership's conduct that could affect the outcome.

title: Books: African Aftertastes
description: LAWRENCE SANDER'S newest caper is laid in a country in deepest Africa, one that is no Garden of Eden but which does have the latest guided missiles and is readying itself for a huge American oil refinery. In its heated atmosphere, THE TANGENT FACTOR. By Lawrence Sondem. 308 pages. Putnam. $9.95. the worst of human pasisions arise. unprovoked murder, treachery, cynical aggression, loveless marriages and pitiless lust for power are only a few of the human qualities that bubble to the top in this cauldron.

title: Art People
description: AFTER a lifetime in, well, nonprofit work, Nelson A. Rocksfeler, oil heir, former Vice President, Governor of New York, father of the New York State Council on the Arts and indefatigable art acquisitor, has discovered the joys of commerce. He has signed contracts with the publishing house of Alfred A.

title: Issues in Middle East Debate
description: WASHINGTON, March 23Following is a glossary of some of the issues involved in the Middle East debate:

title: 3 Nations Support a Curb On Antarctica Krill Fishing
description: A tentative agreement to protect maim oceanic resource before there has been any largescale exploitation has beep drafted at a 13nation conference in Canberra Australia The convention could become a landmark in international law.

title: Yanks Get a Leg Up on Season
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.Stretch em out! bellows the drill leader, and the players jokingly twirl their outstretched arms like wingflapping birds trying to become airborne.

title: Met May Lose `Tut Show Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to charge special groups $25 a person on Monday nights, when it is normally closed, to view next winter's Tutankhamen exhibition, a show that has drawn unprecedented crowds on a national tour. The plan might mean, however, that the museum would have to give up Federal funds earmarked to help it meet the show's expenses.

title: Logan Board, in a Move to Save Hospital, Agrees to New Officials
description: The governing board of Arthur C. Logan Hospital agreed yesterday to replace the management of the bankrupt 214bed ho.spital as part of a plan to save it from imminent liquidation.

title: Deaths
description: FITZGERALDMary J. Beloved sister of James, Beatrice, and Gertrude. Devoted aunt of James and Gerard. Reposing at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave (at 20th St) until Saturday. Blessing will be offered at the Church of Immaculate Conception, at 10am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: A Careful Choice
description: Books of The Times

title: For Children
description: THIS BERGERFOLK, will present a folk music concert for children, at 3 P.M. on Saturday, at The New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, in the Heckacher Oval, 111 Amsterdam Avenue. For Free reservations, call 7992200, extenion 237.

title: AliSpinks Rematch: N.J. Site a Possibility
description: Preliminary discussions have been held to stage the heavyweight rematch between Leon Spinks and Muhammad Ali at Giants Stadium if plans fall throug to hold the title fight in Africa.

title: Boston U. Six Defeats Wisconsin in Semifinal
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 23 (AP)Boston University got goals from John Bettie and Tony Meagher 1 minute 16 seconds apart in the second period to break a 11 tie and help the Terriers gain a 52 victory over the defending champion. Wisconsin, in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic As sociation hockey tournament.

title: William Witman 2d, ExAmbassador With 40 Years in Foreign Service
description: William Whitman 2nd, a former United States ambassador to Togo and a Foreign Service officer for nearly 40 years, died March 12 at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington, D.C., following surgery for a pulmonary illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Arlington, Va.

title: :Frogi.Wet...P041it to... Asbury Park, Spring Is Busting Out An Over.
description: For the traditionalists, there is egg rolling at the Greenburgh Nature Center. Fore those drawn to floral exotica, there is a hunt for watercress at Tibbetts Brook Park in Yonkers. But for those seeking a simple first step into spring, Westchester's parks and nature reserves are open and ready. A walk through the woods, punctuat-

title: Deaths
description: BRACKENRev. Msgr. Lawrence H. The Board of Directors and Managers of the Catholic Child Care Society of the Diocese of Brooklyn record with profound sorrow the passing of their esteemed colleague of many years. Rev. Msgr. Lawrence H. Bracken, P.A. Deepest sympathy is extended to his bereaved family.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Events and Openings
description: THE OTHER SIDE OF THE MOUNTAIN, directed by Larry Peerce; stars Jill Kinmont, Timothy bottom and Marilyn Hessen, at neighborhood theaters.

title: U.N. Wheat Conference Defers Efforts to Complete New Pact
description: GENEVA, March 23A United Nations conference agreed today to resume later this year its attempts, so far unsuccessful, to create an international pact to stabilize world trade in wheat.

title: New School Forms Its Own Ad Agency
description: The New School for Social Research, which offers an array of courses in the fastgrowing field of adult education, has decided to form its own inhouse advertising agency.

title: Pop: Bobbi Baird
description: THE program of songs that Bobbi Baird offered at Town Hall on Wednesday evening as part of the Interludes series was put together with a rare touch of imagination and balance. There was series .of adventures in which the fa. miliar frequently came dressed in the unexpected and the. less familiar was presented in a context that provided sonie point of recognition.

title: Notes on People
description: A parasite is what Britain's Princess Margaret was called in Parliament yesterday by Dennis Canavan, an antimonarchist Labor Party member. Mr. Canavan caused an uproar when he made the criticism in a question to Denis Healey, Chancellor of the Exchequer, Will the Chancellor stop all unnecessary spending for the underprivileged, including the 1,000 pounds a week we give to a parasite like Princess Margaret? he asked. The Speaker of the House, George Thomas, invoked an old Commons rule that forbids criticism of the royal family by name and directed Mr. Canavan to withdraw his derogatoiy remarks. I am sorry if I offended you, said Mr. Canavan. I withdraw it.

title: Art: Projects From Platit Forms
description: T. 0 GO STRAIGHT UP in the air was once the ambition of sculpture. The freestanding figure was indeed the very model of sculpture, just.as the vertical manthe man who kept his head high in conditions no matter how dauntingwas the very model of the hero.

title: Dollar at Another Low Against Yen
description: The dollar sank to yet another new low against the yen in Tokyo, but rose against the British pound and French franc in Europe and New York in very quiet preEaster foreignexchange trading yesterday, The Associated Press reported.

title: Reserve Report
Auto Repair Crisis Is Predicted
description: WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI)Too few automobile mechanics are qualified to handle an impending avalanche of new technology, and the result will soon be a worsening crisis for consumers seeking car repairs at a fair price, Congress was told today.

title: Yugoslays, After Rare Tour, Tell of a Primitive Cambodia
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 23 Yugoslav reporters just back from Southeast Asia have been describing a primitive land where communications often consist of messages carried between villages, where the capital's only newspaper appears three times a month and where there is no money but some prices are being fixed.

title: Italian Police Unable to Increase Officials Protection
description: ROME, March 23The Italian police had been so hard pressed even before the abduction of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro that they have not been able to increase their protection measures for Politicians and high officials.

title: After 18 Holes
description: Four under parBobby Walzel, Lou Graham. Howard Twitty.

title: Oh, for a Haldeman!
description: WASHINGTONThose of us inclined to condemn the national press corps for its growing tendency to titillate rather than inform simply haven't taken into account the severe pressure under which Washington reporters have been operating for the last year. Jimmy Carter has been playing hell with what might be called the source system and Washington journalists have been traumatized psychologically.

title: DATA REVISION SHOWS MONEY SUPPLY RISE
description: The Federal Reserve, releasing longawaited and substantial revisions in its statistics, disclosed yesterday that the nation's money supply expanded faster in 1977 and early 1978 than it reported earlier.

title: Unwed Parents: The Arrangement Seems Legitimate to Them
description: In a roomy old apartment on Central Park West, lateafternoon sunlight streams through the windows and brightens the golden down on the baby's head. She gurgles with pleasure as her mother, smiling, cuddles the child on her lap. Soon the door will burst open and the baby's equally angeliclooking 4.yearold brother will charge in, full of tales about his afternoon at a friend's house. As the last light fades over the park, their father will come home and the family will sit down to dinner.

title: Indians vs. Cuba Series Snagged
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., March 23 Inaction appears to have sidetracked the latest attempt to stage baseball games between a major league team and Cuba.

title: Byrne Found Not Guilty of Assault Charge
description: BELLEVILLE, March 23 (AP)Governor Byrne was found not guilty today of assault and battery charges lodged against him after a demonstration by opponents of the state income tax during last November's campaign.

title: Sydney C. W ragge, a Top Designer Of Women's Fashions, Dead at 70
description: Sydney C. Wragge, a leading women's fashion designer and manufacturer for more than 30 years, died last night in. Boca Raton, Fla., of cancer of the bone marrow. He was 70 years old.

title: 6 Dillon Assistants Are Asked to Resign For Using Marijuana
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 23Six assistant district attorneys in Nassau County have been asked to resign because they used marijuana, District Attorney Denis E. Dillon said today. He also said he would request the appointment of a special prosecutor to .determine whether criminal charees should be filed.

title: The Irish Playwright and His Da'
description: In common with the title character in Da (for Dad), Hugh Leonard's affectionate memory play at the Hudson Guild Theater, the playwright's own father worked for many years as a gardener for a rich family in Dublin and was pensioned off for a pittancc and a trinket (30 pairs of spectacles accidentally welded together into bulbous mass during the San Francisco earthquake).

title: OLIN AND 3 EXAIDES INDICTED ON DUMPING MERCURY IN NIAGARA
description: The Olin Corporation and three former company officials were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of concealing the dumping Of 38 tons of mercury into the Niagara River at Niagara Falls, N.Y., from 1970 to 1977.

title: Disparate Events in Capital Underline Issue of F.B.I. Curbs
description: Two disparte events in Washington this week serve to underscore an issue that is of abiding concern to millions of Americans: How is the nation to control the Federal Bureau of Investigation?

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A 16-year-old student in the Bronx was accused of killing an 11-year-old boy. The suspect, Jose Osorio, of 785 East Tremont Avenue was arrested about six hours after the body of Juan Rodriguez was found by a younger brother in the bedroom of their fiveroom apartment at 816 East 179th Street.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 24, 1978

title: Dyson, 2 Days After Report He's Running, Bows Out of a Possible Comptroller Race
description: ALBANY, March 23John S. Dyson, the State Commerce Commissioner, took himself out of the race for State Comptroller today, two days after he was first reported to be interested in running for the job.

title: Compatriots Offer Homage to Mompou
description: It all began with a planned collective interview last Tuesday with three formidable Spanish musicians, Montserrat Mall& soprano; Alicia de Larrocha, pianist, and Federaco Mompou, composerpianist. These close friends from Barcelona were going to take part in a concert of Mr. Mompou's music, as a tribute to his forthcoming 85th birthday, in Alice Tully Hall this Sunday lit 8 P.M.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Stock exchanges and commodities markets in the United States will be closed today in observance of Good Friday. Banks in New Jersey and Connecticut will also be closed, but banks in New York will remain open. Federal offices and the Postal Service will operate on a normal schedule.

title: Sales of New Cars Show 36% Advance For Latest 10 Days
description: American newcar sales in the midMarch selling period soared to their highest level so far this model year, prompting officials of the'nation's Big Four domestic automobile manufacturers to declare that their long-talked-about spring buying spree had finally begun.

title: Three Men Linked to Mobs Found Slain in Brooklyn
description: The body of a reputed organized-crime figure, once accused of extorting money from a prominent Queens nightclub owner who was later murdered, was found stuffed in the trunk of a rented car early yesterday in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn.

title: Vidal A. Tan, Former President Of University of the Philippines
description: Vidal A. Tan, a former president of the University of the Philippines, died Feb 7 at his home in Quezon City, the Philip. pines. He was 87 years old.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, MARCH 24, 1978 Prime Minister Begin called on Americans for support at the conclusion of what he called difficult talks with President Carter that failed to dispel sharp differences with Washington over Middle East issues. Mr. Begin said Israel wanted the Middle East peace offort to proceed, but he was also adamant abOut Israel's having to make new concessions on the key questions that led to the impasse in the negotiations., President Carter told membr of the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee that the diplomatic process has come to a halt. and asked for their help. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: U.S. Defense Debate Arises Over Whether Focus on Europe Neglects Other. Areas
description: WASHINGTON, March 23A major debate has broken out over the military priorities of the Carter Administration, with defense analysts in and out of government questioning whether the new emphasis on strengthening Western defenses in Europe will be at the expense of a capacity to respond to challenges in other Darts of the globe.

title: Villella May Get Arts Job
description: Edward Villella, the dancer, is under consideration by Mayor Koch for the chairmanship of the city's Commission on Cultural Affairs, the independent advisory body that helps shape municipal cultural policy. The unsalaried post was vacated last December by Martin E. Segalwho had created the job during the Beame administrationbecause he did not have the ear of the new Mayor,

title: Aiello Moves to Halt Goldin Vocational Schools Audit
description: The Board of Education yesterday took the first legal steps to stop City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin from conducting an audit of the performance and success rate of the graduates of New York citv's vocational high schools.

title: More U.N.  Units Enter Lebanon; Israel to Start Pullout Next W eek
description: TEL AVIV, March 23More elements of the United Nations peacekeeping force moved into southern Lebanon today, and Defense Minister Ezer Weizmann was quoted as having said that Israeli withdrawals would begin next week.

title: In Men's Fashions, a Late Entry Proves a Winner
description: It was one of the very last men's fashion shows of the season and it started 40 minutes late. But the audience, which was loaded with fashion world VIPs, seemed to agree that the fall collection of Jeffrey Banks was well worth the wait. For sheer volume, the collection, shown the other day, was impressive: Besides the suits, sport coats, evening clothes and topcoats that he is now designing for B. Glanzrock, Mr. Banks showed furs, shearlings, suede and leather outerwear, sweaters, shirts, ties and scarves (worn with almost everything.)

title: He Was Named for Aly, Darling
description: HIALEAH, Fla., March 23The tack boxes spaced along the shedrow at Barn AA are painted red and blue, the devil's red and deep blue of Calumet Farm's racing silks. These are the colors Whirlaway and Citation carried when they swept the Triple Crown races of 1941 and 1948. They are the colors flown by Pensive and Ponder and Hill Gail. and Iron Liege and Tim Tam when those good ones dashed home first the Kentucky Derby.

title: HENRY W. WELLS, TAUGHT LITERATURE AT COLUMBIA
description: Dr. Henry W. Wells, retired professor of English and comparative literature at Columbia University and curator of the Brander Matthews Museum there, died Wednesday in Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx. He was 83 years old and lived at 777 Kappock Street in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Around the Nation
description: RENO, March 23 (AP)A claim by two sisters that onethird of Nevada belongs to the Shoshone Indian tribe must be reconsidered by the Federal District Court here, an appeals court has ruled.

title: CurtissWright Opens Bid For Control of Kennecott
description: The CurtissWright Corporation, going ahead with its proposed plan to start proxy fight for control of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, said yesterday that it would shortly nominate a 17member slate of directors to run the giant copper company.

title: Mets Harrelson Traded to Phillies
description: ST. PETERSBURG. Fla., March 23The Old Guard of the New York Mets lost another charter member tonight when Bud Harrelson was traded to the Philadelphia Phillies for a minor league infielder and about $50,000.

title: Sweden's Economic Success Sours
description: STOCKHOLM  Sweden, a model of economic success since World War II, has come to realize that the backbone of its economy is disintegrating and the country may have entered a long period of decline.

title: Goodell Captures Freestyle
description: LONG BEACH, Calif, March 23In 1976, as a high school junior, Brian Goodell conquered the world by winning two gold medals in Olympic swimming. Tonight, as a college freshman, he conquered a new world by winning his first National Collegiate title.

title: Directorship for Mrs. Wharton
description: Directorship for Mrs. Wharton

title: Deaths
description: WEINBERG  Dr. Harold M. Aged 88. Beloved husband of Anna Masltensity Weinberg, father of Edward H.. and his wife Adele, James L., and his wife Edith and Marshall M; Grandfather of Deborah, Joel, Adam, Jed and Nina. Brother of Dora Levine, Ida Schwartz, and Miriam Hammerstein. Services Friday March 24 1978 12 o'clock noon at Riverside Chapel, 76th St & Amsterdam Ave. Family will sit Shiva at residence 860 Sth Ave., N.Y.C. March 23,24

title: A Metropolitan Guide to Spring and Easter
description: A Metropolitan Guide to Spring and Easter

title: Advertising
description: Among the hundreds of automotive executives who gathered this week for the opening today of Auto Expo New York is Alan B. Ross, vice president-advertising of Subaru of America. Naturally he used the occasion to talk about his company's latest entry into network television advertising.

title: Philharmonic: Davis Conducts Tippett
description: SIR MICHAEL TIPPETT'S The Midsummer Marriage, first staged in 1955, is an opera much discussed, and it has been recorded, but it _yet has to be given by a major organization in this city. In the meantime there is the suite .of Ritual Dances that Sir Michael ar- rangead ana tnat turns up every now and then, as it did at last night's New York Philharmonic concert. Andrew Davis, the young British conductor, was in charge.

title: Riverdell Director Says He Ordered an Inquiry in 1966
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 23Today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, a director of Riverdell Hospital testified that heconcerned about the rising number of sudden deaths at the institution in 1966had. directed the president of the hospital's medical staff to conduct an investigation that would not cast a poor light on the level of practice inc our hospital.

title: ALBANY TAX ACCORD FAVORS THE RICHER
description: ALBANY, March 23The taxcut accord reached between Governor Carey and the legislative leaders would be less generous to those earning under $50,000 than the Governor's original plan and more ,generous to those earning above $75,000, projections by the State Budget Division indicated today.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Danza Espanola No. 7, Granados; Variant. in F, Handel; Gondola Song, Mendelssohn; Excerpts from Rinaldo, Handel; Norwegian Dance No. 2, Grieg; Guitar Works, Dowland; Sinfonia in G, Bach.

title: Minneapolis Proposes Eased School Integration Plan
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March. 23Asserting that it could not meet and: maintain federally ordered quotas for further school desegregation, the Minneapolis Board of Education today submitted new plan that prescribed much less pupil shifting and included a method of voluntary desegregation proposed by parents from one school district.

title: CITY'S UNIONS REJECT A PARTIAL PAYMENT
description: New York City proposed yesterday to pay part of the cost-of-living adjustments due its workers, but municipal labor unions rejected the offer because it did not include such nonmayoralagency employees as teachers and hospital workers.

title: RobinsonHumphrey: Southeast Success
description: ATLANTAPeople don't care what we think about I.B.M. and .A.T.&T. But they do care what we think about Delta Air Lines and CocaCola.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: A NEW LEASH ON LIFE: Peering through the windows of the Chemical Bank branch at 488 Madison Avenue, passersby could see some of the pets being offered for adoption in a joint effort by the bank and the Humane Society of New York. Animals will be on display there through the end of this week, in a quest for owners.

title: Met May Lose Tut Show Aid
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to charge special groups $25 a person on Monday nights, when it is normally closed, to view next winter's Tutankhamen exhibition, a show that has drawn unprecedented crowds on a national tour. The plan might mean, however, that the museum would have to give up Federal funds earmarked to help it meet the show's expenses.

title: Press Competition Heats Up in California
description: LOS ANGELES, March 23Newspaper competition in southern California, mostly placid affair since the Times-Mirror Company and the Hearst Corporation Merged four newspapers into two here 16 years ago, has begun to heat up recently with some unusual twists.

title: French Left Accepts Giscard Offer
description: PARIS, March 23French opposition leaders, in a reversal of their customary policy of staying aloof, accepted today President Valery Giscard d'Estaing's invitation to consult with him on priorities for France before the new government is formed.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Is Off 3.1%
description: WASHINGTON. March 23The Association of American Railroads renorted today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 15.9 billion tonmileq, off 3.1 percent from the year-earlier level. Carloadings in the Same period totaled 421,047 cars, down 11 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc. reported intercity truck tonnaee rose 3.1 percent from a Year ago.

title: South Africa Releases 3 More Blacks Seized In Crackdown in October
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, March 23The South African Government today released three more of the black activists it seized in a nationwide crackdown last Oct. 19, including Dr. Nthato Molana, chairman of the Committee of 10. The committee, banned in the crack- down, was demanding selfgovernment for Soweto, the huge black township outside Johannesburg.

title: Jazz: Red Garland
description: RED GARLAND is a jazz pianist with what can be viewed, in terms of today's music, as an oldfashioned charm, He delights in tine dramatic quanties or a melody in much the way that Erroll Garner did and is as insistently, rompingly rhythmic as Mr. Garner. And, in total contrast to the jazz milieu in which he first became widely knownthe Miles Davis group of the mid1950'she is eagerly responsive to his listeners, acknowledging every display of applause with a big, sweeping bow.

title: Target Califano
description: RALEIGH, N. C., March 22Last winter the joke in this state was that Republican Senator Jesse Helms, facing a hard reelection campaign, was running against Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera of Panama, But. now that the first of the canal treaties has been ratified, everybody down here seems to be running against Joe Califano.

title: Bridge
description: One of Britain's brightest young players recently settled on this side of the Atlantic and will be based in New York City.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; Below 42d Street
description: ART (GR 34014)

title: At the Movies
description: IM in the ironic position of someone who achieved commercial success rather late life after spending years on the stage and in making quality films that no one went to see: Robert Shaw was saying  the , other day.

title: Alan Bates, Bette Midler To CoStar in The Rose
description: Alan Bates, the British actor who has scored on stage and screen both here and in England, has been signed to costar with Bette Midler in The Rose, a musical romance to be produced by Marvin Worth and Aaron Russo for 20th CenturyFox,

title: Out in the Open With Israel
description: In diplomacy, a breakdown in negotiations is usually a continuation of the bargaining by other means. Unable to compromise their disagreement, President Carter and Prime Minister Begin propose to have it out by appealing directly to the people in each other's country. The days ahead will bring some rough but unacknowledged intervention by each in the politics of the other to see whose policy buckles first under the political pressure. We believe that Mr. Carter has taken the wiser side of the argument and chosen the most responsible method pressing it upon the Israelis.

title: Dean Witter Reynolds Had Quarter Net Drop
description: Consolidated net income of Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc. for the second quarter. ended Feb. 28 plunged to $713,000, or 9 cents a share, from $4.2 million, or 86 cents a share, for the yearearlier quarter.

title: Construction Workers Take Over at a Hearing
description: Several hundred construction workers jeered and heckled yesterday at a New York State legislative hearing on the stalled Battery Park City in lower Manhattan. The legislators had virtually no control over the daylong session.

title: Lebanon Pleads for Refugee Aid to Avert Catastrophe
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon; March 23Urgent aid appeals were made today on behalf of 200,000 Lebanese and'65,000 Palestinians who have fled their homes in southern Lebanon ahead of invading Israeli troops.

title: World News Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, March 23The Atomic Energy Commission decided in 1966 to conceal a loss of nuclear materials from the public on the ground that premature disclosure could lead to sensational and probably inaccurate press reports.

title: Coast Bombing Expected to Go On Despite Arrests
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23Attacks on Government and corporate property by radical groups in the West are expected to continue despite the ,arrest Tuesday in Tacoma, Wash., of three persons believed to be the only remaining members of one underground group.

title: Lebanon Pleads for Refugee Aid to Avert Catastrophe
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 23Urgent aid appeals were made today on behalf of 200,000 Lebanese and 65,000 Palestinians who have fled their homes in southern Lebanon ahead of invading Israeli troops.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, March 23(AP)The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that the Federal Communications Commission had given it final permission to expand its Dataphone Digital Service to 42 more cities.

title: ANTIRECESS1ON PLAN AT SUMMIT MEETING URGED BY CALLAGHAN
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Prime Minister James Callaghan of Britain urged the leading industrial nations today to begin to coordinate a plan of action for adoption at an economic summit meeting in July to pull the world out of the recession in which it finds itself.

title: Deadline Extended In Dispute on Subs
description: A deadline for halting construction on 16 nuclear attack submarines has been extended two months by the General Dynamics Corporation under an. interim solution to its cost dispute with the Navy, it was announced yesterday.

title: Deaths
description: McLOUGHLINHelm, On March 22, 1978. Beloved wife of the late WilIiam. Devoted mother of William, Carol, Kevin and the late Ellen. RePosing Albert R. Conner Funeral Home, 4955 Broadway, (207 St). Funeral Mass Good Shepherd Church, Saturday 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery Dona. tions to the American Cancer Society preferred,

title: Death
description: JOHNSONRobert F., 73, Jefferson Village, Yorktown, NY, March 21, 1978. Husband of Mary McGroarty Johnson. Father of Dr. Kenneth, Warren, Alice, and Virginia Johnson, Mrs. Kaser (Mary Elaine) Singh, Mrs. Lynn (JoAnn) Peet, and Mrs. Edward (Doris) Rogers. Church blessing, Easter Vigil Saturday, March 25, 9:30 AM, St. Elizabeth Ann Seton Church, Shrub Oak. Reposing Clinton Funeral Home. 728 North Division St, Peekskill, Friday 24, 79PM.

title: Restaurants
description: IT IS doubtful that there is another restaurant in New York that enjoys a popularity more overwhelming than that of Parioli Romanissimo. From the standpoint of getting reservations, this is the most difficult restaurant we have had to review. Whenever we called, we were told reservations are taken only for 6, 8 or 10 o'clock; and to get them at 8, we found it necessary to call two and a half weeks in advance.

title: Con Ed Welders Fear APlant Job, But Company Says Work or Quit
description: The welder was explaining why he was afraid to take a temporary assignment at Consolidated Edison Company's Indian Point II nuclear plant in Buchanan, N.Y.

title: Desai Says That India May Seek an Alternative To American Atom Fuel

Ninety percent of all colleges and universities have no language requirement for admission. Fewer than a quarter of all high school students take any foreign language, a drop of 10 percent since 1965.

title: Screen: Mania's World:Swedish Drama
description: PSYCHIATRISTS are the villains of "Near and Far Away" and, as depicted by the Swedish director and co-scenarist Marianne Ahrne, they're sitting ducks. As Mania, an earnest student who works in a mental hospital, becomes more and more attached to a handsome, mute young man on her ward, her superiors notice only that there's a case of countertransference under way. Mania is gentle and loving, full of understanding and wonder, and her teachers are, by comparison, a bunch of cold, careerist dunderheads who think they can help anguished patients by prescribing sleeping pills. Small wonder, then, that the handsome young man would rather make eyes at Mania than talk to anyone else.The film, which opens today at the Cinema Studio, is ambiguous about the reasons for the young man's silence, but he seems to have made a conscious decision to stop speaking, rather than having fallen victim to some mysterious ailment. His lover, whom Mania goes to visitand of whom she is very commendably not jealoussuggests that the young man has chosen to explore the world within rather than the world without, and that sometimes actual words only get in the way of true knowledge.Mania, who has never had the good sense to change her name to anything less redolent, never emerges as more than a cardboard figure, and Lilga Kovanko plays her with a great deal of warmth but not much variety. Robert Farrant, as the mute, is sometimes afforded the camera's intensive scrutiny, sometimes used only as Mania's foil; he is often compelling, but always a little more elusive than the screenplay demands.The other actors function more as props than as characters. The story's two doctors, played by Helge Skoog and Jan Erik Lindqvist, exist only to espouse rigid attitudes and behave with improbable insensitivity, and Annicka Kronberg, playing Mania's temporary roommate, is merely someone for the heroine to talk to. Owe Stefanson, as an inmate whose specialty is demanding cigarettes from strangers who have already given him cigarettes, seems at least as interesting and troubled as the mute, but Mania is considerably less interested in befriending this much less attractive fellow.Miss Ahrne's film is carefully made and elegantly photographed, but it flows much too smoothly from one prettily austere setting to another, with no texture to catch the eye and no loose ends to hold the interest. Events proceed according to a schedule that is apparent 15 minutes into the film, and there are no real surprises in store.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Times yesterday erroneously described the terms of merger agreement between the Security Pacific Corporation and American Finance System Inc. If the merger takes place, holders of American Finance common stock would receive $10 in market value of Security Pacific common shares. Holders of American Finance percent preferred stock would receive $25.25 a share in cash and holders of American Finance $6.75 preferred stock would receive approximately $104 share in cash. Shareholders of both classes of preferred would also receive accrued dividends, The total value of the transaction would be more than $64 million.

Services will be held Friday, Mar 24, 11AM at The Riverside North Miami Beach. Interment in Mt Sinai Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Aiding a Vision in Portugal
description: When Portugal's tired dictatorship gave way to revolutionary spring four years ago, Mario Soares, the Socialist leader, held out a bold vision of the future. One of the poorest and least industrialized countries in Europe would establish democracy and join the Common Market, and thus transform itself into a modern and wellrun society. Today, Mr. Soares is Prime Min- ister of a truly democratic Portugal but its progress impeded. Political advance is frustrated by economic constraint. The difficulties are more external than domestic. For that reason, there are things the other Western nations can and should do to help.

Downstairs, the big all you can eat restaurant, which features entertainment and dancing, remains physically unchanged but is now called the New York Yankees Riverboat, a psychologically difference. that is not apt to make the place a magnet for Yankees haters or Mets fans.

title: Notes on People
description: Since Christmas, John N. Mitchell, the former Attorney General, has been out of prison on furlough, first to undergo surgery to remove an aortic aneurism in the abdomen, then to appear this week before a House subcommittee looking into allegations of South Korean influencebuying in Washington. Yesterday Mr. Mitchell, who has spent only six months inside a minimumsecurity Federal prison in connection with his one-to-four year Watergate coverup conviction, asked for and received another furlough extension. He will enter ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center in New York for orthopedic surgery to replace a hip. Mr. Mitchell, who is 64 years old, has for years suffered from degenerative arthritis.

title: The Failings of a National Test
description: The obvious and even alarming educational deficiencies of high school graduates have inspired a movement create a uniform and national series of tests of student competency. They would be offered to determine whether pupils should be promoted from one grade the next and ultimately given a diploma. The underlying idea is that neither society nor children benefit from mindless promotion and graduation of the ignorant. Poor children, especially, are cruelly deceived if they are passed through high school without the tools needed to succeed in a competitive society. The trouble with the proposed tests is that they would only accelerate the separation of youngsters into successes and failures and, what is worse, on a uniform and national scale.

Miller, the president of the United Mine Workers union, announced tonight the acceptance by a majority of the union's 160,000 striking members of .contract terms that will end the I09day strike, the longest'contnuous walkout of miners ever, on Monday morning. .

title: NEW PLANT TO CLEAN WATER FOR 8 TOWNS

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CHOICE CUTS New, quality films for family viewing aren't so easy to come by, even at Easter time. But some revival fare this weekend .ineludes worthy features that still retain appeal for youngand old. Take The Red , Balloon (1957), a delightful Frenchmade fantasy by Albert Lamorisse, depicting a small boy's ride high over the rooftops of Paris. The feature drew praise when it opened here, including an enthusiastic endorsement by Bosley Crowther of The New York Times.

title: Books of The Times
description: While no one would deny Norman Mailer's narcissism, I can think of additional reasons why he might have wished to publish a novel he wrote when he was 20 years old and that was rejected by 20 publishers at the time. If Mr. Mailer is generally regarded as one of our most important living writers, then it should be worthwhile to see how he began. A Transit to Narcissus, a facsimile printing of the original typescript, including Mr. Mailer's own handwritten revisions, serves as an anthropological picture of rather special American primitive.

A good part of the success came from the combination of Nathaniel Merrill and Robert. O'Hearn, whose direction, sets and costumes were brilliant and evocative. Also, despite the vagueness and heavy going of the libretto, there was some gorgeous Music in the opera.

title: Homegrown Berries: An OldFashioned Custom Survives
description: The berries people grow today are quite different from those grown in the 19th century, according to my long lived relatives. My great aunts, my father's sister and my mother all lived just over or just under one hundred years. In turn they heard reminiscences of ancestors whose lives overlapped theirs. They always had been well supplied with fresh native fruits they grew or picked in the wild.

title: European Invention
description: BEFORE the invasion of the Americas by European whites, the residents of the Western Hemisphere were divided into more than 2,000 cultures and even more societies. The native American peoples practiced customs and modes of life of remarkable diversity, held a great variety of beliefs and world views and spoke many languages unintelligible to one another. When Columbus made his landfall in 1992, in fact, these people had no conception of themselves  no name for themselves  as a single entity. For all practical purposes, at least, the.collectivity we call American Indians was nonexistent. Columbus, who thought he was somewhere off the Asian coast, casually referred to the natives he saw as Los Indios (India then was the name for all of Asia east of the river Indus), and the name stuck as a collective designation for all native Americans. This fateful misno. mer exemplifies the bald fact that the idea of the Indian was a white invention, and an ideological weapon of deadly effectiveness. By enabling the conquering whites to lump together under one racist stereotype all of the cultures between what is now Canada and Chile, the concept of an American Indian has been an invaluable aid in the subjugation of the people it names.

title: StarGazing Stars
description: AS the subtitle indicates, this is history in the heroic mode. Gale E. Christianson, an associate professor at Indiana State University, sets the stage with a quick survey of prescientific astronomy, encompassing paleolithic huntergatherers, stargazing Babylonians, sunworshiping Egyptians, UreeK ana Koman systematizers ana mealevai taropeon codifiers. From Aristotle through Ptolemy to St. Thomas Aquinas, the job of astronomers was to save the phenomena  to devise an intellectually satisfying scheme that accounted for all (or nearly all) the observational data.

title: ART VIEW
description: Styles in art often undergo very ,rapid changes in our culture: that is certainly obvious to even the most casual observer of the contemporary scene. What may be less apparent to the part of the art public that does not especially concern itself with such things is that styles in explaining new art alsohave their periods, as distinct from each other as Picasso's Blue Period was from his Analytical Cubism. More Often than not, styles in explanation follow closely on shifts in the Zeitgeiston the changing spirit of the times. uonvicuons about the quality of this or that artist or work of art may remain the same, but the reasons given for that conviction vary according to the intellectual climate. In periods of radical ferment,* the reasons are likely to have a radical flavor. quieter or more conservative periods, there occurs a shift something more traditional. In some respects, indeed, there appears to be less pressure on art to change today than on the literature written to explain and defend it.

title: FollowUp on The News

title: A Semester at Sea in Mystic
description: MYSTIC 'IGREW up 'n Cape Cod but came to Mystic Seaport to learn about the sea, said Dana Gaines, a Williams College student from Edeartown. Mass. The Cane is pretty touristy now and has lost its maritime flavor. Here I can meet all the seacoast types, the boat builders and oldtimers I've always wanted to get to know.

title: Conservation Units Step Up Efforts to Save East End Open Spaces
description: With Suffolk County's fannacquisition program facing political and economic snags, private land foundations are stepping up their activities to preserve open space on the East End.

title: Laurie Robin Paster Fiancee Of Lawrence M. Teitelbaum
description: Dr. and Mrs. Julius Paster of Teameek N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurie Robin Paster, to Lawrence Mace Teitelbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Teitelbaum, also of Teaneck.

title: LIVINGON THE ROAD
description: We began to get acquainted with Ruth James in 1964, in the course of our studies of the children of migrant farm workers. She was the considerably older sister of one of those children. We recall asking to talk with her one day because she had been such a strong influence on all her younger sisters and brothers. She was willing to answer our questions, but quite convinced that she had nothing to tell us. Moreover, she emphatically denied that she was, fact, doing quite a lot to bring up the family's young ones: I'm not a mother. The publichealth nurse came here to give everyone in the camp some shots, and she said I was the mother of my brothers and sisters. I told her no. How could I have kids that old and be my age? She asked how old I am. I told her, 16. She said, Anything is possible where migrants are concerned. I remember the words, each one them. I've been wondering what kind of nurse she is! And she knew my sister, the next one down from me, is 14! I bore her when I was 2!

title: Computers Redrawing Police Precincts in Queens
description: There are 2,440 miles of streets In Queens, and over the next several months the; New Yorks City Police Department will be feeding revised data on each block in the borough into the computers that are the heart of the police communications system.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: IN recent months three leading radical intellectuals  Michel Foucault, Christopher Lasch and Herbert Marcuse  have published new books that express the disenchantment of 60's writers in the grim and frivolous 70's. Although their books are very different in scale and subject, they all portray modern life as a prison or a fascist supermarket where docile consumers prowl the aisles, listening to mental Muzak piped in by the authorities, trapped in the delusion of free choice. For these writers, our advanced industrial capitalist society is a jail; our social scientists and psychiatrists are the jailers; our cultural habits and artifacts are the bars of our cells, our padded walls and tranquilizing drugs; our very thoughts even our most liberal or liberated visionsare our invisible chains.

title: A Walking Tour Through Nuremberg's Old Inner City
description: Let me tell you of a truly great city that I have learned to love to visit-focusing on an almost miraculously restored inner city, a mile in diameter, with beautiful fountains (one called the Beautiful Fountain), perhaps the best bratwurst in the world, a castle complex worthy of Prague brooding above bridges reminiscent of Florence and Venice, marvelous churches and the great Germanic Museum.

title: DINING OUT
description: NERO'S, opposite the Livingston Roller Rink, seems to be a gathering place for half of Essex County on weekends. If you want a table on a Saturday night, arrive by 6 o'clock or be prepared to wait at the bar sometimes as long as two hours. This was the advice of a Nero's patron who didn't mind the wait.

description: There is a tremendously gaudy diamond ring on the third finger of Willie Nelson's right hand, the sort of ring that Southern used-car salesmen get when they've finally landed a dealership. He

description: The Easter retail season took on rosy glow last week as reports indicated an upturn after a slow beginning. A giant retailer and a clutch of Wall Street analysts were among the redfaced, but for a very different reason. Color them embarrassed.

description: According ding to Don Nichols, next Sunday's Formula One dash through the streets of Long Beach, Calif., isn't yet on a par with some of the famous European Grand Prix races such as Monaco, Austria or Italy. But it is an important race for American teams and drivers.

States Wrestling Federation national freestyle open championships at Hofstra University.

title: Peking Offers Technical Courses For Officials of Chinese Ministries
description: PEKING, March 25 (Agence FrancePresse) - Evening classes for government ministers have opened in Peking, the official Hsinhua Press Agency reported today.

title: Interest Groups Gaining Influence At the Expense of National Parties
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The rising number and influence of groups that lobby for special causes are changing the character of the American political process, weakening the two national parties and causing the retirement of some senior members of Congress, according to elected officials and other political leaders and experts interviewed in the last few weeks.

title: A Speed Trap Close to Home
description: RENO (UPI) The police chief's wife was one of the first caught in a speed trap set up by her husband. Chief James Parker said he established a radar patrol at the request of the City Council in a 25 mile-an-hour zone. His wife, Nancy, was cited for driving 36 miles an hour.

title: What's Doing\sub}sub} Around CANTERBURY
description: INVADERS AND PILGRIMS - The Romans came and settled. Today the French pour in off the boats and stagger home with bargains. The pilgrims in Chaucer's Canterbury Tales came to Canterbury's great cathedral. So fa- mous was the journey on horseback that canter has become an everyday verb. In the cathedral, Archbishop Thomas Becket was murdered after he had opposed his king's takeover of the church. Today Original Sin is the name given to a banana covered with ice cream that is served just outside the cathedral. And yet the lure of Canterbury and the attraction of the surrounding country remain.

title: Questions/Answers
description: When is it sure to stop feeding the birds? M. V., Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: Legislators Remain Torn: To Vote Conscience or Constituency?; Death Penalty Furor Won't Go Away
description: For Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall, steadfast opponent of capital punishment, the constitutionality of the death penalty turns on the opinion an informed citizenry. Between 1972, when the Supreme Court found the death penalty as then administered unconstitutional, and 1976, 35 states enacted death penalty statutes. Even that legislative activity was not conclusive for Justice Marshall.

title: Piece of Heaven Takes Bay Shore, Pays $8 40
description: Things went swimmingly and according to plan for Sigmund Sommer's Piece of Heaven and Ruben Hernandez yesterday in the 19th running of the Bay Shore Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: Rubella Debate Divides Doctors and Lawmakers
description: HARTFORD I don't like to stick needles in these kids unless I have to, said Dr. Albert U. Peacock, an opponent of vaccination against rubella, also known as German measles.

title: Ajax: The Traffic Stopper of Rio
description: When my husband and I were transferred to Rio de Janeiro eight months ago, we did not suspect that our 150pound Great Dane, Ajax, would become such an instant sensation on the already colorful streets of the city. But Ajax has been a traffic stopper. wherever we go, whether on the crowded thoroughfares of urban Rio, or in the forsaken villages of the Brazilian interior. Furthermore, having to cope with the questions we are inevitably asked has had a very positive effect on our once halting Portuguese.

title: Half of a Suit by Cohn and Schine On McCarthy Film Dismissed
description: A New York State Supreme Court justice has dismissed half the $40 million defamation suit brought against the National Broadcasting Company over Tail Gunner Joe. the film about the late Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that NBC showed last year.

title: THE MARKETS

title: ROBERT COLES: DOCTOR OF CRISIS
description: Quietly, modestly, he has observed people in crisis situations and written about them for two decades. While he is now hailed by many as a major social critic and even a saint, he continues to wrestle with his own middleclass failings that, he feels, keep him from accomplishing more.

title: At Home and Abroad, Begin Has Much More Trouble Now
description: There may have been worse weeks In the 30year friendship of the United States and Israel, but that was no consolaticin. The best chance in decades for peace in the Middle East seemed to be fast disappearing. Two days of talks failed to budge Menachem Begin or President Carter, and their faces were grim maps as the two made their farewells. For once, said Zbigniew Brzezinski, the national security adviser, appearances are not deceiving. Not to make matters worse, the Administration decided not to issue even the usual formal statement, which would have summarized the deep disagreements.

title: Two Fly Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: T0 vary a popular saying, anybody who consults a psychiatrist oughtto have his head examined. The problem is, if we are to believe the two books under review, we may have no choice. Society, it appears, is rapidly becoming psychiatrized and, to lesser degree, psychologized. The boundaries among education, welfare, criminal justice, mental health and attitudes toward simply oddball behavior are being erased and the mentalhealth experts are taking over. The student who cannot or will not learn, the welfare recipient, the criminal, the psychologically disturbed, and even alcoholics and homosexuals and political dissidents are corning to be seen as sick people, to be cured by the magic of modern psychiatry .and psychology.

title: Miss Namuth Wed To Edward Klein
description: Tessa Suzanne Namuth, a researcher at Newsweek magazine, was married last Monday to EdwardKlein, editor of The New York Times Magazine. Judge Myles J. Lane of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: A Competitive Drive: Trucks
description: Rail executives have a recurring nightmare in which the Secretary of Transportation declares large segments of the rail system unfit for moving dangerous goods and thus diverts much of the declining industry's business to prosperous and growing truckers. And to be sure that the nightmare doesn't be- come a reality the Association of American Railroads has mounted a campaign to persuade the public that rails are safer than trucks for transporting hazardous materials.

title: The Poison We Spill at Sea
description: The Titanic, the Morro Castle, the Torrey Canyonthe names have come to symbolize not only great disasters at sea but also great leaps forward in maritime safety. Now we must add the Amoco Cadiz to the list.

title: FILM VIEW
description: In Dustin Hoffman's new film, Straight Time, there's scene in which Mr. Hoffman, who plays an edgy, self-destructive excon, is in an automobile on a Los Angeles freeway with his parole officer, a portly, alternately sadistic and patronizing slob. The scene slowly builds a smashing climax in which the excon seizes control the car, pulls it over to the side of the road and leaves the parole officer. his pants pulled down around the ankles, hand- cuffed to a fence. It's a funny, scarifying scene, breathlessly staged. It's emotionally satisfying for the way in which the underdogthe exconturns the tables on his tormentor and it owes a great deal to Ulu Grosbard, the director, as well to Mr. Hoffman, whose performance makes an otherwise downbeat film sometimes exhilarating.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: In Victorian England the lower depths of great houses contained an extraordinary number of servants. This entertaining (and sometimes horrifying) picture-cum-text book de-scribes the lives of these multitudinous downstairs people and the inhuman amount of work expected of them in the big houses of noblemen. Here, too, are accounts of the customary trio of servants (cook, parlormaid and housemaid) employed by the middle classes. For these overworked maids, books were written, such as Hints to Young Women About to Enter Service, in which the Christian message was used to make good servants: . . . rest assured of this, that we can never be truly happy or comfortable in this world, til God gives usgrace not only to submit to the position in which He has placed us, but to be heartily contented and thank-

title: Behind the Sayisms and Smilisms
description: DURING the remarkable Presidential campaign of Jimmy Carter, journalists assigned him observed a candidate who seemed to rule his political life from an emotional cloister, the walls of which no reporter was able to penetrate. They came to Know his caretully designed campaign style, but the boys and girls on the bus who rode behind him, use Timothy Crouse's phrase, never got to know the man from Plains. They observed and reported on his disingenuous rhetoric, his parabolic symbols and his constant smile. But they were never able to nail down who or what he was.

title: New York Held Only State to Fail to Regain Job Loss

title: `As a People Live, So Do They Sing
description: mong the fascinating things we've learned is that in world songs, the repetition of text decreases and wordiness increases in direct relation to the economic productivity of culture. We've also discovered that orchestral complexity is an index of political complexity in any given culture. Other aspects of performance style have also been found to be reliable indicators of social structureof the feminine role of social solidarity, for example, or of sexual mores, of stratification and much more. The fact is, we can now roughly predict the basic social structure of culture frorti a cantometrics profile of its singing style, and we see that one of the main functions of song is a reinforcement of the social continuity of its culture: As a people live, so do they sing!

title: Arts  and Leisure Guide
description: Mummenschanz, a troupe of three mimes who appear as anything from mere blobs to caterpillars to humanoids, opened what was to be a three-and-a-half week engagement at the Bijou on Broadway last March 30. Popular and critical opinions, however, wouldn't hear of a closing, so that the troupe was given an openended run. On Thursday, Mummenschanz celebrates its first anniversary with a special program. The original Swiss trio (Andres Bossard, Floriana Frassetto and Bernie Schurch), who have been on national tour, will join with the present cast (Dominique Weibel, James Greiner and Louis Gilbert) for the birthday performance. Swiss chocolate cake and hot chocolate will be served free at intermission and after the show. (See Theater)

title: Flowers On a Jade Plant? Easy Does It.
description: Our first jade plant purchased in December, 1963 began as a fourinch rooted cutting. Today, it is 56 inches high with a trunk 13 inches in cir cumference. This year marked its third year for blooming. In fact cuttings taken from it in September or October bloom concurrently with the mother plant starting in November. The mother plant's flowers continue into March. While each cluster of tiny white flowers is small, the individual flower is lovely and the overall effect impressive.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox
description: Isn't it about time that the basketball powers-that-be revised the archaic rule regarding personal fouls? When the sport was basically a shooting game, the regulation that eliminated a player from a contest after he committed certain number Of fouls, was a reasonable one. However, today's game, with its continuous body contact and rapid movement, places too much responsibility in the hands of the officials. Dozens of borderline calls are made in every game, and any one of thes6 questionable decisions could rsult in the disqualification of a key ,player, thus affecting the outcome of the game disproportinately.

title: L.I.R.R STRIKE SAID TO SEEM INEVITABLE
description: MINEOLA, L.I., March 25With less than a week remaining before a strike deadline, the head of the 1,400member Long Island Rail Road Trainmen's Union said yesterday that Governor Carey's refusal to intervene in the stalled contract negotiations between the union and the railroad appears to make a walkout inevitable.

title: How to Found A Company And Lose Sleep
description: For years, out of that wellknown, persistent feeling that life was going by, that wasn't accomplishing anything, I had dreamed of starting a theater. Surely, to be a generating source for worthwhile projects, to see them through from beeinnine to endto have a choice- that would be satisfying. Then, one night, I was rereading Brecht's The Life of Galileo. Early on, Galileo says, Yes, I am dissatisfiedand that's what you should be paying me for. I'm dissatisfied with myself.. .. I'm 46 years old, and I've never accomplished anything that satisfied me!

title: `This Show Is About The Sheer Joy Of Dancing
description: BOSTON The house lights were up in Boston's Colonial Theater and the audience had begun filing out through the baroque spendor of the lobby into the snowheaped streets. The curtain was up, too, and several people were clustered onstage comparing clipboards. They glanced toward the wings as a patter of applause broke out at the rear of the house, where a few theatergoers had recognized the slight, bearded figure making his way across the stage to join the group. Bob Fosse, whose Dancin  they had just seen, acknowledged their salute with a halfembarrassed wave before joining the clipboard holders. A couple of things, he said, and they began taking notes. A transition between dances had been too slow (It's got to go one, two 1) and some instrumentation hadn't been clear (I couldn't hear the woodblocks at all). There were other problems. A rehearsal was set for the next day.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Part 2. Among the folk who make their living by spinning American dreams, no credo is more cherished than this: One gstod dream deserves another. title: Vermont Cheese: For Seeing as Well as Eating
description: A week after still another storm delighted skiers and drove others mad in New England, my two younger daughters, aged 9 and 12, and I slipped our crosscountry skis into the back of our car and set off for Vermont. My wife, who would have prepared Metter Tor such an excursion, was away for the week; all I took along in the way of food was a loaf of French bread and a handful of apples and oranges and nutsspartan supplies that I figured could be made into something resembling a ski lunch with the addition of a few wedges of Vermont cheddar, bought, of course, in a Vermont general store. As it turned out, we found more interesting places to buy our cheesethe small factories that produce it.

title: At Home: Au Revoir, Au Pair Despair
description: 0 NE of the institutions I hold responsible for undermining the American family is the school system. When they so changed the curriculum that it became impossible for parents to help their children with their homework, we lost one of our last opportunities to win their gratitude and resnect. The new math was bad enough, but when my 13-year-old son asked me to help him with an essay in which he had been enjoined to avoid all pronouns, I could see that things had indeed passed beyond my comprehension. I'm not sure I can survive in a world without pronouns.

title: Her Life As a Rebel
description: WILL the women's movement survive its novelists? This question seems urgent in the wake of Alix Kates Shulman's new novel, Burning Questions. Mrs. Shulman has undertaken to write not merely another of those vaguely fictionalized chronicles about 1 he inchoate misery of a housewife-and-mother who finds her tongue and her freedom from patriarchal oppression after joining a consciousnessraising group; no, Mrs. Shulman aspires loftier deeds than personal confession. With the story of a feminist leader who calls herself Zane IndiAnna (because she comes from Indiana), an early convert to women's liberation in the 1960's, she hopes to capture the apotheosis of radical feminism, an instructive exemplar who will be no less than the Representative Woman of our revolutionary times.

title: Amin Invites Carter to Uganda To See There Is No Mass Killing
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 25 (UPI)President Idi Amin of Uganda, saying he loves President Carter like a brother, today invited Mr, Carter to visit Uganda and see for himself that there have been no mass killings.

title: Ideas for Making a City Livable In Winter Assayed in Minnesota
description: WAYZATA, Minn., March 23In 1885, a New York journalist visiting nearby St. Paul described Minnesota as another Siberiaunfit for human habitation. The city was outraged and one of its newspaper editors retorted: The winter Atmosphere of Minnesota Is so dry, so pure, so clear and so bright that it is a privilege to live in it. It builds healthy, hearty men and women and develops the gentler traits and expands the heart and intellect.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Somebody asked the other day why Merce Cunningham stages the special category of programs he calls Events. By way of reply, it didn't do any good to define an Event as an intermissionless collage of entire Cunningham dance pieces or sections of his'new and old, works. Nor did it do any good to go on about how such unconventional structuresconsisting of choreographic fragments not meant originally to combinedwere in line with Mr. Cunningham's general esthetic of exploring new possibilities of movement and perception. The question remained: If Merce Cunningham could still produce a major individual repertory dance work such Inlets, which had its East Coast premiere in Massachusetts this month, then why did he want to do Events?

title: The World

Burns, The New York Times correspondent in southern Africa. about their fears and hopes for themselves and the country in light of the internal settlement reached by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith acrd three black leaders r this month. The fou were Edward SuttonPryce. member of the rightwing Rhodesian Action Party; Kenneth Mew, principal Of Ranche House College. multiracial adult education center in Salisbury;. Leslie Holland, marketing manager for the .Salisbury Bottling Company, and Diana Mitchell, a principal figure in the National Unifying Force, o liberal group that is urging inclusion of the Patriotic Front, a guerrilla organization, in a Rhodesian settlement. On this page are excerpts of the conversation, which took place at Meikles Hotel in Salisbury.

title: THE ADVENT OF THE LASER AGE
description: It was early in the 21st century when the last trickle of oil ran out. But by this time America was ready. In Washington, D.C., the President pushed a button that turned on a thin sliver of intense light and directed it at a capsule containing form of hydrogen extracted from sea water. Laser Generator No. Ithe first American laser power plantwas on stream, replacing the last great oilfed electric power station.

title: CRIME
description: How's this for a situation? A kidnapping goes sour, and a rich boy and his guard are held as hostages. The police encircling the house in a posh London area are stalemated. In the house there is a black mamba, the deadliest of African snakes. The boy had ordered a harmless snake as a pet, but the shipment got mixed up, and now the monster is loose, ready to strike. The criminals know about this little extraneous factor. So do the police. But what is to be done?

title: Genetic Messages
description: To most of us, the initials DNA have an unfamiliar, even menacing ring, although, as Franklin H. Portugal and Jack S. Cohen write in A Century of DNA, Friedrich Miescher began the study DNA in 1869 at the German university of Tubingen by isolating a substance from human pus cells that he called nuclein. Only within the last 25 years has it been established that DNA's strings of sugar and phosphate, linked by small compounds called adenine, guanine, cytosine and thymine, carry the basic information of heredity  an idea as culturally unsettling as Einstein's theory of relativity or the concept of an exploding universe. The scientific facts about DNA have only reached the schoolroom during the last 20 years, making it one of those subjects  such as rockets to the moon or Mars, or ultraminiature computer circuitry  that divide people over 90 from their children.

title: A Day With Housing Inspectors

title: A Rare Look At Yugoslav Art
description: BROOKVILLE THE exhibition of Naive Art in Yugoslavia at the C.W. Post Art Gallery is a happy revelation that marks a special occasion. Since this is the first time these pamungs and tiellIpLUreti nave Men displayed in this part of the United States, Most of us are being introduced to Yugoslavia of extraordinary historical significance and esthetic accomplishment. The works brilliantly reaffirm the notion that nave art can be as resourceful and as exciting as any other art form.

title: I MET A TRAVELLER
description: What happens when a bright, articulate 11-year-old Jewish American Princess finds herself living in Jerusalem because her beautiful and unconventional artistmother has taken an Israeli lover? Will Josie Hayden experience terror as she lives through the fearful weeks of the Yom Kippur War? Will she ap- preciate America more as she learns the life stories of the Russian immigrants she befriends? Will she develop an awareness of the joys and burdens of being a Jew? Will her contact with Arabs, Jews and Christians help her develop politically? Or, as she feels the first stirrings of womanhood, will she gain some insights into the problems of competing with a sexually liberated mother who is selfish, childlike and shallow?

title: The Great Divide.
description: Now it's all over but the revving up for next time. Last Friday, more than half the 160,000 men who dig 50 percent of the nation's coal glumly voted to ratify the third contract they'd been presented with during 17 weeks of strike. The most remarkable thing about it all was that the national sense of urgency about the consequences of a continued walkout had evaporated.

title: Novels and Stories
description: Amid the ugly, interminable violence of Northern Ireland, Jennifer Johnston's second novel attempts to raise the simple voice of humanity. A quiet subtext to the melodramatic headlines, shrill political rhetoric and sentimental songs, it focuses on Joe Logan. a lonely I2-year-old Cathu- lic boy who daydreams at school and secretly writes poetry. While his father, disabled in the Irish civil war, lies in bed praising his own past and pitying his present life, Joe's mother does menial work to support the family. Her hope is to keep Joe off the streets and out of the Movement, which has already crippled her husband and brought her older boy, Brendan, back from a steady job in England.

But regardless of how they start, after first photographic possibilities have been exhaustedpictures of family and friends, and travel photographs made on vacationmany of these budding photographers start looking for new worlds to conquer.

title: Lightning Kills Carolina Mayor
description: MORGANTON, N.C., March 25 (AP)The Mayor of Lexington, N.C., was killed last night and four persons were injured when lightning struck a campsite where 18 campers were sleeping. The Mayor, Harry Vernon Anderson Jr., 45 years old, and most of the other campers from three family groups were huddled under a tarpaulin seeking shelter from a rainstorm, the police said. The group was on an outing in the Mount Jonas Ridge area of Burke County, about 20 miles northwest of here.

title: Keeping the Peace in South Lebanon
description: In all the years of United Nations peacekeeping operations, no force has had a more difficult assignment than the bluehelmeted units now moving into South Lebanon. The 4,000 troops from half a dozen nations who will be patrolling the strip of Lebanese territory north or the Israeli border will have the same mission as the United Nations contingents on the IsraeliSyrian border or in the Sinai: to separate hostile forces. But unlike the two other border zones, South Lebanon is the scene of an ongoing conflict.

title: Headliners
description: Karl Wallenda, founder and patriarch of the Great Wallendas, the most famous troupe of wirewalkers in circus history, fell 100 feet to his death from a tightrope stretched between two beachfront hotels in San Juan, P.R. Mr. Wallenda had seen a son-in-law and a nephew die in the act in 1962, and another son-in-law in 1972, but in both cases he carried on with a career which, according to circus historians, was the longest on record. He was 73  four years older than the current American life expectancy for newborn white males.

title: Audrey Paula Saal Marriid
description: Audrey Paula Saal, daughter of Mrs. Jack Saal of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and the late Mr. Saal, was married yesterday to Eugene Wolotsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hyman Wolotsky also of Mount Vernon. The ceremony was performed in the Huntington (LI.) Towne House by Rabbi Joseph Chait. The bride is a marketing analyst with the CBS Inc. Her husband is a specialeducation teacher . at Mount Vernon High School. His father is associate to the provost and dean of the faculties at the Bank Street College of Education and his mother is assistant to the dean of the School of Social Work of Hunter College.

description: SAILING TODAY

title: Flames 6, Bruins 3
description: ATLANTA, March 25 (AP)Guy Chouinard and Harold Phillipoff each scored a pair of goals to power the Atlanta Flames to a 63 victory over Boston tonight, snapping the Bruins sixgame winning streak. The triumph clinched a playoff spot for the Flames, who will enter postseason play for the fourth time in their six years in the league.

title: Detroiters Back Diggs Despite Indictment
description: DETROIT, March 25Charlie Diggs in trouble with the law, but not with the voters of his downtown 13th Congressional District.

title: RISE IN FOOD PRICES_ STAYS AT HIGH LEVEI:, FOR A SECOND MONTH
description: WASHINGTON, March 25Food price increases last month came close to the uncomfortably large rise in January, according to preliminary samples for the February Consumer Price Index, to be disclosed Tuesday.
