title: Over The Alps On Foot And Skis
description: Cuckoos were singing on the roofs of the chalets and cows, sheep and goats were grazing in green meadows when my friend Eric and I, with a guide and two porters, left Zermatt in Switzerland on a golden morning in May. Though we walked through the valley kneedeep in wild flowers, we all wore ski clothes, for we were bound for the glaciers of the Haute Route on a sixday trek over the Alps to Chamonix in France.

title: The. Talented and the Brave Go to a Birthday Party
description: About 1 A.M., Rocky Converse, Who lived in Hollywood for many years as Mrs. Gary Cooper, surveyed the scene in the upstairs sanctum at Regine's.

title: MUSIC  VIEW
description: Zubin Mehta, the new music director of the New York Philharmonic, officially takes charge Sept. 14, when he will conduct his opening concert at Avery Fisher Hall. Mr. Mehta is a big name music, but his work really is not very well known here. He has conducted at the Metropolitan Opera, and he has made several guest appearances nereabouts, but few of us on this side of the country have been exposed to his Ideas or his personality to any great extent. Thus, it is with more than normal interest that music lovers are going to be examining the 197879 Philharmonic programs, which have just been released.

title: Hofstra Bows in Lacrosse
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., March 25Hofstra lost its home opener in lacrosse today to Virginia, 1511. The Cavaliers, fourthranked in the nation, led at halftime, 98. Virginia was led by Tom Holman, from Garden City, L.I., who scored five goals. Hofstra's Keith Huff scored three goals and Mike Fowler had five assists.

title: Chinese Report New Sheep Variety;
description: HONG KONG, March 25 (Reuters)Chinese herdsmen have produced a new breed of sheep that yields black lustrous: wool, the Hsishua press agency reported, today. The new breed, developed In Sinkiang Autonomous Region, is reported to be able to endure drought and heat.

title: Opera: Die Frau Ohne Schatten
description: The Metropolitan Opera first presented Die Frau ohne Schatten by Richard Strauss in 1966. To almost everybody's surprise that example of StraussHofmannsthal symbolism turned out to be the hit of the season.

title: Shedding New Light on Operas At the Metropolitan
description: When reviewing an opera, critics discuss the relative merits of principal singers, the conductor and the dramatic impact of the production as a matter of course. But when the critics take notice of the lightingand on a fairly regular basis, at thatthen something significant is happening in the control room. This has been the case at the Metropolitan Opera since December, 1976, when Gil Wechsler joined the staff as the Met's first fulltime lighting designer. Whether creating the atmosphere required for John Dexter's stark production of Dialogues of the Carmelites, freshening up the lighting plots of older productions such as the Don Giovanni that was televised 10 days ago, or creating the magic inherent in spectacular productions like Die Frau ohne Schatten, Mr. Wechsler's work has elicited the praise of patrons and critics alike.

title: Lasker, Ex-Head of Stock Exchange, Picked by Christian and Jewish Unit
description: Bernard J. Lasker, a senior partner in the stock brokerage firm of Lasker, Stone & Stern and a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has been elected national Jewish cochairman of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

title: With Spice, Without Meat
description: She and her husband, Sastri, are bOth from Andhra Pradesh, the state in southern India of which Hyderabad is the capital, and, like the majority of people of that region, they are vegetarians.

title: JoAnne R. Decker Engaged
description: Marie B. Ellis of Highlands, N. J., and John R. Decker of Port Washington, LI., have announced the engagement of their daughter, JoAnne Rogers

title: Its Success Depends on the Will of the Combatants
description: UNITED NATIONS  United Nations peacekeeping forces cannot make peace, they can only keep it so long as the combatants let them. At best, they provide a breathing space for resolution of the differences that caused the fighting, at worst, an excuse for the rest of the world to forget the crisis until the shooting starts all over again.

title: Rough Deal
description: THE. art of painting rarely, if ever, makes frontpage news because of its intrinsic esthetic interest. Only when it becomes attached to other, more compelling interests  money, power, celebrity, crime, personal scandal and violent death  does,. painting and the artists who produce it attain headline, status; something has to go drastically wrong for the artist in order for art to become big news.

title: Charles Madison Sarratt, Dean Of Alumni at Vanderbilt University
description: Charles Madison Sarratt, vice chancellor emeritus and dean of alnuil at Vanderbilt University, died Friday at a hospital in Nashville, Tenn. He had resided on the university campus for most of his life. Mr. Sarratt was 89 years old and had been actively associated with Vanderbilt for more than 60 years.

description: TRENTON

title: Premier Theater To Reopen May
description: TARRYTOWN

title: DINING OUT
description: DEER PARK has a heavy concentration fastfood chains and proportionately fewer traditional restaurants. That may be reason enough to recommend Vintage House in the Deer Park Motor Inn. In addition, I have received number of readers suggestions that I review it. Any recommendation would be geograpnicai rawer than gastronomical, because while complete dinners are moderately priced, the food is only passable.

title: Editors Choice
description: DULLES, by Leonard Mosley. (Dial /James Wade, $12.95.) Biography of Eisenhower Secretary of State John Foster, C.I.A. director Allen and their sister, Eleanor Dulles, who ran the Berlin desk at the State Department.

title: Cairo's Traffic: Cars and. Sheep In a Blue Haze
description: CAIRO, March 25The driver or & black and white Fiat taxi weaving through the Cairo traffic boasted to his passenger that he had learned to drive in the army. As an afterthought, he added that he had wound up his military service behind bars for having run down a dozen pedestrians with his army truck.

title: Leslie Ellen Gerwin Fiancee of Physician
description: The engagement of Leslie Ellen Gerwin, daughter of Beverly A. Gerwin of Encino, Calif., and the late Nathan Gerwin, to Dr. Bruce Robert Leslie of Boston, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen H. Leslie of New York, has been announced.

title: Segregation Found Still Widespread
description: EGREGATION of black families in the New York metropolitan area continues to be widespread, according to a recent report to the Tristate Regional Planning ComMission.

title: Parents Stake Claims on Day Camps
description: DESPITE the passing winter's icy temperatures and persistent snows, the summer camping season has begun. It started with a trickle of brochures in January, burst into a blizzard of questions and phone calls in February, and will be in full flower through April when Westchester parents meet directors, visit camp sites, and make the final decisions about where to send their youngsters for the summer. .

title: Province in Pakistan Increases Penalty for Drinking to 6 Months
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, March 25 (Reuters) Moslems who are found drinking alcohol will face a sentence of up to six months in prison and a $500 fine under a new ordinance published here.

title: Britain Decides How to Spend Its Oil Largesse: Aid for Aging Industry
description: A study on how the income from North Sea oil should be spent was released by the British Government last week, and its conclusions were clearly designed to reassure businessmen that the unique opportunity, as the report put it, would not be frittered away.

title: GARDENING
description: The role of small accents in the creation of a garden is not always well understood. Standard landscape plantings of'rhododendrons, Colorado blue spruce and a flowering dogwood or two are easily and inexpensively individualized by such effective additions as a single clematis vine on a lamppost, or a drift of varicolored primulas beneath the dogwood tree. (They will bloom while the tree's flowers are still in bud.)

title: Lacrosse Pets A Special Day
description: MANHASSET, LI., March 25Richie Moran, the lacrosse coach at Cornell, came home to Long Island yesterday.

title: Rally for Bhutto Held in Dacca
description: DACCA, Bangladesh, March 25 (AP)Members of the proChinese National Awarni Party demonstrated in front of the Pakistani Embassy to protest the death sentence passed on ZuHiker All Bhutto, Pakistan's former Prime Minister.

title: The Facts, Ma'am
description: JON Tuska's The Detective in Hollywood, like his The Filming of the West last year, represents a large yet curiously modest attempt to write the history of a movies genre, The author's pro- logue is packed with disclaimers: My exposure to detective fiction has been desultory on the whole. I possess nothing like the encyclopedic knowledge of so many who talked with me in my various travels as was putting this book together.... Some rather eminent critics have recently undertaken to approach this form of creative endeavor with metaphysical or sociological implications. I confess I am not up to it. . . . I do not know, as I have said, all there is to know of the subject of detective fiction; and certainly I would remark the same about detective films. ... I do not arrogate to myself the assumption critics must make, that I am able to best determine what was good cinema and what was not, which films are worth watching, and which ones are best left neglected. . . .

title: HOME CLINIC
description: ALTHOUGH stairs that creak squeak every time they are stepped on are great for sound effects on a television show, they can be a nuisance to the homeownerand they can be an indication loose treads (the part you step on) or risers (the vertical pieces that the treads rest on), a condition that should ? ? ? ? ?

title: IN BRIEF
description: Spring came in like a lion: The CurtissWright Corporation, as expected, has locked horns with the management of the Kennecott Copper Corporation in a battle for control of the nation's leading copper producer. The year's first major corporate struggle pits the $309million-a-year nuclear and aerospace company based in New Jersey against the $977-million-a-year Kennecott company in a proxy battle to elect Kennecott's 17member board. CurtissWright, with a 9.9 percent stake in the copper company, feels that the $567 million Kennecott spent to acquire the Carborundum Company should rightlyhave been used to directly benefit Kennecott shareholders, and has indicated that if successful, it would sell Carborundum and make the proceeds available to Kennecott stockholders. Kennecott, in defense, has filed suit in New York to block Curtiss Wright's solicitation of proxies, while in Utah, where Kennecott is a major employer, state securities officials won an order temporarily barring CurtissWright from voting its Kennecott interest at the May 2 annual meeting in New York, soliciting proxies or buying any more Kennecott stock.. .. The dispute between the Navy and the General Dynamics Corporation over the price of nuclear submarines, on the other hand, appeared headed for a settlement. Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, announced that General Dynamics had decided to continue work on the subs, a job that employs almost 14,000 workers, after the Navy agreed to make an immediate provisional cash payment to ameliorate the drag on General Dynamics's fis nances caused by cost overruns.

title: Calamities and Continuities
description: THE names of many of the writers whose work discussed in this collection of critical essays will be familiar to anyone seriously interested in modern European literature. Among them are Mandelstam, Kafka, Walter Benjamin, Nabokov and Hermann Broch. Mr. Alter also writes about some less wellknown figures, such as Tchernichovsky, S.Y. Agnon and Lea Goldberg, who were driven to Pales. tine, or chose to make their homes there, and contrib. uted to the renascence of Hebrew literature. Finally, he reflects on the achievements and predicaments some of the younger Israeli writers, as well as those several American Jewish authors.

title: Security Means Life
description: WASHINGTONFrom the vastness of a great nation stretching from ocean to ocean, bordered north and south by friendly neighbors and allies, it is difficult for us to understand security in others terms. Economically. socially, militarily and politically, we are the most secure nation on earth. But from this secure base, can we also empathize with a nation whose vulnerability stands in stark contrast?

title: Unemployment: Uncle Sam Got It Wrong
description: JULIUS SHISKIN is the United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, an able economist and a dedicated public servant. But on New Jersey unemployment, Julius Shiskin is dead wrong.

title: Robert Welborn to Marry Caryl Bartelman on May
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. .Raymond C. Bartelman of Hinsdale, Ill., of the engagement of their daughter, Caryl Ann Bartelman, to Robert Michael Welborn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Welborn of Mountainside, N.J. The wedding is planned for May 20.

title: DINING OUT; A Changeable Value; The Willow Inn (Buffet) The Willow Inn (Dinner)
description: THE Willow Inn is, in effect, two restaurants, both domiciled in the same converted country house. The first appears on Thursday and Sunday nights, and offers an informal buffet with a wide assortment of appealing platters. The emphasis is on fish and seafood. The buffet dinner is so inexpensive it can be labeled a bargain.

title: Swiss Are the Most Thrifty
description: GENEVA, March 25 (Reuters)  The Swiss are the most thrifty people in the world, with an average of over $8,000 each in the bank, according to the International Savings Bank Institute here . A report issued this week by the institute, which represents banks and savings institutions in 55 countries, said that Americans, with an average of $3,781, were fourth, after the Japanese and the Belgians.

title: 7 Die in Chicago House Fire,
description: CHICAGO, March 25 (Reuters)Five children were among seven people who died today when fire destroyed a home On the city's South Side, the police said. The bodies of the children, 5 to 13 years old, were found in a bedroom. The bodies of a woman and a man were found In another bedroom. The children and the woman had the surname Hampton. The family relationships were not immediately known, nor was the cause of the fire.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: YOU can go home again. That is, if the essence of the town is youyour flesh and blood, your meat and drink, your ichor, your ambrosiaall inwrought in your memory, eternal, immutable.

description: AMERICAN parts makers and service station owners are increasingly vying with importedcar dealers in supplying service and parts to the owners of foreign cars.

title: Film: 'Word Is Out' Documentary:Twenty-six Homosexuals Are Interviewed on Lives
description: Most of the 26 homosexual men and women interviewed in "Word Is Out" are photographed at home, and a couple of their homes look alike. A curvaceous blond woman, with teased hair and bright blue eyeshadow and little earrings, sits flanked by photographs of her children in a suburban living room; another woman, who seems to be a man until she identifies herself as a mother, appears in a similar setting. As it later turns out, these two people are ensconced on the very same sofa, and they have been lovers for nine years, ever since they were introduced by their neighborhood Avon lady.One of the most appealing things about this graceful, funny and often very moving documentary, now at the Eastside Cinema, is its altogether disarming presentation of material that might have invited prejudice or misunderstanding; in this case, what could have been a titillating revelation is artfully molded into nothing more than a wry and tender little surprise. "Word Is Out," made by the Mariposa Film Group, is comfortably constructed and quite informative, but what really carries the film is its casual seductiveness. Even filmgoers who imagine they'd rather sit through root canal work than find out what it's like to be homosexual may wind up unexpectedly captivated by the film's friendly, even-handed approach to a potentially divisive subject."Word Is Out" is at times extremely romantic, full of people gently reminiscing about what it was like to fall in love for the first time. And, as befits its romantic spirit (and its obvious desire to appeal to filmgoers of all sexual persuasions), the movie leaves sex to the imagination. One woman, who stridently announces herself to be a black lesbian (and who sits before a stained-glass window bearing a combined feminist and black power logo), simply talks about the way she gradually found herself looking forward to lunch dates with a particular woman friend much more enthusiastically than she awaited her dates with men in the evening.A man wistfully describes an adolescent crush that blossomed into a 10-year love affair. And another man, a student, remembers being so thrilled by someone who brushed against his knee as they watched Part Three of Kenneth Clark's "Civilisation" series that he eagerly dashed back to catch Parts Four and Five.The film's most stirring sequence involves a young man who dated the same girl for years but never felt adequate to the situation. Then he had a quick homosexual experience; still, the earth failed to move. Finally, he met a man he could really care about. "When I was in high school, I thought I was one of those cold people who could never love anybody," he says quietly. "And when I fell in love with this guy, it meant so much to me. It meant I was a real person . . . I was using a part of myself that I never felt before . . . and the best part, too." At a preview screening of "Word Is Out," there wasn't a dry eye in the house after that particular revelation.Much of the film is laced with humor: a hefty comedienne recalls joining the WAC's, marching into the mess hall and hearing cries of "Good god, Elizabeth, here comes another one!" One fellow in makeup and a nose ring complains that "toy stores are sexist, so you have to buy the Ken doll and then go over to Barbie's department to get a tutu."Most of the interviewees are quite appealing, but a few of them aren't, and that's one of the film's most refreshing aspects. One man, an actor who endlessly congratulates himself for being "weird," would be a bit grating under any circumstances. The film simply presents him as part of a very broad spectrum, and the lack of any insistence upon gay supremacy or solidarity leaves the viewer quite free to draw his or her own conclusions.The people presented here range from their 20's to their 70's, from being almost overbearingly articulate to communicating mostly through facial gestures, from being extroverted and affectionate to feeling isolated and private. The one thing they seem to have in commonsomething that makes the film particularly attractiveis a kind of confidence and certainty, the ability to speak matter-of-factly and behave with firm conviction.

title: Coal Industry Problems Expected o Persist Long After Mines Open
description: WASHINGTON, March 25The shortterm effects of the United Mine Workers strike, ended with the signing of a new contract tonight, are not expected to he serious, Government officials said today.

title: Kidnappers in Italy Report Trial of Moro Under Way
description: ROME, March 25Terrorists belonging to the Red Brigades announced today that they had started a people's trial of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, whom they kidnapped nine days ago. in an ambush that killed his five police bodyguards. The terrorists made their statement in a message sent to newspapers in three Italian cities.

title: Carter Names Dominican Envoy
description: WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP)President Carter announced today that he would nominate Robert L. Yost, a Deputy Inspector General at the State Department, to, be United States Ambassador to the Dominican Republic. Mr. Yost, 55 years old, would replace Robert A. Hurwitch, who has resigned. Mr. Yost, who entered the Foreign Service in 1946 in Spain, was Ambassador to Burundi from 1972 to 1974.

title: Swift and Cranky
description: THE jacket of this first collection of essays by Fran Lebowitz looks like the engine of the Santa Fe Super Chief that used to bring witty writers to Los Angeles, where they would get desalinized they didn't get back East fast. I used to think that maybe there was something in the New York air that made people funny in this fast, mean way. There was a sort of bias cut to the attitude  you wanted to throw your arms around their very crankiness. And you knew they hated that. Even some of them who were not writers were funny. Miss Lebowitz is irresistibly cranky. She is a writer. She is not a wise guy, not a dinnerparty shortstop. She is almost famous for her columns, The Lebowitz Report in Mademoiselle and I Cover the Waterfront in Andy Warhol's Interview magazine.

title: Deaths
description: SOKOLOFOr Orrin Dwight, Beloved husband of Rickl. Devoted son of Lawrence & Stella Sokoto? and deer brother of Dr Myles Sokoto! & Jo. netball. Funeral services today at 10AM from Boulevard Perk West in Hewiltt NY

title: POINTS OF VIEW
description: There has been considerable concern over excessive growth of reserves in the banking system and the fact that the money supply has not responded to, such growth. But the fact is that, while the Federal Reserve System, can influence moneymarket interest rates and bank reserves within a very short time span, the impact of its actions on variables, such as the money supply takes place over a much longer period.

title: BRIDGE
description: Some unusual events at the bridge table have the appearance of setting a record but there may be no way to prove the point. What, for example, is the biggest trick differential achieved by two declarers nlaving the same contract?

title: Penguins 2, Red Wings
description: PITTSBURGH, March 25 (UPI)Blair Chapman scored on his own rebound at 13:11 of the third period tonight to give the Pittsburgh Penguins a 22 tie with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: The Orpheus Ensemble Has No Conductor to Blame
description: disgruntled maestro once defined an orchestra as one hundred musicians working togetheragainst the conductor. The Or Apheus Chamber Ensemble, which will present an allMozart program at Carnegie Hall tomorrow evening with pianist Peter Serkin as guest soloist, is a group of 25 young musicians working together without a conductorby choiceand this aspect of their performances has always generated special interest.

title: F .B.I
description: WASHINGTON, March 25A figure in Cleveland crime. circles was murdered last fall after alleged members of an organized crime family in that city obtained information from Federal Bureau of Investigation files indicating that he had been a Government informer, Justice Department sources have confirmed.

title: Rail Disasters Spur Crackdown
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  On the morning after his railroad's seventh derailment in three weeks; Gerald L. Nichols, general manager of the Louisville and Nashville, sat in his office, answering telephone calls from Federal investigators: They have begun a finetooth inspection of the entire L.& N. system, followine a tankcar explosion last month in Waverly, Tem., that cost 15 lives. Between calls, Mr. Nichols was directing the cleanup of the latest derailment, the tension showing in his face.

title: Dr. Justine Meehan And Dr. Daniel Carr Plan a Fall Wedding
description: Dr. Justine Mary Meehan, who serving an internship in internal medicine at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, and Dr. Daniel Barry Carr, a resident in internal medicine there, plan to be married in the fall.

title: Special Sights Around Washington
description: As a native Washingtonian, I love my city with a civic passion. A deep personal pride sweeps over me whenever show a firsttime visitor the majestic grace of the Capitol dome, or the democratic simplicity of the White House, or that sacred spot, the Lincoln Memorial best seen late at night when Lincoln is alone with his thoughts. Then, after my visitors have seen these essential sights, I like to share with them three of my most favored places that are not on the usual sightseeing tours. One has a profound spiritual meaning for me; one is blatantly military, one represents pure luxury.

title: TypeCast in Fine Tradition of Art
description: 'GEORGIA O'KEEFFE is one of the most widely acclaimed art books in more than 20 years. Published in 1976 and priced at $75, it has sold well over 22,000 conies.

title: The Region
description: Labor negotiations, in their early stages, inescapably dwell on rites and rituals, and last week's talks between the city and the Transport Workers Union had the usual display of hot tempers and cooler second thoughts. Yet the threat is quite real, with the deadline less than a week away, that city, transit services could come to a halt.

title: `Virginia Opera Canceled
description: Next Wednesday's performance of Mercadante's Virginia at Carnegie Hall by the Opera Orchestra of New York has been canceled because of the illness of Montserrat Caballe. The ?O- prano was to have sung the title role. Persons holding tickets for the performance may get refunds by mailing tliem to the Opera Orchestra of New York, 10 East 53d Street, New York, gy. 10022 and enclosing a self-addressed. stamped envelope.

description: How come?

title: MALL IN MASSACHUSETTS TO PROCEED. AS SCHEDULED
description: BOSTON, March 25 (AP)Although Mayor Theodore E. Dimauro of Springfield and Mayor Ernest E. Proulx of Holyoke discussed alternatives to a $20 million shopping mall in Holyoke with Gov. Michael S. Dukakis yesterday, the construction will proceed as scheduled.

title: Weaver and His Miracles
description: MIAMI, March 25Earl Weaver said yes, his plani for the annual miracle were all in line. There are a lot of good people out there, he said, nodding toward the playing field. He said that when a team won 97 games you didn't start tearing it apart.. He said the ,Orioles would open the baseball season with approximately the same players who raced the Yankees and Red Sox through 161 ga mes last summer and wound up tied with Boston for second place.

title: PEOPLE
description: Gloom at the top: Chrysler, the nation's No. 3 automaker, said last week that, based on its profit performance in 1977, bonuses for its top executives were reduced substantially. Their salaries, however, went up in spite of the $50 million loss the company recorded for the fourth quarter of last year.

title: Federal Jury Finds for Berkey in Antitrust Case
description: A Federal court jury in Manhattan voted Berkey Photo Inc. $37.6 million in damages last week in a monopoly case against the Eastman Kodak Company. The award, which under antitrust laws will be trebled by the court to $113 mil- lion, raises questions about whether big companies must give their competitors early warning of products they are about to introduce.

title: Received Ideas
description: DONALD DAVIE is a poet and critic, in that order, if we take him at his word. Insistent upon the poetry, he has always offered his criticism as a rhetoric in the service of. poetry in general and his own poems in particular.. An Englishman by birth one heart, he writes UMW poetry on tue assumption that poems truly indicate the state of a nation: styles are cultural symptoms. So he keeps in touch with public issues by finding them concealed or trans- formed in poems, and construing them in literary and moral terms.

title: Lowest Traffic Death Rate
description: CONCORD, N.H., March 25 (AP)New Hampshire recorded the lowest highway traffic death rate in its history in 1977, according to state statistics. The state registered a fatality rate of 2,6 for each 100 million miles traveled, compared with a national rate of 3.3.

title: The World,
description: After all the maneuverings by Rhodesia's 263,000 whites to prevent a transfer of power to the 6.7 million blacks, last week's swearinghi of an interim multiracial Government didn't seem quite yeal.

A long shot, True Statement, finished second and the favored Silver Series was third, five lengths behind the winner.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Backward
description: FIRSTPERSON narrators, darting their sidelong glances, jotting their notes on shirt cuffs, claim to be participants but often seem to be lying. If they weren't there, all we would miss is the report; the events themselves would go on anyhow. Which doesn't necessarily weaken the story. What seems to matter, in the long run, is not Mir much the narrator affects the plot, but how much the plot affects the narrator.

title: Toronto Curbs Sex District After Murder of Boy
description: TORONTO, March 25A sexmurder trial whose details kept this city absorbed for more than a month has ended with the conviction of three men and the acauittal of a fourth.

description: There's a story, one I prefer not to think apochryphal, about Arturo Toscanini conducting a rehearsal and becoming gradually unsettled by single musician who tended to anticipate a particular beat. At length, and in a rage, the Maestro threw down his baton, fixed his ferocious eye the offender, and roared Every then and now, maybebut always, my God, never!

description: William Satire's excellent account of the firing of former Federal prosecutor David Marston ('The Philadelphia Story, Feb. 19) brings to the foreground a question Americans have been asking since the inception of our political system: When will justice stop making a mockery of itself and truly triumph? The answer is the same now as it always has been: whenever elected officials stop viewing it in terms of political consequences rather than in terms of their responsibility to execute real justice. And those who want to see what this highquality combat looked like can catch it on television exactly five months from now, on Aug. 26.

title: The Whistler and the Caption Vetarans of Phone Fixing
description: Oddly enough, one of the redoubtable phone freaks of yesterday now works for. A.T.&T; Joe (The Whistler) Engressia, blind since birth, has perfect pitch. He can whistle the 2,600- cycle tone used by blue boxes to make longdistance callsfree. Blue box tones must be, within 2 percent of accuracy to succeed, and their owners used to call up The Whistler and have him tune their .boxes by ear. Mr. Engressia that since the

description: TONIGHT

title: BEGIN'S PEACE STAND UNANIMOUSLY BACKED BY ISRAEL'S CABINET
description: JERUSALEM, March 26Prime Minister Menachem Begin received unanimous endorsement from his Cabinet today on proposals for a Middle East settlement that have placed him sharply at odds with the views of President Carter.

title: Pop by the Sylvers, BrothersSisters Act
description: THE SYLVERS have been triply blessed. To begin with, they are a cute brothers and sisters act. Secondly, they have been given some superior and extremely commer- cial material to record  Boogie Fever for example. And thirdly, they have been enjoying a new rush of popularity since some of their music figured in the soundtrack for the most successful movie of the moment, Saturday Night Fever.

title: Jewish Group Urges Rights Action
description: MIAMI, March 26 (AP)The American Jewish Congress, holding its national convention here today, announced that it would not meet again in Florida until the state approved the Federal equal rignts amendment. The congress, witn 500 delegates at this meeting, thus joins several other national organizations that have declared they will not meet in states where the legislatures oppose the amendment.

title: Eliot Feld Ballet Set  For a Broadway Season
description: The Eliot Feld Ballet will perform in its first Broadway season from April 10 through April 23 at the Plymouth Theater. The company will appear un- -der-the aegis of the Shubert Organization, marking that theatrical producer's first presentation of a major ballet company.

title: ShortTerm Rates in U.S. Decline Because of Weak Dollar Overseas
description: Despite many projections of higher interest rates this year, some key shortterm interest rates have declined substantially from midJanuary to midMarch. The decline, which has both surprised and bolstered the bond market, has been caused chiefly by the weak dollar.

title: Second Park and Ride Facility Is Being Opened for Commuters
description: New York City's second park and ride facility for Manhattanbound commuters will be opened this morning in Queens at Shea Stadium, where the parking field was expanded to 1,500 spaces for the purpose. The field is adjacent to the Willets Point station of the IRT Flushing line, No. 7.

title: The Art of Being Kissinger
description: One explanation of why the State Department has rejected a portrait of Henry Kissinger is that it didn't quite capture his character. Another is that he thought it made him look somewhat short. Whatever the reasons for the rejection, there remains a variety ways to proceed.

title: One Man Had a Dream so Harlem Has a Black Museum
description: After 25 years of working in antiques stores, boutiques, restaurants, answering services and in many other jobs he held while building. his collection, Thomas F. Moore finally unveiled his dream yesterday.

title: Jane B. Beltzer, Student, Is Bride of Adrian Mecz
description: Jane B, Beltzer and Adrian Mecz, seniors at the. Albany Law School, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Beltzer of Troy, N. Y. Mr. Mecz is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Leopold Mecz of New York. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Mordecai Kieffer of Temole BethEl in Troy.

title: Miss Evert Easily Tops Mrs. King
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 26 (UPI)Chris Evert, nearing the peak of her game in only her second tournament following a fourmonth layoff, routed Billie Jean King, 60, 64, today to win a $100,000, event on the women's tennis tour.

title: An Air Force Inquiry On Drugs Criticized
description: DENVER, March 24A secret Air Force investigation of narcotics use and alleged espionage at an intelligence base has led to charges of a witch hunt, a service inquiry into the methods employed by its Office of Special Investigation and a strong Defense Department rebuke.

description: WASHINGTON, March 26 (AP)Jerome Kurtz, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, said today that taxpayers using the shortform 1040A return were making fewer errors this year, a testimonial to Government efforts to simplify taxfiling chores.

title: Sporting Gear
description: A good way to develop stronger leg muscles and reduce the likelihood of knee injuries is with the LegLift Exerciser. You sit in the chair and place padded roller bars across your ankles. A cable runs from the bars axle to iron weights behind the seat, As you rais,e and lower your legs, you lift and lower the weight behind you. For $150 you can get the whole system except the weights, and for $30 you can get just the bars and the cable, which you can connect to a chair or a table. Available from the manufacturer, Olympia Sports, 745 State Circle, Ann Arbor, Mich. 48104.

More than 60 members of the Robison family gathered at 59th Street and Fifth Avenue to protest against the imprisonment and harassment that they said their relatives were suffering in the Soviet Union.

description: A mother and her 4-year-old daughter were found dead in a bathtub in their Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning. The police had no immediate cause of the deaths and ordered autopsies.

title: Mayas of Guatemala Live a Bleak Life as Migrant Workers
description: EL BAUL, GuatemalaSmoke curled out of the opensided huts where the Indian women gossiped quietly as they prepared the corn and beans that their men would eat when they tramped back from a 10hour day cutting sugar cane. Barefoot, children in traditional costumes shouted in the Quiche language as they played among the paltry belongings left hanging from the rafters by the migrant workers. Watching the scene in silence, three young men sharpened their machetes until each sang like a violin.

And how could you not smile if served tea from a pearly white teapot that played a lyrical Bach gavotte as it poured?

Fire Inspector Dave Dallas said that the blaze was being investigated as a possible arson. The dead were identified, by the police as Caroline Necco and her sons,. Mike, 16 years old, and Tony, 9. title: Argentine Junta Marks Takeover
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 27 (Reuters)Argentina's ruling military junta marked two years in power today and said civilians would play an .increasingly important part in running the country. There are only two civilians in the national Government. Provincial governments, municipalities, state companies and unions are run by military officers, put into power after the junta overthrew President Maria Estela Peron.

title: Tel Aviv Zoo Puzzled By Collapse of Giraffe
description: TEL AVIV, March 27 (AP)Nobody knows what's wrong with Shlomo, giraffe at the Tel Aviv Zoo. He has collapsed and seems to be unable to get up. Unless his keepers get him back on his feet, he may die.

description: WASHINGTON, March 27The White House issued a statement today acknowledging that members of Congress are holding direct discussions with the White House on the formulation of a national health Insurance policy.

title: L.I.R.R. Union to Ask Lifting of Strike Ban
description: Representatives of the United Transportation Union are to appear in Federal Court in Brooklyn today in an effort to have the court lift a temporary restraining order against a strike on the Long Island Rail Road.

description: The New York Rangers, stacking up victories over weak and ailing teams, continued a threeweek playoff surge last night with a 52 victory over the St. Louis Blues at the Garden and took a 7point lead in their race with the Pittsburgh Penguins for a wildcard berth.

title: Murray Vernon Funeral Set
description: A funeral mass for Murray Vernon, hoard chairman and chief executive officer from 1955 to 1963 of the old Jacob Ruppert Brewery in Manhattan, will he held at 11 A.M; tomorrow in St, Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Vernon, who was 82 years old, died Sunday. Hp was also a founder and board chairman from 1917 to 1968 of S.E.&M. Vernon Inc., a major manufacturer of stationery products in Elizabeth, N.J. Since 1968 he was board chairman of Murvern Enterprises Inc., an investment holding company in Greenwich.

title: ,Record Number Of WornenEnter Divinity Schools
description: Women are enrolling in divinity schools in record numbers, but they are pursuing more diversified careers than male ministerial students, in part because they choose to do so and in part because.of a lack of jobs open to women ministers.

title: G.M. Agrees to Fine for Using Wrong Pollution Control Parts
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)The General Motors Corporation has agreed to pay a $170,000 fine for installing wrong pollution control parts on 5,826 cars, the Justice Department announced today.

description: Harold L. Malakoff, retired president of the Cities Service Research and Development Company, died yesterday in his home at 1404 Outlook Drive, Mountainside, N. J., after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.

description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (Reuters)The State Department said today that Rhodesia's internal agreement on majority rule was illegal as well as seriously inadequate.

Justice Frank S. Samansky, 70, Long on the State Supreme Court
description: Justice Frank S. Samansky of State Supreme Court died Sunday at his home in Brooklyn. The judge, who was 70 years old, had been ill earlier this year, but returned to the bench two weeks no.

title: Madison Group Fighting Plan to Develop Old Dodge Estate
description: MADISONFor months, residents of this Morris County community have been speculating anout the future of the estate of Geraldine Rockefeller Dodge.

title: Those Extra-High-Power Lines
description: New extra-high-voltage power lines will soon traverse more than 200 miles of upstate New York. The lines will be carried on steel towers up to 174 feet high, spaced at quartermile intervals, In bad weather, they may glow, and crackle like bacon frying. One line is al- ready being built by the State Power Authority between the Canadian border and a point near Utica; another proposed by two utilities to run from Monroe to Oswego Counties; some 1,400 miles of these 765kiloyolt lines are already operating in other states. Utilitie prize them for their efficiency, but .many of the People who live near them fear their electric and magnetic fields. One farmer has suggested they might fry birds in midair.

title: AIR FORCE IS STUDYING POSSIBLE MISSILE SITES
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (AP)The Air Force said today- that iris looking at sites in 10 Western states as possible bases for the nation's first mobile landbased intercontinental ballistic missile system.

description: MOSCOW,. March 27 (Reuters)Members of the Supreme Soviet received visiting American Congressmen in the Kremlin today and criticized American proposals to deploy neutron bombs in Europe, members of the group said.

title: Councilman Wright On Trial on Charges In $5,000 Kickback
description: City Councilman Samuel D. Wright went on trial yesterday on extortion and conspiracy charges in connection with an alleged 55,000 kickback he sought and received in 1973.

LOUIS, March 27 In explaining his 41 points in Kentucky's 9488 victory for the National Collegiate basketball championship tonight, Jack Givens wondered why Mike Gminski, the 6-foot-II-inch Duke .center, had not gone out near the foul line to defend against his shots from that area.

title: Bridge:

title: 'Sylphide' Opens Beacon's Ballet Film Series
description: The Beacon Theater opens what it calls the First Ballet Film Festival today with an unusual, potentially controversial, film version of the 19th-century Romantic ballet "La Sylphide."The three-week series will alternate five different programs. If some of the ballets on camera have been seen in New York before, most of the actual films have not. The "Sylphide," for instance, is a Paris Opra Ballet production that attempts to go back to the original 1832 French version, although the production consistently presented in the United States has been the 1836 version from Denmark by August Bournonville.Tomorrow, the Beacon will present two films made by a West German television producer shortly after the New York City Ballet's 1972 Stravinsky Festival, one of which is George Balanchine's "Pulcinella" from that festival. The other is the City Ballet in Mr. Balanchine's "Liebeslieder Walzer." Thursday brings in Alicia Alonso's "Giselle" with the National Ballet of Cuba. The 1964 film, starring Miss Alonso, was seen at a gala for the New York Public Library's Dance Collection but has not had general release in New York.The other two films are a 1967 view of the Bolshoi Ballet and the previously distributed and very successful filmed version of Rudolf Nureyev's production of "Don Quixote" for the Australian Ballet.Meanwhile, we have "La Sylphide," starring Ghislaine Thesmar and Michael Denard, both of whom will appear live on stage at the theater tonight in a precurtain pas de deux. Miss Thesmar's husband, the choreographer Pierre Lacotte, first tried to reconstruct the original "Sylphide" in a production for French television in 1971. Presumably this is the same film. In 1972, the Paris Opra Ballet transferred the production to its stage.If we are to believe the rather inaccurate handout provided by the Beacon, Mr. Lacotte discovered a long-lost notation of some of the original choreography by Philippe Taglioni and much of the original score by Jean Schneitzhoeffer in an attic belonging to a godchild of the son of Marie Taglioni, who created the title role March 12, 1832 in Paris. Because modern audiences have been familiar only with totally new choreographic versions or the 1836 Bournonville recension with a score by the Danish composer Hermann Lowenskjold, Mr. Lacotte's attempted reconstruction is, of course, of great interest.Alas. It is so stylistically and dramatically out of kilter with what we know about Romantic ballet in general and "La Sylphide" in particular that it is difficult to have confidence in the authenticity of the choreography itself.The story and the structure are identical to the Bournonville versionthe Taglioni version survived into Petipa's day in Russia. In this film version, James, a Scottish farmer, is still torn between his fiance, Effie (Laurance Nerval), and the sylphide; a woodland spirit.Yet here, so wrongly, the sylph is made to appear no different from the mortals around her. The crucial distinction, that she wears toe shoes while Effie and her friends do not, is not maintained. All are on pointe.Repeatedly, James gathers her in his arms and partners her while the dramatic point is that she must die at the human's touch. In Act I, a strangely modern pas de trois, in full Antony Tudor psychological style, shows James interchangeably partnering the two women in his life.Stylistically, of course, 19th-century Romantic ballerinas could not turn so quickly on their toes or keep their legs up so high. Nor did the man have such bravura dancing. What Mr. Lacotte has done is not try to replicate authentic style, but possibly to give us some of Taglioni's choreography. His Sylphide certainly darts around much more than her Bournonville counterpart, and she works harder, too. This film is worth seeing for every balletomane precisely because it is so wrong-headed.

A company spokesman said the multimilliondollar twomonth conversion, expected to get under way June 5 , is designed to meet rcord demand for Jeep vehicles and it not a response to poor sales of A.M.C. passenger cars.

description: MANILA, March 27 (AP)A hand grenade exploded yesterday inside the grounds of President Ferdinand E. Marcos summer residence, but no one was hurt, officials said. Mrs. Marcos had planned to visit the vacation home in Baguio, 120 miles north of Manila, but canceled the trip at the last minute, officials said.

title: Market Place

title: Orpheus, Conductorless Orchestra
description: Orpheus made its Carnegie Hall debut last night. Not the Orpheus Chamber Orchestra or something like that. Just plain Orpheus. This is a group of 26 musicians who formed a chamber orchestra in 1972, and since then have gone it alone, without even a conductor. It is a coop group in which all members have an equal say about programs, soloists, tours and everything that pertains to the operation. Even the program notes are Orpheus-derived; they were written by William Purvis, who plays horn, in the orchestra.

title: The Economic Scene

title: Egyptians Still Back Peace Move But Wonder How It Can Proceed
description: CAIRO, March 27  The fighting in Lebanon has left Egyptians, whether on the official or private level, with no clear idea of how President Anwar elSadat's peace initiative, which has been stalled for two months, can proceed.

The United States Parks Service, taking over administration of the museum from the city, plans new programs and exhibits in addition to the renovations.

The People's Development Corporation, a housing rehabilitation group in the South Bronx, thinks so. The corporation has just received a half-million-dollar grant from two Federal departmentsLabor, and Housing and Urban Developmentto hire and train some 60 jobless youngsters for community improvement projects.

title: What MiddleClass Tuition Squeeze?
description: Judging by the mail, our editorials challenging the need for expanded Federal aid for middleclass students touched a nerve. Many readers are convinced that rising college costs are squeezing out the children of middleincome families in favor of the rich, who can afford to pay what they must, and the poor, who are eligible for Government scholarships.. If college is to remain accessible to the majority, they argue, Uncle Sam will have to help more by granting tuition tax credits to all.

title: Kentucky's Tortured Champions
description: ST. LOUIS, March 28Out on the court his Kentucky players were cutting down the nets as mementos of the National Collegiate basketball championship. But the Wild cats coach, Joe B. Hall, in his navy blue threepiece suit, had walked back into the stands to embrace his family and shake hands with some rooters with blue and white buttons. He's the greatest, one of the Kentucky rooters was saying now as the coach returned to the court for the presentation sere monies. He's the greatest coach there is. But a stranger asked the rooter what he would have thought of Joe B. Hall if Kentucky had lost to Duke last night. I, the rooter replied, would have cut his throat. Or perhaps Joe B. Hall would have cut his own throat. Sadly, that's the aura that Kentucky basketball projects. Before the championship game, Joe B. Hall had talked of how this had been a season without celebration because of the burden of being No. 1 in the wireservice polls and of being expected to win the title. New Jersey in January and February will cost insurance companies $169 million, the American Insurance Association said yesterday. Wilfred Perry, a vice president of the association, said that 260,000 claims, a record, were filed by New Jerseyans for damages between Jan. S and Feb. 8.

title: Notes on People
description: THE Vatican announced yesterday that Pope Paul VI, after twoweek bout with influenza, had recovered sufficiently to hold two general audiences today. One is scheduled in St. Peter's Basilica and the other in the Hall of Audiences, adjacent to the Vatican. The Pope usually holds single Wednesday general audience, but two are to be held today because of the many pilgrims in Rome for the Easter holidays. The Pope had to cancel all Easter Week activities because of his illness, but did celebrate mass on Sunday in St. Peter's Square.

title: The Cities: A Sound, if Modest, Policy
description: Of all the tasks the Carter Administration has set for itself, none seemed more difficult than the effort fashion a national urban policy. The underlying question can be asked politely: Could the Administration address the real and urgent needs of the decaying urban present without committing itself imprudently to the uncertainties of the urban .future?. Or it can be asked more cynically: Could, the Administration satisfy mayors, minorities and other heavily Democratic supporters of cities if it had little or no new money to spend? Now the much delayed national urban policy has been issued and the questions have their initial answers.

title: Film: 'First Time,' Comic Memoir by Berri
description: BENEATH the rather sunny 16-year-old exterior of Claude Langmann (Alain Cohen), there are raging the lusts of a rather sunny, 16-year-old boy who has made do, until now, with girlie magazines, saucy novels by such as Boris Vians ("I Spit on Your Grave") and the occasional attentions of a slow-witted male cousin named Leon. "I'd have preferred a girl cousin," Claude tells us matter-of-factly on the soundtrack, "but I didn't have any choice."There is nothing wrong with Claude that time and heterosexual experience won't see him safely through, which is the subject of "The First Time," Claude Berri's latest comic memoir about growing up healthy, bright, sensitive and generally happy, to become eventually Claude Berri, the successful, funny and infinitely generous French film maker."The First Time" picks up the story of the same Claude, also played by Mr. Cohen, in Mr. Berri's first film, "The Two of Us" (1968), about the film maker's experiences during the German occupation, when he was a little boy and was sent from Paris to live in the country with a crusty, wheezing old anti-Semite, played by Michael Simon.Mr. Berri's use of autobiographical material, as well as his continuing relationship with Mr. Cohen as his surrogate screen self, inevitably recalls Franois Truffaut's Antoine Doinel films in which Jean-Pierre Laud, as Antoine, has gown before our eyes from adolescence to manhood. There is a major difference between the work of the two directors, though. Mr. Truffaut's comedies are illuminated by a kind of madness, an awareness of ultimate despair. They are the work of the permanent outsider, someone who will never feel quite at home in the bourgeois society he thinks he admires.Mr. Berri's films, including "Marry Me, Marry Me," which is the story of Claude as a young man, are obviously the work of someone who feels completely at home, a fellow whose family ties are emotionally secure in ways that will forever elude the poor, obsessed Antoine."The First Time," which opens today at the Columbia 2 Theater, is all about sex  about Claude's disastrous first encounter with a woman for pay, then about his more successful encounters with girls his own age  yet the mood is so gentle, so understanding, so optimistic, the film has the air of pure fantasy. This may be exactly what the director and writer intended, yet I prefer Mr. Berri in a somewhat less benign frame of mind, as he was in "Male of the Century," in which Claude had grown into an impossibly arrogant  and hilarious  male chauvinist.Though Mr. Cohen is comically serious and charming as the young Claude, Charles Denner, who plays his furrier-father, gives the film its real substance. The straight, no-nonsense relationship between the father and the son is the nicest thing about the movie. Also it's often funnier, in that it is more surprising, than the catalogue of Claude's encounters with women.These are clever and, considering the unsuccessful nature of some, amazingly serene. It's as if, in looking back, Mr. Berri cannot bring himself to fake melodramatic crises when heand weknow that, after all, everything turned out all right.

title: Private Lives
description: IT IS a tradition. Every year at my daughter's'0;birthday party, somebody gets burned byi the, boiling vegetable oil that seems to be necessary in order to achieve the charred chunks of beef we are fondueing. This is tolerable if the victim is a child, because children ought to be burned if they insist on waving their fondue forks around in the air, and stabbing one another, like a gaggle of gluesniffing pirates. This is not, however, tolerable if the victim is a faller. But I am getting ahead of myself, and I'm too tired to keep up.

title: When Separate Is Equal
description: Some 13.000 students at Brigham Young University Provo, Utah, live off. campus. Landlords who wish rent to them must sign an agreement with the university, a Mormon institution, to separate the sexes by building or wing. Two years ago, a nonstudent sought to .rent an apartment in one of these approved buildings, only to discover that it was reserved for males. She sued, and when the suit was dismissed on technical grounds, the Department of Housing and Urban Development referred her complaint to the civil rights office the Justice Department. Now Justice has put the university and 36 landlords on notice that their rules violate an amendment to the Federal Housing Act which prohibits landlords from refusing to rent to any person because of sex. The Justice Department charge does not distinguish between students and nonstudents.

description: High school and the years immediately after are often considered crucial and turbulent times for American youth, but according to an eightyear study by University of Michigan social scientists these times do not significantly alter a young person's personal insights or outlook on life.

title: Coast New Town amiliar Look
description: IRVLNE, Calif.What appears to be a sprawling Tudorstyle house is set behind a wide lawn in West Yale Loop here, and next to it is an equally large house in more or less Spanish colonial style. A big house inspired by New England architecture is next. and so on down the street. It could be Beverly Hills, but for one catch. These are not .singlefamily houses. There are two and sometimes three mailboxes in front of each building, because these estates are two or three separate houses joined in a single building. Every detail, down to the placement of only one door in the front and the other entrances otf to the side, is designed to give the impression that West Yale Loop is a street of huge estates.

title: About Real Estate
description: FORT LEE, N. J.For four years every traveler over the George Washington Bridge could see two tall skeletons of unfinished apartment houses on the Fort Lee horizon, lasting evidence of the national construction debacle or 1974. On each one a crane perched at the 30thfloor level, immobile, until recently, since the day that work stopped.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Far be it from me to say that the chic straw handbags Bloomingclaie's will unveil the end of this week are copies. No such thing. They are just inspired by, and look a lot like, the very chic straw handbags designed by Fernando Sanchez. Ifthis irritates Mr. Sanchez, he may get some small consolation from knowjng that usually only good designs get knocked off. Such is the price of talent, and the penalty of originality. The bags, in taupe and oxblood shades, sometimes trimmed with black, come in three sizes and shapes. The small size is $23, the medium $27 and the large $32. Look on the main floor, wherever they put the handbags that day.

title: Topics
description: When Chief Justice Warren E. Burger agrees with Judges David L. Bazelon and J. Skelly Wright, his former colleagues on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, it's news. But agree they did the other day when Judge Bazelon, the evercontroversial Chief Judge of that court, stepped aside so that Judge Wright. his equally colorful ally on the liberal wing, could assume the chief judgeship of what may be the nation's secondranking tribunal after the Supreme Court. The Chief Justice, temporarily putting aside years of judicial feuding, expressed satisfaction that he and Judge Wright will be working closely on court business while Judge Bazelon will continue his regular judicial duties.

title: TV. 'A.E.S.', Hospital Comedy
description: AS A.E.S. HUDSON ST. Is a new weekly series, on ABC Thursdays at 9:30 P.M., it must, suppose, be examined for any unusual signs of television life. This is another comedy product froth the shop - Of Danny Arnold, the man responsible for Barney Miller and Fish. But whereas Barney Miller is set in seedy New York police station, A.E.S. Hudson St. takes place in a seedy New York hospital. A.E.S. stand's for Adult Emergency Service:

title: Kodak Drops Firm In Berkey Lawsuit
description: The Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that in its appeals of verdicts against it in a Federal antitrust suit brought by Berkey Photo Inc. it was dropping the law firm that had been handling the case.

title: Nicklaus Is Masters Choice
description: RENO, Nev., March 29 (UPI)Jack Nicklaus, this year's leading money winner on the PGA Tour, was installed today as a 72 favorite in next week's Masters tournament by the Plantation Casino oddsmakers. Hale Irwin and Hubert Green were listed at 61, Toni Watson 81, Tom Weiskopf 101 and Ben Crenshaw and Gary Player 121.

title: Battista A Bowler Undeterred
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., March 29Dick Battista Is not only the only professional athlete with a heart transplant, but he also is the only one of the 144 bowlers in the $70,000 Long Island open with a cracked rib.

title: Growing Lettuce Indoors
description: To grow lettuce indoors, a bright sunny window is essential. Leaf types can be grown in 10-to-12-inch pots and the semihead bibbs can be grown either individually in fourinch pots or three to four plants to 10-to-12-inch pot.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MILAN, Italy, March 29 (AP)Sandy Mayer and Stan Smith of the United States moved into the quarterfinals of the $125,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today. Italys rising 21-year-old star, Gianna Ocleppo, pulled the upset of the day by downing Peter Fleming, 60, 6.4. Fleming doublefaulted frequently and was victimized by his opponents passing shots.

title: Mae Schoenfeld Jacobson, 72, Actress in the Yiddish Theater
description: Mae Schoenfeld Jacobson,- an actress in New York's Yiddish theater, died Toes= day at her home in New York City. She was 72.

title: Design Notebook
description: At left, a ceramic capital from the loggia, right, that had formed the entrance to Louis Tiffany's home. It will be installed in the Met in front of the wisteria window, above.

title: JEAN GELB
description: Jean Gelb, an artist whose work represented in a number of museum collections, died here on Monday. She was 72 years old.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, MARCH 30, 1978

title: Children, in Test, Buy Drug Trappings Freely at Head Shops; Why Not the Real Thing?; Advertised in High Times; Lettucene for Social Smoking; A Room Deodorizer Zoning Suggested
description: Like babes in Toyland, three boys from 11 to 14 and a 13-year-old girl went on a buying spree recently in head shops around the metropolitan area. They came back with $300 worth of drugculture paraphernalia that included a buzz bomb, a Power Hitter, several bongs, a baby bottle fitted with both a nipple and a hashish pipe and a felttipped pen that allows a surreptitious snort of cocaine in the classroom.

title: A.T.T. Antitrust Challenge Off to Stormy Start
description: Harold S. Levy, chief antitrust lawyer of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, served notice yesterday that the company planned a new series of challenges to the Federal antitrust suit aimed at breaking up the Bell System.

title: Rights Tribunal Opens in Frankfurt
description: FRANKFURT, West Cermany, march 29The third Bertrand Russell international tribunal began hearings today on alleged human rights violations in West Germany after its purpose was denounced by both the political leadership and leftist segments.

title: SIR STEWART DUKE-ELDER
description: LONDON, March 29 (AP)Sir Stewart DukeElder, an eye surgeon who treated three monarchs, died on Monday, the Institute of Ophthalmology said today. He was 80 years old. Sir Stewart, who wrote several textbooks on ophthalmology, was eye doctor to Queen Elizabeth II, her father, King George VI, and her uncle, King Edward VIII.

title: Ski Information
description: New York StateIn New York call 755.8100, out-of-city-518.474.5677

title: DOLLAR SINKS AGAIN, BUT BANK OF JAPAN RESTRICTS SUPPORT
description: TOKYO, Thursday March 30The United States dollar plunged yesterday to another postwar low of 221.60 yen, a sharp decline of 4.42 yen from the previous day's closing rate, on the Tok3io foreign exchange market. It was the fifth consecutive day of declines here for the American currency.

title: U.S. Naval Chief Visits Israel
description: TEL AVIV, March 29 (Reuters)The United States Chief of Naval Operations, Adm. James L. Holloway, arrived in Israel today for a threeday courtesy visit following a similar stay in Egypt. Admiral Holloway is the highestranking American officer to visit Israel.

description: A 19-year-old Lodi youth was arraigned on a homicide charge after the body. of a 17-year-old boy was found in a shallow grave in nearby Moonachie.

title: The U.N. Today
description: March 30, 1978

title: U.S. Steel Lifts Prices by 2.2%; Wheeling Joins
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a price increase of 2.2 percent, or $10.50 a ton, on all its basic steel products, effective April 1.

title: Mahar to Move Up As Columbia Coach
description: . Buddy Mahar, an assistant basketball coach at. Columbia University, has been selected as the new head coach, it was learned yesterday. His appointment is to be announced at a news conference today.

title: Israelis Say Weizman Is Flying To Cairo Today to Resume Talks
description: JERUSALEM, .March 29  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman will fly to Cairo tomorrow in an effort to get peace negotiations with Egypt restarted, official sources said today.

title: Disks: Russian Piano Music
description: TWO of these disks of Russian piano music are debut recordings. One is by Mark Zeltser, a Soviet artist who studied with the late ,Tacob Flier in Moscow and two years ago emigrated to the United States. He Waved with the New

title: Home Beat
description: Twenty years ago, when a Mies van der Rohe steel table was de rigueur for modern architects, the status symbol for more traditional interior decorators was a Vesey steel table.

title: Finally, a Day Deserving of Easter Finery
description: A sort of delayed Easter parade, postponed by rain from its proper day, took over sunny but breezy midtown Manhattan yesterday. It filled Fifth Avenue with promenading shoppers and turned the BroadwayTimes Square area into a crowd scene far beyond the usual Wednesday:Matinee pilgrimage.

title: Jazz: Vache at Crawdaddy
description: SINCE World War 11, very few young jazz musicians whose roots were in prewar jazz have gained prominence. MoSt of Ahem, faced with a bebop world, settled into regional, parttime Dixieland groups. Bob Wilber and Dick Well stood, who appeared in the immediate postwar years, and Kenny Davern, who emerged in the 50's, were seemingly the last traditionally oriented jazzmen who would build successfully on that foundation.

title: Dentists Are Opposing Rules to Restrict Advertising
description: . NORTH BRUNSWICK, March 29 (UPI) New Jersey dentists, trying to attract more ousiness with advertising, joined forces today against proposed state reguations, calling them too stint and liable to drive UP the costs of dental care.

title: Votes Are Pledged On Landmark Status For the Music Hall
description: Five. members of the New York City Board of . Estimate who cast 16 of its 22 votes said yesterday that they would vote for an interior landmark designation for Radio City Music Hall despite the objections'of its owners.

title: Bergsten Says Time Needed to Aid Dollar
description: A senior Administration official said yesterday that time and patience were needed to resolve the dollar crisis, which he described as a reflection of major economic structural changes the world's economy is undergoing,

title: CITY AND UNIONS FIND SOME CASH AVAILABLE FOR INCREASES IN PAY
description: Despite Mayor Koch's continued insistence that the city cannot afford raises for its employees, both the city and the municipal labor unions now agree that there will be enough savings in next year's budget to finance some increases for the 200,000 city workers.

title: Meadowlands Land Swap Is Voted
description: SECAUCUS, March 29  The Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission today urged the slate to agree to a 150acre land exchange that is critical to plans by Hartz Mountain Industries to build a 1.6 million-squarefoot shopping center, and a major residential and commercial complex astride the New Jersey Turnpike here.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Sound
description: MOUNTING a phono cartridge in a tone arm is the one step in setting up a sound system that invariably makes me think I'm in the wrong trade and there must be an easier way to make a living. In the course of proles sionally testing cartridges and turn tables, I have fitted cartridges into tom arms .dozens of times, but never with out unforeseen difficulty and uncontrollable loss of temper. Working with the minuscule nuts, bolts and wires that attach the cartridge requires nimble and preferably slender fingers, keeneyesight, the right tools, prior experience and an uncommonly high threshold of frustration.

title: Preservation Clinic Scheduled for April
description: INTERIOR restoration and preservation will be the subject of an allday conference April 22 in Princeton, N.J., where serious do-it-yourselfers and professionals will exchange ideas and techniques on caring for everything from 18thcentury plaster molding to 20thcentury leaded glass.

title: A Blooming in the Bronx
description: The greening of New York is late this yearexcept the Bronx, a place hardly synonymous with spring in the public mind. There the season is in full bloom at the restored Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden.

title: COURT AMENDMENTS STILL FACE A HURDLE
description: ALBANY, March 29Legislators, the Governor and the Chief Judge of the state's highest court are at odds over the drafting of laws to put into effect three constitutional amendments dealing with.the courts.

title: New Hampshire Governor Strikes a Responsive Chord
description: CONCORD, N.H., March 28The thing about the New Hampshire flag flap is that the mockery of outsiders was not echoed here. No one here laughs at Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. anymore.

title: STATE DEPT. STUDIES PRAVDA'S ANALYSIS
description: WASHINGTON March 29The State Department said today that an authoritative article published yesterday in Moscow on United StatesSoviet relations was a serious, thoughtful commentary, and added, We are studying it carefully.

title: An Official Secrets Act?; ABROAD AT HOME
description: BOSTON, March 29The British Of ficial Secrets Act, much criticized in Britain,. is often cited in this country as a dangerous example of what we must avoid. It forbids the disclosure of literally anything about the Government without official approval. Even former Cabinet members who .write about their experience have duty to clear manuscripts with the Civil Service.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: BOC International Ltd., formerly known as the British Oxygen Company, disclosed yesterday that it had completed arrangements to raise its stake in Airco Inc., New Jersey industrial gas producer, to 55 percent from its present 49 percent. the

title: Police Department Set to Promote Woman Inspector to Deputy Chief
description: The New York City Police Department will soon have_its first woman chief. .

title: Woman Seeking a Police Job Sues Paramus, Accusing It of Sex Bias
description: NEWARK, March 29A 24-year-old Bergen County woman who holds brown belt in karate and who is a marathon distance runner filed suit in United States District Court here today, charging Paramus officials with. sex discrimination in the hiring of police officers.

title: The Virtues of the Neutron Bomb
description: Ever since the Carter Administration asked Congress last summer for funds to produce enhancedradiation nuclear warheads, critics ranging from Soviet propagandists to Western cartoonists have had a field day attacking the socalled neutron bomb. The archetypical capitalist weapon, Moscow has called it, a destroyer people but not property. Grim forecasts of lingering radiation deaths have filled newspaper columns worldwide. Rarely have the relevant questions been asked: the neutron weapon really more terrible than other nuclear weapons? And, more important, would its deploy. ment make .nuclear war more likely?

title: An Exhibit on Alcoholism Offers Sobering Visions at a Museum
description: Alice sits bent and disheveled in stained dress and dirty woolen booties, drinking alone in her apartment. Not far away, Freddie and two friends are staggering around in a bar at Grand Central Terminal. .

title: Insurgent Joins Race For Board of Amex, Challenging Levitt
description: An insurgent is challenging the nominating committee and board of governors of the American Stock Exchange by putting forward his name as an inde pendent candidate for board membership in the election April 10.

title: Moro Makes Appeal In a Letter, Fearing He May Tell Secrets
description: ROME, March 29  Former Prime Minister Aldo Moro, abducted two weeks ago, appeared today to have directed veiled appeal to the Italian Government to make an offer of negotiations for his release from his kidnappers.

title: Market Place
description: Two recently completed.independent studies conclude that the capital gains tax is a blunt instrument that affects different taxpayers differentlyimposing severe penalties on longterm holders whose nominal gains actually represent losses after adjustments for inflation.

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: UNION SPRINGS, Ala.Horse trailers filled the parking area and bird dogs yelped and danced in their kennels on the opening day of the Dixie open puppy classic at Sedgefields Hunting Preserve.

title: Ballet: Live and on Film
description: THE Beacon Theater's Ballet Film Festival opened Tuesday night with a gala that included, in addition to the movie version of La Sylphide, divertissements performed live by that film's stars, Ghisla ine Thesmar and Michael Denard of the Paris Opera Ballet, Since the film attempts to reconstruct a famous Ro- mantic ballet, and Miss Thesmar and Mr. Denard are notable exemplars of Romantid style, it was appropriate that all their offerings were related to Romanticism.

title: Precious Metals Futures Decline and Then Edge Up on Bargain Hunting
description: Prices of precious .metals futures declilled along a wide front yesterday, partly in response to weak basic commodity markets and partly in reflection of lower Euronean bullion .ouotations.

title: POLICE SAY 2 BOYS KILLED NUMBERS RUNNER FOR $500
description: Two boysone 13 years old and the other 14were arrested last night and charged with shooting to death a 25year Bronx man early yesterday in return for the promise of a $500 payment.

title: StockBuying Rise by Institutions Helps to Lift Dow 2.94 to 761.78
description: Increased institutional buying enabled the stock market to post a modest gain yesterday in accelerated trading.

title: Notes on People
description: THE Library Of Congress has two of the five known manuscripts of Lincoln's Gettysburg Address, and Daniel J. Boorstin, the Librarian, vows it is going to hang onto both of them. For the past year, efforts have been made to obtain one of the manuscripts for the National Battlefield Park at Gettysburg, Pa., and the issue has flared up again at a Senate Appropriations subcommittee hearing. Senator Richard S. Schwelker, Republican of Pennsylvania, told Mr. Boorstin that it was a waste to have two copies of the famous Lincoln speech In the library and none at the battlefield, since Gettysburg is where it all began. Mr. Boorstin replied that the library had promised the donors of the manuscripts, three., children of John Hay, Lincoln's. secretary- Ao preserve them for posterity and to protect them against loss, dispersion or deterioration. Continuous display of a fragile manuscript is harmful, Mr. Boorstin said, and one would suffer measurable and Irreversible damage if put on display at Gettysburg.

description: MILAN, March 29 -- It is said that Milanese women are among the most fashionable in the world, and that's probably true. If there exists a new trend in clothes it can be found on the streets of this large, industrial city in northern Italy. During the current showings of 197879 Italian ready-to-wear Mottling, tne street scene nas oeen parucularly inspiring: At times, the clothes seen on the boutiquelined Via Monte Napolean or in the lobby of the Principe e Savoia Hotel rival the clothes seen on the runways,

title: New Construction in February Climbed 24% to $9.7 Billion
description: New construction in February amounted to S9.7 billion in contract value, 24 percent more than in the same month last year, according to the eeport yesterday by the F. W. Dodge Division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company.

title: Members of U.S. Delegation Meet 10 Jewish Women in Moscow Hotel
description: MOSCOW, March 29 (UPI)--members of a delegation traveling with the House Armed Services Committee met today with 10 Jewish women and promised to help one of them seeking medical care for her infant daughter in the United States.

title: Blinded Pilot Guided to Landing
description: EGLIN AIR FORCE BASE, Fla., March 29 (AP)A pilot who was injured and partly blinded when his F-5E fighter lost its canopy in a simulated air battle was talked through a safe landing by the pilot of another F5E flying alongside him, the Air Force said today.

title: Northwest Airlines Strike Planned
description: MINNEAPOLIS, March 29 (Reuters)Pilots for Northwest Airlines Inc. said today that they planned to strike the airline on April 29 after a mandatory 30day coolingoff period. The Air Line Pilots Association said that the National Mediation Board had issued permission for the pilots to strike after Northwest rejected the board's offer for binding arbitration.

title: CARTER OFFERS. RISE IN AID FOR FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29In a move I to head off growing Congressional pres sures, President Carter today offered for the first time to pay corn and ,cotton farmers to let a small part of their land lie idle this spring and to pay wheat farmers a higher subsidy if they do not harvest part of what they have already planted.

title: The Railwaymen's Ball
description: Following are excerpts from an open letter that the Czech playwright and humanrights advocate Pavel Kohout (his. Poor Murderer appeared on Broadway in 1976) wrote recently, to Lubomir Strougal, the- Prime Minister of Czechoslovakia. It was translated by Ruth Tosek and is to appear in the May issue of the journal Index on, Censorship.

title: Attempt to Free Tanker Fails
description: BOCA GRANDE, Fla.,March 29 (UPI) A final attempt to free the grounded Mobil oil tanker Eclipse from a sandbar in a narrow channel two miles off Boca Grande failed early today. The Coast Guard and oil company .crews awaited the arrival of two oil barges to begin transferring some of the 100,000 barrels of oil from the holds of the 567foot ship.

title: ExRep. J. Hardin Peterson Sr.; Servedin the House for 18 Years
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 29 (AP)J. Hardin Peterson Sr., a United States Representative for 18 years, died yesterday in Lakeland General Hospital. He was 84 years old and had been ill since October.

description: Elizabeth Keith Oxenaar, a classical harpist and singer who had performed on the CBS , radio network under the professional name of Lysbeth. Hughes, died Tuesday of cancer at the home of friends, Mr. and Mrs. Peter L. Kenney of Owenoke. Park, Westport, Conn. She was 66 years old and had been living in Nantes. Fla.

In the consolation, Bob Ciaffone defeated Ellen .1z5oby and Median Anderson defeated Patrick Reily to take- the last chance: In other sections Ira Hessel defeated Bill Kiehnhoff for the intermediate title; Dee Archer won the beginners; Mel Leifer teamed with Fred Block to win the doubles.

In other. words, styling took on new meaning.
