title: `Extension Colleges Under a Cloud
description: Major colleges and universities in New York State have granted thousands of degrees through offcampus extension centers that are academically deficient, the State Board of Regents was told yesterday.

title: F.D.I.C. Closely Monitoring Affairs of Troubled Banco Credito
description: SAN JUAN, P.R., March 29An Intensivesearch is under way to find a buyer for the financially troubled Banco Credito y Ahorro Ponceno, one of. Puerto Rico's largest banks, which has absorbed heavy losses in recent years.

title: OFFSHORE SINAI OIL IS MOVING TO ISRAEL
description: JERUSALEM, March 29Israel has begun producing oil offshore in the Gulf of Suez south of the occupied Sinai town of El Tur. Two wells began operation on. Sunday and a third is nearing completion.

title: Dollar Weakens in New York
description: The dollar was weaker against most European currencies in moderate trading in New York yesterday but gained marginally against the British pound. In The price of gold dropped $2.25 a troy ounce in Zurich to close at $181.375, compared with $1S3.625 on Tuesday. In London the metal dropped $1.75from $183 on Tuesday to $181.25 yesterday. The dollar's closing rates, compared, to Tuesday rates. in New York included: 2.0280 West German marks, down from 2.0347; 4.6020 French francs, down from 4.6400; 1.8765 Swiss francs, down from 1.8875. The BritiSh pound cost $1.8802, compared with $1.8850 Tuesday, and the Canadian dollar cost 88.26 United States cents, compared with 88.17.

title: Proxmire Accuses Banks of Cutbacks In New York Loans
description: New York City's six biggest banks cut back their loans to the city after the Federal Government began its loan program, Senator William Proxmire said yesterday, adding that the banks own figures proved this.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Stage: 4 OneActers by O'Neill
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Pro Hockey in the Meadowlands?
description: Three troubled National Hockey League franchises have communicated with the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority about transferring their teams to the Meadowlands complex in East Rutherford, N.J., an N.H.L. general manager said yesterday.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our living room paneling  (Masonite teak) is too dark. don't like the idea of painting over it the reason we used paneling was to avoid the mess of painting. Is it possible to bleach the paneling? - H.R., Baltimore.

title: 32 LARGE RETAIL CHAINS RAISED FEBRUARY SALES
description: Improved sales were achieved in February by 32 of the nation's largest retail chains, despite severe weather in a large part of the country, according to a survey by Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: POOR BRACING CITED IN COLLAPSE OF ROOF
description: HARTFORD, March 29The major reason for the collapse of the Coliseum roof at the Hartford Civic Center last January was a gross and obvious design error resulting in insufficient internal support for the spaceframe roof, the chief engineer investigating the incident said today.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: Article 2 -- No Title

title: Deaths
description: ACKERMANBertha.Makin .Society regrets the passing of its esteemed charter member. Services .Boule. vard.Park West 115 West 79 St, Sun day April Tat 10AM.

title: MARTIN PLAA
description: PARIS, March 29 (UPI)Martin Plaa, former professional tennis player and trainer of the Four Musketeers, died today of a heart attack. He was 77 years old. The Four MusketeersJean Borotra, Rene LaCoste, Henri Cochet and Jacques Brugnondominated world tennis for 10 years beginning in the 1920's. Brugnon died last week.

title: Fiscal Board Allows Schools In Yonkers to Give Pay Raises
description: .YONKERS,March 29The State Emergency Financial Control Board for Yonkers, today gave the city's Board of Education permission to pay members of the teachers'. union wage:increases due them in, the first year of a twoyear contract, but held off approval of the continued payment of these raises as well as an additional increase due in the second year

title: Bank of Nova Scotia Purchases 40% of Manila's Security Bank
description: The Bank of Nova Scotia, Canada's fourth largest bank in terms of assets, announced yesterday that it had purchased 40 percent of the total capital of the Security Bank and Trust Company in, Manila, becoming the second Canadian bank to invest in a commercial bank in the Philinoines. Royal Bank of Canada. the largest bank in Canada, has a 30 percent interest in the Traders Bank.

title: Five Die in Illinois Fire
description: HAMILTON, Ill., March 29 (UPI)Five persons, including two children, died today in a fire that engulfed a twostory rural frame home. Four of the victims were identified as Sharon J, White, 26 years old; her son, James D. White, 8; Betty Sue Bettis, .18; and her son, Tommy, 1. The name of the fifth victim was not immediately released.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, March 29The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said today that the Hexcel Corporation of Sayreville, which until last year manufactured ,PBB's, a fire retardant the department has classified as a suspected cancercausing agent, has agreed to install a comprehensive pollution control program.

title: U.S. and Soviet At a Low Point
description: MOSCOW, March 28In recent weeks, as the Soviet leadership has expressed annoyance with the Carter Administration, several themes of discord have emerged that tell something about the fickle nature of SovietAmerican relations.

title: U. S. May Raise Contribution to Schools to Nearly 7 Billion
description: The Federal Government is preparing to strengthen and expand the $2.7 billion cornerstone of its school aid program, Title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, which provides supplementary instructional support for six million disadvantaged students.

title: F.B.I. Chief Plans MinorityHiring Drive and New Effort on Terrorism
description: WASHINGTON, March 29William H. Webster, the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that he was dissatisfied because the number of blacks and members of other minority groups in the bureau was so small and that he had ordered accelerated recruitment and training of special agents from among these groups.

title: Theater
description: Events Today

title: This Time Ali Lost in Absentia; Red Smith; Sports of The Times; How Good Is Holmes?; The More the Merrier
description: MIAMI, March 29Muhammad Ali looked all washed up on the tube. To be sure, he didn't appear on the tube and he wasn't lurking behind the slot machines when Larry Holmes, did a job on Earnie Shavers in Las Vegas the other day. Just the same, the performance served to indict Ali a fighter, in absentia.

title: P.L.0 Will Hold Fire in Lebanon, a Top Aide Says
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 29A highranking official in the Palestine Liberation Organization said in an interview today that the guerrillas would hold their fire in some parts of southern Lebanon to avoid ..providing a pretext to perpetuate Israeli occupation.

title: Stage: `Volpone by the Cocteau Repertory
description: THE sprightly, animated version of Ben Jonso'n's mordant comedy, Volpone, being presented by the Jean Cocteau Repertory at the Bouwerie Lane Theater, is somewhat stripped down and quite unpretentious. Yet it preserves the convoluted invention of Jonson's plot and keeps intact in his avaricious and corrupted characters what William Butler Yeats called Jonson's cold implacability.

title: Illegal Queens Gambling Halts
description: Illegal casinotype gambling operations in Queens closed, at least temporarily, last night in the wake of threatened arrests this week by District Attorney John J. Santucci. Policemen inspected 23 buildings in which the socalled Las Vegas Night gambling had been conducted but found all shut. Most of the gambling had been in buildings owned by religious groups, but law enforcement officials said that much of the gambling had actually been run by professionals.

title: Lettuce Is Easy to Grow, But Use Your Head
description: LETTUCE Is said to be about 95 percent water, which doesn't leave much substance to talk about. Yet 5 percent flavor is enough for those who know lettuce to allow space for it in the garden, even if is the only crop grown.

title: Lilco Raises Its Quarterly Dividend
description: The Long Island Lighting Company increased its quarterly dividend on common stock to 42 cents a share from 40% cents a share at the monthly meeting of the board of directors yesterday. The new quarterly rate is equivalent to an annual rate of $1.70 a share, a rise of 7 cents. With the exception of 1974, the dividend has been increased each year since 1958.

title: U.S. Steel Lifts Prices by 2.2%; Wheeling Joins
description: The United States Steel Corporation yesterday announced a price increase of 2.2 percent, or $10.50 a ton, on all its basic steel products, effective April 1.

title: Bill to Cut Takeout in N.Y. Put Off
description: A disagreement among the six offtrack betting regional organizations in New YorkState has temporarily. shelved legislative plans to reduce the parimutuel takeout at New York Racing Association tracks.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Books of TheTimes
description: TO BE in my shoes or sevenleague boots last year, you would have to have been Theodora Hecht Ottinger, known as Teddy, aged thirtyfour, test pilot, native of San Diego, graduate of the University of Southern California (degree in engineering),. winner of the international Harmon .Trophy, breaker

title: Utah Court Rules CurtissWright Will Not Be Held in Contempt
description: A state court judge in Utah ruled yesterday that the CurtissWright Corporation would not be held in contempt of court for failing to heed an earlier court order that the company halt plans to wage a proxy fight.

title: V.A. Target:  Vietnam Veterans Who Cannot Readjust
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (AP)--Veterans Administrator Max Cleland says that 80 percent of Vietnamera veterans have adjusted well, picked up their lives and moved'on and the V.A. must now focus on the hard.core who cannot readjust.

title: 15 Said to Die in Polisario Raid
description: ALGIERS, March 29 (Reuters)At least 15 Mauritanian soldiers were killed when guerrillas of the Polisarin Front blew up a train carrying iron ore last weekend, the Algerian news service reported. The guerrillas are fighting for the independence of the former Spanish Sahara territory. Sources in the Mauritanian capital, Nouakchott, said Monday that there had been no casualties in the incident.

title: Arabs Assail Role Of Soviet and Cuba On Horn of Africa
description: CAIRO, March 29The Arab League wound up its council meeting today by formally condemning the aggressive intervention of the Soviet Union and. Cuba in the Horn of Africa and calling for their forces to withdraw immediately.

title: Bridge:
description: One of the most exciting forms of team competition, the double knockout, has been entirely abandoned at national level because of the difficulties of scheduling such, an event with a very, large number of teams. Numbers have been declining in recent years because of the tendency of weaker players to play in secondary events played simultaneously, so the double knockout may be due for a revival.

title: Article 5 -- No Title
description: Article 5 -- No Title

title: Shubert Computerizing All Its Ticket Sales
description: Shubert Computerizing All Its Ticket Sales

title: Children, in Test, Buy Drug Trappings Freely at Head Shops
description: Like babes in Toyland, three boys from 11 to 14 and a 13-year-old girl went on a buying spree recently in head shops around the metropolitan area. They came back with $300 worth of drugculture paraphernalia that included a buzz bomb, a Power Hitter, several bongs, a baby bottle fitted with both a nipple and a hashish pipe and a felttipped pen that allows a surreptitious snort of cocaine in the classroom.

title: CARTER OFFERS RISE IN AID FOR FARMERS
description: WASHINGTON, March 29In a move to head off growing Congressional pressures, President Carter today offered for the first time to pay corn and cotton farmers to let a small part of their land lie idle this spring and to pay wheat farmers a higher subsidy if they do not harvest part of what they have already planted.

title: Hungarian in 56 Uprising Facing Deportation by U.S.
description: MIAMI,March 29 (AP)Janos Hagl, who tells of risking his life in the 1956 Hungarian uprising and leading his family to freedom through barbed wire and booby traps, now finds himself nearly vanquished by the United States Immigration . and Naturalization Service.

title: Danny. Meehan, a Dancer, Singer And Composer, 47 Dies of Cancer
description: Danny Meehan, who was nominated for a Tony Award for his performance as the hoofer who befriended Barbra Streisand in the Broadway musical Tunny Girl in 1964, died yesterday of cancer; in Mount Sinai Hospital after. a threemonth illness. He was 47 years old.

title: People and Business
description: Paul Reistrup announced yesterday that he was quitting as president of Amtrack, and the national passenger train service said it was immediately beginning a search for a successor. The decisions came in a meeting of the rail network's board of directors in Washington.

title: Violin: Susan Eddlemon
description: LISTENING to Susan Lang Eddlemon play violin showpieces at Carnegie Recital Hall Tuesday night, one got the impression that this performer, trained at the Juilliard School by Joseph Fuchs, could do just about anything she wanted with her chosen instrument.

title: Personal Beauty
description: SUMMER isn't all that far away. If you want to look nifty in your bikini by June, now is the time to start getting into shape. All over town, exercise studios are urging you to swing on a trapeze, fold yourself into yoga positions and do balletor jazz dancing. Choose something, but don't just sit there.

title: U.S. Relations With Brazil Have Reached a Low Point
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 29Relations between the United States and Brazil, which President Carter is visiting today, are in a delicate phase. In fact, the Government has hinted strongly that Mr. Carter is unwelcome.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, cornpiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by corn_ bined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Phillies, <With Harrelson, Beat Mets
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 29The New York. Mets got their first look of the Tear at the Philadelphia Phillies today, got their first look at Bud Harrelson in a red and white Phillies uniform and came away from both encounters with memories and a 76 defeat

title: Cothpanies Report Earnings
description: For periods as snown. (N1 indicates stock Is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (0) over-thecounter.

title: NEW &
description: There's a new outpost of China Seas at Macy's. The textile concern, which is best known for its Indonesian batiks, has taken over a corner of the mainfloor Ar cade, where scores of wares made from China Seas fabrics are being sold. Colorful umbrellas hang from the ceiling to form a multipatterned, tentlike effect. Sayings are draped over a long bar so that all the designs can be seen at a glance. A table setting in front uses two sarongs as runners and is set with vinylized place mats, napkins and China Seas dinnerware (which is sold Macy's Cellar). The back and side walls of the shop display pillows, vests, clogs and a variety of desk accessories _all made, naturally, from China Seas batiks. It's the largest retail outlet for the company's products. No yard goods, but the sarongs ($16) could be cut up into pillow covers, napkins, place mats and the like. A basket holding a dozen cocktail napkins is $18; a telephonebook cover is $15, a pencil box $5. A mirror shaped like fan, with a fabric backing and a silken tassel, is $45 and just about the most expensive thing in the department.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN copper, which is nor mally used for most house wiring, was in short supply during the late 1960's and early 1970's, many house builders switched to aluminum wiring, which cost less and was more readily available.

title: Brazilian Air Force Buzzes 2 Press Planes
description: BRASILIA, March 29 (AP)Brazilian Air Force jet fighters intercepted and buzzed American airliners carrying part of the White House press corps here yesterday to cover President Carter's visit.

title: Auctions
description: THE auction of modern Mexican art that Sotheby Parke Bernet, Madison Avenue at 76th Street, presented a year ago, caused a few problems before the sale, but it proved to be so successful that a repeat performance of sorts win be given next Wednesday at 2 P.M. Even the Mexican art dealers who had been concerned that a specialized sale last year might deflate values of Mexican art were delighted with the results of that auction And no wonderabout 40 percent of the art works sold went back to Mexico.

title: Penn State Hires Stewart
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa., March 30 (AP) Pena State's basketball coach, Dick Harter, hired a former colleague, Dick Stewart, as an assistant today, uniting the pair for the third time. Stewart, who was dropped as Fordham's coach after 1 seasons, was with Harter at Oregon, again as an assistant, after they both left Penn following a 281 season in 197071.

title: Issue and Debate Battle Lines Forming on Carter's Plan to SellJets to Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Six weeks ago, the Carter Administration unveiled a plan to sell Israel,. Egypt and Saudi Arabia a total of 200 fighter aircraft over the next five years. Al- though the Administration's socalled Middle East package is not expected to be submitted to Congress for three weeks, the question as to whether should be approved has provoked fierce debate on Capitol Hill, with the White House heavily engaged in fending off criticism of the deal on several fronts.

title: Stage: Kudrev, Mime
description: IN 1967, Simon Kudrov, tho appeared on Wednesday in an impromptu performance space at the Manhattan Plaza artists housing development, was honored with the titles of Laureate of Acting and Pantomime in his native Russia. Bureau- cratic nods aside, Mr. Kudrov truly is a mime worth celebrating. He, combines technical skill with an extraordinary physical dexterity that, while more muscular than that of Marcel Marceau, brings to mind that French mime's feats of kinetic sleight-of-hand.

title: American Is Released On Bail by Nigerians
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters) Nigerian authorities released a detained American businessman today, a day before President Carter is due to arrive in Lagos, the Nigerian capital, the State Department said.

title: I.C.C. SEEKS REBATES FROM TEXAS WAREHOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, March 3(AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission said today it was seeking $4.5 million in civil penalties from a Texas warehouse it accused of having collected illegal rebates from trucking companies.

title: Argentine Military Leader to Act on Plan to Broaden His Government
description: BUENOS AIRES, March 30President Jorge Rafael Videla has announced that he will put in motion a plan designed to replace Argentina's military dictatorship with a more broadly based government, including representative civilian figures.

title: The Background of Transit Controversy in New York
description: Q. What is the controversy about?

title: Koch Said to Have Chosen 34th St. As Site of New Convention Center
description: Mayor Koch will announce soon that he has decided that New York City's longsought convention center will be built on West 34th Street, knowledgeable city officials said yesterday.

title: Dr. Keith. 0. Guthrie Jr., Physician Who,Headed Medical Groups, 63
description: Dr. Keith 0. Guthrie, Jr., a physician who headed a number of medical groups, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan, at 355 East 72d Street.; He was 63 years old.

title: Spur's. Clinch in Division
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio, March 30 (AP)George Gervin's .28 points, including six free throws in the final three minutes, carried San Antonio to a 99,, 95 victory overthe Cleveland Cavaliers tonight;,:clinching: the Spurs first Nal.. tional, Basketball Association Central Division championship.

title: Wane Offer Delays Strike Threat by Drivers at News
description: The threat of a midnight strike, by deliverers at The Daily News was staved off early today, when their union's president announced. a major wage Proposal by representatives of The News and The New York Times, and then delayed any strike deadline until 8 A.M.

title: BELL HINTS AT EASING SECRECY CONTRACTS
description: WASHINGTON, March 30Attorney General Giiffin B. Bell said today that if the Federal courts decided that the _Government could enforce contracts that prohibited employees from disclosing classified information without firk subInitting it for review, he would seriously Consider offering proposals to make the `contracts more reasonable.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Rondo In F (K.616), Mozart; War March of the Priests from Athalie, Mendelssohn Etude in A flat, Moszkowski; Mandolin Concerto, Hasse; Dance of:the...Comedians, Smetana; Pour ra,reprocher de Marie, from La Fille de Regiment, Don izetti.

title: Penguins Beaten, 63, Crippling Playoff Hopes
description: BOSTON, March 30 (UPI)  Terry O'Reilly scored two goals and Brad Park added a goal and three assists tonight to help the Boston Bruins overwhelm Pittsburgh, 63, and virtually rrinnle the Peneuins riiayoff hopes.

title: Bridge:
description: Two fine players returned to the arena after long periods of inactivity and captured the opening event at the American Bridge Association's Spring Nationals in Pittsburgh Wednesday nieht.

title: News Summary
description: Tension between Brazil and the United States appeared to have lessened as President Carter concluded talks with Brazilian leaders, but the two countries seemed still to be far apart on the issues of human rights and nuclear policy. Mr. Carter conceded that those differences existed, but he insisted that major factors that bind us in harmony With Brazil are much more important. [Page Al, Columns 45.]

title: Mr. Carter's WIN
description: It has not required an economics expert to see that from its inception the Carter Administration has been on a collision course with inflation. Within a month of his election, before he had even taken office, for example, Mr. Carter renounced any intention to use wage and price controlsalthough, throughout his campaign, he had declared that he would impose them if necessary.

title: Reagan Bars Support in G.O.P. Primaries
description: WASHINGTON,, March 30  Ronald Reagan's political action committee, Citizens for the Republic, will not give money to candidates who oppose Republican incumbents in primary elections no matter how conservative the challenger or how liberal the incumbent.

title: A Day in the World's Busiest Courthouse
description: Look closely now at the world's busiest courthouse, at 100 Centre Street, on a day 37 years after Fiorello H. La Guardia slopped Mortar on its cornerstone and expressed the dedicatory hope that the $19.3 million streamlined structure would prove too large for actual needs.

title: Carter's Urban Policy Encountering Mixed Weather in Sun Belt
description: HOUSTON, March 30From the corner of Gray and Gillette Streets on these afternoons of early spring, the sun seems to cast a golden glow around the skyscrapers of downtown Houston, those towering expressions of the vitality and prosperity for which this city has become xnown.

title: Vibrant Night Life in the. New Bohemia
description: SoHo, NoHo and TriBeCa are thought of as a home for Jazz and experimental music, but that is not entirely so. The Ballroom, at 458 West Broadway just south of Houston Street, is presenting By Strouse, a revue of Charle8 Strouse songs on Friday, Satur day and Sunday evenings ,at 10:30. Mr. Strouse, who put together the revue, wrote the music for Annie, Bye Bye Birdie, and Applause, and his new show has garnered enthusiastic reviews, including one by Joi, S. Wilson in The New York Times. There is an $8 music charge and a $7 minimum, with a light menu; the information number is 4739367.

title: An AllStar Julius Caesar Goes to Brooklyn
description: AS a director in his native England and in his adopted theatrical borough of Brooklyn, Frank Dunlop has always battled tradition and cast his actors against type, but his Julius Caesar, in previews this weekend at the Brooklyn Academy Music, sounds positively heretical.

title: Oil Spill's LongTerm Effect Could Be Slight
description: PORTSALL, France, March 29Scientists monitoring the Amoco Cadiz tanker disaster here, the worst oil spill in history, are cautiously predicting that it will not have longterm or irreversible environmental effects on the Brittany coastline and the surrounding seas.

title: NEW POLICY APPROVED TO ADMIT INDOCHINESE
description: WASHINGTON, March 30President Carter has approved the elements of, an interim refugee policy that will permit the admission of all Vietnamese boat people refused asylum elsewhere and of those Indochinese in refugee camps who have close family and political ties to the United States.

title: Gor Howe Still Amazing Fans at 50
description: SPRINGFIELD, .Mass. March 30Gordie Howe is still, amazing, people. A living legend at 30 and again at/40, Howe will be .50 years old tomorrow, still playing hockey and still scoring, coals. I'm nothing special, he submits. I'll just retire at 65 like everybody else.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Frorn Firehouse to Theater
description: Over the wide red door at 304 West 47th Street the big white letters and numerals read 54 ENGINE 54 and the obvious conclusion is Correctthis is a firehouse.

title: Handbook Published To Help the Elderly
description: A guide directed to the older person and to community groups interested in neighborhood rejuvenation has been published by the Mutual Aid Pro!ect for Older People, a program sponsored by the Citizens Committee for New York City.

title: Carter's Meetings With Brazilians Seem to Cut Tension Despite Rifts
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, March 30President Carter concluded his talks with Brazil's leaders today with no visible narrowing of the differences on human rights and nuclear pcliey, but with an apparent reduction in the tension between the two Governments.

title: N.A.A.C.P.Weighs Suit to Integrate Chicago Schools
description: CHICAGO, March 30;  Describing Chicago's schools as the most classically, segregated system it has ever encountered, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said today that it would seek a court order to force the system to desegregate if voluntary plan of the school board, which is overdue, was deemed unsatisfactory.

title: $63,101 Award Favors Blacks in Bias Suit
description: CLEVELAND, March 30 (AP)A Federal jury has ordered a white neighbor to pay a black couple $63,101 after he was, found guilty of trying to stop the, couple from buying a home in Cleveland suburb.

title: Deaths
description: GOLDBERGSol I. We mourn the sudden & untimely passing of our esteemed member and friend. The New York & Downstate Chapter of the Society of Industrial Realtors

title: ANTITRUST AIDES SEE NO NEED TO SPLIT UP OIL AND COAL SECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, March 30An analysis by the antitrust division of the Justice Department concluded today that there was no need for Congress to require oil companies to get out of the coal business.

title: Algeria and Bechtel Shape Deal for Sahara Gas Field
description: Algeria, which has been pushing hard to develop, its gas resources and gas exports to the United. States and Europe, is close to signing a $550 million contract, with the Canadian subsidiary of the Bechtel Corporation todevelop a large gas field in the Sahara.

title: A U.S. JUDGE IS TOLD OF 9W BAG's IMPACT
description: A New Jersey trucking executive testified in United States District Court in Manhattan yesterday that New York State's ban on 10ton trucks on Route 9W in southern Rockland County was forcing his company's drivers onto alternative routes that added between 15 and 30 minutes to their trios.

title: Notes on People
description: They refuse to recognize the Soviet Government's order stripping them of their citizenship the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich and his wife, the opera singer Galina Vishnevskaya, said in London yesterday. We consider that the Soviet Government tricked its people by telling them that we took part in antiSoviet activity, Mr. Rostropovich said. We consider ourselves citizens who did nothing against our people. That is why we do not- recognize this act depriving us of our citizenship. We remain Russian and Soviet people. His wife added: In depriving us of our Soviet nationality and condescendingly allowing our children to retain theirs, the Soviet Government has acted like a slave owner. I will never recognize this illegal and arbitrary act. The land which God has given me cannot be taken away from me.

title: Prosecutor in Jascalevich Case Held in Contempt After Outburst
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 30The judge in the murder trial of. Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich held the prosecuting attorney, Sybil R. Moses, in contempt of court today after angry exchanges over the admission of key evidence. Surprised court observers here said they could not recall another case of a prosecuting attorney having been held in contempt.

title: 9 Indicted in Massive
description: Nine men, including a New York City police detective, were indicted yesterday by a grand jury in Queens on charges of hijacking millions of dollars worth of cargo and stock certificates at Kennedy International Airport and selling them.

title: Witness Says He Heard of Plotting To Tie Senator Musto to Gamblers
description: TRENTON, March 30A former police informant testified in Federal Court today that he had heard of a plot to frame Senator William V. Musto, Democrat of Union City, on gambling charges while he was in prison in New York last year.

title: U. S. Investigations Disclosed by Textron
description: Texton Inc., said yesterday that it was under criminal investigation by the Internal Revenue Service for alleged illegal payments it had made in Iran.

title: A Day in the World's Busiest Courthouse
description: Look closely now at the world's busiest courthouse, at 100 Centre Street, on a day 37 years after Fiorello H. La Guardia slopped mortar on its cornerstone and expressed the dedicatory hope that the $19.3 million streamlined structure would prove too large for actual needs.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK
description: ART (GR 37014)

title: The Pop Life
description: BOOTSY? William Collins often sticks a question mark after his nickname, as in the title of his latest albumn, Bootsy? Player of the Year (Warner Brothers). And why not?, Bootsy, who also calls himself Bootzilla, Casper (the friendly ghost) and the Player, dares his fans to take him seriously. Plenty of them do. His shows at the Felt Forum tomorrow night will be packed with Bootsy fans, and his recent album is already gold, with sales in excess of 500,000 units.

title: ATLANTIC CITY SELLS LANDFILL FOR CASINO
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 30Atlantic City sold six acres of unused city landfill today for $956,000 to a developer who wants to put a casino hotel on it.

title: Opera: Tosca
description: ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Opera will be windirig up its 197778 season in little more than two weeks, Puccini's durable and popular Tosca did not enter the current repertory until Wednesday night, when the first of six scheduled performances was given.

title: Vance and Gromyko Plan To Meet Soon in Geneva On Strategic Arms Issue
description: WASHINGTON, Mareh 30As part of an effort to step up progress in the talks on limitation of strategic arms, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will probably meet with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union in late April or early May in Geneva, State Department officials said today.

title: Death Penalty Stand Is Ridiculed by Carey
description: ALBANY, March 30  Governor Carey joined a debate over religious teachings and the death penalty today, and in the process ridiculed a Republican State Senator who had said that, without capital punishment, there would never have been a Christian faith.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Governor Byrne announced today a new Blue CrossBlue Shield enrollment program that would make hospitalmedical insurance coverage available to those turned down because of health reasons.

title: The Way Back From Cyprus
description: Since 1974, when Turkish troops, using American weapons, occupied twofifths of the island of Cyprus, relations between Ankara and Washington have been sour. Congress has limited the flow of additional arms until Turkey pulls back its forces; successive Turkish Governments have refused to define their conditions for withdrawal under such pressure. Both the United States and Turkey will end up losers if no way can be found to break out of this bind. Turkey could point the way by revealing its proposals for a Cyprus settlement.

title: Deaths
description: DEWEYBeniamln H.. Jr.,On March 26, 1978. Beloved husband of Laura. Devoted father of Stephen & Margot. Memorial service Saturday, April 1, 11AM at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church, Main St., Port Washington, N.Y. Contributions in his name to Sierra Club Foundation, 800 Second Ave., NYC 10017 or Family Service Association of Nassau County, 129 Jackson St., Hempstead, N.Y. 11550 would be appreciated.

title: CARTER, IN BRASILIA, ATTACKS U.S. STEEL ON PRICE INCREASE
description: President Carter denounced yesterday as excessive and inflationary a steel price increase of $10.50 a ton by the United States Steel Corporation: Hours later, the National Steel Corporation, another major producer, announced a far lower increase.

title: In Current World Climate, Little Inhibits Soviet Curbs on Dissent
description: MOSCOW, March 30At times the Soviet Government's harshness toward political and cultural deviation at home seems somewhat inhibited by Western public opinion and by foreign policy considerations. But iust at this moment those inhibitions appear extremely thin. There is no Belgrade conference any longer to provide a forum for complaints about human rights. Relations Notes on the Soviet Union with the United States are so bad that American disapproval may have little leverage. As a result, dissidents and Western analysts expect n period of renewed tightening domestically, and they see signs that it has already begun.

title: Restaurants; Two Sarnmy's ? Eat, eat.; Mimi Sheraton
description: ONCE upon a time, long long ago, there was a Rumanian Jewish restaurant named the Parkway, one flight up at 157 Chrystie. Street on the Lower East Side. Its menu featured Rumanianstyle broiled skirt steak and rib steaks: spicv garlicladen aroundmeat satisaees. called karnatzlach; eggplant salad, and such Jewish dishes as calvesfeet jelly (pitcha), 'stuffed derma, chopped liver, unborn chicken eggs, silverdollar potatoes (which were really round french fries), Platefuls of browned onion, the chickenfat cracklings known as greeven and grated onion and radish.

title: Trust as a LaborManagement Cost Item

Yet, distrust limits productivity gains and the possibility of curbing inflation. One large company recently calculated that at least 50 percent of labor costs could be attributed to distrust.

title: Evonne Goolagong Steps Painfully. Toward Final
description: OAKLAND, Calif., March 30Evonne Goolagong, who has a ]0montlrold perfect excuse to stay home, has taken the first step toward the title she wins every other yearand she took it on two sore feet.

description: George Papashvily, an immigrant from Soviet Georgia who with his wife, Helen, was author of a humorous 1945 best-selling book about his madcap adventures in the, United States, died on Wednesday in Cambria, Calif., after a long illness. His exact birthdate is unknown, .but he was about 80 years old.

The money from the President's disaster relief fund will be available for removing debris, repairing streets, roads, bridges and public buildings, and for temporary housing.

description: The Delaware & Hudson Railway Company narrowly escaped bankruptcy again yesterday with approval of a $250,000 loan from the United States Railway Association, the Federal lending agency that oversees efforts to revitalize freight-carrying railroads in the Northeast. _

title: New Face: David Schechter

As a stagecrazy youngster hamming his way through the New York City public school system he regularly lost patience with sitting in rows, listening. He wanted to be out there, somewhere, inching theater, so once in a while he simply took off.

title: New Bond Issues
Florida Law Blocks Busing. Order; I.E.W.Vows to Seek Court Action
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare said today that it had been blocked for the first time by new antibusing legislation from compelling a school district to desegregate.

title: In a Study of Newborns, the Boys Seem More Active

title: Hotel Is Planned Over Racquet and Tennis Club

title: The Limits of College Desegregation
description: For more than a decade, civil rights groups, Federal agencies and state officials have been at odds over racial separatism in staterun universities supported with Federal funds. Under pressure from the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund, the Department of Health, Education and Welfare ruled in the early 1970's that the Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibited the continuation of superior white and inferior black institutions. Nonetheless, during the NixonFord years, integration proceeded at a snail's pace. Last spring, an exasperated Federal District Court judge ordered H.E.W. to accelerate the pace and it responded with the most vigorous enforcement campaign ever. Last week, H.E.W. initiated formal action to deprive North Carolina of $10 million a year because it failed to submit an acceptable desegregation plan. The Carter Administration has clearly gone beyond mere jawboning. But the severe problems encountered in negotiating fair agreements with the states suggest the need for restraint in invoking this ultimate economic sanction.

title: Major, Monument of PostModernism
description: Is it an oddity, a trailblazing new design or, in the words of one architect, the world's first Chippendale skyscraper? The design was made public only yesterday, but the proposed new headquarters tower for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at 550 Madi- son Avenue seems already on its way to becoming one of the city's most controversial buildings.

title: Publishing: The Case Of the Real Writer
description: ERLE STANLEY GARDNER may not have been the most prolific and bestselling American aukthor. But until someone with more impressive statistics comes along, hewill Certainly, suffice. From the time of publication of his first novel, The Case of the Velvet Claws, in March 1933, until his death on March 11, 1970; Gardner turned out 141 books for William Morrow & Company: 82 of them Perry Mason mysteries and 29 other whodunits under the pseudonym of A. A. Fair.

Moses, in contempt of court today after angry exchanges over the admission of key evidence. Surprised court observers here said they could not recall another case of a prosecuting attorney having been held in contempt.

But negotiators continued to bargain in a tense atmosphere as they sought to work out a pay formula that would avert a strike threatened for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

Mary Tyler Moore is still on hand as host, joined by, among others, Carol Burnett, Art Carney, Sherman Hemsley, Art Linkletter, Tony Randall and Isabel Sanford, all of whorn seem somewhat dour, almost taciturn, for the occasion, Perhaps they are merely overworked.

Edward Gorey, a confirmed balletomane as well as a celebrated artist, is unveiling his sets for Swan Lake (Act II). Alba Calzada, a principal dancer with the Pennsylvania Ballet, will appear as guest artist at all performancestonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M., and Sunday at 1 and 5 P.M. And two stalwarts from American Ballet Theater, Ted Kivitt and Karena Brock, will dance the Don Quixote pas de deux twice Sunday. Tickets, $4.50 to $8.50. From New York, take the Long Island Expressway to the Meadowbrook Parkway; go south to exit M5 west and follow the Hempstead Turnpike a mile to the John Cranford Adams Playhouse. Informa. tion: (516) 7988296.

Evans,. chairman of the, corporation, which is the parent of the Union Pacific Railroad Cornpany. Mr. Lovett, 82 years old, is a partner In Brown Brothers Harriman, the commercial bankers. description: ALBANY, March 30A legislative program increasing welfare benefits for residents of adultcare homes was announced today by Governor Carey, who also called for stronger controls over the residential facilities. -

title: Screen: 'Sept. 30, 1955,' When James Dean Died:Admirer of Actor
description: WE SEEM to be in the grip of a whole new batch of movies that are as much meditations on the meaning of various aspects of American popular culture as they are demonstrations of that culture"Saturday Night Fever," "American Hot Wax," "Handle With Care" now James Bridges's funny, solemn, dead-on-accurate "September 30, 1955."The film, which opens today at the Cinema II, is all about the sturm und drang precipitated on that day, nearly 23 years ago, in one small Arkansas college town when word is received that James Dean has been killed in a car crash in California.Actually the town takes the news rather well. "After all," says one typical young woman, "he was only a movie star," But for Jimmy J. (Richard Thomas), the death means the loss of someone whose only released film, "East of Eden," defined his own amorphous personality and still unfulfilled life. For a few hours Jimmy J. goes to pieces in the manner he imagines James Dean might have, given the same more or less tacky circumstances.Like Mr. Bridges's "The Paper Chase," the new film is full of affection and carefully observed detail of place and period. But also like the earlier film it lacks the edge of satire that can make the difference between a good film and a great one, between a film that is somehow in thrall to its sentiments instead of being in charge of them.Mr. Bridges likes Jimmy J. so much that he sees more in him than many of the rest of us probably can. Is it because he knows that at the end of the film, after Jimmy J. goes roaring off to California on his James Dean-like motorcycle, Jimmy J. will grow up to be a writer and director of movies, like Mr. Bridges? If so, he knows more than I do.My conviction from the film is that Jimmy J. will land in Hollywood; work at odd jobs and, eventually, settle down as the manager of a supermarket. It is thus apparent that I find the film's implications sadder and more depressing than Mr. Bridges, who, I assume, is drawing on his own life and knows what's going to happen next."September 30, 1955" was filmed in Arkansas and even has the look of a movie of the 50's, when film makers were starting to go on location in the interests of accuracy. It is beautifully cast and acted with self-absorbed intensity by a number of young performers who are very, very funny, especially by Deborah Benson, as the college's pretty, square, homecoming queen, a girl who loves Jimmy J. a lot, but who loves conventional behavior even more, and by Lisa Blount, as Jimmy J.'s ex-girlfriend, someone who shares his nutty adoration of James Dean and who must pay a high price to grow up.The problem with "September 30, 1955" is that Jimmy J. never does grow up. Essentially he is a figure of comedy, a fellow desperate for direction and out of touch with reality.Mr. Bridges and Mr. Thomas, who was John-Boy on TV's "The Waltons" for so many years, insist on treating him as a figure of magic and mystery, as if he were a poet in his own right. To model one's life on that of a movie star to the extent that Jimmy J. does suggests arrested development  though it does say something important (and scary) about the influence of what are sometimes called the popular arts.It is the latter that makes "September 30, 1955" so interesting, as well as the ways in which Mr. Bridges recallscomicallyJimmy J.'s attempts to relate the humdrum events of his life with those of the melodramatic movie fiction he so admires. Jimmy J. himself is a cipher to me but the movie around him is extremely stylish, even to the manner in which it takes on in modified formthe shape of juvenile-delinquent films of the 50's. Mr. Bridges is a sophisticated, knowing film maker, but I wish he had built his movie around a tougher, more knowing character we might have believed in."September 30, 1955," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some mildly obscene language.

Outside was the third baseman, Lenny Randle, in his jogging clothes. He'had left the hotel early .to get a head start on the day's ekercises.

title: LastMinute Assault on Abortion
description: Since 1970 New York State has been governed by a pioneer abortion statute that served as a model for the nation. It has given all women, rich or poor, the right to a safe abortion when medically necessary. The New York State standard became important again late last year when Washington placed tight restrictions on Federal Medicaid funding of abortion. Today, only 14 states, including New York, still provide broad Medicaid abortion coverage for the poor.

Carloadings in the same period totaled 410,946 cars, down 14.6 percent from last Aar. The American Trucking Associations.Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage fell 1,2 percent from last year.

title: Mets Lose, Foster Traded

title: Film: The 'Amsterdam Kill' Opens:Guns and Flowers
description: THERE'S a Chinese drug-smuggling ring operating out of Amsterdam, and an American narcotics agent seems to be the kingpin. It might be Leslie Nielsen; it might be Bradford Dillman; it might be Richard Egan. For all the difference the fine points of the plot make in "The Amsterdam Kill," it might even be your old Aunt Betty. All that matters is the body count, which is impressive enough to have given a film without sex scenes an R rating. There are so many shootings, and so many hapless victims, that one thug even barges into a kitchen by mistake, machine-gunning a helpless chicken."The Amsterdam Kill," which opens today at a number of neighborhood theaters, has all the weariness of a genre movie but none of the comfortable familiarity. In a misguided attempt to appeal to an international audience, the film flits from London to Hong Kong to Amsterdam; one key scene takes place, for no clear reason, at a horse show in Utrecht. One important Chinese character wears tweeds, plaids and a watchchain on his waistcoat. There are so many shots of airports and train terminals that it begins to seem as if one has purchased a Eu-rail pass rather than a movie ticket. The film is so intent on taking place everywhere that its nervous geography becomes terribly jarring.Robert Mitchum plays a good cop who's been disgraced, but who is still good, the only honest man in a cesspool of international corruption, a disillusioned fellow who can still rise to a challenge if the stakes are high enough . . . oh, you know the type. Mr. Mitchum knows the type, too, so intimately that he manages to lend unexpected weight and dignity to moments of no consequence at all. This is the flimsiest movie Mr. Mitchum has made in some time, but for that very reason his performance is particularly arresting.Most of his dialogue sounds like dialogue, and Mr. Mitchum delivers both the punchy lines ("Let's go stick our finger in somebody's eye".) and the implausible ones with the cool, dependable air of a man who's only following orders. But there's something impressive about the imperturbability with which he marches through the most potentially embarrassing situations.Robert Clouse also directed "Enter the Dragon" and "Black Belt Jones," which makes him sound as if he ought to know a thing or two about action footage. Here, however, Mr. Clouse proves himself capable of showing a car being driven through a houseboat and into a canal without generating any excitement at all. The same thing holds true for the film's final demolition scene, which involves a bulldozer, a greenhouse and a very large number of innocent mums and roses.The film's only real selling point is the abundance of fresh flowers that begin to figure into the drug-smuggling plot during the last half-hour. Mr. Clouse can't make a chase through a flower market look any more thrilling than a stroll in a garden might be, but the flowers are nicely photographed and prettily arranged. And, after all, it's springtime.

title: O.&M. May Be Tapped For Schaefer Account
description: It looks like Ogilvy & Mather, which recently was dropped out of the competition for the Schlitz beer account, is going to get Shaefer instead. It's the No. 1 beer here you know.

title: News Summary

Mr. Carter conceded that those differences existed, but he insisted that major factors that bind us in harmony with Brazil are much more important. [Page Al, Columns 45.]

title: Stock Sales of Women's Bank End
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (UPI)The nation's first Federally chartered women's bank has completed its initial stock sales and expects to open for business in May. The final shares of the Women's National Bank's $2 million issue of 100.000 shares of common stock were sold late Tuesday, according to Emily Wohach, the bank's president and chief executive. Sale of the stock, which cost $20 a share, began in midOctober.

title: Art: Women Talking to Women
description: ANN CHERNOW's paintings, graphics and works on paper at the Aaron Berman Gallery, 50 West 57th Street, deal with a single theme women talking to other women. What they say (as reported in the title oreacnpainting) is tne IMO or everyday stuff that marks a genuine (and often an irresoluble) crisis. (I get along without you very well, for instance.) Most of the women in question have an archaic look: a hairstyle that was popular several decades ago; a way of dressing that predates our own era. Even their makeup is frantic and ineffective by the standards of the late 1970's.

title: Kennecott in Credit Agreement
description: Kennecott Copper Company announced yesterday that it had entered into a new $450 million, eightyear, revolving credit agreement with a group of 24 commercial banks. The full amount is to be available until June 30, 1932, with the amount to be gradually reduced thereafter. The company said the credit will be used first to retire almost $94 million outstanding under an existing term loan from banks and to repay $130 million in shortterm notes.

title: ALLAN K. MURRAY
description: Allan K. Murray, a retired vice president of Bankers Trust Company in New York City, died yesterday in his home on South Main Street, Southampton, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: Art: Jules Olitski As PostRaphaelite
description: UNLESS it is written by a genius, prose can date swiftly and fatally. As a medium, it lacks the compensations of tone, rhythm, texture and color, which,. in poetry, music and painting, can ottset any archaism and return them to circulation. Of all types of prose, critical journalism is the most likely to bite the hand that writes it. Even if critics speak for the majority, life and taste move on, leaving them more often than not holding the bag in alltoo permanent print. Perhaps their work should, after a number of years, be granted the immunity from quotationthat politicians seem to enjoy  especially where their promises are concerned.
